site_title: Airlines had their safest year on record in 2023: Iata
summary: The International Air Transport Association (Iata) reported that 2023 was the safest year on record for commercial air travel, despite a 17% increase in flights to 37.7 million. The only fatal accident involved a Nepalese plane crash that killed 72 people. Additionally, 29 non-fatal accidents occurred in 2023, totaling 72 accidents. This marks a significant improvement in air travel safety, with the low crash rate attributed to various factors, including enhanced safety measures and improved pilot training.

images.alt_text: Global airlines are forecast to reach  a record revenue of almost US$1 trillion in 2024.

site_title: BYD amps up brutal China EV price war with bigger discounts on new car versions
summary: Chinese electric vehicle giant BYD unveiled lower-priced new versions of its Han sedans and Tang SUVs, deepening the country's price war with discounts of 10.35-14.3% lower than previous models. The new Han sedans and Tang hybrid SUVs, available as plug-in hybrids and pure EVs, respectively, will start at prices 15-20% lower than last year's versions. BYD's aggressive pricing move comes as China's new energy vehicle sales fell 38.8% in January, despite a renewed discounting push led by Tesla.

images.alt_text: Pratarnwong (left) and his sister are part of the Phornprapha family that established the Siam Motors Group.
BYD says that its premium Denza brand, which is 10 per cent owned by Mercedes, will launch in Europe in the fourth quarter.
BYD Auto Industry general manager Liu Xueliang oversees the Asia Pacific automotive markets at the Chinese maker.
BYD markets its luxury models under the Yangwang and Fang Cheng Bao brands.
Record deliveries in the fourth quarter, when BYD overtook Tesla as the world’s top seller of electric cars, did not translate into another bumper profit.

site_title: An Italian feast for BT readers
summary: BT Club, a membership benefits program for The Business Times readers, hosted its first dining experience, "A Night in Puglia: A Feast for the Senses," at Fico in Singapore. The event, which sold out within two weeks, featured a curated Italian menu, including off-menu items such as squid ink pasta and grilled lobster, along with free-flowing wine for two hours. A lucky draw was held, with six winners taking home prizes, including a handcrafted Decibelist wireless speaker worth S$800. The event marked the first of its kind organized by BT Club.

images.alt_text: Immerse yourself in the world of Jaeger-LeCoultre and haute horology at an upcoming BT Club watchmaking experience.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia H2 profit rises 185% on powertrain solutions, building materials growth
summary: Hong Leong Asia, a mainboard-listed company, reported a net profit of S$34.1 million for the second half of 2024, up 185% from the previous year. The company's powertrain solutions unit, Yuchai, and building materials unit saw an increase in gross profits. Earnings per share rose to 4.56 Singapore cents, up from 1.6 cents in the previous year. This growth is attributed to the success of these business units, driving the company's H2 growth.

images.alt_text: Hong Leong Asia chief executive Stephen Ho said that it may be another two years before the company sees more replacements
Stephen Ho, Hong Leong Asia chief executive, said that the company is well-placed to take bid for contracts that require a proportion of precast products to be manufactured locally.

site_title: Private credit firms see more Asia growth as banks retreat
summary: Private credit firms expect a 10%+ growth in Asia-Pacific lending in 2024, driven by higher-quality borrowers and sectors like education, healthcare, and consumption. As banks pull back, private credit has become a rival to mainstream lending, attracting investors with higher returns. Demographic shifts and the energy transition sector are also expected to drive capital flows. However, concerns remain over China's economic slowdown and geopolitical tensions, which may impact certain markets. Key players, including Goldman Sachs and Blackstone, are training their sights on Asia, with the US$1.7 trillion global private credit market poised for growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Maybank Q4 earnings up 8% to RM2.3 billion on higher revenue
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest bank, reported a net profit of RM2.3 billion for the fourth quarter, up 8% from the same period last year, driven by strong gains in its insurance segment and operating income. Revenue increased 14% to RM17.1 billion, with the group's full-year earnings rising 17% to RM9.3 billion. The bank attributed the performance to offsetting declines in net interest income. Maybank expects a firmer growth outlook for Asean economies, targeting a return on equity of 11% for 2024.

images.alt_text: Maybank says Muzaffar Hisham will take over Islamic banking group CEO's role effective Mar 1.
Maybank Singapore is promising an FD rate of 2.9 per cent per annum for a minimum placement of S$20,000 in OA funds for 12 months.

site_title: Simpler government tender category from April, among moves to improve ease of doing business
summary: Singapore is set to launch a new government tender category, Tender Lite, in April 2024, which will make it easier for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to participate in government contracts. The new category will cover tenders valued at up to S$1 million for general goods and services, and will streamline contract conditions and reduce security deposits and liquidated damages. The government is also expanding eGuarantee@Gov to all relevant agencies by end-2024, aiming to reduce transaction costs and increase efficiency.

images.alt_text: The recently-launched eGuarantee@Gov enables businesses and individuals to provide a banker's guarantee or insurance bond to government agencies virtually.

site_title: US consumer spending fuels strong Q4 GDP growth
summary: US GDP grew at a 3.2% annualized rate in Q4, driven by strong consumer spending, which increased at a 3% rate, and state and local government investment. This follows a 4.9% growth pace in the July-September quarter. Domestic demand was stronger than initially thought, growing at a 2.9% rate. Despite a weak start due to bad weather, economists expect growth to remain above the non-inflationary growth rate of 1.8%.

images.alt_text: The Conference Board says that its consumer confidence index slipped to 106.7 this month from a downwardly revised 110.9 in January.

site_title: Supply still matters: Why US housing inflation relief may be short-lived
summary: US Federal Reserve officials expect housing inflation to cool in coming months, driven by the fading of pandemic-era rent and home price increases. However, they acknowledge that a shortage of single-family homes and apartments may lead to future price pressure, accounting for about a third of the consumer price index. Experts warn that supply constraints could risk secularly faster inflation, with some arguing that policymakers have leaned too hard on tight credit policy. The Fed's immediate goal is to achieve "disinflation" in shelter costs, but longer-run problems with housing availability remain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A new housing construction is seen as real estate prices rise in Beverly Hills, California, U.S., June 2, 2021. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson

site_title: Hong Kong vows return to fiscal balance as deficit surges
summary: Hong Kong's fiscal deficit is projected to surge to HK$101.6 billion for the 2023-2024 financial year, its fourth budget shortfall in five years. Financial Secretary Paul Chan vows to narrow the deficit to HK$48.1 billion for the next financial year. To achieve fiscal balance, the government will consolidate public finances and implement measures to boost the housing market and tourism industry, including a HK$1 billion investment to attract visitors. The city's economy is expected to grow 2.5-3.5% this year.

images.alt_text: The move will bring in about HK$910 million of additional revenue each year.
Confidence in Hong Kong has waned as home prices tumble to a seven-year low.

site_title: South Korea to send military doctors to hospitals amid doctors’ protest
summary: South Korea will deploy military and community doctors to hospitals amid a mass walkout by trainee doctors protesting a government plan to increase medical school admissions. Approximately 9,000 trainee doctors have joined the protest, disrupting hospital services and forcing some patients to be turned away. Prime Minister Han Duck-soo has urged the young doctors to return to work by Thursday, offering to address their concerns. The government has warned of suspending licenses for non-compliant doctors, and the plan has sparked opposition from senior doctors and private practitioners.

images.alt_text: Doctors shout slogans and carry signs reading 'Opposition to the increase in medical schools' during a protest against the government's medical policy, near the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 15, 2024.
Doctor protesters hold placards reading "Stop populist medical policy", during a protest against the government's medical policy near the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 14, 2024.

site_title: Vietnam’s ‘rice bowl’ cracks in monster heatwave
summary: Southern Vietnam, including Ho Chi Minh City and the Mekong Delta, suffered an unusually long heatwave in February, with temperatures reaching up to 38°C, causing severe drought and low water levels in canals. The heatwave, attributed to El Nino and global climate change, has impacted agricultural production, with farmers struggling to transport crops and experiencing subsidence and landslides due to water pumping. The region has seen over 80 canals dry up, resulting in significant damage and economic losses.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on February 23, 2024 shows a farmer looking at his crop in a dry rice field in southern Vietnam's Ca Mau province, amid a long heatwave. Southern Vietnam including business hub Ho Chi Minh City and its "rice bowl" Mekong delta region suffered an abnormally long heatwave in February, forecasters said February 28. (Photo by Tan Dien / AFP)
India’s 5 per cent broken parboiled variety has been quoted at a record US$542 to US$550 per tonne this week.
International visitors to Vietnam totaled 12.6 million in 2023, equivalent to 70 per cent of pre-pandemic levels.
The latest call comes as the most populous city in Vietnam seeks more investments in green development.

site_title: US home-buying demand nears worst since 1995 with mortgage rates above 7%
summary: US home-buying demand is near its worst since 1995, with mortgage rates above 7% for the fifth week. The Mortgage Bankers Association's index of mortgage applications for home purchases dropped 4.5% in the week ended Feb 23, the weakest since October 1995. Despite a slight easing of contract rates to 7.02%, Federal Reserve officials are in no rush to ease policy, keeping mortgage rates high. This has pushed home-financing costs higher, reducing momentum in the housing market.

images.alt_text: Though their 2 per cent inflation target uses an index that is less sensitive to shelter costs, Fed officials still see housing and rent dynamics as an important, unresolved part of their inflation battle.
US MANHATTAN united states housing Photographer: Alex Kent/Bloomberg
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increases 19 basis points in the week ended Feb 16 to 7.06 per cent
Builder sentiment began rebounding late last year as mortgage rates declined, falling below 7% in December.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending rose 0.9 per cent.
Buyers have been sidelined by high mortgage rates, which hit a recent peak in October at 7.79 per cent.
The National Association of Realtors (NAR) Pending Home Sales index rises 8.3 per cent to 77.3, rebounding from a downwardly revised record-low of 71.4 in November.
Purchases of new single-family homes increase 8 per cent to a 664,000 annual pace last month, after an upward revision to November’s figure.
The Mortgage Bankers Association’s (MBA) index of mortgage applications to buy a home increases 7.5 per cent to 174.3 in the week ended Jan 19.
Contract closings decrease 1 per cent from a month earlier to a 3.78 million annualised rate, according to National Association of Realtors (NAR) data.

site_title: Hong Kong raises tax for high earners, first hike in two decades
summary: Hong Kong has raised taxes on high earners for the first time in two decades, aiming to lower the city's fiscal deficit. The two-tier tax system, set to take effect in April, will tax income up to HK$5 million at 15% and anything higher at 16%. This move is expected to generate about HK$910 million in additional revenue each year, affecting around 12,000 individuals.

images.alt_text: Confidence in Hong Kong has waned as home prices tumble to a seven-year low.
Speakers at the inaugural Climate Business Forum: Asia-Pacific say there is ample room for the region's advancement in green finance.

site_title: Accounting workforce, regional agreements get boosts to support Singapore’s hub status
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to boost the local accountancy workforce by relaxing requirements for the Singapore Chartered Accountant Qualification, allowing more polytechnic graduates to become professional accountants. The move strengthens the accounting sector, a key enabler of Singapore's role as a "reliable and trusted hub for business and trade." The Ministry of Finance also enhances trade processes, including a six-month pilot for Asean Mutual Recognition Arrangement, to facilitate the flow of goods and reduce regulatory costs, positioning Singapore as a global trade node.

images.alt_text: Teo Ser Luck, the president of the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants says the new programme will teach new directors how to corporatise their companies.
The best way for Singapore to deal with inflation is for business and wages to grow in real terms, says Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.
Singapore is setting aside resources for future spending as it is “currently in a sound fiscal position”, says Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 28)
summary: OCBC, Singapore's second-largest lender, reported a 27% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$7.02 billion for FY2023, crossing the S$7 billion mark for the first time. The bank expects lower net interest margins and slow loan growth in 2024 due to a global growth slowdown. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for Singapore to transform to meet its "very ambitious" productivity growth targets, while CapitalLand Investment posted a S$170 million loss for the second half of FY2023 due to revaluation losses.

site_title: Worldline takes 1.15 billion-euro hit from merchant services write down
summary: Worldline, a French payment company, reported a net loss group share of 817 million euros for 2023, despite a 6% rise in full-year revenue. The loss was primarily due to a 1.15 billion-euro goodwill impairment linked to its merchant services activities, reflecting a change in valuation paradigm in the payments industry. The impairment is non-cash and does not affect the company's adjusted net income. Worldline targets organic revenue growth of at least 3% for 2024 and adjusted EBITDA of at least 1.17 billion euros.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of payments company Worldline is seen at the company headquarters in the financial and business district of La Defense, near Paris, France, October 26, 2023. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo

site_title: UMS Q4 earnings fall 3% to S$15.7 million on lower semiconductor sales
summary: UMS Holdings reported a net profit of S$15.7 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2023, down 3% from the same period last year, due to lower semiconductor sales. Revenue fell 27% year-over-year to S$73.5 million, with a 78% surge in aerospace sales offsetting the decline. The group expects to remain profitable in FY2024.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) lost 0.6 per cent or 18.39 points to finish the trading day at 3,138.93.
Olam's earnings per share stands at S$0.0567 for the half year, up from S$0.0478 the previous year.

site_title: US dollar firmer before key inflation data, kiwi sinks as RBNZ holds rates
summary: The US dollar strengthened 0.2% to 104.07, its highest level since February 2022, as markets await inflation data for clues on when central banks may ease policy. The New Zealand dollar fell 1% to its lowest since February 16 after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand held interest rates steady. The Australian dollar also declined after inflation data showed it remained above the Reserve Bank of Australia's target. Markets expect the European Central Bank to cut interest rates if inflation is stickier in the euro area, which could lead to a stronger US dollar.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against a basket of peers, including the yen, euro and sterling, is down 0.1 per cent at 103.67.
FILE PHOTO: Four thousand U.S. dollars are counted out by a banker counting currency at a bank in Westminster, Colorado November 3, 2009.  REUTERS/Rick Wilking/File Photo

site_title: The squawkus about Aukus is getting louder
summary: The Aukus pact between Australia, the UK, and the US continues to face growing doubts and criticisms, particularly in Australia. Critics argue that the pact's strategic, political, and technical viability are in question, citing concerns about relying on the US, the cost of acquiring and maintaining nuclear-powered submarines, and the UK's military-industrial base. Despite these concerns, the Australian government remains committed to the pact, and its defenders argue that it is a necessary step to strengthen deterrence against China's growing military and territorial ambitions.

images.alt_text: Crews flying Pacific missions on the US Navy’s top maritime surveillance and attack aircraft will be using AI algorithms to rapidly process sonar data gathered by underwater devices of the US, UK and Australia.

Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese shakes hands with China's President Xi Jinping at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, November 6, 2023. AUSTRALIA OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN AUSTRALIA

site_title: Mastering the art of time
summary: Jaeger-LeCoultre, a renowned Swiss luxury watch brand, is hosting a BT Club experience to showcase its fine watchmaking artistry. The event, on March 9, will feature a hands-on workshop where participants can assemble the Manufacture Calibre 822 movement, used in Reverso watches, under the guidance of a Jaeger-LeCoultre watchmaker. Upon completion, attendees will receive a certificate, a Reverso tote bag, and an exclusive bespoke gift. Limited slots are available, and registration can be done at www.gevme.com/btclubxjlc.

images.alt_text: BT readers enjoyed a dinner organised by BT Club at Fico

site_title: Bitcoin eyes US$60,000, biggest monthly rally since late 2020
summary: Bitcoin surged 4.5% to US$59,244, its highest since December 2021, as investors flocked to the cryptocurrency ahead of its April halving event and potential Federal Reserve rate cuts. This marks its largest monthly rally since December 2020, with a nearly 40% gain in February. The rally is driven by traders seeking higher-yielding assets and the prospect of increased volatility.

images.alt_text: The original digital currency has increased as much as 5.2 per cent to US$54,438 after trading in a narrow range for more than a week.

site_title: Leading your own mental health journey
summary: Several psychologists wrote self-help books during the pandemic to help individuals navigate their mental health journey without expert help. These books, such as "How To Be Your Own Therapist" and "Think Like A Therapist," offer guidance on mental wellness. While the effectiveness of these books is not explicitly stated, they are seen as a viable alternative to traditional therapy. The books aim to empower individuals to take control of their mental health and well-being, potentially leading to improved mental wellness.

site_title: Far East Orchard H2 net profit up four times on gains from student accommodation investments
summary: Far East Orchard reported a net profit of S$57.7 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, more than four times the S$13.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue improved 20% to S$92.8 million. The group attributed the increase to a fair-value gain on investment properties of S$58.3 million. This is a significant jump from the S$2.6 million gain in FY2022, driven primarily by the growth of its student accommodation investments.

images.alt_text: Far East Orchard on Friday said it expects higher profit after tax for its FY2023 results, to be announced in end-February.
Far East Orchard's revenue jumped 36.7 per cent to S$134.1 million for 9M FY2023, from S$98.1 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: China solar industry’s record-breaking growth to stall in 2024
summary: China's solar industry is expected to slow its record-breaking growth in 2024, with a conservative estimate of adding 190 gigawatts of new solar capacity, down from 216 GW in 2023. The industry faces challenges such as renewable power overcapacity, curtailment, and insufficient storage capacity, leading to cancellations of planned investments and job losses. The country's renewable energy law revision is expected to address the situation, and the industry is also struggling with international trade barriers and grid connection difficulties.

images.alt_text: The China Electricity Council (CEC) forecast that grid-connected wind and solar would make up around 40 per cent of installed power generation capacity by the end of 2024, compared with coal’s expected 37 per cent.
Almost 510 gigawatts of renewables were installed in 2023, setting a record for the 22nd straight year, says the International Energy Agency.
The change underscores some of the problems China faces after it added a record amount of solar capacity this year in its attempt to peak and eventually zero out emissions.
The predicted shake-out is happening even as installations continue to pick up pace with 142.6 gigawatts has been added in China in the first 10 months of the year.

site_title: Nissan plans 2027 driverless ride-share service for ageing Japan
summary: Nissan plans to launch an autonomous vehicle ride-share service in Japan by 2027 to address the nation's aging population and lack of taxi drivers. The service, which will begin with a trial in Yokohama, aims to provide a solution to the country's transportation problems. Nissan will conduct safety-related discussions with the government and proceed gradually. The company has been conducting driverless vehicle trials since 2018 and aims to have the nationwide service running by fiscal year 2027.

site_title: Large non-listed companies required to make climate disclosures from FY2027
summary: Singapore will be the first country in Asia to require large non-listed companies to make climate disclosures starting from the 2027 fiscal year, aligning with International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) standards. Companies with annual revenue of at least S$1 billion and total assets of at least S$500 million will be required to report their Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions, with listed companies starting to disclose Scope 3 emissions from 2026. A three-year transitional period will apply to non-listed companies, with the possibility of extension depending on industry readiness and global developments.

images.alt_text: SGX chief regulatory officer Tan Boon Gin.
Process, people and technology have to be aligned for organisations to fully harness the potential of automation for ESG reporting and compliance.
PHOTO: WONG PEI TING, BT
A standardised data framework supported by advanced technology solutions can provide clear data backed by robust controls.
By setting clear climate reporting guidelines, Singapore is affirming its commitment to the green movement.

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower as investor optimism wanes, STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.6% lower, down 18.39 points, to 3,138.93. Investors shifted focus to economic indicators ahead of US interest rate data, leading to a decline in the broader market. Regional markets also fell, with the Nikkei 225 and Bursa slipping 0.1% and 0.9% respectively. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top decliner, while Jardine Matheson Holdings was the top gainer, rising 1.3%.

images.alt_text: CMG20231215-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.
The Europeans have remodeled their fiscal rules - the Stability and Growth Pact - to increase flexibility in the effort to maintain fiscal discipline in the long run.
Before designing your portfolio, define your objective and assess your risk tolerance. Investing in stable, blue-chip stocks should enable you to sleep at night.

site_title: China broadens law on state secrets to include ‘work secrets’
summary: China has expanded its state secrets law to include "work secrets", which will take effect from May 1. The revised law requires government agencies and work units to protect information that could cause adverse effects if leaked, even if it's not a state secret. Analysts say this move further demonstrates President Xi Jinping's focus on national security, following a 2023 update to Beijing's anti-espionage law. The law's expansion has raised concerns among the foreign business community in China, with recent raids on management consultancies and espionage allegations against a Japanese pharmaceutical executive.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese Premier Li Qiang speaks during the 26th ASEAN-China Summit at the 43rd ASEAN Summit in Jakarta, Indonesia, on September 6, 2023. Yasuyoshi Chiba/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Forty-seven companies pull their listing plans from China’s stock exchanges so far this year, compared with 29 withdrawals during the same period one year earlier,

The unusual decision for a state-owned enterprise to raise funds for an LGFV is a sign Guizhou province, one of the poorest and most indebted regions of China, is stepping up efforts to address the financing pressures brought on by maturing LGFV debt.
Liu Haoling will replace Ju Weimin’s roles as the vice-chairman and president of CIC, the sovereign wealth fund says.

site_title: Hong Kong’s biggest developer sees first-half profit fall 6%
summary: Hong Kong's largest developer, Sun Hung Kai Properties, reported a 6% decline in first-half profit to HK$8.9 billion due to high interest rates and economic uncertainty. The company's underlying earnings were impacted by muted residential property transactions and high vacancy rates in offices. The increasing supply of new homes has prompted developers to cut prices, leading the Hong Kong government to scrap levies curbing homebuyer demand.

site_title: New Asme chief targets better policy recommendations, collaboration and growth abroad
summary: Ang Yuit, newly elected president of the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (Asme), aims to champion collaboration among Singapore's SMEs and encourage international growth. Asme will focus on proactive policy recommendations, including developing human capital, harnessing artificial intelligence, and addressing environmental, social, and corporate governance matters. Ang emphasizes the need for SMEs to work together, beyond a "me and mine" mindset, and to explore overseas opportunities to drive growth and cut costs. He also recognizes the importance of government support, but notes that SMEs must take action to make things better for themselves.

images.alt_text: The recommendations cover five areas: manpower; digitalisation; internationalisation; sustainability; and grants, incentives and schemes.

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried says 63 to 78 months should guide sentencing for FTX fraud
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX, is set to be sentenced on March 28 after being found guilty of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy in November. Lawyers for the former billionaire have requested a sentence of 63-78 months, a range they believe is an appropriate punishment for stealing $8 billion from customers. Bankman-Fried faces up to 110 years in prison, but the proposed sentence would significantly reduce the potential punishment.

images.alt_text: Prosecutors says much of the evidence that could be offered at a second trial was already presented at the first trial.
(From left) Changpeng ‘CZ’ Zhao; Sam Bankman-Fried; Do Kwon.
A federal jury in New York convicted Sam Bankman-Fried, leaving the 31-year-old former tycoon the possibility of spending the rest of his life behind bars.

A 12-member jury in Manhattan federal court convicted Sam Bankman-Fried on all seven counts he faced after a monthlong trial in which prosecutors made the case that he stole US$8 billion from the exchange’s customers out of sheer greed.

site_title: German property slump to widen office quality gap: Moody’s
summary: Moody's Investors Service predicts Germany's construction slump will widen the office quality gap, with high raw material and financing costs weighing on building activity through 2024. The shortage of new office space will benefit landlords of prime properties, while secondary stock will underperform due to weaker economic activity and environmental regulations. A record low sentiment among German homebuilders and ongoing project cancellations have contributed to the crisis, with a recovery in building activity in 2025 remaining uncertain. The European Central Bank's pause on interest-rate increases and expected borrowing cost cuts later this year offer some relief.

images.alt_text: The skyline with the banking district is seen during sunset in Frankfurt, Germany, February 27, 2024.  REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach

site_title: Derwent upgrades rent growth guidance for London offices
summary: Derwent London has upgraded its rent growth guidance for its London office portfolio, predicting a 5% increase in rental values this year, up from 2.1% in 2023. Demand for energy-efficient and amenity-rich buildings has led to a shift in tenant preferences, putting pressure on older properties. Despite this, Derwent's development projects have seen an 8.1% increase in value, with tenants committing to new leases at higher rents. The company's portfolio valuation declined 10.6% to £4.9 billion due to higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: A general view shows the City of London financial district from an office window in Canary Wharf in London on October 2, 2023. (Photo by HENRY NICHOLLS / AFP)

epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
Mary Austin inherited the property from Mercury upon his death in 1991 and has been living here ever since
The number of homes sold for more than £5 million (S$8.5 million) in January is down 17 per cent from last year.

Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
The property market in London has been hit by a tax clampdown aimed at investors and foreign buyers along with Brexit and changing working patterns after the pandemic.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank initiates ‘buy’ on optimism about Thomson Medical’s growth plans
summary: Maybank has initiated coverage on Thomson Medical Group with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$0.08, citing optimism over the healthcare provider's long-term growth plans. The target price implies a 50.9% potential upside from the current price. Analyst Eric Ong believes Thomson Medical's strong portfolio of healthcare assets in the region justifies a premium valuation. The company is expanding in Vietnam and has significant potential for growth in Malaysia, particularly with the planned establishment of a Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone.

images.alt_text: Thomson Medical Group's revenue fell 8.6 per cent to S$168.1 million.
This is the third time Thomson Medical has submitted an application to SGX seeking a grace period to restore its public float.
Thomson Medical had applied to the SGX on Jan 2, 2024 for a further extension of time to restore its public float.
Thomson Medical’s public float dipped to 9.98 per cent in September, while listing rules mandate that at least 10 per cent of a listed company’s shares must be held by public investors.

site_title: Buffett’s annual letter should be required reading for CEOs
summary: Warren Buffett's annual letter to shareholders offers valuable lessons for CEOs and corporate boards. Key takeaways include communicating with investors in plain English, embracing the "do-nothing" approach to investing, and prioritizing patriotism and stakeholder capitalism. Buffett also stresses the importance of selecting trustworthy managers and avoiding "rascals" in business. Additionally, he highlights the value of succession planning, naming his successor, and maintaining a conservative approach to business. These principles, according to Buffett, have contributed to Berkshire Hathaway's success and longevity.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett, 93, assures investors that vice-chairman and designated successor Greg Abel was "in all respects ready to be CEO of Berkshire tomorrow".
The job of any investor is to figure out how to thrive no matter the circumstances, not complain about them.

site_title: Homebuilder Taylor Wimpey to build fewer houses in UK this year
summary: Taylor Wimpey, a UK-based homebuilder, expects to build around 9,500-10,000 homes in Britain this year, a 7% decrease from 2023. The company cited persistent weakness in the housing market and macroeconomic concerns. Its annual profit slumped 49% to £470.2 million, in line with market expectations. Despite easing mortgage rates, the market remains uncertain, with reduced sales rate of 0.67 homes per outlet. The company's CEO, Jennie Daly, noted signs of improvement but emphasized the need for caution due to the uncertain macroeconomic backdrop.

site_title: Hong Kong scraps property curbs to boost weak housing market
summary: Hong Kong has removed property curbs aimed at cooling the housing market, citing the need for a boost to the weak market and to generate revenue. The measures, which included a 15% tax on non-residents and a 7.5% levy on resident buyers, will be cancelled with immediate effect. The government also announced plans to raise taxes on high earners and ease mortgage rules, allowing buyers to borrow more and purchase more expensive homes. The move aims to revive growth in the ailing financial hub and alleviate pressure on the city's strained finances.

images.alt_text: Speakers at the inaugural Climate Business Forum: Asia-Pacific say there is ample room for the region's advancement in green finance.
High mortgage rates will continue to limit investment demand, but a cut in buyer stamp duties may attract some cash-rich mainlanders to buy luxury homes.
Hong Kong is vying with the likes of Singapore and Dubai to woo digital-asset businesses.

According to a Reuters tally, around 20 Hong Kong-listed Chinese real estate developers have defaulted on dollar bonds which would require them to enter into restructuring talks with creditors or face liquidation.

site_title: Global rich keep luxury property prices rising as Manila, Dubai soar: Knight Frank
summary: Luxury property prices rose 3.1% in 2023, defying the trend of falling prices, driven by double-digit gains in Manila (26%) and Dubai (15%), according to Knight Frank. This is attributed to wealth portfolios recovering and affluent buyers targeting luxury properties. In contrast, commercial real estate investment declined 46% in 2023, with the office market shrinking to 22% of global investment. Private real estate investors are expected to increase their buying activity in 2024, taking advantage of market "dislocation."

images.alt_text: The number of homes sold for more than £5 million (S$8.5 million) in January is down 17 per cent from last year.
New York is one of several global cities where rents on luxury apartments fell in the fourth quarter last year.

Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Pertamina to intensify exploration in Indonesia’s east amid higher oil, gas output targets
summary: Indonesia's state-owned energy company Pertamina aims to intensify exploration efforts in eastern regions to achieve higher oil and gas output targets. Upstream unit Pertamina Hulu Energi aims to increase oil production to 627,000 barrels per day, up from 566,000 barrels per day in 2023. The company also plans to pursue mergers and acquisitions in Africa, the Middle East, and Southeast Asia to grow its footprint. Pertamina targets a 4-5% increase in total oil and gas output in 2025, with a focus on biofuels, petrochemicals, geothermal energy, and carbon capture and storage.

images.alt_text: Pertamina is revamping Balikpapan to increase its capacity to 360,000 bpd and to be able to produce fuel with Euro V emission standards.

The logo of the state-owned oil company Pertamina is seen beside the track ahead of the MotoGP Indonesian Grand Prix at the Mandalika International Circuit in Kuta Mandalika, Central Lombok, on October 12, 2023. (Photo by Yasuyoshi CHIBA / AFP)

The logo of the state-owned oil company Pertamina is seen beside the track ahead of the MotoGP Indonesian Grand Prix at the Mandalika International Circuit in Kuta Mandalika, Central Lombok, on October 12, 2023. (Photo by Yasuyoshi CHIBA / AFP)

site_title: Malaysian court reinstates ex-PM Muhyiddin’s graft charges
summary: A Malaysian court has reinstated graft charges against former Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, who was acquitted last year. The Court of Appeal unanimously decided that the High Court's ruling was incorrect, allowing the charges of abuse of power to proceed. Muhyiddin was charged with four counts of abuse of power and three counts of money laundering, related to RM232.5 million in funds sent to his party's bank account while he was in office. The decision is a fresh blow to the opposition leader, who has denied any wrongdoing.

site_title: China’s Baidu revenue climbs after AI helps it weather China downturn
summary: Baidu's revenue rose 6% in the fourth quarter, driven by its ChatGPT-style service, which has attracted over 100 million users. The company's net income declined 48% to 2.6 billion yuan, but its results were better than expected. Baidu is seeking to monetize generative AI and has joined Silicon Valley peers in developing its own AI platform, Ernie. The company aims to create an AI ecosystem and is investing $140 million in local developers to create AI-native applications. Despite this, analysts expect Baidu's earnings growth to slow in 2024 due to rising costs and a challenging economic environment.

images.alt_text: Baidu sign is seen at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song
Samsung is making a push to expand its small share in China, the world’s largest smartphone market.
Baidu’s Ernie Bot has amassed 70 million users three months after its public rollout, and the company claims its self-developed model has matched GPT-4 in terms of general capabilities.
Baidu's deal for Joyy's YY Live has expired three years after it was unveiled because regulators did not approve the transaction by Dec 31.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Baidu's AI chatbot Ernie Bot is displayed near a screen showing the Baidu logo, in this illustration picture taken June 28, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Swisscom in advanced talks to buy Vodafone Italia for US$8.7 billion
summary: Swisscom is in advanced talks to buy Vodafone Italia for US$8.7 billion, merging the business with its Italian subsidiary Fastweb. The proposed purchase is in cash and debt-free, with Vodafone's shares rising 1.7% in early trading. Vodafone believes the deal delivers the "best combination of value creation, upfront cash proceeds and transaction certainty." The acquisition would see Vodafone exit its third-largest market.

images.alt_text: As part of the agreement, Vodafone will use OpenAI technology running on Azure to enhance customer service operations including its consumer chatbot, and Vodafone employees will have access to Microsoft Copilot.

site_title: How much wealth you need to join the richest 1% around the world
summary: The world's 500 richest people added $1.5 trillion to their combined fortunes last year, with Elon Musk adding the most. To join the top 1% in the US, one needs at least $5.8 million, a 15% increase from last year. Monaco remains the country with the highest threshold worldwide at $12.8 million. The widening wealth gap between rich and poor countries is attributed to rebounding markets in the US and other Western nations, with poorer nations like Burundi struggling due to increased borrowing costs and price surges.

images.alt_text: Private real estate investors, the most active buyers in 2023, look set to increase their buying activity in 2024, says Knight Frank.

site_title: Aston Martin annual losses narrow as prices hit record levels
summary: Aston Martin's annual losses narrowed to £171.8 million, more than halving from £451 million last year, after selling prices reached record levels. The company delivered Valkyrie models and other special edition cars, but deliveries of DB12 and Valour models were delayed. Aston Martin expects positive cash generation in the second half of this year and keeps its near- and medium-term forecasts unchanged. The company has been investing in marketing to position itself in the ultra-luxury segment.

images.alt_text: The loss-making British luxury carmaker is seeking to refinance at a tumultuous time in debt markets following the surge in interest rates and uncertainty around rate cuts.

The British luxury carmaker retains the rest of its 2023 outlook, however, saying demand remains strong as it plans to bolster cash and margins by rolling out next-generation sports cars and limited editions this year and next.

site_title: Singapore teen golfer Chen Xing Tong rubs shoulders with world’s best at Sentosa
summary: Singaporean teenager Chen Xing Tong, 15, competes in the US$1.8 million HSBC Women's World Championship at Sentosa's Tanjong Course, one of 66 players. She earned her spot by defeating eight Singaporeans, including three professionals, and is known for her "fearless" style of play. Despite feeling pressure as a small fish in a big pond, Chen has the support of her family and mentor Shamuri Sidek, a 77-year-old former professional. The tournament features reigning Major champions and a star-studded field, including Lilia Vu, Jin Young Ko, and Lydia Ko.

images.alt_text: NAPLES, FLORIDA - NOVEMBER 17: Lilia Vu of the United States plays her shot from the third tee during the second round of the CME Group Tour Championship at Tiburon Golf Club on November 17, 2023 in Naples, Florida.   Michael Reaves/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael Reaves / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Tiger Woods is the most successful player of the past 25 years with 15 major golf championships – second only to Jack Nicklaus.
The PGA Tour sought to keep up with the increase in prize purses LIV Golf was able to offer by introducing much higher purses for designated events.

site_title: CPF Special Account closure not aimed at saving interest monies: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's government is closing Central Provident Fund (CPF) Special Accounts (SAs) for those aged 55 and above, to be completed by 2025. The move aims to ensure long-term savings are put in a retirement account, earning a 4% interest rate, rather than the lower 2.5% in Ordinary Accounts (OAs). The government is not trying to save interest monies, and those aged 55 and above can transfer their SA savings to the Retirement Account (RA) and withdraw from the Ordinary Account (OA) if needed.

images.alt_text: ‘Fairer’ to retain CPF Special Account for those already aged 55 and above: Foo Mee Har
A larger balance in the Enhanced Retirement Sum enablre the distribution of a higher amount from CPF Life in retirement. This goes a long way to ensure a safe and basic income stream.
The move to shift members' savings in the CPF Special Account to the Ordinary Account when they turn 55, and to close the SA has sparked unhappiness.
CPF contribution rates for those aged 55 to 65 will be raised by a further 1.5 percentage points in 2025.
For CPF members who are 55 and above in 2025, their special accounts will be closed, with the savings transferring to retirement account up to the Full Retirement Sum.

site_title: Levi’s wants you to rethink your denim shopping
summary: Levi's aims to transform into a full-fitter brand, focusing on its own stores and e-commerce. Under CEO Michelle Gass, the company plans to increase sales through direct-to-consumer channels to 55% of revenue within six years, up from the current 42%. To achieve this, Levi's is expanding its product assortment, including tops, jumpsuits, and puffer jackets, and investing in digital technologies such as artificial intelligence to enhance customer experiences. The company's sales through retailers declined 2% in the most recent quarter, while sales through its own channels increased 11%.

images.alt_text: Levi will continue to sell other products at the retailer.

site_title: Government funds are set up to meet ‘real commitments’, spending needs: DPM Wong
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced the government's approach to managing its finances, stating that it is setting aside resources for future spending as it is in a "sound fiscal position." The government is introducing a Refundable Investment Credit scheme and increasing spending on new investments, research, and innovation to support growth. Wong emphasized the importance of having a stable fiscal foundation, noting that the days of structural fiscal surpluses are over due to slowing growth and declining investment returns.

images.alt_text: The best way for Singapore to deal with inflation is for business and wages to grow in real terms, says Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.
This overall fiscal surplus represents about 0.1 per cent of gross domestic product.

site_title: China’s aviation fuel demand seen up 13% in 2024: CNPC research
summary: China's aviation fuel consumption is expected to rise 13.1% in 2024 to 39.3 million tonnes, driven by a robust recovery in passenger travel. Crude oil imports are forecast to increase 0.1% to 565 million tonnes, or 11.3 million barrels per day. Meanwhile, diesel demand is expected to fall 2.8% to 196 million tonnes, while petrol consumption is predicted to grow 1.3% to 165.1 million tonnes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Airbus A380-800 aircraft from China Southern Airlines lands at the Beijing Daxing International Airport that is under construction, during a test flight in Beijing, China May 13, 2019.   REUTERS/Stringe

site_title: China’s CDH in talks to buy minority stake in US$1.7 billion Vietnam grocery chain: sources
summary: China's CDH Investments is in talks to buy a minority stake in Vietnam's Bach Hoa Xanh (BHX) grocery chain, valued at up to $1.7 billion. CDH, one of China's biggest alternative investment firms, has emerged as the frontrunner after outbidding rivals. The deal could be struck as early as next month if negotiations are successful, marking global investors' interest in Vietnam's growing business sectors despite the country's property sector woes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman pulls a cart at a supermarket in Hanoi September 20, 2014. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo

site_title: The Los Angeles gallery that found a market in great experimentalists
summary: Los Angeles gallery Commonwealth and Council has built a reputation for showcasing experimental and conceptual artists who address issues of marginalization and decolonization. Owners Young Chung and Kibum Kim have taken risks on artists with unconventional practices, such as transforming into human disco balls, and have fostered a cult following among influential curators and museum directors. Despite financial struggles, the gallery has gained recognition for its locally rooted but globally relevant programming, with artists featured in the Whitney Biennial and Venice Biennale. The gallery's commitment to supporting emerging artists has earned it a loyal following among collectors.

images.alt_text: From Thursday, Yoko Ono’s impact on conceptual art will be on display in a retrospective exhibition at the Tate Modern in London.

site_title: Meta’s Zuckerberg to deepen tie-up with LG on next-gen devices
summary: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg met with LG Electronics CEO William Cho to deepen their strategic alliance on extended-reality technology, including AI integration into consumer devices. The two discussed ways to create a "distinctive ecosystem" with Meta's large language models and LG's content and TV business. Zuckerberg is in Seoul as part of his Asian tour, which also includes meetings with Samsung Electronics, amidst Meta's accelerating investment in AI and growing competition in hardware.

images.alt_text: Mark Zuckerberg is returning to Seoul as Meta is racing to compete in AI with powerful competitors from OpenAI and Microsoft to Alphabet.
The rapid growth of generative AI has triggered fears that the new technology could be used to disrupt major elections across the world this year.

LG Display has received letters of intent (LOI) for the sale of the liquid crystal display (LCD) plant from four to five parties, including BOE Technology Group, TCL’s LCD unit CSOT as well as financial investors.
The new LG Signature OLED T TV, a transparent television, is presented at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas.
Indonesia’s president signed a regulation on Monday requiring digital platforms to pay media outlets that provide them with content.

site_title: GoTo, TikTok compliance with Indonesia’s trade regulation nears 100%, says GoTo CEO
summary: Indonesian tech company GoTo and Chinese-owned TikTok are nearing compliance with the country's trade regulation that bans in-app transactions on social media. GoTo's e-commerce unit Tokopedia is now facilitating TikTok's e-commerce services, and the company expects to receive a quarterly e-commerce fee based on Tokopedia's gross merchandise value. The partnership is expected to benefit GoTo's e-commerce and financial services segments, with the potential to offer digital payments and "buy now, pay later" credit schemes on TikTok. Compliance is expected within a month and a half.

images.alt_text: Grab and GoTo are reportedly discussing a range of scenarios under which both companies could merge.
TikTok has completed a deal agreed in December to buy 75.01 per cent of Tokopedia for US$840 million.
Sea-Lion is part of a S$70 million artificial intelligence initiative in Singapore announced in December 2023.

site_title: India’s Tata Capital plans to raise US$750 million in debut foreign funding next fiscal year
summary: Tata Capital, a non-bank financial company, plans to raise US$750 million in its debut foreign funding through offshore bonds or loans in the next fiscal year. The company aims to grow its loan book by 25% and expects a similar rise in borrowing needs. Tata Capital will start roadshows for the funding by the end of March, and has received a first-time issuer rating of BBB- from S&P Global Ratings and Fitch Ratings. The move is part of the company's diversification efforts, as Indian companies increasingly tap overseas markets for fundraising due to easing US yields and expected rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Tata’s first iPhone assembly plant is in the southern state of Karnataka which it took over from Taiwan’s Wistron last year.
Tata and Airbus are already cooperating to make the C-295 transport aircraft in Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s home state of Gujarat.
A company logo is seen outside the Tata steelworks near Rotherham in Britain, March 30, 2016. REUTERS/Phil Noble
Consolidated revenue rises to 605.83 billion rupees (S$9.7 billion) in the three months to Dec 31 from 582.29 billion rupees a year earlier, TCS says.

site_title: Apple cancellation of car effort boosts urgency of bets on AI, Headset
summary: Apple has abandoned its self-driving car project, Project Titan, and is shifting resources to generative artificial intelligence (AI) and mixed-reality headsets. The decision follows months of deliberation and will impact the company's future revenue streams. Apple will focus on catching up with rivals in the AI industry and turning the Vision Pro headset into a mainstream hit, rather than pursuing a massive car market. The move is seen as a strategic shift to boost long-term profitability, but it eliminates a potential revenue source and may slow down growth.

images.alt_text: Apple exiting the EV market before it really revved up underscores just how tough the business has become.
“More than simply replacing an existing algorithm with a new one, we rebuilt the iMessage cryptographic protocol from the ground up,” Apple says.
The probe against Apple was sparked by a complaint in 2019 from Sweden's Spotify Technology.
Apple is also exploring the use of AI to generate code for testing applications, an often tedious process.

site_title: New York’s School of American Ballet toasts 90th anniversary
summary: The School of American Ballet in New York City is celebrating its 90th anniversary. Founded by choreographer George Balanchine in 1934, the school has grown to become the most prestigious academy for young dancers in the US, with nearly 800 students from 34 states and 12 countries. The school's legacy was celebrated at a gala, which raised over $1.3 million for the scholarship program, with notable alumni and guests attending. The event highlighted the school's commitment to nurturing artistic talent and its continued relevance in the digital age.

images.alt_text: Ballet greats unite for London Ukraine benefit gala

site_title: Toyota’s global output rises by 7% in January
summary: Toyota's global vehicle production increased by 7% in January to 740,332 vehicles, marking the 13th consecutive year-on-year rise. Sales worldwide rose 11% driven by strong US demand, offsetting declining sales in Japan. US sales surged 23%, while European sales gained 2%. However, domestic sales in Japan dropped 14%. Petrol-electric hybrids accounted for nearly two-fifths of Toyota's global sales in January.

site_title: Global LNG demand seen rising in 2024 from China, Europe
summary: Global liquefied natural gas (LNG) demand is expected to rise in 2024, driven by China's return to the market and increasing consumption in Europe. Asia spot LNG prices hit their lowest levels in nearly three years, incentivizing imports from China and India. Europe's new demand will continue to grow, but new capabilities will not be available soon, putting pressure on prices and volatility. TotalEnergies' executive expects a 50% rise in global LNG demand by 2040.

images.alt_text: The expansion follows the discovery of 250 trillion cubic feet of new gas deposits in the North Field, taking overall reserves to about 2,000 trillion, Qatar's Minister of Energy Saad al-Kaabi says.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows a logo of Shell petrol station in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James//File Photo
Tight supply of liquefied natural gas is maintaining prices and price volatility above historic averages, Shell says.

site_title: Country Garden faces liquidation petition in new blow to China property sector
summary: A liquidation petition has been filed against Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese property developer, for non-payment of a US$205 million loan. The petition, filed by Ever Credit Limited, a unit of Kingboard Holdings, has raised concerns about the country's liquidity crisis-hit property sector. Country Garden has vowed to "resolutely" oppose the petition, which is set for a court hearing on May 17. This latest development comes a month after Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted property developer, was ordered to be liquidated.

images.alt_text: The loss is attributed to an increase in fair value loss on investment properties, the write-down of completed properties for sale and properties under development for sale, and an increase in net impairment losses on financial assets.
Authorities are struggling to arrest a slowdown in China’s property market, which saw new home sales last month tumble 34.2 per cent from a year earlier.
An office block in London's Canary Wharf financial district is selling for 60 per cent less than it sold for in 2017 after it was seized by lenders from a Chinese investor.
Sunac says that more than 90 of its projects had been added included to whitelists from cities including Beijing, Tianjin, Chengdu and Chongqing.

Country Garden, China’s largest private property developer, says in a statement to Reuters that its projects were included on the so-called “white lists” of the provinces of Heinan, Hubei, Sichuan, Shandong and the municipality Chongqing.

site_title: Toyota gives no answer to union demands at second round of wage talks
summary: Toyota and the union failed to reach a pact on wages and bonuses in their second round of pay talks, instead deepening their debate on workplace issues. The union had demanded a response to their pay demands, but Toyota did not provide one. The company and union will continue negotiations into next week, with a formal offer for 2024 pay hikes set for March 13. This year's labor talks are closely watched by the Bank of Japan, which sees sustainable wage hikes as necessary for normalizing its monetary policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a Toyota logo at the Tokyo Motor Show, in Tokyo, Japan October 24, 2019. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Singapore must transform to meet ‘very ambitious’ productivity targets, achieve real growth: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for the country to transform and achieve "very ambitious" productivity growth targets to meet its 2-3% annual growth goal over the next decade. This requires firms to adopt new business methods, workers to acquire new skills, and the development of new sectors to replace declining ones. To combat inflation, Wong stated that real growth in wages and business is the best approach, and that Singapore's inflation is under control due to effective monetary policy tightening. The government is also investing in research and development, and introducing workplace-fairness legislation to support workers.

images.alt_text: They provided ideas for unemployment support, aid for older and younger workers, freelancers, lower-wage workers and workers with disabilities.
In the first day of debate on Budget 2024, a total of 29 MPs made suggestions from "multi-tiered" financial support for retrenched workers to subsidies for part-time diplomas.

Singapore can continue to secure growth by serving as a trusted node and connector, offer a strong innovation ecosystem, and transforming through tripartism, says Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.
‘Fairer’ to retain CPF Special Account for those already aged 55 and above: Foo Mee Har

To start with, the interest-free loans can be calibrated towards courses in high-growth industries that lack local manpower, or in other economically important areas, said Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh.

site_title: Glencore eyes Shell Singapore assets as Cnooc pulls out: sources
summary: Glencore is evaluating a potential acquisition of Shell's oil refinery and petrochemical units in Singapore, in partnership with Chandra Asri Petrochemical. The assets, including a 237,000 bpd refinery and a one-million-metric-tonne ethylene plant, would give Glencore a foothold in Asia's main oil hub. However, the aging site has struggled to make money on its products and faces competition from newer refineries in China. Glencore and Chandra Asri have declined to comment on the potential deal, while Shell has not commented on its strategic review of the assets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows a logo of Shell petrol station in South East London, Britain, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/May James//File Photo
Tight supply of liquefied natural gas is maintaining prices and price volatility above historic averages, Shell says.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of commodities trader Glencore is pictured in front of the company's headquarters in Baar, Switzerland, July 18, 2017.  REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Prabowo eyes former bankers to be Indonesia’s next finance minister
summary: Indonesia's presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto is set to appoint a former banker as his finance minister, prioritizing financial expertise and effective leadership. Potential contenders include former health minister Budi Gunadi Sadikin, Deputy State-Owned Enterprises Minister Kartika Wirjoatmodjo, financial regulator chairman Mahendra Siregar, and Bank Negara Indonesia president-director Royke Tumilaar. Prabowo aims to secure funding for his campaign promises while maintaining fiscal discipline, as he prepares to take office after officially being declared president-elect.

images.alt_text: During his campaign, Prabowo managed to turn his image into one that appealed to the young as a likeable uncle.

Prabowo Subianto, presidential candidate and Indonesia's defense minister, center, and Gibran Rakabuming Raka, vice-presidential candidate and son of President Joko Widodo, center left, during a drawing for candidate numbers at the Election Commission's office in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday, Nov. 14, 2023. Three pairs of candidates will start campaigning later this month to win over more than 200 million voters ahead of the Feb. 14 elections. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
Indonesian Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo speaks during the 10th ASEAN finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Jakarta, Indonesia, August 25, 2023. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan
Bambang Susantono, chairman of Indonesia Nusantara Capital Authority shows Indonesia's future capital Nusantara layout in a presentation.
Indonesia plans to exempt more nationalities from visa requirements while simplifying permits to make it easier to host events in the country.
Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto celebrates on stage as unofficial vote counts show that he is poised to become Indonesia's next president.
Indonesia's Prabowo Subianto gestures after casting his ballot to vote in Indonesia’s presidential and legislative elections in Bogor, Indonesia, Feb 14, 2024.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment reverses into the red in H2 with S$170m loss
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) reported a net loss of S$170 million for the second half of its fiscal year, reversing its profit from the same period last year. The loss was attributed to fair value losses from revaluation of its investment properties, primarily in China and the US. Excluding the loss, cash profit after tax and minority interests stood at S$781 million. Revenue fell 3.2% to S$2.8 billion, while earnings per share dropped 79.2%. CLI aims to double its funds under management to S$200 billion by 2028, with plans to accelerate organic growth and expand operations in India and South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: An artist impression of lyf Shibuya Tokyo (above) which will open in the fourth quarter of 2024.
CapitaLand Sea Logistics Fund intends to develop its recently-acquired freehold site in Bangkok into an automated logistics campus.

site_title: Indonesia president says economy remains strong, probability of recession only 1.5%
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo stated the economy remains strong despite global risks, with the probability of recession at 1.5%. The country aims to achieve 5.2% economic growth in 2024, surpassing last year's 5.05%. Widodo emphasized the need to maintain the low recession probability and be vigilant over geopolitical tensions affecting global supply chains and food prices.

site_title: Asia: Shares muted ahead of Federal Reserve comments
summary: Asian stocks were muted on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's comments, following lackluster consumer confidence data in the US and Germany. The Bank of Japan may consider interest rate hikes in April or next month after better-than-expected Japanese consumer inflation data. Global equities rose on Tuesday despite US and German consumer pessimism. Investors will focus on US economic data, including the Personal Consumption Expenditure (PCE) price index, and comments from three Fed officials, which could influence the timeline for US rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.3 per cent to 38,972.41 on Tuesday.
The pan-European Stoxx 600 closed 0.2 per cent higher, boosted by a 1.7 per cent jump in basic resources, recovering from Monday’s four-month low tracking higher metal prices.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 53 to 48.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust maintains DPU S$0.0261 for H2
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust maintained its distribution per unit (DPU) at 2.61 Singapore cents for the second half of 2023, despite a 2.9% decline in gross revenue to S$29 million due to a weaker Japanese yen. Net property income fell 3.3% to S$22.2 million, while distributable income rose 3% to S$18.2 million. The trust's aggregate leverage stood at 35.2% as of December 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: The warehouse, DPL Ibaraki Yuki, is located in Yuki-shi in the Ibaraki prefecture in Japan.
Gross rental income and net property income (NPI) rise on a Japanese yen basis, although NPI in Singapore dollar terms falls due to a weaker yen against the Singapore dollar.

site_title: Virgin Galactic revenue misses estimates, will focus on Delta ships
summary: Virgin Galactic's fourth-quarter revenue fell short of estimates, reaching $2.8 million, below analyst expectations of $2.98 million. The company lost 26 US cents a share and reported full-year revenue of $6.8 million, lower than the expected $7 million. Virgin Galactic plans to focus on developing its Delta spaceplane, pausing flights in the latter part of 2024 to control costs, and aims to enter the new spaceplane into operation starting in 2026.

images.alt_text: Virgin has launched a series of flights carrying researchers and tourists to the edge of space this year with its VMS Eve carrier aircraft and space plane VSS Unity.

site_title: TikTok begins removing Universal Music Publishing content after deal stalemate
summary: TikTok has begun removing Universal Music Publishing Group (UMPG) content from its platform after a licensing agreement expired on January 31. The company is likely to remove all UMPG content by the end of February, although it is still open to negotiating a new deal. UMPG represents artists such as Taylor Swift, Jon Batiste, and Ariana Grande, and their music accounts for 20-30% of popular songs on TikTok. The move comes after a stalemate between TikTok and UMPG over a new licensing agreement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Universal Music Group logo is seen displayed in this illustration taken, May 3, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

(FILES) This picture taken on April 26, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a screen displaying the Tiktok social media platform's logo and the European flag. Tech giants Meta and TikTok are contesting the scope of an EU law that from March will set new rules on competition in the digital marketplace. The European Commission has designated 22 big online companies as "core platform services" to be subject to additional scrutiny and obligations under the Digital Markets Act (DMA) aiming to crack down on anti-competitive practices. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)
TikTok's "election centres" are designed to better inform Europeans about the electoral process.

site_title: South Korea birth rate falls to all-time low
summary: South Korea's birth rate has reached a record low, falling to 0.72 in 2023, down nearly 8% from the previous year. The country's fertility rate is far below the 2.1 children needed to maintain its current population of 51 million. If current trends continue, the population is expected to nearly halve to 26.8 million by 2100. Despite government efforts to encourage women to have more children, including cash subsidies and support for infertility treatment, the birth rate remains low, with the average age for South Korean women to give birth at 33.6 years old.

images.alt_text: South Korea Exchange also will publish major financial indicators of listed firms by sectors, including price-to-book ratio and return on equity.

Doctors shout slogans and carry signs reading 'Opposition to the increase in medical schools' during a protest against the government's medical policy, near the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 15, 2024.
The Bank of Korea held its key policy rate at 3.50 per cent at a policy review in Seoul, keeping it unchanged for a ninth straight meeting as expected by all 38 analysts polled by Reuters.
The report comes after China’s population fell for a second consecutive year in 2023 with the number of new births dropping to around half of that in 2016.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.3% at the opening bell on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping to 3,148.09. Gainers outnumbered losers 53 to 48, with Seatrium trading flat and Thomson Medical rising 3.9%. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS down 0.2%, OCBC declining 2%, and UOB inching up 0.04%. The decline follows a mixed performance in global markets, with the US Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping 0.3% and the S&P 500 rising 0.2%.

images.alt_text: OCBC's net profit for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2023 rises 12 per cent to S$1.62 billion.

site_title: New Zealand central bank holds rates, flags less hawkish policy track
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand held its cash rate steady at 5.5% and trimmed its forecast peak for rates, contrary to market expectations. The decision reduced the risk of further tightening and signaled a slightly more dovish outlook, causing a selloff in the New Zealand dollar and a rally in bonds. The central bank lowered its forecast cash rate peak to 5.6% and continues to foresee a cut until mid-2025, citing balanced inflation risks and declining core inflation and inflation expectations.

images.alt_text: People enter the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) headquarters in Wellington, New Zealand, on Thursday, Dec. 12, 2013. New Zealand's central bank stepped up its inflation-fighting rhetoric and signaled it will start raising interest rates in the first half of next year as the economy strengthens. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: Tikehau and UOB Kay Hian partnering on private credit as interest continues to grow
summary: Tikehau Capital and brokerage UOB Kay Hian have partnered to launch a private credit fund focusing on mid-sized companies in Asia-Pacific, with an initial target of $300 million. The fund, which will provide financing to cash flow-positive and profitable companies in markets such as Australia, Hong Kong, and Singapore, has received $50 million each from both parties. The partnership comes amid growing interest in private credit, with the global market expected to reach $2.8 trillion by 2028, driven by increasing demand for alternative assets and limited access to traditional credit for middle-market companies.

images.alt_text: Market data shows private equity and private credit have significantly outperformed traditional asset classes in recent years.
The partnership will be managed by Private Credit at Goldman Sachs Alternatives, with a dedicated on-the-ground team across multiple Asia-Pacific markets.
The insolvency of European luxury property group Signa could hurt more players across the financial industry, but demand for private debt is said to remain high.

site_title: Gold prices firm ahead of US inflation print
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,031.99 per ounce ahead of the US inflation print and Federal Reserve officials' remarks on interest rate trajectory. US bond yields fell, making non-yielding bullion more appealing. Fed Governor Michelle Bowman signaled a patient stance on easing rates, while investors await the core personal consumption expenditures price index on Thursday. Gold prices also rose for platinum, palladium, and silver, with traders betting on 78 basis points of rate cuts for 2024.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was little changed at US$2,031.03 per ounce.

site_title: 17Live’s H2 loss widens to US$129.7 million on de-Spac expenses
summary: 17Live, a livestreaming platform operator, reported a net loss of US$129.7 million for the second half of 2023, widening from US$9 million in the same period last year. The loss per share increased to US$0.0224, while operating revenue fell 21.7% to US$127.9 million. The company attributed the decline to intense competition and a shift in focus towards higher-margin revenues. Despite this, the group posted an adjusted Ebitda increase of 26% and improved gross profit margin to 41.2%.

images.alt_text: 17Live has redesignated chairman Joseph Phua as CEO and executive chairman following the resignation of current CEO Lin Chien-Lin.

Left: Ng Jing Shen, chief technology officer of 17Live. The live-streaming platform listed on the Singapore Exchange after completing a business combination with Vertex Technology Acquisition Company.
Since the business combination was completed on Dec 8, 17Live has been in the red every day. The sell-off had already started earlier in December, when it was still trading as VTAC.
A Spac's cash management, expense fee and number of shareholders can affect its redemption price, say analysts.

site_title: US renews inquiry into Applied Materials’ Chinese business
summary: US government agencies have issued new requests for information about Applied Materials' shipments to Chinese customers, reviving a sensitive topic as Washington tries to sever sales of advanced chipmaking gear. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the US Attorney's Office for the District of Massachusetts have issued subpoenas, while the Commerce Department and other agencies have made similar requests since 2022. Applied Materials, the US's largest supplier of semiconductor equipment, is cooperating with the government but cannot predict the outcome of these matters.

site_title: Siblings help China’s BYD grab early lead in Thai EV market
summary: China's BYD has taken an early lead in Thailand's electric vehicle (EV) market, thanks in part to the efforts of siblings Pratarnwong and Pratarnporn Phornprapha, who established the Siam Motors Group as BYD's sole national distributor in Thailand over a year ago. Sales have exceeded expectations, prompting BYD to ramp up supply to meet demand. In just 15 months, BYD has become Thailand's largest international EV market, with the Phornprapha family's Rever Group playing a key role in its expansion.

images.alt_text: BYD says that its premium Denza brand, which is 10 per cent owned by Mercedes, will launch in Europe in the fourth quarter.
BYD markets its luxury models under the Yangwang and Fang Cheng Bao brands.
Record deliveries in the fourth quarter, when BYD overtook Tesla as the world’s top seller of electric cars, did not translate into another bumper profit.

site_title: China’s thrifty shoppers create new stock winners and losers
summary: Chinese consumers are tightening their purse strings due to a real estate crisis and job insecurity, affecting confidence. This trend has boosted earnings and share prices for price-conscious brands like Yum China Holdings and Fast Retailing, while premium brands like Starbucks and L'Oreal have seen their stock performance decline. Consumer prices have fallen for four straight months, intensifying a price war among retailers and making luxury items harder to sell.

images.alt_text: Forty-seven companies pull their listing plans from China’s stock exchanges so far this year, compared with 29 withdrawals during the same period one year earlier,

The unusual decision for a state-owned enterprise to raise funds for an LGFV is a sign Guizhou province, one of the poorest and most indebted regions of China, is stepping up efforts to address the financing pressures brought on by maturing LGFV debt.
China is expected to boost fiscal stimulus again this year, but its plans won’t be clear until a national budget is released in March.

site_title: OCBC posts record S$7.02 billion earnings for FY2023; expects lower NIMs, slow loan growth in 2024
summary: OCBC, Singapore's second-largest lender, reported a record net profit of S$7.02 billion for FY2023, a 27% year-on-year increase. The bank expects lower net interest margins and slow loan growth in 2024 due to a global growth slowdown. Net interest income grew 3% year-on-year to S$2.46 billion, while non-interest income rose 25% to S$811 million. OCBC's operating expenses grew 19% to S$1.31 billion, and the bank declared a final dividend of S$0.42 per share. The bank's CET-1 ratio stood at 15.9% as of December 2023, higher than its local peers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An OCBC Bank signage is pictured at their office in Singapore July 11, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: PropNex H2 profit down 27.1% to S$25.8 million amid buyer caution
summary: PropNex reported a 27.1% decline in net profit to S$25.8 million for the half year ended December 2023, due to buyer caution amid cooling measures, high interest rates, and macroeconomic uncertainties. Revenue dropped 14.9% to S$473.8 million, while commission income from agency services fell 7.7%. Despite this, the company retained its strong foothold in the residential market, capturing 62.5% of private new launches and resale segments. PropNex expects a return in buying sentiment in 2024 and plans to expand its sales force to 15,000 by 2026.

images.alt_text: The panel at BT's Property Outlook 2024 (left to right): BT senior property correspondent Leslie Yee; PropNex Realty's CEO Ismail Gafoor; Alan Cheong, executive director for research and consultancy at Savills Singapore; and Justin Quek, CEO at OrangeTee & Tie.
