Which sectors in Singapore property - residential, commercial, or industrial - offer best prospects?
Homeowners can expect to pay the same or lower property tax bills at each of the band levels.

site_title: UK inquiry finds banks shut 142,000 small business accounts in a year
summary: The UK Treasury Committee has found that eight major banks shut nearly 142,000 small business accounts in a year, citing risk appetite and financial crime concerns. Only three banks listed "risk appetite" as a reason, with 4,214 cases. The committee chair, Harriett Baldwin, expressed concerns that discussions on 'de-banking' may be happening informally, and questioned the fairness of treatment of small business customers. The Economic Secretary to the Treasury, Bim Afolami, is set to face questions on whether banks are treating small business customers fairly and if legislation could offer better protection.

images.alt_text: British supermarkets’ most recent earnings have revealed solid growth over the Christmas period, with price cuts and customer loyalty initiatives boosting sales.
Some businesses reported container hire costs had quadrupled, while others faced delivery delays of three to four weeks, as well as cashflow difficulties and shortages of parts.
Household consumption in Britain has still not returned to its level before the Covid-19 pandemic when adjusted for inflation - similar to the picture in some other European countries.

site_title: Family Dollar fined US$41.7 million over rodent-infested warehouse
summary: Family Dollar, a US retail chain, has been fined US$41.7 million for distributing contaminated products from a rat-infested warehouse. The company pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor count of holding products in unsanitary conditions, causing them to become adulterated. The infestation was discovered in July 2021, and the company temporarily closed stores in 2022 before reopening them. The fine is estimated to be the value of the tainted products, and the company must meet "robust" corporate compliance and reporting requirements for the next three years.

images.alt_text: The new plan is in addition to Macy’s decision in January to close five stores and cut 2,350 jobs, or 3.5 per cent of its overall workforce.
Grocery prices remain in the spotlight as Britons grapple with a cost-of-living crisis stretching into its second year.

A woman passes Japanese cosmetics company Shiseido's counter at a department store in Tokyo January 15, 2010. Shiseido said it will buy U.S.-based Bare Escentuals Inc for $1.7 billion in a bid to revamp its global brand and expand in North America.   REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao (JAPAN - Tags: EMPLOYMENT BUSINESS)

A Doordash delivery person rides their bike on Church Avenue in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn on December 4, 2020 in New York City. A rule issued January 9, 2024, by the US Labor Department making it tougher for companies to classify workers as "independent contractors" could take a toll on the gig economy -- and is likely to face challenges. This includes drivers of ride-hailing services such as Uber and Lyft, or delivery workers for companies like DoorDash. (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: A sustainable trade ecosystem is Asean’s best route to building resilience
summary: Asean is well-positioned to thrive in the face of global trade challenges, driven by emerging high-growth corridors and the integration of Asean suppliers into the global trade ecosystem. The region's sustainable trade ecosystem can be future-proofed by creating a genuinely sustainable trade ecosystem that meets core environmental, social, and governance (ESG) goals. Key initiatives include developing a green data ecosystem, promoting inclusive and sustainable finance, and implementing standardized regulations to drive resilient trade. Partnerships between regulators, governments, financial institutions, and corporates are crucial to driving sustainable trade finance and achieving a more resilient regional trade ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Patrick Lee, cluster CEO of Singapore and Asean markets at Standard Chartered, describes the Asean region as attractive, with significant markets like Indonesia and Vietnam having growing populations, a young demographic, a rising middle class and increasing affluence.

site_title: Golden Agri’s H2 profit falls 96.1% to US$15.3 million; proposes S$0.00613 final dividend
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 96.1% drop in H2 profit to US$15.3 million, down from US$392.4 million in H2 FY2022, due to lower revenue and a decline in joint venture profits. The company recommended a lower final dividend of S$0.00613 per share, down from S$0.00991 in the same period last year. Revenue fell 18% to US$4.9 billion, led by a decline in the palm, laurics, and others segment, with the company citing record-high crude palm oil prices in FY2022 as a factor in the normalization of its financial performance.

images.alt_text: Golden Agri-Resources’ revenue for the nine-month period ended Sep 30, 2023, fell 15 per cent year on year to US$7.3 billion.
Fitch Solutions unit BMI notes that the year-to-date average for crude palm oil prices stands at RM3,805.20 per tonne, versus last year’s average of RM4,910.
Earnings per share stood at US$0.0144 for the half year, down from US$0.0307 the previous year.
BMI Research, a unit of Fitch Solutions, noted that CPO prices have averaged RM3,872 per tonne this year as at May 19, nearly 20 per cent lower than they were at end-2022.

site_title: Hotel Properties swings back to black with S$578.2 million H2 net profit
summary: Hotel Properties Limited (HPL) reported a net profit of S$578.2 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, reversing its net loss of S$17.2 million in the first half of 2023. Revenue increased by 16.8% to S$323.1 million, and earnings per share rose to S$1.1024. The company's financial year net profit was boosted 14 times to S$561 million, with revenue increasing 22.2% to S$642.1 million. The board recommended a first and final dividend of four Singapore cents per share and a special dividend of two Singapore cents per share.

images.alt_text: Tycoon Ong Beng Seng is alleged to have offered benefits worth over S$384,000 to former transport minister S Iswaran.
ST20221117_202202929138/Feline Lim/lxcanopy17 Ong Beng Seng at the opening of the HPL Canopy Link in Singapore Botanic Gardens on 17 November 2022.
The board of directors has recommended a first and final cash dividend of S$0.04 per ordinary share, as well as a special dividend of S$0.01 per share

site_title: Australia’s monthly inflation rate steady at 3.4% in January
summary: Australia's monthly inflation rate remained steady at 3.4% in January, supporting the case for the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) to cut interest rates later this year. The result, which was below economists' estimates, was influenced by a broader economic slowdown that's moderating price pressures. The RBA is expected to embark on an easing cycle as early as August, with borrowing costs currently at a 12-year high of 4.35%. The steady inflation rate will be a key factor in the RBA's deliberations at its March meeting.

images.alt_text: National Australia Bank CEO Ross McEwan said on Thursday that inflation was easing in Australia and interest rates appear to have peaked.
Australia's annual pay growth picked up to 4.2 per cent, from 4.1 per cent, the highest since early 2009 and just above market expectations of 4.1 per cent.

site_title: EC World Reit posts calculated Q4 DPU of S$0.0069 as distributions stay suspended
summary: EC World Reit reported a calculated distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0069 for Q4 2023, despite distributions remaining suspended due to insufficient funds. The Reit's gross revenue fell 11.8% and net property income declined 12.7% compared to the prior year, mainly due to a weaker yuan and lower occupancy rates. The manager attributed the decline to the early termination of China Tobacco's leases and a deteriorating market situation in China. The Reit's portfolio valuation declined 43% to 4.3 billion yuan, and the manager is exploring restructuring options and divesting assets through market sales.

images.alt_text: Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou owned by EC World Reit

The illegal mortgages imposed over Fuzhou E-Commerce and Fuheng Warehouse have not been discharged as of Thursday (Feb 2), as the sponsor Forchn Holdings is still exploring various options to discharge the mortgages.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou is one of the properties still illegally mortgaged by EC World Reit's sponsor.
Forchn Holdings, the sponsor of EC World Reit, is said to be working on solutions to discharge the remaining two illegal mortgages on Fuzhou E-Commerce (above) and Fu Heng Warehouse.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou owned by EC World Reit
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou owned by EC World Reit
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou is one of the three  EC World Reit properties that have been mortgaged by the Reit's sponsor.
The properties – Fuzhou E-Commerce, Fu Heng Warehouse (above) and Hengde Logistics – have been mortgaged without approval from EC World Reit.
The troubled Reit is seeking legal advice on the validity of the mortgages on the three properties, Fuzhou E-Commerce, Fu Heng Warehouse and Hengde Logistics.

Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of six properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio. The Reit's gross revenue was down 9.5 per cent to S$27 million in Q3 FY 2023, from S$29.8 million a year ago.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, CLI, Jardine C&C, CDL, UOL, Golden Agri-Resources
summary: OCBC's net profit rose 12% to S$1.62 billion for the fourth quarter, driven by a 2% increase in operating profit and lower allowances. CapitaLand Investment reported a net loss of S$170 million, while Jardine Cycle & Carriage posted an underlying profit of US$576.8 million. City Developments Limited saw a 51.2% rise in net profit to S$250.8 million, and UOL's net profit surged 373.9% to S$572.7 million. Meanwhile, Golden Agri-Resources reported a significant decline in net profit to US$15.3 million, and Olam Group announced a 15.4% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$230.8 million.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, advancers narrowly beat out decliners 285 to 280, after about 2 billion securities worth a collective S$1.2 billion changed hands.

site_title: CDL net profit drops 75% to S$317.3 million for 2023, targets S$1 billion in divestments
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) reported a 75% drop in net profit to S$317.3 million in 2023, largely due to higher financing costs. The company's revenue rose 50% to a record S$4.9 billion, driven by its property development segment. CDL aims to divest S$1 billion in assets this year to alleviate debt burden. Despite missing earnings estimates, the company remains bullish on its Singapore portfolio and certain sectors, including private rented accommodation in Japan and Australia. Cash reserves stood at S$2.2 billion, with cash and available credit totaling S$3.6 billion.

images.alt_text: Some 13 STI constituents across six sectors are expected to benefit from Budget, says Maybank Securities and RHB.
The 204-room hotel is managed by Marriott International and features a 43m rooftop pool, spa, and various meeting spaces.
An artist impression of Yardhouse, an upcoming UK private rented sector development spanning 17-storeys.

site_title: Oil rises more than US$1/barrel as Opec+ mulls extending output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose over $1 a barrel on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures increasing 1.4% to $83.65 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising 1.7% to $78.87 a barrel. This comes as Opec+ considers extending its voluntary oil output cuts into the second quarter to provide additional support, following an agreement to cut 2.2 million barrels per day for the first quarter. The move aims to stabilize the market and provide additional support.

images.alt_text: The new palm oil replanting subsidy will rise to 60 million rupiah (S$5,149) per hectare.
Brent crude futures settled with a gain of 91 cents, or 1.11 per cent, at US$82.53 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Chip-tool maker ASM issues disappointing outlook, shares plunge
summary: ASM International, a chip equipment maker, has issued a disappointing outlook, projecting revenue for the first quarter below market expectations. The company expects revenue of 600-640 million euros, missing analyst estimates of 643 million euros. ASM attributed the shortfall to "softer conditions" in the wafer fabrication equipment market, despite a broader semiconductor market recovery. Shares plummeted as much as 4% due to the disappointing outlook, contrasting with ASML Holding's record high closing price as it expects a rebound in demand for its products.

site_title: Samudera Shipping H2 profit down 77% to US$34.6 million on lower freight rates
summary: Samudera Shipping reported a 77% drop in net profit to US$34.6 million for its second half year, down from US$150.3 million in the previous period, and a 68.6% drop in full-year net profit to US$101.2 million. Revenue also declined 46.1% to US$277 million and 41.2% to US$582.9 million. Earnings per share for FY2023 fell to US$0.1881 from US$0.5985 the previous year.

images.alt_text: Singapore mainboard-listed Samudera Shipping Line operates a thriving regional container shipping business providing feeder services between Singapore and other ports in Asia.
The crisis stemming from the diversions from the Red Sea to avoid rebel attacks has led to soaring freight rates as vessels route around Africa,
China-based electric vehicle maker Nio shares closed within a whisker of their 52-week low at US$7.06, after dropping 1.5 per cent.
COSCO SHIPPING has the best YTD total returns for 2024 among transportation stocks on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Arm’s February surge prompts early bull to step to the side
summary: Arm Holdings' stock price surged in February, reaching a 95% gain for the month, but a prominent analyst downgraded the stock to neutral from buy, citing an "extreme" valuation of 36.5 times revenue projections. The stock closed at $137.95 on Feb 27, down 5.6% on the day, and remains under pressure despite a bullish forecast from Nvidia. Analysts now predict a 30% downside, with half still recommending a buy and the average price target suggesting a significant decline.

images.alt_text: Arm’s technology for creating data centre processors is already in use by Amazon.com, Microsoft and Ampere Computing, which supplies chips to Oracle.

site_title: eBay reports strong holiday quarter, expands buyback plan
summary: eBay reported a strong holiday quarter with a profit of $1.07 per share and $2.56 billion in sales, exceeding analyst estimates. The company also expanded its existing stock buyback program by $2 billion, increasing the total repurchase authorization to $3.4 billion, providing investors with fresh hope for boosting profits.

images.alt_text: The job cuts follow a wave of US tech layoffs after the industry hired heavily during the pandemic, including among behemoths such as Amazon and Google.
EBay chief executive officer Jamie Iannone is trying to sell watches and other luxury items as well as refurbished items to appeal to cost-conscious shoppers.
The company had in June acquired Certilogo, a provider of AI-powered apparel authentication, and bought trading cards marketplace TCGplayer last year.
The San Jose, California-based company is aiming to sell more luxury items like watches to boost revenue while also offering refurbished items to appeal to price-conscious shoppers.

site_title: Beyond Meat tops revenue estimates, plans ‘steep’ cost cuts in 2024; shares soar
summary: Beyond Meat topped fourth-quarter revenue estimates with US$73.7 million, driven by resilient demand for its faux meat patties in international markets. The company plans "steep" cost cuts in 2024, including operating expense reductions and cash use. CEO Ethan Brown also announced pricing actions in 2024. Despite a 7.8% drop in net revenue, shares jumped 84% in extended trade.

images.alt_text: Bogged down by inflationary pressures, customers are opting for lower-priced animal protein over alternatives such as plant-based products.

site_title: Barclays to sell US$1.1 billion of US credit card debt to Blackstone
summary: Barclays has agreed to sell approximately US$1.1 billion of US credit card debt to Blackstone, a deal expected to reduce the bank's risk weighted assets by around £1 billion. The transaction reflects Barclays' strategy to prioritize growing lending to consumers and will free up capacity to expand lending. Barclays will continue to service the accounts for a fee, with Blackstone's investment made through insurance accounts managed by the company's asset-based finance group.

site_title: Chinese chipmaker cleared in US criminal trade secrets case
summary: A US district judge has cleared a Chinese chipmaker, Fujian Jinhua Integrated Circuit, of economic espionage and other criminal charges in a setback for the US Justice Department's efforts to crack down on intellectual property theft by China. The verdict came after a non-jury trial, in which the judge found US prosecutors failed to prove that the company misappropriated proprietary data from Micron Technology. The ruling may temper the Biden administration's pursuit of aggressive prosecutions to protect American technology, following a significant settlement between Micron and Fujian Jinhua.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. and Chinese flags are seen in this illustration taken, January 30, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
VW says it takes allegations of human rights violations very seriously, and its investigations could result in the end of a supplier relationship if a serious violation is confirmed.
The talks underscore trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies.

site_title: Blood in the water from US office Reits could draw highly speculative investors
summary: The US office sector's challenging environment, driven by changing work patterns and a higher interest rate environment, is prompting highly speculative investors to buy into Singapore-listed US office Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits). Manulife US Reit, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, and Prime US Reit have all halted or reduced distributions, with some unitholders relying on them. Investors with a higher-risk appetite or speculative objectives may find opportunities in the current low valuations and high volatility, but caution is advised due to the Reits' high gearing and uncertain market outlook.

images.alt_text: Significant portions of the proceeds will pay for part of Manulife US Reit’s US$122 million acquisition of two freehold office towers, Centerpointe I & II, in Fairfax, Virginia.

site_title: Miami Beach office asking for top rent signs first tenant
summary: J Goldman & Co, a New York-based hedge fund, signed a 10,000 square foot lease at the Fifth Miami Beach office building, the first tenant for the property. The building, which has 60,000 square feet of rentable space, is expected to reach US$170 per square foot in rent, more than double the average rate in Miami's Brickell neighborhood. The property, developed by Sumaida + Khurana and Bizzi & Partners, is the first new office building in over 15 years in Miami Beach's South of Fifth neighborhood, amid a surge in demand for offices in the Miami area.

site_title: WuXi is now most-sold Chinese stock by foreigners on US ban fear
summary: Foreign investors have sold 5.5 billion yuan ($1 billion) of WuXi AppTec shares this year, making it the most-sold Chinese stock by foreigners due to fears of US sanctions. The company's shares have declined significantly, erasing a combined $14 billion in market value, amid efforts by US lawmakers to block Chinese biotech companies from accessing federal contracts. A bill targeting WuXi AppTec and other Chinese firms may be considered by the US Senate committee, with a 30% chance of passing in 2024, according to estimates.

images.alt_text: A congressional committee focuses on China introduced a bill late last month that would restrict federally funded medical providers from allowing China’s BGI Group, Wuxi Apptec and other biotech firms from getting genetic information about Americans.

site_title: Starbucks, US union agree to form ‘framework’ for organising, bargaining
summary: Starbucks and Workers United have agreed to a "framework" for organizing and collective bargaining, guiding the process for workers to unionize and negotiate store-by-store agreements. The framework includes a fair process for organizing and achieving collective bargaining agreements. Starbucks has also agreed to provide benefits to unionized workers, including the ability to receive customer tips from credit card transactions, as a sign of good faith. This marks a potential resolution to an ongoing court case and sets a constructive path forward for the nationwide labor campaign.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 rises on miners, tech support; German shares at record high
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.2% on Tuesday, boosted by a 1.7% jump in basic resources and a 1% surge in tech stocks, which reached its highest level since December 2000. Germany's DAX index hit a record high, up 0.8%, while investors await inflation data that could signal interest rate cuts this year. The recent market rally has lost steam due to concerns over inflation and economy growth, but some analysts still expect a rate cut in June.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.3 per cent to 38,972.41 on Tuesday.

site_title: Hot stock: Olam up as much as 10% as H2 profit rises 15.4% to S$230.8 million
summary: Olam Group, a mainboard-listed agri-business company, posted a 15.4% rise in net profit for its second half ended Dec 31, 2023, reaching S$230.8 million. The company's earnings per share increased to S$0.0567, up from S$0.0478 the previous year. Revenue dropped 10.8% to S$23.6 billion, but sales volume grew 11.8% and Ebit was up 19.3%. The board proposed a final dividend of S$0.04 per share, and the company announced a share buyback programme for up to 5% of total outstanding shares.

images.alt_text: Olam Group says all its businesses in Nigeria “continue to operate normally”.
Cosco shipping expects to report a net profit of about S$1.9 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2023.

India’s rice output is expected to drop this fiscal year for the first time in eight years, raising the prospect of New Delhi extending curbs on exports of the grain to control food prices in the lead-up to elections.

site_title: Singapore agritech firm Archisen partners  Malaysia’s FarmByte to develop vertical farm in Johor
summary: Singapore agritech firm Archisen has partnered with Malaysia's FarmByte to develop a 52,000 sq ft indoor vertical farm in Johor Bahru, valued at RM36.7 million. The farm, expected to be operational by end 2024, will produce over 306,000 kg of vegetables annually, targeting the Malaysian and Singaporean markets. The joint venture, where FarmByte owns 70% and Archisen 30%, aims to foster growth and job creation in the agricultural industry.

images.alt_text: Archisen’s CEO Vincent Wei (second from right) and FarmByte’s CEO Aiman Syed Jaafar (second from left) inked the Heads of Agreement on Nov 14 to develop an automated vertical indoor farm in Johor Bahru.
Let's have pride in home-grown produce

site_title: Coupang’s sales jump after loyalty perks retain shoppers
summary: Coupang reported a 23% revenue rise in the December quarter to $6.6 billion, beating analyst estimates. The company posted its first net income since 2010, driven by a one-time tax accounting gain. Its loyalty program and same-day delivery services helped retain customers, with active users reaching 21 million, a 16% increase from last year. Coupang aims to expand into new markets, including Taiwan, as peers like Alibaba and PDD Holdings venture abroad.

site_title: Apple’s EV wind down offers reprieve to Tesla and Detroit rivals
summary: Apple has exited its electric vehicle (EV) program, providing a reprieve to Tesla and Detroit rivals. The move is a sign of the tough business of the EV market, where growth is slowing and charging infrastructure is patchy. Tesla may benefit the most, as a high-tech EV would have been a status vehicle, but now it faces less competition. The exit also means that Apple's $61 billion in cash will no longer be invested in the market.

images.alt_text: “More than simply replacing an existing algorithm with a new one, we rebuilt the iMessage cryptographic protocol from the ground up,” Apple says.
The probe against Apple was sparked by a complaint in 2019 from Sweden's Spotify Technology.
Apple is also exploring the use of AI to generate code for testing applications, an often tedious process.
The Apple design team is tasked with devising the look and feel of devices and software, as well as developing new features and interfaces.

site_title: US durable goods orders post largest drop in nearly four years
summary: US durable goods orders, a key indicator of business investment, plummeted 6.1% in January, the largest drop in nearly four years, according to the Commerce Department. The decline was largely driven by a sharp drop in commercial aircraft orders, with civilian aircraft orders falling 58.9% and Boeing receiving only three orders in January. Despite the weak data, economists do not foresee a recession, citing a tight labor market and elevated inflation. Business investment in equipment is expected to remain mixed, with some pockets of strength in manufacturing and computer electronics.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee walks past a fuselage section under construction at Boeing Co.'s 787 Dreamliner campus in North Charleston, South Carolina, U.S., May 30, 2023. Gavin McIntyre/File Photo

site_title: Booking.com owner sells debt for stock buyback as travel cools
summary: Booking Holdings, the owner of Booking.com, plans to raise 2.75 billion euros (S$4 billion) from a euro-denominated bond sale to fund a stock buyback. The move comes after the company's shares plummeted 10% last week due to disappointing earnings, which were weighed down by a war in Israel and currency fluctuations. The bond sale will help the company replenish its cash reserves, allowing it to repurchase shares and stabilize its stock price. This is a relatively rare move for a company in the travel sector.

site_title: Hot stock: OCBC falls 3.1% after Q4 earnings miss
summary: OCBC's shares fell 3.1% after the bank reported a Q4 net profit of S$1.62 billion, missing analyst estimates. The bank's non-performing loan ratio decreased to 1% and net interest margin rose 2.29%. OCBC attributed the decline in net interest margin to higher funding costs. Despite a 12% year-on-year gain in net profit, the bank's operating expenses grew 19% and total allowances for the quarter stood at S$187 million, down 41% from the prior year.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of OCBC new signage / logo
Like most banks, OCBC’s net interest margin (NIM) also benefitted from rising interest rates, rising 21 basis points from a year ago to 2.27 per cent in the third quarter ended September.
FILE PHOTO: An OCBC Bank signage is pictured at their office in Singapore July 11, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

OCBC reported a net profit of S$1.7 billion for the second quarter ended June, up 34 per cent from a year earlier, driven by growth in net interest income, while slightly offset by a spike in general allowances
Generic pictures of OCBC new signage / logo
The lender was the last among its local peers to report its quarterly results this season.

site_title: Could AI really boost labour productivity?
summary: Large language models (LLMs) are showing promising signs of boosting productivity growth in white-collar jobs, particularly in customer service centers and consultancy. Studies have found that LLMs can improve the speed and quality of text-based businesses by 14% in white-collar occupations, especially benefiting novice and low-skilled workers. However, it's unclear how generalizable these results are, and some scholars argue that AI may displace workers rather than enhance their capacities, leading to potential disequalizing effects and challenges for policymakers to navigate.

site_title: Marriott offers Taylor Swift concert trips for 500,000 points
summary: Marriott International's loyalty program, Marriott Bonvoy, is sponsoring Taylor Swift's Eras Tour, offering 250 prizes worth nearly $300,000 to members and non-members alike. To enter, participants can use 500,000 points or simply register for a Marriott Bonvoy account. Winners will be chosen lottery-style, with grand prizes including four-day trips to see Swift perform in multiple cities. The promotion aims to grow Marriott's global member base, with 70% of hotel growth occurring outside the US.

images.alt_text: US singer Taylor Swift (L) and her father Scott Kingsley Swift (top R). Australian police are investigating a 71-year-old man for the alleged assault of a photographer in Sydney in the early hours of Feb 27. The accuser identified the man as Taylor Swift's father.
The idea of Singapore paying Taylor Swift to only perform here does not sit well with some people
Taylor Swift’s six concerts in March could boost Singapore’s economy by up to S$500 million in tourism receipts, according to economists’ estimates.

Feb 11, 2024; Paradise, Nevada, USA;  Recording artist Taylor Swift reacts during the first quarter between Kansas City Chiefs and San Francisco 49ers of Super Bowl LVIII at Allegiant Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joe Camporeale-USA TODAY Sports     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
Taylor Swift will hold six shows at the National Stadium from Mar 2 to Mar 9.
The billionaire singer has made economic waves throughout her record-shattering global tour, in a phenomenon dubbed “Swiftonomics”.
Taylor Swift’s relationship with Travis Kelce is captivating the NFL and popular culture this season.

site_title: Best World Q4 net profit drops 15.2% to S$40.4 million on China’s sales decline, rising distribution costs
summary: Best World International reported a 15.2% drop in net profit to S$40.4 million for Q4 2023, citing a decline in China's sales and rising distribution costs. Revenue decreased 4.6% to S$201.3 million. The company proposes no dividend for FY2023, citing an uncertain business climate.

images.alt_text: The mainboard-listed group records slightly lower revenue and higher cost of sales, partially offset by higher interest income.

site_title: Who’s a ‘qualified director’?
summary: A Singaporean director is calling for more transparency in the pre-qualification process for board directors, citing the lack of clear criteria and oversight. Independent directors, in particular, face unclear standards. The director suggests establishing a joint panel to interview proposed appointees and certify their qualifications, addressing the perceived lack of transparency in the process.

site_title: Indonesia’s elections: Continuity and potential surprises
summary: Indonesia's presidential election has concluded with Prabowo Subianto securing almost 60% of the vote nationwide, defying expectations of a second-round election. The victory appeals to various demographics, including age, race, and party preference, making it a notable result. Analysts had predicted a close contest between Prabowo and Anies Baswedan, with some anticipating a second round. Prabowo's campaign successfully repositioned him as a likable figure, particularly among the young.

images.alt_text: Prabowo Subianto, presidential candidate and Indonesia's defense minister, center, and Gibran Rakabuming Raka, vice-presidential candidate and son of President Joko Widodo, center left, during a drawing for candidate numbers at the Election Commission's office in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Tuesday, Nov. 14, 2023. Three pairs of candidates will start campaigning later this month to win over more than 200 million voters ahead of the Feb. 14 elections. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
Indonesia's Prabowo Subianto gestures after casting his ballot to vote in Indonesia’s presidential and legislative elections in Bogor, Indonesia, Feb 14, 2024.

site_title: The EU gives carbon traders what they want – more rules
summary: The European Union has agreed on two key regulations to shape the future of carbon markets, setting benchmarks for offset credits and cracking down on greenwashing. The Carbon Removal Certification Framework (CRCF) will certify quality carbon removals, while the Green Claims Directive requires companies to get approval for environmental marketing claims, with fines of up to 4% of annual turnover for non-compliance. These regulations aim to create trust in the market and distinguish between high-quality and low-quality products, paving the way for growth in the industry.

images.alt_text: Hamburg-based maritime-technology firm OceanScore says Asia-based shipowners will foot 500 million euros under the European Union Emissions Trading System this year for a start, and rise each year thereafter.
The green shift in the 27-nation bloc will affect every corner of the economy, requiring more sustainable consumer lifestyles and more effort from businesses and agriculture.

site_title: US dollar edged lower ahead of economic data, yen rises
summary: The US dollar edged lower against a basket of peers, including the yen and euro, ahead of key economic data, while the yen rose 0.25% to a two-year high of 150.28. Japan's core consumer inflation exceeded forecasts, keeping expectations of the Bank of Japan's policy path alive. The euro also rose, driven by scaled-back expectations of European Central Bank rate cuts. Markets await the release of the US PCE deflator on Thursday, which could suggest less aggressive bets on Fed easing.

images.alt_text: The data shows exporters are increasingly turning to the swap market to convert their overseas earnings and remittances into yuan, rather than outright US dollar selling.
FILE PHOTO: Four thousand U.S. dollars are counted out by a banker counting currency at a bank in Westminster, Colorado November 3, 2009.  REUTERS/Rick Wilking/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks mixed after lackluster data
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones slipping 0.3% to 38,972.41, while the Nasdaq rose 0.4% to 16,035.30. The Conference Board reported a drop in consumer confidence and new durable goods orders decreased 6.1% in January. Despite this, the S&P 500 rose 0.2% to 5,078.18. Markets are pricing in fewer Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in 2024, with Goldman Sachs chief David Solomon stating a recession remains possible.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Friday, Feb. 16, 2024. Wall Street is ending the week on a bit of a sour note, with stocks and bonds falling after economic data continued to fuel speculation the Federal Reserve will be in no rush to cut interest rates. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: JPMorgan CFO expects trading revenue to decline in first quarter
summary: JPMorgan Chase CFO Jeremy Barnum expects trading revenue to decline 5-10% in the first quarter, citing weaker market performance compared to the previous year. Investment banking fees are expected to rise in the low-to-mid teens, while the IPO market is weaker than expected. JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon's succession plan is being taken seriously, with the bank shuffling executives in various units to prepare them for leadership roles. Dimon has also sold $150 million of his shares, citing financial diversification.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase CEO and chairman Jamie Dimon‘s compensation climbed about 4.3 per cent to US$36 million for 2023.

JPMorgan’s fund business says it has decided not to renew its membership of the Climate Action 100+ investor group after “significant investment” in its investment stewardship capabilities over the last couple of years.
JPMorgan’s aggressive expansion strategy comes as some other lenders have been shrinking their presence.

site_title: US consumer confidence ebbs in February; inflation expectations fall
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 106.7 in February, down from 110.9 in January, as households worried about the labour market and domestic politics. Inflation expectations dropped to 5.2%, the lowest level since March 2020. While concerns about food and gas prices eased, consumers are more concerned about the labour market and US political environment. This marks a reversal of the previous three months of steady increases in consumer confidence.

site_title: PUB to build world’s largest facility to help remove CO2 from ocean
summary: Singapore's Public Utilities Board (PUB) plans to build the world's largest facility to remove CO2 from the ocean, with a capacity to remove 3,650 tonnes yearly by 2025. The $20 million plant, Equatic-1, will mimic natural seashell formation and produce hydrogen, with the potential to scale up to 110,000 tonnes yearly. The technology, developed by Equatic, works by pumping seawater through electricity, trapping CO2 for at least 10,000 years. The project aims to help PUB decarbonize its water treatment processes and achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2045.

site_title: Frencken’s H2 net profit down 20.7% to S$20.4 million; numbers show recovery from H1 despite tech downturn
summary: Frencken Group, a semiconductor and machine manufacturer, reported a 20.7% decrease in H2 2023 net profit to S$20.4 million, despite a recovery from the first half of the year. Revenue decreased 1.3% to S$391.8 million, and net profit plummeted 37.4% to S$32.5 million for the full financial year. The company attributes the decline to the cyclical downturn in the semiconductor industry, inflationary cost pressures, and global geopolitical uncertainties. However, revenue and net profit in H2 2023 showed improvements due to continued demand from key customers.

images.alt_text: IDC has upgraded the semiconductor sector’s market outlook to “growth” from “trough”, as it called the bottom of the correction.
Frencken Group's revenue declined 5.6 per cent year-on-year to S$184.4 million

site_title: Food Empire H2 net profit falls 9.6%, but full-year revenue at new high of US$425.7 million
summary: Food Empire Holdings reported a 9.6% decline in net profit to US$29.8 million for its second quarter, despite a 2.9% increase in revenue to US$227.5 million. The company attributed the revenue growth to its Kazakhstan and Commonwealth of Independent States markets, as well as its South-east Asia and South Asia segments. Full-year revenue reached a record US$425.7 million, with net profit down 6% to US$56.5 million. The board proposed a dividend of 10 Singapore cents per share.

images.alt_text: Sudeep Nair, chief executive officer of Food Empire.

site_title: Microsoft's deal with Mistral AI faces EU scrutiny
summary: Microsoft's deal with French tech startup Mistral AI has raised eyebrows in the European Union, with lawmakers demanding an investigation into the tech giant's concentration of power. The 15-million euro investment in Mistral, which will make its AI models available via Microsoft's Azure cloud computing platform, has sparked concerns over the company's motivations and potential breach of EU competition rules. European lawmakers have questioned the deal, citing concerns over regulatory pressure and the potential for systemic risks, with some calling for an investigation into the partnership.

images.alt_text: Mistral has positioned itself as a plucky European champion challenging US dominance in the field.

site_title: Streaming subscriber growth in US halved in 2023
summary: US streaming subscriber growth halved to 10.1% in 2023, down from 21.6% in 2022, according to research firm Antenna. Streaming giants like Netflix, Peacock, and Paramount+ drove the most growth, reaching 242.9 million total subscriptions at the end of 2023. The industry is shifting from focusing on acquisition to managing subscribers, with companies prioritizing content spend and ad offerings to drive revenue. This marks a new phase of sobriety for the industry, which had previously focused on creating content to draw and retain subscribers.

images.alt_text: Roku has raised its quarterly revenue forecast, a sign that ad spending was continuing to improve thanks to cooling inflation and hopes of a pause in interest rate hikes.
Attendance at cinemas has not recovered to pre-pandemic levels, putting pressure on Paramount's film studio as well.
The NFL has broadcast contracts with four companies, Paramount Global, Comcast, Fox, and Walt Disney’s ESPN.
Disney’s investment in streaming ad technology comes as advertisers are moving away from broadcast and cable TV, along with viewers.

Although Netflix's executives said the deal with WWE did not signal a change to its focus on entertainment, it nevertheless sets Netflix on a collision course with traditional media as the streamer builds out its advertising business.

site_title: GHY expects 94 million yuan loss following cancelled China football games with Al Nassr
summary: GHY Culture & Media expects a 94 million yuan (S$17.6 million) loss due to cancelled football games with Al Nassr Football Club. The games, scheduled for Jan 24 and Jan 28, were postponed following Cristiano Ronaldo's injury. GHY paid a US$10 million collaboration fee for the games, and the company will attempt to mitigate the loss through discussions with Al Nassr. The tournament is now expected to be postponed to the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Al Nassr Football Club has apologised following the cancellation of two matches where football superstar Cristiano Ronaldo was unable to play.
Mainboard-listed companies Gallant Venture and GHY Culture & Media expect to post net losses for FY2023.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding H2 net profit rises 64.7% on rise in shipbuilding revenue
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 64.7% increase in H2 net profit to 2.4 billion Chinese yuan (S$443.2 million) due to the depreciation of the yuan, reduced raw material costs, and improved vessel prices. Revenue for the shipbuilding segment rose 23% to 12.1 billion yuan. On a per-share basis, earnings increased to 60.13 yuan cents from 36.51 yuan cents. The company attributes its gross profit margin improvement to these factors during the second half of FY2023.

images.alt_text: 中国造船公司扬子江（Yangzijiang Shipbuilding）的造船场。

site_title: Yanlord records H2 loss of 2 billion yuan; FY23 ‘exceptionally unusual’ with China’s real estate credit crisis, CEO says
summary: Chinese property developer Yanlord Land Group reported a net loss of 2 billion yuan (S$378.9 million) in the fiscal second half of 2023, reversing from a net profit the same period last year. The loss was attributed to increased fair value loss, write-downs, and net impairment losses. Revenue rose 64.6% to 28.6 billion yuan, driven by higher average selling prices, while cost of sales increased 79.1% to 24.5 billion yuan. The company attributed the results to China's real estate-related credit crisis, which began in 2021 and persisted through the year, making 2023 "exceptionally unusual."

images.alt_text: Yanlord sells all units at Shanghai Poetic Villa inaugural launch, bags 3.2b yuan in pre-sales
Evergrande crisis, China property curbs pose near-term challenges for Singapore developers

site_title: Police find scores of guns at French star Delon's home
summary: French screen legend Alain Delon, 88, had 72 unlicensed firearms seized from his rural home in Douchy-Montcorbon, south of Paris. Officers also found over 3,000 rounds of ammunition and a shooting range. Delon has no authorization to own firearms, despite playing gun-toting characters in films. His health has been in decline since a 2019 stroke, and a family feud is ongoing, including a complaint filed by his youngest son against his sister.

images.alt_text: 72nd Cannes Film Festival - Red Carpet Arrivals - Cannes, France, May 19, 2019. Alain Delon poses with his daughter Anouchka Delon before receiving his honorary Palme d'Or Award. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe

site_title: Europe and the world need Ukraine to prevail
summary: The ongoing Russia-Ukraine war poses significant global risks, including food security and energy price instability. Russia's aggression is a classic example of 19th-century-style imperialism, with Ukraine's sovereignty and identity being targeted. The EU and other countries urge continued support for Ukraine, warning that a Russian victory would send a dangerous message that "might makes right." A 10-point peace formula proposed by Ukraine, supported by the EU, aims to strengthen food security, nuclear safety, and human rights, and is seen as the only serious peace proposal on the table.

images.alt_text: A local resident walk pasts the railway station destroyed by a Russian missile attack in Konstyantynivka, Donetsk region, on February 25, 2024, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by Anatolii STEPANOV / AFP)

Residents of Kostyantynivka in Ukraine wait in line for materials to repair their broken windows after a Russian missile attack. Just 10 per cent of Europeans still believe that Kyiv can “win” against Moscow, according to a recent key report.
An apartment building in Dnipro, Ukraine, that was damaged by a Russian drone strike. Two years ago, on Feb 24, 2022, Russia brought war back to Europe on a scale not seen since World War II.
A makeshift memorial to late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, who died in a Russian Arctic prison, in front of the former Russian consulate in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, on Feb 20, 2024.

site_title: MPs suggest tweaks, raise questions about labour policies for various worker groups in Budget debate
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 debate saw MPs suggest tweaks to labor policies for various worker groups, including unemployment support, aid for older and younger workers, freelancers, lower-wage workers, and those with disabilities. Ideas included extending financial support to the broader middle of affected workers, sector-specific support, and ample time for reskilling. MPs also called for greater government transparency, tracking of scheme outcomes, and measures to increase SkillsFuture Credit take-up rates. The government is open to suggestions, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announcing plans to address concerns and expand support for vulnerable groups.

images.alt_text: Singapore can continue to secure growth by serving as a trusted node and connector, offer a strong innovation ecosystem, and transforming through tripartism, says Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.
In the first day of debate on Budget 2024, a total of 29 MPs made suggestions from "multi-tiered" financial support for retrenched workers to subsidies for part-time diplomas.

site_title: Home-price growth in the US accelerates as buyer demand picks up
summary: US home-price growth accelerated in December, with prices rising 5.5% from a year earlier, according to S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller. The national index surpassed the 5% annual gain in November, driven by a decline in mortgage rates from 7.79% to 6.61%. The tight supply of homes listed for sale fueled pent-up demand, pushing purchase prices higher. 10 of 20 markets beat prior records, with San Diego experiencing the largest year-over-year gain at 8.8%.

images.alt_text: US MANHATTAN united states housing Photographer: Alex Kent/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as traders brace for economic data
summary: US stocks opened flat on Tuesday, Feb 27, as investors awaited crucial economic data that could influence interest-rate cuts and the recent rally. The S&P 500 rose 5.07 points, or 0.10%, to 5,074.60, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 37.73 points, or 0.24%, to 16,013.98. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose 18.67 points, or 0.05%, to 39,087.90, as investors braced for inflation reports and economic data.

site_title: Geo Energy H2 profit falls almost 40% as finance costs hike by US$5.5 million
summary: Geo Energy Resources reported a 40% drop in net profit to US$34.8 million for the second half of 2023, primarily due to a US$5.5 million increase in finance costs. Revenue fell 31.7% to US$249.2 million, mainly due to lower average selling prices. Despite production volume decreases, the company still outperformed its 2023 target, and the board proposed a final dividend of 0.6 Singapore cent per share.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's ban on coal exports could dampen its stability, credibility as top exporter: S&P Global
Geo Energy H2 net profit rises to US$129.8m on stronger coal prices, proposes final dividend of S$0.05

site_title: Maersk says Red Sea disruptions could last into second half of 2024
summary: Maersk warns of potential disruptions in the Red Sea supply chain, which could last into the second half of 2024 due to attacks on shipping by Houthi militants. To mitigate costs, the company advises clients to build longer transit times into their supply chain planning and consider alternative routes. Maersk has added 6% more vessel capacity to offset delays. The company's head of North America, Charles van der Steene, advises clients to be prepared for potential shifts in supply chain costs.

site_title: Hong Kong burnishes role as Asia’s green financial hub
summary: Hong Kong is solidifying its position as Asia's leading green financial hub, with the city issuing over a third of Asia's green finance in bonds and loans, totaling over $80 billion in 2022. According to HKMA chief executive Eddie Yue, the growth is a significant increase from $4 billion in 2020. The development is part of Hong Kong's efforts to support the transition to a low-carbon economy through its Green Week, which includes the inaugural Climate Business Forum: Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: China is the world’s biggest market for EVs and smart vehicles.
High mortgage rates will continue to limit investment demand, but a cut in buyer stamp duties may attract some cash-rich mainlanders to buy luxury homes.

According to a Reuters tally, around 20 Hong Kong-listed Chinese real estate developers have defaulted on dollar bonds which would require them to enter into restructuring talks with creditors or face liquidation.

The Oasis statement was referring to reports that NEC had received multiple buyout offers from global private equity funds for JAE before agreeing to tender much of its 51 per cent stake at a discount.

site_title: Interest-rate cuts expected to send money into private assets
summary: Interest-rate cuts are expected to drive investors out of traditional assets and into private assets, such as private equity and private credit. Market watchers predict that lower interest rates will make riskier products more attractive, with some clients expressing renewed interest in alternative investments. Private assets have outperformed traditional asset classes in recent years, driven by an "illiquidity premium" and low borrowing rates. As rates fall, investors will look for value creation through operational improvements rather than financial engineering, and the private-credit space is seen as a sweet spot with potential for capital appreciation later this year.

images.alt_text: Julius Baer has announced its exit from the private debt business following steep losses from loans made to real estate group Signa, which collapsed under the weight of higher interest rates.
Even with exits constrained, investors want to allocate more money because the returns justify it. That demand may be also be higher than it appears.
The insolvency of European luxury property group Signa could hurt more players across the financial industry, but demand for private debt is said to remain high.

site_title: Cordlife braces for 25-30% slide to FY23 net profit amid mishandling scandal
summary: Cordlife Group, a mainboard-listed private cord blood bank, anticipates a 25-30% slide in its net profit for the FY23 due to ongoing investigations into mishandling of its cord-blood unit. The company's cord blood storage tanks were found to have been exposed to temperatures above acceptable limits, and samples are being sent for viability testing. If findings confirm adverse effects, it may further impact FY23 results, with shares closing up 7.1% on Tuesday before the announcement.

images.alt_text: Cordlife Group's new group CEO Yiu Pang Fai has close links to the board and major shareholders.
Shares of Cordlife Group hit a three-year high amid heavy trading on Monday (Jun 26) after the company said it was aware of a possible transaction for an offer for its shares.
New shareholder may be 'new blood' needed for Cordlife's anaemic trajectory

site_title: Sheng Siong H2 profit climbs 3.6% as finance income doubles
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket chain, reported a 3.6% increase in net profit to S$68.3 million for the second half of 2023, driven by a doubling of finance income to S$5.8 million. Revenue rose 2.2% to S$677.2 million, with new store openings contributing 1.9%. The company proposed a final one-tier cash dividend of 3.2 cents per share, higher than the previous year's 3.07 cents.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong H2 net profit rises 4.8% to S$66.9m on boost from new store openings
Large supermarkets must charge at least S$0.05 for disposable carrier bags

site_title: Sony cuts 900 jobs in gaming, shuts down London division
summary: Sony is cutting 900 jobs in its gaming division, accounting for about 8% of its employees, and shutting down its London division. The layoffs will affect three of its most successful subsidiaries: Insomniac (Spider-Man), Naughty Dog (The Last of Us), and Guerrilla (Horizon). The move is intended to help the company grow and develop, according to retiring president and CEO Jim Ryan. The job cuts are part of a larger restructuring effort, with Ryan stating that changes are necessary to continue the business's growth and development.

site_title: Delfi H2 net profit down 14.1%; special dividend proposed on rising confidence, strong net sales
summary: Delfi Ltd, a chocolate manufacturer, reported a 14.1% decrease in net profit to US$21.1 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, despite a 9% increase in revenue to US$255.2 million. The company attributed the decline to a challenging global environment and rising commodity prices. In response, directors proposed a special dividend of 0.52 US cents and a final dividend of 1.74 US cents per share, subject to shareholder approval at the annual general meeting on Apr 23.

images.alt_text: Delfi said that higher selling and distribution costs are expected as it increases investments in its brand building initiatives.
Delfi's strong bottom-line performance comes on the back of a 16.2 per cent year-on-year increase in revenue to US$286.2 million.

site_title: Tetra Pak to close Singapore factory, 300 workers affected
summary: Tetra Pak is closing its Singapore factory in Jurong, affecting around 300 workers, as part of its consolidation of packaging material production into other regional factories. The company will maintain an office in Singapore, with plans to relocate to a new location. Retrenched workers will receive support packages, including career coaching and job assistance, through the union and government agencies.

site_title: OCBC sets up division for innovation and sustainability, picks FairPrice’s Elaine Heng as head
summary: OCBC announces the establishment of a new division, Group Strategy, Innovation and Sustainability, headed by Elaine Heng, former chief executive of retail business and deputy group CEO at FairPrice Group, effective April 22. The division aims to drive growth and future-proof the bank's businesses through innovative practices and sustainability efforts. Heng will work closely with the bank's chief sustainability officer to identify opportunities and capture emerging trends, complementing OCBC's innovative culture. The move follows the bank's addition of a chief sustainability officer last August.

images.alt_text: Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks over the five trading sessions through to Feb 22, with S$141 million of net institutional outflow.
The banks noted that this was in line with recommendations from Singapore’s National Wages Council, for companies to help lower-income employees with the rising cost of living.

site_title: EU Parliament passes nature law despite political backlash
summary: The EU Parliament has passed a landmark nature law despite opposition from farmers' groups, who protested the law's environmental policies. The law aims to restore nature on a fifth of EU land and sea by 2030, reversing the decline of natural habitats. It passed with 329 votes in favor, 275 against, and 24 abstentions. The European People's Party, the largest lawmaker group, opposed the law at the last minute, citing excessive bureaucracy for farmers. The law now needs EU country approval before entering into force.

images.alt_text: Hamburg-based maritime-technology firm OceanScore says Asia-based shipowners will foot 500 million euros under the European Union Emissions Trading System this year for a start, and rise each year thereafter.
A view of Pasir Panjang Terminal.

site_title: Yellen cites monetary tightening as risk in global outlook
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen cited global monetary tightening and geopolitical risks as potential downsides to a favorable economic outlook. Despite this, she highlighted the strength of the US economy, which has driven global growth resilience. Yellen credited Biden administration policies, including infrastructure spending and clean energy investments, for the US economy's surprising resilience. Global growth is expected to rise 3.1% this year, with the International Monetary Fund warning of risks from wars and inflation. Yellen continues to monitor economic challenges, particularly in countries with prolonged conflicts and debt troubles.

images.alt_text: Shipping containers at the Port of Taicang in Taicang, Jiangsu Province, China, on Thursday, Aug. 24, 2023. China’s economy was meant to drive a third of global economic growth this year, so its dramatic slowdown in recent months is sounding alarm bells across the world. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Prince William pulls out of godfather's memorial service due to 'personal matter'
summary: Prince William has pulled out of the memorial service at Windsor Castle for his godfather, the late King Constantine of Greece, due to a personal matter. The palace declined to provide further details. This comes after his wife Kate, 42, underwent abdominal surgery last month and is not due to return to public events until after Easter. The absence is rare for the British royals, but not unheard of, and is not related to his father King Charles' health as he undergoes cancer treatment.

images.alt_text: The Princess of Wales during a walkabout meeting members of the public on the Long Walk near Windsor Castle, Berkshire, where the Coronation Concert to celebrate the coronation of King Charles III and Queen Camilla is being held. Picture date: Sunday May 7, 2023.  Andrew Matthews/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: World economy has growing shot at soft landing, G20 draft says
summary: The G20's draft closing statement suggests a growing chance of a soft landing for the global economy, citing faster-than-expected disinflation. The statement notes that risks to the global economic outlook are more balanced, with upside risks including faster-than-expected disinflation. Inflation has receded in most economies, thanks to monetary policies and moderating commodity prices. However, the draft avoids naming military conflicts, including Russia's invasion of Ukraine, amid divisions among G20 officials.

images.alt_text: epa11147146 Managing Director of International Monetary Fund (IMF) Kristalina Georgieva attends a session at the World Governments Summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, 12 February 2024. The World Governments Summit Organization is an international, impartial, nonprofit group whose goal is to influence how governments operate in the future. The summit is held in Dubai between 12-14 February.  EPA-EFE/STRINGER
Leaders of the G20 nations attend the second working session of the G20 Leaders' Summit at Bharat Mandapam in New Delhi on September 9, 2023. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Jardine Cycle & Carriage H2 underlying profit rises 0.5% to US$576.8 million
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (JC&C) reported a 0.5% increase in underlying profit to US$576.8 million in the second half of 2023, driven by strong results from Astra, one of Indonesia's largest diversified business groups. The group's underlying profit for the full year grew 5.8%, with Astra contributing US$1 billion to the group's earnings. JC&C's net profit for the half year rose 124.8% to US$567.1 million, while full-year net profit was US$1.2 billion, up 64.2% from 2022. The company proposed a final one-tier tax-exempt dividend of US$0.90 per share for the year.

images.alt_text: There are 5.6 per cent more COEs in the August-October quota period than the previous three-month period.

site_title: US retailer Macy’s forecasts annual sales below estimates, to shutter 150 stores
summary: Macy's forecasts annual sales below estimates, citing weak demand for apparel and shoes. The retailer plans to close 150 stores through 2026 and monetize $600-750 million of assets. This decision comes after closing 5 stores and cutting 2,350 jobs in January. Macy's also plans to open 15 Bloomingdale's locations and 30 new Bluemercury stores to accelerate growth for its luxury brands. The company expects fiscal 2024 net sales between $22.2 billion to $22.9 billion, below analyst estimates.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - DECEMBER 11: A Macy's store is seen at Herald Square on December 11, 2023 in New York City. Macy's stock rose more than 17% during morning trading after reports from the Wall Street Journal that Arkhouse Management, a real-estate focused investing firm, and Brigade Capital Management, a global asset manager, have offered to buy the retail chain for $5.8 billion.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Macy’s spokesperson said the layoffs were part of its plan “to deploy a new strategy to meet the needs of an everchanging consumer and marketplace.”
People walk by a Macy's department store in New York City, US, Dec 4, 2023.

site_title: Thailand to start spending 2024 fiscal budget in early April
summary: Thailand's 3.48 trillion baht (US$96.96 billion) budget for the 2024 fiscal year will be ready for use in early April, allowing for faster spending. The budget plan aims to revive Southeast Asia's second-largest economy, which unexpectedly shrank in the final quarter of 2023. The budget act is expected to be passed into law by April 3, after a parliamentary approval process. The government has announced higher spending to address economic concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Locals and tourists play with water as they celebrate the Songkran holiday which marks the Thai New Year in Bangkok, Thailand, April 13, 2023. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo

site_title: GuocoLand starts preview for Lentor Mansion project at prices from S$2,082 psf
summary: GuocoLand starts previews for its 99-year leasehold Lentor Mansion project in Singapore, with prices starting from S$2,082 per square foot. The 533-unit development, located in District 26, features three 16-storey towers and three eight-storey blocks. Units range from two-bedroom to five-bedroom units, with prices starting from S$1.149 million. The project marks GuocoLand's third condominium launch in the Lentor Hills estate, following Lentor Modern and Lentor Hills Residences.

images.alt_text: GuocoLand's strong first-half performance is attributed to high-quality income-generating assets in Singapore such as Guoco Midtown (pictured).
An artist's impression of Lentor Hills Estate highlighting the two sites currently on the market.
GuocoLand-Hong Leong Holdings tie-up is sole bidder for Lentor Gardens site at URA tender

site_title: Sinarmas Land’s H2 net profit down 24.6%; further slowdown expected this year
summary: Sinarmas Land reported a 24.6% drop in H1 net profit to S$163 million, down from S$216.1 million in the same period last year. Revenue for the period fell 0.5% year-over-year to S$743.2 million. The company expects a slowdown in its operational area in 2024 due to property supply surpassing demand and customers' cautious stance. Net profit for FY2024 is expected to shrink 20.7% to S$272.5 million.

images.alt_text: Property developer Sinarmas Land's net profit for H1 FY2023 fell 14.1 per cent, despite an increase in revenue.

site_title: Gaza’s warring enemies cautious over truce talks after Biden says deal is close
summary: US President Joe Biden says a ceasefire in Gaza is close, with a deal potentially reached in under a week to halt the war for Ramadan. Israel and Hamas have agreed on a proposal for a 40-day truce, with militants freeing some hostages in exchange for the release of hundreds of Palestinian detainees and humanitarian aid. However, Hamas is still seeking a clear path to a permanent end to the war and Israeli withdrawal. Qatar, the main mediator, remains hopeful for a breakthrough, but senior Hamas officials say significant gaps remain to be bridged.

US Ambassador to the United Nations Linda Thomas-Greenfield casts a veto vote on a UN Security Council resolution to demand an immediate humanitarian ceasefire in Gaza.

Israeli army soldiers are positioned with their Merkava tanks near the border with the Gaza Strip in southern Israel on October 9, 2023. Israel continued to battle Hamas fighters on October 9 and massed tens of thousands of troops and heavy armour around the Gaza Strip after vowing a massive blow over the Palestinian militants' surprise attack. (Photo by JACK GUEZ / AFP)
Demonstrators gather with signs during a protest outside the Kirya military base which houses the Defence Ministry in Tel Aviv, Israel, Feb 13, 2024.

site_title: Cautious bids seen for Holland Drive site with land cost expected to top S$1 billion
summary: A 12,388 sqm residential parcel in Holland Drive, Singapore, is up for sale with an expected land cost of over S$1 billion, yielding approximately 680 private housing units. Market watchers anticipate muted demand due to the site's high land price, despite its attractive location near the One Holland Village mixed-use development and the Holland Village MRT station. Analysts predict two to five bids, with the highest bid ranging between S$909 million and S$1.6 billion per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: First China-made international jet could gain ground in Asia-Pacific on Airbus, Boeing delays: observers
summary: China's first international jet, the Comac C919, could gain ground in the Asia-Pacific market due to delayed deliveries by Airbus and Boeing. The C919 made its international debut at the Singapore Airshow and will conduct showcase flights in Indonesia, Malaysia, and other countries. Despite being years away from competing internationally, Comac has received over 1,000 orders, and the company aims to produce 150 planes a year by 2028. However, international sales are uncertain due to geopolitical tensions and certification requirements, with some experts predicting a wait-and-see approach to observe the aircraft's performance in China.

images.alt_text: Aviation industry observers say the proposed levy by Singapore to fund sustainable jet fuel use will have a minor effect on ticket prices.
Airbus chief sustainability officer Julie Kitcher said Singapore's recently announced levy for outbound travellers as part of its sustainable air hub drive is a “very positive and concrete” step.
Steven Townend (right) says aviation financing has recovered faster for regions that have very large domestic capital markets which support their domestic industry.
Singapore company DroneDash will partner will Malaysia's Aerodyne Group on cross-border drone delivery trials to begin in 2024.
From engines and seatbelts to wiring and screws, a single plane needs millions of parts from suppliers across the world, making them vulnerable to supply chain hiccups.

Following the trade days, the Singapore Airshow will open its doors to the public on Feb 24 and 25, with an estimated 60,000 visitors expected to attend. Flying displays will be held twice a day at 11.30 am and 2.30 pm over the weekend.
China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow on Feb 18.
VietJet is one of the fastest growing carriers in the region.

site_title: Eurozone lending stagnates as recovery remains elusive: ECB
summary: Eurozone lending stagnates at zero since autumn, with banks increasing loans to firms by 0.2% in January and credit to households growing by 0.3%, the slowest pace since 2015. The European Central Bank's efforts to stem inflation by raising interest rates to record highs have brought bank lending to a standstill. Despite expected interest rate cuts, the ECB's data suggests the economic recovery in the eurozone remains elusive, with the region still struggling to gain momentum.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 27)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore to transform and innovate to sustain growth, positioning itself as a trusted node and connector in the global-Asia market. FedEx opened its regional headquarters in Singapore for the Asia-Pacific, Middle East, and Africa region. PropertyGuru Group cut 79 jobs and closed unprofitable units as part of a strategic review. The first China-made international jet, the C919, may gain ground in the Asia-Pacific market due to delayed deliveries by major aircraft makers.

site_title: Alibaba's South Asian e-commerce giant Daraz announces layoffs in memo
summary: Daraz Group, an Alibaba-owned e-commerce platform, has announced layoffs across its operations in Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and Myanmar, citing "unprecedented challenges" in the market. The move aims to adopt a more streamlined and agile structure, with no disclosed number of employees affected. The company's acting CEO, James Dong, stated that the layoffs are necessary to ensure long-term sustainability and growth, with plans to focus on improving consumer experience and operational efficiency.

images.alt_text: James Dong, who heads Alibaba’s South-east Asian arm Lazada Group, will replace Daraz founder Bjarke Mikkelsen as acting CEO with immediate effect.

site_title: World’s biggest climate finance club GFanz to aid Brazil’s transition
summary: The Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFanz) has pledged to support Brazil's climate ambitions, aiming to halve emissions by 2030 and accelerate industry decarbonization. The initiative includes a climate transition platform led by the Brazilian Development Bank and a Brazil Country Chapter to raise awareness and collaboration on climate finance. GFanz, co-chaired by Mark Carney and Michael Bloomberg, will provide expertise and mobilize capital to finance projects supporting Brazil's green growth goals and advancing its G20 Presidency's climate finance priorities.

site_title: Next-gen wealth transition? This philanthropist has a larger vision
summary: Alice Hung, founder of Paeonia Group, plans to give most of her wealth away through the Paeonia Foundation, a philanthropic endeavor focused on supporting talent and research in science and technology. Hung, a self-made entrepreneur, aims to build a legacy by donating to education and the academe, and has already gifted S$5 million to Nanyang Technological University to establish a professorship in science and technology. Unlike many ultra-wealthy individuals, Hung believes her children should build their own fortunes, and her foundation's vision is to lend a hand to the needy and develop young minds in science and technology.

images.alt_text: Alice Hung, founder, Paeonia group
NVPC chief executive officer Tony Soh says: “Through this inaugural summit, NVPC... is stepping up by broadening and aligning giving efforts at the national level."

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, February 27, 2024 (Ep 10)
summary: Singapore stocks declined on Tuesday as traders awaited US inflation data, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.1%. Meanwhile, Bank Negara Malaysia stated that the ringgit should appreciate this year due to a strong economy. In Hong Kong, the government cracked down on crypto shops and exchanges, further tightening regulations on the industry.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 56 to 47.
The currency has slumped 4 per cent against the US dollar so far this year, extending its poor performance in recent years.

site_title: Malaysia to seal free trade deal with UAE by June: trade minister
summary: Malaysia is expected to conclude a free trade agreement with the UAE by the end of June, according to Trade Minister Tengku Zafrul. The deal is expected to boost investment in Malaysia's energy, digital economy, electric vehicle, and chip sectors, particularly from the UAE's sovereign wealth funds. The agreement could also make Malaysia a hub for UAE investments in Asia. This comes after Mubadala Investment Company, a UAE sovereign wealth fund, is already an investor in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: The currency has slumped 4 per cent against the US dollar so far this year, extending its poor performance in recent years.

King of Malaysia Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar looks on during a welcoming ceremony at the National Palace in Kuala Lumpur, on January 31, 2024. (Photo by HASNOOR HUSSAIN / POOL / AFP)
Malaysia’s year-on-year inflation growth has stayed below 2 per cent since September last year.

Incentives encouraging companies to move their bases to the Tun Razak Exchange include an industrial building allowance, and tax exemption on 70 per cent of the statutory income for a period of five years for property developers.

site_title: Five guidelines for building a stock portfolio
summary: Investing in the stock market requires a tailored approach. Key tips include defining investment objectives and risk tolerance, ensuring adequate industry and geographic diversification, and monitoring portfolio performance. A well-diversified portfolio should consist of 30-100 stock positions, with a mix of growth, blue-chip, and dividend stocks. Position sizing should consider the risk-reward ratio, and maintaining some cash on hand can provide opportunities to buy stocks at discounted prices. Regular portfolio reviews are essential to ensure alignment with investment goals and risk tolerance.

images.alt_text: Daily activities such as shopping for food could spur interest in a grocery chain's financials. Sheng Siong Group is listed on SGX.

The start of the New Year is a great time for making resolutions on how to improve your investment performance. By doing so, you can improve your investment process and position yourself to enjoy a better return.

site_title: WTO approves services trade rules, overcoming objections
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has approved new rules facilitating trade in services between 71 member states, including the European Union, China, and the US. The rules, which were negotiated by Costa Rica, are expected to reduce costs by over $119 billion annually. Despite initial objections from India and South Africa, a "spirit of compromise" led to the agreement. WTO chief Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala hailed the outcome as a significant milestone for the organization and praised India and South Africa for finding a way forward, calling services the "future of trade."

images.alt_text: The Director-General of the World Trade Organization (WTO) Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala addresses the audience at the start of a conference of the heads of Germany's diplomatic missions abroad, on September 4, 2023 at the Foreign Office in Berlin. (Photo by John MACDOUGALL / AFP)

site_title: The ultimate product placement: Thailand on The White Lotus
summary: Thailand is partnering with HBO's "The White Lotus" for the third season, with the country's tourism industry expected to benefit from the show's influence. The Thai government has approved a rebate of 150 million baht (S$5.6 million) for international productions and waived personal income tax for foreign talent. The show's production is expected to attract international visitors, with searches for Thailand on Expedia increasing by 50% since the announcement. Four Seasons Resorts in Maui and Taormina are among the locations featured in the show, and tourism authorities are hoping to showcase more than luxury properties. The partnership is expected to generate significant revenue for Thailand's tourism industry, with the country welcoming 28 million visitors last year.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift’s six concerts in March could boost Singapore’s economy by up to S$500 million in tourism receipts, according to economists’ estimates.
Thailand received about 28 million foreign tourists last year versus a record of nearly 40 million in pre-pandemic, with spending of 1.91 trillion baht.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s IHC adds AI-powered observer to board
summary: Abu Dhabi's International Holding Co (IHC) is adding an AI-powered observer, Aiden Insight, to its board. The virtual entity will analyze decades of business data to help human board members make better strategic decisions. The move is part of the UAE's push to become a global leader in AI technology. IHC is backed by Emirati AI company G42 and Microsoft, and is part of a US$1.5 trillion empire controlled by Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan. Aiden Insight will attend board meetings as a non-voting observer and focus on risk assessment and compliance monitoring.

images.alt_text: Zhuhai Wanda managed nearly 500 malls across China as at the end of November, including 204 from independent third parties.
“The increased allocation will include investments to grow the company’s domestic and international carbon management platforms,” Adnoc says.
Hong Kong’s ties with Middle Eastern investors have been growing in recent years.
