site_title: China wine dispute may be resolved in weeks: Australian trade minister
summary: Australian Trade Minister Don Farrell says a trade dispute over wine tariffs with China may be resolved in a few weeks. China lifted trade barriers in response to improved relations, and a review of the wine tariffs is expected to lead to their removal next month. The tariffs, imposed by Beijing last year, had blocked Australian wine exports worth about $800 million to China.

site_title: UOL posts 374% leap in H2 profit to S$572.7 million on gains from Parkroyal Kitchener sale
summary: UOL Group reported a 373.9% leap in net profit to S$572.7 million for its fiscal second half ended Dec 31, 2023, driven by a S$442.3 million gain from the sale of a wholly owned subsidiary holding Parkroyal on Kitchener Road. The group's half-year profit was down 12% to S$145.5 million before fair-value and other gains. A special dividend of S$0.05 per share is proposed on top of a first and final dividend of S$0.15 per share. The full-year profit was up 43.9% at S$707.7 million.

site_title: Tech and beverage families go property shopping
summary: Wealthy individuals, including tech giant Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma, have been active in property shopping in Singapore. Ma's wife bought three shophouses on Duxton Road for over S$40 million. Other notable transactions include the sale of Serene Centre to the Teo family for S$105 million. The housing market is expected to see stability in 2024, with condo resale prices falling for the first time in five months. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) have reported mixed results, with some experiencing significant declines in distribution per unit (DPU) due to high interest rates.

images.alt_text: Private property owners have baulked at seeing their property tax bills shoot up this year, after a two-tiered tax hike designed as a de facto wealth tax kicked in

Wee Cho Yaw's accomplishments stretch far beyond banking, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Residential rents are starting to come off their highs., writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Market players are watching closely to see if the government will award the Marina Gardens Crescent site to GuocoLand-Hong Leong group, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Book review: Four pillars to help you make better financial decisions
summary: Renowned author William J. Bernstein's book, "The Four Pillars of Investing," provides a comprehensive guide to creating and maintaining a successful investment portfolio. The book outlines four key pillars: theory, history, psychology, and business, which serve as the foundation for making informed investment decisions. Bernstein emphasizes the importance of a long-term approach, diversification, and minimizing costs to achieve financial goals. The book offers practical strategies and case studies, making it an essential resource for investors seeking to improve their financial literacy and make better investment decisions.

The bulk of stock ratings falls into the buy/hold cagegory; a sell recommendation is rarely seen, says author Martin Fridson.

site_title: US Reit unitholders urged to submit tax forms on time to help trusts preserve cash
summary: US Reit unitholders are urged to submit tax forms on time to help trusts preserve cash, as Reits that suspend or reduce distributions may face US withholding taxes. If unitholders fail to submit tax documents, Reits will be exposed to withholding taxes, potentially impacting their ability to preserve cash and meet loan repayment obligations. Unitholders must return completed US withholding tax forms and certificates to protect their interests and help Reits meet loan repayment obligations.

images.alt_text: Goals for its recapitalisation plans include avoiding selling buildings at significant discounts to current valuations, and restarting distributions earlier than planned, Kore's manager said.

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower as traders eye macro data, STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.4% lower, with the Straits Times Index falling to 3,157.32, as investors awaited macroeconomic data for clearer interest rate guidance. Asian markets had a mixed day, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.9% and the SSE Composite Index adding 1.3%. The US Federal Reserve's comments on interest rates and personal consumption expenditures data are expected to influence investor sentiment. UOB was the top gainer, while Jardine Matheson Holdings was the biggest loser, shedding 2.2%.

images.alt_text: The Europeans have remodeled their fiscal rules - the Stability and Growth Pact - to increase flexibility in the effort to maintain fiscal discipline in the long run.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished  0.2 per cent lower at 39,069.23 on Monday, pulling back from an all-time high.

site_title: PropertyGuru cuts 79 jobs, closes unprofitable units in strategic review
summary: PropertyGuru Group, a leading property portal, has cut 79 jobs, about 5% of its workforce, as part of a strategic review aimed at adapting to volatile market conditions and changing customer needs. The company will close two branches in Vietnam and consolidate technology delivery to improve collaboration and innovation. Roles in customer support will be redesigned across marketing, product, and enterprise sales to serve customers holistically and with enhanced value. Affected staff will receive severance pay, a goodwill payment, and access to an outplacement service for three months.

site_title: Roboadvisers need their own money
summary: Digital wealth management platforms, such as roboadvisers, face financial viability concerns despite growing assets under management. Despite years in the market, none of the main players in Singapore have reported profits. The low-fee business model is under scrutiny, with startups focusing on volume and scale. Meanwhile, companies like Grab, which recently reported its first profitable quarter, face pressure to maintain profitability.

images.alt_text: Insects as a source of alternative proteins aren’t for everyone, as some startups in South-east Asia have found out over the years, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.

VCs, too, have raised money for their funds, but it isn’t all cheery there, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
The rise of fintech in the region has partly been driven by the opportunity to serve the "underbanked" population, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
Lazada's recent layoffs suggest its plans to IPO may not be on the cards any time soon, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.

site_title: Samsonite considers options after takeover interest, including going private
summary: Samsonite International, a Hong Kong-listed luggage maker, is considering options after receiving takeover interest from buyout firms. The company is working with advisers to study possibilities, including going private, and has held preliminary discussions with a select group of suitors. Shares surged 14% in Hong Kong following a Bloomberg report, with the company's market value reaching around HK$37 billion (S$5.4 billion). Deliberations are ongoing, with no certainty on whether a transaction will occur.

site_title: SBS Transit H2 profit up 2.7% as public transport operating profit grows 10.3%
summary: SBS Transit's fiscal second half net profit rose 2.7% to S$34.3 million, driven by a 10.3% increase in operating profit to S$21.9 million. Lower premises, repairs, and staff costs contributed to the growth, offset by higher fuel and electricity costs. Revenue from public transport services decreased 0.2% to S$752.9 million due to lower fuel indexation for bus service fees.

images.alt_text: SBS Transit posts 67.3% fall in H2 profit

ComfortDelGro should disclose its strategic options to assure investors and avoid exit from STI

site_title: Indonesia plans to double palm oil replanting subsidy to spur participation
summary: Indonesia plans to double its palm oil replanting subsidy to 60 million rupiah (S$5,149) per hectare to boost farmer participation in the program. The new subsidy aims to replace 2.5 million hectares of old trees by 2025, with a target of 180,000 hectares of area to replant annually. The government hopes to increase take-up and reduce administrative hurdles, which have been slow due to concerns over loss of income. The total subsidy is expected to reach 10.8 trillion rupiah per year, funded by levies collected from crude palm oil exports.

images.alt_text: The group says the sales volume of its palm products had increased during the period, resulting in a rise in revenue.
Indonesia set a target to replant 180,000 hectares of palm trees on smallholders’ land every year to boost output without clearing more forest.
Companies have to submit paperwork and pay fines to obtain cultivating rights on their plantation by Nov 2, 2023.
Indonesia, the world’s biggest exporter of palm oil, uses proceeds from the levy to subsidise biodiesel and fund palm replanting programmes.

site_title: Li Auto jumps 25% as earnings withstand China EV price war
summary: Li Auto's shares surged 25% in Hong Kong after reporting net income of 11.8 billion yuan ($2.2 billion) last year, making it the first of three major Chinese EV startups to post an annual profit. The company's vehicle shipments more than doubled, and analysts praised its better-than-expected profitability per vehicle. Li Auto reiterated its goal of selling 800,000 vehicles this year, despite ongoing price competition, and is set to unveil a new minivan and refreshed SUVs on Friday, which could have a "transformational impact" on its market perception.

site_title: Taiwan Jan export orders beat expectations on AI demand, but outlook soft
summary: Taiwan's export orders beat expectations in January, increasing 1.9% to $48.42 billion, driven by strong demand for artificial intelligence applications. However, the outlook remains soft due to high interest rates in Western markets and geopolitical uncertainty. Orders from China rose 28%, while those from the US and Europe declined. Despite a traditionally low season for orders, the economy ministry expects a 11-15.7% decline in February orders, citing risks including US interest rates, China-US trade disputes, and broader geopolitical uncertainty.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cargo trucks work inside a container yard in Keelung, Taiwan, January 7, 2022. REUTERS/Ann Wang

site_title: Thomson View relaunched for en bloc sale at lower S$918 million reserve price
summary: Thomson View Condominium, a 255-unit development, is relaunched for en bloc sale at a lower reserve price of S$918 million, down from previous attempts in 2022 and 2021. The site, zoned for "residential" use, has a plot ratio of 2.1 and potentially yields 1,240 residential units. The sale does not require a pre-application feasibility study, and interested parties have until Apr 18 to submit their offers. The site's proximity to the Upper Thomson MRT station and nearby amenities are expected to attract buyers.

site_title: FedEx opens regional headquarters in Singapore for Asia-Pacific, Middle East and Africa
summary: FedEx has opened its regional headquarters in Singapore for the Asia-Pacific, Middle East, and Africa (AMEA) region, marking a significant move from its previous location in Hong Kong. The 2,694 sqm office in the Centennial Tower will serve as a hub for the company's operations across the region, with approximately 35,000 employees serving 100 countries and territories. FedEx President for AMEA, Kawal Preet, cited Singapore's geographic advantages and growing markets in South-east Asia as key factors in the decision. The move is seen as a vote of confidence in Singapore as a key global hub for trade, logistics, and connectivity.

images.alt_text: FedEx says it will consolidate some Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa (AMEA) headquarters functions in Singapore “to connect all of our operations in this region with greater speed and agility.

site_title: Fintech enabler Fluid raises US$5.2 million in Series A led by Insignia
summary: Fluid, a Singapore-based fintech startup, has raised US$5.2 million in Series A funding led by Insignia Ventures Partners. The funding will be used to expand product capabilities and onboard bigger suppliers, with a focus on streamlining business-to-business payments. Founded in 2023 by Trasy Lou Walsh, Steven Li, and Ruoyun Yang, Fluid offers a platform that allows suppliers to take on buyers with credit terms while enabling buyers' access to purchase financing. The startup's total funding now stands at US$7 million.

site_title: Expedia to eliminate 1,500 jobs as travel growth moderates
summary: Expedia is eliminating approximately 1,500 jobs, about 9% of its workforce, as part of a leadership transition and efforts to revive growth. The Seattle-based company cited a need to invest in core strategic areas for growth, following disappointing holiday results and a weaker-than-expected outlook for the current quarter. This move comes as the online travel company and its peers, such as Airbnb and Booking Holdings, contend with moderating travel growth.

images.alt_text: Hotel chain owners, including IHG have benefited from a tourism boom over the past year and as travel demand is expected to surpass pre-pandemic levels.
Airbnb has been working to adapt its app to the local market and raise awareness to drive traffic and is starting to see the effort pay off.
Now, the famous couple is getting ready for a monumental weekend, with millions eager to follow along.
Expedia's shares, which have gained over 60 per cent since November, slid more than 12 per cent in extended trading.
Klook co-founder Eric Gnock Fah says one of the startup's growth pockets is helping millions of consumers in Asia book travel online for the first time.
The company has greater exposure in Europe and the Middle East than rivals such as Expedia Group.
Expedia’s total gross bookings across travel products rose 7 per cent from the year-earlier period to US$25.69 billion.

site_title: Biggest Thai bank said to be near purchase of Home Credit Vietnam
summary: SCB X, Thailand's largest bank by market value, is close to acquiring Home Credit Vietnam for up to $900 million. The deal, which values Home Credit Vietnam at $800 million to $900 million, is expected to be announced this week after SCB X outbid rivals. Home Credit kicked off the sale process last year, also attracting interest from Kasikornbank and KB Kookmin Bank. The move follows Home Credit's decision to streamline operations and focus on European investments.

images.alt_text: Founded in 1997, Home Credit has operations in countries across Asia, central and eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.

site_title: Gold prices steady as US inflation data looms
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$2,031.03 per ounce as investors awaited US inflation data due later this week, which could impact interest rates and the appeal of non-yielding bullion. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields slipped to 4.2775%, making gold more attractive. Recent remarks from Fed policymakers suggested no rush to cut interest rates, with markets pricing in 80 basis points of rate cuts for 2024. Investors also await data on durable goods orders and the core personal consumption expenditures price index.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was up 0.1 per cent, making greenback-priced bullion less affordable for overseas buyers.

site_title: Evergrande founder’s ex-wife sues son over US$128 million in loans
summary: Ding Yumei, ex-wife of China Evergrande Group founder Hui Ka Yan, has filed a lawsuit in Hong Kong against her son Peter Xu over US$128 million in loan payments. Xu, who previously ran Evergrande's wealth management unit, is accused of failing to make payments for loans borrowed in June 2020. The lawsuit comes as Evergrande faces a liquidation order and Hui Ka Yan's personal fortune is being urged to help repay investors. Ding holds a 5.99% stake in Evergrande worth US$16 million, and her Canadian passport suggests she may have assets outside of the company.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The Evergrande logo is seen on residential buildings in Nanjing, in China’s eastern Jiangsu province on August 18, 2023. Troubled Chinese real estate giant Evergrande was issued a winding-up order on January 29, 2024, after failing to convince a Hong Kong court that it had a working restructuring plan. (Photo by STRINGER / AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Thailand’s high-speed rail link to China delayed at least two years, incurs extra costs
summary: Thailand's high-speed rail project, aiming to connect Bangkok to Kunming via Laos, has been delayed by at least 28 months and will require an additional 4.7 billion baht (S$176 million) in funding. The project, first proposed in 2010, was initially expected to be completed by 2026, but changes to the design of a section of the railway have led to the delay. The first stage of the project, covering 251 km from Bangkok to Nakhon Ratchasima, is currently under construction and more than 15% complete.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's US$7.3 billion HSR project has been viewed by observers as a big step towards Asean’s push for seamless integration and connectivity in the region.

Thailand has completed 12 per cent of the first stage, expects a test run by 2026 and the official launch the following year, according to Pichet Kunadhamraks, director-general of Department of Rail Transport.

site_title: Hunting down opportunities in Singapore’s real estate markets
summary: Singapore's housing market stayed stable in 2023 despite headwinds, with the public housing market seeing around 25,000 transactions annually. Experts predict that buyers will need to take a long-term approach to planning due to the new flat classification system. Prices continue to trend up, with limited fresh supply, and certain industrial assets still offer yields. The market is expected to remain moderate and stable, making it a good time to review portfolios. Experts also suggest looking into overseas properties and strata-titled office units as investment options.

images.alt_text: Find out if you should be buying residential, commercial or industrial real estate at the BT Property Outlook Seminar 2024.
The BT Property Outlook 2023 seminar attracted about 130 readers and subscribers.

The panel at BT's Property Outlook 2023 (left to right): PropNex Realty chief executive Ismail Gafoor; Qian Wenlan, professor of finance and real estate, and Ng Teng Fong chair professor in real estate at NUS Business School; Edmund Tie chief executive Desmond Sim; BT senior property correspondent Leslie Yee.

site_title: EU’s volatile emissions-trading scheme will soon cost Asian shipowners big money
summary: Asian shipowners operating vessels to and from the EU will face significant costs under the European Union Emissions Trading System (EU ETS), with estimated annual costs of 500 million euros to 1 billion euros. The system, which began in January 2024, requires shipowners to surrender EU Allowances (EUAs) equivalent to 40% of their emissions liability for voyages to and from the EU, rising to 70% in 2025 and 100% in 2026. The costs are expected to increase due to the volatile carbon price, which is dictated by supply and demand for EUAs.

site_title: Straits Trading’s H2 net loss narrows to S$43.5 million
summary: Straits Trading Company reported a net loss of S$43.5 million for the second half year ended December 2023, narrowing from the prior year's H2 net loss of S$121.8 million. The real estate segment remained the main contributor to the group's performance, with a lower fair value loss from certain investment properties. The hospitality segment also returned to profitability in H2, driven by stronger operating performance.

images.alt_text: A freehold Good Class Bungalow at 8A Cable Road, Chatsworth Park.

The underlying properties being offered are a freehold Good Class Bungalow (GCB) located at 8A Cable Road, Chatsworth Park (pictured), and a 999-year leasehold condominium unit in Duchess Residences at Bukit Timah.
Gains in Straits Trading's property revenue was offset by a decline in tin mining and smelting revenue.
Chew Gek Khim, executive chairman of Straits Trading, which is seeking to adopt a new scrip dividend scheme.
Ms Chew Gek Khim, executive chairman of The Straits Trading Company.

site_title: PepsiCo, IBM sell bonds through Singapore to reap tax benefit
summary: US companies, including PepsiCo and IBM, are selling bonds through their Singapore subsidiaries to reap a tax benefit. Singapore's domestic tax law allows companies to deduct interest payments on debt from taxable income, reducing effective borrowing costs. This tactic has led to a record surge in debt sales from Singapore, with corporates selling US$51.5 billion of notes last year. The benefit may be available for at least three years, but a new OECD rule may soon stop firms from using this technique. The sales have pushed debt sales volume from Singapore to an all-time high.

images.alt_text: The soda and snacks giant forecast annual organic revenue growth of at least 4 per cent, compared to the 9.5 per cent growth reported for fiscal 2023.
IBM has focused on streamlining its operations around software and services in recent years, divesting managed infrastructure, weather and health businesses.

site_title: Record-breaking projections light up Tokyo skyscraper
summary: Tokyo's city government headquarters now features the world's largest permanent projection mapping display, "Tokyo Night and Light," certified by Guinness World Records. The display, featuring soaring birds, traditional patterns, and illustrations of landmarks like Mount Fuji, began on Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Officials hope it will attract tourists and add color to the city's skyline year-round, capitalizing on Japan's surge in foreign visitors since pandemic-era border closures ended.

images.alt_text: The JP Tower and its surrounding facilities have an overall floor area of around 861,700 square metres, and include office space, green areas, residential units, hotel rooms, and shops and restaurants.

site_title: China Everbright Water’s FY2023 profit rises 17% to HK$1.2 billion
summary: China Everbright Water's net profit for FY2023 rose 17% to HK$1.2 billion, driven by a 17% increase in earnings per share to HK$0.4151. The company's board proposed a final dividend of HK$0.0581 per share, up from FY2022's HK$0.0514. Revenue fell 0.3% to HK$6.7 billion, while gross profit margin increased to 42% due to lower direct costs. The company highlighted its healthy financial position and gearing ratio of 60.7%.

images.alt_text: The PBOC is expected to hold its liquidity operations on the first working day after the Chinese New Year holiday ends, which would be Sunday.
Xi Jinping's drive against corruption has ensnared former officials at state-owned banks, the banking regulator and state-owned oil and tobacco firms in recent weeks.
Tang Shuangning, former chairman at China Everbright Group, was expelled from China’s Communist Party earlier this month for severe violations and disciplines.
The notes are rated ‘AAA’ by Shanghai Brilliance Credit Rating & Investors Service.

site_title: Japan’s inflation beats forecasts, end of negative rates still in sight
summary: Japan's core consumer inflation rose 2.0% in January, beating economists' median estimate of 1.8% and staying within the Bank of Japan's 2% target. The slowdown was partly due to a drop in energy costs, indicating waning cost-push pressure. This news supports expectations that Japan will end negative interest rates by March or April, as companies are expected to offer hefty pay hikes to labor-management wage talks. The core inflation rate has slowed for three consecutive months, with the "core core" index rising 3.5% year-on-year in January.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda says Japan’s economy is likely to experience a positive cycle, in which higher job and wage growth leads to moderate rises in inflation.
The Nikkei share average started 1980 at 6,867 and ended the decade at 38,915.
Japan’s economy has unexpectedly slipped into recession in the fourth quarter of last year, losing its title as the world’s third-biggest economy to Germany.
The bank is “certain to attain” its net profit target of 920 billion yen (S$8.2 billion) this financial year through March, a record for the bank, says CEO Toru Nakashima.
Asahi is among a number of Japanese companies seeking growth in the US.

site_title: Goldman, Morgan Stanley are backstopping riskiest slices of CLOs
summary: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are increasingly willing to backstop the riskiest parts of new collateralized loan obligations (CLOs), offering to temporarily hold onto equity portions of the structures as a bid to win more market share. This move allows them to gain an edge in the lucrative industry of arranging CLOs, but also comes with significant risks if they cannot quickly find a buyer, incurring capital charges or selling at fire-sale prices. The banks' willingness to underwrite CLO equity is seen as a creative technique to entice managers and a way to solve for the most difficult part of the capital structure.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians in front of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Friday, Feb. 16, 2024. Wall Street is ending the week on a bit of a sour note, with stocks and bonds falling after economic data continued to fuel speculation the Federal Reserve will be in no rush to cut interest rates. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Puma sees sneaker demand picking up in second half of year
summary: Puma expects demand for sneakers and sports gear to pick up in the second half of 2024, driven by major sporting events such as the European soccer championships and Summer Olympics in Paris. The company plans to introduce new products and implement a revival plan, despite a subdued 2024 outlook. Puma's shares rose 3.9% in early trading before paring gains, and the company will invest in its first global brand campaign in 10 years. Despite a 30% decline in stock value over the past year, Puma aims to spur growth by building out its higher-priced offerings and streamlining distribution.

site_title: New Zealand set to scrap world-first tobacco ban
summary: New Zealand's coalition government is set to repeal a world-first tobacco ban, which was scheduled to take effect in July, allowing tobacco sales to those born after 2009. The ban, which aimed to reduce nicotine content and limit tobacco retailers, was heavily criticized by researchers and campaigners, who warned it could lead to increased smoking rates and health inequities. The repeal decision was made as a matter of urgency, without seeking public comment. Associate Health Minister Casey Costello plans to introduce measures to help people quit smoking and tighten regulations on vaping.

images.alt_text: Air New Zealand is facing intense competition on its international routes, particularly from North America.
Air New Zealand has come under pressure as more airlines return to the Pacific long haul routes into the US as global travel revives after the Covid pandemic.
Record immigration is the overwhelming driver of the surge in population.
The swaps pricing points to the risk of a policy error by the RBNZ and underscores the difficulties that markets face in trying to gauge the outlook as the global tightening cycle peaks.

site_title: Australian police investigate Taylor Swift's dad over alleged assault
summary: Australian police are investigating a 71-year-old man, identified by a photographer as Taylor Swift's father Scott Kingsley Swift, for allegedly assaulting him at Neutral Bay Wharf in Sydney on February 27. The incident occurred when the man disembarked a super yacht in the early hours of the morning. The 51-year-old photographer was reportedly punched by the 71-year-old man. The police have declined to formally identify the suspect, citing that they do not release suspect names unless charges are laid. The investigation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift’s six concerts in March could boost Singapore’s economy by up to S$500 million in tourism receipts, according to economists’ estimates.

site_title: Alibaba leads record deal to create US$2.5 billion China AI firm
summary: Alibaba Group Holding led a record $1 billion funding round for Moonshot AI, a year-old Chinese artificial intelligence startup, boosting its valuation to $2.5 billion. This deal, along with others, signals Alibaba's continued investment in generative AI, a technology used by ChatGPT. The funding round joins existing backers, including Meituan and Sequoia China, and follows Alibaba's efforts to turn around a flagging company under new chiefs Joseph Tsai and Eddie Wu.

images.alt_text: The valuation of the Suning stake is far smaller than the US$4.6 billion the Alibaba's Taobao paid for it in 2015, representing a roughly 90 per cent loss.
“A local partner is basically an opportunity to keep you very tightly integrated in the dialogue about what’s happening,”  says Michael Evans, president of Alibaba Group.
Alibaba reports revenue of 260.35 billion yuan (S$48.9 billion) for the three months ended Dec 31.

site_title: Malaysia ringgit undervalued, should be trading higher, says central bank governor
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor, Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour, has stated that the ringgit is undervalued and should be trading higher due to the country's positive economic fundamentals and prospects. The currency has slumped 4% against the US dollar this year, but Ghaffour believes it should appreciate due to improving exports, a recovery in tourism, and increased investments. Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has also expressed confidence in the economy's prospects, citing strong fundamentals and low inflation and unemployment rates.

images.alt_text: Some companies, such as state-owned oil and gas company Petroliam Nasional, are in a position to benefit from the plunge in the ringgit.

site_title: Chipmaker Broadcom sells remote-access unit to KKR in US$4 billion deal
summary: Broadcom is selling its end-user computing unit to private-equity firm KKR in a US$4-billion deal. The unit, which allows users to access desktops and applications from any device, will operate as a standalone company and continue to be led by its existing management team. The deal is expected to close in 2024, following Broadcom's US$69-billion purchase of VMware last year. KKR has a history of carve-out deals and sees potential for growth in the technology services sector.

images.alt_text: The layoffs will begin on Jan 26 and affect some 1,267 positions, Broadcom said in a submission to the California Employment Development Department.
Broadcom chief executive officer Hock Tan aims to turn VMware into the centrepiece of his software operations after previously purchasing CA Technologies and Symantec’s corporate security business.

site_title: China’s Zhida weighing HK$1 billion Hong Kong IPO this year
summary: Zhida Technology Development, a Chinese EV charging system maker, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong that could raise approximately HK$1 billion (S$172 million). The IPO, potentially taking place this year, is being worked on with Shenwan Hongyuan Group. Founded in 2010, Zhida serves over one million car owners and 70 car brands across China, and its IPO comes amid a slowing new-energy vehicle sales market in China.

images.alt_text: Shein has been subject to scrutiny from the US, with Senator Marco Rubio among those asking the SEC to block its listing.

site_title: As growth gets harder to achieve, Singapore must transform, innovate and be a global-Asia node: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Singapore to transform, innovate, and deepen its standing as a global-Asia node for technology, innovation, and enterprise. The country must restructure its economy to sustain transformation, encourage innovation, and boost productivity-driven growth. Key initiatives include a new Refundable Investment Credit scheme, a SkillsFuture Level-Up program, and a strengthened research, innovation, and enterprise ecosystem. Heng also highlighted the importance of tripartism, workers taking ownership of their career development, and fostering greater connection and collaboration among stakeholders.

images.alt_text: In the first day of debate on Budget 2024, a total of 29 MPs made suggestions from "multi-tiered" financial support for retrenched workers to subsidies for part-time diplomas.
DPM Lawrence Wong said he hopes this year's Budget will give Singaporeans confidence to build a better future even in an increasingly troubled world.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly lower as traders await fresh data
summary: Asian markets began the week mostly lower, following record-setting gains last week, as traders await fresh economic data and central bank rate cut outlook. Tokyo stocks advanced at the open, driven by a cheaper yen and US chip-linked shares, while Shanghai stocks rose and Hong Kong fell. Investors are eyeing the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure, the US Personal Consumption Expenditure price index, due Thursday, and comments from Fed officials on Wednesday and Friday, which could provide insights into the central bank's rate cut plans.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished  0.2 per cent lower at 39,069.23 on Monday, pulling back from an all-time high.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 56 to 47.

site_title: Malaysia companies brace for costly fallout as ringgit hits 26-year low
summary: Malaysia's ringgit has hit a 26-year low, causing businesses to face costly fallout. The weakening currency makes importing materials and servicing foreign debt more expensive. Industries such as airlines, construction, and telecommunication firms are particularly at risk due to currency mismatch. Companies like AirAsia and Axiata Group face financial strain from rising debt servicing costs. However, state-owned oil and gas company Petroliam Nasional and plantation company Sime Darby Plantation may benefit from the plunge in the ringgit.

site_title: China airlines can boost US flights to 50 per week, US says
summary: The US Transportation Department has approved Chinese airlines to increase weekly round-trip US flights to 50 starting March 31, up from 35, representing about one-third of pre-pandemic levels. The move is seen as a step forward in normalizing the US-China market, with over 150 weekly flights allowed before restrictions were imposed in 2020. The approval comes as China simplifies visa applications for US tourists and US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo aims to boost travel and tourism between the two countries, which could add $30 billion to the US economy and 50,000 jobs.

images.alt_text: The Comac C919 is China's first international airliner and could gain sales as aviation giants Airbus and Boeing grapple with supply-chain disruptions.

site_title: West Bank museum showcases Gaza ‘artistic demonstration’ against war
summary: A Palestinian museum in the West Bank is showcasing art and heritage from Gaza, presenting an "ongoing artistic demonstration" in solidarity with the war-ravaged territory. The display features works from hundreds of Gaza-based artists, including traditional paintings, costumes, and archaeological artifacts, amidst the destruction and siege. The exhibit aims to preserve Palestinian heritage and affirm the oneness of the Palestinian people, which the Israeli occupation is trying to destroy, following the devastating war that has killed at least 29,782 people.

site_title: Hong Kong budget expected to ease property curbs, boost tourism
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan is set to unveil a budget that will ease property curbs and boost tourism, aiming to cement the city's status as a global financial center. The government is expected to cut buyer stamp duties, potentially attracting cash-rich mainlanders to buy luxury homes, despite high mortgage rates limiting investment demand. The city is also expected to roll out measures to boost tourism, including fireworks and seasonal activities, in an effort to revive the struggling economy. A budget deficit is expected, but no cash handouts are anticipated.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is vying with the likes of Singapore and Dubai to woo digital-asset businesses.

According to a Reuters tally, around 20 Hong Kong-listed Chinese real estate developers have defaulted on dollar bonds which would require them to enter into restructuring talks with creditors or face liquidation.
Singapore also has targeted incentives for foreign companies looking to set up regional hubs, an approach that is paying off.

site_title: Xi crackdown on ‘hedonistic’ bankers fuels industry brain drain
summary: China's economy is struggling as confidence among domestic consumers and international investors craters. President Xi Jinping's crackdown on bankers deemed "hedonistic" has led to salary cuts and bonuses being slashed by up to 60%. The industry is experiencing a brain drain, with 80% of firms in the banking and financial services sector losing talent in the past six months. Xi's push for "common prosperity" and "centralised and unified leadership" is seen as stifling innovation and forcing bankers to prioritize ideology studies over career advancement.

images.alt_text: More than 150 weekly round-trip passenger flights were allowed by each side before restrictions were imposed in early 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, but until August 2023, Chinese and US carriers could each fly only 12 a week between the two countries.

site_title: Inflation in UK shops falls to lowest level in nearly two years
summary: The UK's shop prices have fallen to their lowest level in nearly two years, with inflation slowing to 2.5% in February, down from 2.9% in the prior month. This marks the ninth consecutive monthly decline, attributed to easing supply-chain pressures, falling input costs, and fierce competition among retailers. Food inflation has also decelerated, with sharp drops in fresh food prices. The data suggests a broader slowdown in inflation and potential signs of an emerging economy recovery.

site_title: Shein considers London IPO amid US resistance to listing
summary: Shein, a fast-fashion company, is considering listing on the London Stock Exchange instead of the US due to hurdles in the US IPO process. The company faces scrutiny from the US, including Senator Marco Rubio's call to block its listing unless it discloses more about its Chinese operations. Shein is still working on its US IPO application, and if it switches to London, it would need to file a new overseas listing application with Chinese regulators. This move could be a boon to the struggling London IPO market, which saw a record-low US$1 billion raised last year.

images.alt_text: Last May, a bipartisan group of US lawmakers urged the SEC to block Shein’s IPO until it verifies it does not use forced labour.

site_title: Biden hosts high-stakes White House talks on Ukraine, shutdown
summary: US President Joe Biden is hosting high-stakes talks at the White House with top Congress leaders to secure billions of dollars in emergency aid for war-torn Ukraine and avert a government shutdown. The talks come after President Volodymyr Zelensky warned of Ukraine's desperate need for Western support to defeat Russia. A partial government shutdown is looming, with Congress still failing to approve 12 annual spending bills. The White House and Congress leaders will discuss a $60 billion aid package and a continuing resolution to keep spending at current levels.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump stands accused in the case of paying hush money to a porn star, for which he faces 34 counts of allegedly doctoring business records as part of a cover-up.

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, speaks during a news conference at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 1, 2023. site_title: Astronomers observe scar on white dwarf 'cannibal' star
summary: Astronomers have observed a scar on a white dwarf star, located 63 light years from Earth, which is believed to have formed as a result of the star ingesting planetary debris. The star, a "cannibal" star, is slowly cooling and is providing new insight into the behavior of these stars at the end of their life cycle. The scar, imprinted on the star's surface, is a result of the star's intense magnetic field interacting with the debris. This discovery sheds light on the complex processes involved in the formation and evolution of white dwarf stars.

images.alt_text:
Artist's impression shows the magnetic white dwarf WD 0816-310, where astronomers have found a scar imprinted on its surface as a result of having ingested planetary debris. When objects like planets or asteroids approach the white dwarf they get disrupted, forming a debris disc around the dead star. Some of this material can be devoured by the dwarf, leaving traces of certain chemical elements on its surface. European Southern Observatory/L. Calcada/Handout via REUTERS

site_title: Bumitama Agri’s H2 profit climbs 94.7% to 1.26 trillion rupiah on higher palm product sales
summary: Indonesian palm oil producer Bumitama Agri reported a 94.7% increase in net profit for the second half of 2023 to 1.26 trillion rupiah, driven by higher palm product sales volume and revenue. Revenue rose 15.8% to 7.95 trillion rupiah, led by crude palm oil product sales. The company's full-year net profit declined 13.3% to 2.45 trillion rupiah, but analysts raised their targets for the company after its Q3 earnings beat expectations.

images.alt_text: Bumitama CSO Lim Sian Choo
RHB Research now rates Bumitama Agri at "buy" after upgrading its call on the stock from "neutral".
Bumitama Agri says its year-to-date performance gap is narrowing from its previous year's record high.
Despite the present softness in crude palm oil prices, the palm oil industry’s long-term fundamentals remain intact, OCBC Investment Research says.
Fitch Solutions unit BMI notes that the year-to-date average for crude palm oil prices stands at RM3,805.20 per tonne, versus last year’s average of RM4,910.

site_title: Amazon’s AWS to invest over US$5 billion to boost cloud computing in Mexico
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) Mexico is investing over US$5 billion to establish a cluster of data centers in the Mexican state of Queretaro, aiming to boost cloud computing in the region. The investment, spread over 15 years, follows growing demand for cloud services as companies adopt new technologies. This move is part of nearshoring, a trend of companies relocating businesses from Asia closer to the US, amid supply chain disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Adding Amazon will increase consumer retail exposure as well as other areas in the Dow, and the move was prompted by Walmart’s decision to split its stock, S&P Dow Jones Indices said in a news release.
Bezos has adopted a trading plan to sell 50 million shares anytime before Jan 31, 2025.
The NFL has broadcast contracts with four companies, Paramount Global, Comcast, Fox, and Walt Disney’s ESPN.
The case differs from other private litigation over the “Buy Box” by focusing on harm to consumers from deceptive practices.
The company says users can ask the software what they’d need to start an indoor garden or ask for Valentine’s Day recommendations, among other questions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Haw Par, Ho Bee Land, Bumitama Agri, Straits Trading, Gallant Venture
summary: Haw Par's net profit rose 58.1% to S$112.4 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, compared to S$71.1 million in the same period last year. In contrast, Ho Bee Land reported a net loss of S$104.1 million for the same period, reversing from a net profit in the previous year.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) lost 0.4 per cent or 13.79 points to end the trading session on Monday (Feb 26) at 3,171.12.

site_title: Bitcoin tops US$57,000 as big buyers circle
summary: Bitcoin surged to a two-year high of $57,036 on February 27, driven by large buyers and the approval of bitcoin-owning exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in the US. MicroStrategy's disclosure of a $155 million bitcoin purchase also contributed to the rally. The cryptocurrency has gained 32% in value so far in February, with ether rising to a two-year high of $3,220. Market participants are anticipating possible regulatory approval of spot ether ETFs, further fueling the price increase.

images.alt_text: The company’s co-founder Michael Saylor is a prominent Bitcoin advocate.
Bitcoin's resurgence has electrified the broader cryptocurrency market, including Ether and other digital coins, which has now exceeded US$2 trillion, as per data from CoinGecko.
Bitcoin has risen around 20 per cent since the start of February, already set for its biggest monthly rise since October.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Tuesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.1% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 2.91 points to 3,174.03, despite overnight losses in global markets. Gainers outnumbered losers 56 to 47, with Seatrium and Thai Beverage being the most actively traded counters. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS and UOB gaining, while OCBC declined. The rise was attributed to a rebound from Monday's losses, which were influenced by global market declines ahead of US inflation data and interest rate cut expectations.

images.alt_text: Haw Par's net profit rises 58.1 per cent for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023.

site_title: Boeing hit by damning FAA report faulting safety culture
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) released a damning report criticizing Boeing's safety culture, citing ineffective procedures, breakdowns in communication, and a lack of trust among employees. The 50-page report, mandated by Congress, identified 27 findings and 53 recommendations to address Boeing's safety shortcomings. The report comes amid pressure from regulators, lawmakers, and customers following a near-catastrophic accident on an Alaska Airlines flight in January. Boeing has created a new chief aerospace safety officer position and adopted a safety management system, but the findings underscore the company's struggles to ensure bad news reaches executives.

images.alt_text: From engines and seatbelts to wiring and screws, a single plane needs millions of parts from suppliers across the world, making them vulnerable to supply chain hiccups.
The door panel that flew off the Alaska Airlines MAX 9 appeared to be missing four key bolts, according to a preliminary report this month from the US National Safety Transportation Board.
The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: US prosecutor seeks to gag Trump in his first criminal trial
summary: US prosecutors have requested a gag order on Donald Trump, citing his history of disparaging witnesses and threats to the prosecutor and his staff. Trump faces 34 counts of allegedly doctoring business records as part of a cover-up related to paying hush money to a porn star. The request comes as Trump faces multiple civil and criminal legal proceedings, including a $355 million penalty imposed in an unrelated civil case. Trump's team has also appealed the penalty and is likely to continue to use the cases to fuel his presidential campaign.

images.alt_text: Nikki Haley, former governor of South Carolina and 2024 Republican presidential candidate, speaks during a campaign event in Troy, Michigan, Feb 25, 2024.
Nikki Haley says she is not giving up and would continue her presidential campaign despite losing on home ground.
FILE PHOTO: An employee works on an assembly line at startup Rivian Automotive's electric vehicle factory in Normal, Illinois, U.S. April 11, 2022. REUTERS/Kamil Krzaczynski/File Photo

epa11150727 US President Joe Biden delivers remarks in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 13 February 2024. President Biden urged the US House of Representatives to pass a 95 billion USD bill with aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. The package passed with bipartisan support in the Senate but is unlikely to pass in the Republican-controlled House due to opposition from hard-right conservatives supporting former US President Donald J. Trump.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS / POOL

Trump assumes that relations between states  are transactional, and, that as long as Beijing or Moscow do not threaten US military and economic interests directly, Washington could make deals with them.

site_title: Restructuring specialists boost Hong Kong staff as China property crisis stokes demand
summary: Restructuring specialists Alvarez & Marsal and Houlihan Lokey have boosted their staff in Hong Kong amid China's property crisis, with around 260 and 150 employees respectively, as debt restructuring deals surge. About 20 Hong Kong-listed Chinese real estate developers have defaulted on dollar bonds, requiring restructuring talks. Demand for debt restructuring professionals has seen a significant uptick since 2023, with firms like Sidley Austin expanding their teams. This trend contrasts with investment banking job cuts in Hong Kong and China.

images.alt_text: For international investors becoming increasingly skittish about China, the sudden trading restrictions give them one more reason to stay away.
Beijing has sought to diffuse a US$9.3 trillion time bomb in hidden local debt by restricting indebted, poorer regions from making new borrowing.
New home prices in China fell 0.3 per cent month-on-month after dipping 0.4 per cent in December, according to Reuters calculations based on National Bureau of Statistics data.
China is expected to boost fiscal stimulus again this year, but its plans won’t be clear until a national budget is released in March.
Beijing’s stringent Covid curbs, persistent crackdowns on the private sector, the property crisis and geopolitical tensions with the West have all combined to erode Hong Kong’s growth prospects.
China's five-year loan prime rate (LPR) was lowered by 25 basis points to 3.90 per cent from 4.20 per cent previously, while the one-year LPR was left unchanged at 3.45 per cent.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, UBS pay men 40% more than women in Australia
summary: Morgan Stanley, UBS, and other major Australian financial institutions have been found to pay men significantly more than women, with a median remuneration gap of 26% across the financial and insurance services sector. The gap is even wider at top banks, with some paying men up to 40% more than women. The Australian government has released the data, which also shows that local stalwarts such as National Australia Bank and Macquarie Group have smaller pay gaps. Finance Minister Katy Gallagher has called for transparency and accountability to drive change, while experts say a male-dominated hierarchy is a major contributor to the pay gap.

images.alt_text: Job seekers at a career fair. The Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported that the annual average weekly earnings for women last year was US$1,005, or 83.6 per cent of the US$1,202 earned by men.

site_title: Micron starts mass production of its memory chips for use in Nvidia’s AI semiconductors
summary: Micron Technology has started mass production of its High Bandwidth Memory 3E (HBM3E) chips for use in Nvidia's AI semiconductors, which are expected to power generative AI applications. The HBM3E consumes 30% less power than rival offerings, supporting soaring demand in the AI market. Nvidia plans to use the chip in its next-generation H200 graphic processing units, set to ship in the second quarter. The move is seen as a boost to Micron's revenue, with the company expecting "several hundred million" US dollars in HBM revenue in fiscal 2024.

site_title: US Fed hikes are hurting consumer mood more than economists think
summary: US consumers' gloomy mood amid a strong economy may be attributed to elevated borrowing costs, according to a research paper by the IMF and Harvard University. The paper suggests that consumers include the cost of money in their economic well-being, which is not factored into official inflation data. This results in a disconnect between official inflation rates and consumer sentiment. The researchers propose alternative measures of inflation that incorporate the cost of money, which significantly narrows the gap between predicted and actual consumer sentiment, explaining over 70% of the average gap in economic sentiment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Newly constructed single family homes are shown for sale in Encinitas, California, U.S., July 31, 2019.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
US households continued to spend in 2023, despite their reduced purchasing power due to inflation on the one hand, and increased interest rates on the other.
FILE PHOTO: Manhattan skyline is seen during sunset in New York City, New York, U.S. March 29, 2023. REUTERS/Amanda Perobelli//File Photo

site_title: BYD pitches floating luxury SUV to win over European buyers
summary: BYD is showcasing a luxury SUV, the Yangwang U8, at the Geneva car show, which can float on water and features a 1,200-horsepower plug-in hybrid. The vehicle represents BYD's push into the luxury market and aims to compete with Mercedes-Benz and Land Rover. BYD also plans to launch its premium Denza brand in Europe in the fourth quarter, with a focus on mass-market products such as the revamped Seal SUV and the fully electric Tang. The company's European expansion aims to create fresh revenue streams and escape price wars in China.

images.alt_text: BYD Auto Industry general manager Liu Xueliang oversees the Asia Pacific automotive markets at the Chinese maker.
BYD markets its luxury models under the Yangwang and Fang Cheng Bao brands.
Record deliveries in the fourth quarter, when BYD overtook Tesla as the world’s top seller of electric cars, did not translate into another bumper profit.
Major US automakers have warned that Chinese cars could spell doom for their own prospects, among them Elon Musk’s Tesla.

site_title: Singapore industrial: Strong growth prospects but no easy ride
summary: The Singapore industrial sector has shown robust growth, driven by undersupply, particularly for high-quality assets. Despite a slowdown in demand due to elevated interest rates in 2023, rents remained strong, with a 1.7% gain in the fourth quarter of 2023. Prime logistics and conventional warehouses outperformed, while high-tech and conventional factories saw modest growth. Expectations for 2024 include a recovery in manufacturing growth, moderate interest rates, and broad-based rental growth led by quality assets. However, investors must navigate JTC's rules and regulations, and the market offers no easy pickings, with short lease tenures and restricted land availability.

images.alt_text:
ST20221114-202263087957-Lim Yaohui-Adeline Tan-atlogistics14/
 
The packing workstation in the warehouse of Schneider Electric's new logistics distribution centre known as Hub Asia on Nov 14, 2022.

The control tower hosts key data such as end-to-end warehouse performance, key service-level metrics, and real-time monitoring of efficiency levels for last mile deliveries.

Schneider Electric, a global leader in digital energy management and automation launched the $110 million logistics distribution centre known as Hub Asia on Nov 14, 2022. Dr. Beh Swan Gin, Chairman of SingaporeÕs Economic Development Board (EDB), and Jean-Pascal Tricoire, Chairman and CEO of Schneider Electric were present to inaugurate the new smart and sustainable logistics facility which will serve as an anchor point in the development of the Tuas South industrial area. This celebration marks an important milestone for Schneider Electric in the lead-up to its 50-year anniversary in Singapore in 2023.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: Zoom gains after sales top estimates on enterprise customers
summary: Zoom Video Communications reported quarterly sales and profit that exceeded analyst estimates, with 2.6% sales growth and $1.42 profit per share. The company announced a $1.5 billion share buyback, likely to be the largest area of focus for investors. This move pushes back on potential large acquisitions, as Zoom has expanded its product line to include phone systems, call centers, and AI assistants to capture more corporate clients.

images.alt_text: The team has now been dismantled, though the exact number of DEI-focused employees affected by the cuts could not be established. A
After vaulting into public consciousness during the pandemic, Zoom has struggled to maintain high revenue growth.

site_title: Oil gains over US$1 on possible shipping disruptions
summary: Oil prices gained 1.11% on Monday, with Brent crude futures rising to $82.53 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures increasing to $77.58 a barrel. The gain was attributed to European diesel demand, constrained by Russian sanctions and shipping disruptions. Analysts cited the diesel supply shortage as a key factor, with US diesel cracks briefly reaching a four-month high. Refineries are expected to restore production in March following planned overhauls.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pump jacks of Wintershall DEA are pictured in Emlichheim near the northern German city of Meppen, Germany, March 9, 2022. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo

site_title: Facebook, YouTube to face new rules under Canada online law
summary: Canada's government has introduced the Online Harms Act, making social media platforms and live-streamed video companies responsible for reducing exposure to damaging content, including bullying, child exploitation, and hate speech. The law will establish a regulatory body and create a new standalone hate crime offence with penalties of up to life in prison. The bill is part of a list of contentious internet regulations introduced by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government, with critics raising concerns about the balance between protecting internet users and safeguarding rights and freedoms.

images.alt_text: It is the first time in seven months that Canada's headline inflation has dipped below 3 per cent.
Activity in the market has begun to heat up recently as it becomes clearer that the Bank of Canada may be in a position to cut interest rates later this year.

site_title: Hong Kong prepares sweeping rules to foil stealthy crypto purchases
summary: Hong Kong is preparing sweeping rules to curb unlicensed crypto purchases, following the 2023 collapse of the JPEX crypto platform, which resulted in HK$1.6 billion losses. Approximately 450 shops, ATMs, and websites offer OTC crypto trades, with some suspected of facilitating banned activities, such as Chinese nationals evading transfer limits and scammers. The new regulations aim to increase oversight and prevent illicit activities, potentially forcing many shops to shut down, and could impact the US$64 billion in digital assets that flowed through Hong Kong in the year to June.

images.alt_text: An advertisement for the unlicensed JPEX crypto platform at a subway station in Hong Kong in 2022. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Deutsche Telekom showcases app-less AI smartphone concept
summary: Deutsche Telekom showcased a futuristic smartphone concept relying on artificial intelligence to handle users' specific needs, eliminating the need for traditional apps. The "T-phone" device, developed in collaboration with Qualcomm and Brain, can respond to prompts, generate tailored recommendations, and send messages. CEO Tim Hoettges predicts a shift away from apps in 5-10 years, citing the integration of multi- and crossmodal Large Language Models. The concept aims to simplify users' lives and enhance their experiences.

images.alt_text: The tech giant will prepare production lines for its high-end Pixel 8 Pro smartphones in the coming weeks.

site_title: US corporate bond sales hit US$153 billion in February record
summary: US corporate bond sales reached a record US$172 billion in February, driven by falling yields and increased demand for debt. This surpasses the prior February record of US$150.9 billion. The sales are part of a busy week, with 18 companies tapping the market, and are expected to continue with March being the most active supply month in the first quarter. Lower borrowing costs are attracting companies to issue bonds, with the average investment-grade bond yield at 5.37% and the average spread for high-grade bonds at its lowest level since November 2021.

site_title: Microsoft strikes deal with France’s Mistral, an OpenAI rival
summary: Microsoft has struck a deal with French startup Mistral AI, an OpenAI rival, to make Mistral's open-source AI models available to Azure cloud customers. The partnership includes a new model, Mistral Large, with "unique reasoning capacities" in five languages. The move comes as Microsoft faces antitrust scrutiny over its deep ties to OpenAI, with a 3.2 billion euros investment in European data centers announced earlier this month. Mistral, formed in 2023, has positioned itself as a European champion in AI, valuing the firm at about $2 billion after a $415 million funding round in December.

site_title: Ho Bee Land’s H2 net loss of S$104.1 million extends losing streak on hit from London portfolio
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a net loss of S$104.1 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, reversing a net profit of S$16 million in the same period last year. The loss was primarily due to a fair-value loss of S$472.2 million on its London portfolio. Revenue grew 12% year-over-year to S$289.4 million, driven by a 26% increase in development property sales. The board recommended a 3 cents per share dividend, down from 8 cents per share in 2022, and expects net losses to widen for FY2023.

images.alt_text: The group is mainly attributing the projected increase in net losses to fair value loss based on indicative valuations of its portfolio of investment properties in London.
Biomedical development Elementum is expected to be completed in the last quarter of this year and contribute to the group's revenue in FY24.

site_title: G20 finance meeting to set aside geopolitics, focus on economics
summary: Finance officials from the G20 nations will meet in Sao Paulo, Brazil, to focus on global economic issues, setting aside geopolitics following deep divisions over Israel's attacks on Gaza. The meeting aims to review economic developments amid slowing growth, record debt burdens, and inflation concerns. The draft communique will likely be concise and ambiguous, omitting direct references to Russia's invasion of Ukraine or the Israel-Gaza war. The goal is to deliver consensus on key economic priorities, with a focus on inequality, taxation reform, and sustainable development.

images.alt_text: Palestinians walk across the rubble of a collapsed building following an Israeli airstrike in the Zuwayida district of central Gaza, Feb 22, 2024.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 falls at start of inflation data-driven week
summary: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.4% on Monday, led by miners, ahead of crucial inflation reports and interest rate cut expectations. Despite a strong start to 2024, the index has gained only 3.4% so far, lagging its US peer S&P 500. Analysts expect a sustained downtrend in euro zone inflation to fuel gains in equities, but traders expect the European Central Bank to keep interest rates steady at its March meeting.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished  0.2 per cent lower at 39,069.23 on Monday, pulling back from an all-time high.

site_title: Investors re-entering real estate, eyeing debt, logistics, living sectors
summary: Investors are re-entering the commercial real estate market, focusing on debt strategies and diversification amid uncertainty and changing economic conditions. The global CRE capital markets are expected to see a significant influx of capital, with $270-570 billion in refinancing debt and $1.4 trillion in living strategies deployed globally over the next five years. Emerging technologies and disruptors like AI, robotics, and renewable energy are also attracting investors, driven by their long-term growth potential.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, the most popular asset classes are hospitality, co-living, logistics, retail and office.

site_title: When fake profiles mean real problems for love
summary: Dating app Tinder is introducing an identity verification feature to curb catfishing and disingenuous behavior on its platform. The feature, which includes submitting a driving license or passport, video selfie, and profile photo, aims to increase authenticity and trust among users. This comes as a response to the growing issue of fake profiles and the increasing popularity of dating apps, with a YouGov survey finding that 42% of millennials in Singapore have used dating apps. The move is seen as a step towards solving the problem of "Where do they all belong?" and comes as the online dating market faces increasing competition and scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Shreya Datta, a tech professional who was a victim of an online scam known as "pig butchering," speaks during an interview with AFP in her apartment in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Feb 9, 2024.
Valentine’s Day: The changing face of love

Dating apps maker Match Group sued Alphabet's Google on Monday, calling the action a "last resort" to prevent Tinder and its other apps from being booted off the Play store for refusing to share up to 30 per cent of their sales.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records
summary: US stocks retreated from records on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing 0.2% lower at 39,069.23. The decline comes ahead of new inflation data and amid uncertainty about the Federal Reserve's policy in 2024. The S&P 500 dropped 0.4% to 5,069.53, and the Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.1% to 15,976.25. Individual stocks also fell, including Alphabet, which dropped 4.5% on concerns over its Gemini AI program, and Kroger, which fell 2.0% after the FTC blocked its acquisition of Albertsons.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 20, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Garuda mulls rights issue, strategic investors as it rebuilds
summary: PT Garuda Indonesia plans to undertake a rights issue to raise additional capital and invite strategic investors to revive its ailing business. The airline expects to launch the equity issue after the Indonesian government makes good on its plan to inject fresh funds. Finance Director Prasetio stated that the airline's priority is to partner with local investors before expanding to international ones.

site_title: US new home sales miss expectations in January
summary: US new home sales rose 1.5% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 661,000 units in January, missing expectations of 680,000 units. The increase was likely due to frigid weather, but demand remains strong due to a persistent shortage of previously owned homes. On a year-on-year basis, sales rose 1.8%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Newly constructed single family homes are shown for sale in Encinitas, California, U.S., July 31, 2019.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Smartphone makers bet on AI to revive sales
summary: Smartphone manufacturers are focusing on AI-powered features to revitalize sales, showcasing unique tools such as real-time voice translation and advanced photo editing at the Mobile World Congress. Companies like Samsung and Honor are highlighting AI-infused features, including language translation and eye-tracking technology, to make their devices more exciting and encourage upgrades. However, sluggish smartphone sales and consumer skepticism about AI may hinder the adoption of these features, with analysts predicting a marginal rebound in sales this year.

images.alt_text: Tim Hoettges, chief executive officer of Deutsche Telekom AG, unveils a concept application-free AI-powered smartphone during a keynote on the opening day of the Mobile World Congress at the Fira de Barcelona venue in Barcelona, Spain, on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024. The annual flagship mobile industry and technology event runs from Feb. 26 to Feb. 29. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg
Xiaomi last year was placed third globally for share of the smartphone market, accounting for 12.5 per cent of global shipments.
Honor CEO George Zhao presents the new Honor Magic 6 Pro smartphones on the eve of the Mobile World Congress, the telecom industry's biggest annual gathering, in Barcelona. Spain, Feb 25, 2024.

site_title: Citi hires JPMorgan’s Raghavan as banking head amid turnaround
summary: Citigroup has hired JPMorgan Chase's Viswas Raghavan as its head of banking and executive vice-chair, as part of CEO Jane Fraser's restructuring efforts to turn the bank into a competitor with its peers. Raghavan is expected to start in summer and will report directly to Fraser, overseeing one of the bank's five core businesses. This move is seen as a significant poaching win for Citigroup, highlighting Fraser's efforts to revamp the bank's operations.

images.alt_text: Citigroup awarded Fraser a total of US$1.5 million in salary and US$24.5 million in stock-based and cash incentive awards for 2023, it said in a filing on Tuesday.
Investments will range from outright acquisitions to greenfield projects and partnerships, Citi’s India investment banking head Rahul Saraf says.
Citigroup last week said it would cut 20,000 jobs over the next two years, after a fourth quarter marred by one-off charges that resulted in a US$1.8 billion loss.

site_title: As Vietnam embarks on renewables push, battery firms hungry for more green financing
summary: Vietnam's government aims to shift its power generation mix towards renewables, but the high cost of storage systems and batteries remains a major hurdle. Industry players, including Cenergy and VinFast, are seeking green financing to develop battery technologies, with some startups hoping to harness Vietnam's abundant renewable energy resources. The country targets a total capacity of at least 2,700 MW and 30,650 MW for pumped storage hydropower and other battery storage sources by 2030 and 2050, respectively. VinFast, a leading carmaker, is expanding its battery production capacity and exploring alternative ways to maximize profits, while startups like Alterno are developing thermal energy storage systems for heating.

images.alt_text: solar panel, installation, worker
Electric cars on display at a VinFast showroom in Hanoi. Vietnam's first automaker Vinfast signed a deal on Jan 6 to set up its first manufacturing facilities in India.

site_title: Google steps up Microsoft criticism, warns of rival’s monopoly in cloud computing
summary: Google has criticized Microsoft's cloud computing practices, warning that its rival is seeking a monopoly that would harm emerging technologies like generative artificial intelligence. Google Cloud vice-president Amit Zavery said Microsoft's collaboration with ChatGPT creator OpenAI and its control over the Azure cloud platform would stifle innovation. Zavery urged antitrust regulators to act, while Microsoft dismissed the claims, citing healthy competition in the cloud market. The criticism follows scrutiny of Microsoft and Amazon's market power in cloud computing in Britain, the European Union, and the US.

images.alt_text: Holding the Meta chief executive personally responsible may be challenging because of a corporate law tradition of shielding executives from liability, especially at larger companies where decision-making is often layered.

site_title: SIIC Environment Q4 net profit falls 90.1%; full-year profit down 22.6%
summary: SIIC Environment, a wastewater treatment company, reported a 90.1% fall in net profit to 20.6 million yuan for the fourth quarter of 2023, down from 209.2 million yuan in the same period last year. Revenue also declined 51.4% to 1.2 billion yuan. The company attributed the decline to construction revenue, which fell 37.1%, and increased finance expenses due to interest rate hikes. Despite this, the company plans to focus on high-quality new project opportunities to strengthen business development momentum.

images.alt_text: SIIC Environment said that it has actively deployed high-quality projects and will keep expanding its wastewater and sludge treatment business as the business sees favourable policy support.
Water supply company SIIC Environment said its CFO Tang Congliang has resigned to “pursue career changes and developments”.

site_title: Adidas is dropping a new batch of controversial Yeezy shoes on digital channels
summary: Adidas is releasing a new batch of Yeezy shoes through its digital platforms, including popular designs such as the 350 V2 sneaker in steel gray. The move aims to boost earnings by selling the remaining inventory from its cancelled partnership with Kanye West, which ended due to antisemitic remarks. Despite criticism, Adidas reports strong demand for Yeezy products, generating €750 million in sales since May last year, and may sell the remaining €250 million at cost to meet earnings forecasts.

images.alt_text: Adidas forecast an operating profit of around 500 million euros (S$723 million) in 2024, against analysts’ estimate of 1.294 billion euros according to a company-compiled consensus.
Adidas’ gross margin for the quarter is up 0.2 percentage points at 49.3 per cent, supported by reduced freight costs and fewer discounts.

site_title: Food weighting in India's consumer price index may be cut as spending shifts
summary: India may lower food's weighting in its consumer price index (CPI) basket, potentially reducing inflation volatility, following a household survey showing lower spending on food. Food's share in the rural consumption basket fell to 46% and 39% for urban consumers, down from 50% and 47% previously. A reduction in food's weighting could ease inflation and limit the need for price controls, although some experts warn that volatility may persist.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Customers buy grocery items inside a superstore of Reliance Industries Ltd, in Mumbai, India, October 7, 2020. REUTERS/Niharika Kulkarni/File Photo

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust ex-CEO files winding-up application against trustee-manager
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's ex-CEO, Wang Qiu, has filed a winding-up application against the trustee-manager, less than a week after Zhang Guiming, the nephew of a non-executive director, filed a similar application. The hearing for Wang's application is set for March 15, coinciding with Zhang's hearing. This move comes after Wang was fired earlier this month as CEO of the trustee-manager.

images.alt_text: Wang Qiu, Dasin Retail Trust, was given notice of termination with effect from Feb 14.
Wang Qiu, chief executive officer of Dasin Retail Trust Management, was given notice of termination with effect from Feb 14.
Ocean Metro Mall, one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust’s initial portfolio. Its trustee-manager says it received a winding-up application deemed to have been served on Feb 20.
Ocean Metro Mall is one of the properties in  Dasin Retail Trust’s portfolio.

site_title: Singapore’s Strangelove for retail
summary: Singapore's retail market is expected to see better days ahead, despite a 1.5% drop in total retail sales in December 2023. Sales recovered to pre-pandemic levels, driven by domestic retail spending and a strong tourism industry, with 13.6 million visitors in 2023. The sector is poised for growth, with prime-floor retail rents increasing 3-5% in 2024. However, key risks include inflation, rising transportation costs, and global supply-chain disruptions. Landlords must balance experiential shopping and tenant curation to maintain occupancy and rental reversions, while consumers may rebalance discretionary spending.

images.alt_text: Christmas vibes along Orchard Road

site_title: Kore’s manager aims FY2026 DPU at ‘highest appropriate level’
summary: KEPPEL Pacific Oak US Reit's (Kore) manager aims to maximize net property income by 2025 through continued investments and restart distributions at the "highest appropriate level" in FY2026. Goals include avoiding selling buildings at significant discounts, refinancing loans prior to maturity, and early distribution restarts, subject to market conditions. This follows the Reit's surprise announcement to suspend distributions for two years.

images.alt_text: Kore makes a net loss of US$91.8 million for H2 FY2023.
One Town Center, one of Prime US Reit's assets in Florida. Analysts are speculating that news of Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's recapitalisation plan could pose a "contagion risk" to Prime.
Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's freehold asset, 105 Edgeview. The counter is down as much as 25 per cent on Wednesday.
Kore will suspend its distributions from H2 2023 until H2 2025
Prime US Reit's manager said demand for US office space “broadly strengthened” in Q4 2023 as reflected by an increase in active tenant requirements and leasing activity.

site_title: Data as AI fuel
summary: Fintechs in South-east Asia are embracing AI and machine learning to develop advanced smart data fabric architectures, enabling seamless data analysis and visualization from various sources. A study predicts that adopting AI in the region could add $1 trillion to the gross domestic product by 2030. Singapore leads in AI and ML penetration in fintech, at 5.36%. A well-organized data foundation is crucial for accurate algorithm training, predictive analytics, and enhanced decision-making, ultimately addressing unique fintech challenges.

images.alt_text: Today, the spotlight is on solutions and products that, in practical application (not just in theory), effectively mitigate specific risks related to investments, currencies, credits, transactions and more.

Left unaddressed, the data challenges faced by financial services firms across Asia and globally will significantly impact their ability to meet business objectives and improve issues such as customer retention and risk transparency.

site_title: High capital expenditure, tech changes could dampen outlook for data-centre S-Reits
summary: Analysts are optimistic about the potential benefits of Singapore-listed data-centre S-Reits due to the government's plans to invest over S$1 billion in AI infrastructure over five years. However, high capital expenditure or significant technology changes could dampen growth. Despite this, some analysts believe the AI boom will still boost these Reits.

images.alt_text: sever, digitization, mainframe

site_title: Nanofilm H2 net profit falls 56.9%; retains profitability in FY23 despite H1 loss
summary: Nanofilm Technologies reported a net loss of S$10.8 million in the second half of 2023, down 56.9% from the previous year. Despite this, the company still managed to achieve a full-year profit of S$3.1 million, a 92.8% decline from S$43.8 million in the previous financial year. The company attributed the recovery to cost optimization and a 42% increase in revenues in the second half.

images.alt_text: Nanofilm Technologies posts a loss of SS$7.6 million for H1 2023, on the back of lower sales and increased costs.
