(From left) Dr Tan Chong Wei, Senior Research Fellow at NTU; Professor Lam Khin Yong, NTU Vice President (Industry); DPM Heng Swee Keat; and Dr Shi Xu, founder and executive chairman of Nanofilm, at the exhibition during the launch of NTI-NTU Corporate Laboratory on Nov 28.

Nanofilm said the acquisition forms a good nexus for the group to launch its new base of operations in Europe since AxynTeC has existing European customers in key applications utilised for medtech and non-consumer electronics coating customers.

site_title: US: Wall St opens muted ahead of busy data week, inflation test
summary: Wall Street opened muted on Monday, Feb 26, 2024, ahead of a busy data week that could provide insights into potential Federal Reserve rate cuts. The Dow Jones rose 13.26 points, or 0.03%, to 39,144.79, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened higher. Investors focus on inflation and economic data, rather than recent AI-led rally, amid concerns over market outlook and tariffs.

site_title: China to dismantle local barriers to build national market
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang urged policymakers to dismantle local barriers hindering fair competition, calling for a unified national market. He emphasized the need to break down explicit and implicit access barriers and promote a unified market "step by step." Li also vowed to deepen fiscal and tax reforms to support the goal. The move aims to remove local protectionism and promote efficiency nationwide.

site_title: EU carbon border tax could hit some Asia exports but has limited impact on emissions: ADB
summary: The European Union's carbon border tax, known as the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), may have a limited impact on emissions and could hurt exports to the EU, particularly those from Asia. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) found that CBAM could reduce global exports to the EU by 0.4% and Asia's exports by 1.1%, but may only reduce global carbon emissions by less than 0.2%. The tariff aims to tackle "carbon leakage" but may also encourage companies to shift production out of the EU. ADB chief economist Albert Park suggests that measures can be taken to reduce the pain for exporters, such as channeling tariff revenues back to exporting countries.

images.alt_text: Asean’s exposure to the carbon border adjustment mechanism could grow as product categories are expanded.
Climate adaptation investments remain a fraction of what is required, noted the ADB.
Vietnam’s growth forecast for 2023 has been cut considerably to 5.2 per cent from 5.8 per cent earlier.

site_title: Growing gloom about war among Europeans
summary: European public opinion has turned pessimistic about Ukraine's chances of winning the war against Russia, with only 10% of Europeans believing Kyiv can "win" against Moscow. A recent report by the European Council on Foreign Relations found that most Europeans predict the war will end in a negotiated settlement, rather than Kyiv achieving its full war aims. Public opinion is divided, with only two countries (Poland and Portugal) believing Ukraine will ultimately prevail over Russia. Despite this, European leaders remain solidly behind Ukraine, with new sanctions against Russia recently agreed by the EU and other partners.

images.alt_text: The action, one day before the second anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, means companies will be placed on the Commerce Department’s “Entity List,” essentially banning US shipments to them.
An apartment building in Dnipro, Ukraine, that was damaged by a Russian drone strike. Two years ago, on Feb 24, 2022, Russia brought war back to Europe on a scale not seen since World War II.

site_title: US dollar lower before inflation-heavy data deluge
summary: The US dollar dropped 0.2% to 103.74 ahead of a macroeconomic data-heavy week, including a Thursday inflation reading and rate decisions from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand and China. Eurozone inflation figures are also expected this week, with European Central Bank officials reiterating their focus on inflation, particularly wage growth. The euro rose 0.3% to $1.0854, while Japan's nationwide consumer prices are forecast to show core inflation slowed to 1.8% in January, potentially complicating the Bank of Japan's plans to end negative interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Real estate loans a ‘question mark’ for Canadian banks’ profits
summary: Canada's major banks, with exposure to the US commercial-property market, are expected to face scrutiny over deteriorating real estate loans, which could lead to higher provisions for potential credit losses. The quality of these loans is hard to predict, with some analysts warning of potential "nasty surprises" as lenders report fiscal first-quarter results this week. While Canadian banks aren't facing a solvency issue, real estate loans will be a "question mark" for their profitability, with provisions likely to keep increasing this quarter.

images.alt_text: US warehouses making effort to become greener amid soaring demand

site_title: Singapore’s new centre for semiconductor material gallium nitride to be operational by 2025
summary: Singapore is set to operationalize its National Gallium Nitride Technology Centre by 2025, with an initial US$85 million investment over the next five years. The centre, developed by Nanyang Technological University and DSO National Laboratories, aims to stimulate research and development, and promote collaborations between industry and academia for the manufacturing of GaN devices. The centre will also nurture a pipeline of research scientists and engineers, supporting Singapore's growing talent base in the field of semiconductor materials.

images.alt_text: At ITAP 2022, DPM Heng announced an investment into a new semiconductor materials centre, green commitments, the launch of a handbook for talent attraction and retention and five refreshed industry transformation maps (ITMs).
Silicon is reaching its limit. What's next?

site_title: Sweden to join Nato in historic move as Hungary ratifies bid in final step
summary: Sweden has officially joined NATO after Hungary ratified its bid, completing the final step in the Nordic country's historic shift to the Atlantic Alliance. Sweden's neutrality, which lasted through two world wars and the Cold War, ended in 2022 following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The move strengthens NATO, with Sweden bringing advanced military resources and increasing military spending to meet the alliance's 2% GDP threshold. The accession is seen as a significant expansion of the alliance, following Finland's membership last year, and has been welcomed by Western leaders as a counter to Russia's actions.

images.alt_text: Swedish membership of Nato would boost national security and help to stabilise the Nordic and Baltic regions, Foreign Minister Ann Linde said on Friday, a day after neighbour Finland said it would seek to join the US-led alliance without delay.

site_title: Haw Par H2 profit surges 58.1 per cent to S$112.4 million on strong recovery of healthcare sales
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 58.1% increase in its second-half profit to S$112.4 million, driven by a strong recovery in healthcare sales, which accounted for 90% of total revenue. Revenue rose 39.7% to S$120.9 million, while gross margin improved to 59.5%. The company's full-year net profit jumped 46% to S$216.6 million. A second and final dividend of S$0.20 per share was proposed, bringing the full-year dividend to S$0.40 per share.

images.alt_text: Wee Ee Lim, president and CEO of Haw Par Corporation, said the US and European markets "helped the company through the most difficult period during Covid".
Haw Par Corporation's earnings for H1 FY2023 was up 34.9 per cent, on the back of a 16.3 per cent revenue growth.

site_title: Jacob Rothschild, philanthropist and financier, dies at 87
summary: Jacob Rothschild, a 87-year-old philanthropist and financier, has died without a specified cause. He was the seventh generation of a banking dynasty and left his family's bank in 1980 to build his own financial empire. Rothschild was a prominent figure in UK philanthropy, chairing the boards of the National Gallery and National Heritage Lottery Fund. He also co-founded asset manager St James's Place and was a noted art collector, restoring Spencer House in London and Waddesdon Manor. Rothschild was awarded the Order of Merit by Queen Elizabeth II in 2002.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Lord Jacob Rothschild speaks at an event marking the signing of an agreement between the state libraries of Israel and Russia, whereby one of the most treasured collections of ancient Hebrew manuscripts and books will be digitised and available for public view online, at the National Library of Israel in Jerusalem November 7, 2017. REUTERS/Ronen Zvulun/File Photo

In February, Concordia, Rothschild & Co’s largest shareholder with nearly 40 per cent of the capital, announced its plans to file a takeover bid and acquire the shares in the bank that it did not own.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio announces tech licensing deal with Forseven
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio has entered a technology licensing deal with Forseven, a unit of CYVN Holdings, allowing Forseven to use Nio's technical information and software globally for vehicle research, manufacturing, and distribution. The agreement follows a similar deal struck by rival Xpeng, which will see Volkswagen pay technology service revenue to the Chinese company from 2024. This marks a shift in the traditional model of foreign automakers charging Chinese partners for technology licensing.

site_title: Hong Kong investor files court injunction on NEC’s JAE stake sale
summary: A Hong Kong-based hedge fund, Oasis Management, has filed a court injunction to block NEC's sale of its stake in Japan Aviation Electronics (JAE) due to what it claims is a breach of fiduciary duty by NEC's board of directors. The sale, which would see NEC tender 51% of its JAE stake at a 14% discount, comes after NEC received multiple buyout offers from global private equity funds. Oasis claims NEC ignored an opportunity to sell shares at a higher price, resulting in direct losses to shareholders.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of NEC Corp is pictured at the CEATEC JAPAN 2017 (Combined Exhibition of Advanced Technologies) at the Makuhari Messe in Chiba, Japan, October 2, 2017.   REUTERS/Toru Hanai

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 26)
summary: Singapore's industrial production grew 1.1% in January, reversing a 2.4% decline in December. However, the key electronics cluster and volatile biomedical cluster both reported falls in output. Condo resale prices fell for the first time in five months, while the CPF Special Account for those aged 55 and above may be "fairer" to retain. BYD aims to increase its market share in Singapore's EV market, and a new R&D centre for gallium nitride semiconductor material is set to become operational in 2025.

site_title: ‘Fairer’ to retain CPF Special Account for those already aged 55 and above: Foo Mee Har
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) Special Account will be closed for members aged 55 and above starting from 2025, with savings transferred to the Retirement Account and Ordinary Account instead. However, some MPs, including PAP's Foo Mee Har, have suggested grandfathering the scheme for those already 55, citing concerns about disrupting retirement planning. The move aims to "rationalise the CPF system" and is expected to affect middle-income seniors who rely heavily on CPF savings for retirement funding.

images.alt_text: A larger balance in the Enhanced Retirement Sum enablre the distribution of a higher amount from CPF Life in retirement. This goes a long way to ensure a safe and basic income stream.
For CPF members who are 55 and above in 2025, their special accounts will be closed, with the savings transferring to retirement account up to the Full Retirement Sum.

site_title: Sumitomo Mitsui eyes further India expansion
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui, Japan's second-largest lender, is considering further expansion in India, driven by the country's rapid economic growth. CEO Toru Nakashima sees opportunities to fill gaps in offerings, such as targeting medium-sized businesses and consumer banking services. The bank has already made a significant investment in India through its acquisition of Fullerton India Credit in 2021. Despite regulatory hurdles, Nakashima aims to overcome challenges to become a full-fledged financial player in India.

images.alt_text: Toru Nakashima, CEO of Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, speaks during an interview with Reuters, in Tokyo, Japan February 6, 2024. REUTERS/Ritsuko Shimizu

site_title: UK retailers report sales slump eased in February: CBI
summary: UK retailers reported a sales slump eased in February, with the Confederation of British Industry's monthly retail sales balance rising to -7 from -50 in January, the slowest fall in 10 months. This follows official data showing British retail sales increased by the most in nearly three years in January. Retailers expect sales to continue falling in March, with plans to reduce headcount and investment. Selling price inflation dropped to its weakest in nearly three years, but companies remain cautious about the sector's outlook.

images.alt_text: epa11028560 The Bank of England in London, Britain, 14 December 2023. The Bank of England is set to announce interest rates decision expected to hold rates at 5.25 percent, a fifteen year high.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
The monthly increase was the biggest since April 2021, the Office for National Statistics says.

Shoppers and pedestrians on Brixton Road in London, UK, on Friday, Sept. 22, 2023. As London flourished as a financial hub over the last two decades and house prices soared, it was many of the residents so key to its cultural and economic success who were hit the hardest. Photographer: Ayesha Kazim/Bloomberg

site_title: IMF urges G20 cooperation on climate, global AI principles
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged G20 major economies to work together to address climate change, avoid trade restrictions, and adopt global principles for artificial intelligence (AI) to boost growth prospects. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva called for "bold action" to rebuild policy momentum on reforms, citing weak global growth prospects and low-income countries' long-term gap with advanced economies. The IMF recommends cooperation on climate change, debt restructuring, and investments in education and gender equality to mitigate the effects of climate change and improve growth prospects.

images.alt_text: epa11147146 Managing Director of International Monetary Fund (IMF) Kristalina Georgieva attends a session at the World Governments Summit in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, 12 February 2024. The World Governments Summit Organization is an international, impartial, nonprofit group whose goal is to influence how governments operate in the future. The summit is held in Dubai between 12-14 February.  EPA-EFE/STRINGER

site_title: MoonSwatch suitcases fetch more than US$600,000 at Sotheby’s
summary: A series of limited edition MoonSwatch watches in special branded suitcases raised over US$607,000 at Sotheby's online auction, with the highest price paid for a set reaching 60,960 francs. The watches, which were produced during full moons or other lunar events, were sold to charity, with proceeds going to Orbis. The MoonSwatch collaboration between Swatch and Omega caused retail pandemonium in March 2023, with sales of the watches jumping 50% at Swatch boutiques.

images.alt_text: Urwerk's UR-230 Eagle watch. With a staff of 25, the company produces just over 200 watches annually at two ateliers in Geneva and Zurich.

site_title: Gallant Venture sinks into the red on higher finance costs, loss from associated companies
summary: Gallant Venture, a developer and utilities provider for industrial parks and resorts in Batam and Bintan, reported a net loss of S$16.1 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, reversing a net profit of S$3.2 million in the same period last year. The loss was attributed to higher finance costs and lower profit contributions from associated companies, despite a 4% increase in revenue to S$94.7 million.

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed companies Gallant Venture and GHY Culture & Media expect to post net losses for FY2023.
Gallant Venture receiving Indonesia Ambassador to Singapore Suryo Pratomo and his team at Batamindo Industrial Park on Jul 29, 2023.

site_title: Malaysia pledges to cut IPO approval time to three months for Main and Ace markets
summary: Malaysia's stock exchange operator and regulator, Bursa Malaysia and the Securities Commission, have pledged to expedite the approval time for initial public offerings (IPOs) on both the Main and Ace markets to three months. The faster approvals will apply to new IPO applications received from March 1, depending on the principal advisers or sponsors satisfactorily addressing regulators' queries and comments within five market days. The goal is to enhance the exchange's attractiveness to companies seeking to list in Malaysia and support their growth prospects.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX), Bursa Malaysia, the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) and the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) have formalised the Asean-Interconnected Sustainability Ecosystem (Asean-ISE) at a recent meeting.

site_title: ‘Built to last’ Berkshire nears US$1 trillion valuation after record profit
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by Warren Buffett, reported a 21% increase in annual operating profit to $37.4 billion, driven by improved underwriting and higher investment income from the insurance segment. The company's market value surpassed $915 billion, approaching the $1 trillion milestone, making it the largest financial firm by market capitalization. Buffett assured shareholders that the conglomerate is "built to last," as its shares rose 1.4% and Class B shares gained 1.3%.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett, 93, assures investors that vice-chairman and designated successor Greg Abel was "in all respects ready to be CEO of Berkshire tomorrow".
Berkshire holds 51.5 million shares, or 5.2 per cent of HP on Nov 30, according to a regulatory filing.

site_title: Japan’s Asahi eyes overseas M&A to quadruple sales of Super Dry beer
summary: Asahi Group Holdings, Japan's largest beer maker, aims to quadruple its overseas sales of Super Dry beer by 2030 through acquisitions in emerging markets. The company is currently looking at targets in Africa, Asia, and South America, as it seeks to tap into the US market, which currently accounts for only 6% of its overseas sales. Asahi's president, Atsushi Katsuki, cited a lack of suitable US targets and investor concerns over the company's limited presence in the US market.

images.alt_text: Asahi is looking to “expand its foundation of shareholders” and expected the sale to contribute to increased liquidity in its shares and the “revitalisation” of capital markets.

site_title: Indonesia's largest party seeks parliamentary probe into alleged election irregularities
summary: Indonesia's largest party, the Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDIP), plans to launch a parliamentary probe into alleged election irregularities in the recent presidential election, with allegations of abuse of power and use of state facilities. The party, which backed Ganjar Pranowo, finished third, behind Prabowo Subianto, who won with 60% of the votes. A parliamentary probe requires support from at least 25 lawmakers and more than half of legislators, and PDIP is backed by another party. The move aims to safeguard democracy and draw public attention to alleged wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Prabowo Subianto gestures after casting his ballot to vote in Indonesia’s presidential and legislative elections in Bogor, Indonesia, Feb 14, 2024.

site_title: MPs cautious about handouts, keen on worker support on first day of Budget debate
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 debate focused on long-term support for workers and businesses, rather than short-term handouts. MPs suggested "multi-tiered" financial support for retrenched workers, subsidies for part-time diplomas, and innovative funding models. The government was urged to prioritize systemic reforms over one-off assistance, and to ensure fiscal sustainability. Key proposals include enhancing the SkillsFuture Level-Up programme, increasing the minimum living wage, and reviewing the dependency ratio ceiling. MPs also emphasized the need for better support for older workers, including retirement adequacy and unemployment support, and warned against potential pitfalls in implementing new schemes.

images.alt_text: To start with, the interest-free loans can be calibrated towards courses in high-growth industries that lack local manpower, or in other economically important areas, said Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh.
Occasional upsides to government revenue do not mean that Singapore has excess funds, said Second Minister for Finance Indranee Rajah.
‘Fairer’ to retain CPF Special Account for those already aged 55 and above: Foo Mee Har

site_title: Cordlife needs a fresh start amid its ongoing scandal, not ‘old blood’ in a new bottle
summary: Cordlife Group, Singapore's longest-running cord blood bank, has appointed 34-year-old Yiu Pang Fai as its new group CEO amid an ongoing scandal over the mishandling of cord-blood units. The appointment is seen as a puzzling one, given Yiu's close links to the board and major shareholders, as well as his lack of experience in the healthcare industry. The company is currently serving a six-month suspension imposed by the Ministry of Health due to temperature excursions in its cord blood storage tanks, which has led to concerns over the bank's ability to restore confidence among shareholders and customers.

images.alt_text: Cordlife Group's lab where corneal lenticule samples will be processed and stored.

site_title: Opportunities in investments to quench global thirst
summary: A global water crisis is looming due to a growing population, climate change, and lack of infrastructure, with the UN predicting a 1% increase in surface water availability. Companies can help combat this crisis through investments in water treatment technologies, smart water networks, and desalination systems. The precision agriculture space also sees opportunities with smarter equipment and real-time data monitoring, reducing water usage and environmental impacts. However, investors must consider the energy-intensive nature of water purification and potential trade-offs with climate change.

images.alt_text: Climate adaptation investments remain a fraction of what is required, noted the ADB.

site_title: WTO chief sees trade missing forecasts on growth headwinds
summary: World Trade Organization (WTO) chief Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala warned that global commerce is performing weaker than forecast due to economic headwinds and a shift towards protectionism. She cited sluggish demand across major economies except for the US and India, and predicted that merchandise trade volumes for 2023 likely fell short of the WTO's forecast for 0.8% growth. The WTO is working on updating its predictions, with risks on the downside, and Okonjo-Iweala emphasized the need to repair and reform the multilateral trading system.

images.alt_text: World Trade Organization (WTO) Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala attends the Building Bridges conference in Geneva, Switzerland, October 2, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Japan's SMFG aims for three successive years of record profit, CEO says
summary: Japan's SMFG aims for three successive years of record profit, with CEO Toru Nakashima predicting a net profit target of 920 billion yen (S$8.2 billion) for the current financial year. The bank plans to drive growth through overseas acquisitions, particularly in Asia, and anticipates a boost from Japan's end of ultra-easy monetary policy. SMFG expects to triple its profit before goodwill amortisation to 90 billion yen in three years, with India and Indonesia being key markets. The bank's war chest for overseas expansion will be financed by its core banking business at home.

images.alt_text: “India’s economic growth is just so fast, that’s really attractive,” says CEO Toru Nakashima in an interview.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, February 26, 2024 (Ep 9)
summary: Singapore's electronics output declined in January, and Seatrium reported a net loss of S$1.7 billion for H2 2023, proposing a 20-to-1 share consolidation. The Singapore shares fell 0.5% on Monday, and markets in Asia mostly declined due to profit-taking after a tech surge.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 71 to 56.
Tokyo’s Nikkei index was up 0.5 per cent, pushing further past the December 1989 record it smashed on Friday.
Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: Not satisfied with pole position, BYD aims for bigger EV market share in Singapore
summary: BYD, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer, aims to increase its market share in Singapore, which currently stands at 46% with 262 EV registrations in January. The company seeks to raise its profile among consumers and improve understanding of green vehicles, despite being a distant second to Tesla. BYD has established a presence in commercial EVs and plans to expand its retail presence, including showrooms and BYD-themed restaurants, to address consumer concerns about EVs. The company's goal is to build a stronger brand in Singapore and become a leader in the global clean energy economy.

images.alt_text: Chinese automobile maker BYD pipped American counterpart Tesla to be the top electric vehicle seller in Singapore in 2023.
BYD markets its luxury models under the Yangwang and Fang Cheng Bao brands.
Tiny electric cars weave through traffic in southern China, their cheap and cheerful designs bringing a touch of colour to the EV revolution in the country's overlooked cities.

site_title: Chinese banks’ greenback purchases via swaps from clients hit record high in Jan
summary: Chinese banks purchased a record $50.9 billion in US dollars via foreign exchange (FX) swaps from clients in January, according to official data. This represents a shift by exporters to convert their overseas earnings and remittances into yuan, seeking higher returns on US dollars and waiting for better exchange rates. Such swaps involve exporters giving banks their US dollars and receiving yuan through a contract that reverses the transaction at maturity.

site_title: China state firm sells bonds to help fund LGFV in rare move
summary: A state-owned firm in China's Guizhou province issued a 1.8 billion yuan bond to help repay debt issued by a local government financing vehicle (LGFV), a rare move highlighting the region's liquidity strains. The bond, rated AAA, will go towards repaying two LGFV bonds in the region, signaling efforts to address financing pressures brought on by maturing LGFV debt. This move is seen as a new channel for LGFVs to repay debt, particularly for debt-laden regions.

images.alt_text: Banks are estimated to have issued 4.5 trillion yuan (S$844 billion) in net new yuan loans last month, more than tripling the 1.17 trillion yuan in December.
LGFVs have been in focus in China’s property slump as many have had severe cash-flow strains.
China has rolled out several measures to resolve local government debt risks, and new issuance of LGFV debt is tightly regulated.

Beijing has taken some steps to alleviate China’s long-standing problem with local debt, providing optimism to investors looking for signs any financial risk from the buildup of such debt is contained.
LGFVs have been under investors’ scrutiny as local governments face fiscal difficulties brought on by sliding land sales and debt-heavy projects failing to generate sufficient revenues.

site_title: Stock markets are booming. But the good times are unlikely to last
summary: Stock markets have broken records, with the S&P 500 index hitting its first all-time high in over two years and the MSCI World Index also reaching an all-time high. Despite middling economic growth and the COVID-19 pandemic, American stocks have offered annual returns of over 8% since 2010. However, experts warn that the good times may be unsustainable due to high valuations and declining corporate profits. The cyclically adjusted price-to-earnings ratio, or Cape, is at a record high, and real earnings growth is expected to decline. Only twice in the post-war period has the US achieved such growth, and it is unlikely that AI will be able to rescue the market from a correction.

images.alt_text: The milestone followed another bumper revenue forecast from the chip designer that drove up its market value by US$277 billion on Thursday – Wall Street’s largest one-day gain on record.
Advocates for diversification find life difficult when stocks are in the middle of a rally. However financial history provides plenty of reason for them to stand firm.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's wealth fund to tap debt market for second time this year
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has hired Goldman Sachs, HSBC, and Standard Chartered to issue an Islamic dollar bond, its second debt market tap this year. The sovereign wealth fund, which manages over $700 billion in assets, aims to raise $5 billion. The deal follows a $5 billion conventional bond raised in January and a $3.5 billion sukuk deal in October, as the PIF ramps up its capital deployment to $70 billion annually by 2025. This move is part of Saudi Arabia's economic agenda to diversify away from oil reliance.

images.alt_text: “If you look at the non-oil GDP, it is growing at very healthy numbers: 4 per cent and north of 4 per cent. We are expecting 5 per cent-plus in the medium term,” Jadaan told delegates at the Saudi Capital Markets Forum in Riyadh. “That is very strong growth.”
In 2019, the kingdom set up the Red sea International Film Festival and last year unveiled two funds at Cannes for production infrastructure and film industry investment.

site_title: Stellantis to sell up to 500,000 vehicles to Ayvens across Europe
summary: Stellantis has reached a multi-billion-euro frame agreement with leasing company Ayvens to sell up to 500,000 vehicles across Europe over the next three years. The deal will aid Ayvens' clients in transitioning to more sustainable mobility options, with vehicle brands including Alfa Romeo, Fiat, and Opel to be offered initially. The agreement allows for flexible terms, including order quantities and delivery dates, depending on fleet requirements and demand.

site_title: Local shares end Monday in the red amid profit-taking; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% on Monday, closing at 3,171.12, amid cautious investor sentiment and profit-taking. Other regional markets also declined, with the Hang Seng Index losing 0.5% and the SSE Composite Index falling 0.9%. The focus for investors this week is on macroeconomic factors, particularly the US core personal consumption expenditures. Local lenders DBS and UOB were among the biggest losers, while Venture Corporation was the top constituent gainer, rising 5%.

images.alt_text: For international investors becoming increasingly skittish about China, the sudden trading restrictions give them one more reason to stay away.
Nvidia is wildly profitable: In the final three months of 2023, it generated more than US$22 billion in revenue.

Despite middling economic growth and the Covid-19 pandemic, stock markets have offered annual returns, after inflation, of more than 8 per cent a year since 2010, including dividends and capital gains.

site_title: UK regulator warns of fundamental issues with housebuilding
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has warned of fundamental issues with the country's housebuilding market, citing concerns over the sharing of sensitive information among major housebuilders and its impact on competition and prices. The regulator has launched an investigation into eight of Britain's largest housebuilders, including Barratt and Persimmon, and said the market needs significant intervention to deliver enough good-quality homes. The CMA's year-long market study found a complex planning system and speculative housebuilding to be major causes of the persistent shortage of homes.

images.alt_text: Home owners have been bolstered by resilient prices, which fell just 1.4 per cent in the 12 months to December, in part because unemployment has remained low despite the economy slipping into recession.
The number of homes sold for more than £5 million (S$8.5 million) in January is down 17 per cent from last year.
Blackstone has bought Cargo which was previously known as 25 North Colonnade, the former headquarters of the Financial Conduct Authority, for about £165 million in 2014.
The largest warehouse in Europe is owned and developed by Tritax Big Box Reit. Tritax has traditionally focused on large UK warehouses that serve as major logistics hubs.
Easing mortgage costs and improving confidence in the outlook for the economy have boosted the number of buyers looking for property.

site_title: Start of churn-and-earn bull market for bonds
summary: A bull market in bonds has begun, with long-term rates in Western markets passing their peak for the cycle. Despite near-term volatility, investors remain at a strategic buy point due to elevated yields and expected returns. Central banks' pivot and the bond market's fourth-quarter turnaround have laid the groundwork for this shift. As the European Central Bank increases its cash rate, the bloc's fiscal rules have been remodelled to increase flexibility in maintaining fiscal discipline. With cash rates still high and credit spreads tightening, investors can add value through active management, including term structure positioning and sector allocation.

images.alt_text: A sculpture of the Euro currency stands in the city centre of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on January 25, 2024. The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to stand pat on January 25, 2024 and call for patience in the ongoing battle against inflation, pushing back against market hopes of rapid interest rate cuts. The Frankfurt-based institution launched an unprecedented rate hiking cycle in mid-2022 after Russia's war in Ukraine pushed food and energy costs higher, sending inflation soaring. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: Denmark drops Nord Stream blast probe without criminal case
summary: Denmark has dropped its investigation into the 2022 explosions that damaged the Nord Stream natural gas pipelines, concluding there was "deliberate sabotage" but insufficient grounds to pursue a criminal case. The decision follows a similar move by neighboring Sweden earlier this month. The investigation, which involved international cooperation, found no evidence of a criminal act. Denmark's Copenhagen police and intelligence service made the announcement in a joint statement.

site_title: Singapore malls are in fine fettle as visiting them remains a way of life
summary: Singapore's malls remain a popular destination despite the growth of online shopping. Despite Covid-19's impact, many mall owners have reported positive occupancy rates and rent reversion, with some achieving full occupancy. The Urban Redevelopment Authority reported a 6.5% vacancy rate for retail space in 2023, down from 7.1% the previous year. Strong demand drivers, including Singapore's weather, compact homes, and good public transport, contribute to mall visits. International visitor arrivals are expected to reach 15-16 million in 2024, driving retail spending.

images.alt_text: Singapore retail sales down 0.4% in December, reversing November’s gain

site_title: China’s sovereign fund appoints new chief investment head
summary: China's sovereign fund, CIC, has appointed Liu Haoling as its new chief investment head, replacing Ju Weimin. Liu will also take on roles as the vice-chairman and president of CIC. Prior to this, Liu held positions as chief risk officer and executive vice-president at CIC. This move is part of a broader leadership shift at the fund, with Liu set to replace Ju as the new deputy secretary of the Communist party authority at CIC.

site_title: George Michael honoured with UK collectible coin
summary: The UK Royal Mint has released a collectible coin honouring late singer-songwriter George Michael, paying tribute to his 1987 hit single "Faith". The coin, designed by Sandra Deiana, features Michael wearing his signature sunglasses. Officially approved by his estate, it is the latest addition to the "Music Legends" series, which has previously honoured David Bowie, Elton John, and Queen. The coin will be available for purchase starting Monday, marking a tribute to Michael's life and legacy.

images.alt_text: Mary Austin inherited the property from Mercury upon his death in 1991 and has been living here ever since

site_title: Christian Dior postpones much anticipated Hong Kong show
summary: Christian Dior has postponed its highly anticipated fashion show in Hong Kong, set to take place in March, without providing a reason for the decision. The event was seen as an attempt to revive the luxury market in the city, which has been impacted by fewer wealthy Chinese shoppers and a shift towards tourists visiting trendy districts. This comes as the city's luxury retailers adapt to changing consumer preferences and a rise in online shopping. The postponement is the latest sign of the challenges facing Hong Kong's luxury sector.

images.alt_text: The most expensive luxury goods makers such as LVMH and Cartier-owner Richemont have shown the most resilience to a downturn in consumer spending.
Customers line up outside a Louis Vuitton store in Hangzhou. Since 2022, the likes of Louis Vuitton and Hermes have been expanding in China's biggest cities.

site_title: Indonesia sees 2025 annual GDP growth at 5.3%-5.6%, says planning minister
summary: Indonesia forecasts annual GDP growth of 5.3-5.6% for 2025, according to Planning Minister Suharso Monoarfa. The country aims for a fiscal deficit of 2.48-2.8% of GDP. The growth rate is expected to pick up to 5.2% in 2024, driven by spending for an election and private investment. The 2025 state budget proposal must adjust to the new president's programs, which will take office in October.

site_title: Nikkei secures all-time closing high as pharma excels
summary: The Nikkei index ended 0.35% higher at a new closing high of 39,233.71, surpassing its all-time peak of 39,388.08. The index gained 16.8% this year, driven by cheap valuations and corporate reforms. The pharmaceutical sector led the gains, with Chugai Pharmaceutical and Daiichi Sankyo rising 6.37% and 3.86% respectively. The broader Topix index also finished 0.5% higher, with traders eyeing the 40,000-point mark as the next milestone.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei share average started 1980 at 6,867 and ended the decade at 38,915.

site_title: Chinese companies axe IPO plans amid listing scrutiny
summary: Forty-seven Chinese companies have pulled their initial public offering plans from China's stock exchanges this year, a 58% increase from the same period last year. The China Securities Regulatory Commission has tightened rules on share listings amid a bearish market, citing concerns over fraudulent listings and restoring investor confidence. The cancellations come under new chairman Wu Qing, who has solicited regulatory opinions from market participants and imposed fines for non-compliance.

images.alt_text: For international investors becoming increasingly skittish about China, the sudden trading restrictions give them one more reason to stay away.
An investor looks at screens showing stock market movements at a securities company in Fuyang in China's eastern Anhui province on January 17, 2024. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
CSRC bans net selling by major firms in first and last 30 minutes of trading.

PBOC says foreign entities owned 2.8 trillion yuan (S$523.3 billion) of onshore Chinese equities at the end of last year, down 13 per cent from 12 months earlier, and a drop of almost 30 per cent from the peak at the end of 2021.

site_title: Meta to set up team to counter disinformation, AI abuse in EU elections
summary: Meta is setting up a team to counter disinformation and AI abuse in the European Parliament elections, which will take place from June 6-9. The team will focus on identifying and mitigating potential threats, including misinformation and influence operations using generative AI. Meta will also add three new fact-checking partners in Bulgaria, France, and Slovakia. The move comes amid concerns about election interference and the rapid growth of generative AI, which can create text, images, and video in seconds. Meta is part of a coalition of tech companies working together to prevent deceptive AI content from interfering with elections globally.

images.alt_text: Mark Zuckerberg is returning to Seoul as Meta is racing to compete in AI with powerful competitors from OpenAI and Microsoft to Alphabet.
Indonesia’s president signed a regulation on Monday requiring digital platforms to pay media outlets that provide them with content.
Meta has said the service that applies to Facebook and Instagram aims to comply with EU rules to give users a choice whether their data can be collected and used for targeted ads.

site_title: Lippo unit under police probe over alleged fraud in case involving UOB loans
summary: The police are investigating Lippo Marina Collection, a subsidiary of Lippo Group, over alleged fraud related to a court ruling in October 2022. The developer, behind the Sentosa Cove condominium Marina Collection, is believed to be under probe for allegedly misusing funds. Lippo Group is currently awaiting a court verdict on damages owed to UOB after a long legal battle that started in 2014.

images.alt_text: LMC is thus liable to pay damages to UOB, the quantum of which will be determined at the assessment of damages, said the Court.
The loan would be used to refinance existing debt obligations of Perpetual Asia, a trustee of Lippo Mall Indonesia Retail Trust.

site_title: India central bank lifting curbs on forex non-deliverable forward arbitrage by banks
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has allowed banks to resume arbitrage trades between the outright foreign exchange over-the-counter (OTC) and non-deliverable forward (NDF) markets. The RBI had imposed a ban on dollar/rupee arbitrage trades in August 2023 due to concerns over banks' large positions, which had ballooned to double-digit billions of dollars. The central bank has now permitted banks to resume arbitrage trades, but in a limited way and slowly, as the Indian rupee enjoys a period of tranquility with low volatility.

images.alt_text: If approved, Paytm will be allowed to continue processing payments via India’s popular unified payments interface.
The Reserve Bank of India in a January order has asked the Paytm unit to stop accepting any fresh deposits in its account or popular wallet from Feb 29.

site_title: Ryanair warns of summer schedule cuts on Boeing delivery delays
summary: Ryanair warned it may cut its summer schedule due to Boeing delivery delays, potentially affecting revenue. The Irish airline expects fewer than 40 737 Max jets by the end of June, down from an initial 50. CEO Michael O'Leary stated the delay has constrained growth, and minor schedule cuts may be necessary if fewer than 40 planes are received by the end of March. This could impact Ryanair's peak summer revenue.

images.alt_text: Ryanair says it will happily add 737 MAX 10 jets to its fleet in 2026, a year earlier than scheduled, should unhappy customers delay or cancel their orders.
FILE PHOTO: A Ryanair Boeing 737-800 aircraft approaches Paris-Beauvais airport in Tille, northern France, September 27, 2018.  REUTERS/Christian Hartmann//File Photo

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Mubadala sign US$1 billion private credit Asia-Pacific partnership deal
summary: Mubadala Investment Company and Goldman Sachs have signed a $1 billion partnership deal to co-invest in private credit opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region, with a focus on India. The partnership will be managed by Goldman Sachs' Private Credit at Goldman Sachs Alternatives, with a dedicated on-the-ground team across multiple markets. This deal is part of Mubadala's efforts to build up its exposure to private credit markets amid a high-interest-rate environment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Goldman Sachs is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
Goldman’s 5,200 price target for the S&P 500 in 2024 is now among the highest on Wall Street.
Europe’s STOXX 600 has risen 13 per cent since hitting a low in late October and has gained about 2 per cent so far this year.
The British pound was last at US$1.30 two years ago.
ESG funds in the United States bled more than a net US$5 billion in the final three months of 2023.

site_title: DBS, Sheng Siong to engage up to 1,000 SMEs in sustainability partnership
summary: DBS and Sheng Siong are partnering to engage up to 1,000 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in a sustainability program over the next two years. The program will help SMEs reduce their environmental footprint, introduce decarbonisation plans, and access sustainable financing solutions. DBS will offer workshops, green solutions, and preferential financing rates, while Sheng Siong will encourage its suppliers to adopt sustainable business practices. The initiative is the first collaboration between two SkillsFuture "Queen Bee" companies and aims to support SMEs in achieving Singapore's Green Plan 2030.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong has more than doubled its sales and tripled its profits over 10 years. Its stock price has also appreciated by more than three times over the period.
From July 3, 2023, supermarket operators with an annual turnover of over S$100 million will need to impose a five-cent per plastic bag charge on all shoppers.
Groceries packed in FairPrice's signature white-blue-red plastic bags at an NTUC FairPrice Xtra outlet.

At Wednesday's launch were (from left) Lee Pak Sing, assistant chief executive officer (trade and connectivity), Enterprise Singapore; Alvin Tan, Minister of State for Trade and Industry; and Dave Ng, chairman, Singapore Logistics Association.
SMEs with higher capital requirements in certain industries, or those looking to expand overseas, are also more likely to benefit from enhancements to the Enterprise Financing Scheme, said observers.
Singapore budget 2024

site_title: WP chief Pritam Singh renews call for interest-free SkillsFuture loan, not just S$4,000 top-up
summary: Workers' Party (WP) chief Pritam Singh renewed his call for an interest-free SkillsFuture education loan, citing concerns that the S$4,000 top-up may not cover workers' retraining needs in high-growth industries. Singh proposed recalibrating the loan towards courses in high-growth industries lacking local manpower or in economically important areas. He also emphasized the need for greater transparency in government policies, addressing financial insecurity, and ensuring employers support workers during economic growth.

images.alt_text: epa10988853 Laborers work on a construction site in Singapore, 22 November 2023. Singapore’s Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) announced on 22 November that the country’s GDP growth is projected to expand at around 1.0 percent in 2023 and 1.0 to 3.0 percent in 2024.  EPA-EFE/HOW HWEE YOUNG
Singapore is raising its local qualifying salary from S$1,400 to S$1,600 for full-time local employees with effect from July 2024.  PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI, ST
Singaporeans aged 40 and above who enrol in a full-time course will get a monthly training allowance of up to 50 per cent of their last drawn pay, capped at S$3,000.
Singaporeans aged 40 and above will receive full government subsidies to pursue a second diploma at polytechnics, Institute of Technical Education, and arts institutions.

site_title: Spending impasse persists amid Republican resistance as partial shutdown looms
summary: US lawmakers are at an impasse as a partial government shutdown looms, with Republicans resisting adding right-wing policy dictates to spending bills. Despite "intense discussions," Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer warns of a "disruptive shutdown" on Friday. The House is set to return Wednesday, with funding for military construction, agriculture, and transportation programs due to lapse by Friday. President Joe Biden summoned congressional leaders to the White House to discuss spending legislation, while House Speaker Mike Johnson has refused to take up a Senate-passed foreign aid package.

images.alt_text: US House Speaker Mike Johnson (centre) at the Capitol in Washington, Jan 18, 2024. Despite the urgency, dozens of conservatives in the House voted against the stop-gap measure but Democrats provided Republican Speaker Johnson enough backing to smooth its passage.

site_title: Singapore factory output turns positive with 1.1% rise in January, but falls short of estimates
summary: Singapore's industrial production grew 1.1% in January, beating December's 2.4% decline, but fell short of economists' median estimate of a 3.7% expansion. The key electronics sector declined 3.4%, while other clusters, such as transport engineering and precision engineering, saw significant growth. Despite the underperformance, economists expect stronger manufacturing momentum this year, citing healthy global demand for Singapore-produced goods and a global recovery in trade.

images.alt_text: Excluding the biomedical cluster, factory output grew 0.5 per cent in December.
Most regional economies recorded improvements in January, though some of them still remained in contraction mode.
S&P Global’s index of US manufacturing in February is seen coming close to stagnating.

site_title: ‘Oppenheimer’ wins Producers Guild Award, is the Best-Picture Oscar next?
summary: Christopher Nolan's biopic "Oppenheimer" won the Producers Guild of America award for Best Picture, completing a sweep of major industry prizes. The PGA's top film award suggests "Oppenheimer" is poised for a best-picture victory at the Oscars next month. The film's success, coupled with its recent wins from the SAG Awards, indicates a strong possibility of taking home the top prize.

images.alt_text: Christopher Nolan accepts the award for Best Director – Motion Picture for "Oppenheimer" at the 81st Golden Globe Awards held at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills, California, U.S., on January 7, 2024.   Rich Polk/Golden Globes 2024/Handout via REUTERS     THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY  NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB downgrades Venture Corp to ‘neutral’ as muted near term priced in
summary: RHB has downgraded Venture Corp to "neutral" from "buy" due to its muted near-term outlook, which has already been reflected in the share price. The brokerage cut earnings forecasts for FY2024 and FY2025 by 4% each, awaiting more visibility on the completion of customer destocking. Analyst Alfie Yeo expects sequential earnings to improve in the second half of 2024, with a 9% year-on-year growth forecast for FY2024 and single-digit growth in FY2025 and FY2026.

images.alt_text: Venture Corporation has made investment in advanced manufacturing systems and automation to drive efficiency, productivity and value creation.

site_title: Indonesia allocates 1.6 million tonnes for additional rice imports this year
summary: Indonesia has allocated an additional 1.6 million tonnes of rice for import this year, on top of 2 million tonnes previously approved, due to expected lower domestic output in the January to March harvest. The country is forecast to produce 32 million tonnes of rice this year, with January to March output expected to be 2.8 million tonnes lower than last year. This move aims to mitigate supply concerns, which have driven rice prices above the government-set cap.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly lower on profit-taking after tech surge
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, with Tokyo's Nikkei index reaching fresh all-time highs after US tech stocks closed at records. However, investors took profits after last week's rally, fueled by Nvidia's stellar results. The US tech-heavy Nasdaq index slipped, despite the Dow and S&P ending higher than ever. Analysts attribute the decline to profit-taking, as investors wait for further market movements.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 71 to 56.

site_title: Malaysia’s king warns against threatening stability under Anwar
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar warned against threatening the country's stability, urging parties to respect the unity government and wait for the next general election. The king's remarks come amid concerns over Malaysia's political stability, following reports of opposition attempts to destabilize the government. Sultan Ibrahim also emphasized the need to narrow the budget deficit and reform subsidy policies to boost the economy. His comments come as Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's administration seeks to maintain stability, with the next general election not due until 2028.

images.alt_text: Sultan Ibrahim, who will reign for five years, is the country’s 17th king.

site_title: South Korea unveils corporate value-boosting plan to replicate Japan, but traders not convinced
summary: South Korea unveiled a corporate value-boosting plan to replicate Japan's success, aiming to reduce the "Korea discount" on stock prices. The plan, titled "Corporate Value-up Programme", encourages and supports companies to return capital to shareholders and improve governance. However, analysts were disappointed by the proposals, citing a lack of incentives and compulsory requirements. The benchmark Kospi index fell 1.42% in morning trade, with losses led by undervalued sectors, as traders expressed skepticism about the plan's effectiveness.

images.alt_text: Doctors shout slogans and carry signs reading 'Opposition to the increase in medical schools' during a protest against the government's medical policy, near the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 15, 2024.
The Bank of Korea held its key policy rate at 3.50 per cent at a policy review in Seoul, keeping it unchanged for a ninth straight meeting as expected by all 38 analysts polled by Reuters.

Temporary won overdrafts for global investors will be  permitted to settle stock and bond trades, reducing the burden of potential settlement failure resulting from delayed foreign exchange procedures.

site_title: AI bubble enters heady phase of jubilation with improbable Nvidia rally
summary: Nvidia's latest earnings report has sent the AI stock bubble into a "hearty phase of jubilation," with the company's revenue tripling to $22 billion and shares rising 68% in the first eight weeks of the year. Analysts predict generative AI will be the decade's growth theme, with Nvidia's earnings demonstrating the strength of AI infrastructure spending. The company's forecast suggests a "whole new industry" has been born, driving a doubling of the world's data centre infrastructure installed base in the next five years. The AI bubble is expected to last months or years, with investors potentially cashing in their stocks for luxury items.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is wildly profitable: In the final three months of 2023, it generated more than US$22 billion in revenue.

Because semiconductor chios are so difficult and costly to produce, there’s a worldwide reliance on just a handful of companies, a dependence that was brought into stark relief by shortages during the pandemic.
The milestone followed another bumper revenue forecast from the chip designer that drove up its market value by US$277 billion on Thursday – Wall Street’s largest one-day gain on record.

site_title: Seatrium’s H2 loss widens to S$1.7 billion, proposes 20-to-1 share consolidation to axe ‘penny stock’ status
summary: Seatrium reported a net loss of S$1.7 billion for the second half of 2023, widening from S$118.3 million in the same period last year. The company's revenue rose to S$4.4 billion, driven by sales to external parties for rigs and floaters, repairs and upgrades, offshore platforms, and specialized shipbuilding. Seatrium is proposing a 20-for-1 share consolidation to increase market interest and attractiveness, and has reached in-principle settlement agreements with Brazilian authorities to pay S$182.4 million in relation to Operation Car Wash. The company expects to book no further impairments in FY2024.

Seatrium expects greater operational productivity following the leaning down of assets and inventories.

CPIB announced on Wednesday that it had commenced investigations against Seatrium for alleged corruption offences.
The Corruption Practices Investigation Bureau has commenced investigations on Seatrium for alleged corruption offences, said the agency in a Wednesday press release.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices fall for first time in five months: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore condominium resale prices fell 0.8% month-on-month in January, marking the first decline in five months, according to SRX and 99.co data. Despite this, prices rose 7.2% year-on-year. The drop is attributed to a short-term correction, with prices expected to recover with new residential projects launching in the coming months. January is historically a slow month for the condo market, and buyers may have been waiting for new launches, such as The Arcady and Lumina Grand.

images.alt_text: Only one EC will be launched this year: the 512-unit Lumina Grand at Bukit Batok Avenue 5.
Median profit for non-landed private homes, including executive condominiums, with a holding period of five years or less doubled to S$247,000 in 2023, from S$123,241 in 2019.

January 2024 marks the sixth straight month of declines for condominium rental prices.
Analysts expect stamp duty collection and property tax takings to increase for Singapore's full financial year ended March 2024.

Overall resale prices clock a fifth consecutive month of increase., rising 0.5 per cent on the month.

site_title: Indonesia digital lending startup Julo working towards IPO
summary: Indonesian digital lending startup Julo is working towards an initial public offering (IPO) as its annual revenue nears $100 million. The company, which disbursed 7.3 million loans totaling $454 million in 2023, is seeking pre-IPO financing and exploring public listing options. Julo expects to reach profitability in 2024 and has raised $80 million from Credit Saison in 2022. The startup joins a growing list of peers that must demonstrate growth and profitability to investors amid elevated interest rates and inflation.

site_title: Ant outbids Citadel Securities for Credit Suisse’s China JV
summary: Ant Group has outbid Citadel Securities to acquire Credit Suisse's investment bank venture in China, with a bid of around 2 billion yuan, but the deal will face close regulatory scrutiny due to China's preference for foreign buyers. The bid will be subject to a thorough review, and UBS Group AG, which owns Credit Suisse, must choose between the higher local bid from Ant and the lower government-approved offer from Citadel. The deal could help Ant Group, backed by billionaire Jack Ma, expand its financial footprint and plug a gap in its operations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Swiss flag is pictured above a logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse in Bern, Switzerland, November 15, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo
Citadel Securities is going against the grain as it seeks to build a platform to bring its market-making capabilities to mainland China.
The valuation of the Suning stake is far smaller than the US$4.6 billion the Alibaba's Taobao paid for it in 2015, representing a roughly 90 per cent loss.
The three adjoining shophouses in Duxton Road are nearing the completion of a refurbishment.
“A local partner is basically an opportunity to keep you very tightly integrated in the dialogue about what’s happening,”  says Michael Evans, president of Alibaba Group.
China’s Ant Group made net profit of 24.5 million yuan (S$4.6 million) in the three months to Sep 31, down 92 per cent from a year earlier.
Alibaba reports revenue of 260.35 billion yuan (S$48.9 billion) for the three months ended Dec 31.

site_title: Zuckerberg’s Asia tour to range from AI to Ambani wedding party
summary: Mark Zuckerberg is embarking on a week-long tour of Asia, visiting Japan, South Korea, and India to discuss artificial intelligence (AI) services and forge business ties. In Japan, he will meet with Meta developers to discuss virtual reality headsets and large language models. In Seoul, he will meet with South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol, Samsung chairman Jay Y Lee, and LG Electronics CEO to discuss AI cooperation and joint headset development. Zuckerberg will also attend the pre-wedding celebrations of billionaire Mukesh Ambani's youngest son in western India.

images.alt_text: Holding the Meta chief executive personally responsible may be challenging because of a corporate law tradition of shielding executives from liability, especially at larger companies where decision-making is often layered.
Zuckerberg stands to receive a payout of about US$700 million a year from the social media giant’s first-ever dividend for investors.
Mark Zuckerberg owns about 13 per cent of Meta and has a net worth of about US$125 billion.
Public rivalry between Musk, 52, and Zuckerberg, 39, intensified after the initial success of Meta’s Threads social media platform in July.

site_title: More firms doing background checks for EP applicants, but high costs remain obstacle
summary: Background-screening companies in Singapore have seen a significant increase in demand for services since the introduction of the Complementarity Assessment Framework (Compass) for Employment Passes. Despite the added cost, some firms still avoid verification where possible, with smaller enterprises (SMEs) being more likely to do only the bare minimum. Companies are now prioritizing background checks for selected candidates and may also screen local hires once they understand the benefits of the process.

images.alt_text: Foreigners who enter Singapore on the EP and S Pass must be of the right calibre and complement the local workforce, says Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.

site_title: Haley soldiers on despite growing inevitability of Trump for Republican presidential nomination
summary: Nikki Haley, a 2024 Republican presidential candidate, remains in the race despite a string of losses, including a 20-point defeat in her home state of South Carolina. Haley attributes her decision to stay in the hunt to the possibility of Donald Trump being convicted of a crime, which could lead to his withdrawal from the nomination. Analysts see her staying in the race largely due to the possibility of Trump's downfall, rather than a genuine chance of winning. Haley continues to raise funds from donors and has a scheduled campaign stop in Michigan, where she faces another early contest.

images.alt_text: Nikki Haley says she is not giving up and would continue her presidential campaign despite losing on home ground.

site_title: Bitcoin-holder MicroStrategy’s X account hacked: security firm
summary: MicroStrategy, a publicly-traded company with the largest corporate Bitcoin holdings, reported a hack on its X account. A phishing exploit on the company's X page tricked users into handing over funds, with the attacker stealing approximately $440,000. The hack was discovered by security firm PeckShield, and the company's co-founder, Michael Saylor, is a prominent Bitcoin advocate. MicroStrategy's Bitcoin holdings are worth roughly $10 billion after the token's latest rally. The company has not commented on the incident.

site_title: Singapore shares fall on Monday; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.5% on Monday, led by declines from local banks, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3168.08. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, declined 1%, 0.2%, and 0.2% respectively. In contrast, US technology stocks hit all-time highs on Nvidia's strong earnings, while European shares closed at a record peak for a second day.

site_title: EU carbon border tax will do little to cut emissions: ADB study
summary: The European Union's planned carbon border tax, the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), is unlikely to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, according to a report by the Asian Development Bank. The policy could instead hurt developing countries in Asia and offset any emissions reduction with increasing carbon-intensive production. The ADB estimates the policy could raise around 14 billion euros in revenue, which could be used to provide climate finance for developing countries. Mechanisms to share emission reduction technology would be more effective in reducing emissions.

site_title: Freddie Mercury’s London residence lists at £30 million
summary: Freddie Mercury's London residence, Garden Lodge, is listing for £30 million. The property, a Neo-Georgian home and studio, was purchased by Mercury in 1980 and was his primary residence until his death in 1991. Inherited by Mary Austin, it has been her home ever since. The property features eight bedrooms, a Japanese-inspired garden, and art deco mirrors, showcasing Mercury's personal taste. Austin plans to sell the property after a successful Sotheby's auction, which raised over $50 million for charities.

images.alt_text: An estimated 1,500 items will be taken from Mercury’s (above) London home, known as Garden Lodge, which he bequeathed to his friend Mary Austin upon his death from Aids-related complications in 1991.

site_title: China’s weak local borrowing raises hope for more central aid
summary: China's local governments have shown reluctance to issue new bonds, with actual offerings down 56% compared to 2023, fueling expectations that the central government will take on more debt. Despite Beijing's efforts to diffuse a $9.3 trillion local debt bomb, some regions may still struggle to find productive projects. Economists predict the central government may announce an expansion of its deficit at the upcoming National People's Congress, but the focus on fiscal policy may not directly translate to increased spending, with the US dollar limiting monetary policy easing.

New home prices in China fell 0.3 per cent month-on-month after dipping 0.4 per cent in December, according to Reuters calculations based on National Bureau of Statistics data.

site_title: Gold prices dip as firmer US dollar dampens appeal
summary: Gold prices declined on Monday, down 0.3% at $2,030.9 per ounce, due to a firmer US dollar. The US dollar index rose 0.1%, making gold less affordable for overseas buyers. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's interest rate cut timing, with a 68% chance of a June cut. Meanwhile, a surge in bitcoin ETF interest is prompting investors to swap out gold-backed ETFs.

images.alt_text: Spot gold is on track for a 1.4 per cent weekly rise.

site_title: Clearing the air on CPF Life: the best annuity in the market
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduced several retirement-related measures, including a higher Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) of S$426,000, enabling members to receive more income from CPF Life. This increase, set to take effect from 2025, will provide a monthly income of S$3,330 from age 65 for life. Critics argue that the move to close the Special Account (SA) for those turning 55 and transfer balances to the Retirement Account (RA) is a step to "rationalise" the CPF. Experts emphasize that CPF Life provides a guaranteed income stream and hedges longevity risk, making it a unique and valuable retirement option.

images.alt_text: As we live longer and inflation stays high, one may need to work one's CPF savings harder.
For CPF members who are 55 and above in 2025, their special accounts will be closed, with the savings transferring to retirement account up to the Full Retirement Sum.

site_title: Oil extends losses in early Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell in early Asian trading on Monday, extending losses from the previous session. Brent crude futures dropped 34 cents to $81.28 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures declined 33 cents to $76.16 a barrel. The decline was attributed to concerns about weak demand in China and delayed US interest rate cuts due to higher-than-expected inflation. Analysts expect oil stockpiles to start falling in the coming weeks as refineries return from maintenance, potentially offering support to prices.

site_title: Keep your portfolios globally diversified as rates fall, Asean growth picks up: panellists
summary: HSBC panelists express cautious optimism for 2024, citing a falling rates environment and emerging growth in Asean. The panel suggests maintaining a globally diversified portfolio. Chief investment officer James Cheo notes a likely "older bull" market in 2024, while portfolio manager William Goh emphasizes the importance of asset diversification, driven by Asia's growth.

site_title: Most UK exporters hit by Red Sea disruption, survey shows
summary: A survey by the British Chambers of Commerce found that 55% of UK exporters, 53% of manufacturers, and 37% of all businesses reported an impact from disruptions in the Red Sea caused by Yemen's Houthi rebels. The disruptions led to increased container hire costs, delivery delays, and cashflow difficulties. The Bank of England has highlighted the Red Sea disruption as a main upside risk to inflation this year, citing concerns that cost pressures may build if the situation persists.

site_title: Overworked and unheard, South Korean doctors on mass walkout say
summary: Over 7,800 South Korean interns and residents, representing about two-thirds of the country's young doctors, have resigned in protest of the government's plan to increase medical school admissions. The doctors, who work 36-hour shifts, claim they are overworked and underpaid, with some earning less than US$5,000 a month. The government has threatened to arrest them if they do not return to work, but the doctors say the order is unconstitutional. The protest has led to hospitals turning away patients and cancelling surgeries, and senior doctors have held rallies urging the government to scrap its plan.

site_title: China’s Honor globally launches AI-enhanced Magic 6 Pro smartphone
summary: Honor, a Chinese technology company, launched its AI-enhanced Magic 6 Pro smartphone globally, featuring an experimental eye-tracking AI function that enables users to control their car remotely by looking at their phone screen. The tool, available in China, is being integrated commercially overseas. Honor also released its new MagicBook Pro 16 laptop with an AI feature allowing users to transfer applications between devices. The company's CEO, George Zhao, emphasized the transformative power of AI in his statement.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: UOB building community through art (Ep 8)
summary: UOB, a leading patron of art in Asia, has championed Southeast Asian art and artists over the past four decades. The bank's annual Painting of the Year competition has had a significant impact, with the latest award featuring artists with disabilities. UOB's Global Heartbeat Run/Walk event raises S$2.5 million, and the bank strengthens relationships with customers through art. site_title: AI is exploding data centre energy use. A Google-created technique may help
summary: Tech giants Google, Microsoft, and Amazon are racing to reduce carbon emissions from their massive data centers. A technique pioneered by Google, called load shifting, involves using software to hunt for clean electricity and ramping up data center operations there. This approach could cut carbon and costs. However, the growth of AI is outstripping the ability to produce clean power, making decarbonization a challenge. To address this, hyperscalers are financing solar and wind farms and using credits to offset emissions. Load shifting has shown promise, with Cirrus Nexus and Google testing strategies that could cut emissions.

site_title: Raffles Medical posts 63.8% drop in H2 profit to S$30.3 million; looks to China, Japan growth
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 63.8% drop in H2 profit to S$30.3 million, citing the end of Covid-19-related activities in FY2023. Revenue fell 18.6% to S$336.2 million. The group aims to grow in China and Japan, with a 18.1% increase in revenue from its Greater China segment and plans to expand in Japan. Despite the decline, the company remains bullish on its overseas expansions, with a focus on medical centers and clinics.

site_title: Xiaomi launches new photo-geared 14 Series smartphone
summary: Xiaomi has launched its new 14 Series smartphone, featuring AI-enhanced and photography-geared capabilities. The devices include a quad-camera configuration in the Ultra model and a triple-camera setup in the standard model. The phones integrate large AI models for real-time transcriptions, photo description, and other applications. This launch comes ahead of the Mobile World Congress, where tech companies are promoting AI features to boost business prospects. Xiaomi, which accounted for 12.5% of global smartphone shipments last year, continues to expand its product line with wearable gadgets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Great Eastern, Seatrium, SingLand, Raffles Medical, Hong Leong Finance
summary: Several Singaporean companies reported financial updates on Monday, February 26, 2024. Great Eastern's insurance arm reported a 13% fall in H2 profit to S$337.4 million, while Seatrium's net loss widened to S$1.7 billion. In contrast, Singapore Land Group's net profit rose 7% to S$102.4 million, and Raffles Medical Group's net loss dropped 63.8% to S$30.3 million. Hong Leong Finance's net profit declined 45.4% to S$46.8 million, and Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust's distribution per unit dropped 7% to 0.07903 euros.

site_title: Uniqlo’s sister brand GU aiming to take on markets in US, Europe
summary: Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, plans to accelerate the openings of new Uniqlo stores to 20 in North America and 10 in Europe each year, aiming to become a global retailer with 10 trillion yen in annual sales. The company's sister brand GU will also expand into US and European markets, with a goal of doubling annual profit to five trillion yen within a few years. GU has already made a foray into North America, opening its first pop-up store in New York City in 2022, and plans to cater to international preferences while avoiding an increase in product types.

site_title: China’s quant clampdown risks damaging fragile markets for years
summary: China's quant clampdown, which restricts computer-driven trading and requires new entrants to report strategies, risks damaging fragile markets for years. Regulators have been monitoring transactions in person and scrutinizing quant funds, which have been hit by chaotic trading sessions and losses. The measures aim to halt a multiyear plunge in equities but raise questions about the government's commitment to a free market. International investors are becoming increasingly skittish about China, and the crackdown may deter global investors, potentially leading to further consolidation and a loss of access to global capital.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for February 23-29, 2024, highlights the tanker and dry bulk market's positive end to the week. Key trends include:

- Capesize vessels experienced a notable increase in activity, with the BCI 5TC index rising from $20,378 to $26,079.
- Panamax vessels declined, with rates decreasing for trans-Atlantic runs and South America.
- Ultramax/Supramax vessels saw mixed fortunes, with stronger rates in the Indian Ocean and Asia.
- Handysize vessels gained, driven by improved enquiry in the Pacific.
- The LNG market maintained its levels, with little fresh enquiry reported for March dates.
- The LPG freight market continued its upward trajectory, with rates rising and TCE earnings increasing.

These trends indicate a positive outlook for the tanker and dry bulk market, with activity increasing in various regions and rates rising for certain vessel types.

site_title: Bob Marley’s ‘Love’ prevails again to stay top of US box office
summary: Bob Marley's biopic "Bob Marley: One Love" led the US box office for a second consecutive weekend, earning an estimated $13.5 million. The film's global take has surpassed $120 million, demonstrating exceptional strength for a music biopic. In third place was Lionsgate's inspirational drama "Ordinary Angels" and Sony's "Demon Slayer" took second with $11.6 million. The film's reviews are strong, and it is already performing well in Japan and South Korea.

site_title: Great Eastern H2 profit falls 13% to S$337.4 million
summary: Great Eastern, a Singaporean insurance provider, reported a net profit of S$337.4 million for the second half of 2023, down 13% from the previous year. The company attributed the decline to the inverted yield curve, which made shorter-term investments more appealing. Despite lower sales, the company's new business embedded value increased 4% in Q4 and the total new customer base grew by over 400,000 in FY2023. The board proposed a final dividend of S$0.40 per share, and the company expects its sales to perform better in 2024 due to a potential decrease in interest rates.

site_title: Singapore’s ‘mild’ green jet fuel levy lags global targets but provides clarity to industry: observers
summary: Singapore has announced a "mild" green jet fuel levy to fund sustainable aviation fuel, set to be applied from 2026. The levy, which will cover 1% of jet fuel used by departing flights, will be increased to 3-5% by 2030. Observers say the levy will have a minor impact on air ticket prices, with estimates ranging from $3 to $16 per flight. The levy provides clarity to the industry and could help boost sustainable fuel production, with Singapore aiming to be a hub for sustainable aviation fuel.

site_title: Vopak scales up biofuel capacity at major bunkering location Sebarok island
summary: Vopak, a Dutch tank storage company, has commissioned 40,000 cubic meters of biofuel capacity at its Sebarok terminal in Singapore. The move marks a significant step towards the greener fuel, as the company repurposes assets from petroleum products to support the blending of biofuels into marine fuels. The development is underpinned by "customer commitment" and aims to diversify the supply chain for marine biofuels, with Vopak's vision of transforming the terminal into a sustainable multi-fuels hub.
