site_title: India central bank asks payment authority to consider Paytm request to become third party app provider
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has asked the National Payments Corporation of India to consider Paytm's request to become a third-party app provider, allowing the payment app to continue processing payments via India's unified payments interface. The RBI previously asked Paytm Payments Bank to wind down its business by March 15, leading to disruption. If approved, Paytm will be able to migrate existing users to a new handle without adding new users.

site_title: Boeing, Airbus struggle to deliver planes as supply chain woes persist
summary: Boeing and Airbus are struggling to deliver planes due to ongoing supply chain woes, with analysts predicting delays until 2030. The travel sector's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic has led to a shortage of skilled labor and parts, causing planes to spend more time waiting for maintenance and engine problems to force aircraft to be grounded. Labour shortages, logistics issues, and energy costs are exacerbating the problem, making it challenging for manufacturers to meet demand. This may result in airlines being stuck with older, less fuel-efficient planes, potentially denting their profits.

images.alt_text: Airbus will set up a centre for sustainable aviation in Singapore, to be located within the existing Airbus Campus at Seletar Aerospace Park

site_title: SingLand H2 net profit rises 7% to S$102.4 million on fair-value gain on investment properties
summary: SingLand reported a 7% rise in net profit to S$102.4 million in the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, driven by a fair-value gain on investment properties of S$14.5 million. Revenue rose 3% to S$358.7 million, largely due to higher income from hotel operations. A final dividend of 4 Singapore cents per share was proposed for FY2023, up from 3.5 Singapore cents per share the year before. Despite a 40% drop in full-year net profit to S$270.8 million, the company expects modest growth in office rentals and moderate improvement in retail rentals in 2024.

images.alt_text: Singapore Land Group remains optimistic on the office sector as it continues to show modest signs of growth

site_title: Issue 89: Singapore to charge for SAF; S-E Asia exchanges join hands on ESG data
summary: Singapore will mandate the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from 2026, with a goal of 1% to 5% of fuel usage by 2030. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) will impose a levy on flight tickets departing from Singapore, which will be used to centrally buy SAF. The levy will be adjusted based on projected SAF prices and the volume of SAF required to meet the SAF targets. This is a unique approach compared to European countries, where airlines are required to purchase and use the mandated percentage of SAF. The move aims to balance sustainability and competitiveness, and Singapore hopes to aggregate SAF demand and raise its negotiating power in the market.

site_title: Singapore’s inflation eases in January despite GST hike; core at 3.1%, headline at 2.9%
summary: Singapore's inflation eased in January, with headline inflation at 2.9% and core inflation at 3.1%, lower than expected. The decrease was attributed to a fall in accommodation and private transport prices, as well as softer core inflation. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry attributed the lower inflation to the Goods and Service Tax (GST) hike. Despite this, economists expect unchanged monetary policy and forecasted inflation to average between 2.5 and 3.5% for the year.

images.alt_text: Disinflation is set for a pause in the first half of the year amid higher GST and the cost public utilities, as well as compounding wage cost pressures, said economists.
Broad-based handouts run the risk of demand-pull inflation, where consumer demand outpaces the supply of goods and services.
Public transport fare hikes, which took effect in December 2023, will pose an upside risk for core inflation.

site_title: DBS extends self-managed money lock feature to all accounts
summary: DBS has extended its self-managed money lock feature, digiVault, to all existing accounts, allowing customers to lock up funds digitally and prevent digital transfers out. Customers can choose how much to lock up and will receive an email confirmation after a two-business-day processing period. To access locked-up funds, customers must personally visit a DBS/POSB branch to verify their identity. This move aims to empower customers with more control over their funds and comes as the bank seeks to intensify its anti-scam public education efforts.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of OCBC signage
Launched by the local banks in November, the feature helps to mitigate losses if a customer’s digital access to bank accounts is compromised.
Serene Koh from OCBC believes digital first doesn’t mean digital only.
OCBC and UOB customers can lock their savings from Thursday; DBS is rolling out a locked account by Dec 7.

site_title: German business sentiment brightens in February: Ifo
summary: Germany's business morale improved in February, with the Ifo institute's business climate index rising to 85.5 from 85.2 in January. This indicates the German economy is stabilizing at a low level, according to Ifo president Clemens Fuest. Despite this improvement, Germany's gross domestic product (GDP) shrank by 0.3% in 2023, making it the world's worst performing major economy, and potentially leading to another recession.

site_title: Eurozone inflation expectations edge up for the year ahead: ECB
summary: Eurozone inflation expectations rose to 3.3% for the next 12 months, up from 3.2% in December, according to a survey by the European Central Bank. Despite rapid inflation decline last year and a record interest rate hike, the ECB expects it may take over a year to reach its 2% target. Consumers still underestimate wage growth, expecting a 1.2% increase, and expect slightly negative economic growth ahead, but reduced unemployment expectations. The ECB expects compensation per employee to rise by 4.6% this year.

site_title: Swiss still love physical cash despite rise of payment apps
summary: Switzerland remains a predominantly cash-based society, with 92% of face-to-face businesses accepting physical currency over mobile payment apps like Google Pay. The acceptance of mobile apps has increased to 59% from 40% in 2021. Despite the trend, campaigners are raising concerns about marginalized groups lacking access to payment apps or cards, and two referendums on the topic are currently underway. The Swiss National Bank's survey contrasts with countries like Sweden, which have become increasingly cashless.

images.alt_text: At last count, there were close to 33,000 shell companies based in Switzerland with Geneva as the leading location, with an estimated one letterbox firm for every 37 citizens in the canton.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, February 23, 2024 (Ep 8)
summary: Inflation eased in Singapore, while Asian markets rallied driven by tech gains. Genting shares fell after disappointing earnings. The Asian markets' rally is attributed to the tech sector's performance, marking a positive trend for the region's markets.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Friday.

site_title: Anwar announces incentives for companies moving to Malaysia’s international financial hub TRX
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced incentives for companies moving to the country's international financial hub, Tun Razak Exchange (TRX), including an industrial building allowance and tax exemptions. The incentives aim to attract businesses to the 28.3-hectare development. Anwar also commented on the weakening ringgit, describing the slide as "concerning" but assigning the central bank to monitor the situation. Despite the currency's recent decline, Anwar expressed confidence in Malaysia's growth prospects, citing positive indicators such as low inflation and unemployment.

images.alt_text: Muhammad Adlan Berhan faces several charges for criminal breach of trust according to Malaysia's Anti-Corruption agency.
The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission has granted businessman Mokhzani Mahathir an additional 30 days to reveal his assets.

Shoppers at Petaling Street in Kuala Lumpur. The weakening of the ringgit has been a silver lining for Malaysia’s tourism sector, making it one of the most affordable destinations for travellers in the region.

site_title: Taylor Swift’s six shows estimated to boost Singapore’s economy by up to S$500 million
summary: Taylor Swift's six sold-out concerts in Singapore are expected to boost the city-state's economy by up to S$500 million in tourism receipts, according to economists' estimates. The concerts, which kick off on March 2, will benefit Singapore's hospitality, food and beverage, and retail activities, with a large number of overseas fans attending the shows. The event is also seen as a longer-term boost to Singapore's reputation, with Swift's endorsement of the city-state as a premier location for music tourism expected to generate sustained economic value.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift will hold six shows at the National Stadium from Mar 2 to Mar 9.
The billionaire singer has made economic waves throughout her record-shattering global tour, in a phenomenon dubbed “Swiftonomics”.
On top of increased search activity for the duration of Swift's Singapore concerts, more actual bookings have also been made at hotels, and some flight prices are recording increases.

site_title: Shell's LNG trading makes US$2.4 billion in final 2023 quarter, sources say
summary: Shell's liquefied natural gas (LNG) trading generated nearly $2.4 billion in the fourth quarter of 2023, accounting for nearly 17% of global LNG trading volumes. This profit was among the highest in Shell's history, driven by strong demand ahead of winter. The company's LNG operations worldwide allow it to benefit from regional shifts in demand and pricing. Shell expects oil, gas, and power trading to play a key role in the energy transition, with its dominant position in the LNG market expected to continue.

images.alt_text: Tight supply of liquefied natural gas is maintaining prices and price volatility above historic averages, Shell says.

site_title: Maritime players ink 5 MOUs for digital innovation, collaboration in sector
summary: Five memoranda of understanding (MOUs) were signed by maritime industry players, including PSA Marine, Advario, and SGTraDex, to further digitalize the sector. The agreements aim to optimize voyage and terminal operations efficiency for liquid bulk vessels in the Port of Singapore. SGTraDex, established in 2021, aims to digitalize the supply chain ecosystem. The move is part of the industry's efforts to improve efficiency and collaboration through digital innovation.

images.alt_text: Vopak has commissioned 40,000 cubic metres of capacity at its Sebarok terminal for the blending of biofuels into marine fuels.
The port is the second-biggest in South-east Asia and its plan will see capacity increase to 27 million twenty-foot equivalent units, from 14 million currently.

Though 2023 was a fruitful year for Singapore's maritime industry, choppy waters are said to lie ahead.
Demand for lower-carbon marine fuel is poised to increase from this year globally as the European Union Emissions Trading System kickstarts for the shipping industry.
Singapore manufacturers have sufficient spare inventory to hedge against supply disruptions, said Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen in Parliament on Jan 9.

site_title: Malaysia’s speciality coffee is on a caffeine rush
summary: Malaysia's specialty coffee industry is experiencing a surge in demand for "affordable luxury" coffee, with chains such as Flash Coffee benefiting from local consumers' boycott of US brands amid the Gaza war. However, concerns arise about an "overdose" of competition, as the market grows. Meanwhile, Neumann Kaffee plans to expand in Indonesia, capitalizing on the increasing coffee market.

site_title: Indonesia residential market to see solid demand in 2024 despite delay to interest rate cuts: analysts
summary: Indonesia's residential market is expected to remain strong in 2024 despite high interest rates, driven by government incentives and increasing demand from the rising middle-income group. Analysts predict landed residential properties will continue to sell well, with Bank Tabungan Negara (BTN) expecting demand to remain in double digits. The government's VAT incentives and high-speed rail linking Jakarta and Bandung have boosted the sector, with developers optimistic about 2024 sales.

images.alt_text: Surveys have consistently shown Prabowo is the candidate to beat.

site_title: Revitalised Chelsea out to pounce on injury-plagued Liverpool at Wembley
summary: Liverpool faces Chelsea in the Carabao Cup final on Feb 25, with Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp looking to claim the first of four potential trophies. However, the Reds are dealing with an injury crisis, with nearly a dozen players missing. Klopp, who is leaving the club at the end of the season, wants to keep the focus on his players, but the team's chances are uncertain. Chelsea, meanwhile, is seeking revenge after a 4-1 loss to Liverpool three weeks ago, and manager Mauricio Pochettino is relying on key players like Raheem Sterling and Christopher Nkunku to unlock Liverpool's defense.

site_title: How rate cuts can change your home loan picture
summary: Singapore's fixed mortgage rates have dropped significantly at the start of 2024, from 4% to 3%, with potential for further falls to 2% by 2025. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are expected to slow down from mid-2024, with chair Jerome Powell hinting at rate cuts this year. Borrowers should be cautious, as the extent of cuts depends on the Fed's response to the US economy, which may lead to a soft or hard landing.

images.alt_text: While home mortgage rates are forecast to be trimmed alongside the US Federal Reserve's expected rate cuts, analysts say the degree of adjustments may differ as banks continue to strive for better risk-return profiles.

site_title: Pakistan wants at least US$6 billion in new IMF loan
summary: Pakistan is seeking a new IMF loan of at least $6 billion to repay billions of dollars in debt due this year. The country's finance ministry plans to negotiate an Extended Fund Facility (EFF) with the IMF, with talks expected to start in March or April. Pakistan faces $25 billion of external debt payments in the fiscal year starting July, and the new loan will aim to ensure balance of payment and debt sustainability, privatize state-owned enterprises, and increase tax revenues. The IMF has stated its willingness to support the post-election government through a new arrangement, but investors are concerned about the impact of political uncertainty on the nation's ability to secure more funding.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has raised its key policy rate by 12.25 percentage points since April 2022, to curb soaring inflation.

site_title: Grab shares plunge after poor outlook clouds first buyback plan
summary: Grab's shares plummeted 8.4% after the ride-hailing company forecast 2024 revenue below analysts' estimates, citing a slowdown in its core online business. Despite robust margins in deliveries and ride-hailing, Grab's plan to buy back up to $500 million in stock was overshadowed by the disappointing forecast. The company's shares fell to their biggest decline since May, following a period of swift expansion into markets from Malaysia to Thailand.

images.alt_text: Grab and GoTo are reportedly discussing a range of scenarios under which both companies could merge.
Grab crosses into the black for 4Q 2023

site_title: BASF plans more German cuts even as group profit set to rebound
summary: BASF, Germany's largest chemical company, plans to cut another €1 billion in annual costs by the end of 2026, mainly affecting its production and administrative activities at its largest chemical complex in Ludwigshafen. The company attributed the cuts to weak demand and high energy costs in its home market, amidst a broader economic downturn in Germany. BASF's group earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) are expected to rebound to €8-8.6 billion in 2024.

It says that its audits have not found any evidence of human rights violations at the two joint ventures and that it has no indication that employees at them were involved in such violations.

site_title: Malaysia’s January inflation steady at 1.5%, beating economists’ forecast
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate remained steady at 1.5% year-on-year in January, beating economists' forecast of 1.6%. The country's core inflation moderated to 1.8% in January, with prices of food and non-alcoholic beverages increasing by 2% and housing, water, electricity, gas, and other fuels also rising 2%. Despite the easing price growth, economists expect inflation to rebound in the second quarter due to price adjustments and tax changes.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour said Malaysia’s exports remained subdued over the quarter due to prolonged weakness in external demand amid strong imports.
Malaysia’s inflation increased 2.5 per cent year on year in 2023, compared with 3.3 per cent in 2022 and remained far below the government's estimate of 3 per cent to 4 per cent.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid disappointing earnings; STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.2% on Friday, Feb 23, amid weak earnings results. Genting Singapore was the biggest loser, shedding 9.7% after delivering weaker-than-expected Q4 financials. DBS analyst Jason Sum attributed the decline to an unforeseen surge in bad debt losses. Venture Corporation shares also fell 2.7%, while Emperador was the only counter to rise, gaining 1%. Markets across the region were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 rising 2.2% and South Korea's Kospi gaining 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Genting Singapore’s shares fell as much as S$0.105 to S$0.925 as at 9.52 am, with 75.8 million shares changing hands.
For the full year, Venture’s revenue fell 21.7 per cent to S$3 billion. Meanwhile, net profit slipped 26.9 per cent to S$270 million.

site_title: China recovery bets grow on Beijing’s moves to stem stock rout
summary: China's stock market is showing signs of a revival, with the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index being the world's best-performing primary gauge this month. Recent rescue measures by Beijing have improved liquidity, reduced currency volatility, and tightened credit spreads, indicating a more lasting recovery. Investors are optimistic about undervalued Chinese stocks, and the offshore yuan has stabilized, while China's 10-year government bond yield is near its lowest level since 2002. A sustained recovery could lead to China's assets being near the cheapest they have ever been versus their peers.

images.alt_text: The law will focus on the “core concerns” of private companies, including protecting their property rights, guaranteeing the interests of entrepreneurs, and managing missed payments for small- and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: GenAI is about to reshape the real estate world
summary: Generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) is poised to revolutionize the real estate industry, offering solutions for property management, leasing negotiation, and investment evaluation. Real estate professionals can leverage GenAI to parse unstructured data, evaluate property performance, and assess existing lease terms, making the process more efficient and cost-effective. The technology's democratizing nature and plug-in environment will enable rapid integration and adaptation to diverse contexts, reducing the time and cost required to adopt GenAI models. This shift is expected to reshape the real estate world, particularly in tech hubs where demand for properties is high.

site_title: Shipping insurance rates soar on Red Sea missile attacks
summary: Shipping insurance rates have increased significantly following Houthi attacks on commercial ships in the Red Sea, exacerbating costs already stretched by soaring freight rates and longer alternative trade routes. The attacks have resulted in a 12% decline in maritime container transport since November, according to IMF data. Insurers are attributing the surge in premiums to the increased risk posed by the Houthi attacks, which have disrupted global trade and led to higher costs for shipping companies.

A UK-registered cargo ship came under attack on 18 February in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, according to the UK's Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO). The attack came just a day after the US forces launched five strikes on Houthi targets, including an unmanned underwater vessel, in Yemen. The US designation of Yemen's Houthis as a 'Specially Designated Global Terrorist group' came into effect on 16 February, due to their increased attacks on shipping lanes in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden since November 2023. The US Department of Defense announced in December 2023 a multinational operation to safeguard trade and protect ships in the Red Sea in response to the escalation of Houthi attacks.  EPA-EFE/YAHYA ARHAB

site_title: G20 voices broad support for two-state solution in Middle East
summary: The G20 foreign ministers, including US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, broadly supported a two-state solution in the Middle East, with virtual unanimity backing the solution as the only possible solution to the crisis. This comes as Israel's parliament voted against recognizing a Palestinian state, and the country faces growing international pressure to create a Palestinian state amid a humanitarian crisis in Gaza. The meeting also tackled Russia's war in Ukraine and global institution reform, with little diplomatic progress.

images.alt_text: epa11150727 US President Joe Biden delivers remarks in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 13 February 2024. President Biden urged the US House of Representatives to pass a 95 billion USD bill with aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. A UK-registered cargo ship came under attack on 18 February in the Red Sea off the coast of Yemen, according to the UK's Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO). The attack came just a day after the US forces launched five strikes on Houthi targets, including an unmanned underwater vessel, in Yemen. The US designation of Yemen's Houthis as a 'Specially Designated Global Terrorist group' came into effect on 16 February, due to their increased attacks on shipping lanes in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden since November 2023. The US Department of Defense announced in December 2023 a multinational operation to safeguard trade and protect ships in the Red Sea in response to the escalation of Houthi attacks.  EPA-EFE/YAHYA ARHAB

site_title: Asia: Markets advance after record rallies
summary: Asian markets advanced on Friday following record highs in Japanese, US, and European markets, driven by Nvidia's quarterly gains and the artificial intelligence boom. The Nikkei 225 reached a record close of 2.2% at 39,098.68, while Shanghai, Sydney, and Seoul also traded higher. However, Jakarta and Singapore were down, and Hong Kong was flat. The rally is expected to set a positive tone for Asian markets, with investors buoyed by the surge in mega tech stocks.

images.alt_text: Passersby look at electric screens, displying Japan's Nikkei share average which surged to a record high, outside of a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan February 22, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: The ‘official’ gold binge has legs
summary: Emerging market central banks continue to stockpile gold, defying higher interest rates and decreasing investment appeal. The reasons behind this trend include geopolitical risks, high inflation, and the decline of trust in US fixed income assets. As global monetary systems evolve, emerging markets are diversifying their reserves away from developed market Treasury bonds and towards their own currencies, increasing demand for gold. China is expected to play a significant role in this trend, with a potential 600-tonne annual gold demand by 2030, nearly 20% more than pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Trading volume is expected to be thin with markets in China and Hong Kong closed for the Chinese New Year holidays.

site_title: China’s new home prices extend declines in January
summary: China's new home prices fell 0.3% month-on-month in January, marking the seventh consecutive decline. Prices dropped 0.7% from a year earlier, the steepest fall in 10 months. The property market has been in a downturn since 2021 due to defaults among overleveraged developers. To support the sector, China's central bank reduced the benchmark mortgage rate, but analysts expect limited impact due to existing mortgage holders not benefiting until next year. The government has also eased purchase curbs in big cities to lure homebuyers.

site_title: America returns spaceship to the Moon, a private sector first
summary: The US has successfully landed an uncrewed commercial robot, Odysseus, on the Moon's south pole for the first time in over 50 years. Funded by NASA, the mission marks a private sector first and paves the way for future US astronaut missions to the Moon. Odysseus, built by Intuitive Machines, touched down near the lunar south pole after a nail-biting final descent, and is now sending data back to Earth. The mission is part of NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services initiative, which aims to stimulate a lunar economy and achieve savings through private sector participation.

images.alt_text: Spiral galaxy NGC 1512, located 30 million light-years away from Earth, is seen in an undated image from the James Webb Space Telescope.

site_title: Malaysia PM says ringgit’s fall concerning but economic fundamentals strong
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim expressed concern over the ringgit currency's 26-year-low against the dollar, but emphasized strong economic fundamentals support a promising outlook. The currency has slumped 4% against the dollar in 2024, but investments and low inflation rates are expected to sustain growth. The government and central bank expect 4-5% economic growth in 2024, with approved investments reaching RM329.5 billion, a record high. Anwar announced incentives for companies moving to the newly launched Tun Razak Exchange financial center, aiming to boost economic growth.

images.alt_text: The local currency fell 0.2% to 4.7965 against the dollar, its weakest level since an all-time low of 4.8850 in 1998 following the fallout from the regional financial crisis.

site_title: StanChart announces US$1 billion share buyback, dividend hike as 2023 profit rises 18%
summary: Standard Chartered announced a US$1 billion share buyback and a 50% increase in dividend payout to 27 US cents per share, following a 18% rise in 2023 pre-tax profit to US$5.09 billion. The bank attributed the increase to strong performance in Asia, despite a US$850 million impairment from its stake in Chinese lender Bohai Bank. The bank also set new guidance, expecting income to grow 5-7% between 2024 and 2026, as it targets to return at least US$5 billion over the next three years.

images.alt_text: Winters’ total remuneration climbed to US$9.9 million last year, from £6.4 million (S$10.89 million) in 2022.

site_title: Thai Jan export growth fastest in 19 months, beats forecast
summary: Thailand's exports grew at their fastest pace in 19 months in January, surpassing expectations with a 10% year-on-year increase. Rice exports rose 17.6% to 947,742 metric tons, driven by improved global demand and a low base last year. Despite this, 2024 rice exports are expected to fall 14.4% to 7.5 million metric tons due to lower production and increased competition. The commerce ministry projects 1-2% export growth for this year, citing a global economic recovery and easing inflation.

images.alt_text: The revised amount is slightly higher than 1.17 trillion baht previously approved and aims to attract more private companies to invest in government projects.

site_title: Thai opposition slams PM for public feud with central bank on rate cut
summary: Thai opposition leader Sirikanya Tansakun criticizes Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin for publicly feuding with Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput over monetary policy, saying it undermines the central bank's independence and poses a threat to credit ratings. The opposition party wants the two leaders to meet to devise a coordinated fiscal and monetary policy response to revive the economy, warning that further disagreements could lead to a sovereign rating outlook cut.

images.alt_text: Srettha Thavisin Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: What China’s persistent deflation means for the world
summary: China's persistent deflation, marked by six consecutive quarters of falling prices, poses significant challenges for the world economy. The country's weak consumer spending power, real estate slump, and tightening regulations have led to reduced demand, forcing businesses to lower prices. Policymakers have pledged to ease price declines, but the deflationary spiral could further depress economic activity, increase debt servicing costs, and trigger recessions. The US-China trade war, led by President-elect Donald Trump's plans to impose 60% tariffs on Chinese exports, exacerbates the situation, dampening prospects for China's export growth and contributing to the deflationary pressure.

images.alt_text: The government will promote the recovery of the property market through measures such as increasing demand and controlling the supply of land for new development.
The world’s second-largest economy is expected to contribute close to 30% of global growth.

Investors are now turning their attention to this month’s Politburo assembly – one of three annually to typically focus on economic policy, although President Xi this year devoted an extra meeting to that cause in September.
FILE PHOTO: Headquarters of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China September 28, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee//File Photo
China is trying to strike a balance between regulating the fast-growing AI sector and promoting its development, amid global concerns about safety and ethical implications.

site_title: The detectives who sniff out ‘superfake’ luxury bags
summary: Luxury authenticators, like Carousell's Heloise Meyer, are like detectives gathering evidence to solve a mystery. They examine every detail, from the zipper's engraving to the leather's feel and smell, to authenticate luxury bags. With the rise of "superfakes" – high-quality counterfeit bags that can fool customers and AI tools – authenticators rely on their intuition, knowledge of genuine bags, and senses to detect the subtlest differences. The luxury industry is adapting with verification tools like microchips, but counterfeiters are evolving, making it a cat-and-mouse game between authenticators and fake makers.

images.alt_text: If you’re mulling over new year resolutions, my hope is that you’ll consider including some “useless” pursuits.

site_title: Digital media upstart Vice laying off ‘several hundred’ staff: CEO
summary: Vice, a digital media company, is laying off "several hundred" staff as part of a strategic shift to realign resources and streamline operations. The company, valued at $5.7 billion six years ago, will no longer publish on its flagship website and instead partner with established media companies to distribute digital content. The move comes after a slowdown in online advertising revenues and tightening credit conditions. The layoffs mark a dramatic fall for the company, which filed for bankruptcy last May.

images.alt_text: Investors are now mulling over how to sell their stakes in the unicorns of yesteryear.

site_title: UK consumer morale falls unexpectedly in February: GfK survey
summary: UK consumer morale fell unexpectedly in February, dropping 2 points to -21, according to a GfK survey. This marked the first decline in four months, as households took a gloomier view of their finances and economic outlook. Despite a rise in consumer price inflation to 4% in January, the Bank of England expects inflation to return to its 2% target by the second quarter. The drop in consumer confidence may impact Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's budget and upcoming national election.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BT Tower communications tower is seen in London, Britain, August 13, 2018. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/File Photo
Tax revenue exceeded spending by £16.7 billion (S$28.3 billion), more than double the surplus a year earlier.
Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak must defy political gravity, and history, as he seeks to win a fifth term of office for the Conservatives.
The UK Treasury pledged in October to provide more clarity on specific areas of crypto by some point in 2024.
Property website Rightmove said on Monday that asking prices for homes rose 0.1 per cent in February compared a year earlier, the first annual increase since August 2023.
Labour Party candidate Gen Kitchen celebrates after winning the Wellingborough Parliamentary by-election at the count centre in Kettering, Britain, Feb 16, 2024.

site_title: JPMorgan CEO Dimon sells about US$150 million of his shares, SEC filing says
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon has sold approximately US$150 million of his shares, according to a SEC filing. This marks the first time Dimon has sold shares since taking charge in 2005. The sale, part of a plan to sell 1 million of his 8.6 million shares, is not related to leadership succession and Dimon has no current plans to sell more stock. Dimon's compensation increased 4.3% to US$36 million for 2023, following the bank's largest-ever annual profit.

site_title: The age of the unicorn is over
summary: The "age of the unicorn" is coming to an end, as investors are struggling to sell their stakes in tech companies that once boasted valuations over $1 billion. Despite the hype around artificial intelligence, venture capital funding has decreased by half since 2021, with only 698 VC-backed firms being purchased by companies last year. Many unicorns are facing financial struggles, with some shutting down or being acquired for parts. However, industry experts believe that the downturn may be a return to a long-run trend, and that startups are rediscovering the concept of frugality, with many being cautious with their hiring and focusing on productivity gains through AI.

images.alt_text: Even with exits constrained, investors want to allocate more money because the returns justify it. That demand may be also be higher than it appears.
Larry Feinsmith (left), JP Morgan Chase’s head of global tech strategy, innovation and partnerships tells Databricks chief Ali Ghodsi about that the bank is working through the risks of AI.
Ryan Reynolds (centre), pictured here in Disney+'s  Welcome To Wrexham, has an impressive portfolio which included a stake in Mint Mobile that was sold to a major telco for US$1.35 billion this year.

site_title: US business activity moderates in February
summary: US business activity moderated in February, with the manufacturing sector showing a 17-month-high reading of 51.5, while the services sector declined to 51.3. Inflation pressures eased, with input prices falling to a 3½-year low. The S&P Global survey suggests the economy continued to expand in the first quarter despite weak January data. Financial markets have pushed back interest rate cut expectations to June from May, citing subdued price pressures.

images.alt_text: With US employment expected to remain firm and household debt service burden near its lowest level since 1980, a meaningful retrenchment of US consumer activity should be avoidable.

site_title: SGX RegCo proposes rule changes to aid company restructuring
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) proposes rule changes to aid company restructuring, aiming to "smoothen and speed up" the process for financially distressed companies. The proposed changes include waiving shareholder approval for significant asset disposals and trading suspension under "exceptional circumstances". The changes, part of Singapore's Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act 2018, aim to balance shareholder and creditor interests and increase the chances of "white-knight rescues" where friendly investors bail out companies. The public consultation period runs until March 22, with SGX RegCo to make a final decision after taking in feedback.

images.alt_text: The intention behind the writers' study of the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act is to obtain qualitative insights into views and perceptions as to the law in practice, from an empirical perspective.
In the Zipmex restructuring case, the Singapore High Court had to consider whether the unregistered foreign Zipmex entities have a “substantial connection” to Singapore as a threshold issue.

Corporate lawyers agreed that temporary relief measures and government financial support for businesses during the pandemic provided a reprieve from the commencement of winding up applications in 2020 and 2021.
While compulsory winding up applications increased in 2023, the numbers were lower and also below pre-Covid levels, said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan.
The SIP comprises two separate processes: simplified debt restructuing programme and simplified winding up programme.

site_title: What’s the future of advertising? Ask Sora
summary: A new AI service called Sora, developed by OpenAI, produces one-minute videos in response to textual prompts, showcasing vivid and detailed visuals. The service's potential impact on the advertising industry is significant, with the possibility of more creative and targeted ads. While Sora may not replace Hollywood, it could lead to a proliferation of short educational and entertaining videos, potentially threatening traditional TV viewing. The technology also has implications for AI progress, computation, and the market valuation of companies like Nvidia.

images.alt_text: A video created by Open AI's newly released text-to-video "Sora" tool plays on a monitor in Washington, DC, Feb 16, 2024.
Sora is a work-in-progress, with the company adding that the model may confuse the spatial details of a prompt, and have difficulty in following a specific camera trajectory.

site_title: India’s stock market surge highlights long-term opportunities
summary: India's stock market has reached an all-time high, surpassing US$4.33 trillion, and has become the world's fourth-largest equity market, ahead of Hong Kong. The surge is driven by positive sentiment, a rapidly growing domestic retail investor base, and sustained foreign institutional investor inflows. Strong corporate earnings, macro stability, and sound monetary policy have created a compelling investment landscape, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) adjusting its India GDP projection upward. This presents long-term investment opportunities for global investors, particularly in sectors such as IT services outsourcing and renewable energy.

images.alt_text: One of world’s fastest rates of economic growth has made India an attractive market for global investors, especially for those looking to pivot away from China.
A trader counts Indian rupee notes in Mumbai. The currency has remained largely stable against the US dollar over the past year, trading at around 83 rupees to the greenback.

site_title: Singtel’s Q3 profit falls 12.5% to S$465 million on exceptional items
summary: Singtel's Q3 net profit declined 12.5% to S$465 million, mainly due to a higher net exceptional loss from Optus and Airtel. The loss was attributed to provisions for costs related to an Australia outage and Airtel's foreign currency convertible bonds. Operating revenue fell 3.2% to S$3.6 billion, while earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) rose 2.6% to S$935 million. The group remains on track to pay its dividend policy, with underlying net profit unchanged at S$559 million.

images.alt_text: The telco said H1 net profit saw a boost from an exceptional gain as a result of regional associate Telkomsel’s integration of IndiHome.

site_title: StanChart CEO Bill Winters’ pay increases to US$10 million
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters' total remuneration increased by 22% to US$9.9 million in 2023, from £6.4 million (S$10.89 million) in 2022. This comes amid a weak deal flow and job cuts in the industry. The news contrasts with HSBC Holdings' CEO Noel Quinn, whose compensation nearly doubled to £10.6 million in 2023. Winters' pay increase has not improved Standard Chartered's shares, which have traded below their 2015 levels due to souring loans tied to Chinese commercial real estate.

images.alt_text: Bill Winters, chief executive officer of Standard Chartered Plc, speaks at the Global Business Summit in New Delhi, India, on Friday, Feb. 9, 2024. The summit runs through Feb. 10. Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday’s open; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.5% at the open on Friday, led by declines from local banks. The Straits Times Index dropped 14.59 points to 3,208.35, with losers outnumbering gainers 63 to 53. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, declined, while Thai Beverage gained 1%. In the US, the Dow Jones index rose 1.2% to a record high, driven by Nvidia's earnings, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also surged.

images.alt_text: Singtel's net profit for the third quarter falls  12.5 per cent to S$465 million due to a higher net exceptional loss.

site_title: Explaining Americans’ pessimism about a strong economy
summary: The US economy is performing well, with no recession in sight, but public opinion remains pessimistic. At least six explanations have been proposed for this disconnect, including the possibility that public perceptions are lagging behind reality, the influence of news media on negative reporting, and the impact of creeping inflation on lower-income households. However, evidence suggests that the lag hypothesis is the most persuasive, as poll respondents are becoming more positive about their own finances and consumer spending has risen rapidly. The narrative has shifted from recession concerns to concerns about the economy's performance, and it may be that the economy is actually doing better than public opinion suggests.

images.alt_text: If one is presiding over a good economy, as Joe Biden is, and persuadable voters seem to be aware that it’s a good economy, why shouldn't he claim credit?

site_title:
Shopee’s parent Sea seen consolidating
Singapore footprint in one-north, Science Park
summary: Sea Ltd, the parent company of Shopee, is consolidating its Singapore footprint into two main buildings: Rochester Commons and 5 Science Park Drive. The company had leased a 200,000 sq ft office space in Rochester Commons for about 10 years but stopped looking for a replacement tenant last year. This move indicates Sea's commitment to its Singapore presence, with the company now focusing on its existing leases rather than expanding its footprint.

site_title: Seoul hopes Japan stock playbook can narrow ‘Korea discount’
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index reached a 20-month high on optimism over the "Corporate Value-up Programme" set to be announced on Monday, aiming to boost company values and narrow the "Korea discount" on stock prices. The programme, inspired by Japan's successful reforms, includes measures to encourage companies to return more to shareholders and introduce an index of firms with strong shareholder value. Analysts expect the reforms to have a positive impact, but warn that follow-up measures are needed to sustain momentum and address challenges such as high inheritance taxes and family ownership.

site_title: Oil settles higher as pressure mounts in the Middle East
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling higher at $83.67 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures at $78.61 a barrel. The gains were driven by escalating tensions in the Middle East, particularly in the Red Sea, where Iran-aligned Houthis have stepped up attacks on ships. However, a build in US crude inventories due to refinery maintenance and outages capped the gains. Market players are pricing in a potential disruption to supply, with the premium for front-month WTI crude futures widening.

images.alt_text: US West Texas Intermediate crude futures (WTI) rose 87 cents, or 1.1 per cent, to settle at US$77.91 a barrel, while Brent crude rose 69 cents, or 0.8 per cent, to US$83.03 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: 🏛️ Budget cheat sheet so that you can sound smart in office
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 announced financial incentives for graduates from the Institute of Technical Education (ITE), including a S$15,000 top-up for diploma programs and a further S$10,000 top-up to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Ordinary Account (OA) for retirement savings. The government also plans to invest over S$1 billion in AI-related projects and provide a S$2 billion top-up to the Financial Sector Development Fund. Additionally, changes to the CPF system include automatic closure of Special Accounts at 55, a raised Enhanced Retirement Sum, and the end of income tax relief for cash top-ups to the Matching Retirement Savings Scheme.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 at all-time high as Nvidia boosts global tech shares
summary: The Stoxx 600 index in Europe reached an all-time high, rising nearly 1% to close at a record high, driven by technology shares after Nvidia's blowout results and upbeat outlook. The technology index is up 12.4% this year, boosted by industry leaders SAP and ASML Holding. The European Central Bank signaled that inflation is coming under control, further boosting sentiment. Other stocks like Mercedes-Benz and Indivior also rose, with Mercedes-Benz announcing a share buyback program and Indivior forecasting annual revenue above estimates.

images.alt_text: Shares of Nvidia surged 16.4 per cent, lifting its market value to almost US$2 billion, after reporting that quarterly profits soared to US$12.3 billion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Genting Singapore, Venture, HRnetGroup, Aztech Global
summary: Singtel's net profit for the third quarter fell 12.5% to S$465 million due to a higher net exceptional loss. Genting Singapore reported a 31% rise in net profit to S$334.9 million for the second half of FY2023. Venture's net profit declined 33.4% to S$130 million, while HRnetGroup's net profit rose 7.1% to S$35.3 million. Aztech Global's net profit surged 134.6% to S$57.1 million. The stock market may be affected by these developments.

site_title: Federal Reserve official warns of inflationary risk of over-consumption
summary: US Federal Reserve officials warn of the potential inflationary risk of over-consumption as the economy continues to spend despite reduced purchasing power due to inflation and increased interest rates. Fed Vice-Chair Philip Jefferson expects growth in spending and production to slow in 2024, but notes the upside risk of continued strength in spending. Jefferson warns about the impact of "keeping up with the Joneses" and excessive consumption, which could slow progress on inflation. The Fed is considering cutting interest rates, but officials are cautious and expect to wait until later this year.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting Singapore falls 9.7% on Friday after Q4 results disappoint
summary: Genting Singapore's shares plummeted 9.7% on Friday, February 23, after the company reported disappointing fourth-quarter financials, with core net profit falling 5% year-over-year and 41% on the quarter. The company's earnings were dragged down by one-off items, including a higher provision on trade receivable balance and impairments. Despite this, analysts remain bullish on the company's outlook, citing a strong post-pandemic recovery and an event-led tourism boom, with maintained "buy" calls and revised target prices ranging from S$1.16 to S$1.30.

images.alt_text: Genting Singapore said Resorts World Sentosa has bounced back to levels nearing the pre-pandemic period.

site_title: Rivian, Lucid tumble as slowing EV demand upsets ramp-up plans
summary: Rivian and Lucid shares plummeted after the companies' earnings reports revealed a slowdown in electric vehicle demand, hindering their ramp-up plans. Rivian forecast flat annual production, while Lucid's forecast fell short of estimates. The uncertain economic outlook and high interest rates are affecting EV demand, echoing Tesla's remarks. The companies' stocks have had a weak start to the year, with Rivian down 34% and Lucid down 12%. The losses could result in over $3.5 billion and $1 billion in market capitalization losses for Rivian and Lucid, respectively.

images.alt_text: he layoffs, part of an aggressive cost-cutting effort, follow job reductions last year and in 2022.

site_title: Eiffel Tower closed for fourth day as its workers strike
summary: The Eiffel Tower in Paris has been closed for the fourth day due to a labour strike by workers who claim financial mismanagement by the company operating the monument is jeopardizing essential renovation work. The strikers, represented by unions, have threatened to continue their walkout as long as necessary. The tower operator, Société d'Exploitation de la Tour Eiffel, denies the allegations, citing a new financial plan that includes a 20% increase in ticket prices to fund renovations until 2031. The city of Paris remains confident that the dispute will not last indefinitely.

images.alt_text: The new facility will host a total of 300 scientists and engineers who had previously been scattered around other Google offices around Paris.
French finance minister Bruno Le Maire said the government would make sure that France remained on track to respect its target of reducing the 2024 state deficit to 4.4 per cent of GDP.

site_title: Google to pause Gemini AI model’s image generation of people due to inaccuracies
summary: Google is pausing its Gemini AI model's image generation of people due to inaccuracies in historical depictions. The issue was raised by users on social media, and Google acknowledged the problem. The company aims to improve the model's accuracy, noting that historical contexts have nuance that requires further tuning. This pause follows a similar issue with Google's Bard AI model last year, which shared inaccurate information about a planet. Google is racing to catch up with rivals OpenAI and Microsoft in the AI software market.

images.alt_text: Makers of AI models have been busy clinching deals with content owners in recent months, aiming to diversify their training data beyond large scrapes of the internet.
Google says that individual users can now access Gemini in their personal Gmail, Docs, Slides, Sheets, and Meet apps through a subscription to Google One AI Premium.
Pricey chips : The costs of doing business are too high for AI startups to survive on their own.

site_title: Grab reports first ever quarterly profit of US$11 million for Q4 2023; announces share buybacks
summary: Grab, a NASDAQ-listed company, has reported its first quarterly profit of US$11 million for Q4 2023, exceeding analysts' consensus of US$638.6 million. Revenue grew 30% to US$653 million, driven by improved performance across all business segments and reduced incentives. The company has also announced a share buyback program of up to US$500 million and plans to forecast revenue and adjusted Ebitda for FY2024. Grab's losses for FY2023 narrowed to US$485 million, down 72% from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Grab and GoTo are reportedly discussing a range of scenarios under which both companies could merge.
Grab attributes the positive Ebitda to increased gross merchandise value and revenue, lowered regional corporate costs and improved adjusted Ebitda across all business segments.

site_title: ECs still a winning proposition for buyers
summary: Singapore's executive condo (EC) market remains firm despite rising prices, driven by strong demand and limited supply. New EC launch prices reached a record high of S$1,417 per square foot in 2023, but growth has been slower than other private properties. ECs continue to offer relatively affordable options, with a 28.9% price increase from 2019. The market's limited supply and government subsidies, including the CPF Housing Grant Scheme, are expected to sustain demand, making ECs a winning proposition for buyers.

images.alt_text: All unit types were well received, with three-bedroom premium and four-bedroom units being most popular, said CDL.
While buying a new executive condominium home is a good way to get into private homeownership, such homes can be fairly unaffordable these days.
The 99-year leasehold Plantation Close EC site, which can yield an estimated 495 units, is located between the future Tengah Park MRT station and Bukit Batok West MRT station.

site_title: Florida lawmakers push to ban social media for children under 16
summary: Florida lawmakers have passed a bill to ban social media for children under 16, citing concerns over online dangers such as sexual predators, cyberbullying, and teen suicide. The legislation, which needs approval from the state House and Governor Ron DeSantis, would require social media platforms to block children under 16 from creating accounts and close existing ones. The bill's sponsor, Republican Erin Grall, claims that social media companies use "addictive features" to harm children, while Governor DeSantis expresses skepticism, citing parental rights.

images.alt_text: Under the agreement, AI-generated content could be given a watermark or tagged in the metadata at source, although the signatories acknowledged that “all such solutions have limitations”.
In June, EU citizens will elect a new European Parliament to pass policies and laws in the region and lawmakers fear the spread of misinformation online could sway voters.
TikTok's "election centres" are designed to better inform Europeans about the electoral process.

(FILES) This picture taken on April 26, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a screen displaying the Tiktok social media platform's logo and the European flag. Tech giants Meta and TikTok are contesting the scope of an EU law that from March will set new rules on competition in the digital marketplace. The European Commission has designated 22 big online companies as "core platform services" to be subject to additional scrutiny and obligations under the Digital Markets Act (DMA) aiming to crack down on anti-competitive practices. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)
The new ads will include a revenue split, offering X’s 80,000 creators another way to make money from their videos.
Over the past few days some users on social media have flagged that the Google Gemini's AI model returns historical images which are sometimes inaccurate.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on Nvidia’s big surge
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, Feb 22, driven by Nvidia's strong results and forecast. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 232.95 points, or 0.60%, to 38,845.19, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 57.03 and 323.61 points, respectively, at the opening bell. This marks the latest in a string of record highs for Wall Street this year, as investors continue to rally behind AI-led growth.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records after blowout Nvidia results
summary: US stocks closed at records on Thursday, driven by Nvidia's blowout earnings, which saw its market value surge to almost $2 billion. The Dow Jones index finished at 39,069.11, up 1.2%, while the S&P 500 jumped 2.1% to 5,087.03 and the Nasdaq Composite Index surged 3.0% to 16,041.62. Nvidia's quarterly profits soared to $12.3 billion, fueled by demand for its technology in artificial intelligence, with other AI-related stocks also experiencing significant gains.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed NVIDIA logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Shares in Nvidia surge 14 per cent, putting it on course to add more than US$230 billion to its market capitalisation.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 232.95 points, or 0.60 per cent, at the open to 38,845.19.

site_title: Nvidia tops Meta record with over US$230 billion jump in value
summary: Nvidia shares surged 14% after reporting blowout results, on track to add over $230 billion to its market capitalization, surpassing Meta's historic stock-market session. The company's artificial intelligence technologies and guidance above expectations drove the surge, with analysts citing "remarkable" strength in AI demand. The market capitalization increase would be the largest single-session gain in history, eclipsing Meta's $197 billion gain. Analysts predict continued growth, with one describing the company as "printing money."

site_title: EU states jostle to host new anti-money laundering agency
summary: EU member states are set to choose a location for the new Anti-Money Laundering Authority (AMLA), with Germany and France among the top contenders. Nine cities, including Brussels and Frankfurt, are in the running. For the first time, EU lawmakers will be involved in the process, following a 2022 court ruling. The agency, which will oversee 40 high-risk financial entities, will have supervisory powers and the ability to impose financial penalties. The voting process is expected to be lengthy, with the chosen headquarters to house about 250 staff.

images.alt_text: Two of the charges stated that Chen had in September 2021 instigated one Yin Hang Liu Shui Dian Hua to forge electronic records to show StanChart that Wang Qiujiao, Chen’s purported girlfriend, had legitimate sources of her wealth.
The seven comprised five men and two women aged from 23 to 74, one of who is believed to be the mastermind of the scheme, Hong Kong customs authorities say.

FILE — The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission building in Washington, Nov. 9, 2022. The Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed receptive on Wednesday, Nov. 29, 2023, to an attack on one of the primary ways the Securities and Exchange Commission enforces laws against securities fraud. (T.J. Kirkpatrick/The New York Times)

site_title: US new vehicles sales set to rise in February
summary: US new vehicle sales are expected to rise 1.4% in February, driven by robust demand and a better supply of vehicles, according to a joint report by JD Power and GlobalData. Total new vehicle sales are estimated to reach 1.2 million units, with consumers expected to spend $40.80 billion. Lower retailer profit margins and higher manufacturer incentives led to lower average transaction prices, with an average incentive spend per unit of $2,565. The average transaction price for new vehicles in February is expected to be $44,045, down $1,919 from last year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 20, 2022 Cars of the Volkswagen (VW) group are transported by rail on the compound at production site of the German carmaker in Emden, northern Germany. - Sales of new cars soared in Germany in March, official figures showed on April 5, 2023 in the latest sign that the industry is shaking off the supply chain problems that have curbed production in recent months. A total of 281,361 new cars hit the road in Europe's biggest economy last month, up 16.6 percent on a year earlier, according to the KBA federal transport authority. (Photo by DAVID HECKER / AFP)

site_title: Reddit files to go public as ‘RDDT’ on NYSE
summary: Reddit is filing to go public on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "RDDT", with plans to raise money for growth and expand its advertising and licensing revenue. The platform, founded in 2005, has over 100,000 online communities and was visited by 76 million people daily in December. Reddit aims to use the funds to make the site a stronger, bigger company, with CEO Steve Huffman crediting the platform's communities with driving campaigns and initiatives. The company reported a net loss of $90.8 million in 2023 on revenue of $804 million.

images.alt_text: Makers of AI models have been busy clinching deals with content owners in recent months, aiming to diversify their training data beyond large scrapes of the internet.
reddit Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
Reddit’s listing is closely watched as a bellwether of an IPO market in the midst of a tentative rebound from a two-year dearth of first-time share sales.
Reddit is considering feedback from early meetings with potential investors in its IPO that it should consider a valuation of at least US$5 billion.

site_title: US offers US$710 million in loans for EV technology projects
summary: The US Energy Department has given preliminary approval for nearly $710 million in loans to electric vehicle technology manufacturing ventures. The loans will support the expansion of a plant in Bay City, Michigan, and an EV battery pack assembly operation in Ohio and Michigan. The projects are expected to create around 200 jobs. The department has disbursed $34.43 billion in loans as of December 2023 and has $221.8 billion in loan capacity remaining.

images.alt_text: Under the revised final regulation expected to be made public as soon as next month, the EPA will slow the pace of its proposed yearly emissions requirements through 2030.
As US factories spin up to produce EVs, semiconductors and solar panels, China is flooding the market with similar goods.
China has become a global powerhouse in electric cars: It’s expected to account for about 60 per cent of the world’s 14.1 million new passenger EV sales this year.
The funding comes amid a broader administration goal of having EVs represent at least half of all new car sales in the US by 2030.

site_title: Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia seek to boost tri-country tourism
summary: Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia are promoting a "One journey, three destinations" tri-country tourism initiative, aiming to boost travel between the three countries. The countries share borders and offer diverse historical, cultural, and natural attractions, including ancient temples, vibrant cultural heritage, and serene countryside. Industry players call for streamlined visa requirements, including mutual recognition of visas and unified application procedures, to facilitate the trip. The move is seen as a way to increase tourism revenue and promote cultural exchange among the countries.

images.alt_text: view, landscape, nature

site_title: Towards a greener future
summary: Singapore's 2024 Budget prioritizes green transition and energy transformation, aiming to be a catalyst for the region's clean energy shift. The government has partnered with the International Energy Agency to set up a Regional Cooperation Centre, focusing on deploying renewables and increasing access to finance for clean energy investments. The budget also introduces measures to support companies in the renewable space, such as enhanced green loans and energy efficiency grants. With the goal of reaching net-zero emissions by 2050, Singapore is well-positioned to lead the region's green energy transformation, with a potential for significant investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Solar panels deployed at Singapore's Kusu Island. The country is committed to accelerate its shift to low-carbon energy sources.
A new initiative named the Future Energy Fund will receive an initial injection of S$5 billion to build critical infrastructure and improve energy security.

site_title: US dollar dips as rally peters out, most PMI data adds to market optimism
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.25% to 103.67, tracking a weekly decline of around 0.5% and a year-to-date gain of over 2%. The decline follows better-than-expected business activity surveys and optimism in markets, with share markets hitting record highs. The euro rose 0.3% against the US dollar, while sterling and the yen remained steady. The US dollar index is still expected to ease interest rates, with traders pricing in a 30% chance of a rate cut in May, down from over 80% last month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: A new dimension to first-timers’ BTO dilemma
summary: Singapore's new Build-to-Order (BTO) framework, set to take effect in the second half of 2024, may simplify the decision for young households choosing between buying a new BTO flat or a resale flat. The new framework introduces Standard, Plus, and Prime categories, with stricter regulations for Prime and Plus flats. The change aims to moderate the "lottery effect" seen in the resale market, where young households can sell their BTO flats for significant profits after the five-year Minimum Occupation Period (MOP). The new framework is expected to provide a more gradual pathway for homeowners to upgrade and promote affordable homeownership.

images.alt_text: From 2003 to 2023, prices of private non-landed housing and HDB resale flats increased by 143.1 per cent and 140.2 per cent respectively. Over the same period, prices of landed homes jumped by a steeper 180.6 per cent.

site_title: BTO flats in Tanjong Rhu, Holland Village to go on sale in June
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) will launch seven Build-To-Order (BTO) projects in June, offering approximately 6,800 flats across six locations in Singapore. Two of the projects, in Tanjong Rhu and Holland Village, will feature two-room flexi, three- and four-room flats with potential views of the Singapore Sports Hub and Marina Reservoir. Analysts expect these projects to be popular due to their prime locations and proximity to MRT stations. The projects are part of the HDB's second BTO sales exercise of 2024.

images.alt_text: Which sectors in Singapore property - residential, commercial, or industrial - offer best prospects?
The three adjoining shophouses in Duxton Road are nearing the completion of a refurbishment.
12 Lorong 12 Geylang is a freehold 184-room hotel with a private parking facility.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly fall
summary: US jobless claims unexpectedly fell to 201,000 for the week ended Feb 17, beating economists' forecasts of 218,000. This drop suggests job growth likely remained solid in February, despite high-profile layoffs at the start of the year. Historically low jobless claims hover, despite the economy's expansion and interest rate increases. The Labor Department's data also showed a 27,000 drop in people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid, a proxy for hiring.

images.alt_text: An attendee signs into a career fair hosted by the New Hanover NCWorks and the Cape Fear Workforce Development Board in Wilmington, North Carolina, US, on Tuesday, June 20, 2023. The Department of labor is scheduled to release initial jobless claims figures on June 22. Photographer: Allison Joyce/Bloomberg
Retail sales dropped 0.8 per cent last month, the Commerce Department’s Census Bureau said on Thursday (Feb 15), also likely weighed down by winter storms.

site_title: US existing home sales rise to five-month high in January
summary: US existing home sales rose 3.1% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.00 million units in January, the highest level since last August. Declining mortgage rates pulled in buyers, but tight supply remains a challenge, with a four-to-seven-month supply and median existing home price increasing 5.1% to $379,100. First-time buyers accounted for 28% of sales, below the 40% needed for a robust market, and all-cash sales made up 32% of transactions.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increases 19 basis points in the week ended Feb 16 to 7.06 per cent

site_title: India's Modi says committed to farmers' welfare, protesting leaders to expand campaign
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has assured farmers of his government's commitment to their welfare, promising to make them entrepreneurs and exporters. Amid a protest by thousands of farmers seeking higher prices for their produce, Modi's comments come months before general elections. The farmers, mostly from Punjab, have been attempting to march to the capital but were stopped 200 km away by police using tear gas, rubber bullets, and water cannons. Modi has proposed a cabinet decision to raise the floor price for sugar cane by 8%, which will benefit cane farmers but not the protesting farmers.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Police fire teargas to disperse farmers marching towards New Delhi during a protest demanding minimum crop prices, at the Haryana-Punjab state border in Shambhu near Ambala about 200 kilometres (125 miles) north of the capital on February 14, 2024. Farmers in India this week launched the "Delhi Chalo", or "March to Delhi", in an echo of January 2021, when they broke through barriers and rolled into New Delhi on Republic Day during a then year-long protest. (Photo by Narinder NANU / AFP)

site_title: Transition finance can be misused to fund heavy emitters that do not decarbonise
summary: Transition finance, aimed at supporting the decarbonization of high-emitting sectors, carries greenwashing and reputational risks if used to fund companies without real change. Regulators are standardizing transition plans, providing frameworks and principles to guide sustainable financing. Investors like Fidelity International are assessing companies' transition credibility using metrics and requesting short-term targets to track progress. To mitigate risks, investors are engaging with portfolio companies, identifying high-risk companies, and voting against management to nudge them towards transition.

images.alt_text: DPM Lawrence Wong said he hopes this year's Budget will give Singaporeans confidence to build a better future even in an increasingly troubled world.
More than 400 companies, including those in key stock indexes, will need to publish sustainability reports by 2026, according to draft guidelines released this month by China’s three main exchanges.
The new taxonomy was a revision to a 2022 document defining what is considered a sustainable investment in support of Indonesia’s pledge to achieve net-zero emissions by 2060.
The challenge in the world of blended finance is scale. It’s a challenge that Singapore, in particular, is trying to solve as part of the nation’s ambitions to become a sustainable finance hub.

site_title: Spirit of old Japan
summary: Ise-Shima National Park in Japan's Pacific Coast is a hidden gem for traditional Japanese culture and natural beauty. The park's stunning coastline, scenic forests, and historic Ise Jingu shrine complex attract millions of visitors each year. Ama women freedivers, who have a 5,000-year tradition, can be found in the region, harvesting seafood and pearls. The area is also famous for its pearl jewelry, and visitors can sample local specialties like Ise udon and sushi tekone. A unique experience in Ise-Shima is kayaking across the Pacific Ocean or rowing one's own boat, offering breathtaking views of the coastline and surrounding landscape.

images.alt_text: Specialised travel itineraries such as wellness tourism, thematic holidays and active tourism are becoming increasingly popular.

site_title: UK economy puts recession behind it, but inflation pressures rise
summary: The UK economy showed strong growth in services firms, with the February S&P Global/CIPS UK Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 53.3, the highest in nine months. However, inflation pressures remain a concern, with wages increasing strongly and factory supplies hit by Red Sea tensions, pushing price increases to their highest since July. The economy is likely to grow by 0.2-0.3% in the first quarter of 2024, but policymakers may err on the side of caution when considering interest rate cuts due to the risk of inflation getting stuck at 4%.

images.alt_text: The Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, attends a press conference in London, Britain, May 11, 2023. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/Pool

site_title: Thai parliament approves looser fisheries rules in first reading
summary: Thailand's parliament has approved eight draft fishery bills in the first reading, loosening regulations on the fisheries industry. The move comes after concerns from the multibillion-dollar seafood sector that current rules are too tough. The bills aim to address concerns from fishermen and the government, while maintaining international standards and obligations. A parliamentary committee will review the drafts, and the new regulations must pass a second and third reading and Senate approval before becoming law. This move follows a crackdown on illegal fishing introduced in 2015, aimed at improving management and inspection systems.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s aquaculture industry is expected to grow rapidly, with million of dollars funding poured into the ecosystem over the past three years.

site_title: Greece to sell entire stake in Piraeus Bank in early March, sources say
summary: Greece's Hellenic Financial Stability Fund (HFSF) is set to sell its entire 27% stake in Piraeus Bank in early March, the fourth such sale in the country's banking sector since October. The sale, valued at over $1 billion, will be offered to institutional investors and retail investors. The move reflects the progress made by Greece's banking sector since the financial crisis ended, with the sector's bad loan ratios falling below 7% and profits expected to jump in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Greece's Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis pledges that the government will remain committed to a path of fiscal discipline while pushing ahead with divestments from state-held assets.

site_title: Tight supplies, improved demand push India rice rates to fresh records
summary: India's 5% broken parboiled rice variety reached record prices at $546-$554 per tonne this week, up from $542-$550. Limited supplies and slight improvement in demand drove the increase. In contrast, Vietnam's 5% broken rice prices dropped to $625-$630 per tonne due to building supplies amid the harvest of the winter-spring crop. Traders in other countries, such as Thailand and Bangladesh, also saw price fluctuations due to local currency fluctuations and anticipated new supply.

images.alt_text: Parboiled rice is the result of a process that involves partial boiling of paddy before milling to boost its nutritional values and change the texture of cooked rice.
India’s 5 per cent broken parboiled variety has been quoted at a record US$542 to US$550 per tonne this week.
Workers unload sacks of rice imported from Thailand from a cargo ship at Malahayati Port in Krueng Raya, Indonesia's Aceh province, on June 22, 2023. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)

site_title: Global trade rift widening as Ukraine war passes two-year mark
summary: The global economy is fragmenting into two separate blocs due to rising geopolitical tensions and concerns over economic security, threatening multilateral trade rules. Two years after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, trade flows between countries supporting Russia and those backing Ukraine have grown 4% slower than within blocs. The World Trade Organization warns that an outright fragmentation could shrink the global economy by 5%, with developing countries suffering the most. Trade restrictions and distortions have increased, pushing countries towards protectionism, and WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala advocates for "re-globalisation" to boost the world economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. and Chinese flags are seen in this illustration taken, January 30, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: India market value to reach US$10 trillion by 2030, Jefferies says
summary: India's stock market value is projected to reach $10 trillion by 2030, according to Jefferies Financial Group. The nation's market, currently the world's fifth-largest at $4.5 trillion, is expected to more than double due to its history of delivering double-digit returns and continued economic reforms. With a 7% GDP growth rate over the past decade, India's economy is on track to surpass Japan and Germany by 2027, driven by demographics, institutional strength, and improved governance standards.

site_title: AT&T grapples with wireless service disruption across US
summary: AT&T is experiencing widespread disruptions to its wireless service across the US, with over 70,000 reports of problems on service-tracking website Downdetector. The outage has affected tens of thousands of customers, making or receiving calls, and is impacting emergency responders in major cities. AT&T is working to restore service, and customers are advised to use Wi-Fi calling until service is restored. The cause of the outage is unclear, and this is not the first time AT&T has suffered a nationwide disruption, with previous incidents in 2008 and 2020.

images.alt_text: AT&T has been analysing Open RAN for six months with a team of hundreds, an executive said and has looked at multiple vendors and sought proposals.
FILE PHOTO: Shoppers walk past an AT&T store at the King of Prussia Mall in King of Prussia, Pennsylvania, U.S. November 22, 2019. REUTERS/Mark Makela/File Photo

site_title: VinFast posts higher revenue in Q4
summary: Vietnamese electric vehicle maker VinFast reported a 133% jump in fourth-quarter revenue to US$437 million, missing analysts' estimate of US$570.9 million. Despite this, the company aims to deliver nearly 100,000 units this year, up from 35,000 in 2023, as it expands into new markets. VinFast's market capitalization has surged to US$85 billion after its Nasdaq debut, but has since declined to US$12 billion due to intensified price competition. The company plans to construct a factory in North Carolina and enter the Indian market, aiming to nearly triple vehicle sales this year.

images.alt_text: The vehicles being recalled were manufactured from March to December last year, VinFast says.

site_title: HDB owners increasingly shut out of ‘ultimate upgrade’ to landed housing
summary: HDB owners in Singapore are increasingly unable to upgrade to landed housing due to rising prices. From 2003 to 2023, HDB resale flat prices increased by 140.2%, while landed home prices rose 180.6%. In 2023, only 15.3% of landed homes were bought by HDB upgraders, down from a peak of 29.5% in 2009. The price gap between public and private housing has widened, with the median price of a five-room HDB flat at S$537,000 and a terrace house at S$2.68 million. The limited supply of landed homes and government policies to keep public housing affordable are expected to exacerbate the issue.
