site_title: Co-living player The Assembly Place eyes pole position, overseas expansion
summary: The Assembly Place, a co-living player, aims to expand its portfolio to 4,000 rooms by year's end and become the market leader in Singapore. Founded in 2019 with six rooms, the company has grown exponentially, managing 1,800 rooms in 102 assets and $500 million in assets. CEO Eugene Lim plans to fortify the business by entering student housing and exploring overseas expansion in countries like Vietnam, Japan, and Australia. The company has secured $15 million to $20 million in Series A funding and has a pipeline of projects, including a 66-room co-living space in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: China’s property foreclosures surge as growth slows
summary: China's property foreclosures surged 48% in January, with 100,400 properties listed for sale, compared to a 37% increase in 2023. This is a sign of the country's economic slowdown, with real estate loans accounting for a large majority of non-performing debt. Foreclosed residential properties were sold at an average discount of 23% in January, and the market is expected to worsen after Lunar New Year, with wider discounts and a downward trend forecast.

site_title: Moderna beats sales estimates as Covid shot gains market share
summary: Moderna posted quarterly revenue of US$2.8 billion for its Covid-19 vaccine, beating analyst estimates by 10%. The company gained market share, capturing roughly half the US retail market during the fall Covid season. Despite a 45% decline from last year, Moderna reaffirmed its 2024 sales forecast of US$4 billion. The company expects approval for its RSV vaccine by May 12 and plans to compete in a market with established players. Moderna's post-pandemic future is seen as boosted by the results.

images.alt_text: According to Oppenheimer, Moderna could have five products on the market by 2026.
Metagenomi will aim to list on the Nasdaq under the symbol “MGX”.

site_title: S$14,000 for a health screening: Doctor Anywhere joins the luxe preventive care market. Will people pay?
summary: Luxury health screening centers are emerging in Singapore, offering high-end services and amenities. DA Orchard MedSuites and Minmed Wellness Collective provide bespoke screening packages, while Healthway Medical and Parkway Shenton offer VIP services with perks like limousine transportation and gourmet meals. These centers cater to affluent individuals, with demand outpacing supply. Prices for health screenings range from S$14,000, sparking questions about the value and necessity of such services.

images.alt_text: “Real” plant-based foods that are less processed, are making a comeback, says a wellbeing practitioner.
Minmed Wellness Collective at Jewel has seven plush screening suites.
Despite most workers believing physical activity and good mental health are linked, nearly one-fifth do not exercise at all.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 22)
summary: UOB's net profit for the fourth quarter increased 21.8% to S$1.4 billion. Despite a short-term hit to net interest margins due to prudent liquidity measures, the CEO believes long-term benefits lie in fees and customer growth. Singapore banks gave junior staff a one-time bonus amid rising cost of living concerns. Delivery Hero terminated talks on the potential sale of its foodpanda business in South-east Asia. The liquidators of Three Arrows Capital plan to distribute an interim dividend by March 31. Atome's CEO, David Chen, stepped down to join GoTo Financial.

site_title: China’s CATL says its lithium mine operating normally
summary: China's CATL battery giant says its lithium mine in Jiangxi province is operating normally as planned after the Chinese New Year break, despite market speculation that output had been cut due to low lithium prices. The company did not provide details on output levels, but one person familiar with the matter said production had only resumed at one of two production lines. Analysts now expect the mine to produce 15,000 to 20,000 tonnes of lithium carbonate equivalent this year, far less than initial expectations.

images.alt_text: Tesla’s arrangement appears to be a departure from CATL’s deal with Ford Motor, which aims to license the Chinese company’s technology to build batteries at a Michigan plant owned by the automaker.
The centre will develop patents to be used around the world – licenced to companies such as current CATL partner Ford Motor.
As part of the partnership, Stellantis and CATL plan to build an LFP battery factory in Europe.
CATL sees its China market share tumble in September to the lowest in more than a year.

site_title: HRnetGroup H2 profit rises 7.1% to S$35.3 million on strong profit margin
summary: HRnetGroup posted a 7.1% rise in net profit to S$35.3 million for the second half of 2023, driven by a strong profit margin. Revenue fell 4.7% to S$283.7 million due to tough economic conditions and sector-wide profit downgrades. The company proposed a final dividend of 2.13 Singapore cents per share for FY2023, up from 1.87 cents the previous year. Net profit for the full year ended December 2023 was down 5.9% to S$63.6 million, and revenue was down 5.4% to S$578.5 million.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2024

site_title: Indonesia 2023 current account swings to deficit, bolsters view on BI pause
summary: Indonesia's current account swung to a $1.6 billion deficit in 2023, primarily due to weakening global demand and merchandise exports. This has bolstered expectations that Bank Indonesia (BI) will keep its key interest rate unchanged for a while longer. A weaker current account balance could affect the rupiah and imported inflation, which are key considerations for BI's policy rate decisions. BI forecast a current account deficit between 0.1% to 0.9% of GDP this year.

images.alt_text: The latest hike takes cumulative rate increases to 225 basis points since August 2022, and suggests that monetary authorities in Indonesia remain focused on tempering prices.

site_title: These are the best restaurants in Seoul and Busan according to Michelin
summary: The Michelin Guide has awarded stars to three Busan restaurants, Fiotto, Mori, and Palate, with Fiotto also receiving a Michelin Green star for its sustainable mentality. In Seoul, Mosu remains the only three-star restaurant, with two new two-star restaurants, Mitou and Restaurant Allen, joining the list. The guide marks Busan's entry into the Michelin guide, following Seoul's inaugural guide eight years ago, and highlights the city's growing profile as a culinary destination.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from top left: Chudaree (Tam) Debhakam, Pichaya “Pam” Utharntharm, Tamara Chavez, Natsuko Shoji, Vicky Lau and Kim Bo-mi.
Getting a second Michelin star helped to boost business at Cloudstreet.

site_title: Meta says not required to pay for Indonesia news content posted voluntarily
summary: Meta Platforms stated it is not required to pay for news content posted voluntarily by users in Indonesia under a government regulation signed by the country's president. The regulation aims to level the playing field between big tech companies and the media industry by requiring digital platforms to pay media outlets that provide them with content. The regulation is expected to take effect within six months, but Meta claims it is not obligated to pay for content posted by news publishers voluntarily.

site_title: Biden calls Putin ‘crazy SOB’ and steps up attacks on Trump
summary: US President Joe Biden called Russian President Vladimir Putin a "crazy SOB" and criticized Republican rival Donald Trump for likening himself to Putin, comparing Trump's legal troubles to Putin's ally Alexey Navalny's death. Biden also made scathing comments about the Republican Party, calling them the "party of chaos and division." The response from Moscow was that Biden's comments were "boorish" but unlikely to offend Putin, who is known for his strong personality. Biden is on a three-day fundraising tour of the West Coast ahead of the November elections.

images.alt_text: Trump assumes that relations between states  are transactional, and, that as long as Beijing or Moscow do not threaten US military and economic interests directly, Washington could make deals with them.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz to update combustion engine cars amid EV demand slowdown
summary: Mercedes-Benz has revised its expectations for electric vehicle (EV) demand, citing slower growth in the industry. The company now expects electrified sales, including hybrids, to account for up to 50% of total sales by 2030, down from its previous goal of 100%. Mercedes-Benz plans to update its combustion engine lineup well into the next decade, with a new lineup expected in 2027. The company's CEO, Ola Kaellenius, attributed the shift to a lack of charging infrastructure and appealing electric models, as well as slower economic growth and supply chain bottlenecks.

images.alt_text: Carmakers have returned more money to shareholders in recent months after benefiting from pent-up demand after years of supply-chain disruptions.
Automakers have benefited from high order banks that accumulated during years of severe supply-chain disruption, which are now slowly returning to normal.

site_title: Zurich Insurance announces US$1.25 billion buyback after record profit
summary: Zurich Insurance reported a record annual operating profit of US$7.4 billion, a 21% increase from the previous year, beating analyst estimates of US$7.1 billion. The company announced a share buyback of up to US$1.25 billion, amid a global pandemic, wars, and climate disasters that have affected insurers' claims. Zurich's strong performance is attributed to premium increases and exclusions of certain business lines.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of insurer and bank AXA Belgium S.A. is seen in Brussels, Belgium February 25, 2023. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo

site_title: Genting Singapore H2 profit rises 31% to S$334.9 million on strong post-pandemic recovery
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 31% increase in net profit to S$334.9 million for the second half of 2023, driven by a significant post-pandemic recovery of its businesses. Revenue rose 26% to S$1.3 billion, while earnings per share increased 79.8% to 5.07 Singapore cents. The company attributed the growth to strong revenue gains and expects ongoing developments, including the soft opening of new attractions at Resorts World Sentosa, to drive future performance.

images.alt_text: CGS-CIMB says on Thursday MBS' solid results could mean a positive surprise for competitor Genting Singapore’s Q4 performance.
Genting Singapore said that Resorts World Sentosa, which is wholly owned by the group, has “continued to benefit from the sustained recovery of travel and tourism.”

site_title: Singapore banks give junior staff one-off bonus amid rising cost of living
summary: Singapore banks are giving junior staff a one-time bonus amid rising cost of living concerns. The gesture aligns with recommendations from Singapore's National Wages Council, which suggests that employers help lower-income employees cope with the higher cost of living. This move is seen as a way for companies to support their employees, particularly those with lower to middle incomes, as they face increased expenses.

images.alt_text: DBS, OCBC and UOB branches in Singapore.

site_title: Reddit in AI content licensing deal with Google: sources
summary: Reddit has struck a deal with Google to make its content available for training the search engine giant's artificial intelligence (AI) models, worth about $60 million per year. The deal underscores the platform's efforts to generate new revenue amid fierce competition for advertising dollars. This is Reddit's first reported deal with a big AI company, and it comes ahead of the platform's initial public offering (IPO) filing, which could detail its financials for the first time.

images.alt_text: reddit Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
Reddit’s listing is closely watched as a bellwether of an IPO market in the midst of a tentative rebound from a two-year dearth of first-time share sales.
The valuations under consideration demonstrate the extent of tech’s retreat from the heady days of the private funding boom that peaked in 2021.

site_title: Eurozone business activity inches towards growth in Feb: survey
summary: The eurozone business activity showed signs of recovery in February, with the services sector breaking a six-month contraction streak and offsetting a manufacturing downturn. The HCOB's preliminary composite PMI rose to 48.9, ahead of expectations, and the services PMI jumped to 50, exceeding forecasts. However, inflationary pressures remained, with output prices indexes rising. The European Commission said the EU's economy is stronger due to the recovery fund, but the Bank of England is expected to keep borrowing costs under pressure due to inflation.

images.alt_text: The European Commission says a flash estimate showed eurozone consumer morale improved to -15.5 this month from -16.1 in January.
While still high, fourth-quarter pay growth is down from a eurozone record of 4.7 per cent, notched in the previous three months, the ECB’s negotiated wage indicator shows.

ECB policymaker Isabel Schnabel has pointed to a number of factors behind the eurozone’s long-running economic underperformance versus the US, including lower investment in technology, more red tape and more expensive energy.
“Lower energy commodity prices and weaker economic momentum set inflation on a steeper downward path than anticipated in the Autumn Forecast,” European Commission says.
A customer shops in a supermarket in Nice, France, August 18, 2022. REUTERS/Eric Gaillard/File photo
Sentix’s index for the eurozone rises to -12.9 points in February from -15.8 in January, above a reading of -15 estimated in a Reuters poll of analysts.
HCOB’s composite PMI for the bloc, compiled by S&P Global, rose to 47.9 in January from December’s 47.6, matching a preliminary estimate.

site_title: IReit Global’s H2 DPU falls 26.6% to 0.0094 euro
summary: IReit Global reported a 26.6% decline in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.0094 euro, down from 0.0128 euro in the prior year period, due to lower income distribution and a larger unit base. Gross revenue rose 15.7% to 36.5 million euros, driven by the acquisition of 17 retail properties in France. For the full year, gross revenue increased 5.4% to 65 million euros, while net property income rose 2.3% to 49.9 million euros.

images.alt_text: Reit manager IReit Global Group said that the lease extension in France will add over 22 million euros of cash flows.

site_title: Aztech H2 net profit more than doubles to S$57.1 million
summary: Aztech Global's net profit more than doubled to a record S$100 million for FY2023, driven by higher revenue and economies of scale. Revenue rose 9.3% to S$896.3 million, with the company attributing the growth to stronger revenue. Aztech plans to increase total dividend for FY2023 to eight Singapore cents per share, up from S$0.045 in FY2022. Despite a challenging outlook for the next six to 12 months, the company remains committed to disciplined operations and innovation.

images.alt_text: Based on the information available to date, the cybersecurity incident does not have any material impact to Aztech Global’s financials or operations, it said in a bourse filing.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, February 22, 2024 (Ep 7)
summary: UOB shares fell after missing earnings expectations. In contrast, US tech company Nvidia posted blockbuster earnings. Japan's Nikkei 225 broke a historical record, as the index surpassed its bubble-era peak.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.

site_title: Venture H2 net profit falls by a third on lower revenue
summary: Venture Corp reported a 33.4% decline in net profit for the second half of 2023, driven by lower revenue. The company's net profit fell to S$130 million, down from S$195.3 million in the previous year, while revenue decreased 30.2% to S$1.4 billion. Despite this, the company's full-year dividend remains unchanged at S$0.75 per share, and its balance sheet remains strong with a net cash position of around S$1.1 billion. Demand is expected to be stronger in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Maybank expects more orders for Venture in FY2024, leading to higher operating margins.

site_title: Congratulations Nikkei, now don’t screw it up
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 stock average reached an all-time high of 39,098.68, surpassing the 1989 bubble-era record. The country must learn from past mistakes to sustain the momentum, with key challenges including maintaining foreign investor interest, managing political concerns, and avoiding another economic downturn. The Bank of Japan must also chart a careful course to avoid repeating past missteps.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei share average started 1980 at 6,867 and ended the decade at 38,915.
Japanese companies' strong earnings suggest the rally that’s pushed major share indexes toward record highs has more room to run.

Visitors offer prayers on the first business day of the year at the Kanda Myojin shrine in Tokyo, Japan, on Jan 4, 2024. Japan’s Nikkei 225 fell after speculation that the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates elevated for longer hurt technology shares, and as a powerful earthquake in the country's northwest on Jan 1 dragged down some companies.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Thursday as regional indices gain, Nikkei 225 makes major rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% or 5.83 points to 3,222.94, driven by regional markets' gains. Japan's Nikkei 225 broke a 35-year record, up 2.2% at 39,098.68. Agribusiness Wilmar International led the STI's gain, while UOB declined 2.5% after posting its fourth-quarter results. Gainers beat losers 326 to 219, with 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.5 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: UOB Q4 profit rises 21.8% to S$1.4 billion; proposes S$0.85 per share final dividend
Wilmar International's chairman and chief executive, Kuok Khoon Hong, expects tough operating conditions to continue into FY2024.
“Yes, if the family members are interested, they’re more than welcome. But I think they need passion, they need love, and they need the desire to be part of the team,” said UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong.
UOB’s net profit for the fourth quarter rose 21.8 per cent to S$1.4 billion, compared with S$1.2 billion a year earlier, due to higher net fee income and other non-interest income.
The Nikkei share average started 1980 at 6,867 and ended the decade at 38,915.

site_title: Indonesia posts 31.3 trillion rupiah budget surplus in Jan
summary: Indonesia posted a budget surplus of 31.3 trillion rupiah (S$2.7 billion) in January, accounting for 0.14% of its gross domestic product. Government revenues reached 215.5 trillion rupiah, 7.7% of the full-year target, while spending was at 184.2 trillion rupiah, 5.5% of the total allocation. The government plans to spend US$216 billion this year with a fiscal deficit outlook of 2.29% of GDP and an economic growth target of 5.2%.

site_title: Axa to return 6 billion euros to investors in new payout policy
summary: French insurer AXA plans to return 6 billion euros (S$8.73 billion) to investors under a new payout policy, with 75% of underlying earnings per share to be returned over the coming years. The policy includes 15% via buybacks, with last year's dividend at 1.98 euros per share. AXA aims to grow underlying earnings per share by 6-8% from 2023 to 2026, and reach an underlying return on equity of 14-16% over 2024-2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Zurich Insurance is seen in Davos, Switzerland January 20, 2020.  Picture taken January 20, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: SIFA 2024: Smart, daring, eclectic works take centrestage
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) 2024 is set to feature a diverse lineup of performances, including climate change-themed opera "Sun & Sea", puppet shows, and multimedia productions. The festival, running from May 17 to June 2, will include works by renowned artists such as Trajal Harrell and Susanne Kennedy. Highlights include "Moby Dick" by French-Norwegian company Plexus Polaire, "Refuge" by experimental band The Observatory, and "The Prose and The Passion" by Singapore playwright Haresh Sharma. SIFA director Natalie Hennedige aims to create a smart and edgy festival that takes risks and reaches out to a wider audience.

images.alt_text: Premier art fair Art SG is drawing collectors from around the world.

site_title: Thousands ordered to flee while they can as bushfire burns in Australia’s south
summary: Thousands of people in Victoria, Australia have been ordered to evacuate due to a bushfire burning out of control. Residents in Raglan and Beaufort, home to around 2,000 people, and surrounding areas have been advised to leave and head east to Ballarat. Over 1,000 firefighters, 24 aircraft, and 100 vehicles are battling the blaze, which covers around 50 square kilometers. State Premier Jacinta Allan urged residents to leave immediately for their safety, as temperatures reached 40 degrees Celsius in the affected area.

images.alt_text: National Australia Bank CEO Ross McEwan said on Thursday that inflation was easing in Australia and interest rates appear to have peaked.
Australia's annual pay growth picked up to 4.2 per cent, from 4.1 per cent, the highest since early 2009 and just above market expectations of 4.1 per cent.

site_title: Dubai property frenzy sees buyers queue for million-dollar homes
summary: Dubai's luxury property market is experiencing a surge in demand, with buyers queuing overnight for million-dollar homes. Nakheel's Bay Villas development sold out its first two phases within hours, with prices starting at $1.2 million and reaching $4 million. The project, which features over 500 homes, is the latest sign of the city's hot property market, which has seen a significant increase in demand over the past couple of years. The sustained strength reflects a turnaround for Nakheel, which has consolidated operations and cut costs after a property crash in 2009.

site_title: Nestle misses full-year organic sales estimates as price hikes deter shoppers
summary: Nestle reported full-year organic sales growth of 7.2% despite missing expectations, due to price hikes deterring shoppers. The company's net profit rose 20% to $12.76 billion. Nestle expects 4% organic sales growth and a moderate increase in underlying trading operating profit margin in 2024, down from a 17.3% margin in 2023.

images.alt_text: The Supreme Court order issued on Thursday (Oct 19) says that lower tax rates in new treaties don’t “automatically” apply to treaties with these countries that contain clauses on parity – also known as the “most favoured nation” clause –unless separately notified by the Indian government.
Nestle confirmed its full-year outlook of organic sales growth between 7 per cent and 8 per cent and underlying trading operating profit margin between 17 per cent and 17.5 per cent.

site_title: Singapore fresh university grads get higher salaries, though fewer find full or part-time work: survey
summary: Singapore's fresh university graduates experienced higher median gross salaries of S$4,313 in 2023, up from S$4,200 in 2022. However, fewer graduates secured full-time, part-time, and freelance jobs, with 84.1% in the labor force finding employment compared to 87.5% in 2022.

images.alt_text: epa10988853 Laborers work on a construction site in Singapore, 22 November 2023. Singapore’s Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) announced on 22 November that the country’s GDP growth is projected to expand at around 1.0 percent in 2023 and 1.0 to 3.0 percent in 2024.  EPA-EFE/HOW HWEE YOUNG
In nominal terms, median monthly household income from work rose by 7.6 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Lloyds profit jumps despite UK outlook, motor finance provision
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported a 57% jump in pre-tax profit to £7.5 billion for 2023, driven by higher interest rates and reduced bad loan provisions. The bank's fortunes are linked to the UK economy, which entered recession in the second half of 2023. Lloyds announced a final dividend and share buyback, but set aside £308 million for potential unpaid loans, down from £1.5 billion the prior year. The bank's performance guidance for 2024 is muted, with a forecasted net interest margin of 2.9% and returns of 13% for the year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A logo is pictured on a sign outside a branch of a Lloyds Bank in London on February 24, 2021. British bank Lloyds on October 25, 2023, posted surging net profit, boosted partly by rising interest rates and lower impairments. Profit after tax soared 51 percent to £3.8 billion ($4.6 billion) in the first nine months of 2023 from a year earlier, the lender said in a statement. (Photo by Tolga Akmen / AFP)

site_title: Asia: Markets open higher after US tech gains
summary: Asian markets opened higher on Thursday, driven by US tech giant Nvidia's beat expectations earnings report, which saw record-high revenue and a quarterly profit of $12.3 billion. Analysts say the bumper profits could drive up Asian markets, with Tokyo stocks moving towards a record high. Hong Kong stocks were down in early trade, while Seoul, Taipei, Bangkok, Manila, and Wellington were up.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.1 per cent higher at 38,612.24 on Wednesday.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 62 to 38.

site_title: Google to make Pixel smartphones in India by next quarter: Nikkei
summary: Google plans to start manufacturing its Pixel smartphones in India by the April to June quarter, as part of its goal to ship over 10 million Pixel phones this year. The move aims to diversify its supply chain away from China. The tech giant has told suppliers to prepare production lines for its high-end Pixel 8 Pro smartphones, although the report did not specify how many phones will be manufactured or if they will be sold in India or exported.

site_title: Wee family members ‘welcome’ as part of bank succession if they have passion, desire: UOB CEO
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong has stated that family members of the bank's controlling Wee family are "more than welcome" to be part of the bank's succession plans if they have a passion and interest in being part of the team. However, maintaining the bank's culture and values, set out by the late chairman emeritus Wee Cho Yaw, is crucial. The bank is already growing a team to take charge, with the CEO noting that his late father's legacy will live on in the principles of doing right by customers and valuing relationships for the long term.

site_title: Delivery Hero terminates talks on potential sale of foodpanda business in South-east Asia
summary: Delivery Hero has terminated talks on the potential sale of its foodpanda business in selected South-east Asian markets, including Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines, due to a lack of agreement on deal terms. The company aims to divest its loss-making business to reach profitability while maintaining growth, amid investor concerns over its cash position. The talks with Grab on foodpanda's sale had previously collapsed.

site_title: China’s Xpeng signs partnership with UAE’s Ali&Sons, eyes Italian market
summary: China's Xpeng signs partnership with UAE's Ali&Sons, aiming to expand into Italy and other Middle East and North African countries. The company will offer G6 and G9 SUV models in the UAE starting from the third quarter, while P7 sedans and G9 SUVs will be delivered in Jordan, Lebanon, and Egypt during the same period. This move is part of Xpeng's efforts to increase its global footprint and compete in the world's largest auto market, with plans for more hiring and artificial intelligence R&D investments.

site_title: China’s Lenovo posts Q3 revenue growth, beats analyst estimates
summary: Lenovo reported October to December revenue of $15.72 billion, a 3% increase from the same period last year, beating analyst estimates. The company's net income fell 23% to $337 million. Lenovo is focusing on expanding its non-PC businesses, including information technology services, which saw a 10% revenue increase. The company also highlighted its strategy to capture AI opportunities, with AI PC shipments expected to reach 167 million units by 2027, accounting for 60% of total shipments.

images.alt_text: Baidu sign is seen at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song
Lenovo’s surge was part of a broader rally among its peers amid signs that a post-pandemic industry slump may have finally ended, helped by cyclical demand for PC replacement and upgrades.

site_title: Malaysia to charge ex-PM Muhyiddin’s son-in-law with graft
summary: Malaysia's Anti-Corruption Commission has announced its intention to charge former Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's son-in-law, Muhammad Adlan Berhan, with graft once he returns to the country. Berhan has been wanted by authorities since August 2023 in relation to a probe into a project involving foreign workers. He faces multiple charges for criminal breach of trust, and the investigation has been completed. The commission's chief, Azam Baki, stated that they are ready to prosecute Berhan upon his return.

site_title: Profits at Britain's Rolls-Royce more than doubled in 2023
summary: Britain's Rolls-Royce reported a 145% increase in annual profit to £1.6 billion in 2023, beating analyst forecasts. The company forecasts a 6% rise in underlying operating profit for 2024, predicting a range of £1.7 billion to £2 billion. This exceeds the current consensus forecast of £1.7 billion. The company attributes the growth to increased aircraft engine sales, improvements in its power business, and ongoing defence orders.

site_title: German economic downturn deepens unexpectedly in February: PMI
summary: Germany's economic downturn deepened in February, with the HCOB German Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 46.1 from 47 in the previous month. This marks the eighth consecutive month of business activity contraction, with the manufacturing sector falling to 42.3 and the services sector rising to 48.2, still in contraction territory. The decline is attributed to chronic weakness in demand, despite falling input prices and shorter delivery times. The economist at Hamburg Commercial Bank stated that the German industry is feeling "bleak" and a recovery may take until the second quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Staff wear protective masks at the Volkswagen assembly line in Wolfsburg, Germany, April 27, 2020. Swen Pfoertner/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Eastspring Investments names new chief investment officer
summary: Eastspring Investments has appointed Vis Nayar as its new chief investment officer (CIO), effective June 3. Nayar joins from HSBC Asset Management, where he was global CIO for equities. He will report to Eastspring CEO Bill Maldonado and join the executive management committee. Nayar brings 25 years of experience to the role, having previously held positions including global CIO for Europe and the UK, and head of systematic equities. His appointment is expected to bolster Eastspring's capabilities and strengthen its investment offerings.

site_title: BOJ chief Ueda keeps upbeat view on inflation, wage outlook
summary: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda said Japan's economy is likely to experience a positive cycle, with higher job and wage growth leading to moderate rises in inflation. Ueda reiterated the BOJ's conviction that conditions for ending negative interest rates are falling into place. The BOJ is on track to end negative interest rates in coming months despite Japan's economy slipping into recession, with more than 80% of economists expecting a rate hike in April.

images.alt_text: With inflation exceeding the BOJ’s 2 per cent target for well over a year, many market players expect the BOJ to end its negative interest rate policy in the coming months.
Two consecutive quarters of contraction are typically considered the definition of a recession.
Kazuo Ueda has been summoned to parliament twice this year after appearing there for about 20 days last year.
The bank delivers its next policy decision on Mar 19.

site_title: Three Arrows’ liquidators to pay out interim dividend by Mar 31
summary: Three Arrows Capital's liquidators plan to distribute an interim dividend of unspecified value by March 31, 2024, to creditors who submit claims by March 14. The total claims from creditors stand at over $3 billion. The liquidation process began on June 27, 2022, after the Singapore High Court recognized the proceedings as a foreign main proceeding. An estimated $1.1 billion worth of assets belonging to the founders and their family members have been frozen.

site_title: GoPizza serves pizza with AI and robotics. But is it a flash in the pan?
summary: GoPizza, a South Korean-based pizza chain, was founded in 2016 as a single food truck by Jay Lim, who aimed to make pizza more accessible. Lim noticed that buying a pizza in Singapore often resulted in high costs and long waiting times. Now, GoPizza is the third-largest pizza chain in Singapore, driven by trends such as single-person households and a post-pandemic labor crunch. The company uses AI and robotics to serve pizzas, aiming to improve efficiency and customer experience.

images.alt_text: Delivery Hero, which owns foodpanda, has been trying to divest its loss-making South-east Asian business in a wider effort to reach profitability while maintaining growth.

site_title: More homeowners cash out as property prices peak
summary: Median profit for non-landed private homes in Singapore, held for 5 years or less, doubled to S$247,000 in 2023, from S$123,241 in 2019. Total deals for such homes nearly quadrupled to 2,507, and the proportion of such deals rose to 28.9% in 2023. This trend may continue, but could reverse slightly in 2025 as interest rates decrease and rents recover.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of private properties in Singapore.

site_title: Vietnam’s VietJet signs on for 20 Airbus A330neo widebodies
summary: VietJet Aviation has signed a memorandum of understanding to purchase 20 Airbus A330-900neo planes, bolstering its long-haul network. The deal comes as the airline looks to expand its operations, with 300 single-aisle aircraft on order. This is part of a handful of commercial agreements concluded in Singapore, including Thai Airways' order for 45 Boeing 787-9 jets and Royal Brunei's four A320-200s. The move adds to VietJet's existing fleet of 84 jets, including seven leased A330 planes.

images.alt_text: VietJet and 10 others, including Nguyen Thi Phuong Thao, are being sued in Singapore
Vietnam was the world’s fifth fastest-growing aviation market in 2022 when it lifted Covid-19 travel restrictions.

site_title: Bored Ape NFT developer returns as CEO of Yuga Labs
summary: Greg Solano, co-founder of Yuga Labs, has returned as CEO of the company, which created the popular Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC) NFT collection. Solano thanked former CEO Daniel Alegre and stated the company will continue developing its Otherside virtual game. BAYC is the all-time best-selling NFT collection on OpenSea, with $2.9 billion in sales volume. Solano's return comes after the company faced criticism and a lawsuit over a controversial token project and the 2022 crypto market crash.

site_title: Japan’s February factory activity extends declines as conditions worsen: PMI
summary: Japan's economy unexpectedly slipped into recession in the fourth quarter of last year, losing its title as the world's third-biggest economy to Germany. Factory activity extended declines, with the manufacturing PMI falling to 47.2 in February, below the 50 threshold for nine consecutive months. Service sector growth eased, and firms showed reduced optimism about future output. The economy's recession marks a significant downturn, following a brief improvement at the start of the year.

images.alt_text: The number of foreign visitors for business and leisure was 2.69 million last month, down slightly from 2.73 million in December.

On a year-on-year basis, core orders, a highly volatile data series regarded as a leading indicator of capital spending in the coming six to nine months, declined 0.7 per cent, versus a forecast for a 1.4 per cent drop.
Two consecutive quarters of contraction are typically considered the definition of a recession.

site_title: South Korea holds rates steady, investors eye timing of pivot
summary: The Bank of Korea held its key policy rate at 3.50% for a ninth straight meeting, as expected by analysts, amid signs of a slowing economy and easing inflation. Governor Rhee Chang Yong is expected to reinforce the stance, pushing back against premature rate cut bets. The central bank maintained its economic growth forecast at 2.1% and inflation at 2.6%, citing risks of acting too soon and potential resurgence in price pressures. Analysts anticipate a rate cut in the third quarter, but timing will depend on the Federal Reserve's decisions.

images.alt_text: Temporary won overdrafts for global investors will be  permitted to settle stock and bond trades, reducing the burden of potential settlement failure resulting from delayed foreign exchange procedures.

The National Pension Service (NPS), the world’s third-largest public pension fund, is in the process of selecting three domestic fund managers to outsource its investments and will finalise the decision by March
Doctor protesters hold placards reading "Stop populist medical policy", during a protest against the government's medical policy near the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 14, 2024.
For companies facing liquidity trouble this year due to high interest rates, banks will offer a temporary cut in interest rates, the commission says.

site_title: Thai PM to keep pressing for rate cut, seeks central bank chief meeting
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has urged the central bank to cut interest rates to 2.25%, citing the public's suffering and high household debt levels. The current rate of 2.50% is a 10-year high, and Thavisin believes there's space for easing. He plans to meet the central bank chief again to discuss the issue, despite the central bank's previous rejection of his call for an urgent rate cut. Thailand's household debt ratio stands at 90% of GDP, and Thavisin sees rate cuts as a solution to address the crisis.

images.alt_text: While investors see a strong case for lower rates, the clash between Srettha and BOT governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput is putting them on edge.

Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, governor of the Bank of Thailand, speaks at the HKMA-BIS High-Level Conference in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. The conference runs through Nov. 29. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg

site_title: Taiwan chip firms flock to Japan as China decoupling accelerates
summary: Taiwanese chip firms are increasingly investing in Japan as part of the global decoupling from China, with at least nine firms setting up or expanding operations in the country over the past two years. Companies like TSMC, Alchip Technologies, and eMemory Technology are establishing new facilities and hiring staff in Japan, driven by the country's supportive government policies and growing semiconductor market. The influx of Taiwanese investment is seen as a response to China's growing semiconductor capabilities and the US push to limit China's progress in the field.

images.alt_text: TSMC is a key producer of tiny microchips that have been the lifeblood of the global economy, powering everything from coffee machines to missiles.

FILE — The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) headquarters in Hsinchu, Taiwan on Oct. 18, 2022. These days it seems impossible to have a conversation about geopolitics or economics without coming back to T.S.M.C., which makes about 90 percent of the world’s most advanced chips, as Nicholas Kristof writes. (Lam Yik Fei/The New York Times)
The company has faced resistance to plans to bring in technicians from Taiwan for the construction project.

site_title: Japan’s Nikkei breaks bubble-era record
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 stock index reached a record high of 39,156.97, surpassing the 1989 record of 38,957.44. This marks the end of a 34-year period of stagnation, following a devastating asset bubble burst in the early 1990s. The index has grown 28% in 2023 and 17% so far this year, driven by the Bank of Japan's monetary policies and the cheap yen. Analysts attribute the rise to expectations of further price and salary increases, but warn of potential downward risks from tightening monetary policies and uncertainty about US interest rates.

images.alt_text: Japanese companies' strong earnings suggest the rally that’s pushed major share indexes toward record highs has more room to run.

A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023. The expansion of Israel’s ground operations in Gaza added more pressure to global markets as investors prepare for a busy week packed with major central bank decisions and a high-stakes announcement of US bond sales. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg
A signboard showing the closing numbers on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Jan 11. Japan's Nikkei has been receiving a gush of foreign inflows as investors flee China.

site_title: Microsoft will use Intel to manufacture home-grown processor
summary: Microsoft plans to use Intel's 18A manufacturing technology to produce a homegrown chip designed in-house. This marks a key win for Intel's turnaround effort under CEO Pat Gelsinger, aiming to compete in the foundry market. The partnership will help Microsoft secure a steady supply of advanced semiconductors for its data centre operations, particularly as demand for AI grows. Intel's foundry business is expected to be bolstered by the deal, which could also help the company secure subsidies from governments to defray costs.

images.alt_text: Pricey chips : The costs of doing business are too high for AI startups to survive on their own.
The growth environment for multi-game subscription services is expected to slow this year.
Apple is also exploring the use of AI to generate code for testing applications, an often tedious process.

site_title: Thai PM plans visa-free travel, concerts to boost tourism
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin plans to boost tourism with measures such as visa-free travel, concerts, and adjusted operating hours for entertainment venues. The goal is to attract global artists like Taylor Swift and stimulate the country's economy. Tourism is expected to grow significantly over the next four years, recovering from pandemic lows. The government aims for 34-35 million foreign visitors this year, up from 28 million last year.

images.alt_text: While investors see a strong case for lower rates, the clash between Srettha and BOT governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput is putting them on edge.

FILE PHOTO: The Bank of Thailand logo is pictured in Bangkok, Thailand, August 5, 2016. Picture taken August 5, 2016.  To match Interview THAILAND-ECONOMY/CENBANK    REUTERS/Chaiwat Subprasom/File Photo

Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, governor of the Bank of Thailand, speaks at the HKMA-BIS High-Level Conference in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. The conference runs through Nov. 29. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg

To some observers of Thailand’s convoluted politics, Thaksin’s parole after returning from self-imposed exile in August was the latest act in an elaborate effort to crush the hugely popular anti-establishment Move Forward party that finished first in last year’s election.
Thailand's GDP fell 0.6 per cent in the October to December quarter on a seasonally adjusted basis, the planning agency said on Monday, down from a revised 0.6 per cent rise in the third quarter.
Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto celebrates on stage as unofficial vote counts show that he is poised to become Indonesia's next president.

site_title: New Arm offering to speed creation of custom data centre chips
summary: Arm Holdings released new blueprints for creating data centre chips, aiming to cut development time to under a year. The technology is already used by Amazon, Microsoft, and Ampere Computing, and is expected to help Arm take market share away from Intel and AMD. The new "compute subsystem" offering ties together cores with other components, enabling faster design and iteration. This could benefit companies like Microsoft, which used the technology to design its "Cobalt" chip, and others looking to build their own platforms and iterate on them quickly.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Arm Ltd logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Impact of US Inflation Reduction Act on the global solar market
summary: The US Inflation Reduction Act has significantly boosted the US solar market, with over $270 billion invested in domestic clean energy projects, including 60 new solar manufacturing facilities. However, regulatory and supply issues continue to affect polysilicon prices, which have diverged globally, with non-China polysilicon trading at triple the price of its Chinese counterpart. This has hindered market growth, with Europe facing a precarious position due to low prices undermining local solar production. The US needs to quickly ramp up homegrown production to achieve supply chain independence and meet its solar potential, with the current administration under pressure to deliver a long-lasting impact on the global green tech industry.

images.alt_text: China is the global leader in the production and installation of solar power, although it’s facing growing challenges.
solar
China solar power sector hit by surge in polysilicon prices amid supply squeeze

site_title: Singapore shares fall on Thursday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index declining 2.02 points to 3,215.09. The decline followed overnight losses in global markets, which were driven by minutes from the Federal Reserve signaling slower interest rate cuts. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS slipping 0.2% and OCBC gaining 0.2%. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 62 to 38, with Dyna-Mac rising 1.9% and Seatrium gaining 1%.

images.alt_text: UOB's net profit for the fourth quarter rises 21.8 per cent on higher net fee income and other non-interest income.

site_title: Australia economy should avoid recession: NAB CEO
summary: National Australia Bank CEO Ross McEwan stated that inflation is easing in Australia and interest rates have peaked, indicating a positive outlook for the economy. He expressed confidence that the country can avoid recession and improve later this year. McEwan's comments come as he prepares to retire in April and be replaced by Andrew Irvine.

images.alt_text: Sydney Harbour Bridge, New South Wales, Australia.

site_title: HSBC cost conundrum intensifies investor bank scrutiny
summary: HSBC is facing growing scrutiny over its high costs, which are pinching profits despite rising revenues in the higher interest rate environment. Consultants and shareholders say the bank needs to quickly address its spending to alleviate pressure on executives. Recent results show lenders struggling with wage bills, regulatory costs, and accelerating investment plans. This intensifies concerns about how big banks manage their expenses, with HSBC's cost conundrum adding to the debate.

images.alt_text: Unfinished residential buildings developed by China's Evergrande Group on the outskirts of Shijiazhuang in China's Hebei province.
HSBC Holdings’ CEO Noel Quinn’s total pay nearly doubled to £10.6 million (S$18 million) in 2023, from £5.56m in 2022.
Monday’s order says it is allowing Expobank to acquire 100 per cent of the unit, owned by HSBC Europe.

Logos sit illuminated on the HSBC Holdings Plc headquarter skyscraper offices in the Canary Wharf business, financial and shopping district in London, U.K., on Tuesday, May 2, 2017. HSBC has appeased investors with $3.5 billion of share buybacks, but after five years of declining revenue analysts are looking for evidence the bank is stabilizing its top line when it reports earnings Thursday. Photographer: Luke MacGregor/Bloomberg

site_title: Gold edges higher on safe-haven demand, weaker US dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,026.9 per ounce amid safe-haven demand due to rising Middle East tensions and a weaker US dollar. The US dollar index fell 0.1%, making gold more affordable for overseas buyers. This came despite minutes of the US Federal Reserve meeting, which suggested no early interest rate cut. The weaker dollar and geopolitical tensions supported gold prices, while oil rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook and tariffs.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was flat at US$2,018.03 per ounce, as of 0341 GMT on Tuesday.

site_title: Maintaining liquidity a short-term hit to NIMs, but long-term benefit to fees, customer growth: UOB CEO
summary: UOB's net profit for the fourth quarter rose 21.8% to S$1.4 billion, driven by higher net fee income and other non-interest income. However, the bank's net interest margins (NIMs) declined to 2.02% due to rising costs in maintaining deposits and lack of loan growth. CEO Wee Ee Cheong noted that while NIMs took a short-term hit, liquidity can provide long-term benefits to fees and customer growth, outweighing the short-term impact.

images.alt_text: CMG20230824-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 /  大华银行 United Overseas Bank (UOB)  [Raffles Place]

site_title: Thai rate-cut case backed by investors amid government pressure
summary: Thailand's weak economy and deflationary streak have strengthened the case for a rate cut, with investors backing the move despite government pressure. The Bank of Thailand (BOT) held rates steady last month, but market expectations suggest a cut is likely at the next meeting in April. Economists and investors see a need for monetary easing to support the country's 3.3% GDP growth forecast this year, which trails recent years' growth rates. The central bank's reluctance to reduce rates is partly due to high household debt, but some warn that interference in monetary policy could undermine investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, governor of the Bank of Thailand, speaks at the HKMA-BIS High-Level Conference in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. The conference runs through Nov. 29. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg

Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks alongside Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Manet during a joint press conference at the Government House in Bangkok on February 7, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)
Thailand's GDP fell 0.6 per cent in the October to December quarter on a seasonally adjusted basis, the planning agency said on Monday, down from a revised 0.6 per cent rise in the third quarter.

site_title: India extends parboiled rice export tax to control prices
summary: India, the world's second-largest rice grower, extended a 20% export tax on parboiled rice to control domestic prices ahead of general elections. The tax, initially set to expire on March 31, will remain in place indefinitely. The move is expected to squeeze global supplies and boost international prices, affecting countries in West Africa and the Middle East reliant on India for rice. This decision aims to curb rising food prices, which account for half of India's consumer price basket, with food inflation at 8.3% in January.

site_title: Hot stock: iFast spikes to over 2-year high on Q4 profit surge
summary: iFast, a financial services company, reported a 917.1% surge in fourth quarter net profit to S$13.2 million, driven by initial contributions from its ePension division. The company's shares hit a record high, reaching S$8.35, their highest level in over two years. Total revenue rose 69.3% to S$82.2 million, with assets under administration increasing 13.8% to a record S$19.8 billion. The group expects its ePension division to be a key growth driver in 2024 and 2025.

images.alt_text: Lim Chung Chun, chairman and chief executive of iFast. The group expects to see "robust growth rates" in revenue and profitability in 2024.
iFast Corp chairman and chief executive Lim Chung Chun said that bond trading, which predominantly operates over-the-counter, has suffered from a lack of price transparency and trading efficiency.

While iFast chief executive Lim Chung Chun did not give a specific percentage of profits that the group will pay out as dividends to shareholders for the next year or two, he said that the group is looking at distributing one-third to half of its net profits in 2024 as dividends.
Earnings per share for Q3 stood at 2.88 Singapore cents per share, compared with 0.71 Singapore cents per share in the year-ago period.

“At the end of the day, we are part of a social enterprise group, and it remains vital that we continue to steward resources wisely to better serve the broader interest of the Singapore community,” said Chuin Ting Weber, chief executive and chief investment officer of MoneyOwl.

site_title: Atome CEO steps down, to join GoTo Financial
summary: Atome CEO David Chen has stepped down to join GoTo Financial, the fintech arm of Indonesia's GoTo Group, as head of consumer lending. Chen will remain as co-founder of Advance Intelligence Group, Atome's parent firm. This departure adds to a recent string of management shakeups in South-east Asia's startup scene. Chen's departure from Atome follows exits from other companies including Carousell and Modalku this year.

images.alt_text: Grab and GoTo are reportedly discussing a range of scenarios under which both companies could merge.
GoTo says full-year loss on that basis is smaller than 3.8 trillion rupiah (S$323 million), or narrower than its previous forecast.

site_title: More multinationals are picking Singapore over Hong Kong for Asian headquarters
summary: Singapore has solidified its position as the preferred destination for Asian headquarters, surpassing Hong Kong with 4,200 multinational firms in 2023. The city-state's independence, talent pool, diversified economy, and tax incentives have made it an attractive choice for global and Chinese companies seeking to hedge geopolitical risks. Even Hong Kong's lower corporate tax rate may be outdone by Singapore's targeted incentives, with companies like FedEx, Microsoft, and General Motors setting up regional hubs. Singapore is expected to attract even more global business than Hong Kong over the next five years.

images.alt_text: The China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park, established in 1994, remains an attractive launchpad for Singapore businesses looking to enter China due to its policy transparency.
Indonesia is the largest source of tourists to Singapore in January, followed by China, Australia, Malaysia and India.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit posts 27.9% drop in H2 DPU to US$0.0214
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported a 27.9% drop in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0214, due to higher interest expenses. Despite a 1.7% increase in net property income to US$24.8 million, the Reit's net income available for distribution dropped 18.2% to US$13.8 million. The Reit retained US$1.3 million for capital reserves and elected to pay management fees in cash to preserve unitholder value. The adjusted FY2023 DPU would have been US$0.0554, 5.8% lower than FY2022.

images.alt_text: Upland Square, acquired by the Reit in July 2022.
Gross revenue for the period under review was up 13.3 per cent to US$36 million, due in part to contributions from Upland Square (pictured).
Dasin Retail Trust's Ocean Metro Mall. The Reit is one of the top performers for the month of May, posting a total return of 11.6 per cent.

site_title: Europe: HSBC, healthcare stocks drag shares lower; Fed minutes, Nvidia results eyed
summary: European stocks declined 0.2% on Wednesday, led by a 8.4% drop in HSBC shares due to a US$3 billion charge on its Chinese bank stake. Healthcare stocks fell 0.8% after a 10-month high, while mining shares lost 0.8% following Glencore's bleak earnings report. Investors now focus on the US Federal Reserve's last meeting minutes and Nvidia's results, which are expected to provide clues on the central bank's rate outlook.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.1 per cent higher at 38,612.24 on Wednesday.

site_title: PropertyBT: Property equities versus physical property (Ep 28)
summary: Morgan Stanley's Wilson Ng discusses the pros and cons of buying physical property versus property-related listed equities, including real estate investment trusts (REITs). He highlights the importance of understanding interest rate movements, which can impact investments. Ng suggests that investors consider REITs as a viable option, but cautions that interest rate fluctuations can affect the sector. The conversation aims to help listeners navigate the Singapore property market.

site_title: Oil rises 1% on signs of tightening supplies
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Wednesday as geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and signs of near-term supply tightness supported market growth. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 87 cents to $77.91 a barrel, while Brent crude rose 69 cents to $83.03 a barrel. Analysts attribute the increase to backwardation, a market structure indicating a tightly supplied market, and US refineries returning from maintenance, which could spur crude usage.

images.alt_text: Globally popular Ceylon Tea is Sri Lanka’s highest foreign exchange-earning crop, brewing US$1.25 billion for the cash-strapped country last year, according to government data.
Brent futures settled US$1.22, or 1.5 per cent, lower to US$82.34 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Mercedes unveils three billion euros buyback as cash flow swells
summary: Mercedes-Benz announced a €3 billion (S$4.4 billion) share buyback program, extending its efforts to reward shareholders amid strong cash flow. The German luxury car maker's decision follows a similar trend by peers such as General Motors and Ford, which returned a combined $22.7 billion to shareholders last year. The move is seen as a response to pent-up demand after years of supply-chain disruptions, but sales are expected to normalize this year as higher living and borrowing costs affect the automotive industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Mercedes-Benz logo is seen at the 43rd Bangkok International Motor Show, in Bangkok, Thailand, March 22, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: UOB Q4 profit rises 21.8% to S$1.4 billion; proposes S$0.85 per share final dividend
summary: UOB's net profit for Q4 2023 rose 21.8% to S$1.4 billion, driven by higher net fee income and other non-interest income. The bank missed a consensus forecast of S$1.5 billion, but core net profit would have been in line. UOB proposed a final dividend of S$0.85 per share, with a full-year dividend of S$1.70 per share. The bank's net interest margin dropped 20 basis points to 2.02%, mainly due to loan margin compression amid competition for high-quality credit.

images.alt_text: Analysts say the trio of local banks are likely to continue to post attractive dividend yields in Q4, which should provide support for their share prices.
One reason the local banks are lagging the STI is central banks are expected to cut interest rates as growth and inflation ease
Sun Xiao, secretary general of CCOIC, an affiliated body of CCPIT, highlights hat Asean remains an attractive destination for Chinese companies. PHOTO: UOB

site_title: ARA H-Trust’s H2 DPS rises 18.6% to US$0.01929
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust's half-year distribution per stapled security (DPS) rose 18.6% to US$0.01929, driven by revenue growth of 2% to US$89.5 million and a 26.4% increase in net property income (NPI) to US$25.7 million. The trust's RevPAR rose to US$96 from US$91, contributing to an 18.9% increase in distributable income. Despite a decline in net asset value per stapled security to US$0.74, the trust's overall portfolio value grew 0.5% to US$751.4 million.

images.alt_text: The 127-room hotel commenced operations in 1998.  It was last renovated in 2016 and is located in a neighbourhood with a mix of retail, commercial, industrial and hospitality properties.
ARA Hospitality US Trust's gross operating profit for the nine-month period is up 8.6 per cent to US$48.7 million.
ARA Hospitality US Trust is refinancing US$270.8 million of its debt facilities at IPO.
Lee Jin Yong, CEO of the manager of ARA US Hospitality Trust. The stapled group reports on Tuesday a 5.2% increase in H1 DPS.
ARA US Hospitality Trust's managers noted that the hotel is located in a market with "declining economic conditions" after the pandemic.

site_title: Head of Boeing‘s 737 MAX programme leaves after mid-air incident
summary: Boeing has replaced the head of its 737 MAX programme, Ed Clark, after a mid-air incident involving an Alaska Airlines MAX 9, where a door panel detached due to missing bolts. Clark's departure comes as Boeing faces its latest crisis, with production curbed by regulators and scrutiny from lawmakers and customers. New management changes, including a senior vice-president for quality and safety, aim to bolster quality efforts. Boeing's board approved the changes, which include Katie Ringgold as vice-president and general manager of the 737 programme.

images.alt_text: Air New Zealand is facing intense competition on its international routes, particularly from North America.
The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

A China Comac C919 aircraft during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore, Feb 18, 2024. Beijing wants to challenge the decades-long dominance of top plane-makers Airbus and Boeing while reducing its reliance on foreign technology.
FILE PHOTO: An employee walks past a fuselage section under construction at Boeing Co.'s 787 Dreamliner campus in North Charleston, South Carolina, U.S., May 30, 2023. Gavin McIntyre/File Photo
Boeing has been scrambling to explain and strengthen its safety procedures after a door plug on a new MAX 9 had become detached during a flight on Jan 5.
The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

FAA is “aggressively expanding oversight of new aircraft with increased floor presence at all Boeing facilities... We will follow the data and take appropriate and necessary action,” says FAA administrator Mike Whitaker.
The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)
The defect follows a string of manufacturing lapses at Boeing, including a near-catastrophic panel blowout on an Alaska Airlines 737 Max last month.
“We will not rush the system, and we will take our time to do it right,” says Dave Calhoun in a letter to employees.

site_title: Dealmaking booms in Japan as most of Asia suffers through bust
summary: Dealmaking is booming in Japan as the country's economy emerges from decades of deflation, prompting a surge in bond trading and a race to hire traders and brokers. Management buyouts are on the rise, and the stock market is nearing an all-time high, giving companies more scope for acquisitions. The government and investors are pressuring companies to bolster growth, leading to a predicted significant increase in the number and volume of deals, according to Akira Kiyota, head of global mergers and acquisitions at Nomura.

images.alt_text: Businessmen walk in Tokyo's business district, Japan, March 23, 2016. To match JAPAN-COMPANIES/ECONOMY    REUTERS/Toru Hanai

site_title: Thai central bank ready to adjust rates if significant change to 'uncertain' economy
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, maintained its policy interest rate at 2.50% during its February 7 meeting, citing the need for financial stability to promote sustainable growth. The decision was made despite the uncertain economy and inflation outlook, with two members advocating for a quarter-point rate cut. The central bank is prepared to adjust rates if the economy and inflation change significantly. The next meeting is scheduled for April 10.

images.alt_text: Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, governor of the Bank of Thailand, speaks at the HKMA-BIS High-Level Conference in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. The conference runs through Nov. 29. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg

Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks alongside Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Manet during a joint press conference at the Government House in Bangkok on February 7, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Federal Reserve officials will dive into balance sheet debate at March FOMC
summary: Federal Reserve officials will discuss and debate the conclusion of the balance sheet reduction effort at their March 19-20 meeting, with policymakers eager to slow the drawdown of bond holdings. The Fed aims to manage the endgame of quantitative tightening (QT) to keep financial markets stable. Officials are considering a taper of the current cap of $95 billion in Treasury and mortgage bonds to buy time to decide when to stop the process altogether. A successful taper is crucial to avoid a repeat of the 2019 liquidity crisis, and officials are weighing the optimal pace to achieve this goal.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.1 per cent higher at 38,612.24 on Wednesday.
FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
With US employment expected to remain firm and household debt service burden near its lowest level since 1980, a meaningful retrenchment of US consumer activity should be avoidable.
Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic said he projected two easings given the likelihood price pressure would move more unevenly toward the Fed’s 2 per cent target.

site_title: US: Stocks dip ahead of Nvidia results, Fed minutes
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.1% to 38,612.24, while the S&P 500 gained 0.1% to 4,981.80. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.3% to 15,580.87, weighed down by Nvidia's 3% drop after outsized expectations for artificial intelligence earnings. The Federal Reserve minutes also signaled slower interest rate cuts ahead, with most officials expressing concern about moving too early.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 80.14 points, or 0.21 per cent, at the open to 38,483.66.

site_title: Nvidia gives upbeat forecast as AI reaches ‘tipping point’
summary: Nvidia predicted a massive sales gain for the current quarter, forecasting revenue of around $24 billion, exceeding analyst expectations. The company's AI technology has reached a "tipping point," with demand surging worldwide across companies, industries, and nations. Nvidia's shares jumped 6% in extended trading, bringing its year-to-date gain to 36%. The company's market capitalization has increased by over $400 billion, making it one of the world's most valuable companies, with investors betting on its continued dominance in the AI computing boom.

images.alt_text: Some 66 per cent of the survey’s respondents say their companies would boost AI investment in 2024, up from 47 per cent in the survey done a year earlier.
Nvidia will release its quarterly earnings results on Feb 21.
FILE PHOTO: NVIDIA logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Mizuho in a client note raised its price target for Nvidia’s stock to US$825 from US$625 ahead of the Santa Clara, California, company’s quarterly results due on Feb 21.

site_title: Cisco to sell US$13.5 billion of bonds to fund Splunk deal
summary: Cisco Systems plans to sell $13.5 billion of bonds to partly finance its $28 billion acquisition of Splunk, a deal agreed in September. The bonds, offered in seven parts, are expected to yield 0.90 percentage point above Treasuries, with proceeds used for general corporate purposes, including the Splunk deal. Bank of America, Barclays, Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan Chase & Co, and Wells Fargo & Co are managing the bond sale.

images.alt_text: Cisco will incur a charge of US$800 million on the layoffs before tax consisting of severance and other costs.
Cisco has in recent years grappled with supply chain issues and a post-pandemic slowdown in demand, which has hastened its push into software offerings such as cybersecurity.
Cisco’s report shows that slowing orders for networking hardware are taking their toll on growth.

site_title: Qantas first-half profit drops, announces new A$400 million stock buyback
summary: Qantas reported a 12.8% drop in first-half profit to A$1.25 billion, missing a consensus estimate. The decline was due to normalizing fares and capacity, with lower revenue per available seat kilometre impacting the bottom line by around A$600 million. Despite this, the airline announced an additional A$400 million stock buyback, citing capital requirements. Qantas predicted its net debt to be at or below the middle of its target range by the end of fiscal 2024.

images.alt_text: John Mullen's appointment comes after Qantas' reputation was shredded by claims it sold tickets for thousands of flights it had already cancelled, leading to the early departure of former chief executive officer Alan Joyce.
The findings inflict further damage to the Qantas brand after a string of reputational crises.

While Mitsuko Tottori’s nomination is a sign of change in Japan Inc, it also reflects JAL’s sweeping organisational shift after a turnaround by industrialist Kazuo Inamori following its 2010 bankruptcy.
Cathay Pacific has 48 per cent fewer captains and first officers than before the pandemic.
Australia’s competition regulator is seeking a record fine of more than A$250 million after suing Qantas for allegedly selling seats on thousands of cancelled flights last year.
Recently, Qantas also scrapped its A$611 million plan to buy out charter flight operator Alliance Aviation Services, after the ACCC blocked the deal.
MYAirline is the second budget carrier in Malaysia which commenced operation in Dec 2022.

site_title: Garmin forecasts strong 2024 revenue, beats quarterly estimates
summary: Garmin beat fourth-quarter earnings expectations and forecast full-year revenue above estimates, driven by strong demand in its auto and fitness businesses. The company expects 2024 revenue of $5.75 billion, a 54% rise compared to the previous year, and saw a 22% increase in its fitness segment. New product launches and collaborations with popular brands have contributed to the growth. Garmin's diversified offerings have also provided a cushion in an uncertain economy.

images.alt_text: Among device makers, Finland’s Oura Health Oy has a ring that’s worn 24/7 that’s claimed to be “like a sleep lab on your finger” and gives you a score out of 100.

site_title: Ratcliffe wants to build new stadium for Man United, bring back glory days
summary: British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe, co-owner of Manchester United, plans to build a new stadium to bring back the club's glory days. Ratcliffe's $1.25 billion deal includes investing $300 million in infrastructure and taking charge of soccer operations. He believes a new stadium would be a world-class facility capable of hosting major tournaments and would restore the club to its former status as a top European team. Ratcliffe aims to bring true change to the club's environment within two to three seasons, with the ultimate goal of surpassing rival Manchester City and Liverpool.

images.alt_text: Jim Ratcliffe, who grew up a United fan, told reporters recently that ownership in the club is the most exciting endeavour of his life.
UK business mogul Jim Ratcliffe struck an agreement in December to acquire, through his chemical conglomerate Ineos Group, a 25 per cent stake in Manchester United.
Sheffield United's Oli McBurnie (second from right, wearing #9) celebrates with his teammates after netting a penalty in the 103rd minute against West Ham4.
For the first time since 2017-18, Real are in pole position in Deloitte’s financial rankings with a reported record revenue of 831 million euros (S$1.2 billion).
