site_title: Rivian cuts 10% of salaried staff as output forecast misses
summary: Rivian Automotive cuts 10% of its salaried staff as part of an aggressive cost-cutting effort, following job reductions last year and in 2022. The company forecasts 57,000 vehicle production this year, below analysts' average estimate of 80,000 units, and expects an adjusted loss of $2.7 billion. The move reflects stagnant demand and economic turbulence, with the company citing "historically high interest rates" as a factor. The stock price has dropped 17% to $12.78.

images.alt_text: Rivian is due to start construction on the plant near Atlanta, Georgia early next year, having announced the site as its second factory at the end of 2021.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Wilmar, iFast, Vicom, United Hampshire US Reit
summary: Stocks in Singapore saw varying performances on Thursday, with UOB's net profit rising 21.8% due to higher net fee income and other non-interest income. Wilmar International's net profit fell 21.3% due to lower commodity prices and non-operating losses. iFast's net profit surged 917.1% on initial contributions from its ePension division. Meanwhile, Vicom's net profit rose 4.5% on higher revenue, and United Hampshire US Reit's distribution per unit fell 27.9% due to higher interest expenses.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers beat losers 312 to 283 after 2.24 billion securities worth S$1.47 billion change hands.

site_title: Are mass-market condo projects still compelling?
summary: Singapore's mass-market condo projects continue to attract buyers, despite rising prices. In 2022, 237,500 households lived in private condos, up 70% from 2012. The Outside Central Region (OCR) segment, where prices are more affordable, saw an average unit price of S$2,145 psf in 2023. PropNex predicts OCR prices will rise at a slower pace of 3-5% in 2024, influenced by factors such as new launch prices and resale market conditions. The successful launch of J’den, which achieved a new benchmark average price of over S$2,400 psf, is unlikely to spark an upward spiral in OCR prices due to differences in attributes.

images.alt_text:
Implementing cooling measures to moderate market overheating can yield immediate unwelcome impacts, yet inaction poses a risk to long-term market stability.
Navigating this challenge demands a nuanced approach.

The private residential non-landed rental market may have wobbled in the second half of 2023, but rents are forecast to move higher in the next few years, on the back of lower supply. Tenant demand may pick up on the back of better economic growth in 2024.

site_title: World Bank warns emerging economies need to grow 'much faster' to repay debt
summary: The World Bank warns emerging economies must grow "much faster" to repay debt due to high borrowing costs, which have dramatically changed the need for developing nations to boost sluggish economic growth. International bond sales from emerging markets reached a record $47 billion in January, with some riskier issuers tapping markets at higher rates. The World Bank's deputy chief economist, Ayhan Kose, says that faster growth is needed to make borrowing manageable, and that some emerging economies may face restructuring debt if growth remains low.

images.alt_text: In the United States, proof that inflation remains sticky and the labour market sound has convinced traders to embrace the Federal Reserve’s push-back against market bets on near-term easing.

site_title: Air New Zealand eyes fare hikes as costs surge, profit slumps
summary: Air New Zealand may raise ticket prices due to rising costs, as the airline reported a 38% slump in interim earnings. Inflation has driven up non-fuel operating costs, impacting the cost of providing air services. The airline is facing intense competition on international routes, particularly from North America. Pratt & Whitney engine maintenance issues and delayed Boeing 787 deliveries are also affecting operations. Air New Zealand forecasts a worsening revenue and cost environment, potentially leading to a decline in full-year pretax earnings.

images.alt_text: Air New Zealand has come under pressure as more airlines return to the Pacific long haul routes into the US as global travel revives after the Covid pandemic.

site_title: Google brings Gemini AI models to enterprise tools
summary: Google is introducing Gemini AI models to its enterprise tools, rebranding its "Duet AI in Workspace" as "Gemini for Google Workspace". The service will be available at a lower price point, starting at $20 per user per month, and will offer capabilities such as writing in Google Docs and generating custom visuals in Google Slides. This move aims to compete with Microsoft-backed OpenAI, which offers similar services starting at $25 per user per month. Gemini will also be accessible to individual users through a subscription to Google One AI Premium.

images.alt_text: Pricey chips : The costs of doing business are too high for AI startups to survive on their own.
Google will introduce a new open-source resource powered by AI that utilises file type identification to help detect malware, the company says.

At the launch event at Google Singapore's office on Monday (Jan 29) were (from left):  Google Singapore managing director Ben King, country director for Singapore at Google Cloud Serene Sia, managing director (South-east Asia) at Google Cloud Mark Micallef, Minister for Communications and Information  Josephine Teo,  Permanent Secretary at Smart Nation Joseph Leong, Permanent Secretary at the Ministry of Trade and Industry Gabriel Lim, and Jacqueline Poh, managing director at the Singapore Economic Development Board.
FILE PHOTO: 3D printed clouds and figurines are seen in front of the Google Cloud service logo in this illustration taken February 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence rises to -15.5 in February
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence rose to -15.5 in February, a 0.6-point improvement from January, according to the European Commission. This marks the first increase in consumer morale since November 2022. Economists had expected a rise to -15.6. The European Union as a whole saw a 0.4-point increase to -15.8 in consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A customer shops at a Carrefour supermarket in Montesson near Paris, France, September 13, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo

site_title: Significant policy shifts in Budget 2024, more steps on road ahead: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced the significant policy shifts in Budget 2024, aiming to equip workers for life through a substantial enhancement of SkillsFuture, and providing better support for families, seniors, and businesses. Key measures include a corporate income tax rebate for businesses, increased healthcare and retirement support for seniors, and a new voucher scheme for young couples to rent a flat on the open market. The budget also aims to encourage a culture of giving and supports workers and companies through training and education initiatives.

images.alt_text: epa10988853 Laborers work on a construction site in Singapore, 22 November 2023. Singapore’s Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) announced on 22 November that the country’s GDP growth is projected to expand at around 1.0 percent in 2023 and 1.0 to 3.0 percent in 2024.  EPA-EFE/HOW HWEE YOUNG

To realise the shared vision of an inclusive society and to protect Singapore’s reputation as a great place to do business, the onus falls on businesses and individuals to take responsibility for their own successes and failures.
Property annual value bands for owner-occupied residential properties will be revised upwards from Jan 1, 2025.
The move to shift members' savings in the CPF Special Account to the Ordinary Account when they turn 55, and to close the SA has sparked unhappiness.
Singaporeans aged 40 and above who enrol in a full-time course will get a monthly training allowance of up to 50 per cent of their last drawn pay, capped at S$3,000.
Some 13 STI constituents across six sectors are expected to benefit from Budget, says Maybank Securities and RHB.
RIC adjustments to include other methods to assess the quantum awarded, in addition to expenditure incurred, could help to secure high-value activities in Singapore, say observers.
Retirees who are owner-occupiers of private homes should be mindful that costs linked to home ownership such as property tax may rise over the long term.
The slew of ostensibly social measures should not negate the central importance of a vibrant, thriving, and sustainable economy to a shared future, says SMU's Eugene Tan.

DPM Wong presented a milestone budget that helps to address everything about the numerous challenges ahead brought about by cost-of-living increases, threats to jobs, wars and global uncertainty, international tax challenges and climate change, among others.

site_title: Bungalow market down but not out
summary: Sales of Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Area houses in Singapore plummeted to a historic low in 2023, with only 1,300 to 1,800 transactions recorded annually. Despite this, buyers remain patient, waiting for sellers to drop prices. In March 2023, a 15,515 sq ft GCB at Binjai Park was sold for S$28.3 million, with plans to demolish the existing house for a new build. The scarcity of landed homes in land-starved Singapore contributes to their value, with only 5% of residents owning such properties.

images.alt_text:
sirgcb - A GCB at Binjai Park with a land area of 15,515 sq ft was sold for S$28.3 million in March 2023. The buyer planned to demolish the existing house to build a new one.

site_title: UK Conservatives lose collective self-confidence as election approaches
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faces a challenging election ahead, with the Labour Party leading in opinion polls. Some Conservatives fear a worse outcome than Canada's 1993 federal election, where the ruling party lost over 150 seats. The UK's first-past-the-post electoral system can lead to unusual outcomes, and tactical voting may impact the election result. Sunak must defy political gravity and history to win a fifth term for the Conservatives, a daunting task given the current political landscape.

images.alt_text: Recent polls have repeatedly shown the Conservatives trailing Labour. A YouGov poll in November put Rishi Sunak’s (centre) party behind by 19 percentage points

Former British Prime Minister Liz Truss spent just 49 days in office before she was ousted by her own party in October 2022 after her disastrous mini-budget spooked financial markets and sank the pound.

epa10922016 British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak departs his official residence, 10 Downing Street, to make a statement on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in the Houses of Parliament in London, Britain, 16 October 2023.  EPA-EFE/TOLGA AKMEN

site_title: LNG’s role as transition energy in Singapore to blossom despite zeal for renewables
summary: Singapore is poised to further develop its liquefied natural gas (LNG) hub in the region, despite growing enthusiasm for renewable energy. The city-state aims to meet its natural gas demand entirely by LNG, with a second LNG terminal expected to be operational in six years. LNG is seen as a transition fuel, with global demand estimated to rise by over 50% by 2040, driven by coal-to-gas switching in China and economic growth in South Asia and Southeast Asia. Singapore's government has announced plans to invest in the energy transition, including a Future Energy Fund with an initial S$5 billion injection.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
MET’s Singapore subsidiary will be 10 per cent owned by Singapore-based Keppel.
The current SLNG terminal operates two jetties and four LNG storage tanks of a total 800,000 cubic metres capacity.
Plans are underway to transform Jurong Island - the pulse of Singapore's energy and chemicals sector - into a space that operates sustainably and exports sustainable products globally

site_title: Sri Lanka repays US$20 million Iranian oil debt with tea
summary: Sri Lanka has repaid $20 million of its $251 million oil debt to Iran through a barter deal, exporting tea worth that amount. The deal allows sanctions-hit Iran to avoid using scarce hard currency for tea imports and allows Sri Lanka to pay with tea due to foreign currency shortages. The agreement, made in December 2021, was delayed by Sri Lanka's economic crisis, but the prime minister's office stated that the deal did not break US sanctions on Iran.

images.alt_text: A general view of the Colombo main port is seen beyond the main wholesale market, on the day President Ranil Wickremesinghe, who is also the island nation's finance minister, presents the annual budget in Colombo, Sri Lanka November 12, 2023.Picture taken November 12, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte

site_title: Private debt’s robust growth warrants caution
summary: Private debt's robust fundraising in 2021 and 2022, with estimated $152 billion and potentially over $215 billion raised in 2023, warrants caution due to elevated credit risks. Despite the US regional banking crisis, investors are drawn to the asset class' potential for higher returns and low correlations with traditional assets. However, recent losses from Julius Baer's loans to real estate group Signa highlight the need for investors to carefully assess credit quality and asset values, with default rates expected to rise to 5% and funding costs for smaller borrowers approaching 10%.

images.alt_text: Julius Baer has been in the cross-hairs since it emerged in November that the firm had run up a US$700 million exposure to Rene Benko’s Signa companies, with shares losing some 15 per cent.
A probe launched since the initial revelation in November showed that risk managers didn’t have a handle on the complex nature of the Benko loans, people familiar with the matter said.
The insolvency of European luxury property group Signa could hurt more players across the financial industry, but demand for private debt is said to remain high.

site_title: Former YuuZoo CEO charged; Interpol Red Notice issued for ex-chairman Zilliacus
summary: Former YuuZoo CEO James Matthew Somasundram was charged on Wednesday over alleged misleading financial reports released by the company between 2015 and 2016. Interpol has issued a Red Notice for ex-chairman Thomas Zilliacus, who is currently out of Singapore and has refused to return. Somasundram faces four charges under the Securities and Futures Act, while Zilliacus and three other individuals allegedly involved in the matter also have warrants of arrest issued against them.

site_title: Apple rolls out iMessage upgrade to withstand decryption by quantum computers
summary: Apple has rolled out an upgrade to its iMessage platform, introducing a new protocol called PQ3, to defend against future decryption by quantum computers. The upgrade rebuilds the iMessage cryptographic protocol from the ground up, providing state-of-the-art encryption. The move comes as US tech firms prepare for "Q-Day," a potential breakthrough in quantum computing that could make current methods obsolete. Apple's upgrade aims to close the window of opportunity for quantum computers to weaken protections, with the new protocol set to fully replace the existing one within all supported conversations this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Apple logo is seen hanging at the entrance to the Apple store on 5th Avenue in Manhattan, New York, U.S., October 16, 2019. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo
Sales of iPhones hit US$69.70 billion, growing 6 per cent to beat analyst expectations of US$67.82 billion.

site_title: Taylor Swift named IFPI 2023 global recording artist of the year
summary: Taylor Swift won the IFPI 2023 global recording artist of the year award for the fourth time, beating out K-Pop acts SEVENTEEN and Stray Kids. The award is based on worldwide sales of streaming, downloads, and physical music formats, and covers her entire body of work. Swift, 34, has previously won the award in 2014, 2019, and 2023. This marks her second consecutive year taking the top spot, according to IFPI Director Lewis Morrison.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift will hold six shows at the National Stadium from Mar 2 to Mar 9.

site_title: ChatGPT cranks out gibberish for hours
summary: ChatGPT, a generative artificial intelligence tool, experienced a 16-hour malfunction where it generated nonsensical responses, including nonexistent words and incomplete sentences. The issue was reported by developers using the tool in a discussion forum on the OpenAI website. OpenAI has stated that they are investigating the cause of the problem, but did not provide further explanation. The tool eventually returned to normal functioning after the malfunction.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ChatGPT logo and AI Artificial Intelligence words are seen in this illustration taken, May 4, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Sinopharm offers to take China-TCM private in nearly US$3 billion deal
summary: A consortium led by state-owned pharma giant Sinopharm has revived a take-private bid for Hong-Kong-listed China Traditional Chinese Medicine Holdings, valuing it at US$2.96 billion. Sinopharm already holds a 32.46% stake in China-TCM and has offered HK$4.6 (S$0.79) per share in cash to buyout the drugmaker. The deal, if successful, would be one of the largest privatization deals for a Hong-Kong listed firm since 2020.

images.alt_text: China drugmaker plunges after Wanda scion doubts Covid TCM efficacy

site_title: China drafts law to protect private firms to boost confidence
summary: China is drafting a law to protect private firms, aiming to boost confidence and innovation in the private sector economy. The law focuses on protecting property rights, entrepreneur interests, and managing missed payments for small- and medium-sized enterprises. The move is part of efforts to improve productivity and address deflationary pressures, sluggish confidence, and a persistent real estate slump. The law is expected to keep policy implementation stable and consistent, treating both state-owned and private companies equally.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower ahead of Nvidia's results, Fed minutes
summary: US stocks opened lower on February 21, 2024, ahead of Nvidia's earnings report and the release of Federal Reserve policy minutes. The Dow Jones fell 80.14 points, or 0.21%, to 38,483.66, while the S&P 500 dropped 12.48 points, or 0.25%, to 4,963.03. The Nasdaq Composite fell 98.66 points, or 0.63%, to 15,532.12. Investors await Nvidia's earnings report, which could impact the AI-led rally, and consider the implications of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting.

site_title: Prime US Reit H2 DPU falls over 90% to US$0.0025; announces 1-for-10 bonus issue
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 90% year-over-year decline in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0025, citing a focus on capital preservation to deleverage the business. The manager also announced a 1-for-10 bonus issue to unitholders. Despite a broadly strengthened demand for US office space in Q4 2023, the Reit's portfolio valuation fell 8.7% year-over-year to US$1.4 billion, and its interest coverage ratio decreased to 3.1 times in FY2023.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit's Centerpointe property. The three US office Reits listed in Singapore – Manulife US Reit, Prime US Reit and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit – suffered steep declines through most of 2023, but rallied in November and December.
Kore makes a net loss of US$91.8 million for H2 FY2023.
Kore will suspend its distributions from H2 2023 until H2 2025

site_title: Dollar steadies ahead of Fed minutes, sterling shrugs off record surplus
summary: The US dollar index steadied ahead of the Federal Reserve's minutes, while sterling remained stable despite a record surplus in Britain's January budget. Markets expect the Fed to cut interest rates in June, with 95 basis points of easing predicted this year. The minutes will provide clarity on the Fed's rate outlook, with hawkish views potentially pushing back rate cut expectations and lifting the dollar. Sterling, however, remains unaffected by the surplus, with economists expecting the Bank of England to keep rates unchanged.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which tracks the performance of the US currency against six others, eased 0.15 per cent to 104.13.

site_title: Suzhou Industrial Park expands Singapore incubator to support new China entrants
summary: The China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park's International Business Cooperation Centre (IBCC) has expanded its premises, offering enhanced support services to new Chinese entrants and Singapore-based companies venturing into China. The centre, established in 2021, has attracted 112 Chinese companies, including Qichacha, Basecare Medical, and JoyMed Technology, which benefit from policy transparency and trade agreements. The expansion aims to facilitate cross-border investment and market access, solidifying Singapore's strategic importance as a gateway to China.

images.alt_text: (From left) CCPIT Chairman Ren Hongbin; Zong Changqing, Economic and Commercial Minister Counsellor, Embassy of the People’s Republic of China; Low Yen Ling, Minister of State for Trade and Industry; SBF Chairman Lim Ming Yan. SBF and CCPIT renew their commitment to the mutual facilitation of business activities.
Indonesia is the largest source of tourists to Singapore in January, followed by China, Australia, Malaysia and India.

Despite global uncertainties and China's challenging restructuring, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat believes that a global recession is unlikely in 2024, and the ASEAN economy will continue to grow. PHOTO: JASON QUAH, ST

site_title: iFast Q4 net profit surges 917% to S$13.2 million
summary: iFast Corporation's net profit for Q4 2023 surged 917.1% to S$13.2 million, driven by higher revenue and initial contributions from its ePension division. Total revenue rose 69.3% to S$82.2 million, with assets under administration (AUA) reaching a record S$19.8 billion. The company expects robust growth rates in 2024, with non-banking operations expected to break even by the fourth quarter. A final dividend of S$0.014 per share was proposed, unchanged from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim Chung Chun, chairman and chief executive of iFast.

site_title: US targets China’s top chipmaking plant after Huawei Mate 60 Pro: sources
summary: The US has suspended permission for Chinese chipmaker SMIC to receive US technology, targeting its most advanced factory after it produced a sophisticated chip for Huawei's Mate 60 Pro phone. The Commerce Department sent letters to US suppliers, including Entegris, suspending shipments of chipmaking materials and parts worth millions of dollars. This move follows pressure from Republican lawmakers to stem the flow of US technology to SMIC and degrade its ability to make advanced semiconductors. The suspension could potentially interrupt SMIC's production for 3-9 months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation (SMIC) is seen at China International Semiconductor Expo (IC China 2020) in Shanghai, China October 14, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song
Huawei arrived in France in 2003, and now runs six research centres and a global design centre in the country.
SMIC's net income reaches US$174.7 million in the three months ended in December, compared to the average analyst estimate of US$139.1 million.

A global race for AI functionality amid a Sino-US technological standoff has left Huawei second-placing its handsets just as the firm tops Chinese smartphone sales for the first time in more than three years.
The complaint follows infringement lawsuits filed by Huawei against Netgear in Germany and China.
The company expects 2023 revenue to exceed 700 billion yuan, amounting to 9 per cent year-on-year growth, according to an internal message last month.
The company spent more than US$13 million lobbying in the past ten years.
Huawei has since sunk billions into chip research and stockpiling in past years, while also building a domestic network of suppliers and manufacturing partners, in some cases with government backing.

site_title: China tightens grip on stocks with net sale ban at open, close
summary: China's securities watchdog, the CSRC, has banned major institutional investors from reducing equity holdings at the open and close of each trading day to prop up the nation's $8.6 trillion stock market. The ban, led by Chairman Wu Qing, aims to curb short selling and prevent market volatility. A task force has been created to monitor short selling and issue warnings to firms that profit from the practice. The move is China's most forceful attempt yet to stabilize its stock market, which has been impacted by a turf war and deflationary price wars.

images.alt_text: The fund's sell order on Monday morning led to rapid stock market declines, prompting the Shenzhen and Shanghai stock exchanges to impose trading restrictions on Lingjun until Feb 22.

PBOC says foreign entities owned 2.8 trillion yuan (S$523.3 billion) of onshore Chinese equities at the end of last year, down 13 per cent from 12 months earlier, and a drop of almost 30 per cent from the peak at the end of 2021.

The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) says it would treat all proposals seriously and implement feasible ones immediately, reiterating its intention to “resolutely maintain market stability and control market risks.”

Anticipation of more fulsome efforts to end the rout had been mounting for days, after Bloomberg News reported that regulators led by the CSRC planned to brief President Xi on the markets as soon as Tuesday.
Yi Huiman's removal comes as Chinese markets are on a knife edge as institutional and retail investors scramble to cut their losses.

site_title: Reddit plans to reserve shares for its big users in IPO, WSJ reports
summary: Reddit plans to reserve shares for 75,000 of its most prolific users when it goes public next month, offering them the opportunity to buy shares at the IPO price before trading begins. This privilege is typically reserved for big investors. The San Francisco-based company filed for its IPO in December 2021 and has been valued at around $10 billion. The IPO, set to take place in March, would be the first from a major social media company since Pinterest's debut in 2019. Details of the reserved shares' number and valuation remain unclear.

images.alt_text: Reddit’s listing is closely watched as a bellwether of an IPO market in the midst of a tentative rebound from a two-year dearth of first-time share sales.
Reddit is considering feedback from early meetings with potential investors in its IPO that it should consider a valuation of at least US$5 billion.
The valuations under consideration demonstrate the extent of tech’s retreat from the heady days of the private funding boom that peaked in 2021.

site_title: China proposes new ESG rules to keep up with Europe
summary: China has proposed new Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) disclosure rules for its largest companies, aiming to align with European requirements and attract foreign investment. Over 400 companies, including those in key stock indexes, will need to publish sustainability reports by 2026. The guidelines will standardize reporting, reduce greenwashing risks, and help drive investment into traditionally high-emitting sectors. China's ESG funds have pulled billions of dollars from China-domiciled ESG funds, but the new rules may bolster the nation's green credentials and attract foreign investors, who have been turning away due to regulatory risks and economic concerns.

images.alt_text: Emission allowance prices are expected to rise this year as tighter regulations help to limit a surplus.
Blades for wind turbines at a logistics depot in Tianjin. China leads the number of peer-reviewed publications in areas including solar and wind power.
Chinese cities have grappled with high air pollution readings in recent months despite authorities’ efforts to improve air quality in recent years.

site_title: A tale of two metals will determine the future of energy
summary: BHP Group, the world's largest copper miner, faces a significant challenge in addressing the looming supply deficit of the metals crucial for a decarbonized economy. Nickel and copper production must surge to meet growing demand, but the company's plans are insufficient. Chinese companies have flooded the market with nickel, driving prices down, while copper prices remain high, making it unprofitable for most mines to produce. BHP estimates $250 billion needs to be spent on growth by 2030 to meet demand, but its current spending is only $0.9 billion, falling short of the required investment to meet the supply deficit.

images.alt_text: The nickel sector is facing thousands of job cuts after a jump in Indonesian supply saw prices plunge 40 per cent in a year.
Base metals have gained this month on optimism that the US Federal Reserve will start easing monetary policy and soften a major headwind for commodity prices.

Materials such as lithium, used in EV batteries, can be found in raw state aross the world, but extracting and refining them can be costly. China dominates the entire value chain in many critical minerals.

site_title: Singapore’s local banks ring in the Year of the Dragon in style
summary: Singapore's local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, celebrated the Year of the Dragon with events, including a two-day Spring Festival at the Ritz-Carlton, Millenia Singapore hotel. DBS hosted over 600 corporate clients on February 14, featuring senior management and festivities. The celebrations marked the beginning of the Year of the Dragon, a significant cultural event in Singapore.

site_title: Preventive healthcare goes upscale
summary: Luxury health screening centres have emerged in cities, offering premium amenities such as plush furniture, soft lighting, and private pods. These high-end centres charge higher prices for advanced imaging and screening equipment, but some critics argue that they may lead to unnecessary testing. The trend reflects the growing demand for preventive healthcare among affluent individuals.

images.alt_text:
ckscreening22 - DA Orchard MedSuites' private pods

PHOTO: DA MEDSUITES

site_title: King Charles to appear on UK banknotes from June
summary: King Charles' portrait will appear on £5, £10, £20, and £50 polymer banknotes in the UK, entering circulation from June 5. The new notes will replace worn-out existing ones, with the goal of minimizing environmental and financial impact. This gradual rollout is in line with guidance from the Royal Household. The move marks Charles' second appearance on Bank of England banknotes, following his profile on coins introduced in late 2022.

site_title: Website creator Wix.com’s profit doubles, sees Studio product boosting 2024
summary: Wix.com, a website creator, reported a 100% increase in earnings per diluted share to $1.22 in its fourth-quarter earnings, beating analyst expectations. The company's Studio product is driving growth, with revenue forecasted to rise 11-13% in 2024. Wix added 189,000 net premium subscriptions, reaching 6.3 million, and saw a 14% revenue growth in the quarter. The company expects bookings to rise significantly in the second half of 2024 and further acceleration in 2025.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect Wix to earn 67 cents per share excluding one-time items on revenue of US$383 million.

site_title: Wilmar H2 net profit falls 21.3% on lower contributions from feed and industrial products
summary: Wilmar International's net profit for the half year ended December 2023 fell 21.3% to US$973.9 million, due to lower contributions from its feed and industrial products division and non-operating losses. Revenue declined 7.1% to US$34.6 billion, and earnings per share dropped 21.2%. The company expects tough operating conditions to continue into FY2024, with chairman Kuok Khoon Hong citing depressed tropical oils margins and challenging operating conditions in China.

images.alt_text: Wilmar believes its sugar merchandising, milling and refining business will also remain “good” till year end on higher sugar prices.
Wilmar’s chief executive Kuok Khoon Hong said that the company’s first half performance had been affected by a slowdown in most markets, except India, in the second quarter of the year.

site_title: Residential rents may bottom in H2 2024 before recovering on supply lag, better economic growth
summary: Singapore's residential rental market may have bottomed in H2 2024, with rents expected to recover in the following years due to lower supply and better economic growth. Despite a sharp spike in new supply in 2023, median gross rents declined in seven districts, while rents rose in Districts 25 (Kranji, Woodgrove) and 22 (Jurong). The government's temporary relaxation of occupancy caps and the introduction of long-stay serviced apartments may also support the market. Investors are advised to keep an eye on upcoming project launches, particularly in Woodlands.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in Singapore. Photographer: Lionel Ng/Bloomberg
January 2024 marks the sixth straight month of declines for condominium rental prices.

The higher proportion of foreigners buying in the CCR is a result of high-net-worth individuals and families from around the region that traditionally regard Singapore as a safe destination to set up investment homes for both capital preservation and appreciation.

Implementing cooling measures to moderate market overheating can yield immediate unwelcome impacts, yet inaction poses a risk to long-term market stability.
Navigating this challenge demands a nuanced approach.

site_title: Some businesses may pass on costs from local qualifying salary hike, but impact likely ‘limited’
summary: Singapore's local qualifying salary (LQS) for full-time workers will increase to S$1,600 from S$1,400, while part-time workers' hourly rate will rise to S$10.50 from S$9. Despite this hike, many businesses already pay local workers above the new minimum, and the impact is likely to be limited. Only sectors that hire foreign workers without progressive wage models may see higher manpower costs. Some smaller businesses may pass on these costs to consumers, but the overall effect is expected to be limited due to competition for labor and high levels of consumer awareness.

images.alt_text: Singapore is raising its local qualifying salary from S$1,400 to S$1,600 for full-time local employees with effect from July 2024.  PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI, ST

site_title: Rio Tinto profit drops 12% but iron ore giant returns more cash to investors
summary: Rio Tinto reported a 12% drop in annual underlying earnings to $11.8 billion, largely due to lower prices for aluminum and its minerals division. However, the company paid a higher-than-expected final dividend, citing easing inflation pressures. Rio Tinto expects iron ore production costs to rise in 2024 due to labor and parts inflation in Western Australia, but remains in a strong financial position.

images.alt_text: May iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange is on track to record its best week in five.

site_title: South Korea to let investors access won quotes from more banks
summary: South Korea will allow foreign investors to access won quotes from more banks, reducing settlement burdens due to delayed foreign exchange procedures. Temporary won overdrafts for global investors will be permitted to settle stock and bond trades. The move aims to lure inflows and improve market access, as the country makes efforts to get its stocks and bonds added to global developed market indexes. Regulations will be changed in the first quarter to reduce foreign exchange costs for global investors.

images.alt_text: The National Pension Service (NPS), the world’s third-largest public pension fund, is in the process of selecting three domestic fund managers to outsource its investments and will finalise the decision by March
For companies facing liquidity trouble this year due to high interest rates, banks will offer a temporary cut in interest rates, the commission says.

site_title: Malaysia gives Mahathir’s son time to show assets in graft probe
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency has granted businessman Mokhzani Mahathir, son of former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, an additional 30 days to declare his assets amid probes into their business activities. Mokhzani had initially been told to comply by January 26, but his request for more time was accepted. The agency ordered both Mokhzani and his brother Mirzan to declare income since 1981. Failure to comply could result in court charges, similar to those faced by a former Malaysian minister who was once an adviser to Mahathir.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, February 21, 2024 (Ep 6)
summary: China boosts the property sector with a series of policies, while Singapore shares fell 0.6% on Wednesday. SIA shares plummeted 9.4% after weaker-than-expected earnings, erasing a 3-week gain. The ringgit currency hit a 26-year low against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 61 to 37.
So far, 214 cities across the nation have set up the mechanism, recommending more than 5,300 projects to banks.
Investors take profit following disappointment from the national carrier’s financial results for the three months ended Dec 31, 2023.

Shoppers at Petaling Street in Kuala Lumpur. The weakening of the ringgit has been a silver lining for Malaysia’s tourism sector, making it one of the most affordable destinations for travellers in the region.

site_title: Trump Presidency II: Things could get messier on foreign and trade policies
summary: US President Donald Trump's foreign and trade policies during his presidency were more pragmatic than isolationist, contrary to critics' expectations. Despite threats to withdraw from NATO and abrogate defense treaties, Trump's diplomatic efforts with North Korea and Russia led to increased stability in the Korean peninsula and reduced US military assistance to Russia's adversary, Ukraine. Trump's trade policies, including revoking the nuclear deal with Iran and promoting the Abraham Accords, have also had positive outcomes. However, a second Trump administration may lead to a renewed effort to improve US relations with Russia and China, potentially at the expense of NATO's security interests and US trade relationships.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump is also promoting a universal reciprocal tariff that would see the United States imposing tariff rates on foreign goods equivalent to what the exporting country charges on US goods.

Former US President Donald Trump speaks to members of media at New York State Supreme Court in New York, US, on Monday, Nov 6, 2023. Trump is facing off against New York attorney general Letitia James in a contentious civil trial that threatens his control over his real estate empire in the state.

ATKINSON, NEW HAMPSHIRE - JANUARY 16: Supporters wait in line ahead of a rally for Republican presidential candidate, former U.S. President Donald Trump at the Atkinson Country Club on January 16, 2024 in Atkinson, New Hampshire. Trump won this week's Iowa caucus, solidifying him as the lead Republican nominee in the first balloting of 2024. The former U.S. President heads to Atkinson, New Hampshire today as he continues campaigning during the primary election.   Brandon Bell/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Brandon Bell / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: US mortgage rates jump above 7% for first time since December
summary: US mortgage rates surged to 7.06% for the first time since December, dealing a blow to the housing market's recovery. The 30-year fixed mortgage contract rate increased 19 basis points in the week ended Feb 16, the largest weekly increase since October. The MBA's index of home-purchase mortgage applications fell 10% to its lowest level since November, while the overall index declined 10.6% to the lowest level this year. Despite being lower than the highest levels in a generation, mortgage rates remain more than twice as high as in 2021.

images.alt_text: A for sale sign stands outside of a home in Princeton, Illinois, U.S., on Wednesday, May 30, 2012. The number of Americans signing contracts to buy previously-owned homes fell in April by the most in a year, indicating the U.S. housing recovery remains uneven. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg
Builder sentiment began rebounding late last year as mortgage rates declined, falling below 7% in December.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending rose 0.9 per cent.
Buyers have been sidelined by high mortgage rates, which hit a recent peak in October at 7.79 per cent.
The National Association of Realtors (NAR) Pending Home Sales index rises 8.3 per cent to 77.3, rebounding from a downwardly revised record-low of 71.4 in November.
Purchases of new single-family homes increase 8 per cent to a 664,000 annual pace last month, after an upward revision to November’s figure.

site_title: Toyota holds off response on wage talks after first round
summary: Toyota has delayed response on wage talks after the first round, with labour-management talks scheduled for Feb 28 and March 6. The union demands record bonus payments and monthly pay raises of up to 28,440 yen. If Toyota agrees, it would mark the fourth straight year of full acceptance. The talks are closely watched by the Bank of Japan, which sees sustainable wage hikes as a prerequisite for normalizing monetary policy. Private-sector economists expect major firms to offer wage hikes of about 3.9% on average, which could lay the ground for the central bank to exit negative rates.

images.alt_text: Small firms, which employ roughly seven out of 10 Japanese workers, hold the key to spreading wage hikes, with many workers in regional Japan on their payrolls.
Young people in Japan are benefiting from a labour shortage that’s especially acute in their age group.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 21)
summary: Singapore saw a post-Covid high of 1,436,404 international visitors in January, driven by a surge in Chinese arrivals. The country is also investing up to S$100 million in a 10 Gbps fibre network upgrade. Meanwhile, Certificate of Entitlement premiums dropped for most categories except commercial vehicles, and liquidators successfully clawed back S$2.3 million from Chuan Hup Holdings. The Straits Times Index fell 0.8% on Wednesday, amid a mixed regional showing, with Singapore Airlines shares declining after underperforming Q3 results.

site_title: DroneDash, Aerodyne aim for world’s first cross-border drone delivery
summary: Singapore's DroneDash Technologies and Malaysia's Aerodyne Group have partnered to conduct cross-border drone delivery trials between Singapore and Malaysia, aiming to be the world's first international drone delivery. The trial, set to begin in 2024, will focus on smaller shipments with higher value, such as electronics and medical supplies. The method is expected to be four times faster and emit up to 92% less carbon dioxide than existing land or sea methods. Regulatory approval is pending, with the companies estimating a trial duration of at least a year or more.

images.alt_text: Civil aviation authorities will cooperate to develop reference materials for commercial air taxis and complex drone operations.
An electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) craft render from manufacturer Eve..
Aerodyne is a drone-based enterprise solutions provider using artificial intelligence to enable large-scale data operations, analytics and process optimisation.
Matternet’s Model M2, a four-rotor copter capable of carrying a 1.8-kilogramme package, is considered safe and reliable, the FAA said in a statement on Wednesday.

site_title: Envy Asset Management liquidators given nod to claw back S$2.3 million from Chuan Hup’s unit
summary: Liquidators of Envy Asset Management have secured a court ruling to claw back S$2.3 million from Chuan Hup Holdings' unit, CH Biovest. The High Court found that the investment return was paid with the intent to defraud Envy Asset Management's investors, who were part of a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam. As a result, Chuan Hup must refund the amount to Envy Asset Management. This ruling marks a significant victory for the liquidators in their efforts to recover losses from the alleged Ponzi scheme.

images.alt_text: Ng Yu Zhi has allegedly tried selling a shophouse  bought with purported fraud proceeds.

site_title: Neighbourhood doctors form co-op for lower costs, better care
summary: Neighbourhood doctors in Singapore have formed a co-operative society called GP+ to provide lower-cost, better care. Founded in 2018, the co-op has 98 members, including GPs, specialist doctors, and allied health professionals, who run over 60 clinics in Singapore. The co-op model allows members to maintain autonomy while sharing costs and best practices, resulting in lower costs for patients and improved communication between healthcare professionals. The co-op aims to keep healthcare affordable, deepen collaboration, and provide better quality care to the public.

images.alt_text: While enrolment in Healthier SG for patients and doctors alike remains voluntary, GP clinics have generally seen an increase in administrative costs arising from their participation.
Bringing automation to clinics

site_title: New sustainability playbook, microsite can help logistics players go green
summary: Singapore's logistics sector has launched a new sustainability playbook and microsite to help companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), adopt green practices. The resources include a step-by-step guide and actionable steps to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, manage packaging waste, and improve employee health and data security. The initiatives aim to help logistics players develop strategies to take advantage of emerging sustainability trends and decarbonise. The playbook and microsite are part of Singapore Logistics Association's Vision 2027 five-year roadmap, which aims to support the sector's sustainability efforts.

images.alt_text: Enterprise Singapore chief executive Lee Chuan Teck said the statutory board hopes revenue generated from its projects will reach pre-pandemic levels soon.
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan was the guest of honour at the Singapore Manufacturing Federation's inaugural Manufacturing Day Summit 2024.
GRACE FU

site_title: OUE Healthcare expects higher H2, FY23 profit on fair-value gains
summary: OUE Healthcare expects a higher year-on-year profit after tax for the second half and full year ended Dec 31, 2023, due to net fair-value gains from its investment properties. This marks a significant improvement from the net loss of S$4 million in the second half of 2022. The company is in the process of finalizing its unaudited financial results, which will be announced by the end of the month.

site_title: HSBC’s record annual profit marred by US$3 billion China hit; shares slide
summary: HSBC reported a record annual profit of $30.3 billion, but missed estimates due to a $3 billion charge on its stake in China's Bank of Communications amid mounting bad loans in the world's second-largest economy. Shares slid 6% after the announcement, despite a $2 billion share buyback. The bank's costs grew 6% in 2023, and it remains cautious about the loan growth outlook in 2024. Despite a strong year, HSBC's earnings momentum is expected to slow, with analysts citing concerns about mainland China's economic challenges.

images.alt_text: So far, 214 cities across the nation have set up the mechanism, recommending more than 5,300 projects to banks.

site_title: China tourists push Singapore’s January visitor arrivals to new post-Covid high
summary: Singapore's international visitors reached a post-Covid high of 1,436,404 in January, driven by a surge in China arrivals. Chinese tourists increased by 60% to 211,194, despite a 30-day visa exemption not taking effect until February. Indonesia took the top spot with 268,972 tourists, followed by Australia, Malaysia, and India. Visitor arrivals are expected to reach 15 million to 16 million in 2024, supported by improved global flight connectivity and the Singapore-China visa exemption.

images.alt_text: The agreement will allow ordinary passport holders from Singapore and China to enter each other’s country without the need for a visa, and for a stay of up to 30 days.
Interest has been rising since both countries announced that the arrangement was in the works – though without a start date –  early last December, say industry players.
Singapore's tourism performance benefitted from a “robust leisure and sporting events calendar” in 2023, says STB.
Taylor Swift will hold six shows at the National Stadium from Mar 2 to Mar 9.

site_title: Japan sees 2.69 million visitors in January, matching 2019’s record pace
summary: Japan welcomed 2.69 million foreign visitors in January, matching the record pace of 2019. The number of visitors for business and leisure was down slightly from December, but arrivals in December set an all-time high. Tourism to Japan is crucial to the economy, with visitors spending over $45 billion last year. Chinese visitors, still below pre-pandemic levels, showed signs of recovery, with a 33% increase in January.

images.alt_text: Visitors stroll at Kiyomizu-dera temple, a popular attraction among tourists, in Kyoto, western Japan June 18, 2022. REUTERS/Satoshi Sugiyama

site_title: HSBC CEO Quinn’s pay almost doubles as bonus pool gains 12%
summary: HSBC CEO Noel Quinn's total pay increased by 89% to £10.6 million (S$18 million) in 2023, driven by a 12% rise in the overall bonus pool. The bank reported a 78% pretax profit increase to $30.3 billion, despite a tepid bonus trend across the industry. This is attributed to HSBC's diversified business, which shielded it from the downturn in investment banking.

site_title: London’s iconic BT Tower in £275 million sale to hotel owner MCR
summary: London's iconic BT Tower is sold to hotel owner MCR for £275 million. The 1964-built, 177-meter-tall tower, which was once the tallest in London, will be repurposed as a hotel. The sale marks part of BT Group's plan to cut costs and real estate holdings. The tower previously hosted a revolving restaurant and corporate events.

site_title: China’s wealthiest provinces accelerate fixed-asset investment to drive growth
summary: China's wealthiest provinces are accelerating fixed-asset investment to drive growth, with Guangzhou and Eastern Zhejiang planning over $374 billion in annual projects. The provinces aim to speed up infrastructure investment and expand high-value sectors. Following a Chinese New Year break, Guangzhou will start 319 major projects, while Eastern Zhejiang will invest over $1 trillion in over 1,000 projects. The move aims to boost economic growth, which has struggled to sustain a strong recovery since the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: The government’s efforts to get overseas companies to return after Covid are falling short, and more will be needed if Beijing is to succeed in its aims.
Chinese leaders are hunting for ways to jump-start the economy, which faces headwinds from a property slump, weak business confidence and persistent deflationary pressures.
For international travels, China witnessed around 13.5 million inbound and outbound trips during the holiday, growing by 2.8 times year on year.
Pacifying this generation amid some of the slowest economic growth in nearly half a century presents a key policymaking challenge for Chinese President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Vicom’s H2 net profit climbs 4.5% to S$13.7 million on higher revenue
summary: Vicom's second-half 2023 net profit increased 4.5% to S$13.7 million, driven by higher revenue. The company expects strong demand for vehicle testing and related work following its appointment by the Land Transport Authority as an authorised partner for On-Board Unit installations, part of the Electronic Road Pricing 2.0 exercise. A final dividend of S$0.0275 per share was proposed, down from the previous year.

images.alt_text: The marginal rise in net profit was a result of higher interest income, which was offset by lower operating profits, Vicom said in a business update.

site_title: China’s childcare costs among highest in world: think tank
summary: China's childcare costs are among the highest in the world, with a cost of raising a child until 18 relative to per capita GDP being around 6.3 times higher than in Australia. The high cost leads to a reduction in women's paid work hours and wage rates, while men's livelihoods remain largely unchanged. China's population fell for a second consecutive year in 2023, with new births dropping to around half of that in 2016. To address this issue, the YuWa Population Research Institute recommends introducing policies such as cash and tax subsidies, improved childcare services, and equal maternity and paternity leave to increase new births to around three million.

images.alt_text: Beijing’s stringent Covid curbs, persistent crackdowns on the private sector, the property crisis and geopolitical tensions with the West have all combined to erode Hong Kong’s growth prospects.
Indonesia is the largest source of tourists to Singapore in January, followed by China, Australia, Malaysia and India.
A jewellery craftsman working on a gold piece at the Chow Tai Fook master studio in Foshan, China, Jan 26, 2024.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid mixed regional showing; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% to 3,217.11, amid a mixed regional market performance. Singapore Airlines shares plummeted 9.4% after its Q3 results underperformed expectations. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.6%, while South Korea's Kospi and Japan's Nikkei 225 fell 0.2% and 0.3% respectively. Market analysts attribute the decline to cautious trading ahead of US Federal Open Market Committee minutes and chipmaker Nvidia's Q4 earnings.

images.alt_text: Investors take profit following disappointment from the national carrier’s financial results for the three months ended Dec 31, 2023.
Sembcorp Industries proposes a final dividend of 8 Singapore cents, bringing the total dividend for FY2023 to 13 Singapore cents.

site_title: South Korea pension fund to support corporate reform efforts
summary: South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS) plans to invest in domestic companies working to boost their value through the "Corporate Value-up Programme". The NPS, the world's third-largest public pension fund, will select three domestic fund managers to outsource its investments, with a final decision expected by March. Analysts see the NPS playing a key role in boosting valuations of Seoul-listed companies through tax incentives and improved governance. The NPS holds a significant stake in large companies and will determine investment size and timing based on portfolio management and market conditions.

site_title: Japan downgrades view of economy on sluggish consumer spending
summary: Japan's government downgraded its view on the economy for the first time in three months, citing sluggish consumer spending and a slow wage recovery. The assessment on consumer spending was also slashed for the first time in two years, with a pickup appearing to be "stalling". Industrial output was downgraded for the first time since March 2023, and recovery in capital spending appears to be slowing. The downgrade suggests a bumpy path out of a recession, challenging the Bank of Japan as it exits its ultra-easy policy this year.

images.alt_text: With inflation exceeding the BOJ’s 2 per cent target for well over a year, many market players expect the BOJ to end its negative interest rate policy in the coming months.

site_title: Foreign investors flee China shares, long-delayed data shows
summary: Foreign investors significantly reduced their holdings of onshore Chinese shares in 2023, with the value of their equities falling 13% from the previous year and 30% from their peak in 2021. At the end of last year, foreign entities owned 2.8 trillion yuan (S$523.3 billion) of Chinese shares, down from a peak of 4 trillion yuan. This decline is part of a broader trend of investors seeking higher returns elsewhere, with the value of bonds held by overseas entities rising 8% last year.

images.alt_text: If the drip feed of bad news about China persists, there is little reason for the market to push up the share prices.

site_title: UK homeowners are proving more resilient than once feared
summary: UK homeowners have shown resilience, with property prices falling just 1.4% in the 12 months to December. Mortgage support measures introduced by the UK government and lenders have been largely unnecessary, with low take-up numbers, despite low unemployment and expectations of interest rate cuts. Only 8,000 borrowers received support via the mortgage charter, and nearly 94,000 homeowner mortgages were in arrears, a 7% increase from the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: The number of homes sold for more than £5 million (S$8.5 million) in January is down 17 per cent from last year.
Blackstone has bought Cargo which was previously known as 25 North Colonnade, the former headquarters of the Financial Conduct Authority, for about £165 million in 2014.
The largest warehouse in Europe is owned and developed by Tritax Big Box Reit. Tritax has traditionally focused on large UK warehouses that serve as major logistics hubs.
Easing mortgage costs and improving confidence in the outlook for the economy have boosted the number of buyers looking for property.

The S&P Global/CIPS UK Purchasing Managers’ Index’s headline measure of the construction industry improves to 48.8 in January from 46.8 in December, its highest since August 2023 although still in no-growth territory.
House prices in January increased by 0.7 per cent from the month before after being flat in December, beating economists’ forecast in a Reuters poll for a 0.1 per cent rise.

site_title: Record US renewable energy investment not enough to meet climate goals: report
summary: US renewable energy investment reached a record high in 2023, but fell short of meeting the nation's climate change goals to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030. Clean energy installations for utilities are hindered by permitting and grid interconnection delays. Electric vehicle sales are meeting forecasts, with 9.2% of light-duty sales in 2023, but growth may underperform last year's 50% increase. The US needs to add 60-127 GW of capacity this year to stay on track, with further increases needed beyond 2024 to meet climate goals.

images.alt_text: With hours to go until the Dubai summit officially ends, US climate envoy John Kerry told ministers that this was “the last COP that we’ll have a chance to be able to keep 1.5 deg C alive. This is it.”

The China Electricity Council (CEC) forecast that grid-connected wind and solar would make up around 40 per cent of installed power generation capacity by the end of 2024, compared with coal’s expected 37 per cent.
Wind turbines have steadily increased, and strong winds have pushed up production of renewable energy.

site_title: Cordlife begins offering refunds to affected parents
summary: Cordlife, a private cord blood bank, has begun offering refunds to parents whose cord blood units were damaged due to improper storage. The company is refunding S$537.50, including fees and GST, for affected parents who paid annual storage fees in 2022 and 2023. However, some parents are not accepting the refund and are planning to pursue legal action, seeking full refunds and compensation. The damage occurred in at least one storage tank, affecting over 2,000 cord blood units. Testing is ongoing, with results expected by end-March.

images.alt_text: The change in leadership comes amid Cordlife serving a six-month suspension from collecting, testing, processing and/or storing new cord blood and human tissue.
Cordlife Group suspended for 6 months after the Ministry of Health found lapses in its cord blood storage tanks.
While Cordlife is in good financial shape at the moment, it should begin weighing its strategic options before too much value is lost
MOH has given a timeline of end-March for the results of testing the viability and potency of cord blood units in the affected tanks and dry shipper of Cordlife.
Robust Plan has brought down its stake in Cordlife Group from 5.47 per cent to 3.67 per cent.
The MOH finds more lapses in the group's processes, including cord blood processing method and temperature warning systems.
Cordlife says that each batch of the samples for testing may take between three and six weeks to be completed, depending on whether a repeat test of samples from the same tank is need.

site_title: Hong Kong bankers earn up to 46% more than Singapore peers
summary: Hong Kong-based finance and technology professionals earn significantly higher salaries than their Singapore counterparts. Analysts in Hong Kong earn an average of US$92,149 per year, 46% more than those in Singapore, while associates earn almost US$123,000, 36% higher. The tech industry also commands higher salaries in Hong Kong due to talent shortages. This wage disparity may benefit Hong Kong in its economic competition with Singapore, despite Singapore's thriving wealth-management sector and lower private banking earnings.

images.alt_text: The new year holiday marks China’s most important national celebration and is a key barometer for consumption early in the year.
Heavy on finance and tech, the Hang Seng index has started an overhaul in 2021 to expand its universe to include more new economy stocks.
The seven comprised five men and two women aged from 23 to 74, one of who is believed to be the mastermind of the scheme, Hong Kong customs authorities say.
An HSBC bank branch in North Vancouver, British Columbia. Photographer: Taehoon Kim/Bloomberg

site_title: Sasseur Reit posts 8.7% rise in Q4 DPU to S$0.01415 on outlet sales growth
summary: Sasseur Reit, a real estate investment trust, reported an 8.7% rise in quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01415, driven by an 81.7% year-on-year increase in variable rental income and 84.6% increase in outlet sales. The Chongqing Liangjiang Outlet maintained full occupancy, while the overall portfolio average occupancy rate remained strong at 97.6%. Despite a 4.6% decline in full-year DPU, the Reit's valuation stayed relatively unchanged due to strong underlying fundamentals.

images.alt_text: Sasseur Reit is a China-based retail outlet mall Reit.
Sasseur Reit's Hefei Outlet mall. The real estate investment trust says its total outlet sales for its portfolio rose 15.8 per cent to 1.1 billion yuan in the third quarter.
In renminbi (RMB) terms, the Reit, who owns four outlet malls in China, including the Chongqing one shown in picture, recorded an 8.4 per cent rise in rental income in the second quarter.

site_title: Glencore's 2023 earnings halve on lower commodity prices
summary: Glencore's 2023 earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) halved to $17.1 billion, down from $34.1 billion in 2022, due to lower commodity prices. The company's net debt increased to $4.92 billion, and it slashed its payout to investors to fund the acquisition of a 77% stake in Teck Resources' metallurgical coal business for $6.9 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong faces mounting pressure to remove property curbs
summary: Hong Kong faces pressure to remove property curbs, with developers and lawmakers lobbying Financial Secretary Paul Chan to scrap extra taxes. The curbs, introduced a decade ago, have contributed to the lacklustre market. Developers, including the Real Estate Developers Association, are urging the government to remove the "baggage" and lift the market. The lobbying efforts come ahead of the budget plan's release on February 28.

images.alt_text: Beijing’s stringent Covid curbs, persistent crackdowns on the private sector, the property crisis and geopolitical tensions with the West have all combined to erode Hong Kong’s growth prospects.

site_title: Citigroup lifts CEO Jane Fraser’s pay to US$26 million
summary: Citigroup has awarded CEO Jane Fraser a total of US$26 million in pay for 2023, a 6% increase from the previous year. This comes after Fraser initiated a major overhaul of the bank to boost profitability and simplify operations. The pay package includes US$1.5 million in salary and US$24.5 million in stock-based and cash incentive awards. Fraser's pay remains the lowest among her peers, following a trend where she was the only major bank CEO to receive a raise in 2022.

images.alt_text: In his new role, DJ Sengupta will build a team at Wrise’s office in Dubai that will focus on meeting wealth management demands from Ultra High Net Worth (UNHW) investors flocking to the region.

A pedestrian walks past a Citibank branch in the ground floor of Citigroup Inc. headquarters in New York, U.S., on Tuesday, March 8, 2011. Citigroup, the third-largest U.S. lender by assets, now earns more than half of its profit from emerging markets, Chief Executive Officer Vikram Pandit said last month. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

A pedestrian walks past a Citibank branch in the ground floor of Citigroup Inc. headquarters in New York, U.S., on Tuesday, March 8, 2011. Citigroup, the third-largest U.S. lender by assets, now earns more than half of its profit from emerging markets, Chief Executive Officer Vikram Pandit said last month. Photographer: Jin Lee/Bloomberg

site_title: UK posts record fiscal surplus in pre-budget boost for Hunt
summary: The UK has posted a record fiscal surplus of £16.7 billion in January, exceeding spending by more than double the surplus a year earlier. This boost could lead to tax cuts in the upcoming budget to rescue the Conservative Party's fortunes ahead of a general election. However, self-imposed fiscal rules may limit the scope for major giveaways, with the Chancellor having no more headroom than estimated. The surplus leaves the budget deficit at £96.6 billion, £9.2 billion less than forecast by the Office for Budget Responsibility.

images.alt_text: The Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, attends a press conference in London, Britain, May 11, 2023. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/Pool

site_title: Singapore to invest up to S$100 million in 10 Gbps fibre network upgrade
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is investing up to S$100 million to upgrade the Nationwide Broadband Network to 10 gigabits per second (Gbps) by 2026. The upgrade aims to provide higher-speed services and competitive prices to businesses and consumers, benefiting over 500,000 households by 2028. Telcos will be responsible for upgrading their networks and equipment, with IMDA providing funding and support. The upgrade is seen as a catalyst for the industry to move towards 10 Gbps services, with the government aiming to enable mass-market access to such speeds by the second half of the decade.

images.alt_text: NetLink Trust currently designs, builds, owns and operates the NBN’s passive fibre network infrastructure.
Singapore Budget 2024

site_title: Indonesia central bank keeps policy rate unchanged at 6% for a fourth straight month
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, maintained its benchmark interest rate at 6% for a fourth consecutive month, aiming to stabilize the rupiah and control inflation. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the rate is sufficient to manage inflation, while other tools will support growth. The rupiah has performed relatively well against regional peers, and the central bank expects it to remain stable and appreciate further. Indonesia's inflation rate remains within the target range, allowing the central bank to keep the policy unchanged until the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Indonesia plans to exempt more nationalities from visa requirements while simplifying permits to make it easier to host events in the country.

site_title: Chinese banks approve US$17 billion of loans under 'whitelist' project
summary: China's Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development announced that 214 cities have set up a "whitelist" mechanism to recommend residential projects to banks for financial support. Under this mechanism, US$17.20 billion of development loans have been approved and 29.4 billion yuan (S$5.49 billion) have been issued to ensure the completion of selected projects. This move aims to stabilize the property sector's debt crisis and boost confidence in the industry, which accounts for a quarter of China's GDP.

images.alt_text: China’s central bank kept a key interest rate that guides mortgages on hold and made a smaller-than-expected cut to another rate in August.

site_title: Australia annual wage growth hits 15-year high in Q4
summary: Australia's annual wage growth reached a 15-year high in the December quarter, increasing to 4.2% from 4.1%. This is the highest rate since early 2009 and was driven by low unemployment and competition for workers. The wage price index rose 0.9% in the quarter, with a record 1.3% jump in the previous quarter due to minimum awards. Analysts expect the best is over, citing a slowing economy.

site_title: AI model backed by Asia’s richest person to launch in March
summary: A consortium backed by Asia's richest person, Mukesh Ambani, is set to launch a ChatGPT-style AI model, dubbed Hanooman, in March. The model, developed in collaboration with Indian Institute of Technology universities and Reliance Industries, aims to work in 11 local languages across four main fields: healthcare, governance, financial services, and education. The model's launch represents a significant step for India in the AI technology development, offering speech-to-text capabilities and potentially transforming the country's ambitions in the field.

images.alt_text: Pricey chips : The costs of doing business are too high for AI startups to survive on their own.
OpenAI led a revolution in artificial intelligence when it placed its ChatGPT program online in late 2022.
In terms of boosting investment returns, hopes largely rest on machine learning, the subfield of AI where computers are trained on massive amounts of data to perform particular tasks.
Code-named Izanagi, the project marks Masayoshi Son’s next big endeavor as SoftBank sharply curtails startup investments.
Under the agreement, AI-generated content could be given a watermark or tagged in the metadata at source, although the signatories acknowledged that “all such solutions have limitations”.
Google will introduce a new open-source resource powered by AI that utilises file type identification to help detect malware, the company says.
Sora is a work-in-progress, with the company adding that the model may confuse the spatial details of a prompt, and have difficulty in following a specific camera trajectory.
Apple is also exploring the use of AI to generate code for testing applications, an often tedious process.

site_title: Your dream Malaysia vacation just got cheaper with ringgit near 26-year low
summary: Malaysia's tourism sector is experiencing a boost due to the country's currency, the ringgit, hitting a 26-year low against the US dollar. The weakening currency has increased tourists' spending power, attracting travelers from further afield. Agency Intrepid Travel has seen a 15% increase in bookings to Malaysia this year compared to the same time in 2023. Analysts predict a stronger ringgit by the end of the year, but for now, the currency's low value is making Malaysia a more affordable destination in the region.

images.alt_text: The local currency fell 0.2% to 4.7965 against the dollar, its weakest level since an all-time low of 4.8850 in 1998 following the fallout from the regional financial crisis.

site_title: Hot stock: SIA dives 9.4% after Q3 results disappoint, erasing 3-week gain
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) shares plummeted 9.4% after the airline's Q3 financial results fell short of expectations, erasing a three-week gain. Despite a 4.9% increase in net profit to S$659 million, analysts were disappointed by the operating profit's 19.3% rise due to higher costs. Analysts downgraded SIA's target price, citing concerns over share price volatility and cargo yields. The airline's guidance for robust passenger demand in the next two quarters was seen as well-reflected in its share price, leading some to raise concerns about the airline's ability to meet its full-year targets.

images.alt_text: SIA
Within the group, the flagship airline’s revenue passenger-kilometres rose 14.3 per cent to 9.6 billion, from 8.4 billion year on year.

site_title: Asia: Stocks lower after Wall Street losses
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday, following US losses, as investors await a key tech earnings report and Fed policy meeting minutes. The Nikkei 225 benchmark fell further from reaching its highest-ever close of 38,915.87 in 1989. The tech-rich Nasdaq fell nearly one percent in US trading ahead of Nvidia's highly anticipated results, with traders expecting strong growth in the AI sector.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down 0.2 per cent at 38,563.80, while the broad-based S&P 500 fell 0.6 per cent to 4,975.51 on Tuesday.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 61 to 37.

site_title: India’s AI market seen touching US$17 billion by 2027
summary: India's AI market is expected to reach $17 billion by 2027, growing at a 25-35% annualized rate from 2024. The country has over 420,000 AI employees, with the highest skills penetration. This growth is driven by increased enterprise tech spending, a growing AI talent pool, and rising AI investments.

images.alt_text: With the political agreement, the EU moves toward becoming the first major world power to enact laws governing AI.

site_title: Sias finds Chemical Industries’ rebuttal ‘contradictory’; requests timeline to appoint new CEO
summary: Sias, the Securities Investors Association (Singapore), has expressed concerns over Chemical Industries' rebuttal to minority shareholder concerns. The association has found that Chemical Industries' co-founder and emeritus chairman, Lim Soo Peng, uses the company's premises for his personal office, contradicting his statement. Sias is requesting a timeline for the appointment of a new CEO and seeking clarifications on the company's board statements, including potential conflicts of interest and private benefits.

images.alt_text: The letter from shareholders comes amid the resignations of Chemical Industries (Far East)'s chief executive officer (CEO) and chief operating officer (COO) – both of whom have served for less than a year in their current roles.

The letter from shareholders comes amid the resignations of Chemical Industries (Far East)'s chief executive officer (CEO) and chief operating officer (COO) – both of whom have served for less than a year in their current roles.

site_title: Brazil rebuilds reputation after decade of crises
summary: Brazil is rebuilding its reputation after a decade of crises, with President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's return to office being a key catalyst. Lula's climate diplomacy efforts have helped reduce deforestation in the Amazon, and he aims to showcase Brazil as an international leader through the G20 and COP30 climate summit. Brazil's natural resources, including arable land, minerals, and renewables, make it a vital player in global trade and food security. Lula's efforts to lead the Global South have been met with mixed success, but he has largely turned the page on past economic and political troubles.

images.alt_text: Delegates at a panel discussion on the topic of "BRICS Rising Influence in the Multipolar International Order" at the Doha Forum in the Qatari capital on Dec 10, 2023.

site_title: Amazon to replace Walgreens in Dow Jones Industrial Average
summary: Amazon is set to replace Walgreens in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, effective next week. The move increases consumer retail exposure and was prompted by Walmart's decision to split its stock. Amazon's addition to the Dow marks the first change since 2020, while Walmart will remain in the index despite its upcoming stock split. The Dow's change takes effect at the open of trading on Monday, and Amazon's shares rose 1.3% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Eli Lilly's stock has jumped 34 per cent this year, bolstered by demand for its diabetes and obesity drugs.
Several top technology companies including Microsoft have announced head-count reductions in recent weeks.
Bezos has adopted a trading plan to sell 50 million shares anytime before Jan 31, 2025.
