site_title: Oxford finally has a hotel worthy of its world renown
summary: Oxford's historic Boswells department store, which closed in 2020, is set to reopen as the Store Oxford, a 54,000-square-foot hotel, in May. Designed by the team behind Parisian hotels Dame des Arts and Hotel des Grands Voyageurs, the hotel will be located in the city centre opposite Balliol College. The Store Oxford will bring a long-awaited hotel to Oxford, a city renowned for its medieval and neoclassical architecture, and is expected to enhance the city's hospitality offerings.

images.alt_text: Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, First Sponsor, Sasseur Reit, First Reit, TalkMed, UOI
summary: Singapore Airlines' net profit rose 4.9% to S$659 million for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2023, driven by robust passenger demand. First Sponsor Group's profits fell 96.8% to S$1.9 million, while Sasseur Reit's DPU increased 8.7% to S$0.01415. First Reit's DPU decreased 6.1% to S$0.0124, and TalkMed Group's earnings dropped 2.8% to S$17.9 million. United Overseas Insurance's net profit fell 6% to S$17.3 million, while Dyna-Mac Holdings' net profit rose 84.7% to S$18.4 million.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers beat losers 281 to 251 after 1.93 billion securities worth S$978.69 million changed hands.

site_title: SAESL announces US$180 million expansion with EDB and JTC Corporation support
summary: SAESL, a joint venture between SIA Engineering and Rolls-Royce, has announced a US$180 million expansion plan to increase its capacity by 40% in aircraft engine maintenance. The expansion will involve the development of new facilities, including a 26,000 sq m facility at JTC's Loyang estate and expansion into Rolls-Royce's existing premises. The project is expected to create 500 new employment opportunities in engineering by 2028.

images.alt_text: SIAEC's revenue for the quarter stands at S$291.7 million, up 40.2 per cent from a year ago.

The hangars at Sultan Abdul Aziz Airport, each being able to fit two wide-body aircraft, will boost SIAEC's airframe check capacity in providing comprehensive maintenance, repair and overhaul of current and next-generation aircraft for its expanding portfolio of airline customers, the company said.
A rendering of the JTC aeroSpace Four, which will be the first standard factory at the Seletar Aerospace Park that will feature green infrastructure solution.

site_title: Oil settles lower, demand worries offset geopolitical price support
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Tuesday, with Brent futures down 1.5% to $82.34 a barrel, despite geopolitical tensions in the Middle East. Demand concerns offset the price support, with global demand growth forecasted to be 1.22 million barrels per day, less than Opec's outlook. The premium for prompt US crude futures reached its highest in four months, encouraging energy companies to sell now.

images.alt_text: Brent futures gained 9 cents to settle at US$83.56 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Black homeownership rate disparity wider than a decade ago
summary: The gap in US homeownership rates between Blacks and Whites has widened to 28 percentage points, the highest among the four major groups, according to the National Association of Realtors. While overall homeownership increased by 10.5 million over the decade, Black homeownership rates rose modestly to 44.1%, while Asian Americans saw a historic high of 63.3% homeownership. Minority buyers face challenges such as high prices, limited supply, and difficulties in saving for down payments, with 55% of Asian and 51% of Black and Hispanic homeowners being first-time buyers.

images.alt_text: Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, dropped 4.7 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.004 million units last month.

site_title: COE premiums dip in all categories except commercial vehicles; Open Category below S$100,000 for first time since May 2022
summary: COE premiums in Singapore's second round of bidding for February 2024 have decreased across most categories except commercial vehicles. Category A premiums dropped 2.8% to S$76,801, while Category B premiums fell 5.2% to S$97,000. Category E, the open category, has dipped below S$100,000 for the first time since May 2022, sliding 6.1% to S$94,006. In contrast, Category C premiums increased 1.4% to S$73,001. The decrease is attributed to increased COE supply and measures by the Land Transport Authority to bring forward guaranteed deregistrations.

images.alt_text: Why a Toyota cost S$200,000 in Singapore
Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for most categories fell in February's first round of bidding.
Chinese car maker BYD has clinched the top electric vehicle seller from Tesla globally.

site_title: Qantas names John Mullen new chairman to lead board overhaul
summary: Qantas appoints John Mullen as new chairman to lead a board overhaul following scandals and missteps, including claims of selling tickets for cancelled flights. Mullen, a veteran of winemaker Treasury Wine Estates and Telstra Group, will join the Qantas board on July 1. His appointment comes after the early departure of former CEO Alan Joyce, whose reputation was tarnished by the airline's handling of ticket sales. The overhaul aims to restore Qantas' reputation and improve its operations.

site_title: More Wall Street firms are flip-flopping on climate. Here’s why.
summary: Major Wall Street firms, including JPMorgan, State Street, and Pimco, have withdrawn from Climate Action 100+, a global climate coalition. The move comes amid Republican attacks and concerns over fiduciary duties, antitrust regulations, and potential legal risks. The firms, which had previously pledged to combat climate change, cited the need to adapt to changing regulatory environments and avoid "woke capitalism" labels. The withdrawal marks a setback for efforts to hold companies accountable for their environmental impact, but some firms, like JPMorgan, say they remain committed to sustainable investing.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan’s fund business says it has decided not to renew its membership of the Climate Action 100+ investor group after “significant investment” in its investment stewardship capabilities over the last couple of years.
Global ESG exchange-traded funds are slightly outperforming benchmark indexes this year, according to Bloomberg data.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on miners, energy drag; France’s Air Liquide hits record high
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1% lower on Tuesday, snapping a four-day winning streak, due to losses in basic resources and energy stocks. Despite upbeat earnings from industry heavyweights and expectations of rate cuts, basic resources shed 1.8% and energy dropped 1.1%. On the flip side, French industrial gases firm Air Liquide surged 8.3% after hiking its 2025 margin target. The Stoxx 600 is now near a record high, supported by earnings and rate cut expectations.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down 0.2 per cent at 38,563.80, while the broad-based S&P 500 fell 0.6 per cent to 4,975.51 on Tuesday.

site_title: Ratcliffe acquisition of Manchester United minority stake completed
summary: British billionaire Jim Ratcliffe has completed his $1.25 billion acquisition of a 25% stake in Premier League club Manchester United. The deal, which also includes a $300 million investment in the club's infrastructure, was completed after Premier League approval was given last week. Ratcliffe, who grew up a United fan, will take control of the club's soccer operations and aims to take the team back to the top of English, European, and world football. The Glazer family, who own the majority stake, will retain control but work closely with Ratcliffe to deliver a bright future for the club.

images.alt_text: Brehme's goal in the 1990 Fifa World Cup final sealed victory for West Germany over Argentina.
Hangzhou and Beijing have announced that they will not host the scheduled Argentina games for March as the fallout continues. Messi has now spoken in an attempt to ease the situation.
Jurgen Klinsmann, who has never won over South Korean fans or media, had promised to deliver the country’s first Asian title in 64 years.

French forward Kylian Mbappe , who arrived in Paris from Monaco in 2017, had extended his contract in 2022 until 2024 but last summer declined to activate a clause allowing him to stay another year at PSG.
UK business mogul Jim Ratcliffe struck an agreement in December to acquire, through his chemical conglomerate Ineos Group, a 25 per cent stake in Manchester United.

site_title: Australia’s Woolworths CEO quits as food price inquiry looms, half-year profit misses
summary: Australia's Woolworths CEO Brad Banducci is quitting after nearly 13 years, amid a public inquiry into suspected price gouging and profit margin inflation by top grocers. The inquiry, set for next month, follows criticism over high grocery costs and Banducci's refusal to stock certain merchandise for Australia Day. Banducci's departure comes as Woolworths flags weaker second-half earnings, missing half-year profit targets. The inquiry's findings could worsen living costs for Australians, who are already struggling with a cost of living crisis.

images.alt_text: An inquiry in 2022 found Star was unsuitable to run the Sydney casino after finding it had lax anti-money laundering controls, allowed patrons to flout China’s capital controls and encouraged problem gamblers.
Australia's annual pay growth picked up to 4.2 per cent, from 4.1 per cent, the highest since early 2009 and just above market expectations of 4.1 per cent.

John Mullen's appointment comes after Qantas' reputation was shredded by claims it sold tickets for thousands of flights it had already cancelled, leading to the early departure of former chief executive officer Alan Joyce.

site_title: Sustainable housing price growth: What does it mean?
summary: Singapore's residential property market is shifting towards sustainable price growth, driven by government cooling measures and economic fundamentals. However, defining sustainable growth is complex, influenced by factors such as gross domestic product growth, household income, and interest rates. Rapid price increases can exacerbate wealth disparities and social polarisation, while inaction poses a risk to long-term market stability. Policymakers must balance immediate housing demands with the needs of future generations, considering the implications of diverting resources into housing subsidies. Achieving sustainable markets requires a nuanced approach, including prudent borrowing levels, targeted subsidies, and managing land supply.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of Orchard Road. Orchard Bel Air, a coveted residential site located right at the doorstep of Orchard Boulevard MRT station is up for sale by tender.

site_title: Thai central bank seen defying pressure from prime minister to urgently cut rate
summary: The Bank of Thailand's Monetary Policy Committee is expected to resist pressure from Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin to cut interest rates, despite data showing a weaker-than-expected fourth-quarter economic output. Analysts from Barclays Bank and Nomura Holdings predict the BOT will keep rates steady at 2.5% in April, citing the central bank's independence and the need to stand firm amid the PM's push for rate cuts. The disagreement has led to uncertainty in Thailand's equity and bond markets, with investors pulling out nearly $1.5 billion from Thai stocks and bonds this year.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks alongside Cambodia's Prime Minister Hun Manet during a joint press conference at the Government House in Bangkok on February 7, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

To some observers of Thailand’s convoluted politics, Thaksin’s parole after returning from self-imposed exile in August was the latest act in an elaborate effort to crush the hugely popular anti-establishment Move Forward party that finished first in last year’s election.
Former Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra arrives at his family compound after he was released from a police hospital in Bangkok, Thailand, Feb 18, 2024.
Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto celebrates on stage as unofficial vote counts show that he is poised to become Indonesia's next president.
Thailand has recently waived visas for citizens of China and India to boost tourism, a key driver of South-east Asia’s second-biggest economy.

site_title: Singapore shares fall on Wednesday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.6% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping to 3,225.84, as investors tracked overnight losses in global markets. Losers outnumbered gainers 61 to 37, with Seatrium rising 1% and Dyna-Mac gaining 3.8%. Banking stocks traded mixed, while US stocks fell on Tuesday due to Nvidia's declining shares ahead of earnings results. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 declined 0.2% and 0.6% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.9%.

images.alt_text: SIA's net profit rises 4.9 per cent year on year to S$659 million for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2023.

site_title: Should you put all your savings into stocks?
summary: The article discusses whether investors should put all their savings into stocks, citing a recent rally in the stock market. Some researchers argue that a 100% equity allocation could outperform a diversified portfolio, citing long-term historical data. However, experts caution that the history of financial markets is too short to make definitive conclusions, and that relying on long-term trends may not be the best approach. Additionally, the article notes that the financial landscape is likely to change significantly by 2074, making it even more challenging to make investment decisions based on historical data.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve officials have pencilled in three rate cuts in 2024 of 75 basis points each, but the futures market is expecting twice the number of rate cuts.
Equities have remained resilient but restrictive monetary policy may impact corporate revenues going forward.

site_title: House building slump could cost Sweden nearly US$100 billion by 2030
summary: A housing construction slump in Sweden could cost the economy up to 1,000 billion crowns ($96 billion) by 2030, according to a report by the Stockholm Chamber of Commerce. The slump, driven by inflation and rising interest rates, has led to a 55% drop in housing starts and increased bankruptcies in the construction sector. The economy is expected to see little to no growth in 2024, and the long-term effects could impact the expansion of green industries in the far north, where companies rely on housing growth.

site_title: US: Stocks slip as chip giant Nvidia slumps
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2% and the S&P 500 down 0.6%, as chip giant Nvidia slipped 4.4% ahead of its earnings results. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.9%. Other stocks on the decline included Applied Materials and Advanced Micro Devices. Despite this, Nvidia's stock is still up 40% year-to-date, driven by enthusiasm for AI-related companies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 51.73 points, or 0.13 per cent, at the open to 38,576.26.

site_title: Germany’s Andreas Brehme, 1990 World Cup winning goal scorer, dies
summary: Germany's 1990 World Cup winning goal scorer Andreas Brehme, 63, has died. Brehme's 85th-minute penalty sealed West Germany's victory over Argentina in the 1990 World Cup final. Bayern Munich announced his death, calling him a "world champion and a very special person." The club will "always keep Andreas Brehme in our hearts."

images.alt_text: Franz Beckenbauer was one of only three men to win the World Cup as player and as a coach.

site_title: National Australia Bank’s quarterly profit falls on higher costs
summary: National Australia Bank reported a 3% drop in first-quarter cash profit to A$1.80 billion due to higher cost pressures and competitive lending. Revenue excluding markets and treasury income was flat, leading to a decrease in net interest margin. The bank's common equity tier 1 ratio stood at 12.0% as of December-end.

site_title: UOI H2 net profit falls 6% to S$17.3 million
summary: UOI, the general insurance arm of UOB, reported a net profit of S$17.3 million for the second half of FY2023, down 6% from the same period last year. Insurance revenue fell 14% to S$48 million, while non-underwriting income rose 20% to S$4.4 million. The company declared a final dividend of 8.5 Singapore cents per share and a special dividend of four cents per share. Total comprehensive income for H2 2023 came in at a profit of S$24.5 million after tax.

images.alt_text: Although net underwriting profit fell 38 per cent to S$3.5 million, this was more than offset by a rise in non-underwriting income to S$2.2 million, which turned profitable after the group recorded a loss of S$0.12 million in the corresponding period last year.
United Overseas Insurance, the general insurance arm of UOB,
Insurance revenue for UOI, the general insurance arm of UOB, grew 7.9 per cent to S$68.4 million for the nine months ended Sep 30, 2023.

site_title: US again casts veto of UN action in Israel-Hamas war
summary: The US has cast its third veto on a UN Security Council resolution calling for an immediate humanitarian ceasefire in Gaza, blocking a demand for an immediate ceasefire as it instead pushes for a temporary ceasefire linked to the release of hostages held by Hamas. The US veto was cast by Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield, citing concerns it could jeopardize ongoing negotiations between the US, Egypt, Israel, and Qatar to broker a pause in the war and hostage release. The resolution was approved by 13 council members, with Britain abstaining.

(Photo by JACK GUEZ / AFP)
Starlink’s network of low Earth orbit satellites can provide Internet to remote locations, or areas that have had normal communications infrastructure disabled.

Jordan's King Abdullah II speaks at a press conference, with US President Joe Biden, at the White House in Washington, United States, Feb 12, 2024.

site_title: A week of expert views on Singapore’s property markets
summary: Singapore's property market is expected to be analyzed by experts in a week-long series of articles. Topics include the best sectors for investment (residential, commercial, or industrial), the impact of market cooling measures, and the meaning of "sustainability" for the housing market. A panel discussion on February 24 will address questions such as whether it's the right time to buy, where first-time buyers should look, and how to navigate ABSD (Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty). The discussion will be held at the "Key to Success: Unlocking Real Estate Opportunities in the Year of the Dragon" seminar.

site_title: Is China a value trap?
summary: China shares are often labeled as value traps due to global macroeconomic factors and geopolitical tensions, but true value investors say fundamentals matter. A value share should have a low price-to-earnings ratio, pay a high dividend yield, have no debt, and trade below its tangible book value. Despite persistent bad news about China, shares that meet these criteria are not necessarily value traps. Instead, they require patience and careful consideration of the four key fundamentals.

images.alt_text: Chinese leaders are hunting for ways to jump-start the economy, which faces headwinds from a property slump, weak business confidence and persistent deflationary pressures.

The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) says it would treat all proposals seriously and implement feasible ones immediately, reiterating its intention to “resolutely maintain market stability and control market risks.”
China's five-year loan prime rate (LPR) was lowered by 25 basis points to 3.90 per cent from 4.20 per cent previously, while the one-year LPR was left unchanged at 3.45 per cent.

site_title: Youth appetite for gold rises as Chinese economy loses lustre
summary: China's post-Covid recovery is losing momentum, fueling a surge in demand for gold among younger consumers. The country's lacklustre economy, combined with soaring youth unemployment, has led to a growing appetite for gold as a safe investment. Master goldsmiths are adapting to this new trend by creating intricate, affordable pieces with added gems, appealing to millennials and Gen Z. Gold prices hit an all-time high in December, with younger consumers drawn to its perceived stability as a value of assets. This shift is seen as a significant change, with legacy jewellers such as Chow Tai Fook embracing social media and Chinese cultural identity to attract younger customers.

images.alt_text: DBS, OCBC and UOB held events to celebrate the Year of the Dragon.

epa11064243 Chinese tourists visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha at the Grand Palace complex in Bangkok, Thailand, 08 January 2024. EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT

Bullion has lost 0.5 per cent last week.

site_title: How to be a Budget winner
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to secure the country's future through targeted measures, but success relies on businesses and individuals taking responsibility for their own successes and failures. The key to being a "Budget winner" is self-agency, strategic thinking, and proactive planning. Leveraging support measures such as the Enterprise Support Package and Refundable Investment Credit scheme, businesses can tap into opportunities in areas like artificial intelligence and workforce transformation. By embracing innovation and taking calculated risks, businesses can reap financial rewards and contribute to the community and economy, ultimately strengthening Singapore's national reserves and prosperity.

images.alt_text: A person looks at buildings in Singapore, on Saturday, Feb. 17, 2024. Singapore expects its budget to swing back to a surplus in the fiscal year beginning April, as recent tax increases shore up revenue and help pay for social assistance seen as priority for the city-state's new generation of leaders. site_title: Jack Ma’s wife said to have bought three adjoining shophouses on Duxton Road
summary: Jack Ma's wife, Zhang Ying, has bought three adjoining shophouses on Duxton Road in Singapore for approximately S$45 million to S$50 million. The properties, with a total land area of 3,239 sq ft, have been refurbished and will be used for office and restaurant spaces. Market observers view the price as high, but note that the shophouses are in a discreet area and may be intended for private use. The sale comes as the shophouse market in Singapore has slowed sharply, with only 15 sales in the fourth quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: A row of shophouses in Amoy Street are among the shophouses that have been put for sale

site_title: Digital banks should count on more than ecosystems, tech to expand in South-east Asia
summary: Digital banks in South-east Asia must focus on more than just technology and ecosystems to succeed, according to market observers. By leveraging their ecosystems, digital banks can access customer data, attract underserved segments, and provide unique value propositions such as superior customer experience and better interest rates. However, competition from traditional banks and digital banks alike is strong, and the segments they target often have lower profit margins. To succeed, digital banks need to balance their tech advantages with a focus on governance, regulation, and risk management, and explore partnerships with merchants and distributors to expand their reach.

site_title: Sovereign wealth funds said to eye McDonald’s China investment
summary: Sovereign wealth funds, including Mubadala Investment, Qatar Investment Authority, and China Investment Corp, are in talks to jointly invest in McDonald's China operations as minority shareholders. The investment comes as the company seeks to expand its presence in the country, which is its second-largest market with over 5,500 restaurants. Negotiations are ongoing, with a potential agreement possibly within one to two months, but valuation remains a key hurdle. The deal could allow McDonald's to pare down its stake, which is currently held by Trustar Capital, a Citic consortium.

images.alt_text: Companies are seeking new horizons on the mainland as the country’s economic woes lead shoppers to pull back.
A McDonald’s fast food restaurant in New York, US, on Monday, Oct. 24, 2022. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The expansion plans would take its restaurant count to about 50,000 in over 100 countries, according to McDonald’s.

site_title: First Sponsor H2 net profit plunges 96.8% to S$1.9 million on lower property handover volume in China
summary: First Sponsor Group, a mixed property developer, reported a 96.8% plunge in second-half net profit to S$1.9 million due to lower property handover volume in China, primarily from The Pinnacle project. Revenue fell 52.9% year-over-year to S$147 million, driven by a 90.1% drop in property sales. Despite this, the group maintained a gross margin of 45.2% and declared a final dividend of S$0.031 per share for FY2023. The group expects a "substantial number" of projects to commence partial handovers in FY2024 if buying confidence returns.

images.alt_text: One of the trio of bungalows in Nassim Road that changed hands for a total of S$206.7 million this year. The transaction is among at least S$700 million of deals in GCB Areas for which buyers did not lodge caveats.
China's five-year loan prime rate (LPR) was lowered by 25 basis points to 3.90 per cent from 4.20 per cent previously, while the one-year LPR was left unchanged at 3.45 per cent.

site_title: Improved efficiency propels Dyna-Mac’s H2 profit up 84.7% to S$18.4 million
summary: Dyna-Mac, a mainboard-listed offshore oil-and-gas contractor, reported a 84.7% year-on-year increase in its second-half net profit to S$18.4 million, driven by improved efficiency and productivity. Revenue rose 21.2% to S$202.9 million. The company attributed its growth to intensified land use, productivity improvements, and cost controls. For the full year, net profit surged 118% to S$28.5 million, with revenue increasing 32.1% to S$385.2 million.

images.alt_text: Dyna-Mac remains optimistic about offshore oil and gas activities, and is looking to acquire new land to provide additional capacity.
Switching gears from tendering widely to engaging customers early on has paid off for Dyna-Mac chief executive officer, Lim Ah Cheng.

site_title: STB gave millions in grants for Taylor Swift concerts to generate major benefits for Singapore economy
summary: Taylor Swift's upcoming concerts in Singapore, from March 2 to March 9, received a grant of up to S$4 million from the Singapore Tourism Board to boost the local economy. The event is expected to generate significant benefits for the tourism sectors, including hospitality, retail, travel, and dining. With over 300,000 tickets sold, including a large number of international fans, the event is likely to have a positive impact on the city-state's economy. The exclusive arrangement was made in exchange for Swift agreeing not to perform elsewhere in South-east Asia during her tour.

images.alt_text: The billionaire singer has made economic waves throughout her record-shattering global tour, in a phenomenon dubbed “Swiftonomics”.
Taylor Swift’s relationship with Travis Kelce is captivating the NFL and popular culture this season.
The tour has been unleashed in China via some 7,000 screens raking in 95 million yuan at the box office – a boon for the industry even though it is not topping the chart.
Now, the famous couple is getting ready for a monumental weekend, with millions eager to follow along.
The Asia leg of Taylor Swift’s tour kicks off on Wednesday with the first of four planned shows, although it is the last, on Saturday, that’s causing the biggest stir.
Taylor Swift accepts the award for Album of the Year for "Midnights" during the 66th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles, California, Feb 4, 2024.

site_title: Canada’s slowing inflation rate bolsters bets on early rate cut
summary: Canada's annual inflation rate slowed to 2.9% in January, the first time below 3% in seven months, prompting bets for an early interest rate cut. Core price measures also eased, with the Bank of Canada's next policy announcement on March 6 expected to keep borrowing rates at 5%, but analysts say this could shift to a rate cut in April. The easing of prices across several categories gives confidence to the Bank of Canada that high interest rates are helping to cool price pressures.

images.alt_text: Receipts for retailers jump 0.8 per cent in December, the biggest increase since April.
Canada central bank’s business outlook indicator rises slightly to -3.2 in the fourth quarter, from -3.5 previously.
The number of homes trading hands rises 8.7 per cent from the previous month – the first gain since June.

site_title: Whirlpool sells 24% stake in India unit for US$468 million
summary: Whirlpool has sold 24% of its stake in its India unit for approximately US$468 million through its subsidiary in Mauritius, reducing its stake from 75% to 51%. The sale is part of the company's plan to reduce debt, with proceeds expected to settle by Wednesday. Whirlpool's profit has fallen for five consecutive quarters due to rising competition and price pressures. The company plans to use the sale proceeds to reduce its debt, citing the need to improve its financial position.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as early rate cut hopes fade; Walmart perks up
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, February 20, 2024, as hopes for early interest rate cuts dwindled. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 51.73 points, or 0.13%, to 38,576.26. This followed Walmart's upbeat earnings report, which lifted the retail sector. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 16.25 points, or 0.32%, and the Nasdaq down 95.81 points, or 0.61%.

site_title: Sabana Reit trustee stresses: EGM ‘not beneficial’ to internalisation progress at this point
summary: Sabana Reit's trustee has reiterated that an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to consider resolutions requisitioned by a group of unitholders is not beneficial at this point, citing substantial work already done on internalising the Reit's management function. The trustee expressed concerns over proposed resolutions, calling them confusing, inconsistent, and potentially placing the Reit in breach of legal considerations. The trustee urges unitholders to consider whether repeating the process would be in their interests, and to focus on the progress made so far in internalising the management function.

images.alt_text: What is the outlook for Reits and property trusts sector in 2024?
Singapore welcomed its first business combination of a special purpose acquisition company in 2023.

site_title: Airbus to set up centre for sustainable aviation in Singapore
summary: Airbus has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Singapore Economic Development Board to establish the Airbus Sustainable Aviation Hub in Seletar Aerospace Park. The centre will focus on sustainable aviation technologies, including decarbonisation through sustainable fuel and hydrogen, and will promote knowledge exchange and joint research initiatives with local enterprises and research institutions. The hub will also develop industry talent through internships and training courses. This move aligns with Singapore's Sustainable Air Hub Blueprint, aiming to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: A China Comac C919 aircraft during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore, Feb 18, 2024. Beijing wants to challenge the decades-long dominance of top plane-makers Airbus and Boeing while reducing its reliance on foreign technology.
A rendering of the JTC aeroSpace Four, which will be the first standard factory at the Seletar Aerospace Park that will feature green infrastructure solution.
After surviving the pandemic, airlines’ biggest challenge is reaching a goal to have net zero carbon emissions by 2050.
The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: TalkMed H2 net profit dips 2.8% to S$17.9 million despite revenue increase
summary: TalkMed Group reported a 2.8% drop in second-half earnings to S$17.9 million due to higher impairment loss, operating expenses, and employee benefits. Revenue increased 4.2% to S$46 million, driven by oncology revenue growth. The group's full-year net profit rose 5.3% to S$32.2 million. Despite a strong Singapore dollar, TalkMed faces competition for medical tourists and is impacted by the Cancer Drug List, which has reduced local patient numbers.

images.alt_text: Incorporated in 2011 and founded by Dr Djeng Shih Kien, SIAMH focuses on diagnosing and treating various diseases and health conditions.

One migrant worker dormitory operator that has shifted into the eldercare sector is TS Group, which is part of a new project exploring the development of apartments for seniors and live-in foreign worker caregivers.

site_title: The strange loyalty of Putin’s global fan club
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is unlikely to become an international pariah following the death of opposition leader Alexei Navalny, as he maintains friendly relations with leaders of powerful democracies, including China's Xi Jinping. Notably, Putin's admirers may soon lead the world's three largest democracies, with potential candidates including Indonesia's Prabowo Subianto, India's Narendra Modi, and the US's Donald Trump, who have all stood aside from international condemnation of Putin for reasons beyond realpolitik.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin attends a meeting with Omsk Region Acting Governor Vitaly Khotsenko at the Kremlin in Moscow, Russia August 28, 2023. Sputnik/Mikhail Klimentyev/Kremlin via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY.
A former KFC restaurant in Moscow re-opened under the brand Rostic's, after American firm Yum!Brands Inc sold its fastfood chain KFC in Russia to a local operator; April 2023.

site_title: Thai PM seeks emergency rate cut, pressuring central bank
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin urged the central bank to cut interest rates in an unscheduled meeting, citing a crisis in the nation's economy. The Bank of Thailand's Monetary Policy Committee is scheduled to meet on April 10, but Srettha called for an urgent meeting to consider reducing interest rates. The finance minister, who also heads the central bank, emphasized the need for action to address people's livelihood and problems. A response from the central bank was not provided.

images.alt_text: Thailand's GDP fell 0.6 per cent in the October to December quarter on a seasonally adjusted basis, the planning agency said on Monday, down from a revised 0.6 per cent rise in the third quarter.

site_title: Malaysia’s biggest lender Maybank announces new top management line-up
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest lender, announced new top management appointments. Muzaffar Hisham will become Islamic banking group CEO on March 1, succeeding Mohamed Rafique Merican. John Chong will take over as global banking group CEO, while Tuan Syed Ahmad Taufik Albar will lead community financial services. Steffano Ridwan will be appointed president director of Bank Maybank Indonesia, effective April 1. The changes aim to drive growth and adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: US dollar keeps a grip on 150 yen; China cut leaves yuan unruffled
summary: The US dollar index eased 0.15% to 104.13, maintaining its grip on the 150 yen, as investors became less certain about Japan's exit from ultra-low rates due to the country's recession. The yen has lost 7% in value this year. China cut its benchmark mortgage rate, but the yuan remained near a three-month low. The US dollar was steady at 150.185, supported by dwindling expectations of a prompt rate cut by the US Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which tracks the currency against six peers, was last little changed at 104.23, after rising 0.18 per cent the previous week.
The yen has touched 150 recently, putting the market on high alert to a possible intervention by Japanese authorities to weaken the yen.
The US dollar index, which measures the currency against six peers, is slightly lower at 104.6, just below a three-month high of 104.97 touched on Wednesday.

site_title: First Reit H2 DPU falls 6.1% to S$0.0124 on currency depreciation
summary: First Reit reported a 6.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0124 for the second half of 2023, due to lower distributable income and currency depreciation. The Reit's full-year DPU fell to S$0.0248, lower than the previous year. The decrease was attributed to higher financing costs and depreciation of the Indonesian rupiah and Japanese yen. Despite the decline, the Reit's overall financial position remains strong, with a gearing of 38.7% and a healthy interest coverage ratio.

images.alt_text: Some 13 STI constituents across six sectors are expected to benefit from Budget, says Maybank Securities and RHB.

Le Meridien Frankfurt Hotel, owned by First Sponsor Group in a joint venture with City Dveelopments and Tai Tak Estates. First Sponsor has declared a final dividend of S$0.032 per share for H2 FY2023.

site_title: Indonesia issues regulations requiring digital platforms to pay media for content
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has signed a regulation requiring digital platforms such as Meta Platforms (Facebook) and Alphabet Inc's (Google) to pay media companies for content. The regulation aims to level the playing field between media and big tech, promoting fair cooperation and providing a clearer framework for cooperation. The move follows similar regulations in Australia, where tech firms have signed deals with media outlets to compensate them for content. The Indonesian regulation takes effect in six months and will not harm content creators.

images.alt_text: For digital banks to succeed in the region, they will need to depend on more than their tech capabilities and ecosystems, say market observers.

site_title: India's food inflation to moderate in coming months, says government report
summary: India's retail inflation rate reached a three-month low of 5.1% in February, with food inflation rising 8.3% compared to 9.53% in December. The government expects inflation to moderate in the coming months due to healthy winter crops and manufacturing profitability. However, cereal and protein prices may continue to rise, and tight monetary conditions in developed countries could extend economic challenges. The government sees "bright" prospects for capital formation and household consumption in the next fiscal year, with economic activity expected to support growth.

site_title: SIC raps A&G, DBS for whitewash bungle, but it was Mapletree sponsor that gave sweeter terms
summary: The Securities Industry Council (SIC) has publicly rebuked Allen & Gledhill and DBS for breaching the Singapore Code on Take-overs and Mergers in their role as advisers to Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) during its merger with Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) in 2022. SIC found that MCT's manager was advised incorrectly on the need for a whitewash waiver, which was later added to the deal. Mapletree Investments, the sponsor, provided sweeter terms, including a cash option for minority investors, which appeased them. SIC decided not to take further action against the advisers, citing their prompt action to mitigate breaches and improved internal processes.

images.alt_text: Reit managers, sponsors should get in front of evolving investor attitudes on mergers
Reit mergers: Time for regulators to wake up
Mapletree Pan Asia Commcerical Trust's manager said its strength is underpinned by its core assets – the Mapletree Business City and VivoCity.

VivoCity, an asset under merged entity Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust. The Securities Industries Council says advisers to the deal leading up to its formation have breached the Singapore Code on Take-overs and Mergers.

site_title: About 29,000 nurses to each get up to S$100,000 in payouts over 20 years under new retention scheme
summary: Singapore's government has announced a new retention scheme for nurses, offering up to S$100,000 in payouts over 20 years to around 29,000 nurses working in public healthcare institutions. The Award for Nurses' Grace, Excellence and Loyalty (Angel) scheme starts in September and provides payouts every four to six years, ranging from S$20,000 to S$30,000. Eligible nurses will also receive a one-off recognition payout of S$5,000 to S$15,000, depending on their years of service. The scheme aims to retain nurses and address the shortage in the healthcare sector, which has seen a 30% growth in nursing intake numbers since 2013.

site_title: Aviation financing industry not fully recovered, says BOC Aviation CEO
summary: BOC Aviation CEO Steven Townend stated that the aviation financing industry has not fully recovered, unlike the airline and leasing industries, which have largely recovered from the pandemic. Townend noted that regions with large domestic capital markets, such as China and the US, have seen faster recovery in aviation financing, while smaller markets like India face challenges due to limited domestic capital markets. BOC Aviation is seizing this opportunity by increasing financial leasing activities, and Townend expects the recovery to be a gradual process.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Airshow will be held from Feb 20-25, with flying displays a highlight of the biennial event.

site_title: Rate cut bets not unreasonable but UK economy picking up, says BOE's Bailey
summary: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey said bets on interest rate cuts in 2024 were not unreasonable, while also noting signs of the UK economy picking up after falling into recession. Bailey repeated that the BOE would not need inflation to fall to 2% to cut rates, which he expects to happen between April and June. Investors slightly raised bets for a first BOE rate cut in June, and sterling slipped to its lowest level against the euro in a month.

images.alt_text: The Governor of the Bank of England, Andrew Bailey, attends a press conference in London, Britain, May 11, 2023. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls/Pool

site_title: Eurozone wage growth slowed in fourth quarter: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported that Eurozone wage growth slowed in the fourth quarter, falling to 4.5% from a record 4.7% in the previous quarter. This easing of wage growth is seen as a relief that inflation may not surge above the target. However, officials are still keen to wait for first-quarter 2024 data before deciding on interest rate cuts. ECB President Christine Lagarde has cautioned against hasty decisions, citing strong wage pressures and low productivity, which may slow inflation's fall.

images.alt_text: “Wage growth continues to be strong and is expected to become an increasingly important driver of inflation dynamics in the coming quarters,” ECB president Christine Lagarde says.

ECB policymaker Isabel Schnabel has pointed to a number of factors behind the eurozone’s long-running economic underperformance versus the US, including lower investment in technology, more red tape and more expensive energy.
“Lower energy commodity prices and weaker economic momentum set inflation on a steeper downward path than anticipated in the Autumn Forecast,” European Commission says.
A customer shops in a supermarket in Nice, France, August 18, 2022. REUTERS/Eric Gaillard/File photo
Sentix’s index for the eurozone rises to -12.9 points in February from -15.8 in January, above a reading of -15 estimated in a Reuters poll of analysts.
HCOB’s composite PMI for the bloc, compiled by S&P Global, rose to 47.9 in January from December’s 47.6, matching a preliminary estimate.
Inflation remains above the European Central Bank’s 2 per cent target, but well below the peak of 10.6 per cent recorded in October 2022 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent energy prices soaring.

site_title: B is for Budget and BT Property Week
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong delivered a budget with tax reliefs and social support, including revisions to annual value bands, which raise property tax thresholds and may result in lower tax bills for many homeowners. The two-tiered tax hike, designed as a wealth tax, has caused concern among private property owners, particularly older Singaporeans who rely on their homes as their primary asset. The government has also introduced concessions, such as a refund on Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) for seniors downgrading to lower-value properties.

images.alt_text: Is Meta’s exit from a grade A office building in downtown Singapore a foreshadowing of more vacancies to come?
Wee Cho Yaw's accomplishments stretch far beyond banking, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Residential rents are starting to come off their highs., writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Market players are watching closely to see if the government will award the Marina Gardens Crescent site to GuocoLand-Hong Leong group, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Walmart will buy TV maker Vizio for US$2.3 billion
summary: Walmart has agreed to buy TV maker Vizio for $2.3 billion in cash, expanding its advertising and media businesses. The deal gives Walmart access to Vizio's 18 million accounts, enhancing its potential connection to households. Vizio's operating system is praised for delivering immersive entertainment at affordable prices. The acquisition is part of Walmart's efforts to redefine the intersection of retail and entertainment, with the company reporting solid revenue growth of 5.7% to $173.4 billion in its fourth-quarter earnings.

images.alt_text: The talks come at a time Walmart is increasingly monetising its reach and troves of shopper data to sell ads on its properties.

site_title: China restricts quant fund Lingjun in effort to boost market
summary: China's Shenzhen and Shanghai stock exchanges have restricted quant fund Lingjun Investment from buying and selling for three days due to orderly trading rules. The move follows rapid stock market declines on Monday after Lingjun's sell orders coincided with the sell-off. The fund, which manages over $11.2 billion, is one of China's biggest quant funds. Regulators aim to revive market confidence and signal a shift towards long-term investments.

images.alt_text: If the drip feed of bad news about China persists, there is little reason for the market to push up the share prices.

The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) says it would treat all proposals seriously and implement feasible ones immediately, reiterating its intention to “resolutely maintain market stability and control market risks.”
A swath of Chinese stocks in Hong Kong surged in response to holiday data showing a 61 per cent gain in rail trips from a year earlier.

site_title: Indonesia’s new green investment rulebook includes coal power plants
summary: Indonesia has launched a revised "taxonomy" or green investment rulebook, which categorizes coal-fired power plants used in nickel facilities as part of the global transition to a green economy. The taxonomy, which uses a traffic light system, labels captive coal power plants as "amber" if they meet certain criteria, such as being built before 2031 and shutting down by 2050. Environmentalists have criticized the move, citing the significant carbon emissions from such plants. The taxonomy also labels mining of critical minerals, like nickel, as "green" if it meets requirements, and investments in early retirement of existing coal power plants as "green".

images.alt_text: A fisherman looks at the Suralaya coal-fired power plant in Cilegon, Indonesia, Oct 31, 2023.
Coal is transported on barges in Samarinda, East Kalimantan in January 11, 2022.

Out of the five investment areas the document has set out, financing the early phase-out of coal has been the more contentious one for the local banks, as the commercial viability of such transactions has not been worked out.

site_title: BAIC’s EV brand to launch first Huawei-backed sedan in 2024
summary: BAIC BluePark, the electric vehicle arm of Beijing Automotive Group, plans to launch its first Huawei-backed sedan in China by 2024. The high-end intelligent sedan will cater to premium mobility experiences and marks Huawei's expansion into the EV market. The partnership signals Huawei's growing presence in the industry, following the success of its EV marque Aito, which topped Li Auto sales in January. This move also indicates Huawei's efforts to compete with established EV makers like Tesla.

images.alt_text: Beijing Hyundai Motor's decision to produce ARCFOX vehicles is “to put together a bridgehead in the renewed push into the Chinese market by setting up a EV production line.

site_title: The twilight of the American sommelier
summary: The American sommelier, once a staple in high-end restaurants, is becoming increasingly expendable due to the post-pandemic restaurant industry's shift towards cost-cutting measures. The pandemic led to a severe labor shortage, raising wages and increasing costs, making it challenging for restaurants to maintain dedicated wine professionals. Many restaurants now rely on hybrid staff or consultants to manage wine lists, resulting in shorter, simpler, and less inventive lists. Experts say the sommelier is now a luxury, with the industry's focus on efficiency and cost-cutting rather than warm hospitality.

images.alt_text: Towering in the heart of T3’s transit area, the new store – by far the largest of Lotte Duty Free’s in the world – sports an 8-metre LED media wall and an all-glass facade.
FILE PHOTO: Bottles of Champagne are seen on display for sale in a wine shop in Paris, France, December 20, 2022. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, February 20, 2024 (Ep 5)
summary: China lowered its mortgage prime rate to boost the property sector, while iron futures plummeted to a three-month low. In related news, the Singapore Exchange will issue S$300 million multi-currency notes. The move comes as stocks in the region struggle, with Singapore shares falling at the opening bell and the STI down 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 50 to 48.
The Nikkei opened flat on Tuesday to stay below but close to topping its 1989 record high.

site_title: CMA CGM says ship transited Red Sea under French naval escort
summary: CMA CGM's container ship Jules Verne successfully transited the Red Sea under French naval escort on February 19, after suspending crossings due to security risks. The decision was made following attacks on vessels by Houthi militants in Yemen. Other major shipping firms have also suspended voyages via the Red Sea, disrupting trade between Asia and Europe. The ship had sailed south from the Suez Canal on February 12 and was escorted by the frigate Alsace.

site_title: Why investors should not fear higher-for-longer rates
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers may afford to ease interest rates, but inflation is unlikely to drop as dramatically as expected. Instead, rates will likely stay higher for longer to meet the 2% inflation target. Higher interest rates can actually be beneficial, driving economic resilience and boosting the economy through a "virtuous circle." In contrast, ultra-low rates, as seen in Japan, can lead to stagnant growth and poor investor sentiment. As structural forces such as globalization, tech wars, and climate change drive higher business costs and consumer prices, investors should expect good returns from assets like equities, real estate, commodities, and longer-duration bonds.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was flat at US$2,018.03 per ounce, as of 0341 GMT on Tuesday.
The US dollar index, which tracks the currency against six peers, was last little changed at 104.23, after rising 0.18 per cent the previous week.

site_title: ValueMax H2 profit rises 44.4% to S$27.8 million on higher revenue
summary: ValueMax has reported a 44.4% increase in second-half net profit to S$27.8 million, driven by a 34.1% rise in revenue to S$179.2 million. The company also announced a final dividend of 2.20 Singapore cents per share for FY2023. Revenue growth was led by its retail and trading of jewellery and gold business, pawnbroking business, and moneylending business. Despite the increase, earnings per share and cost of sales rose due to inflation. The company faces a challenging business environment with volatile gold prices and heightened competition in the moneylending sector.

images.alt_text: ValueMax said it will continue to explore acquisition opportunities  and suitable locations to grow its network of pawnshops and retail outlets, as well as its moneylending business.
Mainboard-listed ValueMax Group intends to cash in on rising demand for more sustainable jewellery, says chief marketing officer and executive director Yeah Lee Ching.

site_title: LG Display draws interest in China plant sale
summary: LG Display has received letters of intent from four to five parties, including BOE Technology Group and CSOT, to buy its Guangzhou, China LCD plant for around 1.5 trillion won (S$1.5 billion) or higher. The sale is part of LG Display's efforts to focus on growing its OLED panel business, which is expected to be less competitive. A bidder is expected to be selected by the first half of this year, and the company is planning to taper off its lower-margin LCD business.

site_title: Swedish landlord Oscar Properties’ CEO, CFO suddenly depart
summary: Swedish property developer Oscar Properties has faced two separate bankruptcy claims from creditors amid a financing crunch in the Swedish real estate sector. CEO Carl Janglin and CFO Magnus Thimgren are leaving their positions, with Janglin remaining until a successor is appointed. The company postponed its fourth-quarter earnings report, citing "number of challenges" in the period, after selling a portfolio of properties at a discount in January. Oscar Properties' struggles come as the Swedish real estate sector faces a dramatic financing crunch.

site_title: Why Taiwan’s 2024 elections matter from Beijing to Washington
summary: Taiwan's 2024 elections are crucial in setting the course for US-China relations, as Chinese President Xi Jinping views eventual control of the self-governed island as a national security issue. The US has positioned itself to stop any military move, with President Joe Biden stating the US would defend Taiwan if attacked. Taiwanese voters will choose between a ruling party determined to maintain independence and an opposition party seeking closer ties with China. The election outcome could fuel or dampen tensions, with a Democratic Progressive Party win maintaining the status quo and a Kuomintang victory potentially de-escalating tensions.

images.alt_text: The island is home to industry giants such as Foxconn, the world’s biggest contract electronics manufacturer, which assembles products for major brands including Apple and Huawei.
Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Lai Ching-te favors warmer ties with the US and has been branded a separatist by China.

A Long March-2C rocket, carrying the Einstein Probe satellite, lifts off from the Xichang Satellite Launch Center in Xichang, in southwestern China's Sichuan province on January 9, 2024. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Boeing says Thai Airways to buy 45 Dreamliners
summary: Thai Airways has ordered 45 Boeing Dreamliner aircraft, with the 787-9 model selected to support its long-term strategy to renew and expand its fleet. The deal, worth around $13.16 billion at list prices, aims to cut carbon emissions and support the growth of Thailand's economy. The acquisition is part of Boeing's efforts to showcase its latest fuel-efficient engines and build on its partnership with Thai Airways.

images.alt_text: Thai Airways is boosting its requirements to as many as 80 Boeing wide-body 787 Dreamliner jets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 20)
summary: Chen Qingyuan, a Cambodian passport holder, faces six new charges for alleged forgery and conspiracy to cheat StanChart in the S$3 billion money laundering case in Singapore. SIA reported a 4.9% increase in net profit to S$659 million for the third quarter, while Sembcorp Industries posted a 15% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$412 million. HDB and condo rents fell 0.7% in January, while an eight-storey hotel in Geylang is up for sale at S$120 million.

site_title: Protecting the welfare of the seafarer
summary: A recent conference organized by the UK-based Seafarers Hospital Society discussed seafarer welfare, with a focus on protecting the health and wellbeing of maritime workers. The conference highlighted the importance of benchmarking and data-led solutions to improve industry standards. A keynote speaker, Captain Kuba Szymanski, emphasized the need for big improvements in mental health support and called for increased transparency and collaboration between stakeholders. The conference also addressed the issue of seafarers being held hostage, with 29 shipping industry groups expressing concern for the 25 seafarers held by the Houthis on the Galaxy Leader.

images.alt_text: Apart from a spike in freight rates caused by the lines passing on the additional costs of longer voyages, the market has tilted in the lines’ favour.

site_title: Global healthcare: From laggards to opportunities
summary: The global healthcare sector is experiencing an increase in utilisation rates, driven by interest in weight-loss drugs, which have the potential to reach $80 billion in sales by 2030. Despite a post-Covid reset, with declining demand for vaccines and therapeutics, the sector is expected to continue growing due to long-term drivers such as ageing demographics. Top-performing segments include healthcare equipment and supplies, pharmaceuticals, and biotechnology, with companies like Intuitive Surgical and Novo Nordisk generating significant returns. Investors can consider exchange-traded funds or actively managed vehicles to gain exposure to the sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A company logo is seen at a Pfizer office in Puurs, Belgium, December 2, 2022. REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: AstraZeneca Diabetes drug Farxiga (dapagliflozin) is displayed at a pharmacy in Provo, Utah, U.S. May 28, 2020. REUTERS/George Frey/File Photo
Abbott says the protein shake is first among the range of products lined up to be launched under its new brand, called Protality.
The investment by Novo, Europe’s most valuable company by market capitalisation, is the largest in Denmark by a private sector organisation, a spokesperson said.

site_title: Germany to approve cannabis Bill this week in legalisation drive
summary: Germany is set to approve a cannabis legalization bill this week, paving the way for its implementation on April 1. The law, which passed the lower house of parliament by Friday, Feb 23 at the latest, will allow adults to possess up to 25 grams of cannabis, grow up to three plants for private consumption, and cultivate cannabis in non-profit clubs with 500 members. The move is seen as a significant step towards a broader legalization of marijuana in Europe's largest economy, despite opposition from some lawmakers.

images.alt_text: People take part in a march to call for the legalisation of cannabis in the streets of Shibuya in Tokyo on May 4, 2023. Japan has passed a Bill to legalise cannabis-based medicines in a landmark revision of its stringent drug laws.
Smoking of marijuana and its use in any other forms for recreation will be banned under the draft bill.

site_title: IHG to return over US$1 billion to shareholders this year after stellar 2023
summary: IHG, the owner of Holiday Inn, reported slightly better-than-expected annual room revenue and plans to return over US$1 billion to shareholders in 2024 due to strong travel demand. The company aims for high single-digit growth in fee revenue through increasing revenue per room and hotel additions. CEO Elie Maalouf attributes the growth to the travel industry's long-term drivers and IHG's strong brand portfolio. Despite economic uncertainties, other travel operators like TUI and European airlines have strong outlooks for 2024.

images.alt_text: Holiday Inn owner IHG’s global revenue per available room, a key performance indicator for the hotel industry, rises 17 per cent in the second quarter.

site_title: Asia: Stocks struggle even as China slashes rates
summary: Asian stocks struggled on Tuesday despite a 25 basis point interest rate cut in China, which was seen as a significant move by policymakers. The cut, which lowered the five-year loan prime rate to 3.95%, failed to boost investor confidence, with markets instead focusing on the lack of further stimulus measures. The Shanghai Composite fell 0.7% and blue chips declined 0.6%. Global markets were also influenced by the US, with US Treasury yields rising and S&P 500 futures 0.2% lower.

images.alt_text: Passersby walk past electronic screens displaying Japan's Nikkei share average outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato

site_title: The Ant-Men of South-east Asia
summary: Startups in South-east Asia are pivoting away from insect farming due to slow regulatory developments and sluggish consumer adoption. Some have shifted focus to producing biomaterials for health supplements and animal feed. Meanwhile, delivery services are facing challenges, with growth slowing down and potential for closure or consolidation. Companies like Grab and GoTo are exploring merger talks, while the parent of online retailer Wish is selling its assets for $173 million.

images.alt_text: Over at Grab, Singapore’s competition watchdog is further scrutinising its takeover of taxi operator Trans-cab, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
VCs, too, have raised money for their funds, but it isn’t all cheery there, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
The rise of fintech in the region has partly been driven by the opportunity to serve the "underbanked" population, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
Lazada's recent layoffs suggest its plans to IPO may not be on the cards any time soon, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.

According to impacted staff, the layoffs were part of a “change of direction” by Lazada, with the former employees noting that such a move came as no surprise, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.

site_title: Swiss watch exports struggle as luxury slowdown persists
summary: Swiss watch exports rose 3.1% in January to 1.9 billion Swiss francs, but growth slowed due to weak demand for luxury and mid-priced watches amid economic and geopolitical concerns. Exports to the US rose 2.2%, while mainland China exports gained 5%, but shipments to Hong Kong fell 4.7%. The number of high-end watches exported fell 4.5% in January, while low-end watches surged 5.5%. The luxury watch industry, which employs 60,000 people, is expected to unveil new models at the annual Watches and Wonders fair in Geneva in April.

images.alt_text: Urwerk's UR-230 Eagle watch. With a staff of 25, the company produces just over 200 watches annually at two ateliers in Geneva and Zurich.
The small ID Geneve start-up launched in 2020, vowing to make high-end watches with a climate- and environmentally-friendly circular production approach using non-traditional materials.
Swiss watch exports are boosted by sales in their largest market, the US, where they rise 35.1 per cent for the full year.
These watches from the collection will be on offer at Centurion New York.
Cracks are appearing in the market for new watches; while the very high end is holding up, the mid-market is weakening.
Vacheron Constantin's Overseas Quartz.

site_title: Europe car sales jump 11% in January on pent-up demand
summary: Europe's passenger-car deliveries rose 11% in January to 1.02 million units, driven by order backlogs and demand for electric cars, which made up 11.9% of total deliveries. However, carmakers face challenges as economies in Germany, the UK, and France slow, adding to consumer concerns. Analysts predict a marginal increase in electric vehicle market share to 16% this year, citing consumer apathy and government incentives being rolled back. This recovery will get more challenging as vehicle output normalizes and orders soften.

images.alt_text: The high cost of EVs has become a significant barrier to broader mass adoption for zero-emission cars.

site_title: SIA Q3 earnings up 4.9% to S$659 million as North Asia markets fully reopen to robust passenger demand
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 4.9% increase in net profit to S$659 million for the third quarter of 2023, driven by robust passenger demand in North Asian markets as China, Hong Kong, Japan, and Taiwan reopened. Revenue rose 4.9% to S$5.1 billion, with passenger flown revenue increasing 10.6% to S$4.2 billion. The group expects a return to pre-pandemic capacity levels within FY2025, despite increased competition and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: The new SQ310 service will operate five times weekly on the national carrier’s Airbus A350-900 aircraft on Mondays, Thursdays, Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays, depending on regulatory approval.
Organised by Experia Events, the Singapore Airshow will feature trade exhibitors from over 1,000 companies.
Within the group, the flagship airline’s revenue passenger-kilometres rose 14.3 per cent to 9.6 billion, from 8.4 billion year on year.
COSCO SHIPPING has the best YTD total returns for 2024 among transportation stocks on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Record Japan profits show Nikkei is primed for all-time high
summary: Japanese companies have logged record quarterly profits, with net income rising 46% to a record 13.9 trillion yen, driven by strong earnings from exporters like Toyota Motor Corp. and domestic firms benefiting from inflation. The rally has pushed the Nikkei 225 index near a historic peak, with many analysts raising their price targets for the stock gauge. Overseas investors remain bullish, citing improved corporate governance and cost-cutting measures, with some firms predicting higher full-year profits.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei opened flat on Tuesday to stay below but close to topping its 1989 record high.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise after China cuts mortgage reference rate; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 3,244.06, driven by China's unexpected cut of its five-year loan prime rate, which aims to stabilize equity markets and boost economic recovery. Regional markets were mixed, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 0.6%, while South Korea's Kospi fell 0.8%. Local stocks including Seatrium and OCBC Bank rose, while Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust fell. The government's cautious approach reflects a shift towards achieving technological self-sufficiency and macro-financial stability.

images.alt_text: Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.
China's five-year loan prime rate (LPR) was lowered by 25 basis points to 3.90 per cent from 4.20 per cent previously, while the one-year LPR was left unchanged at 3.45 per cent.

site_title: Malaysia’s January exports exceed forecast to rise 8.7%, first expansion in 10 months
summary: Malaysia's exports grew 8.7% year-over-year in January, exceeding forecasts, driven by higher shipments of petroleum products and manufactured goods. The country's total trade increased 13.3% to RM234.7 billion, with a trade balance surplus of RM10.1 billion. Economists expect exports to continue growing, supported by demand from ASEAN countries and the US, but with a gradual recovery due to tepid global demand and China's economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the Bandar Malaysia High-Speed Rail station in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
Malaysian ringgit has dropped nearly 4 per cent this year.
Bank Negara governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour said Malaysia’s exports remained subdued over the quarter due to prolonged weakness in external demand amid strong imports.

site_title: US recession nowhere in sight, but inflation may prove more stubborn
summary: The US economy narrowly avoided a recession in 2023, with second-half GDP growth accelerating relative to the first half. Despite signs of slowdown, such as declining industrial sales and residential housing construction, US employment remained firm and household debt service burden was near its lowest level since 1980. Fiscal support from the US Infrastructure Act and Inflation Reduction Act helped preserve jobs, and corporate America chose to maintain its workforce at the expense of profitability. Looking ahead, economists expect the US economy to slow further in 2024 but avoid a recession, driven by firming industrial and construction sectors and election-year government spending.

site_title: Malaysia's ex-PM Mahathir still in hospital, recovering from infection
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 98, is still in the hospital recovering from an unspecified infection. He has been treated at the National Heart Institute since January 26 and is currently being treated and recovering, according to his spokesperson. The spokesperson clarified rumors about Mahathir's condition, stating he is not in critical condition. No discharge date has been announced, but photos show Mahathir sitting in a chair reading a newspaper, indicating a slow recovery.

site_title: Money laundering accused faces six new charges for alleged forgery and conspiracy to cheat StanChart
summary: Chen Qingyuan, a Cambodian passport holder and one of 10 foreign nationals involved in a S$3 billion money laundering case in Singapore, has been slapped with six new charges for forgery and conspiracy to cheat Standard Chartered Bank (StanChart). The charges allege that Chen instigated the forgery of electronic records in September 2021 to show StanChart that his purported girlfriend had legitimate sources of wealth. The new charges bring Chen's total to 10, with over S$20 million worth of his assets seized or issued prohibition of disposal orders.

images.alt_text: Su Wenqiang now faces 11 charges in Singapore court.

Six of the new charges alleged that Su Wenqiang used around S$476,700 in proceeds from operating an unlawful remote gambling service in the Philippines to purchase luxury goods, jewellery and alcohol.
Vang Shuiming (left) and Su Wenqiang are among the 10 foreign nationals accused in the money laundering case, which has seen more than S$3 billion in assets seized.
A row of shophouses in Amoy Street are among the shophouses that have been put for sale
Chen is one of 10 individuals embroiled in the S$2.8 billion money laundering case. He faces charges involving over S$8 million.
In August last year, Su Jianfeng was charged with possessing some S$17 million worth of in cash, which were benefits from unlawful remote gambling activities.
Chen is one of the 10 accused in the S$2.8 billion money laundering case, which first came to light in August this year.

site_title: Much ado about foreign buying of Singapore homes
summary: Foreigners buying residential assets in Singapore have increased in the Central Region (CCR) due to high-net-worth individuals and families seeking safe investment homes for capital preservation and appreciation. The doubling of the Additional Buyer’s Stamp Duty (ABSD) rate from 30% to 60% for foreign buyers in April 2023 has effectively reduced demand. The government's pre-emptive measure may have been necessary to prevent an imbalance in the market and marginalize Singaporeans' housing aspirations. The higher ABSD rate has resulted in fewer foreign buyers, leading to a decrease in demand for CCR properties.

images.alt_text: Top views shots of Cairnhill estate and Orchard Road area.

site_title: Sustainable aviation fuel: What is it and why is it making flights pricier?
summary: Singapore to impose levy on flights starting from 2026, requiring airlines to use sustainable aviation fuel. The levy amount varies based on distance and class of travel, with estimates of S$3 for short flights to Bangkok and S$16 for flights to London. The aim is to increase green fuel use to 3-5% by 2030, in line with the country's target of 1% of all jet fuel used by 2026.

images.alt_text: SIA and Scoot say sustainable fuels are critical to the group’s goals of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.
Singapore's 2030 target for reducing aviation sector emissions includes operations at both Changi and Seletar Airports.
Solar panels deployed at Singapore's Kusu Island. The country is committed to accelerate its shift to low-carbon energy sources.
The revamped departure hall at Changi Airport Terminal 2 on Nov 1, 2023.

site_title: Stock markets are driving a new American century
summary: The US is experiencing a resurgence in its financial dominance, with publicly traded US firms accounting for 44.9% of global market capitalization. The dominance is attributed to the decline of China's stock market and the European Union's economic struggles. The rise of tech companies, particularly in the US, is also contributing to the growth of US equities. As tech continues to rise in importance, it is expected to favor US public markets, with major US tech companies selling to the entire world and dominating US listings. Despite concerns about America's global influence, the US's financial dominance is expected to continue, with US markets and companies leading in various financial markets.

images.alt_text: Microsoft, through its partnership with OpenAI, is seen as one of the biggest beneficiaries of AI.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 69.92 points, or 0.18 per cent, at the open to 37,975.37.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Breezy Bitcoin reclaims US$1 trillion crown
summary: Bitcoin has reclaimed its spot as the world's largest cryptocurrency, surpassing a market value of $1 trillion for the first time since 2021. The cryptocurrency has surged 22% this year, reaching a price of $52,005. The US regulatory approval of spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs) has contributed to the market's growth, with $60,000 in Bitcoin added in the first month of their launch. The sector has also seen robust crypto trading volumes, with centralised exchanges recording a 4.4% increase in January. Analysts expect Bitcoin to hit all-time highs by mid-2025, with some predicting a peak of $150,000.

images.alt_text: The entrance of the world’s largest cryptocurrency into the world’s largest stock market “marks the end of the beginning of Bitcoin’s maturation and growing-up phase.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Worldcoin’s white paper on its website says that, over the next 15 years, a total of 10 billion of the tokens will be released into the market.
Dogecoin and shiba inu, the eighth and 15th largest cryptocurrencies respectively, often experience wild price swings.

site_title: Chinese tourists flock to South-east Asia as overseas travel bounces back
summary: Chinese tourists flocked to Southeast Asia's tourist hotspots during the Lunar New Year break, with visitor numbers and spending exceeding pre-Covid levels in destinations like Singapore, Thailand, and Malaysia. Visa-free access boosted traffic, signaling a robust travel revival since Beijing lifted strict Covid restrictions. The increase provides relief to countries relying on Chinese spending, but the outlook for a sustained recovery is overshadowed by a sluggish mainland economy and volatile financial markets.

images.alt_text: epa10883323 Chinese tourists and others visit the Emerald Buddha Temple inside of the Grand Palace in Bangkok, Thailand, 26 September 2023. Thailand started the five-month visa exemption scheme for Chinese and Kazakh visitors effective from 25 September 2023 to 29 February 2024, with the aim to generate tourism revenue.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK
Per-capita tourism revenue over the eight-day festival in China this year slumps 9.5 per cent versus a similar timespan in 2019.

site_title: Lockbit cybercrime gang disrupted by international police operation
summary: The Lockbit cybercrime gang, notorious for holding victims' data hostage, has been disrupted in a rare international law enforcement operation led by Britain's National Crime Agency and the US Federal Bureau of Investigation. The operation, known as "Operation Cronos," has taken control of the gang's extortion website. Lockbit and its affiliates have hacked major organizations such as Boeing and ICBC, making money by stealing sensitive data and threatening to leak it unless a ransom is paid. The operation is ongoing and developing, marking a significant blow to the gang's operations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man holds a laptop computer as cyber code is projected on him in this illustration picture taken on May 13, 2017. REUTERS/Kacper Pempel/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Barclays aims to cut costs by £2 billion in bid to boost returns
summary: Barclays aims to cut costs by £2 billion to boost returns above 12% by 2026. The bank achieved a 9% return on tangible equity in 2023 and plans to return £10 billion of capital to shareholders. Barclays is reorganizing into five new operating divisions and will reduce costs through a major cost-cutting drive. The move follows months of speculation about the bank's future direction.

images.alt_text: A Barclays bank branch in London. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
Barclays has pledged US$1 trillion of sustainable and transition finance by 2030.
Barclays also expects “energy clients to produce transition plans or decarbonisation strategies” by 2025.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows signage on a branch of Barclays Bank in London, Britain, March 17, 2023.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo
Barclays has one of the lowest valuations among peers, with shares down by around 24 per cent in the last year, driven in part by a hefty disposal of stock by a top investor, Qatar Holding.

site_title: Higher training allowance could entice more workers to reskill before it’s too late
summary: Singapore has introduced a new SkillsFuture Level-Up Programme to encourage workers aged 40 and above to reskill before it's too late. The programme offers a monthly training allowance of up to 50% of their last-drawn pay, capped at S$3,000, and provides a S$4,000 top-up in SkillsFuture credits. The move aims to address the challenges faced by professionals, managers, and executives (PMEs), particularly older ones, who are becoming increasingly vulnerable due to economic restructuring and technological advancements.
