The programme is seen as a timely intervention to support workers in upgrading their skills and staying relevant in the job market.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024: Upskilling package reflects urgency to protect mature workers

site_title: Star plunges on risk Sydney casino license may be stripped
summary: The New South Wales state gaming regulator has launched a second inquiry into Star Entertainment Group's suitability to operate its Sydney casino, potentially leading to the license being stripped. The 2022 inquiry found lax anti-money laundering controls, flouting China's capital controls, and encouraging problem gamblers. The regulator has expressed concerns over Star's ability to hold a license, raising the possibility of the company losing its license. The stock price plummeted 26% in Sydney trading, wiping out A$1.3 billion in value. A decision on the license is expected by May 31.

images.alt_text: The Star casino, operated by Echo Entertainment Group Ltd., stands in Sydney, Australia, on Friday, March 16, 2012. Crown Ltd. last month doubled its stake in rival Echo Entertainment, owner of the only casino in Sydney, and sought regulatory approval to buy more. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, SGX, Gallant Venture, GHY Culture, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: Sembcorp Industries posted a 15% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$412 million for the second half of 2023. The Singapore Exchange plans to issue S$300 million worth of notes with a 3.45% interest rate. Gallant Venture and GHY Culture & Media expect net losses for the full year, citing higher finance costs and foreign exchange losses. Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager faces a winding-up application after unitholders approved its removal.

site_title: China cuts mortgage reference rate more than expected to revive property market
summary: China lowered its five-year loan prime rate (LPR) by 25 basis points to 3.95% from 4.2%, and the one-year LPR remained unchanged at 3.45%, in an effort to stimulate credit demand and revive the property market. The move, the largest cut since 2019, is expected to provide support to risk-proxy currencies, including the Australian dollar. However, the impact on sustained momentum remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Hainan, China’s southernmost province with a 10 million population, cut the down payment to 20 per cent from 25 per cent.
The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) in Beijing, China.
The government’s efforts to get overseas companies to return after Covid are falling short, and more will be needed if Beijing is to succeed in its aims.
Authorities are struggling to arrest a slowdown in China’s property market, which saw new home sales last month tumble 34.2 per cent from a year earlier.
Chinese leaders are hunting for ways to jump-start the economy, which faces headwinds from a property slump, weak business confidence and persistent deflationary pressures.

site_title: Ringgit tanks to 26-year low; central bank maintains economic prospects remain positive
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell to a 26-year low of 4.79 against the US dollar, its weakest point since the Asian financial crisis in 1998. The currency has depreciated by over 4% against the greenback since January and 2.6% against the Singdollar. Despite this, Bank Negara governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour maintained that Malaysia's economic growth remains positive, driven by external demand and strong domestic spending, with a forecast of 4-5% growth in 2024.

images.alt_text: Malaysian ringgit has dropped nearly 4 per cent this year.

site_title: What’s so special about a rainbow-check scarf?
summary: Acne Studios' rainbow-check Vally scarf, introduced in 2019, has become a ubiquitous fashion trend worldwide, sold at over 380 locations and worn by people from various backgrounds. Despite its high price tag of $320, the scarf has been replicated and sold at lower costs, with some consumers opting for DIY versions. While some have criticized the style's prevalence, others praise its unique design and versatility, with some even using it as a status symbol, with one creator joking that seeing the scarf in their neighborhood indicates a rising rent.

images.alt_text: Preloved fashion sale raises S$8,045 for charity

site_title: Michelangelo's David gets spa treatment in Florence
summary: Michelangelo's iconic statue of David at the Accademia Gallery in Florence undergoes a bi-monthly cleaning process to preserve its condition. Using a portable vacuum and synthetic fibre brush, Italian restorer Eleonora Pucci gently dusts the 5.1-meter sculpture, ensuring the Carrara marble remains free of dust deposits that can compromise its lustre. The meticulous cleaning process, which takes at least half a day, is part of the museum's effort to maintain the Renaissance icon's integrity and dignity, with the goal of preserving it for future generations.

images.alt_text:
TOPSHOT - Italian restorer Eleonora Pucci cleans Michelangelo's statue of David using a backpack vacuum and synthetic fibre brush at the Galleria dell'Accademia, in Florence on February 19, 2024. Michelangelo's masterpiece received a delicate beauty treatment on Monday, part of routine maintenance on one of the world's most recognisable nudes.

Every two months, the marble sculpture of a muscular and steely-eyed David -- completed by a 29-year-old Michelangelo in 1504 -- undergoes the careful cleaning from his home within Florence's Accademia Gallery, where it has resided for over 150 years. (Photo by Tiziana FABI / AFP)

site_title: Gold holds ground as focus turns to Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$2,018.03 per ounce on Tuesday, despite a stronger dollar and elevated Treasury yields, as investors awaited the minutes of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting for clues on interest rate cut timing. US gold futures rose 0.3% and the dollar index increased 0.1%, making greenback-priced bullion less appealing to overseas buyers. Analysts expect the minutes to have limited impact on gold prices, which may remain technically driven in the near term.

images.alt_text: Bullion has lost 0.5 per cent last week.

site_title: South Korea doctors walk off job over medical school slots
summary: In South Korea, over 1,600 trainee doctors walked off the job to protest a government plan to increase medical school slots by 2,000, aiming to alleviate a shortage of doctors. The move has caused some hospitals to delay surgeries, and the government has ordered more than 700 trainee doctors to return to work. The protest, led by the Korean Medical Association, claims the plan won't address underlying issues like working conditions and lack of specialists in lower-paying fields.

images.alt_text: epa11151511 Doctor protesters hold placards reading 'Stop Populism medical policy', during a protest against the government's medical policy, near the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, 14 Febriaru 2024. Members of Gyonggi-do Medical Association of doctor protesters gathered to oppose government plans to increase the number of students at medical schools.  EPA-EFE/JEON HEON-KYUN

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts cut Elite Commercial Reit targets after factoring in  vacancies, lower payout ratio
summary: Analysts have lowered their target prices for Elite Commercial Reit after the real estate investment trust reported a 40.9% drop in distribution per unit for the second half of 2023. The drop was attributed to a marginally enlarged unit base and lower payout ratio amid macroeconomic uncertainty. Despite this, analysts maintain "add" and "buy" recommendations, citing the Reit's attractive dividend yield and stable cash flow. Target prices have been reduced by 22-24% with some analysts expecting potential upside of 43.4% from the current price.

images.alt_text: Revenue and net property income are higher year on year.
Great Western House, Birkenhead. The 58 properties have a total net lettable area of 1.3 million square feet, and include Great Western House in Birkenhead (pictured), and a building in Newport Road,
Great Western House, Birkenhead, one of the properties in Elite Commercial Reit's portfolio. The overall portfolio's valuation as at Dec 1, 2023 stands at £412.5 million.

site_title: Made-in-China airliner seeks buyers at Singapore Airshow
summary: China's COMAC showcased its C919 aircraft at the Singapore Airshow, seeking international buyers to challenge the dominance of Airbus and Boeing. The single-aisle model made its maiden flight outside China and attracted a contract from China's Tibet Airlines to buy 40 C919s and 10 ARJ21s. However, finding a major carrier buyer may be difficult due to the "made-in-China" stigma, and Boeing will be absent from the airshow following a recent safety crisis. The airshow is expected to draw 50,000 trade attendees, marking a recovery in air travel after the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Singapore's 2030 target for reducing aviation sector emissions includes operations at both Changi and Seletar Airports.
After surviving the pandemic, airlines’ biggest challenge is reaching a goal to have net zero carbon emissions by 2050.
China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow on Feb 18.
The Singapore Airshow will be held from Feb 20-25, with flying displays a highlight of the biennial event.

China's first domestically manufactured passenger aircraft Comac C919 flies over Victoria Harbour during its inaugural voyage outside the mainland, in Hong Kong, China December 16, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 2.32 points to 3,223.59. Losers outnumbered gainers 50 to 48, with Seatrium trading flat and Singtel falling 0.4%. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS and UOB slipping 0.2% and 0.1% respectively. The decline followed overnight gains in European markets, where the Stoxx 600 hit its highest in over two years.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp's net profits rise by 15 per cent to S$412 million for the second half of the year ended Dec 31, 2023.

site_title: Eight-storey hotel in Geylang up for sale at S$120 million guide price
summary: An eight-storey, 184-room hotel in Geylang, Singapore, is up for sale at a guide price of S$120 million, translating to around S$2,758 per square foot. The hotel sits on a freehold site spanning 12,993 sq ft and offers various potential value-enhancement options, including converting underutilized areas into higher-value uses or refurbishing the asset. The property is expected to appeal to family offices, high-net-worth individuals, and corporates due to its limited supply and prime location between the Central Business District and the Paya Lebar sub-regional hub.

images.alt_text: Three CapitaLand units emerged at the top of the ranking of real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts in the latest Singapore Governance and Transparency Index (SGTI) 2020.
Citadines Mount Sophia Singapore is being sold by CapitaLand Ascott Trust at 19.4 per cent above its book value as at end-2023.

site_title: BEPS: Hypocrisy and tax protectionism in disguise?
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has introduced two pillars, One and Two, to combat Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS), a tax planning strategy used by multinational enterprises (MNEs) to evade taxes. Pillar One aims to allocate taxing rights to destination jurisdictions where MNEs' customers are located, while Pillar Two introduces a minimum corporate tax of 15%. Critics argue that the proposals are hypocritical, academically flawed, and politically motivated, as they unfairly target developing countries with lower tax rates. The U-turn to levy a top-up tax is seen as a response to the developed world no longer being a net exporter of e-commerce services.

images.alt_text: The IIR will subject the overseas profits of multi-national enterprise groups that are parented in Singapore to a minimum effective tax rate of 15 per cent, regardless of where they operate.
In the new Pillar Two world, Singapore must consider other means to continue positioning itself as the preferred FDI location.

Current incentives may need to be widened and future-proofed, both to entice companies evaluating Singapore as a potential investment destination, and to reassure those operating here that they will be supported.

site_title: HDB, condo rents fall in January, volumes rise: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB and condominium rental prices in Singapore fell 0.7% in January, marking the sixth consecutive month of declines, according to SRX and 99.co. The Core Central Region saw a 0.4% increase, while the Rest of the Central Region and Outside Central Region declined 1.6% and 1%, respectively. Private rental volumes rose 6.2% to 6,016 units, with HDB rentals decreasing 0.7% and rising 8.6% year-over-year. Experts attribute the decline to higher mortgage payments, increased property taxes, and rising retrenchment numbers, while also noting that tenants may be seizing opportunities to negotiate lower rental rates.

images.alt_text: The highest transacted price for a resale flat in January 2024 is S$1.57 million for a five-room flat in Toa Payoh.
Overall resale prices clock a fifth consecutive month of increase., rising 0.5 per cent on the month.
Singapore's private rental market continues to face downward pressure.
Both Huttons and OrangeTee & Tie are projecting HDB resale price growth to range between 3 and 5 per cent for 2024.
Generic image of HDB in Singapore

site_title: Digital wealth platforms report growing AUM, but have yet to see profits
summary: Singapore-based digital wealth platforms Endowus, Syfe, and Stashaway reported growing assets under management (AUM) in 2023, mainly driven by existing clients. Despite increased revenue, the platforms have yet to show profitability, with Endowus reporting a 51.4% increase in losses to $26.8 million and Syfe narrowing losses to $9.9 million. StashAway's losses narrowed to $27 million. The platforms plan to focus on their existing markets, with Endowus expanding in Hong Kong and Syfe targeting its Singapore, Hong Kong, and Australia businesses for profitability.

images.alt_text: MoneyOwl is winding down operations, as low revenues and high operating costs made financial viability a stiff challenge.
Samantha Horton, Syfe's chief business officer will continue to lead the Australia market in the wake of the resignations.
Chiam Sheng Shi from Endowus conducting a financial literacy course to delivery partners from foodpanda.

site_title: ANZ’s A$4.9 billion Suncorp deal to progress after court win
summary: ANZ Group Holdings has won its fight to overturn a competition watchdog decision to block its A$4.9 billion purchase of Suncorp Group's banking arm after the Australian Competition Tribunal ruled in its favor. The decision now requires final approval from the Queensland state government and Treasurer Jim Chalmers, who will carefully consider whether the acquisition is in the national interest. The tribunal found the acquisition would not substantially lessen competition, citing reduced consumer-choice frictions and integration efficiencies.

images.alt_text: Australian banks have been shedding jobs as they look to automate their businesses and make use of technology to re-engineer back-office operations.
The bank’s common equity tier 1 ratio is down 13.1 per cent at the end of December 2023, compared with 13.3 per cent at the end of September 2023.

site_title: Sembcorp executives guide for higher dividends, earnings as H2 profit rises 15% to S$412 million
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 15% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$412 million for the second half of its financial year ended Dec 31, 2023. The group attributed the increase to higher contributions from its gas and renewables segments. A final dividend of S$0.08 per share was proposed for the half-year, bringing the total dividend for FY2023 to S$0.13 per share. The company's profit before exceptional items increased 30% to S$809 million in FY2023, driven by higher power prices in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Some 13 STI constituents across six sectors are expected to benefit from Budget, says Maybank Securities and RHB.
Sembcorp Industries' share price is at over five-month high amid heavy trading.
Sembcorp Industries' gross renewables portfolio in India now stands at 4.2 gigawatts with its latest project award.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust receives winding-up application
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager received a winding-up application on February 20, served on February 19, from Zhang Guiming, the nephew of a non-executive director on the board. The trustee-manager is seeking legal advice and intends to dispute Zhang's claims, citing the application's late service.

images.alt_text: Notice of the EGM, and details of the meeting, will be sent to unitholders once the trustee-manager has verified the unitholding of the requisitionists whose unitholdings are registered in the name of nominee companies.
Ocean Metro Mall, one of Dasin Retail Trust's portfolio assets. Its unitholders are seeking to hold an extraordinary general meeting to internalise its trustee-manager.
The 400-million-yuan onshore facility is for Dasin Retail Trust's acquisitions of its initial portfolio including Ocean Metro Mall.
The offshore facility in default is used to finance the acquisitions of the trust’s initial portfolio comprising Xiaolan Metro Mall, Ocean Metro Mall, Dasin E-Colour and Shiqi Metro Mall.
This loan facility was to finance the acquisition of Doumen Metro Mall, and was announced by the trust in September and October last year, the trust said in a filing to the bourse.

site_title: Capital One to buy Discover Financial in US$35.3 billion all-stock deal
summary: Capital One has agreed to acquire Discover Financial Services in an all-stock deal valued at US$35.3 billion. The combined entity will be the sixth-largest US bank and will have 60% of its shares owned by Capital One shareholders and 40% by Discover shareholders. The deal is expected to face intense regulatory scrutiny due to the Biden administration's focus on boosting competition in the US economy. The acquisition aims to build a payments network that can compete with major players like Visa, Mastercard, and American Express.

images.alt_text: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission had rejected the deal in August after ANZ had attempted to buy Suncorp’s bank in 2022 as part of plans to expand its retail banking franchise.
Monday’s order says it is allowing Expobank to acquire 100 per cent of the unit, owned by HSBC Europe.
Wang Qiu, chief executive officer of Dasin Retail Trust Management, was given notice of termination with effect from Feb 14.

Lenders have benefited from the European Central Bank’s historic monetary-tightening campaign, but its expected conclusion has sparked warnings that increases in lending revenue will be capped, curbing earnings growth for banks in the region.

site_title: UK minister expects laws on stablecoins, staking within six months
summary: The UK government aims to introduce new laws regulating stablecoins and staking services within the next six months, as part of its efforts to provide clarity on specific areas of crypto by 2024. Economic Secretary to the Treasury Bim Afolami said the government is "pushing very hard" to make legislation happen, with stablecoins expected to be regulated under existing payments laws. A new classification for staking is also expected, avoiding collective investment status. Broader crypto regulation proposals remain in limbo.

images.alt_text: The crypto exchange also has benefited from its partnership with Circle, which issues the USD Coin stablecoin.
Bitcoin has tripled since the start of last year in a comeback from the 2022 digital-asset rout.
Bitcoin has tripled since the start of last year in a comeback from the 2022 digital-asset rout.
The SEC approved the listing of 11 spot Bitcoin ETFs, but caution is warranted.
Tether’s USDT token is on the verge of surpassing US$100 billion in circulation for the first time.

site_title: Key to unlocking blended finance’s promise remains elusive
summary: Singapore's ambitions to become a sustainable finance hub are hindered by the challenge of scaling blended finance, a solution to finance "unbankable" projects in developing countries. Despite the promise of blended finance, there is a lack of scale, with concessional capital stagnating at around $1 billion per year and deal volumes far below needed levels. To address this, industry experts suggest pooling projects under a single structure, but creating a homogeneous pool of assets remains a difficulty.

images.alt_text: Skyline of Central Business District and Marina Bay Financial Centre taken from ArtScience Museum on Sept 8, 2020.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 hits two-year high; German, French shares lag
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index hit a two-year high on Monday, closing 0.2% higher after healthcare stocks surged 1% led by AstraZeneca's approval of a cancer treatment. Meanwhile, French and German shares declined, with France's benchmark index revised down to 1% growth forecast due to economic concerns. Germany's DAX was down 0.2%, and investors will monitor economic data to gauge the continent's status.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Monday.

In a report released on Monday, RHB analyst Shekhar Jaiswal said the measures announced under the Budget last Friday were comprehensive and help to ensure that the nation will be able to deliver two to three per cent in annual gross domestic product growth rate over the next decade.

site_title:
How CPF changes in Budget 2024 
impact retirement planning
summary: The Singapore government has announced changes to the CPF (Central Provident Fund) system as part of Budget 2024, aimed at improving retirement adequacy. Starting at age 55, CPF members' savings in the Special Account will be transferred to the Ordinary Account, where they will earn 2.5% interest. The Special Account will be closed, and future contributions will go into the Ordinary Account, Medisave Account, and Retirement Account. The changes aim to ensure CPF members have a stable income stream and to prevent excessive savings in the Special Account.

images.alt_text: For CPF members who are 55 and above in 2025, their special accounts will be closed, with the savings transferring to retirement account up to the Full Retirement Sum.
CPF contribution rates for those aged 55 to 65 will be raised by a further 1.5 percentage points in 2025.

site_title: Toyota Industries faces crackdown for engine emissions cheating: Nikkei
summary: Japan's transport ministry plans to order Toyota Industries, the world's largest forklift truck manufacturer, to take steps to prevent engine emissions cheating. Toyota has admitted to tampering with performance test data for multiple forklift and automobile engine models. The ministry may withdraw certification for some engine types, including a potential loss of certification for an excavator engine and two forklift engine models. The regulator will assess the severity of the misconduct before deciding on further action.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Toyota logo is seen at its booth during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 19, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: China vows to centralise tech development under Communist Party
summary: China's Communist Party has vowed to centralize tech development, enhancing its role in steering the country's science and technology industries. The party will refine a mechanism to lead technological works, with President Xi Jinping overseeing the plan. This move marks an escalation of Beijing's prioritization of domestic technological development, aiming to reduce reliance on foreign technologies, particularly semiconductors and AI. China's top deputy, Liu He, oversees the development of homegrown chip technologies, following a successful Huawei moonshot chipmaking effort.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A logo of Huawei is seen during the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai on July 6, 2023. Huawei said on December 29, 2023 it expected an increase of almost nine percent in its revenue in 2023, despite US sanctions against the Chinese tech giant. (Photo by WANG Zhao / AFP)
A Huawei Technologies Co. store in Shanghai, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Cordlife names ex-TransGlobal executive director Yiu Pang Fai as new group CEO
summary: Cordlife Group has appointed Yiu Pang Fai as its new group CEO, succeeding Tan Poh Lan, who resigned to pursue personal interests. The change in leadership comes amid Cordlife serving a six-month suspension from collecting, testing, processing, and storing new cord blood and human tissue, following an audit that found suboptimal temperatures and damaged cord-blood units. Yiu Pang Fai has experience in high-profile deals and previously held executive positions at TransGlobal Group and Macquarie Infrastructure and Real Assets.

images.alt_text: Cordlife Group suspended for 6 months after the Ministry of Health found lapses in its cord blood storage tanks.
Mainboard-listed Cordlife was in November slapped with a six-month suspension from collecting, processing and storing new cord blood and providing any new types of tests.
Cordlife’s lab is capable of storing the corneal lenticule samples at below minus 150 deg C.
Cordlife says that each batch of the samples for testing may take between three and six weeks to be completed, depending on whether a repeat test of samples from the same tank is need.
Robust Plan has brought down its stake in Cordlife Group from 5.47 per cent to 3.67 per cent.
The MOH finds more lapses in the group's processes, including cord blood processing method and temperature warning systems.
While Cordlife is in good financial shape at the moment, it should begin weighing its strategic options before too much value is lost

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust unitholders OK removal of trustee-manager, internalisation of its function at EGM
summary: Dasin Retail Trust unitholders approved the removal of its trustee-manager, Dasin Retail Trust Management, at an EGM on Feb 19, with 99.9% of units voting in favor. The decision follows the termination of CEO Wang Qiu on Feb 14 and comes after unitholders demanded outstanding payments of over S$780,000 owed by the trustee-manager. The unitholders also passed a resolution to internalize the trustee-manager function, with CEO Michael Chui stating the process will start immediately.

images.alt_text: The trust's legal adviser has said the requisition notice is not valid.
Ocean Metro Mall is one of three malls that will be in Dasin Retail Trust’s initial portfolio.
The employment of Chinese real estate veteran Wang Peng as the new CIO with take effect from Feb 13.
Wang Qiu, Dasin Retail Trust, was given notice of termination with effect from Feb 14.

site_title: With air networks redrawn, Singapore emerges as the best connected among its regional rivals
summary: Singapore has emerged as the best-connected city among its regional rivals, with the fewest number of flights to Europe having been cut compared to other major hubs. The post-Covid travel boom has led to a surge in demand for air travel, but airlines face challenges in meeting passenger demand due to a shortage of new aircraft and spare parts. Traditional gateways like Singapore and New York have benefited from their existing connections, while other cities such as Manila and Jakarta have lost access to key European destinations. The industry is expected to continue recovering, but financial pressures and labor shortages are expected to persist.

images.alt_text: Dubai Airports forecasts that Dubai International will receive 88.8 million passengers, close to the record 89.1 million seen in 2018.
After surviving the pandemic, airlines’ biggest challenge is reaching a goal to have net zero carbon emissions by 2050.
The revamped departure hall at Changi Airport Terminal 2 on Nov 1, 2023.
Air New Zealand has come under pressure as more airlines return to the Pacific long haul routes into the US as global travel revives after the Covid pandemic.
China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow on Feb 18.
Singapore's 2030 target for reducing aviation sector emissions includes operations at both Changi and Seletar Airports.
Within the group, the flagship airline’s revenue passenger-kilometres rose 14.3 per cent to 9.6 billion, from 8.4 billion year on year.
FILE PHOTO: An employee walks past a fuselage section under construction at Boeing Co.'s 787 Dreamliner campus in North Charleston, South Carolina, U.S., May 30, 2023. Gavin McIntyre/File Photo

site_title: The new realism in venture capital is healthy
summary: The venture capital market has shifted towards a more realistic approach, with a growing stockpile of "dry powder" ($4 trillion) due to constrained exits and higher interest rates. Despite this, investors are still allocating more money, driven by the returns justifying it. The dry powder is a sign of private capital's growing attraction as an asset class, and investors are eager to allocate funds. The author believes this trend is healthy, as it leads to increased scrutiny of business models and return on investment, and ultimately benefits private equity managers.

images.alt_text: Historically, investors have expected bigger returns from private equity because of its riskier nature.

site_title: Parole for Thailand’s Thaksin reflects rise of new threat to old guard
summary: Thailand's former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra has been granted parole after serving a self-imposed exile, sparking concerns of a deal between Thaksin and the royalist-military establishment to counter the rise of the anti-establishment Move Forward party. Thaksin's early release comes after the party advocated for institutional reforms, including amending laws protecting the monarchy, and was blocked from forming a government. Analysts believe Thaksin's parole was a quid pro quo, allowing him to return to Thailand without facing prosecution, while the establishment aimed to prevent the rise of another anti-establishment force.

images.alt_text: Former Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra arrives at his family compound after he was released from a police hospital in Bangkok, Thailand, Feb 18, 2024.
Thailand's former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra leaves a police hospital after being granted parole.
Former Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra will be freed, possibly as soon as this weekend.
“Based on the criteria, Thaksin qualifies for a special parole,” Corrections Department says.
Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin made a pitch to potential investors about the Landbridge project during his recent visit to the US.

Thai politician Pita Limjaroenrat attends the TIME 100 Next Gala in New York City on October 24, 2023. TIME’s annual TIME100 Next list recognizes 100 individuals who are defining the next generation of leadership — Artists, Phenoms, Leaders, Advocates and Innovators — poised to make the climb and in doing so, make history. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)
Thai politician Pita Limjaroenrat said his reformist party Move Forward had to “restrategise”, acknowledging that election runners-up Pheu Thai had control over the electoral system.

site_title: EU's von der Leyen wins backing for second term as EC president
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has won backing from her German centre-right party for a second term, putting her in a strong position to secure another five years as EU leader. The Christian Democratic Union (CDU) nominated her as their top candidate for the EPP, a pan-European centre-right umbrella group, following a party meeting in Berlin. Von der Leyen, the first woman to hold the job, has steered the EU through major challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. She will face a majority vote in the European Parliament in June, but her chances seem likely due to her broad backing among EU leaders.

images.alt_text: A potential second term as European Commission chief for Ursula von der Leyen will have a huge role in defining the EU’s longer-term political and economic character.

site_title: Singapore developer to build luxury township near Cambodia’s new airport
summary: Singapore-based developer Sir Stamford Raffles Group is building a 22.6-hectare luxury township, Marum Estate, near Cambodia's new Techo Takhmao International Airport, set to open in 2025. The township will feature 642 landed residences, 259 shophouses, and various amenities, with a focus on attracting affluent Cambodians and international buyers. The development is part of a larger push by the airport to become a regional transit hub, capable of handling 50 million passengers per year by 2050. Ng Aung San, founder of Sir Stamford Raffles Group, sees Cambodia as a promising investment opportunity due to its growing tourism and business sectors.

images.alt_text: Planning for new urban areas at the Binh Duong - Vietnam's locality with the largest total industrial park area

site_title: Oil gains marginally as demand jitters counter Middle East conflict
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose 9 cents to settle at $83.56 a barrel on Monday, despite lingering supply concerns from the Middle East conflict. Demand jitters were countered by weakening demand forecasts from the International Energy Agency. US producer prices increased, amplifying inflation concerns and lifting the dollar, making dollar-denominated oil less attractive to investors. Market analyst Fawad Razaqzada attributed the oil price gains to supportive measures such as the Middle East situation and Opec's intervention, but noted that the dollar's strength has been offsetting these gains.

images.alt_text: After surviving the pandemic, airlines’ biggest challenge is reaching a goal to have net zero carbon emissions by 2050.
Brent crude futures were down 58 cents, or 0.69 per cent, at US$82.89 a barrel on Monday morning.

site_title: Grab-GoTo merger a quick fix but hard sell
summary: Grab and GoTo, Southeast Asia's ride-hailing giants, are reportedly discussing a potential mega merger after three years of failed negotiations. The companies are exploring various scenarios, including Grab acquiring GoTo using cash, stock, or a combination of both. Both companies have struggled to turn a profit, with Grab's shares down 59.7% and GoTo's down 75.1% since their respective IPOs. A merger could help boost market share and cut competition, but it also poses challenges, including regulatory hurdles and the need to balance short-term profitability with long-term growth.

images.alt_text: Grab and GoTo have held on-and-off talks to combine without success in the past, after years of fierce competition in ride-hailing, food delivery and financial technology.
Food delivery is facing growth challenges as it comes off heady times during the pandemic.
Media reports previously said both the companies were in preliminary discussions related to a variety of scenarios about a potential deal.

site_title: China’s securities watchdog opens ears for proposals to revive market
summary: China's securities watchdog, the CSRC, held seminars with market participants to propose tighter scrutiny on company listings and trading behavior. The proposals include stricter controls on initial public offerings, harsher punishments for lawbreakers, and a fairer trading mechanism. The CSRC, led by Chairman Wu Qing, aims to "resolutely maintain market stability and control market risks." The watchdog will treat all proposals seriously and implement feasible ones immediately, following recent actions such as punishing employees at China Merchant Securities and fining Shanghai-based semiconductor company S2C for fraud.

images.alt_text: Anticipation of more fulsome efforts to end the rout had been mounting for days, after Bloomberg News reported that regulators led by the CSRC planned to brief President Xi on the markets as soon as Tuesday.
Yi Huiman's removal comes as Chinese markets are on a knife edge as institutional and retail investors scramble to cut their losses.
Xi Jinping has shown signs of becoming increasingly involved in the nation’s financial and economy policies.
China's securities regulator will also ban securities lending to investors who sell stocks on the same day of purchase.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains amid post-Budget optimism; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% on Monday, driven by optimism over the 2024 Budget's potential to boost local companies. Analyst Shekhar Jaiswal cited comprehensive measures that could lead to 2-3% annual GDP growth. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC gained, while ST Engineering, exposed to the defence sector, shed 0.3%. Thai Beverage was the top gainer, while Seatrium fell 3.2%. Major regional indices ended mixed.

images.alt_text: Some 13 STI constituents across six sectors are expected to benefit from Budget, says Maybank Securities and RHB.
RIC adjustments to include other methods to assess the quantum awarded, in addition to expenditure incurred, could help to secure high-value activities in Singapore, say observers.
A new initiative named the Future Energy Fund will receive an initial injection of S$5 billion to build critical infrastructure and improve energy security.

site_title: Saudi Arabia sees medium-term non-oil growth at over 5%
summary: Saudi Arabia expects non-oil growth to reach over 5% in the medium term, according to Finance Minister Mohammed Al Jadaan. This is slightly lower than a previously projected 6% figure, but still outperforms the wider region. The country is accelerating its economic diversification plans under Vision 2030, with non-oil activities driving growth. Despite a 0.9% contraction in overall GDP last year, non-oil GDP grew 4.6% in 2023, and the government expects higher spending to drive domestic growth and support non-oil GDP.

images.alt_text: In 2019, the kingdom set up the Red sea International Film Festival and last year unveiled two funds at Cannes for production infrastructure and film industry investment.

site_title: Putin grants HSBC approval to sell Russian unit to Expobank
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has granted approval for HSBC to sell its Russian unit, HSBC Bank (RR), to privately-owned Expobank. The deal allows Expobank to acquire 100% of the unit, paving the way for HSBC's full exit from the Russian market. The approval comes after months of negotiations, despite Moscow's restrictions on foreign asset sales. HSBC had previously taken a $300 million loss on the expected sale of its Russian business, and the deal is expected to have a negligible financial impact on the bank.

images.alt_text: The logo of Expobank is seen on a building in Prague, Czech Republic, September 8, 2017.   REUTERS/David W Cerny/Files
Russian company Automotive Technologies is assembling the Citroen C5 Aircross at the Kaluga factory, according to two employees at different Russian car dealerships.
The EU has so far listed more than 620 companies, with the near entirety from Russia.
Since its invasion of Ukraine in Feb 2022, Moscow has gone on a shopping spree for soldiers, imported weapons, and ramped up its own arms production.
The move significantly expands the US financial battle against President Vladimir Putin, whose forces show little sign of relenting in Ukraine’s east.

site_title: America’s steel madness
summary: US Steel to be acquired by Nippon Steel for $14.1 billion, making it the world's second-largest steel producer. The deal includes retaining US Steel's name, headquarters, and manufacturing facilities, with a pledge not to move jobs overseas. Despite initial concerns from US politicians, the acquisition is seen as a "good deal" as it reverses US Steel's fortunes and improves the American steel industry's prospects. The White House has called for scrutiny of the deal, and the US Steelworkers union opposes it.

images.alt_text: Outside the US Steel Great Lakes Works plant in Ecorse, Michigan, Sep 24, 2019.
Citing several unnamed sources, Bloomberg said the three Japanese megabanks had extended a commitment letter to Nippon Steel for the dollar-denominated loans.

site_title: Messi sets record straight over Hong Kong absence
summary: Lionel Messi addressed speculation over his absence from a recent Inter Miami friendly in Hong Kong, stating that he had an inflamed adductor and couldn't play due to injury. Messi denied rumors that he avoided the game for political reasons, citing a close relationship with China and multiple visits to the country throughout his career. As a result, Hangzhou and Beijing have announced they will not host Argentina games scheduled for March, amid ongoing fallout from the incident.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: [US, Mexico & Canada customers only] Feb 4, 2024; Hong Kong, HONG KONG;  Inter Miami player Lionel Messi on the sideline in a preseason friendly soccer match against Hong Kong XI at Hong Kong Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Lam Yik/Reuters via USA TODAY Sports/File Photo
Messi’s no-show at the highly anticipated match in Hong Kong on Sunday caused a furore that has shown no sign of waning, with fans still demanding answers and a refund three days on.

Lionel Messi’s (third from left) non-appearance will add to the problems Hong Kong faces in trying to restore its reputation as a world-class centre, in the wake of a crackdown on dissent and strict pandemic curbs.

site_title: Dubai Airports reiterates need for new facility as traffic rises
summary: Dubai Airports forecasts that Dubai International Airport will receive 88.8 million passengers this year, close to the record 89.1 million in 2018. The operator highlights the need to expand beyond the main hub and develop a second facility, Dubai World Central (DWC), to accommodate growing traffic and long-haul connecting flights. DWC's expansion plans are back in focus, but no firm plans have been announced, with Emirates pushing for a major increase in infrastructure to cater to future growth.

images.alt_text: Dubai, the biggest tourism and trade hub in the Middle East, was quick to reopen after the pandemic.

site_title: China’s Hainan cuts down payment for first-home buyers
summary: China's southernmost province, Hainan, has cut the minimum down payment for first-time homebuyers to 20% from 25%, in an effort to boost slumping home sales. This move follows recent relaxation of homebuying curbs in Beijing and Shanghai. The ratio for second homes remains unchanged at 30%. The move aims to stimulate the housing market, which has seen subdued sales despite a surge in existing home transactions during the Spring Festival holiday.

site_title: Seletar Aerospace Park to add 11,000 sq m development with green features by 2027
summary: The Seletar Aerospace Park will expand by 11,000 sq m by 2027, featuring the first standard factory with green infrastructure solutions, JTC aeroSpace Four. The development will offer "plug and play" smart factory solutions for aerospace manufacturing and maintenance, repair and overhaul activities. The facility will include an electric vehicle charging system to support sustainability goals. This expansion aims to increase standard factory units by 25% and provide advanced aerospace manufacturing and MRO capabilities.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Airshow will be held from Feb 20-25, with flying displays a highlight of the biennial event.

L-R: Nandina REM CEO Karina Cady; CCO Allison Nam; COO Dazril Phua; 
Dr. Jonathan Low, Coordinating Director (R&D) Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre, A*Star

site_title: HSBC introduces new bonus system for most junior employees
summary: HSBC introduces a new bonus system for most junior employees, called "on target variable pay," which is set using external benchmark data and internal pay data. This change aims to improve transparency on compensation and will apply globally to staff in grade 4-8 roles, including mid-ranking managers and junior operations staff. The new mechanism replaces the previous compensation plan, which did not have specific bonus targets set.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: HSBC logo is seen in this illustration taken December 22, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
HSBC has said it was not barred from hiring the former SVB employees.

(FILES) A sign is pictured above a branch of a HSBC bank in central London on April 26, 2022. The British banking giant HSBC announced on Monday, October 30, net profit almost tripled in the third quarter over one year to 5.6 billion dollars (5.3 billion euros), boosted in particular by "the positive impact of high interest rates". (Photo by Niklas HALLE'N / AFP)

site_title: Japan moves to allow investment funds to hold crypto
summary: Japan's government has agreed to submit a revised bill to allow venture capital firms and investment funds to hold digital assets directly. The move aims to partially ease regulations in areas such as token listings and taxation. If approved, it would open up Japan's investment sector to greater exposure in digital assets, benefiting web3 startups. The bill will be debated in the current session of the Diet, Japan's parliament, with the potential to support the growth of web3 firms and reinvigorate Japan's economy.

images.alt_text: More than 6.2 trillion yen (S$54 billion) has been spent on the fuel subsidy programme so far.

FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during a news conference at the prime minister's office in Tokyo, Japan, 13 December 2023. Prime Minister Kishida said he will replace several ministers implicated in a political fundraising scandal.    FRANCK ROBICHON/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Binance has taken some steps to expand its Asian footprint elsewhere too, including in South Korea and Thailand.

site_title: Billionaire founder of Daiso Industries dies at 80
summary: Billionaire founder of Daiso Industries, Hirotake Yano, has died at 80 due to heart failure. Yano, known for pioneering the dollar-shop business model, had a net worth of approximately US$1.9 billion. He founded Daiso in 1977, which became successful as Japanese consumers sought goods with better value for their money. The company has 4,360 domestic stores and 990 overseas locations, generating revenue of 589.1 billion yen in the year ended February 2023.

site_title: Pfizer inflammatory bowel disease drug wins EU approval
summary: Pfizer's inflammatory bowel disease treatment Velsipity has received approval from the European Commission for use in patients aged 16 or older with ulcerative colitis who did not respond to previous treatments. The approval, based on late-stage trial results, will make the drug available in all 27 EU countries, including reimbursement applications. With 2.6 million people in Europe living with ulcerative colitis, Pfizer expects Velsipity to compete with Bristol Myers Squibb's Zeposia, with estimated 2030 sales of $2.2 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A company logo is seen at a Pfizer office in Puurs, Belgium, December 2, 2022. REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Greenback holds steady after strong US data dents rate-cut hopes
summary: The US dollar held steady at 104.23 against a basket of six peers, after rising 0.18% the previous week due to strong inflation data. The dollar index rose to its highest since mid-November, but slipped after retail sales fell in January. Investors are dialing down interest rate cut expectations from the Federal Reserve, citing the strong inflation data. The euro remained unchanged at $1.0777, while sterling rose 0.1% to $1.2612. The minutes from the Fed's last meeting are expected to be released this week, with investors expecting 90 basis points of rate cuts this year.

images.alt_text: The yen has touched 150 recently, putting the market on high alert to a possible intervention by Japanese authorities to weaken the yen.

site_title: RBA will cut rates deeper than markets expect
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to cut interest rates deeper than markets anticipate, according to Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Despite the RBA raising rates by 4.25 percentage points, the average US outstanding mortgage rate has only risen 50-basis points, suggesting a more aggressive easing cycle in Australia. The RBA is expected to make six rate cuts starting in September, bringing the cash rate down to 2.85% by June 2025, ahead of market pricing of just two cuts. This move aims to prevent unemployment from rising above 4.5% and address slowing economic growth.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates steady at a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent last week, having last hiked by a quarter point in November.
The Reserve Bank of Australia has left interest rates at a 12-year high.
Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Michele Bullock said Australia’s inflation challenge is not over, while there were some encouraging signs.

site_title: BHP reports flat first-half profit; warns of inflation, high interest rates impact
summary: BHP Group reported a flat first-half profit, citing strong revenue growth of 6% driven by higher iron ore and copper prices. The miner warned of higher costs from lagged global inflation and higher interest rates impacting household consumption in the first half of 2024. BHP predicted strong commodity demand in China and India, but remains cautious on top consumer China until its stimulus policies' effectiveness becomes clearer. The company declared an interim dividend of US$0.72 per share, unchanged from the previous year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A small toy figure and mineral imitation are seen in front of the BHP logo in this illustration taken November 19, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: SGX prices S$300 million notes due 2027 at 3.45% per annum
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will issue S$300 million worth of notes with a 3.45% per annum interest rate, maturing on February 26, 2027. The notes, denominated in SGD, will be issued in SGD250,000 denominations and will be used for refinancing existing debt and general corporate purposes. The notes will be issued on February 26, 2024, under SGX's S$1.5 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB serving as joint lead managers.

site_title: Chinese EV maker HiPhi suspends operations for six months
summary: Chinese EV maker HiPhi has suspended operations for at least six months, citing financial struggles as the industry faces a slowdown. The Shanghai-based manufacturer, which produces premium HiPhi electric vehicles, barred workers from entering its factory and will pay them minimum wage after a 70% pay cut. The move comes as consumer demand wanes and escalating trade tensions hurt the export outlook, adding to the financial woes of other EV companies.

images.alt_text: The additional employees would represent a 25 per cent expansion of Xpeng’s workforce from the latest headcount of 15,829 at the end of 2022.
Record deliveries in the fourth quarter, when BYD overtook Tesla as the world’s top seller of electric cars, did not translate into another bumper profit.
Major US automakers have warned that Chinese cars could spell doom for their own prospects, among them Elon Musk’s Tesla.
China is estimated to have overtaken Japan as the world’s largest auto exporter in 2023.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, February 19, 2024 (Ep 4)
summary: Chinese stocks experienced a holiday boost, while Olam Group stated there's no evidence of fraud in Nigeria. Meanwhile, the Malaysian ringgit is near a record low. The Singapore shares opened flat after the Budget 2024 announcement, with the STI down 0.01%. Asian markets were mixed, with China enjoying a Lunar New Year bump.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 64 to 48.
Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets gained as traders returned from a week-long break.

site_title: Yemen's Houthis claim attack on ship in the Gulf of Aden, say it could sink
summary: Houthi militants in Yemen claimed attacking a UK-registered ship, Rubymar cargo ship, in the Gulf of Aden, which is now at risk of sinking. The crew is safe, according to Houthi military spokesperson Yahya Sarea. The attack occurred in the Bab al-Mandab Strait off Yemen, where Iran-aligned Houthi forces have made repeated drone and missile attacks against international commercial shipping. US and British warplanes have carried out retaliatory strikes across Yemen.

images.alt_text: Red Sea attacks raise freight charges, but still manageable for businesses: MTI
The Saudis have called for restraint in the US and UK strikes against the Houthis, trying to keep its own peace talks alive with the militants.

Generic photo of general scene at PSA (Singapore) at Pasir Panjang Terminal on Feb 9, 2023. Can use for stories on economy, shipping, ports, containers terminal, sailing, port hub, cranes, shipping vessels, harbour, transshipment, merchant, cargo ship.

site_title: Gaza war hits Israeli economy with 19.4% Q4 drop
summary: Israel's economy contracted by 19.4% in the fourth quarter of 2023, with the US$500 billion economy shrinking annually due to the ongoing war in Gaza. The war halted economic growth, causing a 26.9% drop in private spending and a 67.8% slide in investment in fixed assets. Despite a 2.0% annual growth rate for 2023, per capita GDP declined 0.1%. The economy is expected to grow 2% in 2024 and rebound sharply in 2025, driven by the high-tech sector and resilience after prior conflicts.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators gather with signs during a protest outside the Kirya military base which houses the Defence Ministry in Tel Aviv, Israel, Feb 13, 2024.

site_title: Opportunities in Asia in a slow-growth world
summary: Asia holds significant long-term potential, driven by growth desynchronisation, slowing US growth, and moderating inflation. Valuations in Asian markets remain reasonable, and earnings growth is expected to outperform the US at twice the rate. Key markets such as Korea, Taiwan, India, and Japan are expected to perform well, with China's current valuations appearing attractive and macro indicators showing positive results from targeted policy support. Investors are advised to focus on income, sustainability, and Asia opportunities, with a potential interest-rate pivot expected in mid-2024.

images.alt_text: India’s bonds have risen over the past three months on the prospect of global index inclusion.
A swath of Chinese stocks in Hong Kong surged in response to holiday data showing a 61 per cent gain in rail trips from a year earlier.
The company says it is seeking financing and is working on generating sufficient cash flow to prevent the potential default.
A new round of staff cuts that began in late 2023 on the Chinese mainland and Hong Kong, key regional investment banking hubs, will gather pace in the coming months.

site_title: EU opens formal investigation into TikTok over possible online content breaches
summary: The European Union has launched a formal investigation into TikTok over possible breaches of online content rules, including those related to protecting children and ensuring transparent advertising. The investigation, led by EU industry chief Thierry Breton, aims to examine TikTok's risk assessment report and responses to requests for information. If found guilty, ByteDance, TikTok's owner, could face fines of up to 6% of its global turnover. The investigation focuses on TikTok's design, algorithmic systems, and measures for protecting minors, as well as its database on advertisements.

images.alt_text: TikTok's "election centres" are designed to better inform Europeans about the electoral process.

site_title: Gallant Venture, GHY Culture & Media expect net losses for FY2023
summary: Mainboard-listed companies Gallant Venture and GHY Culture & Media have posted separate profit guidances for their full-year results, both expecting net losses. Gallant Venture attributes its loss to higher finance costs and lower profit contributions from associated companies, while GHY Culture & Media cites foreign exchange losses due to the appreciating Singapore dollar against the yuan. Both companies expect further details to be disclosed when their financial results are announced.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: 13 blue-chip stocks that could benefit from Singapore’s Budget 2024
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 is expected to benefit 13 STI constituents across six sectors, with a focus on incentivizing investments in green transition, human capital, and high-quality foreign direct investment. Financial institutions, such as DBS, OCBC, and UOB, are expected to benefit from lower asset quality risks and increased loan growth. Property developers UOL and CDL are also likely to gain from the lower Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty clawback rate. Reits, industrials, and technology companies, including Singtel and Venture Corp, are expected to benefit from tax rebates and increased consumer spending. The budget is seen as pro-business and pro-social, lifting market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The net institutional fund flows for the first six weeks of 2024 showed  net withdrawals of S$463 million.
RIC adjustments to include other methods to assess the quantum awarded, in addition to expenditure incurred, could help to secure high-value activities in Singapore, say observers.
Retirees who are owner-occupiers of private homes should be mindful that costs linked to home ownership such as property tax may rise over the long term.
The slew of ostensibly social measures should not negate the central importance of a vibrant, thriving, and sustainable economy to a shared future, says SMU's Eugene Tan.
Budget 2024 is the first instalment of Forward Singapore programmes – flagship agenda of the fourth generation People’s Action Party leadership, led by Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: German homes are still overvalued despite price drop: Bundesbank
summary: Germany's homes remain overvalued despite a 4% decline in owner-occupied residential property prices last year, according to the Bundesbank. The price drop is attributed to the European Central Bank's interest rate hikes and the domestic economy's struggles with expensive energy imports and sluggish exports. The German statistics office reported a 8.9% decline in property prices for the first nine months of the year, highlighting the ongoing impact of the property boom's unraveling.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Apartments are illuminated inside residential buildings at the bank of Berlin-Spandauer-Schifffahrtskanal in Berlin, Germany, November 10, 2023. REUTERS/Lisi Niesner/File Photo

site_title: US awards US$1.5 billion to GlobalFoundries for domestic semiconductor production
summary: The US government has awarded $1.5 billion to GlobalFoundries to expand domestic semiconductor production. The contract chipmaker will build a new facility in Malta, New York, and expand existing operations in Burlington, Vermont. The grant will be accompanied by $1.6 billion in available loans, generating an estimated $12.5 billion in overall potential investment across the two states. This move aims to strengthen domestic supply chains and support the US's growing technology sector.

images.alt_text: Customers in end markets such as communications infrastructure and data centre have been working down existing chip inventory, weighing on demand for GlobalFoundries.
GlobalFoundries says it expects adjusted profit per share to be in the range of 53 cents to 64 cents in the three months to December, above estimates of 52 cents.
Aerial view of GlobalFoundries new US$4 billion expansion facility in Singapore.

With its new 23,000 sqm facility, 
GlobalFoundries said it will produce an additional 450,000 300mm wafers per year and create 1,000 jobs.

site_title: Shareholder returns are at peak for European banks: JPMorgan
summary: European banks' capital returns to shareholders have reached a peak, according to JPMorgan strategists, who warn that the expected conclusion of the European Central Bank's monetary-tightening campaign will cap earnings growth. Despite the European economy avoiding a recession in 2023, its prospects are currently seen as weak, and regulators' scrutiny may increase. JPMorgan remains underweight on the sector, citing negative EPS revisions and the likelihood that dividends and buybacks will not be safe if the credit and macro environment weakens.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 19)
summary: Singapore's 2030 target to reduce aviation sector emissions includes both Changi and Seletar airports. From 2026, outbound travelers will face a levy for flights using non-sustainable aviation fuel. The aviation industry faces challenges such as affordable airfares and adequate manpower. Singapore's 2024 Budget has an investment tilt, lifting market sentiment. The Straits Times Index rose 0.1% amid post-Budget optimism, while property tax changes are unlikely to impact homebuying decisions.

images.alt_text: Air China flight CA403 encountered smoke in its forward cargo hold and lavatory on its way to Changi Airport and had to make an emergency landing.

site_title: Pine Grove owners lower reserve price to S$1.78 billion in fifth en bloc attempt
summary: The Pine Grove condominium, a 660-unit development in Singapore, is set for a fifth collective sale attempt. The reserve price has been lowered to S$1.78 billion, an 8.7% decrease from the previous price of S$1.95 billion. The site, with a plot ratio of 2.1, has a full potential for redevelopment into a 2,050-unit development. A minimum of 80% of owners must agree to the lower price for it to be accepted. The tender is scheduled to open on March 6 and close on May 5.

images.alt_text: Monies that go into buying and sprucing up houses in GCB Areas can be productively used in many other areas.
The market is expected to be held up in part by a substantial number of occupiers displaced by the recent collective sales of Far East Shopping Centre and Shenton House, says Knight Frank.
Noel Gifts expects to book S$30.6 million from the sale of 10 units it owns at the freehold industrial property.

site_title: China’s JD.com versus US’s Elliott in battle for UK’s Currys
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce giant, has joined US activist investor Elliott in a battle to buy UK retailer Currys, which has rejected Elliott's initial offer of $880 million. Currys shares surged 38% after JD.com confirmed interest, with analysts speculating that the retailer's low valuation triggered the interest. JD.com is evaluating a possible cash offer for the entire company, which would represent a shift for the online specialist.

images.alt_text: Dada will conduct an independent review with the assistance of independent professional advisers, JD.Com says.
E-commerce giant JD.com says that the ruling is a landmark moment in upholding market fairness through the rule of law.
JD.com reports net revenue of 247.7 billion yuan (S$46.1 billion) for the third quarter, missing analysts’ average estimate of 249.26 billion yuan.

site_title: Indonesia will turn to ‘Swiftonomics’ to boost tourism spending
summary: Indonesia plans to implement 'Swiftonomics' to boost tourism spending, exempting more nationalities from visa requirements and simplifying permits to host events. The country has formed a $86 million tourism fund to bid for events like concerts and sports tournaments. Tourism Minister Sandiaga Salahuddin Uno expressed optimism that these measures will attract more visitors, following a recent surge in foreign tourists to 1.1 million in December. The government also plans to impose a visitor levy in Bali to fund tourism development and protect the island from the impact of tourism.

images.alt_text: Indonesia launches the 142-kilometre railway line connecting the capital Jakarta to Bandung city in October.
Many countries and regions have launched emissions trading systems (ETS) to put a price on carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions and incentivise companies to invest in low carbon technology.
The Jakarta Composite index last traded 1.7 per cent higher after earlier hitting an over one-month peak, and was inching toward the record high of 7,403.578 points hit in January.

site_title: German recession doesn’t mean severe downturn, Bundesbank says
summary: Germany's economy isn't experiencing a severe downturn, despite potential recession, according to the Bundesbank. Output may be falling for a second consecutive quarter, but a significant, broad-based, and prolonged decline in economic output cannot be identified. The central bank warns against reading too much into the current situation, citing a stable labor market, rising wages, and declining inflation. The IMK institute, however, forecasts a 61.7% recession probability for the second quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk on a shopping street in the southern German town of Konstanz January 17, 2015.REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann//

site_title: China state banks earmark 60 billion yuan for property projects
summary: China's state-owned lenders have earmarked 60 billion yuan (S$11.4 billion) for property projects, aiming to boost lending to the struggling housing market. The big four state lenders have approved loans for over 60 billion yuan worth of real estate projects, with more in the pipeline. This comes after Beijing urged local authorities to support developers and draft lists of eligible projects. The move aims to address the slowdown in China's property market, which saw new home sales tumble 34.2% from a year earlier.

images.alt_text: A man walks past unfinished residential buildings developed by China Evergrande Group in the outskirts of Shijiazhuang, Hebei province, China February 1, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Saudi wealth fund, Singapore’s PSA consider Global Ports IPO
summary: Saudi wealth fund, Public Investment Fund (PIF), and Singapore's PSA International are considering an initial public offering (IPO) for Global Ports, a port operator owned by PIF and PSA. The IPO is part of PIF's plan to diversify Saudi Arabia's economy and raise funds for Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's Vision 2030 plan. Global Ports operates container terminals in Dammam and manages Riyadh Dry Port. The IPO timing and size are still being considered, with PIF also exploring an IPO for Nupco, a medical procurement firm.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: General view in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, June 21 2020. REUTERS/Ahmed Yosri/File Photo

site_title: Consider lowering ABSD for foreigners buying homes in selected areas such as Marina South
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) rejected a nearly S$770.5 million bid for a 99-year leasehold Marina Gardens Crescent site in Marina South due to the bid price being too low. The site's uncertainty over housing demand, lack of local schools, and fear of low demand from foreigners may have driven developers to be cautious. To revive foreign buying interest, the government could consider lowering Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) rates for non-Permanent Residents (non-SPRs) in selected areas, such as Marina South and Sentosa.

images.alt_text: The government plays a critical role in ensuring adequate private housing supply.

The Marina Gardens Crescent site (in orange and dark grey) drew just one bid at a URA tender that closed on Jan 18, 2024. In contrast, the nearby Marina Gardens Lane plot (in purple) received four bids at a URA tender In June 2023.,

site_title: Aviation industry faces challenges of affordable airfares, inadequate manpower
summary: The aviation industry faces significant challenges, including maintaining affordable airfares, especially during peak travel seasons, and attracting and retaining skilled workers. By 2026, the industry needs approximately 480,000 technicians and 350,000 pilots. Malaysia has implemented a ceiling price on domestic flights to make air travel more affordable for its citizens. Industry experts highlight the need for sustainable solutions to address these challenges, including investing in training programs and improving working conditions to attract and retain talent.

images.alt_text: The revamped departure hall at Changi Airport Terminal 2 on Nov 1, 2023.
Singapore's 2030 target for reducing aviation sector emissions includes operations at both Changi and Seletar Airports.

site_title: 90% of startups worldwide fail; but data for South-east Asia incomplete
summary: Approximately 90% of startups globally fail, with two-thirds never generating a positive return for investors. However, data on startup failure rates in South-east Asia is incomplete due to isolated figures and a lack of comprehensive regional summaries. The varying levels of development across countries in the region may influence ecosystem maturity, which could play a more significant role in determining startup success.

images.alt_text: ContextLogic will sell assets including Wish to Qoo10 for US$6.50 per share in cash
GDMC aims to manufacture advanced therapy modalities such as customised messenger RNA, plasmid DNA, and lentiviral vectors.
European aerospace major Airbus is also providing its services to develop Qosmosys’ prototype.

site_title: Google, Microsoft will dominate AI as computing costs surge
summary: Artificial intelligence startups are struggling to afford the high costs of AI chips and cloud computing, leading to the dominance of large technology companies like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon. Startups such as Unitary and OpenDialogue AI are finding it difficult to rent access to these rare AI chips and cloud computing services, resulting in high costs that can be 100 times more than what they charge clients. As a result, many startups will likely fold or be acquired by larger companies, further consolidating the market and limiting competition.

images.alt_text: Google’s Gemini is its largest, most capable and flexible AI model to date. An updated version can handle even larger amounts of text and video.

Cohere is focusing on business applications of AI, for instance making professionals more efficient at their jobs.

site_title: New bids in to revive KL-Singapore high-speed rail, but govt funding remains missing link
summary: Malaysia's plan to revive the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore high-speed rail (HSR) using private sector financing is unlikely due to the government's refusal to provide funding guarantees. Seven consortia, including Berjaya Land and YTL Corp, have submitted proposals, but all have requested government support. Analysts say private financing alone cannot revive the project, citing the need for government support for land acquisition, subsidies, and infrastructure maintenance. The government's debt level is already high, and reviving the HSR could trim allocations for priority sectors like health and education.

images.alt_text: Indonesia launches the 142-kilometre railway line connecting the capital Jakarta to Bandung city in October.

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi (left) emphasised the need for Thailand and China to promote the early implementation of the China-Laos-Thailand connectivity concept during his meeting with Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin.
Indonesia's US$7.3 billion HSR project has been viewed by observers as a big step towards Asean’s push for seamless integration and connectivity in the region.

Artist's impression of the upcoming Bandar Malaysia High Speed Rail station in Kuala LumpuR; the Sultan of Johor has been pushing for the revival of the high-speed rail project, which was cancelled in 2021.

site_title: Japan’s December core machinery orders rise 2.7% month/month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 2.7% in December from the previous month, exceeding expectations, but declined 0.7% year-on-year. Despite the increase, the government still views machinery orders as having "stalled" for 14 months. Economists expect core orders to rise 4.6% quarter-on-quarter in the January-March period. Weakening in the non-manufacturing sector and limited domestic demand may restrain the pace of recovery.

images.alt_text: Outside of Japan, signs of a scaling back are everywhere, with the exception of China.
More than 6.2 trillion yen (S$54 billion) has been spent on the fuel subsidy programme so far.
With inflation exceeding the BOJ’s 2 per cent target for well over a year, many market players expect the BOJ to end its negative interest rate policy in the coming months.

A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure on the trading floor at the Nomura Securities Co. headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Jan. 11, 2024. The Nikkei 225 rose 1.8% to the highest level in about 34 years on Thursday. Photographer: Nao Sano/Bloomberg
Two consecutive quarters of contraction are typically considered the definition of a recession.

site_title: Saudi Arabia pushes deeper into entertainment with new film fund
summary: Saudi Arabia is launching a $100 million film fund to invest in the kingdom's film industry, aiming to produce content that reflects Saudi culture and values. The partnership between MEFIC Capital and Roaa Media Ventures will collaborate with international studios, capitalizing on the region's fastest-growing movie production markets. With a population of over 32 million and a 25% annual growth rate, Saudi Arabia is one of the top markets for local-language content in the Middle East, and the fund is part of the government's efforts to diversify the economy and improve its image abroad.

site_title: Hong Kong records most Chinese New Year tourists since pre-covid
summary: Hong Kong recorded the most Chinese New Year tourists since pre-COVID, with over 1.2 million visitors during the eight-day festival. This surpasses the number from 2018 and indicates a rebound in consumption in China's economy. Nearby Macau also saw a record 1.4 million tourists, boosting casinos. Overseas tourism, particularly to Singapore, showed signs of recovery, with increased passenger numbers and a significant increase in Chinese-Singaporean travel.

images.alt_text: New York is one of several global cities where rents on luxury apartments fell in the fourth quarter last year.
The private estates are large housing complexes often used by Hong Kong agents to gauge activity in the second-hand market.
Inter Miami’s visit is part of a series of efforts by Hong Kong officials to create a buzz in the city and boost spending.

site_title: Louboutin’s famous red sole heels tread winding path to trademark protection in China
summary: Christian Louboutin's iconic red sole heels continue to face challenges in securing trademark protection in China. The French luxury brand has been embroiled in a decade-long legal battle with the China Trademark Office, with the case centered on the distinctive appearance of the shoes. In 2020, a survey found that 60% of designer brands had their work plagiarized, and 25% were aware of counterfeit versions. The trademark registration process remains stalled, with the current status marked as "under rejection review." Louboutin has also targeted another company, Wanlima, for allegedly copying its unique shoe design, with the court ruling in favor of Louboutin in August 2022.
