Since 2021, more than 50 Chinese property firms have defaulted on debt, including the two firms that once dominated the country’s housing market: Evergrande and Country Garden.
Customers line up outside a Louis Vuitton store in Hangzhou. Since 2022, the likes of Louis Vuitton and Hermes have been expanding in China's biggest cities.

site_title: China seen cutting mortgage reference rate for first time since June
summary: China is set to cut its benchmark mortgage reference rate for the first time since June, as banks' improving net interest margins give authorities some leeway to use monetary stimulus to shore up faltering economy growth. A survey of 27 market watchers predicts a reduction of 5-15 basis points, with 92.6% of respondents expecting a cut. The move aims to support China's slowing economy and mitigate the impact of US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The property market, once a pillar of the world’s second-biggest economy, has suffered a liquidity crisis since 2021, triggering many developers to default on, or delay, debt payments.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Xpeng to hire 4,000, invest in AI
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Xpeng plans to hire 4,000 employees, representing a 25% workforce expansion, and invest 3.5 billion yuan in AI research and development. The company aims to release around 30 new products or revised models within three years. Xpeng's expansion plans contrast with rivals, which are cutting costs amid weakening demand in China's largest auto market. The company's CEO, He Xiaopeng, described 2024 as the "knockout round" for Chinese auto brands, where Xpeng plans to buck the trend and enter a high-speed positive cycle.

images.alt_text: The addition of foreign stocks to the index may send a signal to more global companies to consider a listing in Hong Kong.
Xpeng's electric vehicle (EV) G9 was on display at the Xpeng booth at the China International Supply Chain Expo in Beijing in Nov 2023.
BYD has met its ambitious three million target, selling 3.01 million cars in 2023 – in the process overtaking Tesla as the world’s top-selling EV maker.
A sign of Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker XPeng Motors is pictured at its booth in a shopping mall in Beijing, China November 3, 2023. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang
Chinese EV maker Xpeng's operating loss for the third quarter stood at 3.16 billion yuan (S$588 million), compared with the estimates of 3.79 billion yuan.

site_title: Nintendo plunges after game makers say Switch 2 pushed to 2025
summary: Nintendo shares dropped 8.5% after reports that the company is pushing back the launch of its Switch successor to early 2025, from the last quarter of this year. This delay may impact blockbuster game releases and sales, as investors had expected a new console in 2024. The company's president, Shuntaro Furukawa, previously stated that selling the existing Switch will be challenging, and without a new console for the holiday season, Nintendo will face competition from newer consoles from Sony and Microsoft.

site_title: Dry weather hampers mass Christmas Island crab migration
summary: Unusually dry weather on Christmas Island has delayed the annual migration of over 100 million red crabs, typically occurring from the island's interior to the sea in February. The crabs' migration was halted due to "exceptionally dry" conditions, with the island receiving only half its average rainfall in the past 12 months. This is the first time the crabs have migrated as late as February since tracking began in the 1980s, with the females staying behind to hatch eggs and the males returning inland. Authorities are concerned about the impact on the crabs' population and mating habits.

site_title: China’s frugal holiday tourists show recovery still needs work
summary: China's tourism revenue declined 9.5% per capita during the Chinese New Year holiday season, despite an 8% increase in domestic trips and a 19% rise in tourism-related sales. The slowdown highlights the challenges in reviving consumer confidence and combating deflation in the country's economy, which is expected to be the top contributor to global growth. Economists warn that the sustainability of the services sector recovery remains uncertain, and additional policy easing may be needed to boost demand and sentiment.

images.alt_text: The government’s efforts to get overseas companies to return after Covid are falling short, and more will be needed if Beijing is to succeed in its aims.
Chinese leaders are hunting for ways to jump-start the economy, which faces headwinds from a property slump, weak business confidence and persistent deflationary pressures.

Even a year after Chinese borders re-opened, the lure of duty-free shopping in Hainan remains strong as flight restrictions, visa delays and the high cost of travel to far-flung international destinations have kept many Chinese travellers home.
For international travels, China witnessed around 13.5 million inbound and outbound trips during the holiday, growing by 2.8 times year on year.
While travel surged above pre-pandemic levels, spending per person fell as consumers sought out cheaper deals.
ADP expects Chinese traffic to reach 65 per cent of 2019 levels in the summer season, starting in April, compared to 50 to 55 per cent currently.
China has been beset by falling prices for much of the last year as the nation struggles to revive domestic demand and consumer confidence.
A dragon installation in Beijing, Feb 7, 2024.

site_title: China’s biggest wind companies squeeze rivals out of record boom
summary: China's top three wind turbine makers, Goldwind Science & Technology, Envision Energy, and Windey Energy Technology Group, dominated the domestic market, accounting for over half of the turbines installed in 2023. Wind additions surged 58% to 77 gigawatts, driven by the end of pandemic-era curbs and a push for clean energy in deserts and interior regions. Local wind companies face weaker profits due to intense competition, with average onshore turbine prices hitting a record low, and manufacturers' profitability likely to remain challenged in 2024.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts 40.9% drop in H2 DPU to 1.33 pence
summary: Elite Commercial Reit reported a 40.9% drop in half-yearly distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.33 pence, down from 2.25 pence in the same period last year. Revenue rose 0.9% to £18.5 million, while net property income increased 21.1% to £21.4 million. The decline in DPU was mainly due to a larger unit base. The company's full-year DPU fell 36.2% to 3.07 pence, and the amount available for distribution to unitholders decreased 21.9%.

images.alt_text: Great Western House, Birkenhead, one of the properties in Elite Commercial Reit's portfolio. The overall portfolio's valuation as at Dec 1, 2023 stands at £412.5 million.

Great Western House, Birkenhead. The 58 properties have a total net lettable area of 1.3 million square feet, and include Great Western House in Birkenhead (pictured), and a building in Newport Road,

site_title: Budget 2024 property tax changes unlikely to impact homebuying decisions: OCBC
summary: OCBC Investment Research believes that property tax changes in Singapore, including revised property annual value bands and a reduced Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) clawback rate, are unlikely to significantly impact homebuying decisions. The changes are expected to result in lower property tax bills, but the impact may be limited. OCBC also projects private residential price growth of 1-3% in 2024 and private home rents to decline by at least 5%. The research team views these measures as a positive for property developers and real estate investment trusts.

images.alt_text: Condominiums, and HDB housing flats as viewed from Sims Avenue on Dec 21, 2023. Can be used for stories on budget, money, URA, property, land, housing, population, economy, and development.

site_title: Foreign direct investment to China slumps to 30 year low
summary: Foreign direct investment (FDI) into China plummeted to a 30-year low in 2023, with the country's direct investment liabilities reaching $33 billion, a 82% decrease from 2022. The decline is attributed to the Covid lockdowns and weak recovery, as well as geopolitical tensions and higher interest rates in other countries. Chinese authorities are struggling to attract foreign companies to return, and more incentives may be needed to achieve their economic goals.

images.alt_text: Chinese leaders are hunting for ways to jump-start the economy, which faces headwinds from a property slump, weak business confidence and persistent deflationary pressures.
For international travels, China witnessed around 13.5 million inbound and outbound trips during the holiday, growing by 2.8 times year on year.
While travel surged above pre-pandemic levels, spending per person fell as consumers sought out cheaper deals.

site_title: Hot stock: Olam surges after investigations show no involvement in US$50 billion Nigerian fraud
summary: Olam Group's shares surged 13.6% on Monday after the company announced it had concluded investigations into Olam Nigeria with no evidence of involvement in a multibillion-dollar Nigerian fraud. The investigation, led by an internal team, found no wrongdoing by the company or its subsidiaries. Olam's shares had previously plummeted to a 52-week low after the company posted a bond for its Nigerian unit's director to secure cooperation with authorities.

images.alt_text: Olam’s announcement confirms a media report that bond was posted for a director of its Nigerian unit.
Olam Group says its board has directed the audit committee to “nevertheless conduct a review of the matter”.
Olam Group's food ingredient unit, ofi, has secured a sustainability-linked facility worth US$1.75 billion to refinance its existing loans.
The group said it expects to continue to incur expenses associated with the execution of its reorganisation plan in H2.

site_title: China’s premier urges ‘forceful’ action to boost confidence
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang urged "pragmatic and forceful" action to boost confidence in the economy, which faces challenges from a property slump, weak business confidence, and deflationary pressures. He called for officials to focus on practical problems and ensure consistent policymaking. Authorities have been trying to stem the equities rout with state funds and regulatory tweaks, and a draft government work report outlining 2024 growth targets will be announced in March. The move aims to jump-start the economy and win back public trust.

site_title: Spring festival spending on China’s duty-free island Hainan hits record
summary: Hainan, China's duty-free island, saw a record 2.49 billion yuan (S$465.6 million) in duty-free spending over the Lunar New Year holiday, a 60% year-on-year rise. The island's duty-free shopping remains strong despite travel restrictions, with 297,000 shoppers spending an average of 8,358 yuan each. Overall, domestic tourism spending in China jumped 47.3% to 632.7 billion yuan, with 474 million domestic trips made during the holiday. The number of passengers using China's railways and flights also increased, but average spending per trip remained 9.5% lower than in 2019.

images.alt_text: The new year holiday marks China’s most important national celebration and is a key barometer for consumption early in the year.
For international travels, China witnessed around 13.5 million inbound and outbound trips during the holiday, growing by 2.8 times year on year.

site_title: Thailand’s Q4 GDP quarterly contraction firms case for rate cut
summary: Thailand's GDP contracted 0.6% in the fourth quarter of 2023, down from a revised 0.6% rise in the third quarter, according to the state planning agency. This unexpected contraction adds pressure for a rate cut, driven by high household debt and China's slowdown. The economy grew 1.7% year-over-year, slower than forecast. The central bank is expected to consider a rate cut at its next policy review on April 10, after it left interest rates steady in February, with two dissenters favoring a reduction.

Thailand's former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra leaves a police hospital after being granted parole.
The revised amount is slightly higher than 1.17 trillion baht previously approved and aims to attract more private companies to invest in government projects.
Thailand has recently waived visas for citizens of China and India to boost tourism, a key driver of South-east Asia’s second-biggest economy.

epa11064243 Chinese tourists visit the Temple of the Emerald Buddha at the Grand Palace complex in Bangkok, Thailand, 08 January 2024. Thailand aims to welcome 8 million Chinese tourists in 2024, a 75 percent of recovery rate from before the 2019 coronavirus pandemic to boost the country's tourism industry after Thailand and China agreed to waive visa requirements permanently for Chinese and Thai citizens, which will come into effect on 01 March 2024, according to Chai Wacharonke, a Thai government spokesperson. site_title: Dubai airport passenger numbers top pre-pandemic levels in 2023
summary: Dubai International Airport (DXB) saw a 31.7% increase in passenger traffic last year to 86.9 million, surpassing pre-pandemic levels in 2019. The airport, the world's busiest international hub, has seen an economic recovery driven by tourism and trade, with India being the top destination country. Dubai Airports forecasts 88.8 million passengers in 2024, close to its record high of 89.1 million set in 2018.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed as China enjoys Lunar New Year bump
summary: Asian stocks were mixed on Monday as China's markets gained following the Lunar New Year, while other markets were affected by a hot US inflation report. Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets rose, and markets in Seoul and Sydney also gained. However, Tokyo and Hong Kong fell after the US wholesale price increase dealt a blow to hopes of an early interest-rate cut. The US markets ended in the red due to concerns over the timing of Fed rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 64 to 48.

site_title: Gold prices recover as softer US dollar lifts appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% on Monday, February 19, as a softer US dollar lifted appeal, partially recovering from last week's 0.5% loss. The recovery was driven by a decline in the US dollar index, making greenback-priced bullion more affordable for overseas buyers. Despite this, traders have pushed back expectations of a US interest rate cut from March to June, citing ongoing inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: US gold futures edged 0.1 per cent higher to US$2,016.00 per ounce.

site_title: Jefferies stops coverage on Paytm until regulatory issues ease
summary: JEFFERIES Financial Group has dropped coverage on Paytm-operator One 97 Communications until regulatory issues ease, citing concerns over the continuity of its business model. The banking regulator's surprise clampdown led to a loss of over half of Paytm's value. The company has tied up with Axis Bank to continue its merchant payments settlement operations. Analysts predict Paytm will dip into its cash reserves to retain users, and the RBI has granted the company an extension of its deadline to wind down business until March 15.

site_title: Indonesia’s new president; Thailand’s PM selling the land bridge
summary: Indonesia's Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto is poised to become the country's next president, according to unofficial vote counts. Thailand's Prime Minister has announced plans to sell a land bridge connecting the two countries. Meanwhile, consumer confidence in Thailand has reached a 47-month high, prompting an extra holiday to boost tourism. In other news, Malaysia's Westports is seeking new investors for expansion, Singapore's GDP growth has been revised down to 1.1%, and an Indonesian solar project has secured a conditional licence to import electricity to Singapore.

images.alt_text: Ahead of Indonesia’s Polling Day on February 14, a mandatory cooling-off period will be held from February 11 to 13.
A man walks past the entrance of Bank Negara Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur. The country’s central bank maintained its overnight policy rate at 3 per cent in January.
Delegates convened at the fourth Asean Digital Senior Officials Meeting in Singapore on Jan 30 in preparation for the Feb 1-2 Asean Digital Ministers Meeting.
Indonesian President Joko Widodo paid a visit to VinFast manufacturing complex in Hai Phong on Jan 13, 2024.

site_title: France cuts 2024 growth forecast as outlook darkens
summary: France's 2024 growth forecast has been lowered to 1% from 1.4% due to the war in Ukraine and Gaza, as well as a slowdown in top trading partners Germany and China. Finance minister Bruno Le Maire announced plans to cut state spending by 10 billion euros to meet the 4.4% deficit target. The government aims to maintain its deficit target despite a darkened economic outlook. Le Maire stated the forecast is "positive, but takes into account the new geopolitical context."

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies headquarters in San Francisco.Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
S&P has cut credit rating for the PBB to BBB-, one step above junk.
The number of homes sold for more than £5 million (S$8.5 million) in January is down 17 per cent from last year.
Germany’s DAX hit an intra-day record high, and ended up 0.6 per cent at a record closing high.
The new facility will host a total of 300 scientists and engineers who had previously been scattered around other Google offices around Paris.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit within a whisker of its 1998 record low
summary: Malaysia's ringgit has dropped nearly 4% this year, putting it just a whisker away from its 1998 record low of 4.885 per US dollar. The currency's weakness is attributed to declining exports, a struggling Chinese economy, and US dollar strength. Analysts predict a stronger ringgit by the end of the year as Malaysia's economic growth gains momentum, with some forecasting a level of RM4.45-4.60 per US dollar. The Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to keep its key interest rate unchanged, providing support for the currency.

site_title: Airlines’ chief pleads for more green fuel to save air travel
summary: Airlines' chief Willie Walsh urged oil producers to increase low-emissions aviation fuel production to meet the industry's goal of net zero carbon emissions by 2050. Demand for sustainable aviation fuel far exceeds supply, with prices 3-5 times higher than conventional jet fuel. Walsh warned that hydrogen will not be a viable alternative and estimated $5 trillion in capital investment is needed for the transition. The industry faces challenges, including supply-chain snarls and uncertain delivery of new aircraft and spare parts, which may lead to aircraft grounding in 2024 and 2025.

images.alt_text: Singapore's 2030 target for reducing aviation sector emissions includes operations at both Changi and Seletar Airports.
Within the group, the flagship airline’s revenue passenger-kilometres rose 14.3 per cent to 9.6 billion, from 8.4 billion year on year.

site_title: Global factory check-up is about to reveal extent of nascent recovery
summary: S&P Global's index of US manufacturing in February is seen coming close to stagnating, according to closely-watched measures of activity for Europe and Asia. This follows a recent uptick in the global index of manufacturing to its highest level since mid-2022, sparking expectations of a nascent recovery. Goldman Sachs economists believe manufacturing activity has troughed and should improve due to resilient global growth and central bank rate cuts in 2024.

site_title: BYD announces new stock buyback and plans more luxury models
summary: BYD, a Shenzhen-based electric vehicle manufacturer, announced a new stock buyback plan to revive its stock price slump. The company also plans to ramp up production of luxury models, boosting its credentials beyond budget-friendly cars. Despite record deliveries in the fourth quarter, BYD's profit fell short of analysts' estimates due to industry-wide price war concerns. BYD's Hong Kong-listed stock was down 11.4% for the year, and the company's shares are expected to trade 1% lower on Monday. The stock buyback aims to support the company's stock price recovery.

images.alt_text: Major US automakers have warned that Chinese cars could spell doom for their own prospects, among them Elon Musk’s Tesla.

site_title: US to soften tailpipe rules, slow EV transition through 2030
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is expected to ease proposed yearly emissions requirements for electric vehicles (EVs) through 2030, slowing the pace of EV sales. The revised regulation, to be made public next month, will result in EVs accounting for less than 60% of total vehicles produced by 2030. Automakers and the United Auto Workers union had urged the administration to slow the proposed ramp-up in EV sales, citing the need for more time to develop charging infrastructure and make EV technology more affordable for consumers.

site_title: DBS Foundation uses getai to educate seniors on scams, digital literacy
summary: DBS Foundation has organised "Your Neighbourhood Getai" events to educate seniors on digital literacy and scams, using getai edutainment. Over 2,800 seniors have attended seven events, covering topics like PayLah! and phishing scams. The initiative is part of DBS' partnership with the Infocomm Media Development Authority to drive digital literacy. With 46,000 scam cases reported last year, DBS Foundation plans to intensify anti-scam education via platforms like TikTok and launch an anti-scam quiz to test seniors' scam quotient.

images.alt_text: Nicholas Ionides, MBS’ vice-president of communications and corporate affairs, with a senior at the reunion lunch organised by MBS and Care Corner.

site_title: Chemical Industries refutes allegations of providing ‘post-retirement perks’ to co-founder
summary: Chemical Industries refutes allegations that co-founder Lim Soo Peng received "post-retirement perks" from the company. The allegations, made by minority shareholders, claimed Lim received a dedicated office, personal support staff, and medical expenses paid by the company. However, Chemical Industries maintains that Lim uses the office solely for official company matters and does not have a dedicated personal administrative staff. The company also clarifies that Lim's directors' fee includes a basic fee paid to all non-executive directors and an additional fee for his role as emeritus chairman.

site_title: S&P 500 shows strong momentum
summary: The S&P 500 Index has shown strong momentum since the beginning of 2024, surging by over 5% from its starting level of 4,745.20. On February 15, the index opened higher and closed at a new record high of 5,029.73, despite a decline in the technology sector. Treasury yields retreated, and a decline in retail sales provided relief to investors. Two possible scenarios for the index's future performance are a bullish scenario, where it may continue to climb, and a bearish scenario, where it may experience a reversal, with potential support levels at 4,989.80 and 4,800.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has finished up 0.9 per cent at 38,773.12.

site_title: Goldman lifts S&P 500 target to 5,200 on profit expansion
summary: Goldman Sachs has raised its target for the S&P 500 to 5,200 by the end of 2024, up 2% from its previous forecast, driven by increased profit estimates. The firm now expects the index to rise 3.9% from its current level, with a median target of 4,950 set by nearly a dozen equity strategists. The upgrade reflects expectations of stronger economic growth and higher profits in the technology and communication-services sectors, with valuation multiples remaining close to current levels.

images.alt_text: Europe’s STOXX 600 has risen 13 per cent since hitting a low in late October and has gained about 2 per cent so far this year.
Nvidia has emerged as a poster child of the AI frenzy and saw a record monthly jump in its market value in January.
The British pound was last at US$1.30 two years ago.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on first trading day after Budget 2024; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore's shares remained relatively unchanged on the first trading day after Budget 2024, with the Straits Times Index (STI) edging down 0.01% to 3,221.58. The budget set aside funds for cost-of-living support, business incentives, and housing support, but also introduced a new SkillsFuture programme and Refundable Investment Credit scheme. Thai Beverage gained 3% while Seatrium rose 2.2%, but Singtel fell 0.8%. Global markets were mixed, with the Dow Jones down 0.4% and the Nasdaq Composite down 0.8%, due to reduced hopes of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates soon.

images.alt_text: Cosco shipping expects to report a net profit of about S$1.9 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2023.

site_title: Westpac sees monetary policy ‘less restrictive’ over next year, Q1 profit drops
summary: Westpac Banking reported a 6% drop in its unaudited first-quarter net profit to A$1.5 billion, citing the impact of hedge accounting and a rapid rise in interest rates. Despite this, the bank expects the economy to remain resilient due to low unemployment and healthy corporate balance sheets. CEO Peter King anticipates monetary policy to become less restrictive within the next year, driven by an economic slowdown and abating inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Westpac will pay a final dividend of 72 Australian cents per share.

site_title: Thai authorities say more investigation needed before indicting ex-PM Thaksin over royal insults
summary: Thai authorities say they need more investigation into a royal insults complaint against former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra before deciding to indict him. Thaksin, released on parole on Sunday, will report back to officials on April 10. The issue revolves around an interview he gave in 2015, where he made comments deemed insulting to the monarchy. Despite Thaksin's pledge of loyalty to the monarchy, the attorney-general's office is still required to conduct further investigation before making a decision.

site_title: Oil down in thin trade as US gears up for Presidents’ Day
summary: Oil prices edged down on Monday morning, with Brent crude futures falling 58 cents, or 0.69%, to $82.89 a barrel. US Federal Reserve officials signaled a more patient stance on interest rate cuts, contributing to the bearish market trend. Markets await China's demand after its Lunar New Year holiday and the impact of Presidents' Day in the US. Tensions in the Middle East and the ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas also influenced the market.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 61 cents, or 0.74 per cent at US$83.47 a barrel on Friday.

site_title: EU to fine Apple about 500 million euros over music services
summary: The European Union is set to fine Apple around 500 million euros over its alleged anti-competitive practices in the App Store. The fine is linked to a complaint from Spotify Technology in 2019, claiming Apple's rules forced it to increase subscription prices. The EU's antitrust arm has also introduced the Digital Markets Act, which aims to prevent powerful firms from favoring their own services over rivals. The fine is expected to be announced next month, marking the EU's first antitrust fine against a major tech company.

site_title: Unrealistic to fully cut financing to coal companies: Singapore banks
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have expressed that cutting all financing for coal companies is unrealistic due to the region's reliance on coal for power generation and the need for an orderly transition process. Despite having some restrictions in coal financing, the banks continue to have client relationships with major coal developers in South-east Asia. The banks aim to enable a just transition by financing clean energy generation and supporting decarbonization goals, but critics argue that their policies are insufficient and that banks should stop lending to coal companies entirely.

Asia slashed the share of fossil fuels in power generation by 8 percentage points to 68 per cent in 2022 from 2015, abating more gas and coal use than Europe and North America.

site_title: Outbound travellers from Singapore to pay levy from 2026 as part of sustainable air hub drive
summary: Singapore will impose a levy on air travelers departing from 2026 to support the use of sustainable aviation fuel, aiming to reduce emissions by 80% by 2050. The levy, set by the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore, will vary by distance and class of travel, with estimates ranging from S$3 to S$16 for flights to Bangkok, Tokyo, and London. The revenue will be used to buy sustainable aviation fuel, which is expected to contribute to 65% of the country's carbon reduction goals. The move is part of the Singapore Sustainable Air Hub Blueprint, which outlines 12 initiatives to lower emissions.

site_title: Sixth Pofma order for Kenneth Jeyaretnam over false claims on Ridout Road rentals
summary: Singapore's Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) has ordered Reform Party chief Kenneth Jeyaretnam to correct false claims that the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) mismanaged rentals for state properties at 26 and 31 Ridout Road. Jeyaretnam's claims were deemed untrue and misleading, contradicting a government review led by Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean, which found the SLA rented the properties at fair market value. The correction notices will be posted on Jeyaretnam's website and social media, as well as on two alternative news sites.

site_title: Seatrium consortium to build third offshore wind project for Dutch electrical transmission operator
summary: Seatrium, a consortium, has been awarded a contract to build the third offshore wind project for TenneT, the Dutch electrical transmission operator, valued at approximately $2.9 billion. The 2-gigawatt high voltage direct current electrical transmission system is expected to be completed on June 1 and will contribute to TenneT's sustainability goal of installing 40GW of offshore wind energy. Seatrium's scope of work includes engineering, procurement, construction, and installation of the offshore converter platform, which will serve the third offshore wind farm, approximately 95 km off the coast of the Netherlands.

site_title: UK property prices show first annual rise since August: Rightmove
summary: UK property prices have seen their first annual rise since August 2023, with asking prices increasing 0.1% in February compared to the previous year, according to Rightmove. This marks the first annual increase in six months. Demand from buyers strengthened, with properties coming onto the market and buyer enquiries increasing by 7%. Mortgage interest rates, although still elevated, have fallen, contributing to the market's stabilization. The Bank of England is expected to lower borrowing costs this year, potentially further boosting the housing market.

images.alt_text: Huw Pill, chief economist at the Bank of England, speaks during the National Association of Business Economics economic policy conference in Washington, DC, Feb 16, 2024.
The average price of a home in the UK rose to £284,691 in December, a 0.1 per cent rise compared to the previous month.

site_title: Cracks start to emerge in global central bank synchronicity
summary: Global central bank synchronicity is weakening as domestic drivers take over from global trends in determining price outlooks. The US Federal Reserve's push-back against market bets on near-term easing has convinced traders to embrace its stance, while the euro area is seeing price pressures retreat faster than expected. The International Monetary Fund's forecasts highlight divergent economic prospects, with improved US outlooks, worse eurozone prospects, and miserable figures for the UK. Central banks are expected to react to local pressures, such as varying inflation drivers, and react at different speeds, leading to a return to more varied policies outside of crisis periods.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank across the Main River, Frankfurt. History suggests central banks ought to be seen as geopolitical assets, says academic Will Bateman.

site_title: Singapore-based company Nandina REM debuts recycled carbon fibre material for aircraft, EVs
summary: Singapore-based company Nandina REM has debuted a recycled carbon fibre material for aircraft and electric vehicles (EVs). The material, produced from retired aircraft, is of higher quality than previously available recycled carbon fibre and will be used for non-critical aircraft components and EVs. Nandina REM will showcase its material at the Singapore Airshow 2024, marking a first for aviation in using recycled carbon fibre in new aircraft production.

site_title: ‘Oppenheimer’ dominates Baftas in major Oscars boost
summary: Christopher Nolan's "Oppenheimer" dominated the 2024 British Academy of Film and Television Awards, sweeping seven awards including Best Film, Best Director, and Best Actor for Cillian Murphy. The film's success boosts its Oscar prospects, with the movie having already grossed over $1 billion and winning at the Golden Globes and Critics Choice Awards. Murphy and Robert Downey Jr. also won awards for their performances, while Emma Stone won Best Actress for her role in "Poor Things".

summary: Singaporean employees laid off face limited protections under employment law. Retrenchment can be disputed, with Amarjit Kaur, head of employment law, offering guidance on how to negotiate exit packages. The NTUC has called for support for displaced workers and caregivers in Budget 2024, amid a 'tough year' ahead.

site_title: What’s the ‘January effect’ for stocks? Is it real?
summary: US stocks have historically shown gains in January, with the January effect being a widely accepted theory. The phenomenon was first identified by investment banker Sidney Wachtel in 1942 and was later confirmed by research. The effect was most pronounced among small-cap stocks from 1940 to the mid-1970s, but its reliability has shrunk since 2000. Despite this, some theories suggest that the January effect may still exist, such as tax-loss harvesting and behavioral factors. In 2024, US stocks are off to a bumpy start, with small caps delivering losses, but historically, big annual gains in December have presaged further gains in the subsequent year.

site_title: Budget 2024: Embracing climate action for sustainable growth
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to accelerate the nation's shift to a net-zero carbon economy, with a focus on clean energy pathways, resilience, and sustainable development. The government has committed to deploying solar panels, geothermal energy, and hydrogen, and has introduced an Energy Efficiency Grant and a S$5 billion Future Energy Fund. SMEs will also benefit from enhanced funding and partnerships with multinational enterprises to support their green transition. The budget also includes measures to support a skilled workforce and build a carbon hub for the region, with a carbon tax rate set to rise to S$50-80 per tonne by 2030.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's latest tanker and dry bulk market roundup (Feb 16, 2024) reports a mixed market with a slight softening in the Pacific, driven by Chinese New Year holidays. Activity in the Atlantic picked up, with a robust fixture from East Coast Canada to the Far East, leading to a noticeable uptick in the C9 index. Conditions in South Brazil and West Africa stabilized towards the end of the week, with a major fixing at $24.00 from Tubarao to China. The C3 index settled at $24.275 on the day.

site_title: New Bob Marley film gets box office love in North America theatres
summary: A new biopic, "Bob Marley: One Love," starring Kingsley Ben-Adir as the reggae singer, topped the North American box office with estimated earnings of $27.7 million, surpassing expectations. The film's strong audience reception contrasts with its 13% positive rating on Rotten Tomatoes. "Madame Web" placed second, while "Argylle" and "Migration" rounded out the top three. "Wonka" dropped out of the top five but reached the $600 million mark globally.
