site_title: Dasin Retail Trust fires CEO of trustee-manager, majority of directors declare proposed EGM on Feb 19 invalid
summary: Dasin Retail Trust has fired its CEO Wang Qiu, effective Feb 14, following a dispute with its previous CIO Lu Zhiqi over outstanding payments. The trustee-manager, Dasin Retail Trust Management (DRTM), has declared a proposed extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Feb 19, convened by minority unit holders to remove DRTM, invalid due to a lack of proper signatures. Two directors, Cao Yong and Zhang Zhencheng, disagree with the decision, arguing the EGM should proceed.

images.alt_text: The employment of Chinese real estate veteran Wang Peng as the new CIO with take effect from Feb 13.

site_title: Scam victims in Singapore lost S$651.8 million in 2023, with record high cases
summary: Singapore saw a record high of 46,563 scam cases in 2023, with victims losing S$651.8 million, a 1.2% increase from 2022. The top 10 scams of concern included job scams, e-commerce scams, and fake friend call scams. Most victims were aged 30-49, with job scams targeting young adults and e-commerce scams targeting those aged 30-49. The police worked with overseas law enforcement agencies to take down 19 scam syndicates, recovering over S$11.5 million. An anti-scam campaign was launched in 2023, urging the public to "ACT" against scams.

images.alt_text: The seven comprised five men and two women aged from 23 to 74, one of who is believed to be the mastermind of the scheme, Hong Kong customs authorities say.
Google is joining other Internet browsers to eliminate third-party cookies.
While write-offs are typically a small fraction of a bank’s balance sheet, the impact of scams can often be “ruinous” for the depositor, says Workers' Party Member of Parliament Jamus Lim.

site_title: How Donald Trump’s candidacy tests the US constitution
summary: Former US President Donald Trump faces 91 felony charges in four cases, including conspiracy to defraud the US and mishandling classified documents. His immunity claim from prosecution as a former president has been rejected by a US district judge and a US appeals court panel. The 14th Amendment to the US Constitution, which bars individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion from public office, is now before the US Supreme Court. The court will consider whether Trump's actions on January 6, 2021, and his efforts to overturn the 2020 election loss make him ineligible to serve again. Trump's eligibility to serve as president, his ability to pardon himself, and potential removal by impeachment are also being questioned.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump was found liable for unlawfully inflating his wealth and manipulating the value of properties to obtain favourable bank loans or insurance terms.
If one is presiding over a good economy, as Joe Biden is, and persuadable voters seem to be aware that it’s a good economy, why shouldn't he claim credit?
Democrat Tom Suozzi celebrates with his family after his victory in the special election to replace Republican Representative George Santos in Woodbury, New York, Feb 13, 2024.
US President Joe Biden accused Donald Trump of bowing to Russian President Vladimir Putin, after Trump said he would encourage Moscow to attack Nato members who failed to meet financial commitments.
Rather than focusing on candidates’ ages per se, we should consider whether they have the capabilities to do the job.
The US presidential elections, where former president Donald Trump is a likely candidate, will be the most consequential election for global investors this year.
President Joe Biden's age has once again become a talking point in US national politics, after recent incidents where he confused the names of foreign leaders.

site_title: Singapore bags S$750 million in aerospace investment commitments; 2,500 jobs to be filled: EDB
summary: Singapore secured over S$750 million in aerospace investment commitments from more than 10 projects, with over 2,500 jobs to be created in the next 3-5 years. The Economic Development Board (EDB) made the announcement at the Singapore Airshow 2024 media briefing. The investments span across different parts of the global aerospace value chain, marking a significant boost for the sector.

images.alt_text: Organised by Experia Events, the Singapore Airshow will feature trade exhibitors from over 1,000 companies.

site_title: Harrison Ford’s Star Wars script fetches £10,795 at UK sale
summary: Harrison Ford's original, incomplete, and unbound Star Wars script, containing revisions and introducing Han Solo on page 56, sold at a UK auction for £10,795. The script, the fourth draft from 1976, was left at a London flat by Ford while filming the first Star Wars installment. The sale set a new record for a Star Wars script, highlighting the appeal of personal links to the items for fans.

images.alt_text: DPM Wong presented a milestone budget that helps to address everything about the numerous challenges ahead brought about by cost-of-living increases, threats to jobs, wars and global uncertainty, international tax challenges and climate change, among others.
Irving Azoff’s Iconic Artists Group acquired Stewart’s interests in his recorded music and publishing catalog, as well as some rights to his name as likeness, for a tidy sum of nearly US$100 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Cosco Shipping, Sri Trang Agro-Industry, Sri Trang Gloves, Olam, Elite Commercial Reit
summary: Cosco Shipping expects to report a net profit of S$1.9 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2023, reversing a net loss from the same period last year. Shares rose 2.8% to close at S$0.146. Sri Trang Agro-Industry swung to a net loss of S$15.8 million for its fourth quarter, while Sri Trang Gloves reported a 10.1% increase in net loss. Olam Group cleared its Nigerian unit of a multibillion-dollar fraud report, with shares ending 0.6% higher. Elite Commercial Reit posted a 40.9% drop in distribution per unit due to higher borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: 新加坡交易所（Singapore Exchange，SGX）标志。SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Air New Zealand warns competition, slow demand will hit earnings
summary: Air New Zealand warned of a potential drop in earnings due to increased competition from US airlines and slowing corporate demand. The airline expects full-year pretax profit to decline to NZ$200 million, down from NZ$585 million last year. Revenue performance is expected to be lower in the second half of the year due to increased capacity and pricing pressure from US carriers, as well as ongoing weakness in domestic demand. The company will incur costs of NZ$35 million in the second half related to engine repairs.

images.alt_text: Air New Zealand aircraft sit on the tarmac at the International Terminal of Auckland Airport in Auckland, New Zealand. Photographer: Brendon O'Hagan/Bloomberg

site_title: Macquarie plans to cut stake in UK gas network operator
summary: Macquarie, which owns a 26% stake in UK gas network operator Cadent, is in early talks to sell a 5% stake, potentially worth £1.3 billion. US-based Federated Hermes, which owns 13% of Cadent, is also considering selling a 4.6% stake. The move comes as Britain targets to phase out natural gas use by 2050 in pursuit of net-zero emissions. Despite the potential sale, Macquarie and Federated Hermes claim to be committed to long-term investments.

site_title: Lilly’s climb has analysts asking US$1 trillion question
summary: Eli Lilly's stock has surged 34% this year due to strong demand for its diabetes and obesity drugs, Mounjaro and Zepbound. Analysts at Morgan Stanley have lifted their price target, predicting a possible market value of around $900 billion, making Lilly the first US company outside of the "Magnificent Seven" to reach a $1 trillion valuation. Lilly's market capitalization surpassed Tesla's last month, and shares hit a fresh record high on Friday, closing at $782.06.

images.alt_text: Abbott says the protein shake is first among the range of products lined up to be launched under its new brand, called Protality.

site_title: Japan carmakers forge ahead with EV investments despite slowdown
summary: Japan's top automakers are investing heavily in electric vehicles (EVs) despite a slowdown in EV sales growth. Executives say they're waiting for the right moment to electrify, citing high inflation and interest rates making EVs unaffordable for many consumers. Toyota, Honda, and Nissan are focusing on hybrids and alternative fuels, with Toyota planning to sell 5 million petrol-electric vehicles annually by 2025. The companies are also investing in EVs at a deliberate pace, with Toyota's CFO stating that electrification is not linear growth, but a long-term strategy.

images.alt_text: The high cost of EVs has become a significant barrier to broader mass adoption for zero-emission cars.
Sales of fully-electric cars, or battery electric vehicles (BEVs), and plug-in hybrids hit 1.1 million globally in January, up from 660,000 in January 2023.

site_title: Serial System expects net loss for FY2023
summary: Serial System Ltd, an electronic components and consumer products distributor, expects a net loss for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2023, primarily due to loss allowance for trade receivables, net foreign exchange loss, and higher interest expenses. The group's weak financial performance is attributed to a slowdown in consumer and industrial demand in Asia, particularly China, amidst macro challenges. This marks a reversal from the US$12.6 million profit reported in FY 2021.

site_title: More training, tighter regulations needed as board directors face ‘increasingly demanding’ role
summary: Board directors face increasing demands from regulators and the market, requiring self-discipline to keep up with company affairs. Industry observers suggest mandatory training hours, performance appraisals, and a cap on directorships to nudge directors into doing their due diligence. Following a High Court ruling that found a former director liable for $146 million losses, experts emphasize the need for directors to be "reasonably and continuously well-informed" regarding their legal and regulatory obligations. A more structured appointment process and regular training are also recommended to ensure qualified directors are appointed and remain informed about their companies.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX), Bursa Malaysia, the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) and the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) have formalised the Asean-Interconnected Sustainability Ecosystem (Asean-ISE) at a recent meeting.
The board's CEO pick reflects not only a company’s pain points and priorities but also its directors’ outlook on the broader business world.
Goh Jin Hian outside the State Courts on Sept 20, 2023. Goh was on Jan 24 found liable for breach of director’s duties, statutory duties and losses suffered by IPP.
Goh Jin Hian, the former chief executive officer of New Silkroutes Group, is charged for false trading.
The Singapore Exchange listing rules have required issuers to publish sustainability/ESG reports since 2016.

site_title: 10 S-Reits that top retail net inflows in the year to date
summary: S-Reits have experienced contrasting trends in the first half of 2024, with institutions booking over S$200 million in net selling and retail investors recording over S$280 million in net buying activity. The 10 S-Reits with largest net retail inflows include Mapletree Logistics Trust, Keppel DC Reit, and CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, which collectively contributed S$250 million to net retail inflows. Despite declines in the iEdge S-Reit Index, retail investors' increased participation has helped S-Reits record significant net retail inflows.

images.alt_text: FCT raised S$200 million of gross proceeds through private placements, the majority of which will be used to repay existing debts, pending the use of such amount to partially fund the proposed acquisition of additional interest in Nex.

site_title: Why Budget 2024 is pro-business as it is pro-social
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 prioritizes a vibrant economy while promoting social equality and mobility. The government allocates S$5 billion to remake the social compact and provides measures to support workers, families, and seniors. Key initiatives include an Enterprise Support Package, Research and Development funding, and investments in artificial intelligence and talent development. The budget also enhances measures to boost businesses, such as the Refundable Investment Credit scheme and the National Productivity Fund. By balancing economic growth with social investments, the government aims to create a stronger and more united nation, benefiting workers, businesses, and society.

images.alt_text: Given its position as a trade node and hub, Singapore can wield significant influence on the region’s green transition and lead in driving the green economy.
With volatile times ahead, Singapore will need to stay agile and constantly calibrate its strategies.
What Budget 2024 has for you

site_title: Everything Everywhere All At Once (for almost Everyone)
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong unveiled the 2024 Singapore Budget, dubbed "Everything Everywhere All At Once," addressing various challenges including cost-of-living increases, job threats, wars, climate change, and global uncertainty. The budget includes targeted tax rebates, property tax adjustments, and increased spending on healthcare, education, and workforce development. It also focuses on sustainability, total defence, and international tax reform. The budget aims to support Singapore's future through increased spending and new tax measures, aiming to remain competitive and attract foreign direct investment.

images.alt_text: With volatile times ahead, Singapore will need to stay agile and constantly calibrate its strategies.
Given its position as a trade node and hub, Singapore can wield significant influence on the region’s green transition and lead in driving the green economy.
Budget 2024 is the first instalment of Forward Singapore programmes – flagship agenda of the fourth generation People’s Action Party leadership, led by Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Kore’s distribution halt reflects Reits’ ‘original sin’ of needing constant access to capital to exist
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (Kore) has suspended its distributions from the second half of 2023 until 2025 due to a decline in its portfolio valuation and increased leverage. Despite good operational performance, the Reit's income available for distribution fell 13.8% to US$52.2 million, partly due to higher financing costs and a decrease in its portfolio's occupancy rate. The suspension reflects the "original sin" of Reits needing constant access to capital to exist, and lenders are wary of exposure to the US office market, which has been volatile.

images.alt_text: The One Twenty Five office complex is one of Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's 13 properties.
Kore makes a net loss of US$91.8 million for H2 FY2023.

site_title: Australia’s barley sales to China boom as wine decision pending
summary: Australia's barley sales to China have surged to 90% of exports in December, six months after Beijing lifted tariffs, highlighting the significant impact of China's return on the country's diversified export markets. The rapid rebound raises questions about Canberra's efforts to diversify markets, particularly in the face of geopolitical risks. With China's dominance, Australian producers may struggle to find alternative high-paying markets, and industry representatives expect a gradual recovery in Chinese demand for Australian wine, potentially returning to 24% market share in a few years.

images.alt_text: A field of barley in Balliang, Victoria, Australia. Photographer: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg

site_title: Lower property tax helps, but retirees must pay heed to costs of owning private homes
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduced changes to property tax rates, with lower thresholds for owner-occupier residential property tax rates raised to S$12,000 and higher-end properties seeing a reduction in tax rates. However, retirees who own private homes must be mindful of rising costs, including property taxes, and consider alternatives such as renting out a room or downsizing to an HDB flat. The government aims to balance property tax rates with the need to fund healthcare and other areas, and may consider further increases in the future.

images.alt_text: Homeowners can expect to pay the same or lower property tax bills at each of the band levels.
Homeowners can expect to pay the same or lower property tax bills at each of the band levels, assuming there is no change in their properties’ annual value and before any rebate.

site_title: The Singapore Edition, newest hotel on Orchard Road, opens its doors
summary: The Singapore Edition, a 204-room hotel on Orchard Road, officially opened its doors on February 18, 2024. The hotel, managed by Marriott International, features a 43m rooftop pool, spa, and meeting spaces. Located on Cuscaden Road, it is a redevelopment of the former Boulevard Hotel by a consortium of City Developments Ltd, Hong Leong Holdings, and Lea Investments. The hotel's official opening was attended by CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and his wife Cecilia Kwek.

site_title: Mom-and-pop investors are starting to tiptoe back into crypto
summary: Retail investors, also known as mom-and-pop traders, are slowly returning to the cryptocurrency market after a significant price collapse in 2022. Crypto notional volumes at Robinhood Markets jumped 242% in December, while Coinbase Global saw a 60% increase in net consumer transaction revenue in the fourth quarter. Although the market is still volatile, the launch of US exchange-traded funds investing directly in Bitcoin has sparked renewed interest, with the price of Bitcoin more than doubling last year. However, retail traders are still not at pre-bull market levels, and experts caution that the market is not yet fully recovered.

images.alt_text: Sullivan & Cromwell "actively participated" in the FTX fraud through legal work that gave it deep insight into the exchange’s inner workings, investors allege.
After initially dropping in reaction to last month’s green light by Washington, bitcoin has rallied about 25 per cent since Jan 22.

site_title: China stocks ready for bullish reopen after upbeat data
summary: Chinese stocks are poised for a strong open after holiday data showed a 61% gain in rail trips from a year earlier, with travel and tourism spending patterns suggesting consumption has revved up despite economic struggles. Onshore shares are expected to catch up with offshore gains, with traders pinning hopes on further policy support and a cut in the reserve requirement ratio. A short-term rebound is anticipated, but longer-term prospects remain uncertain, with doubts over the market's prospects amid geopolitical tensions and regulatory crackdowns.

images.alt_text: China's economy is flagging under the weight of a property crisis, weak confidence and deflation pressures.
For international travels, China witnessed around 13.5 million inbound and outbound trips during the holiday, growing by 2.8 times year on year.

site_title: Grand Venture Tech seeks to broaden its skill sets to chase next stage of growth
summary: Grand Venture Tech, a Singapore-based manufacturing service provider, is expanding its capabilities to prepare for the next stage of growth in the semiconductor industry. The company has acquired ACP Metal Finishing, a surface treatment specialist, to provide component machining, sheet metal fabrication, and surface treatment works under one roof. CEO Julian Ng aims to work with original equipment manufacturers to understand their products and provide recurring business, generating more revenue to buffer against cyclical fluctuations. The acquisition is part of the company's culture of innovation and acquisition, with plans to diversify into front-end operations and develop advanced materials.

images.alt_text: IDC has upgraded the semiconductor sector’s market outlook to “growth” from “trough”, as it called the bottom of the correction.
ACP Metal Finishing is is a surface treatment specialist involved in various electrochemical and chemical processes to coat metals.

site_title: US dollar steady after producer prices push back on Fed rate cut outlook
summary: The US dollar remained steady on Friday amid concerns about the US economy's strength, despite higher-than-expected producer prices that raised expectations for a Fed rate cut. Producer prices rose 0.8% in January, the largest in five months, but the dollar index still gained 0.01% to 104.26. The yen weakened 0.22% to 150.23, sparking concerns of a possible intervention by Japanese authorities to weaken the currency. Fed funds futures show a 10.5% chance of a rate cut in March and 33.7% odds of easing in May.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the currency against six peers, is slightly lower at 104.6, just below a three-month high of 104.97 touched on Wednesday.

site_title: TID launches Lentoria at prices from S$1,965 psf
summary: TID has launched Lentoria, a 99-year leasehold project in Lentor Hills, Singapore, with prices starting from S$1,965 per square foot (psf). The 267-unit project, which includes one-bedroom units from S$1.18 million (S$2,190 psf) and four-bedroom units, will be previewed until February 27, with sales booking starting on March 2. Developer TID, a joint venture between Hong Leong Group and Mitsui Fudosan, aims to manage a good sales pace despite competition from other projects in the area.

images.alt_text: Private home buyers may cheer if lower land prices for housing sites translate into lower selling prices of new homes.

site_title: Refundable Investment Credit, strong fiscal position could give Singapore edge: tax experts
summary: Singapore's Refundable Investment Credit (RIC) scheme, introduced in the 2024 budget, aims to encourage companies to make significant investments in key sectors and new growth areas. The scheme offers up to 50% of qualifying expenditure, exceeding similar offers from Ireland and the US. Experts say the strong fiscal position of Singapore and the clarity of the RIC will give the city-state an edge in attracting high-value investments. However, more clarity is needed on how the scheme will be computed and its potential impact on certain nationalities, with concerns raised about potential delays in refunds and favoritism towards US MNCs.

images.alt_text: DPM Wong presented a milestone budget that helps to address everything about the numerous challenges ahead brought about by cost-of-living increases, threats to jobs, wars and global uncertainty, international tax challenges and climate change, among others.
The slew of ostensibly social measures should not negate the central importance of a vibrant, thriving, and sustainable economy to a shared future, says SMU's Eugene Tan.

site_title: Singapore engineer pivots from oil rigs to ‘fish farm of the future’
summary: A high-tech fish farm, Eco Ark, has been launched off the coast of Singapore, producing 30,000 tonnes of seafood a month. The facility, founded by retired engineer Leow Ban Tat, uses advanced technology to filter seawater and simulate ocean conditions, resulting in cleaner and healthier fish. The farm aims to reduce Singapore's reliance on imported food and meet the city-state's goal of locally sourcing 30% of its food by 2030. Eco Ark's technology is expected to be exported, with plans to build similar facilities near coastal areas.

images.alt_text: Closed containment aquaculture systems, like the Eco-Ark in 2019, must be used for the farms in the tender.

site_title: Retail investors net buy S$1 billion of Singapore stocks in early 2024
summary: Retail investors in Singapore have net-bought S$1.1 billion of local stocks in the first six weeks of 2024, with the financial services and S-Reit sectors being the main beneficiaries. This follows a similar trend to the same period in 2023, with net institutional fund flows showing net withdrawals of S$463 million. The trend contrasts with the first six weeks of 2023, where retail investors withdrew around S$190 million from Singapore stocks.

images.alt_text: Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks over the five trading sessions through to Feb 8.

site_title: Sydney home auctions surge as rate-cut expectations drive buyers
summary: Sydney home auctions saw a surge in successful sales, with a preliminary clearance rate of 81.7% in the past week, the highest since mid-October 2021. This comes as Australians expect interest rates to fall, driving up demand and property prices. Despite a 12-year high interest rate, property prices have resumed rising, with a combination of migration-driven growth and limited supply contributing to the trend. Experts predict further interest rate cuts, with some expecting a cash rate of 2.85% by June 2025.

images.alt_text: A house with solar panels in Sydney. Almost 16 per cent of homes in Australia use solar power, the highest uptake in the world.
Purchases of private homes in Singapore by foreigners who are not Permanent Residents has fallen sharply with the application of 60 per cent ABSD.

site_title: What Budget 2024 has for you
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to build a shared future by tackling immediate challenges and equipping Singaporeans for longer-term obstacles. The budget includes support for older workers, with an upskilling package and increased CPF contribution rates. It also offers extra S$600 CDC vouchers for every household and a S$1.9 billion boost to the Assurance Package. Other measures include changes to property tax, a refundable Investment Credit scheme, and increased support for SMEs and SkillsFuture initiatives. The budget focuses on addressing the country's cost of living and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Thai tycoon Thaksin tastes freedom in homeland, 15 years after fleeing
summary: Thailand's former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, 74, was released on parole after six months in detention, marking his first day of freedom in 15 years. The decision was made despite Thaksin's family being in power and his health issues, sparking controversy. Thaksin was granted parole after his sentence was commuted from eight years to one year by the country's king, and he was released from a luxury hospital wing. His return and early release have raised concerns about the extent of his influence and the fairness of his treatment.

images.alt_text: Former Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra will be freed, possibly as soon as this weekend.
The revised amount is slightly higher than 1.17 trillion baht previously approved and aims to attract more private companies to invest in government projects.

site_title: China’s travel spending during Chinese New Year holidays beats pre-Covid levels
summary: China's travel spending during the Chinese New Year holidays surged by 47.3% year on year, surpassing pre-Covid levels, with domestic tourism spending reaching 632.7 billion yuan and international trips totaling 13.5 million. The tourism boost offers temporary relief to policymakers, but its sustainability remains uncertain amid deflationary risks. The holiday period also saw a record-breaking box office revenue of over 8 billion yuan, with average spending per trip reaching 1,335 yuan.

images.alt_text: China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow on Feb 18.

site_title: Sri Trang Agro-Industry sinks into red with Q4 loss of 422 million baht
summary: Sri Trang Agro-Industry, a rubber group, reported a net loss of 422 million baht (S$15.8 million) for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2023, due to a non-recurring item and impairment loss. Revenue decreased 14.3% to 21.7 billion baht, primarily affected by El Nino and oversupply in the glove business. The company's full-year loss reversed from a net profit of 4.8 billion baht a year earlier.

images.alt_text: In a business update, the group said revenue for the quarter under review was down 42.5 per cent to 16.9 billion baht.

site_title: China leaves key rate steady as yuan limits manoeuvring room
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, left its key interest rate steady at 2.5% on February 18, as policymakers sought to shield the yuan from volatility. This decision came amid a property crisis, weak confidence, and deflation pressures. Despite the lack of a rate cut, the central bank injected a small amount of cash into the financial system, and Chinese banks may still lower their lending rates in the coming week. Experts believe there is still room for a rate cut, but the PBOC is cautious to avoid yuan depreciation.

images.alt_text: For international travels, China witnessed around 13.5 million inbound and outbound trips during the holiday, growing by 2.8 times year on year.
China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow on Feb 18.

site_title: January was awesome for stock pickers, but can they keep it going?
summary: Actively managed large-cap stock mutual funds outperformed the Russell 1000 index in January, with 73% beating the index and an average 0.57 percentage point difference. This was the best January performance since 1991. However, economist Burton Malkiel, author of "A Random Walk Down Wall Street," believes that it's unlikely active fund managers will prevail in the long run due to the market's efficiency and the difficulty in beating the overall market. Historically, 90% of active managers have failed to beat index funds over 10-year periods, and those who succeed rarely repeat the feat.

images.alt_text: A swath of Chinese stocks in Hong Kong surged in response to holiday data showing a 61 per cent gain in rail trips from a year earlier.
In terms of boosting investment returns, hopes largely rest on machine learning, the subfield of AI where computers are trained on massive amounts of data to perform particular tasks.

site_title: Dubai’s golden visas are helping city defy global office slump
summary: Dubai's golden visas have contributed to the city's resilience against the global office slump. The UAE's reforms, including long-term residency, abolished a local partner requirement, and allowed unmarried couples to live together, have attracted expatriates and encouraged entrepreneurship. Data shows a 30% increase in active business licenses in 2023, a 26% rise in entities registered at the Dubai International Financial Centre, and record-high office space occupancy. The influx of foreign workers and investors has boosted the commercial real estate market, with average villa rents surging to nearly $88,500.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 61 cents, or 0.74 per cent at US$83.47 a barrel on Friday.

site_title: China’s first home-grown airliner makes international debut in Singapore
summary: China's Comac C919, its first domestically produced airliner, made its international debut at the Singapore Airshow on February 18. The narrow-body aircraft, which competes with Airbus and Boeing models, has been certified within China but not internationally. Comac plans to invest tens of billions of yuan to expand production capacity and pursue European Union Aviation Safety Agency validation. The C919 has gained attention in the industry due to the global supply crunch and growing demand for new planes, with some forecasts predicting seven to 10 deliveries in 2024.

images.alt_text: A China's Comac C919 aircraft performs during a preview of the Singapore Airshow in Singapore on February 18, 2024. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Top investors share the toughest lessons they had to learn
summary: Top investors shared their toughest lessons, revealing painful mistakes and valuable takeaways. Key lessons include the dangers of excessive leverage, trusting one's gut, and understanding market expectations. Investors also emphasized the importance of patience, understanding key stakeholders, and avoiding unrealistic claims. Notable lessons include: Bill Gross learned to limit leverage, Ann Miletti trusted her instincts, and Thomas Lee cautioned against assuming a positive trend will continue. The investors also stressed the value of teamwork, understanding the relationship between investment capital and human capital, and being wary of unrealistic market claims.

images.alt_text: Traders work during the BBB Foods Inc. initial public offering (IPO) on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Friday, Feb. 9, 2024. Mexican discount retailer BBB Foods Inc. priced its initial public offering at the top of a marketed range to raise about $589 million, adding momentum to a rebound in US listings. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Tech giants sign pact against AI-made political deepfakes
summary: Tech giants Meta, Microsoft, and TikTok have signed a pact to combat AI-generated deepfakes intended to deceive voters ahead of crucial elections worldwide. The agreement, signed by 20 companies, aims to develop solutions to identify, label, and control AI-generated images, videos, and audio meant to mislead voters. The tech companies will also work together to detect and address deceptive election material on their platforms, potentially annotating AI-generated content to make it clear it is generated by AI.

images.alt_text: A video created by Open AI's newly released text-to-video "Sora" tool plays on a monitor in Washington, DC, Feb 16, 2024.
TikTok's "election centres" are designed to better inform Europeans about the electoral process.
According to the Washington Post, the companies will agree to develop ways to identify, label and control AI-generated images, videos and audio that aim to deceive voters.
The general elections on Feb 14 in Indonesia, the world’s third-largest democracy, offer a glimpse of how generative AI may transform large-scale political campaigning, experts say.
US regulators have been considering making AI-generated robocalls illegal, with the fake Joe Biden call giving the effort new impetus.

site_title: Layoffs show that tech jobs aren’t sacred anymore
summary: Tech companies, including Microsoft, have announced significant layoffs, with over 32,000 tech workers losing their jobs this year, according to Layoffs.fyi. The industry, once known for job security and ease of employment, is experiencing a shift, with some leaders embracing a more traditional approach to business. While the layoffs have caused unease, the US economy continues to add jobs, and unemployment remains below 4%. Experts believe that the industry will eventually bounce back, with new startups and investments emerging, and companies will once again hire with abandon.

images.alt_text: Workforce reduction is often regarded as a quicker and simpler way to respond to performance shortfalls.

site_title: Oil settles up, records weekly gain on Middle East tensions
summary: Oil prices settled higher on Friday, with Brent crude futures rising 61 cents to $83.47 a barrel, driven by growing Middle East tensions. The risk of a wider conflict in the region supported crude prices, despite the International Energy Agency's forecast of slowing demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.49% to $79.19 a barrel. The market reaction to news from the Middle East was moderate, with analysts citing small disruptions to oil flows.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures has settled up US$1.26, or 1.5 per cent, at US$82.86 a barrel.

site_title: Trump fined US$355 million, banned from business in New York in fraud trial
summary: A New York judge has ordered Donald Trump to pay US$355 million over fraud allegations, finding him liable for unlawfully inflating his wealth to obtain favorable bank loans and insurance terms. Trump's sons Eric and Donald Trump Jr. were also found liable and ordered to pay more than US$4 million each. The ruling, which also banned Trump from running companies in the state for three years, was a major blow to his business empire and financial standing. Trump's legal team has vowed to appeal the decision.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden's age has once again become a talking point in US national politics, after recent incidents where he confused the names of foreign leaders.
The video posted by the Biden-Harris HQ TikTok account shows US President Joe Biden answering rapid fire questions.
If one is presiding over a good economy, as Joe Biden is, and persuadable voters seem to be aware that it’s a good economy, why shouldn't he claim credit?
Democrat Tom Suozzi celebrates with his family after his victory in the special election to replace Republican Representative George Santos in Woodbury, New York, Feb 13, 2024.
US President Joe Biden accused Donald Trump of bowing to Russian President Vladimir Putin, after Trump said he would encourage Moscow to attack Nato members who failed to meet financial commitments.
Rather than focusing on candidates’ ages per se, we should consider whether they have the capabilities to do the job.

site_title: OpenAI inks deal valuing it at US$80 billion
summary: OpenAI has concluded a deal with investors, reportedly valuing the California start-up at $80 billion or more. The agreement, led by Thrive Capital, would nearly triple the company's value in under 10 months. The firm, known for its ChatGPT program, has faced a roller-coaster year, including a major crisis when CEO Sam Altman was fired and then brought back. Microsoft has injected $13 billion into OpenAI in the past few years, as the company competes with Google in developing AI tools.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on January 23, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows screens displaying the logos of OpenAI and ChatGPT. ChatGPT maker OpenAI has said it will introduce tools to combat disinformation ahead of the dozens of elections this year in countries that are home to half the world's population. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP) / To go with "China-technology-education-AI", FOCUS by Poornima WEERASEKARA

site_title: First Bank of England interest-rate cut is months away despite recession: Pill
summary: The Bank of England's chief economist, Huw Pill, stated that a first interest-rate cut is still several months away despite the UK's recession. Pill argued that inflation may persist due to the economy's low growth capacity, a tight labor market, and poor productivity. The economy contracted 0.5% in the last two quarters of 2023, but Pill believes that a recession alone may not be enough to alter the inflation outlook. He emphasized the need to see further evidence of a sharp decline in underlying domestic inflation before considering a rate cut.

images.alt_text: Labour Party candidate Gen Kitchen celebrates after winning the Wellingborough Parliamentary by-election at the count centre in Kettering, Britain, Feb 16, 2024.
The average price of a home in the UK rose to £284,691 in December, a 0.1 per cent rise compared to the previous month.

epa10713638 A shopper at a supermarket in London, Britain, 27 June 2023. UK supermarket chiefs are set to face intense questioning from MP’s over food inflation at parliament in London 27 June. UK food inflation has fallen for the second month in a row as supermarkets cut the price of household staples. Food inflation however still remains high 8.4 percent.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
NatWest shares closed down 1.6 per cent on Tuesday at £204.40, nearly £100 lower than a year ago.
The unemployment rate fell to 3.8 per cent from 3.9 per cent in the three months to the end of November.

epa10498611 A row of houses in London, Britain, 02 March 2023. UK house prices in February dropped by the most in more than 10 years according to mortgage lender Nationwide showing signs of a slowdown in the housing market due to high inflation and rising borrowing costs.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL
The central bank is watching pay figures carefully for signs that price pressures will stick around longer than they expect.
RICS' report adds to signs of strengthening momentum in Britain’s housing market after high inflation and rising interest rates crimped demand in 2023.

site_title: FTX investors sue Sullivan & Cromwell claiming law firm aided fraud
summary: FTX investors have sued Sullivan & Cromwell, alleging the law firm "actively participated" in the FTX fraud through its work on the exchange's inner workings. The lawsuit claims the firm gave it deep insight into the exchange's operations and knew about the "untruthful and fraudulent conduct" of customer money misappropriation. This is the second law firm to face investor litigation over aiding and abetting the FTX fraud, following Fenwick & West.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FTX logo is seen in this illustration taken March 31, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Nintendo telling game publishers Switch 2 will be delayed
summary: Nintendo has delayed the release of its next-generation Switch 2 console to the first quarter of 2025, citing the seven-year-old Switch's approaching end of life cycle. The delay was advised to game publishers, contradicting earlier expectations of a late 2024 release. The company has sold over 132 million units of the Switch, indicating the need for a successor. Nintendo has not commented on the delay, but the news was reported by the Video Games Chronicle.

site_title: Why technology holds the key to improving healthcare workforce experiences
summary: Healthcare institutions in the Asia-Pacific region are leveraging technology to improve workforce experiences and address challenges such as burnout, high turnover rates, and absenteeism. 67% of healthcare leaders in the region plan to use digital health technology to reduce workforce shortages. Technologies like cloud-based solutions, workflow automation, and artificial intelligence (AI) are being adopted to automate administrative tasks, provide support to staff, and enhance patient care. Partnerships among players in the healthcare ecosystem are needed to ensure the best outcomes, and continuous education and training for healthcare workers are key to successful adoption of digital technologies.

images.alt_text: A cornerstone of Singapore’s policies is supporting families, and the government has pledged in the report to provide more assurance for Singaporeans that “they will be taken care of at every life stage as basic needs like education, retirement, healthcare and housing will be met”.
A recent survey of 1,200 Singapore residents found 42 per cent (or about four in ten) of respondents saying they would not be financially prepared to manage the costs of cancer treatment.

site_title: China’s Wang Yi held ‘constructive’ talks with Blinken in Munich
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken held 'constructive' talks with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi at the Munich Security Conference, discussing lifting sanctions against Chinese companies and individuals. Both sides also exchanged views on regional issues, including the Ukraine crisis and the Korean Peninsula. Wang Yi emphasized that "de-risking" and seeking decoupling from China will only backfire on the US. The meeting follows recent progress in bilateral relations, including agreements on fentanyl and military communications.

site_title: EU fails to pass rules on gig workers amid industry opposition
summary: The European Union failed to pass rules regulating workers' rights in the gig economy, with the legislation opposed by many industry companies, including Uber. The bloc was unable to get enough votes, derailing the EU's efforts to define the employment status of millions of people working from online platforms. The failure comes with little time to spare before European elections in June, potentially delaying new worker protections by years. Industry representatives, including Uber, expressed concerns that any EU-wide rules must maintain platform workers' independence while providing them with protections.

images.alt_text: Uber says revenue from its core ride-share business has grown 34 percent, driven in part by "outsized trip growth" in Latin America and Asia-Pacific markets.

site_title: RTO? WFH? Why post-Covid work norms are so confusing
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to lasting changes in corporate life, with widespread adoption of remote work arrangements. However, the shift to Return to Office (RTO) has not been uniform across continents, industries, or types of work. Regional variations, including a higher rate of RTO in Asia and Europe, contrast with the Americas, where hybrid schedules are more prevalent. Women and educated workers tend to value working from home more, while specific work cultures, such as Japan's 996 culture, also influence remote work patterns. Conflicts between employers and employees have arisen, with some companies pushing for stricter RTO policies, leading to worker protests and lawsuits.

images.alt_text: Bangkok and the northern city of Chiang Mai have ranked among the most polluted cities in the world on a number of days last year.

site_title: German property bank's investor turns short seller as crisis deepens
summary: A German property bank, Pfandbriefbank, is facing increasing criticism and short selling amid a deepening crisis in the property market. An investor turned short seller, Petrus Advisers, has urged the bank to disclose the extent of its problem real-estate loans, warning of a "downward spiral" if it doesn't. The bank's shares have plummeted 40% since the start of the year, and its credit rating has been downgraded to "junk". Short sellers now hold a cumulative 8% stake in the bank, betting against its shares as investors become increasingly concerned about its exposure to the US and German property markets.

images.alt_text: S&P has cut credit rating for the PBB to BBB-, one step above junk.

site_title: Softbank’s founder Son seeks to build US$100 billion AI chip venture
summary: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son is seeking up to $100 billion to fund a new AI chip venture, code-named Izanagi, to compete with Nvidia and supply semiconductors for AI applications. The project aims to create an AI chip powerhouse, with Son envisioning a company that can complement Arm Holdings. SoftBank will reportedly provide $30 billion, with potential additional funding from Middle Eastern institutions. The venture is Son's next big endeavor after curting startup investments, and it's seen as a major bet on the future of artificial general intelligence (AGI).

images.alt_text: Arm’s share price rise has made for massive gains for recent bullish options bets.
Arm is benefiting from a push beyond smartphone technology, helping fuel growth and profitability.
Under the agreement, AI-generated content could be given a watermark or tagged in the metadata at source, although the signatories acknowledged that “all such solutions have limitations”.

SoftBank is one of Invitae's backers. As at Sep 30, Invitae has roughly US$1.4 billion outstanding on two sets of bonds.

site_title: WTO chief insists global trade body still counts
summary: WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala insisted the organization remains relevant despite few major deals on the table ahead of its biennial ministerial meeting. 75% of global trade occurs under WTO terms, and Okonjo-Iweala warned that if the WTO becomes irrelevant, it could lead to a "free-for-all" with no tariffs or rules governing trade. WTO members are meeting in Abu Dhabi from February 26-29 to finalize a fisheries deal, but other landmark agreements are uncertain due to geopolitical tensions and US election uncertainty.

images.alt_text: World Trade Organization (WTO) Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala attends the Building Bridges conference in Geneva, Switzerland, October 2, 2023. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: How Australian billionaire ‘iron lady’ Gina Rinehart built a thriving mining empire
summary: Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart has retained her position as the country's richest person, with a net worth of US$30.2 billion, according to Forbes' latest list. Rinehart, 70, remains active as chairman of Hancock Prospecting, with no clear successor in sight. She has diversified the company's interests, including lithium exploration, and has expressed concerns over excessive regulation and taxation affecting the resource sector. Rinehart has also expanded her global network, meeting with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and supporting former US President Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: Robert Kuok is the 112th richest person globally is turning 100 years old in October this year, with a net worth of US$11.8 billion
Michael Bambang Hartono, co-owner of Djarum Group.
CP Group senior chairman Dhanin Chearavont set a long term direction three decades ago when he pinpointed retail and telecoms as growth sectors of the future.

site_title: Budget 2024: Quick takes on lower property tax bills with revised annual value bands
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduces revised annual value (AV) bands for owner-occupier residential property tax rates, increasing the lower threshold to S$12,000 and the highest band to over S$140,000. This change aims to keep up with market trends and is expected to result in lower property tax bills for homeowners, with some potential savings ranging from 24% to 360. The adjustments are considered fair and beneficial for most homeowners, particularly those affected by the recent surge in rental prices.

images.alt_text: Homeowners can expect to pay the same or lower property tax bills at each of the band levels, assuming there is no change in their properties’ annual value and before any rebate.

Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.

site_title: Ed Sheeran spoils Singapore concert fans with special guest JJ Lin
summary: Ed Sheeran performed a sold-out concert in Singapore, marking the largest show of his Asian tour with a record 60,000-strong crowd. The 26-song setlist featured a five-piece band and pyrotechnics, including indoor fireworks at the finale of "Bad Habits." The surprise of the evening was an unannounced duet with local singer JJ Lin, where Sheeran sang part of Lin's 2015 hit "Twilight" in Mandarin. The performance was a birthday celebration for Sheeran, who turned 33 during the show.

site_title: Budget 2024: Support for short-term costs while keeping Singapore competitive
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to support short-term costs while maintaining the city-state's competitiveness. The government introduced a 50% corporate income tax rebate and a new Refundable Investment Credit to attract high-quality investments. The budget also includes measures to alleviate households' cost-of-living concerns, such as an extra S$1.9 billion in the Assurance Package, a 50% personal income tax rebate, and property tax changes. Additionally, the government is investing in upskilling for older workers, including a new SkillsFuture Level-Up Programme and adjustments to the Central Provident Fund system.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.
Budget 2024 is the first instalment of Forward Singapore programmes – flagship agenda of the fourth generation People’s Action Party leadership, led by Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

The global minimum tax of 15 per cent under the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) 2.0 is set to take effect. But the new Refundable Investment Credit Scheme seeks to help Singapore remain competitive.
SMEs with higher capital requirements in certain industries, or those looking to expand overseas, are also more likely to benefit from enhancements to the Enterprise Financing Scheme, said observers.
The IIR will subject the overseas profits of multi-national enterprise groups that are parented in Singapore to a minimum effective tax rate of 15 per cent, regardless of where they operate.

site_title: Japan successfully launches new H3 rocket after failure last year
summary: Japan's space agency, JAXA, successfully launched a second test model of its new flagship rocket, the H3, after a failed inaugural flight last year. The rocket, built by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, had a successful liftoff at 9:22 am Tokyo time and was on course with its engines working properly. The H3 is designed to carry a 6.5 metric ton payload into space and reduce launch costs to as low as $44.5 million. The successful launch marks a significant boost to Japan's space program, with plans to launch 20 satellites and probes by 2030.

images.alt_text: SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket lifts off with Intuitive Machines' Nova-C moon lander on top.
An artist illustration of the SLIM (Smart Lander for Investigating Moon) landing phase on the Moon, provided  by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA).

The launch comes on the heels of North Korea placing its first spy satellite into orbit last month, allowing Kim Jong Un’s regime to keep an eye on US troop movements in the region.

site_title: US: Stocks down as inflation data dims hope of early rate cut
summary: US stocks declined on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.4% and the S&P 500 Index down 0.5%, after a bigger-than-expected increase in wholesale prices raised concerns about inflation and interest rate cuts. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.8%. US Treasury yields rose, with the 10-year yield reaching 4.3%, amid expectations of higher interest rates. The Fed's planned path for rate cuts this year remains unchanged, but those calling for a quick rate cut are likely to be disappointed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 9, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid//File Photo

site_title: Singapore 4.0: Paving a decisive way forward
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduces measures to address disruptions and challenges, including adapting to the new global minimum tax regulations and implementing a Refundable Investment Credit (RIC) scheme. The government also bolsters business competitiveness with a 50% corporate tax rebate and enhanced enterprise financing schemes for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs). Additionally, the budget focuses on securing climate resilience, with measures to bolster the green loan scheme and enhance grant support for businesses. The government aims to drive productivity growth and innovation through investments in emerging technologies like generative artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: SMEs with higher capital requirements in certain industries, or those looking to expand overseas, are also more likely to benefit from enhancements to the Enterprise Financing Scheme, said observers.

site_title: New AI-video tool by maker of ChatGPT worries media creators
summary: OpenAI has released a new AI tool called "Sora" that can create short videos from simple text commands, raising concerns among artists and media professionals. The tool can generate complex scenes with multiple characters and accurate details, but has limitations such as mixing up left and right. Industry reactions range from excitement to concern, with studios and video game creators seeing potential benefits, while experts warn of the risk of abuse and the potential to replace human creators. The tool's release has sparked debate about the impact of generative AI on the creative industry.

images.alt_text: In this photo illustration, a video created by Open AI's newly released text-to-video "Sora" tool plays on a monitor in Washington, DC on February 16, 2024. OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT and image generator DALL-E, said it was testing "Sora," which would allow users to create realistic videos with a simple prompt. The Microsoft-backed company said the new platform was currently being tested but released a few videos of what it said was already possible, with the accompanying input made to generate the video. (Photo by Drew Angerer / AFP)
Sora is a work-in-progress, with the company adding that the model may confuse the spatial details of a prompt, and have difficulty in following a specific camera trajectory.

site_title: Budget 2024: CPF changes for senior workers include Special Account closure, higher Enhanced Retirement Sum
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced changes to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) system in the 2024 budget. From 2025, CPF Special Accounts (SAs) for those aged 55 and above will be closed and savings transferred to Retirement Accounts (RAs) up to the Full Retirement Sum (FRS). SA savings that remain will be transferred to the Ordinary Account (OA), earning a lower interest rate. The Enhanced Retirement Sum (ERS) will be raised to four times the Basic Retirement Sum (BRS), allowing more members to fully commit their CPF savings for higher payouts.

images.alt_text: The Ordinary Account interest rate will remain unchanged at 2.5 per cent.
The Majulah Package will cover 1.6 million older Singaporeans and is expected to cost S$8.2 billion in total.
The CPF logo inside the newly renovated CPF Tampines Service Centre on Sept 10, 2022.

site_title: Europe: Markets round off busy week of data, earnings with fresh 2-year highs
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6% to hit a fresh two-year high, driven by miners and expectations of imminent rate cuts by the European Central Bank. The pan-European index of 50 largest companies hovered near its highest level in 23 years. German and French stocks extended gains to record highs, while the UK's FTSE 100 rose 1.5% after stronger-than-expected retail sales. The ECB is expected to start cutting rates in April, with some economists predicting a more gradual easing cycle.

site_title: AI can write but is it any good at picking stocks?
summary: Financial firms are integrating AI into various operations, but harnessing its power to predict stock price movements remains a challenge. Machine learning, a subfield of AI, is being used to analyze vast amounts of data and identify patterns, but results so far show little evidence of a tangible advantage. Predictive AI has shown promise in detecting complex patterns, while generative AI can improve natural language processing. Despite its potential, AI adoption in stock picking has been slow, with only 45% of AI-powered funds outperforming benchmarks, and many hurdles remain, including noisy markets and lack of explainability.

site_title: An action plan for Singapore’s shared future in a new reality
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 emphasizes the need for the nation to adapt to a new reality marked by conflict, climate change, and technological disruptions. The government will focus on three interconnected strategies: attracting high-quality investments, differentiating through cutting-edge innovation, and amplifying its role as a trusted regional leader. Key measures include the Refundable Investment Credit, Enterprise Support Package, and a $5 billion Future Energy Fund to support Singapore's green transition. The budget aims to create a resilient economy that benefits the many, rather than the few, and will require constant calibration of strategies to stay ahead in volatile times.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024 is a timely platform to drive initiatives that can strengthen enterprise digitalisation, sustainability, and internationalisation as levers for growth.
A new initiative named the Future Energy Fund will receive an initial injection of S$5 billion to build critical infrastructure and improve energy security.

site_title: Prince Harry hopeful King's cancer will bring royal family closer
summary: Prince Harry expressed hope that his father King Charles' cancer diagnosis will bring the British royal family closer together. In an interview, Harry stated that any illness or sickness can have a reunifying effect on a family, citing examples from his own life and others. The king's cancer diagnosis has prompted Harry to reconnect with his family, particularly after a period of estrangement.

images.alt_text: Britain's King Charles won plaudits last month for being open about his benign prostate condition, with doctors saying many more members of the public had come forward with symptoms.

site_title: A potential end-of-term Budget with something for everyone
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024, the first installment of the Forward Singapore programmes, aims to balance the fiscal position and provide broad-based support. The budget features a planned surplus of S$800 million, a 50% personal income tax rebate, and increased community development council vouchers. It also includes a mid-career SkillsFuture Credit for all Singaporeans aged 40 and above, as well as a MediSave Bonus for adult Singaporeans aged 21-50. The budget's emphasis on employment and cost-of-living issues has led some observers to conclude that it may be an election Budget, with the government seeking to address voters' concerns ahead of the next general election.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.
This overall fiscal surplus represents about 0.1 per cent of gross domestic product.
Budget 2024

site_title: Budget 2024: Upskilling package reflects urgency to protect mature workers
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 announced measures to boost mid-career workers' prospects, focusing on the more mature age group. The government will provide a S$4,000 SkillsFuture Credit top-up for those aged 40 and above, subsidies for a second full-time diploma, and a training allowance to partially offset income loss during training. Industry experts welcomed the support but emphasized the need for more to improve career prospects, including SME guidance on hiring and developing talents, and the importance of practical experience, networking, and mentorship in career advancement.

images.alt_text: The new S$4,000 credit that is part of the programme will be more targeted in scope, as the government will restrict its usage to selected training programmes that have better employability outcomes.

site_title: US consumer sentiment steady in February
summary: US consumer sentiment remained steady in February at 79.6, unchanged from January, indicating consumers' confidence in the economy. One-year inflation expectations rose to 3.0%, while the five-year inflation outlook remained unchanged at 2.9%. This suggests consumers feel more assured about the economy, following improvements in December and January, according to Surveys of Consumers Director Joanne Hsu.

images.alt_text: NOVI, MICHIGAN - NOVEMBER 24: Shoppers look at clothes while others walk around Twelve Oaks Mall on November 24, 2023 in Novi, Michigan. The National Retail Federation projects that an estimated 182 million are planning to shop in-stores and online through the five-day Thanksgiving weekend.   Emily Elconin/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Emily Elconin / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Budget 2024: More support for older Singaporeans to help meet retirement needs
summary: Singapore's 2024 budget, known as the Majulah Package, aims to support 1.6 million older citizens with retirement needs. The package includes a yearly CPF bonus of up to S$1,000, a one-time bonus of S$1,000 to S$1,500 for those with low means, and increased funding for Age Well SG initiatives. The government will allocate S$8.2 billion, with S$7.5 billion coming from a new fund and S$700 million from investment income. The package will benefit seniors born in 1973 and earlier, with enhanced schemes for low-income seniors and those who own no more than one property.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.
Activities that the RIC scheme will support include the set-up or expansion of manufacturing facilities, new innovation and R&D activities, as well as activities in support of the green transition.
Singapore is raising its local qualifying salary from S$1,400 to S$1,600 for full-time local employees with effect from July 2024.  PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI, ST

site_title: US: Wall St opens subdued after hot producer prices data
summary: Wall Street opened subdued on Friday after a hotter-than-expected producer prices report, which dampened expectations of imminent interest rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones fell 21.41 points, or 0.06%, to 38,751.71, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened higher. The producer prices report raised concerns about inflation and the Fed's future rate decisions, leading to a cautious market tone.

site_title: Budget 2024: SME schemes will drive sustainability but guidance, implementation ‘crucial’
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to drive sustainability among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through expanded schemes. The Energy Efficiency Grant has been expanded to include data centres and their users, while a new advanced tier offers larger support for companies making significant energy efficiency investments. The Enterprise Financing Scheme - Green has also been extended for two years to help SMEs adopt green solutions. However, guidance and implementation of these schemes remain crucial for SMEs to maximize their benefits, with industry watchers noting the need for time, resources, and knowledge to acquire expertise.
