site_title: Budget 2024: ABSD concessions an ‘olive branch’ but won’t offer much relief to developers
summary: Singapore's 2024 budget offers some relief to housing developers with the revised ABSD remission scheme, which applies to projects on residential land acquired on or after July 6, 2018. The scheme lowers the clawback rate for developers who sell at least 90% of their units within the prescribed timeline. Single Singaporeans aged 55 and above can also claim a refund of ABSD when purchasing a lower-value replacement private property. While the move provides some relief, market watchers say the penalties remain "very punitive" and that further reductions are needed to alleviate developer hardship.

images.alt_text: The extension of the ABSD concession is expected to better support seniors who wish to right-size.

site_title: Budget 2024: More than S$11 billion to be injected into R&D, AI, finance, clean energy
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 allocates over S$11 billion for research and development, artificial intelligence, finance, and clean energy. The government will invest S$5 billion in the Future Energy Fund to improve energy security, and S$3 billion in the Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2025 (RIE2025) plan. Additionally, more than S$1 billion will be invested in AI compute infrastructure, talent, and the industry to support the National AI Strategy 2.0. The government will also increase funding for the Financial Sector Development Fund by S$2 billion.

images.alt_text: Generic of people at the Marina Bay Waterfront boardwalk outside The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands. Tags: Tourists; tourism; skyline; population; Singapore; Marina Bay.

site_title: Manulife extends Asia earnings goal by two years
summary: Canada's largest insurer Manulife Financial Corp has extended its goal for Asia unit to account for half of its core earnings by 2027, two years later than initially set, due to the impact of the pandemic and a change in accounting method. The Asia unit generated 37% of the group's overall core earnings in 2023, but has faced challenges including China's slowing economy. The revised target reflects the ongoing resilience of the region despite these challenges.

site_title: Budget 2024: Enterprise Support Package to help SMEs contain costs, though impact will vary
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 offers a S$1.3 billion support package to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) contain costs. The package includes a 50% corporate income tax rebate capped at S$40,000 for profitable businesses, and a S$2,000 cash payout for those with at least one local employee in 2023. The Enterprise Financing Scheme has been enhanced with increased loan quantum, and the SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit has been extended to June 30, 2025. However, the impact of the package may vary across companies, with those with higher capital requirements or expansion plans benefiting more.

images.alt_text: Buildings in the central business district in Singapore, on Wednesday, Feb. 14, 2024. Singapore's economy expanded by a slightly more modest pace than initially expected in 2023, as manufacturing activity contracted and services growth slowed. Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg

site_title: US single-family housing starts fall in January; permits rise
summary: US single-family housing starts dropped 4.7% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.004 million units in January, likely due to harsh weather conditions. However, permits for future construction rose 1.6% to 1.015 million units, suggesting a potential rebound in the coming months. The decline in starts was largely driven by single-family homebuilding in the Midwest, South, and West, while the Northeast saw a rise. A survey showed confidence among single-family builders reached an 18-month high in February, amid expectations of interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: us housing mortgage Photographer: Michaela Vatcheva/Bloomberg
Builder sentiment began rebounding late last year as mortgage rates declined, falling below 7% in December.

site_title: Budget 2024: Quick takes on lower ABSD clawback rate for developments with 90% of units sold
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a lower Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) clawback rate for housing developments that have sold at least 90% of units within their prescribed sale timeline. The current 5% non-remittable clawback rate will be reduced for developers selling 90% of units, giving them more flexibility on sales. Analysts welcome the move as a relief to the property sector, but note that the rate reduction is not significant. The change is expected to benefit luxury developers, which have been hit hardest by ABSD increases.

images.alt_text: The ABSD clawback rate will be lowered for residential developments that have sold at least 90 per cent of units within five years of the land acquisition.
The revised ABSD remission scheme will apply to projects on residential land acquired on or after Jul 6, 2018.

Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.
The extension of the ABSD concession is expected to better support seniors who wish to right-size.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Hang Seng Index to stay unchanged after review
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index will remain unchanged after its quarterly review, with no additions or subtractions to the 82-member list. The index has been expanding its universe to include more new economy stocks since 2021, adding 30 members. Despite hopes for inclusion, the index has struggled, falling 4.2% year-to-date. However, cheap valuation bets from money managers and speculative options traders have fueled optimism about a China rebound.

images.alt_text: A signboard showing the closing numbers on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Jan 11. Japan's Nikkei has been receiving a gush of foreign inflows as investors flee China.
The Hang Seng Index sank 1.27 per cent, or 196.70 points, to 15,336.86 on Monday morning.
Bull statues are placed in font of screens showing the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside Exchange Square, in Hong Kong, China, August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Sri Trang Gloves Q4 net loss widens 10.1% despite higher revenue
summary: Sri Trang Gloves reported a 10.1% widening of its net loss for the fourth quarter to 42.3 million baht (S$1.6 million), despite a 11.5% increase in revenue to 5.3 billion baht. The company attributed higher sales volume to a diversified customer base and strong growth in Asia, Africa, and South America. However, lower average selling prices due to oversupply led to a 12.4% decrease in gross profit. The company also reported a full-year net loss of 152.7 million baht, down 90.8% from the previous year.

images.alt_text: An employee handles latex gloves at an automated production line at a Top Glove Corp. factory in Setia Alam, Selangor, Malaysia, on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2020. The world’s biggest glovemaker got a vote of confidence from investors in the credit market, as the coronavirus fuels demand for the Malaysian company’s rubber products. The World Health Organization is taking an unprecedented step of negotiating directly with suppliers to improve access to gloves, face masks and other forms of protective equipment. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

site_title: Retailers demand more action from EU to resolve Red Sea crisis
summary: Retailers in the EU are urging the European Union to take action to resolve the Red Sea crisis, which has disrupted global supply chains and led to increased costs for businesses. The crisis, caused by Houthi militant attacks, has forced shipping companies to reroute container vessels, resulting in delays and cost increases for firms reliant on the Suez Canal. The disruption has also raised concerns about inflation taking longer to unwind in Europe, affecting consumers. Eurocommerce is calling for intensified and coordinated efforts to address the situation.

images.alt_text: Britain is the world's fifth-largest tea importer and gets more than half of its imported tea from Kenya and India.
Hundreds of ships are simply avoiding the area, sailing thousands of miles around Africa instead
Red Sea attacks raise freight charges, but still manageable for businesses: MTI
Huthi attacks have prompted some shipping companies to detour around southern Africa to avoid the Red Sea, a vital route that normally carries about 12 per cent of global trade

site_title: STI ends 1.4% higher on broad optimism, Budget boost
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.4% to 3,221.94, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street and strong January exports data, validating the Singapore economy's recovery. The market also benefited from Finance Minister Lawrence Wong's Budget 2024 speech, which included support for businesses and households facing rising cost pressures. Asian stocks capped their fourth consecutive weekly gain, with regional and global interest rate environments remaining supportive for risk markets.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong advanced on Friday on gains from the past two sessions, with investors looking to the release of new US inflation data later in the day.

site_title: Zico Holdings expects to post ‘substantial net loss’ for FY2023
summary: Zico Holdings, a professional services provider, expects to report a substantial net loss for its financial year ended Dec 31, 2023. The expected losses are attributed to a provision for loss allowance related to its investment in the Philippines and slower corporate finance and consultancy activities in Singapore and Malaysia due to economic uncertainty and elevated interest rates.

site_title: Budget 2024: Refundable Investment Credit scheme could boost Singapore’s competitiveness
summary: Singapore's Refundable Investment Credit (RIC) scheme, announced in the 2024 budget, aims to boost the country's competitiveness by providing a refundable tax credit for substantial investments in high-value activities. The scheme covers a range of activities, including R&D, digital services, and decarbonisation, and is consistent with the Global Anti-Base Erosion Rules for Qualified Refundable Tax Credits. Tax consultants praise the scheme for its potential to alleviate costs and incentivise multinational enterprises to invest in Singapore, despite some concerns about its impact on competitiveness.

images.alt_text: With volatile times ahead, Singapore will need to stay agile and constantly calibrate its strategies.
A new initiative named the Future Energy Fund will receive an initial injection of S$5 billion to build critical infrastructure and improve energy security.

site_title: Japan mulls extending fuel subsidies amid political backlash: sources
summary: Japan's government and ruling party officials are considering extending fuel subsidies beyond May amid a feeble economy and political pressure. The economy slipped into a recession last year, and the government has spent over 6.2 trillion yen ($54 billion) on the fuel subsidy programme since 2022 to curb domestic fuel prices. This move aims to address rising living costs and boost consumer spending.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during a news conference at the prime minister's office in Tokyo, Japan, 13 December 2023. Prime Minister Kishida said he will replace several ministers implicated in a political fundraising scandal.    FRANCK ROBICHON/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

Fumio Kishida, Japan's prime minister, speaks during a news conference at the prime minister's official residence in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday,  Oct. 4, 2021. Kishida replaced the top ministers responsible for managing the Covid-19 pandemic as he announced a new cabinet on Monday, amid pressure on the government to reopen the economy while avoiding another wave of infections. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during a news conference at the prime minister's office in Tokyo, Japan, 13 December 2023. Prime Minister Kishida said he will replace several ministers implicated in a political fundraising scandal.    FRANCK ROBICHON/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: India central bank extends deadline for Paytm banking unit wind-down
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has extended the deadline for Paytm Payments Bank to wind down its operations from February 29 to March 15. The RBI had initially asked the bank to stop accepting fresh deposits on February 29 due to persistent supervisory concerns and an investigation into overseas transactions by the country's crime fighting agency. The extension allows the bank more time to manage its operations and wind down its services.

images.alt_text: Earlier in February, the Enforcement Directorate had started a probe into Paytm on suspicion of violation of foreign exchange rules.
Macquarie had started coverage of Paytm with "underperform" when the stock was listed in 2021.
The payments firm competes with the likes of Walmart’s PhonePe and Google, and is widely used for everything from buying groceries to household items.

site_title: Budget 2024: Rise in local qualifying salary a ‘natural adjustment’ but smaller companies likely to be hard-hit, say observers
summary: Singapore's government is raising the local qualifying salary (LQS) for full-time local employees from S$1,400 to S$1,600, effective July 2024, and for part-time local employees from S$9 to S$10.50 per hour. The move aims to increase the minimum wage for local workers, with the government co-funding wage increases under the Progressive Wage Credit Scheme up to 50% for the first time. Industry observers warn that smaller companies may struggle to absorb the increase, but see potential benefits for companies in the long run, including increased productivity and investment in automation.

images.alt_text: Changes to the local qualifying salary will be implemented from Jul 1, 2024.
Singapore's FY2023 fiscal deficit widens to S$3.6 billion from earlier estimate of S$0.4 billion, in part due to the S$7.5 billion Majulah Package.
This overall fiscal surplus represents about 0.1 per cent of gross domestic product.

Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.

site_title: India's tech sector growth rate seen halving to 3.8% in FY24
summary: India's technology sector growth rate is expected to slow down to 3.8% in FY24, down from 8.4% in the previous fiscal year. The National Association of Software and Service Companies (Nasscom) forecasts revenue to reach $253.9 billion, driven by lower to mid-single-digit contributions from various segments. This slowdown is attributed to clients holding back spending and delaying decision-making.

images.alt_text: Indian tech companies are also looking to promote their capabilities in artificial intelligence (AI) as demand for such services picks up. “Almost every discussion with clients involves some element of generative AI,” says Infosys CEO Salil Parekh.

site_title: Anchor Fund @ 65 and Growth IPO Fund invest in 9 companies; preparing them for public listing
summary: Singapore's SGX has seen muted IPO activity, with most listings coming from the junior Catalist board, in recent years. However, two funds established in 2022, the Anchor Fund @ 65 and Growth IPO Fund, have invested in 9 companies to prepare them for public listing. The funds, which total S$1.5 billion, work with portfolio companies to advise on listing requirements, drive growth and profitability, and engage with investment banks and market makers. This effort aims to improve SGX's IPO appeal and attract high-growth companies to list on the exchange.

images.alt_text: Since the business combination was completed on Dec 8, 17Live has been in the red every day. The sell-off had already started earlier in December, when it was still trading as VTAC.
market watchers are mixed on whether the local bourse will see new listings of business trusts, a key yield product of the Singapore Exchange (SGX).
Pegasus Asia is reportedly expected to release its announcement by Dec 22, while Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition's will be released next week.
The payment of the redemption amount will be made on or about Feb 13, Pegasus said in a bourse filing.
NTAA is one of three Spacs listed on the Singapore Exchange in January 2022, alongside Pegasus Asia and Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation.

site_title: Budget 2024: Extra S$600 CDC vouchers for every Singaporean household as Assurance Package gets S$1.9 billion boost
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 injects an additional $1.9 billion into the Assurance Package to support households amid high living costs. The package includes $600 in Community Development Council vouchers per household, a one-off cost-of-living special payment of $200-$400, and additional U-Save rebates for HDB flat residents. The government also provides rebates for Service and Conservancy Charges and tops up the GST Voucher fund to permanently defray GST expenses for lower- and middle-income households. These measures aim to soften the impact of rising costs, but social scientists note that they are short-term solutions.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The move will cost the government S$240 million.

Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.
The CDC vouchers will be disbursed in two equal tranches of S$300, with the first in end-June this year, and the second disbursed in January 2025.

site_title: Swiss Re’s full-year profit soars on higher interest rates
summary: Swiss Re's net income rose to US$3.2 billion in 2023, driven by higher underwriting margins and interest rates, exceeding estimates. The company expects a further increase in profit to US$3.6 billion this year. Swiss Re reported a net income of US$1.9 billion for its key property and casualty business, with claims linked to natural catastrophes hitting US$1.3 billion. The company plans to increase its dividend payout and targets a combined ratio of less than 87% for 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of insurance company Swiss Re is seen in front of its headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland February 12, 2019.  REUTERS/Arnd WIegmann/File Photo

site_title: London’s prime homes suffer sharpest price drop in five years
summary: London's luxury homes experienced a 7.1% decline in prices in January compared to the previous year, marking the largest drop in almost five years. The number of homes sold for over £5 million (S$8.5 million) dropped 17% from last year. Higher interest rates and a cost-of-living crisis have affected demand, while increased supply has put downward pressure on prices. The decline is part of a broader UK housing market struggle, with buyers waiting for rate cuts and the outcome of the general election later this year.

images.alt_text: Blackstone has bought Cargo which was previously known as 25 North Colonnade, the former headquarters of the Financial Conduct Authority, for about £165 million in 2014.
The largest warehouse in Europe is owned and developed by Tritax Big Box Reit. Tritax has traditionally focused on large UK warehouses that serve as major logistics hubs.
Easing mortgage costs and improving confidence in the outlook for the economy have boosted the number of buyers looking for property.

The S&P Global/CIPS UK Purchasing Managers’ Index’s headline measure of the construction industry improves to 48.8 in January from 46.8 in December, its highest since August 2023 although still in no-growth territory.
CBRE data shows total investment in the City of London slumped to £3.6 billion in 2023, a shadow of the pre-pandemic £12 billion annually.
House prices in January increased by 0.7 per cent from the month before after being flat in December, beating economists’ forecast in a Reuters poll for a 0.1 per cent rise.

site_title: Budget 2024: Quick takes on SkillsFuture Level-Up programme
summary: Singapore's government has introduced the SkillsFuture Level-Up programme to support mid-career workers aged 40 and above in acquiring new skills and competencies. The programme includes a S$4,000 credit top-up for selected training programmes, a monthly training allowance of up to S$3,000, and support for pursuing another subsidised full-time diploma. The aim is to enhance the country's lifelong learning ecosystem and support workers in adapting to evolving demands and technological advancements.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans aged 40 and above will receive full government subsidies to pursue a second diploma at polytechnics, Institute of Technical Education, and arts institutions.

According to UOB's survey, 84 per cent of businesses said they were somewhat or highly affected by inflation, with its effects being most felt in the industrials, oil and gas as well as manufacturing and engineering sectors.

site_title: Thousands seek to quit Myanmar after military service announcement
summary: Thousands of young people in Myanmar are seeking to leave the country after the military announced it would enforce a law requiring all men aged 18-35 and women aged 18-27 to serve in the military for at least two years. The law, previously unused, has sparked widespread anxiety and fear among those who could be affected, with many choosing to flee to neighboring Thailand. The Thai embassy in Yangon has been overwhelmed with applicants, with over 1,000 people lining up to seek visas, and the embassy has issued 400 numbered tickets per day to manage the queue.

images.alt_text: Since October, the Tatmadaw, as the military is known, has suffered personnel losses while battling a coordinated offensive by an alliance of three ethnic minority insurgent groups, as well as allied pro-democracy fighters who have taken up arms against the junta.

epa10779215 (FILE) - Myanmar State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi (R) waits for the arrival of Chinese President Xi at the presidential house in Naypyitaw, Myanmar, 17 January 2020 (reissued 01 August 2023). According to state media, Myanmar's Chairman of the State Administration Council granted amnesty on 01 August 2023 to ousted civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi for a number of offenses, more than two years after she was detained in the 2021 military coup.  EPA-EFE/NYEIN CHAN NAING

Wednesday’s sanctions are the latest aimed at the fuel the junta uses to conduct aerial bombings in its war with anti-coup forces that have often targeted civilians, as well as the military’s ability to produce arms.

Members of the Mandalay People’s Defense Forces at their base camp in Myanmar’s northern Shan State. Myanmar sent a senior official to take part in a high-level Asean meeting for the first time earlier this week.

site_title: US producer prices rise more than expected in January
summary: US producer prices rose 0.3% in January, exceeding expectations, due to strong gains in services costs. The increase follows a revised 0.1% decline in December and a 0.9% year-over-year gain in the 12 months through January. This data, combined with a stronger-than-expected increase in consumer prices, fuels concerns about inflation picking up. The producer price index's core measure, which excludes food, energy, and trade services, jumped 0.6% in January.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People shop in a supermarket as rising inflation affects consumer prices in Los Angeles, California, U.S., June 13, 2022. REUTERS/Lucy Nicholson
Import prices jumped 0.8 per cent last month, the largest gain since March 2022, after a revised 0.7 per cent decline in December.
Retail sales dropped 0.8 per cent last month, the Commerce Department’s Census Bureau said on Thursday (Feb 15), also likely weighed down by winter storms.
The producer price index for final demand dropped 0.2 per cent in December instead of dipping 0.1 per cent as previously reported.

(FILES) Cranes wait to unload cargo shipping containers from ships at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California on June 7, 2023. An increase in exports helped to reduce the overall US trade deficit in August to the smallest since late 2020, according to government data released on October 5, 2023. The trade gap shrank to $58.3 billion, down nearly 10 percent from July's revised figure of $64.7 billion, said the Commerce Department. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

Shoppers outside of the Ralph Lauren store in the Magnificent Mile shopping district of Chicago, Illinois, US, on Saturday, Dec. 2, 2023. site_title: Budget 2024: Property tax changes welcomed to ease homeowners’ tax burdens
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduces changes to property tax bands, aiming to ease homeowners' tax burdens. The lowest threshold for AV bands is raised to S$12,000, while the highest AV band increases to over S$140,000. Homeowners can expect the same or lower property tax bills at each band level. The changes will help alleviate the impact of a two-step hike in property tax rates and a surge in residential property AVs, which rose 41% in 2022 and 2023.

images.alt_text: Homeowners can expect to pay the same or lower property tax bills at each of the band levels.

Budget 2024 tackled immediate cost-of-living worries for households and businesses, while also laying out plans to strengthen Singapore’s economic competitiveness, support young families, and help workers to stay relevant.

site_title: Budget 2024: Single Singaporean seniors to get ABSD refund when ‘right-sizing’ to lower-value property
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduces a new concession allowing single Singaporeans aged 55 and above to claim a refund of Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) when purchasing a lower-value private property to replace their existing residential property. This move aims to support seniors who wish to 'right-size'. The concession will take effect from Feb 16 and requires the individual to sell their first property within six months after purchasing the replacement property.

images.alt_text: At the Redas Spring Festival Celebration, Redas president Tan Swee Yiow notes: “With this demographic shift comes an increased demand for senior-living accommodation with comprehensive support amenities.”
It is time to cut 15-month waiting period for ‘downgraders’, tweak ABSD, bring back estate tax, says PropertyGuru.
Non-owner-occupied residential properties account for around two-thirs of the tax revenue increase, said Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat on Tuesday.
Replacing the revenue generated through property taxes with higher corporate and individual tax rates could have a negative impact on Singapore’s attractiveness.

site_title: NatWest sees revenue dropping with rate cuts on horizon
summary: NatWest's pre-tax profit for the fourth quarter dropped 12% to £1.26 billion, a 12% decline from the same period last year. The bank expects total income to fall to £13-£13.5 billion this year, largely due to falling interest rates and increased competition for deposit customers. The Bank of England is forecast to cut benchmark interest rates five times starting in May, further reducing interest income. Despite the decline, shares surged 3.9% as the bank has no exposure to a potential £10 billion Financial Conduct Authority review.

images.alt_text: HSBC, Barclays, Lloyds Banking Group, NatWest Group and Santander UK are expected to take part in the meeting with finance minister Jeremy Hunt.

site_title: Mercedes E 200 review: From star to finish
summary: The Mercedes E 200 has been reviewed, highlighting its impressive turbo engine with a mild hybrid setup, providing a nice kick of acceleration. The car features a 12.3-inch display for driving info and a 14.4-inch touchscreen for main infotainment duties. The E 200 is available in three versions - Avantgarde, Exclusive, and AMG Line - with prices ranging from S$35,000. The car is designed to be elegant, plush, and solid, making it a desirable executive vehicle for those who want to make a statement with their purchase.

images.alt_text: The Toyota Vellfire is a big, uniquely Japanese take on overland luxury travel.

site_title: Budget 2024: Upcoming corporate tax changes under Pillar 2 of BEPS 2.0 provide ‘welcome certainty’ to affected firms
summary: Singapore's corporate income tax regime will implement two components from the second pillar of the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) 2.0 framework starting January 1, 2025. The Income Inclusion Rule will subject overseas profits of multinational enterprise groups parented in Singapore to a minimum effective tax rate of 15%, while the Domestic Top-up Tax will require MNE groups to pay a minimum effective tax rate of 15% on their Singapore profits. These changes aim to provide 'welcome certainty' for affected firms and will apply to MNE groups with annual group revenues of at least $1.1 billion.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024 is a timely platform to drive initiatives that can strengthen enterprise digitalisation, sustainability, and internationalisation as levers for growth.

site_title: Web cartoons platform Naver eyes US$4 billion value in US summer IPO
summary: Naver Corp is planning a US initial public offering (IPO) for its online comics operator, Webtoon Entertainment, with a potential valuation of $3 billion to $4 billion. The company, which owns Naver Webtoon and Wattpad, aims to raise up to $500 million. The IPO, which could occur as early as June, will help the business expand abroad and drive its ambitions in the US market. However, analysts note that the business's growth outlook is slowing, and rising competition from Apple and Amazon may impact the IPO's success.

images.alt_text: Kakao fought an intense battle for SM with Hybe, the label behind boyband sensation BTS, electrifying South Korea as two of the best-known K-pop labels slugged it out over for control of their destinies.
Hybe is doubling efforts to sign up new artists to the Weverse app, seeking to draw fans from around the globe and pursue profitability.

site_title: Taiwan to bring in Indian migrant workers to ease job crunch
summary: Taiwan and India signed a memorandum of understanding to bring in Indian migrant workers to address labor shortages in various industries. The move comes as Taiwan's demand for workers continues to expand, and the country is unable to fulfill itself. A small-scale pilot scheme will be implemented, with the possibility of more Indian workers being allowed in if successful. The agreement aims to expand Taiwan's foreign workforce beyond its traditional source countries in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. logo atop a building at the Hsinchu Science Park in Hsinchu, Taiwan, on Tuesday, Jan. 9, 2023. TSMC is scheduled to release earnings results on Jan. 18. Photographer: Mike Kai Chen/Bloomberg

site_title: Budget 2024: Quick takes on Enterprise Support Package
summary: The Singapore government introduced a S$1.3 billion Enterprise Support Package to help businesses manage rising costs, including wage bills, rental, and utilities costs. The package includes a 50% corporate income tax rebate of up to S$40,000 for 2024, a minimum cash payout of S$2,000 for non-profitable companies with at least one local employee, and enhanced financing schemes and extended SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit. The measures aim to support businesses that make efforts to restructure and transform, with a focus on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Feb 14, 2024.

site_title: Budget 2024: Tweak in ABSD on land to give developers more leeway on sales
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a tweak to the Additional Buyers' Stamp Duty (ABSD) regime, granting developers more leeway on sales. The revised rule lowers the ABSD clawback rate for residential developments that have sold at least 90% of units within five years of land acquisition. This change aims to ensure a prompt release of housing supply while providing flexibility to developers. The revised rate applies to sites acquired between July 6, 2018, and December 15, 2021.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect stamp duty collection and property tax takings to increase for Singapore's full financial year ended March 2024.

site_title: Budget 2024: S$100 million for the arts; S$20 million to spur donations for Team Singapore athletes
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 allocates S$100 million over four years to support the arts sector through the refreshed Our SG Arts Plan. The National Arts Council will develop and showcase diverse arts offerings, strengthen the talent pool, and provide more development opportunities for self-employed artists. Additionally, S$20 million will be allocated to encourage donations for Team Singapore athletes. The government aims to make the arts more accessible to all Singaporeans, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stating the government's full confidence and support for the arts sector.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024 is a timely platform to drive initiatives that can strengthen enterprise digitalisation, sustainability, and internationalisation as levers for growth.

site_title: Eurozone’s low productivity may slow inflation’s fall: ECB
summary: Eurozone's sluggish productivity growth may slow inflation's fall to the European Central Bank's 2% target, according to ECB policymaker Isabel Schnabel. Lower investment in technology, more red tape, and expensive energy are cited as factors behind the eurozone's underperformance compared to the US. This could delay the ECB's victory against high inflation and interest rate cuts, with Schnabel urging caution to avoid a second inflation flare-up. Higher productivity growth is seen as crucial for securing price stability and supporting monetary policy.

images.alt_text: “Lower energy commodity prices and weaker economic momentum set inflation on a steeper downward path than anticipated in the Autumn Forecast,” European Commission says.
A customer shops in a supermarket in Nice, France, August 18, 2022. REUTERS/Eric Gaillard/File photo
Inflation remains above the European Central Bank’s 2 per cent target, but well below the peak of 10.6 per cent recorded in October 2022 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent energy prices soaring.
A key ECB survey now sees inflation at 2.4 per cent this year, down from 2.7 per cent seen three months ago and well below the 2.7 per cent projected by ECB staff.
In the European Union as a whole, consumer sentiment falls by 0.2 points to -16.2.
The latest round of Consumer Expectations Survey shows the median household expected prices to grow by 3.2 per cent in the following 12 months, down from 4 per cent a month earlier.

site_title: Budget 2024: S$200 in LifeSG credits for 1.2 million NSmen
summary: Singapore's government will provide S$200 in LifeSG credits to 1.2 million past and present national servicemen, including those enlisting in 2024, as part of efforts to express appreciation and gratitude. The move, costing S$240 million, follows the S$100 digital credits given in 2022. The credits can be spent at over 100,000 merchants and are valid for one year from the date of issue.

site_title: Thailand plans 1.19 trillion baht public-private investment projects during 2020-2027
summary: Thailand plans to invest 1.19 trillion baht (S$44.5 billion) in public-private partnership projects from 2020 to 2027, aiming to boost long-term economic growth. The revised amount is slightly higher than the previously approved 1.17 trillion baht. The government also approved an investment of 18.4 billion baht for Laem Chabang port in Chonburi province. This move aims to attract more private companies to invest in government projects, following a forecast of 2.8% growth this year. The government is also expediting high-value infrastructure projects to catch up with regional peers.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, February 16, 2024 (Ep 3)
summary: Singapore stocks rallied on Friday, driven by the release of Budget 2024, which promised more incentives for businesses in financial services, artificial intelligence, and sustainability. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.5% to close at a two-year high. The rally also followed a surge in Asian markets after a strong performance on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 81 to 25.
Hong Kong advanced on Friday on gains from the past two sessions, with investors looking to the release of new US inflation data later in the day.

site_title: Australia's push to put more solar panels on rental homes
summary: Australia aims to increase the share of clean energy to 82% by 2030, but most rental homes lack solar power, with only 4% of rental homes having solar. Despite having the highest solar capacity per capita in the world, renters face limited incentives to install solar systems themselves, and landlords have limited incentive to install solar due to the lack of relationship with energy retailers. Efforts are underway to encourage landlords to install solar, including grants, rebates, and low-interest loans, with technologies like SolShare making solar more accessible to renters and low-income households.

images.alt_text: The problem is exacerbated in Sydney where there’s strong opposition to high apartment blocks among local residents.

site_title: Budget 2024: Firms hiring foreigners must pay locals minimum S$1,600 wage, up from S$1,400
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduces a minimum wage of S$1,600 for local employees working at companies that hire foreign workers, up from S$1,400. This change, effective from July 1, 2024, aims to keep pace with wage growth and adjust the local qualifying salary computation for foreign worker quotas. The new minimum hourly rate for part-time workers is S$10.50 per hour, up from S$9 per hour. The changes aim to support local workers and ensure fair compensation.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong will deliver the 2024 Budget Statement in Parliament at 3.30 pm on Feb 16.
One suggested move was to reintroduce estate duties or inheritance taxes, with rates varying by property value and type.

site_title: Budget 2024: Couples waiting for BTO flats will get one-year voucher to rent HDB flat in open market
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduces a one-year voucher for eligible young families waiting for Build-To-Order (BTO) flats, allowing them to rent an HDB flat in the open market. The voucher aims to support families with urgent housing needs, particularly those with young children. The voucher's dollar amount was not announced, but it will provide temporary housing solutions while BTO flats are being completed. This move aims to alleviate pressure on the Parenthood Provisional Housing Scheme (PPHS) and support young families in the interim.

site_title: Hong Kong arrests seven in US$1.8 billion money laundering case
summary: Hong Kong authorities arrested seven individuals suspected of being involved in a US$1.8 billion money laundering case, the largest in the financial hub. The seven suspects, aged 23 to 74, are believed to be the mastermind and accomplices. Authorities seized HK$165 million (S$28.3 million) worth of assets and contacted regional law enforcement authorities, including India. The scheme allegedly involved online scams and the sale of electronics and rare gems. Investigations continue, and the suspects were released on bail.

site_title: Budget 2024: Higher CPF contribution rates for workers 55 to 65; closure of Special Account for those aged 55 and above
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced key changes to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) in the 2024 budget. Contribution rates for workers aged 55 to 65 will increase by 1.5 percentage points in 2025, while the Special Account for those aged 55 and above will be closed and savings transferred to the Retirement Account. The Silver Support Scheme will be enhanced, and the Matched Retirement Savings Scheme will be extended to those above 70. Quarterly payments under the Silver Support Scheme will also increase by 20%.

images.alt_text: Budget 2024 is a timely platform to drive initiatives that can strengthen enterprise digitalisation, sustainability, and internationalisation as levers for growth.

site_title: Cosco Shipping says it expects to post net profit for FY2023
summary: Cosco Shipping International expects to post a net profit of approximately S$1.9 million for its financial year ended Dec 31, 2023, reversing the net loss booked in FY2022 due to a non-cash impairment of goodwill. The company's FY2023 net profit was negatively affected by non-renewed subleases, higher financing costs, and lower contributions from associated companies. Despite this, Cosco's shares gained S$0.004 or 2.8% to close at S$0.146 on Friday. The company's final results will be released no later than Feb 29.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Containers of Chinese companies China Shipping and COSCO (China Ocean Shipping Company) are loaded on a container as it is leaving the port in Hamburg, Germany March 11, 2020. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo

site_title: Morgan Stanley seeks up to US$1 billion in GE HealthCare shares
summary: Morgan Stanley is seeking up to $1.1 billion in GE HealthCare shares as part of a debt-for-equity swap. The lender is marketing 13 million shares at $81.50 to $83.00 per share, with multiple orders exceeding available shares. This deal is part of GE's debt-for-equity exchange program, following the spin-off of GE HealthCare in January 2023.

site_title: Nikkei soars to within sight of all-time peak, closes at 34-year high
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei index soared to a 34-year high, closing at 38,487.24, after surpassing its post-economic bubble era record of 38,188.74. The index is on track to eclipse its all-time peak of 38,957.44, reached in December 1989. The Nikkei is up 14.0% for the year, marking a significant milestone for the Japanese economy.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure on the trading floor at the Nomura Securities Co. headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Jan. 11, 2024. The Nikkei 225 rose 1.8% to the highest level in about 34 years on Thursday. Photographer: Nao Sano/Bloomberg

site_title:
Blame baby boomers for US 
housing market inventory shortage
summary: A lack of available properties in the US housing market can be attributed to baby boomers choosing to age in place, rather than downsizing and selling their homes. Nearly 40% of baby boomers have lived in their current homes for 20 years or more, and 16% for 10-19 years. This has led to an inventory shortage, making it difficult for first-time buyers and young families to enter the market. As mortgage costs rise, many homeowners are reluctant to sell, exacerbating the issue, and contributing to higher home prices.

images.alt_text: A for sale sign stands outside of a home in Princeton, Illinois, U.S., on Wednesday, May 30, 2012. The number of Americans signing contracts to buy previously-owned homes fell in April by the most in a year, indicating the U.S. housing recovery remains uneven. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg

site_title: Budget 2024: Grant for charity collaboration extended, new tax deduction for overseas humanitarian aid introduced
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduces a new tax deduction scheme, Overseas Humanitarian Assistance Tax Deduction Scheme (OHAS), to encourage donations towards humanitarian causes abroad. The scheme allows for a 100% tax deduction on cash donations made through designated charities for emergency humanitarian aid. Additionally, the Charities Capability Fund Collaboration Grant will be extended for three years to support collaborative projects among charities. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of a "stronger culture of giving" to bind the society closer together.

images.alt_text: CPF contribution rates for those aged 55 to 65 will be raised by a further 1.5 percentage points in 2025.

The Majulah Package is expected to have a total lifetime cost of S$8.2 billion. To cover this, S$7.5 billion will be set aside in the new Majulah Package Fund, said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong in his Budget speech on Friday (Feb 16).

site_title: Budget 2024: S$8.2 billion Majulah Package to benefit 1.6 million Singaporeans
summary: Singapore's Majulah Package, a S$8.2 billion package, aims to benefit 1.6 million Singaporeans, including seniors and low-income individuals. The package includes means-tested bonuses, a Medisave Bonus, and a one-time MediSave Bonus for all seniors born in 1973 or earlier. Eligible individuals will receive up to S$1,000 in annual bonuses, with the first bonus credited in March 2025. The package is expected to have a total lifetime cost of S$8.2 billion, with S$7.5 billion set aside in a new fund.

The Majulah Package will cost the government a total of S$7 billion and will benefit 1.4 million older Singaporeans.

site_title: Budget 2024: Annual income threshold for dependant-related reliefs to be raised to S$8,000 from YA2025
summary: The Singapore government has announced that the annual income threshold for dependant-related reliefs will be raised to S$8,000, starting from the Year of Assessment 2025. This change aims to address rising costs of living and wage levels. Currently, taxpayers can claim reliefs for dependants with an annual income of S$4,000 or less. The decision follows feedback from the public, tax practitioners, and labour Members of Parliament.

site_title: Budget 2024 highlights: From S$1.9 billion in household support, to property tax changes
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024, delivered by Finance Minister Lawrence Wong, aims to tackle cost-of-living concerns and strengthen the country's economic competitiveness. Key announcements include a S$1.9 billion household support package, a S$1.3 billion Enterprise Support Package for businesses, and a Refundable Investment Credit to attract high-quality investments. The budget also introduces a new SkillsFuture Level-Up Programme for mid-career workers and raises the Local Qualifying Salary to S$1,600. Additionally, it provides housing support for young families and tweaks the Central Provident Fund (CPF) system.

site_title: HSBC to improve ties with Hong Kong unit Hang Seng to mitigate risk
summary: HSBC is planning to strengthen ties with its Hong Kong unit, Hang Seng Bank, to mitigate potential risks amid economic turmoil in China. The move comes as HSBC pivots towards Asia and faces concerns about financial sector health in the world's second-largest economy. Hang Seng's bad loans ratio has increased due to exposure to the mainland property sector, prompting HSBC to share expertise and best practices with its Hong Kong unit. The plan aims to enhance risk management and promote a strong risk culture.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Bostic eyes two cuts amid expected uneven progress on inflation
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic projected two interest rate cuts in 2024 due to uneven progress on inflation, fewer than his colleagues' forecasts of three cuts. Bostic attributes his more conservative outlook to less steady inflation reduction.

site_title: Conservatives suffer setback in parliamentary elections in Britain
summary: The UK Conservative Party suffered crushing defeats in two parliamentary elections, losing seats in Kingswood and Wellingborough, with Labour Party candidate Gen Kitchen winning both by significant margins. The defeats come as the British economy shrinks, interest rates are high, and the health service faces crisis. The results compound Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's difficulties, with opinion polls showing the party trailing Labour by double-digit margins. Analysts predict further pressure on Sunak, potentially leading to calls for his resignation, and a possible general election later this year.

site_title: China builder Logan gets respite as liquidation petitions fail
summary: A Hong Kong court dismissed petitions to liquidate two key units of Chinese developer Logan Group, giving the company breathing room to push through its debt restructuring plan. The decision comes after a group of bondholders initially filed the petitions but later withdrew, satisfied with Logan's restructuring proposals. The move offers Logan fresh time to sign support agreements with all creditor groups for its $8 billion offshore debt overhaul plan by the end of April.

site_title: Budget 2024: Higher payouts, income cap under enhanced Workfare Income Supplement scheme
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduced enhancements to the Workfare Income Supplement scheme, set to benefit around half a million workers starting Jan 1, 2025. The maximum annual payout will increase to S$4,900, with individual payouts based on age and wage. The income cap to qualify for the scheme will also rise to S$3,000, ensuring lower-wage workers continue to receive benefits. The enhancements apply to both Workfare Income Supplement and Workfare Skills Support schemes, benefiting lower-wage workers and senior workers.

site_title: Budget 2024: First planned surplus in 7 years in FY2024, albeit ‘small’, at S$778 million
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 is expected to achieve a small surplus of S$778 million, marking the first planned surplus in 7 years. The budget reflects an expansionary stance, with higher operating revenue and total expenditure, driven by increased spending in transport, healthcare, and education. The overall fiscal position is considered balanced, with contributions from invested reserves. Economists see this as an opportunity for a potential election, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stating the government is prepared to call an election if necessary.

site_title: Budget 2024: Individuals to get 50% personal income tax rebate for 2024
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a 50% personal income tax rebate for all tax resident individuals in the country for the year of assessment 2024, capped at S$200. The rebate aims to support middle-income workers amid rising living costs, expected to cost the government S$350 million.

site_title: Budget 2024: Lower property tax bills for homeowners, with revised annual value bands
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 introduces lower property tax bills for homeowners. The annual value (AV) bands for owner-occupied residential property tax rates will be revised from January 2025, resulting in homeowners paying the same or lower property tax bills, assuming no change in properties' AVs. The lower threshold will be raised to S$12,000, and the higher threshold will be raised to over S$140,000, with corresponding adjustments to bands in between. The move aims to uphold the intent of the property tax changes while providing relief to those residing in high-value properties.

site_title: Budget 2024: Cheaper pre-school, special needs school fees in enhanced social support efforts
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to boost social support with measures to make pre-schools more affordable, enhance subsidies for lower-income families, and support families of persons with special needs. The government will cut full-day monthly childcare fee caps and introduce ComLink+ progress packages for eligible lower-income families. Additionally, families of persons with special needs will receive reduced maximum monthly fees at special education schools and special student care centres. The packages will be rolled out progressively from the second half of 2024 and will focus on supporting social mobility and employment.

images.alt_text: The enhancements to the Workfare Income Supplement scheme will apply to work done from Jan 1, 2025, and are expected to benefit around half a million Singaporeans.

site_title: Budget 2024: 1.4 million Singaporeans to get one-time S$300 MediSave Bonus
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 includes a one-time S$300 MediSave Bonus for adult citizens aged 21-50 to help build medical savings. About 1.4 million Singaporeans will benefit, estimated to cost the government S$300 million. The government also sets aside S$3.5 billion over the next decade for the Age Well SG initiative, supporting seniors with preventive care and healthcare costs. Per capita household income thresholds for healthcare subsidies will be raised, benefiting around 3 million Singaporeans.

site_title: Budget 2024: New fund for future energy investments, with initial S$5 billion injection
summary: Singapore has set up a Future Energy Fund with an initial S$5 billion injection to support investments in new energy initiatives and transition the country's energy system from natural gas to clean energy. The fund aims to help the country move towards a cleaner energy mix over the next two decades, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stating that significant effort and costs are required for this transition. The fund will help Singapore achieve its goal of reducing its reliance on natural gas and increasing its use of clean energy sources.

site_title: After breakout 2023 season, world’s No 1 golfer Lilia Vu hungry for more trophies
summary: Lilia Vu, the world's No. 1 female golfer, is set to compete in the HSBC Women's World Championship at Sentosa Golf Club in Singapore, where she finished joint-14th last year. Vu, 26, had a breakout 2023 season, winning two Majors and being named LPGA Tour Player of the Year. Despite heavy expectations, Vu says she doesn't feel pressured to perform, crediting her positive mindset and ability to focus on her own game. The tournament, featuring 19 Major champions and 18 Solheim Cup players, is expected to be a challenging test of Vu's skills.

site_title: Budget 2024: Singapore to enable broadband speeds 10 times faster than current standards
summary: Singapore aims to enable mass market access to broadband speeds of up to 10 gigabits per second by the second half of the decade, 10 times faster than current standards. The government will allocate additional resources to upgrade its national broadband network to support emerging technologies like artificial intelligence and immersive media. This move is part of the country's efforts to stay competitive in the digital age.

site_title: Indonesia’s KAI gets US$450 million loan from China to cover bullet train cost
summary: Indonesia's state railway company KAI secured nearly $450 million in loans from China's Development Bank to cover the increasing cost of its first high-speed railway. The project, launched in October, was initially expected to cost $1.2 billion but is now over budget due to elevated land procurement costs and pandemic-related delays. The loans are in addition to the $4.55 billion approved in 2017 and will be used to fund the construction of the 142-kilometer railway line connecting Jakarta to Bandung city.

site_title: Budget 2024: ITE graduates to get up to S$15,000 if they enrol for, and subsequently attain a diploma
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a new two-part ITE Progression Award to help ITE graduates offset the costs of obtaining a polytechnic diploma. ITE graduates aged 30 and below will receive up to S$15,000, including a S$5,000 top-up to their Post-Secondary Education Account (PSEA) for enrolling in a diploma program, and a further S$10,000 injection to their CPF Ordinary Account upon diploma attainment. This aims to support upskilling efforts and provide a head start in buying a home or saving for retirement.

site_title: Budget 2024: S$2 billion top-up for financial sector development, S$3 billion more into R&D
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 allocates an additional S$2 billion to develop the financial sector and S$3 billion for research and development. The government also invests S$1 billion over five years to enhance artificial intelligence capabilities, aiming to reinforce the country's global competitive lead. The Financial Sector Development Fund will receive an additional S$2 billion, while the Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2025 plan will receive an additional S$3 billion. These investments will support national priorities in advanced manufacturing, sustainability, and healthcare.

site_title: UK retail sales jump, signalling quick end to recession
summary: UK retail sales surged 3.4% in January, the largest jump in almost three years, suggesting a quick recovery from recession. Despite overall sales still being 1.3% below pre-pandemic levels, the increase points to a fading effect of high interest rates on consumer spending. The economy is expected to grow slightly in 2024 as inflation cools and interest rates are forecast to fall, with potential tax cuts in March potentially boosting the economy further.

site_title: Budget 2024: S$4,000 SkillsFuture top-up, monthly training allowance for Singaporeans aged 40 and above
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 includes a S$4,000 SkillsFuture Credit top-up for individuals aged 40 and above, on top of the existing S$500 credit, for targeted training programs with better employability outcomes. The government will also provide full subsidies for a second diploma at polytechnics, the Institute of Technical Education, and arts institutions for those aged 40 and above, starting from the 2025 academic year. Additionally, a monthly training allowance of up to S$3,000 will be provided for full-time courses, with a cap of 24 months.

site_title: Budget 2024: New Refundable Investment Credit for high-value economic activities; S$2 billion top-up to National Productivity Fund
summary: Singapore will introduce a new Refundable Investment Credit (RIC) to stay competitive and attract high-value investments, with a top-up of S$2 billion to the National Productivity Fund. The RIC will support substantive economic activities, such as manufacturing, digital services, and green transition, with a refundable cash feature. Companies will be eligible for credits based on qualifying expenditures incurred over 10 years, to be offset against corporate income tax.

site_title: Budget 2024: S$1.9 billion more for Assurance Package, extra S$600 CDC vouchers for all Singaporean households
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced an additional S$1.9 billion for the Assurance Package to help residents cope with cost-of-living concerns and economic uncertainties. This includes extra S$600 CDC vouchers for all Singaporean households, split into two tranches, and one-off cost-of-living special payments of S$200 to S$400 for eligible residents. Additionally, eligible HDB households will receive 2.5 times the regular U-Save rebates and up to four months of Service and Conservancy Charges rebates.

site_title: Budget 2024: S$1.3 billion support package to help businesses manage costs
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong introduced a $1.3 billion support package, called the Enterprise Support Package, to help businesses manage costs. The package includes a 50% corporate income tax rebate capped at $40,000 for the year 2024, enhancements to the Enterprise Financing Scheme, and an extension of the SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit.

site_title: Nike to cut 2% of workforce as sportswear giant seeks savings
summary: Nike plans to cut 2% of its global workforce, approximately 1,670 employees, as part of its efforts to reduce costs and counter a weaker sales outlook. The job cuts follow a December announcement aiming for US$2 billion in cost savings. The company cited growing consumer caution weighing on sales and increased competition. The cuts will occur in two phases, with the first phase starting Friday and the second phase completed by the end of the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: The company’s wholesale business has been under persistent pressure as retailers keep a tight lid on product stocks and cut back on orders.

site_title: Philippines picks San Miguel-led group to upgrade main airport
summary: The Philippines has selected a San Miguel-led consortium as its preferred bidder to upgrade and operate the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) in Manila. The 15-year concession agreement, valued at $3 billion, aims to nearly double the airport's capacity to 60 million passengers annually and increase air traffic movements to 48 hours. San Miguel's group will receive 82% of airport revenues, beating rival bids from GMR Airports Consortium and Manila International Airport Consortium. The upgrade is part of the government's efforts to modernize its infrastructure and privatize operations.

site_title: Budget 2024: SME schemes extended, enhanced to encourage MNE partnerships, sustainability
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to encourage partnerships between small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and multinational enterprises (MNEs) to boost local companies' capabilities and sustainability. Existing schemes for SMEs will be enhanced to support partnerships, adoption of green solutions, and emission reduction. The government will also extend support for green loans and expand the Energy Efficiency Grant (EEG) to more sectors, providing two tiers of support for companies to reduce their emissions. The goal is to help local companies raise their capabilities and win new opportunities, making them industry leaders in their own right.

site_title: Budget 2024: FY2023 revised fiscal deficit widens to S$3.6 billion; FY2022 posts surplus
summary: Singapore's FY2023 fiscal deficit widened to S$3.6 billion, from an earlier estimate of S$0.4 billion, due to the S$7.5 billion Majulah Package. The primary deficit narrowed as higher-than-expected operating revenue offset higher spending. FY2022's final tally swung from an expected deficit to a surplus of S$1.7 billion. The revised budget balance took into account S$3.5 billion in capitalization and reduced interest costs, resulting in a widened overall fiscal deficit.

site_title: New Zealand population jumps the most since end of World War Two
summary: New Zealand's population surged by 2.8% in 2023, the largest calendar-year jump since World War Two, driven by record immigration. The population rose to 5,305,600 people, with 145,100 net immigrants in 2023. Despite a natural increase of just 19,200, the population growth was largely influenced by labour shortages post-pandemic. The Reserve Bank expressed concerns about the impact on inflation, but may not signal interest-rate cuts anytime soon.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Friday after key exports data; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Friday, Feb 16, driven by a 16.8% year-on-year increase in key exports in January, largely due to a surge in non-monetary gold shipments. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 16.56 points to 3,193.25. Other gainers included Genting Singapore, ESR-Logos Reit, and Big Three banks. This follows a positive trend on Wall Street, where stocks rose after weak retail sales data was offset by investor bullishness.

site_title: China steps up ‘whitelist’ mechanism for property sector: media
summary: China's government has accelerated its "whitelist" mechanism to inject liquidity into the crisis-hit property sector, approving over 8,200 residential projects for development loans from five state-owned banks. The move aims to free up funding for the debt-riddled industry, which accounts for a quarter of China's GDP. While the mechanism is seen as a positive step, banks' reluctance to lend to the sector could hinder the progress, and loans can only be used for project completion, not debt repayment.

site_title: EU privacy watchdogs urged to oppose Meta’s paid ad-free service
summary: EU privacy watchdogs are urging the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) to oppose Meta's paid ad-free service, citing concerns that it undermines the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and may be copied by other companies. The service, launched in Europe last November, requires users to pay a fee to ensure their privacy. A group of 28 organizations, including NOYB and the Irish Council for Civil Liberties, warned that the model could lead to widespread surveillance capitalism and undermine data protection standards.

site_title: Budget 2024: Higher co-funding level, income ceiling for Progressive Wage Credit Scheme
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to support employers in raising the salaries of lower-income workers. The Progressive Wage Credit Scheme (PWCS) will have a higher co-funding level of 50% and a wage ceiling of S$3,000 in 2025. The government will also increase the qualifying income cap for the Workfare Income Supplement Scheme. The enhancements will be funded by a S$1 billion top-up to the PWCS fund.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after Wall Street highs
summary: Asia markets rose on Friday, driven by Wall Street gains and eurozone records, despite weak US retail sales and recession in Britain and Japan. Asian shares are on track for their fourth consecutive weekly gain, supported by a "regional and global interest rate environment" that favors risk markets. Despite recession woes, investors are optimistic about US growth momentum, with the S&P 500 reaching an all-time high.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 81 to 25.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average has finished up 0.9 per cent at 38,773.12.

site_title: Budget 2024: Forward Singapore a ‘crucial road map’ to chart the way through less stable external environment
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to guide the country through a "less stable and favourable" external environment, Finance Minister Lawrence Wong said. The budget forecasts a mixed outlook for 2024, with geopolitical risks and global inflationary pressures expected to recede, but uncertainties tilted to the downside. Wong emphasized the importance of the Forward Singapore exercise, a social compact to refresh the Republic's way forward, and outlined plans to implement major initiatives to strengthen social cohesion and solidarity.

site_title: Australian winemakers bet on expected China reopening with big shipments to Hong Kong
summary: Australian winemakers have shipped millions of bottles of wine to Hong Kong in anticipation of China lifting tariffs on Australian wine, expected to occur in early 2024. The shipments are worth around US$65.5 million, up from recent years, as Chinese drinkers increasingly prefer more expensive bottles, preserving margins for winemakers. The move is part of a larger effort to revive a trade worth hundreds of millions of US dollars, with Australian officials and industry optimistic that China will lift tariffs and allow Australian wine to re-enter the Chinese market.

site_title: Bitcoin breaks US$50,000 for first time since 2021
summary: Bitcoin surged above US$50,000 for the first time in over two years, driven by optimism over US approval of broader trading in the cryptocurrency. The asset has rallied about 25% since January 22, fueled by expectations of the creation of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that allow public investment in crypto. The rally marks a recovery following scandals and collapses in the crypto industry, and is seen as a sign of growing momentum for the currency, with analysts predicting further gains if weekly price movements exceed 10%.

site_title: Malaysia Q4 GDP growth up 3% on year, slower than economists forecast as exports weaken
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded at a 3% year-on-year pace in Q4, slower than economists' forecast due to weak exports. Exports declined 6.9% and imports increased 1.3%, leading to a 3.2% decline in trade to RM695.6 billion. Despite this, household spending remained the key driver of the economy, supported by an improved labor market and easing cost pressures. The central bank governor expects the economy to perform better this year, driven by domestic expenditure and tourism, but warns of downside risks from weaker-than-expected external demand.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in construction and stagnant manufacturing activity is weighing on the Malaysian economy.
Malaysia's central reiterated that at the interest rate of 3%,  the monetary policy stance remains supportive of the economy.

site_title: Rod Stewart banks US$100 million for song catalog: report
summary: Rod Stewart sold his recorded music and publishing catalog, as well as some rights to his name, to Irving Azoff's Iconic Artists Group for nearly US$100 million. This deal comes as music rights have become a hot market, with Sony recently acquiring half of Michael Jackson's recording and publishing catalog rights for at least $600 million. The sale is a sign of demand for music catalogs as an asset class, with investors seeing long-term value in streaming. Azoff's Iconic has raised over $1 billion in new capital for catalog acquisitions.

site_title: Thailand plans to waive visas for more countries
summary: Thailand plans to waive visas for citizens of several more countries, including those from Europe and Latin America, to boost tourism. The move follows the success of visa-free travel for China and India, which has helped stimulate the economy. The government expects around 34-35 million foreign visitors this year, up from 28 million last year, with a record 40 million in 2019. The visa-free program is aimed at increasing tourism revenue and contributing to Thailand's economy.

site_title: Australia lists nickel as ‘critical mineral’ to unlock billions in support
summary: Australia has classified nickel as a "critical mineral," allowing access to billions in government support to boost the industry. The move comes as the sector faces thousands of job cuts due to a 40% plunge in prices over the past year. Resources Minister Madeleine King said the classification will provide companies with access to financing and grant programs, and discussions are underway to ensure high Australian standards are reflected in international pricing. The move aims to support the development of a battery chemicals industry in Australia, valued at billions.

images.alt_text: Nickel is essential to the manufacture of stainless steel and of batteries that are fuelling the world’s transition to greener energy.

site_title: Singapore exports up 16.8% in January, far higher than market expectations
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 16.8% year-over-year in January, exceeding market expectations, driven by a surge in non-monetary gold shipments to China and Hong Kong. This marked an improvement from the 1.5% decline in December and a 25.1% year-over-year slump in January last year. Total trade grew 14.1% year-over-year, with electronics exports showing a 0.7% year-over-year growth. Economists predict modest growth in 2024, with some expecting a gradual and fragile exports recovery.

images.alt_text: In 2023, total merchandise trade fell 11.7 per cent year on year, after expanding 17.7 per cent the year before, driven by declines in both oil and non-oil trade.
On a seasonally adjusted basis, NODX value reached S$14.6 billion in December, down from S$15 billion in November.

site_title: Top AI memory maker SK Hynix may add to 95% rally
summary: SK Hynix, a top memory supplier for artificial intelligence, is expected to continue its 95% rally as investors remain bullish on its lead in the high-bandwidth memory (HBM) market. The company has partnered with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) to develop its next-generation HBM chip, fueling market speculation of its dominance in the space. Analysts predict a 20% return over the next 12 months, with options traders showing increased bullishness, driven by its competitive advantage in HBM and deep relationships with AI processor designers.

images.alt_text: Semiconductor firms have pledged to invest more than US$230 billion on American soil since President Joe Biden took office, spurred by the 2022 Chips Act.
SK Hynix is expected to begin mass production of the next version of HBM, called HBM3E, in the first half of the year.
SK Hynix is expected to report holiday-quarter earnings later this month.

site_title: Macau sees record Chinese New Year visitors in boost for casinos
summary: Macau reported a record 1.08 million visitor arrivals in the first six days of the Chinese New Year holiday, a 3.7% increase from 2019, with 77% coming from mainland China. The city's hotel occupancy rate reached 97% on Feb 12-13, boosting casinos' gaming revenue. This surge in visitors, mainly from China, signals a strong month for casinos, with gaming revenue expected to surpass US$2.5 billion in February, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Gross gaming revenue grows 400 per cent to 19.5 billion patacas (S$3.3 billion), according to data released by the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.

site_title: Google announces free AI cyber tools to bolster online security
summary: Google has announced a new initiative to bolster online security with free AI cyber tools. The company will introduce an open-source resource powered by AI to detect malware and protect products like Gmail and Google Drive. Google also plans to release a white paper on AI for cyber defense and propose a policy agenda to advance AI research and guardrails on autonomous cyber defenses. This move aims to counter the increasing use of AI by hackers, who are integrating AI into their cyber operations.

site_title: Gold heads for second weekly dip as traders reassess US rate bets
summary: Gold prices are set for their second straight weekly drop, falling nearly 1% for the week, as traders reassess US rate-cut hopes following surprisingly hot US consumer prices. US gold futures rose 0.1% to $2,016.00 per ounce, while spot gold remained flat at $2,003.95 per ounce. Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta President Raphael Bostic expressed caution against delaying interest rate cuts, while Chicago Fed president Austan Goolsbee warned against delaying rate cuts for too long. The first possible rate cut is expected in June.

site_title: Temasek divests 1.1% stake in Indian hospital chain for 3.95 billion rupees: sources
summary: Temasek, a Singapore investment company, has sold a 1.1% stake in Indian private hospital chain Medanta for 3.95 billion rupees (S$64 million), retaining a 17% stake. The exit is expected to generate a 26% realized internal rate of return over nine years, with a multiple of eight times invested capital. Temasek initially invested 7 billion rupees in Medanta in 2015 and has made three exits in its India portfolio since 2024.

site_title: SIC flags breaches by advisers Allen & Gledhill, DBS during 2022 Mapletree merger
summary: The Securities Industry Council (SIC) in Singapore has found that law firm Allen & Gledhill (A&G) and DBS breached the Singapore Code on Take-overs and Mergers while advising on the merger of Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust in 2022. A&G's adviser advised incorrectly that a whitewash waiver was not required, while DBS was aware of the need for the waiver but failed to raise the issue with A&G. Both parties have taken steps to improve their internal processes and controls, and the SIC has decided not to take further action, citing their prompt action to mitigate the breaches.

site_title: What Prabowo’s presidency in Indonesia will mean for the world
summary: Indonesian presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto is expected to win the country's presidential election by a wide margin, taking on the task of balancing Indonesia's relations with the US and China. As president, Prabowo will need to manage the US-China rivalry, potentially strengthening ties with the West while maintaining relationships with Beijing. His focus on building Indonesia's military power may be viewed negatively in the region. Prabowo has expressed skepticism towards the EU and has a disputed human rights record, which may affect his ability to work with European partners.

site_title: It’s not always the economy
summary: Investors struggle to identify clear insights in financial markets due to shifting economic projections. Last year's experience, marked by an initial recession narrative followed by near-all-time highs, highlights the pressure to take a stance on economic trends. To overcome this, investors should focus on five key questions: market composition evolution, earnings contributors, return drivers, fundamental technicals, and asset flows. By examining these factors, investors can develop a more nuanced understanding of the markets and make more informed investment decisions, rather than relying on collective concern or surface-level data.

site_title: Taylor Swift set to bring momentary boost to Australian economy
summary: Taylor Swift's upcoming concert tour in Australia is expected to generate a temporary economic boost, with a projected A$1.2 billion in economic value in Melbourne alone. Fans, like 19-year-old student Genevieve Mylne, will spend around A$2,000 on tickets, flights, and accommodation to attend the seven shows across two cities. However, economists warn that this spending may come at a cost, potentially crowding out purchases in other areas, particularly in weak discretionary sectors, due to households' financial pressure and low savings rate.

summary: Jurgen Klinsmann was sacked as South Korea's coach after just under a year in the position following a defeat to Jordan in the Asian Cup semi-finals and revelations about a team brawl. The Korea Football Association cited Klinsmann's poor managerial performance, leadership, and attitude, saying he failed to display the expected capabilities to bring competitiveness to the team. The decision comes ahead of the 2026 World Cup qualifying games, with the KFA planning to find a new head coach.

site_title: Google to launch anti-misinformation campaign ahead of EU elections
summary: Google is launching an anti-misinformation campaign across five EU countries ahead of the EU parliamentary elections, aiming to counter the spread of pro-Russian propaganda and misinformation. The campaign, run by Google's internal Jigsaw unit, will feature animated ads with "prebunking" techniques to help viewers identify manipulative content. The ads will be translated into all 24 official EU languages and will run for at least one month, with the results to be published in summer 2024. The move comes as the European Digital Services Act comes into force, requiring online platforms to tackle illegal content and risks to public security.

site_title: OpenAI introduces AI model that turns text into video
summary: OpenAI has introduced an AI model called Sora, which can generate minute-long videos based on text prompts. The software can create complex scenes with multiple characters, specific motion, and accurate details. Sora can also animate still images. However, the model is still a work-in-progress, with potential issues including confusing spatial details and difficulty following camera trajectories. The software is currently available for testing and feedback purposes, with OpenAI developing tools to detect when videos are generated by Sora.
