The Nokia Oyj headquarters in Espoo, Finland, on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023. Nokia Oyj plans to cut as many as 14,000 jobs, or 16% of its workforce, as a dearth of investment in fifth-generation mobile infrastructure forces it to take cost-cutting measures. Photographer: Roni Rekomaa/Bloomberg

site_title: Manchester United’s complex deal has traders tearing up playbook
summary: UK business mogul Jim Ratcliffe's deal to acquire a 25% stake in Manchester United through his chemical conglomerate Ineos Group is set to be completed for $1.3 billion. The tender offer for the shares, which was initially set to close on February 13, was extended to February 23, leading to volatility in the stock price, which has fluctuated between $20 and $21 per share. The final proration figure will determine the post-deal valuation of the shares, expected to settle at around mid-teens.

images.alt_text: Manchester United now expects full-year revenue of £635 million to £665 million.
Arsenal's Gabriel Magalhaes (second from right) scored against Liverpool the last time the teams met in the Premier League on Dec 23, 2023
Manchester United have not been crowned Premier League champions since Alex Ferguson’s final season in charge, in 2013.

site_title: Thailand to offer medical coverage for tourists
summary: Thailand has launched a scheme offering up to $14,000 in medical coverage to tourists in the event of an accident, aiming to reassure visitors that the country is safe. The Thailand Traveller Safety scheme, launched on January 1, provides up to $37,270 in compensation for death and will run until August 31. The move comes as the tourism sector struggles to recover from the pandemic, with arrivals at 28 million in 2023, a significant decrease from 40 million in 2019. The government hopes to attract more visitors and boost revenue to $55 billion in 2024.

images.alt_text: epa10883323 Chinese tourists and others visit the Emerald Buddha Temple inside of the Grand Palace in Bangkok, Thailand, 26 September 2023. Thailand started the five-month visa exemption scheme for Chinese and Kazakh visitors effective from 25 September 2023 to 29 February 2024, with the aim to generate tourism revenue.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: JPMorgan, State Street drop out of largest investor climate group
summary: JPMorgan Chase and State Street have withdrawn from the Climate Action 100+ investor group, citing concerns over the coalition's new priorities that threaten their independence. The group, which aims to convince companies to act on climate change, had asked its members to engage with policymakers and publish details on their talks with companies to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. State Street cited its independent approach to proxy voting and portfolio company engagement, while JPMorgan cited significant investment in its investment stewardship capabilities. The exits are a blow to efforts to coordinate Wall Street action on tackling climate change.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan’s aggressive expansion strategy comes as some other lenders have been shrinking their presence.

site_title: Silverlake Axis half-year profit down 11% despite revenue increase
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 11% drop in net profit to RM88.6 million for the first half of FY2024, despite a 1% increase in revenue to RM397.4 million. The decline was attributed to a change in revenue mix, with software licensing revenue falling 53% to RM26.5 million. Total expenses rose 11% to RM119.5 million, mainly due to annual salary increments and new headcount. The company remains below the industry benchmark for expense-to-revenue ratio and has a robust pipeline of deals worth RM1.4 billion.

images.alt_text: The enterprise technology company says that Silverlake’s independent directors are of the view that the proposal should be explored in line with the company’s longer-term expansion and growth.

site_title: Airport group ADP sees full recovery in China traffic in 2025/2026
summary: Airport group ADP expects Chinese traffic to reach 65% of 2019 levels by summer 2024, with a full recovery possible in 2025 or 2026. Despite hopes for a recovery in long-haul flights, subdued demand and economic growth in China's second-largest economy are cited as constraints. ADP targets annual growth of above 4% in 2024 earnings and 7% in 2025, with shares up 2.1% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: This year’s festival helps draw 3.05 million visitors to Harbin, generating 5.91 billion yuan (S$1.1 billion) in tourism revenue.
During the New Year holidays, more than 128 million passenger trips were made on China’s transport network, up 78.4 per cent from 2023 and 33.1 per cent from 2022.
The 2019 Golden Week lasted seven days, as the mid-Autumn festival did not coincide with the National Day celebrations, which this year boosted the length of the holiday by one day.

site_title: STI ends 1.2% higher on upbeat mood across region, ahead of national Budget
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.2% to 3,176.69, driven by an upbeat mood across the region ahead of the national Budget. Markets shrugged off January's inflation print, with notable gains from Taiwan, Japan, and Indonesia, including a record high for Taiwan's key index. Singapore's banking sector led the gains, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB advancing. The rally comes as the Ministry of Trade and Industry revised down Singapore's GDP growth for the final quarter of 2023, but still expects a growth of 3% in 2024.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average has finished up 0.4 per cent at 38,424.27.
One Town Center, one of Prime US Reit's assets in Florida. Analysts are speculating that news of Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's recapitalisation plan could pose a "contagion risk" to Prime.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Deb 15)
summary: Singapore's fourth-quarter GDP growth is revised down to 2.2% for 2023, lower than the initial estimate of 2.8%. The country's economy grew 1.1% in 2023, down from 3.8% in 2022. Meanwhile, developers sold 281 private homes in January, the lowest in 15 years, and the six-month T-bill yield rose to 3.66%. The government has upgraded its 2024 forecast for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) to modest growth, with an expected recovery in electronics. The 2024 Budget Statement is set to be delivered on Friday.

site_title: Singapore businesses set up shop in Niseko
summary: Singaporean businesses are setting up shop in Japan's premier ski resort, Niseko, with a focus on food and beverage, hospitality, and accommodations. Key players include Mandala Club, Luke's Alpine Club, Nylon Coffee, and Roketto, which offer unique experiences such as ski-in, ski-out F&B outlets and events. Despite challenges like the language barrier, high costs, and labor crunch, many entrepreneurs see opportunities in Niseko, particularly during the winter holiday season. With Singaporeans accounting for 11% of foreign visitors to Niseko, the resort is poised to become a year-round destination with the arrival of the Shinkansen service in 2030.

images.alt_text: OOAK Niseko is situated high up in the mountain with a spectacular view of Mount Yotei.

site_title: SIA passenger traffic for January up 14.4%, slower than passenger capacity growth of 16.5%
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 14.4% year-on-year rise in group passenger traffic to 12.6 billion revenue passenger-kilometres in January 2024, slower than passenger capacity growth of 16.5%. Revenue passenger-kilometres rose 14.3% to 9.6 billion, while cargo loads increased 19.7% to 469.1 million tonne-km. The group's passenger load factor was 85.3%, 1.6 percentage points lower than the previous year, due to the shift in the Chinese New Year to February.

images.alt_text: Organised by Experia Events, the Singapore Airshow will feature trade exhibitors from over 1,000 companies.
FILE PHOTO: An employee walks past a fuselage section under construction at Boeing Co.'s 787 Dreamliner campus in North Charleston, South Carolina, U.S., May 30, 2023. Gavin McIntyre/File Photo
The acquisition comes as the group looks to expand its point-to-point mobility services and offerings in the region.

site_title: Indonesia, Singapore sign outline pledge on carbon storage
summary: Indonesia and Singapore signed a letter of intent on cross-border collaboration for the capture and storage of carbon dioxide (CCS). This move follows Indonesia's new law allowing CCS operators to allocate 30% of storage capacity for imported CO2. The two countries will form a working group to seek a bilateral agreement on CO2 transport and storage. Indonesia has over 400 gigatonnes of storage capacity and 15 CCS projects with a combined investment of nearly $8 billion. This outlines a significant step towards sustainable development and environmental stewardship for both countries.

images.alt_text: Many countries and regions have launched emissions trading systems (ETS) to put a price on carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions and incentivise companies to invest in low carbon technology.

site_title: India ministers, farmers unions to hold talks to end protests
summary: Indian farmers' unions meet with government ministers to discuss demands for a minimum price for their produce to ensure their livelihood. The talks follow two days of protests, during which police used tear gas and barricades to stop thousands of farmers from marching to New Delhi. The protests come ahead of national elections in which Prime Minister Narendra Modi is seeking a third term, and the farmers are seeking fair crop prices to avoid financial crisis.

images.alt_text: India wins US support for food scheme, ends WTO blockade

site_title: Oil demand growth slowing as non-Opec supply expands, says IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has predicted that global oil demand will peak by 2030 as the world shifts to cleaner energy. This contradicts the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) forecast, which expects oil use to rise for the next two decades. The IEA trimmed its 2024 growth forecast, citing a slowdown in oil demand growth due to expanding non-Opec supply. This marks a stark difference in estimates between the two forecasters.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell 19 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to settle at US$82.00 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Sri Lanka's inflation expected to hit 5% in medium term
summary: Sri Lanka's economy is expected to recover from a severe financial crisis, with inflation expected to return to 5% in the medium term. The island nation's economy stabilized after a US$2.9 billion IMF programme was implemented in 2022. A recent spike in inflation, rising to 6.4% at the end of last month, is expected to be short-lived and return to the targeted 5% as the economy continues to recover.

site_title: General Motors, Panasonic sign investment deals with Canadian graphite producer
summary: General Motors and Panasonic have signed agreements to purchase 18,000 tonnes of active anode material annually from Canadian graphite producer Nouveau Monde Graphite. The investment, valued at US$1.2 billion, includes building a graphite concentrator and refining facility in Quebec. GM and Panasonic will also invest in Nouveau Monde Graphite to produce high-quality graphite in North America, supporting the production of electric vehicle batteries.

images.alt_text: A Chevrolet Bolt electric vehicle (EV) at a dealership in Colma, California, US, on Friday, Jan. 26, 2024. General Motors Co. is expected to release earnings figures on January 30. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Tesla’s arrangement appears to be a departure from CATL’s deal with Ford Motor, which aims to license the Chinese company’s technology to build batteries at a Michigan plant owned by the automaker.
The unit expects the Kansas plant to take its annual auto battery capacity to 80 GWh a year.

site_title: EU cuts eurozone inflation, growth forecasts for 2024
summary: The European Commission has cut its 2024 eurozone inflation forecast to 2.7% and growth forecast to 0.8%, citing lower energy commodity prices and weaker economic momentum. The revisions are attributed to the European Central Bank's interest rate-hiking campaign last year. Despite the downward forecast, the commission expects inflation to drop further in the long term. The commission also downgraded its forecasts for Germany and France, with growth expected to reach 0.3% and 0.9% in 2024, respectively.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags flutter outside the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Yves Herman//File Photo
“Wage growth continues to be strong and is expected to become an increasingly important driver of inflation dynamics in the coming quarters,” ECB president Christine Lagarde says.
Inflation remains above the European Central Bank’s 2 per cent target, but well below the peak of 10.6 per cent recorded in October 2022 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent energy prices soaring.
The latest round of Consumer Expectations Survey shows the median household expected prices to grow by 3.2 per cent in the following 12 months, down from 4 per cent a month earlier.
The new data comes after the ECB faces years of criticism that a decade of ultra-low interest rates and copious asset purchases mostly favoured wealthy people with ample financial assets.

site_title: FWD mulls options for US$10 billion insurer after IPO delay: sources
summary: FWD Group Holdings, a Hong Kong-based insurer controlled by billionaire Richard Li, is considering options including a potential stake sale after delaying a planned IPO. The company may seek a valuation of over $10 billion and has expressed interest from global insurers like Sun Life Financial, which has approached FWD to discuss a potential deal. A deal could provide an exit for long-standing shareholders and allow FWD to reduce debt, boost sustainable profitability, and grow. Discussions are ongoing, but no transaction is guaranteed.

images.alt_text: FWD's job cuts take place mainly in Hong Kong and Singapore.

site_title: Goldman Sachs raises Europe’s STOXX 600 2024 target to 510
summary: Goldman Sachs has raised its 2024 target for Europe's STOXX 600 index to 510, citing improving economic activity, a potential decline in interest rates, and attractive valuations. The index has risen 13% since October and 2% this year, driven by moderation in eurozone manufacturing activity and declining consumer prices. Goldman also revised its recommendations for various European sub-sectors, including upgrading the industrial goods and services sector and travel and leisure stock index. The brokerage attributed these upgrades to improved demand, lower energy costs, and wage stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, December 30, 2021.  REUTERS/Staff

site_title: India’s rice rates steady at record highs, Vietnam activity picks up
summary: India's parboiled rice exports remain at record highs, trading at US$542 to US$550 per tonne, despite subdued demand from African buyers. Vietnam sees increased trading activity after the Chinese New Year, with 5 per cent broken rice offered at US$637 to US$640 per tonne. Pakistan's rice exports are expected to surge to a record high due to India's decision to curb shipments, offering the grain at nearly 16-year-high prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers lift a sack of rice to load onto a truck at a wholesale grain market in the northern Indian city of Chandigarh February 9, 2012. REUTERS/Ajay Verma/File Photo

site_title: UBS taps Debt Capital Market Asia co-head to lead private credit
summary: UBS appoints Ben Sung as head of Corporate Book for South-east Asia, leading the bank's private credit business in the region. Sung, former co-head of Debt Capital Markets in Asia, will manage private credit and structured lending for the region. The move comes after several Singapore-based bankers left Credit Suisse's APAC Financing Group, which had lower risk appetite. This follows a trend of banks in Asia increasing staffing to boost their share of the US$1.7 trillion asset market.

images.alt_text: The market for new AT1s by European banks has been busy this week.
FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at a branch of Swiss bank UBS in Zurich, Switzerland February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann
John McDonald, group chief marketing officer, UBS
The scale of the retrenchment in private banking is one of the biggest seen in Asia and comes as wealth from the Greater China region has tumbled amid a property crisis and the faltering economy.
UBS is making progress on a complex integration and restructuring of Credit Suisse, which it acquired in an emergency rescue.

site_title: India trade gap shrinks to a nine-month low in January
summary: India's trade deficit narrowed to US$17.5 billion in January, the lowest in nine months, due to softening commodity prices. Exports rose 3.1% to US$36.92 billion, while imports grew 3% to US$54.41 billion, narrowing the gap between the two. This is lower than economists' forecast of a US$20 billion deficit and the December deficit of US$19.8 billion.

site_title: A candid look at expat lives in Asia
summary: A new Amazon Prime Video series, Expats, explores the lives of transplanted wives in Asia, starring Nicole Kidman as a grieving mother whose young child goes missing in a Hong Kong night market. The show, based on the 2016 novel by Janice YK Lee, initially promises a nuanced look at expat life but struggles to balance its focus on grief with advancing its narrative arc. The series' pacing is criticized for stagnating, and its failure to delve deeper into the complexities of expatriate life is seen as a missed opportunity.

images.alt_text: It is critical for companies to ensure that employees are adequately covered and that their healthcare and wellbeing needs are taken care of.
S'pore is 9th most expensive Asian city

site_title: Japan's Nikkei pushes to 34-year peak as chip shares climb
summary: Japan's Nikkei index reached a 34-year peak, closing at 38,157.94, its highest level since January 1990. The benchmark index rose 1.21% as chip-related shares surged, driven by gains in Tokyo Electron and SoftBank Group. A weak yen and dovish monetary policy also supported the Nikkei, which remains just 800 points below its all-time high in 1989. Analysts expect the Nikkei to potentially test its level by end-March, but may retreat at the start of the new fiscal year in April.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past a signboard showing the closing numbers on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, along a street in Tokyo in January 11, 2024. Tokyo's Nikkei index closed above 35,000 for the first time in nearly 34 years on January 11, buoyed by US Tech rallies and hopes for an end to decades of sluggish inflation. (Photo by Richard A. BROOKS / AFP)

site_title: 💼 Can office life actually benefit younger workers?
summary: Younger workers may benefit from office life, as it can increase exposure and visibility to senior management. A study by Indeed found that 33% of workers in Singapore prefer hybrid work. Career coach Adrian Choo advises that "face time" is essential for career advancement, and workers should invest in in-person interactions to build relationships and gain recognition. Conversely, fully remote workers may unintentionally hurt their careers if managers regard them as "out of sight, out mind." Hybrid work offers the best of both worlds, allowing workers to balance flexibility with face-to-face interaction.

images.alt_text: BT

site_title: BHP says value of assets smashed by nickel price collapse
summary: MINING giant BHP reported a US$2.3 billion write-down of its Australian nickel operations due to "current market conditions". The value of its assets has been significantly impacted by the collapse of nickel prices, with the company struggling to compete with cheap shipments from neighboring Indonesia. The move is a result of the growing demand for nickel in the production of stainless steel and green energy batteries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A small toy figure and mineral imitation are seen in front of the BHP logo in this illustration taken November 19, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: ECB’s Lagarde says wages gaining importance as inflation driver
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde stated that strong wage growth is becoming a significant driver of inflation in the coming quarters, posing risks to the 2% inflation target. Despite disinflation expected to continue gradually in 2024, policymakers require more assurance that price gains are headed back to the target. The ECB's forward-looking wage tracker signals strong pressures, but some levelling off in the last quarter of 2023 is anticipated. Rate cut timing remains uncertain, with officials debating an initial cut in April or June.

images.alt_text: Inflation remains above the European Central Bank’s 2 per cent target, but well below the peak of 10.6 per cent recorded in October 2022 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent energy prices soaring.
The latest round of Consumer Expectations Survey shows the median household expected prices to grow by 3.2 per cent in the following 12 months, down from 4 per cent a month earlier.
The new data comes after the ECB faces years of criticism that a decade of ultra-low interest rates and copious asset purchases mostly favoured wealthy people with ample financial assets.
Inflation across Eurozone jumps to 2.9 per cent in December from 2.4 per cent in November, just shy of expectations for a 3 per cent reading.

site_title: Indonesia markets cheer Prabowo’s likely presidential election win
summary: Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index surged 1.3% on Thursday, its largest gain in two months, as Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto declared victory in the presidential election, putting him on course for a decisive win. Prabowo's 58% lead in sample counts and 57% expected outcome in official count have eased investor uncertainty, with analysts predicting a smooth transition and potential for policy continuity. The market is expected to remain positive, with stocks linked to infrastructure and nickel producers rising, and the rupiah stabilizing in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Defence Minister and presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto gestures as he addresses his supporters during a campaign rally in Jakarta, Indonesia February 10, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: Rents start to dip for luxury apartments in New York and Hong Kong
summary: Luxury apartment rents in cities like New York and Hong Kong have started to decline, with prime residential rents falling 0.6% in the fourth quarter. New York saw a 2.5% drop, while Hong Kong's prime rents fell 2%. Toronto experienced the largest decline, dropping 4.8%. Despite this, global luxury rents still increased 5.2% year-over-year, with cities like Sydney posting significant gains. Experts expect slower rent growth this year due to affordability constraints and increased supply.

images.alt_text: The US housing market has sagged as the Fed began hiking its benchmark interest rate in 2022 to quash inflation.
Singapore's private rental market continues to face downward pressure.
Hong Kong buildings from Victoria Peak. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Banks’ real estate losses will be hyperlocal
summary: Commercial property losses in the US and Europe are expected to be hyperlocal, varying by individual buildings rather than a systemic crisis. Experts predict some real pain for landlords and lenders, but others will see filling units and rising rents. Occupancy rates have recovered more in Asia-Pacific and Europe than in the US, with price declines in overbid markets like San Francisco outpacing those in other major cities. Bank exposures to US property vary, with smaller regional banks having more lending to almost $2 trillion, while the 25 biggest banks have less than $1 trillion.

images.alt_text: Office buildings are seen in downtown San Francisco as the city struggles to return to its pre-pandemic downtown occupancy rate, falling behind many other major cities around the country, according to local media, in California, U.S., June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Carlos Barria

site_title: Thailand mulls US$1 billion global sovereign bond offer, first in two decades
summary: Thailand is considering issuing a US$1 billion global sovereign bond, its first in two decades, to bridge a budget gap and fund investments locally. The Finance Ministry aims to complete a cost-benefit analysis by May and has preferred raising billions in foreign currency due to low interest rates. The bonds, likely denominated in US dollars, will provide a benchmark for Thai companies tapping overseas markets and finance sustainability-linked projects. Authorities are weighing the higher borrowing cost against local costs, with Deputy Finance Minister Julapun Amornvivat stating that foreign exchange and other fees will apply.

images.alt_text: Bangkok and the northern city of Chiang Mai have ranked among the most polluted cities in the world on a number of days last year.
Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin makes a pitch to potential investors about the land bridge project during his visit to the US. PHOTO: X

The newly approved borrowing is part of a wider revised debt management plan for the fiscal year, which includes the restructuring of existing debt of 2 trillion baht and debt repayments of about 400 billion baht.

site_title: Philippine central bank keeps benchmark rate unchanged at 6.50%
summary: The Philippine central bank maintained its benchmark interest rate at 6.50% for a third consecutive meeting, citing receding risks to inflation outlook. Annual inflation in January was 2.8%, the slowest in over three years, following lower price increases in food, utilities, and fuel. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) aims to keep inflation within its 2-4% target range for 2024.

site_title: SGX, SET, Bursa Malaysia, IDX team up to implement common ESG metrics through joint initiative
summary: The Singapore Exchange, Bursa Malaysia, the Stock Exchange of Thailand, and the Indonesia Stock Exchange have formalized the Asean-Interconnected Sustainability Ecosystem, a joint initiative to implement common Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) metrics across the region. The four exchanges agreed on a foundational governance structure and operational blueprint, marking a significant step towards advancing sustainable development in the Asean region. This collaboration aims to promote transparency and consistency in ESG reporting, ultimately contributing to the region's sustainable growth and development.

images.alt_text: Derivatives traded volume in January 2023 reaches the highest since March 2022.

site_title: Airbus plans special dividend, takes new space charge
summary: Airbus reported a 4% increase in core adjusted operating profit to 5.8 billion euros in 2023, driven by a 11% rise in revenue to 65.4 billion euros. The company predicted a core profit of 6.5-7 billion euros for 2024 and announced a special dividend of one euro per share. Airbus also delayed the entry of its A321XLR single-aisle jet to the third quarter of 2024 and aims to reach a production target of 75 single-aisle jets per month by 2026.

images.alt_text: Dynamatic already makes escape hatch doors for the A220 and flap track beams, a component connected to the wing, for Airbus’ range of A320 single-aisle jets and the twin-aisle A330.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The Airbus logo pictured at the company's headquarters in Blagnac near Toulouse, France, March 20, 2019.  REUTERS/Regis Duvignau/File Photo/File Photo
The European planemaker is on track to meet its production ramp-up goals this year, CEO Guillaume Faury says.

site_title: Hot stocks: US office S-Reits slump on distribution suspensions, gearing woes
summary: US office real estate investment trusts (Reits) slumped on Thursday, February 15, after Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (Kore) suspended distributions for two years due to rising leverage and a 10.1% year-on-year decline in distributable income. Manulife US Reit also suspended distributions as part of its recapitalisation plan. Prime US Reit faced a "contagion risk" from Kore's developments, with its gearing increasing to 43.7% and interest coverage ratio at 3.2 times.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit is one of the top four performers during the period.

Tripp Gantt, chief executive of Manulife US Reit's manager, says priorities for 2024 will focus on asset dispositions and maximising proceeds to further reduce indebtedness and fund capital expenditure.
The Reit's net property income fell 3.3 per cent to US$23.4 million, from US$24.2 million in the corresponding year-ago period.

FCT raised S$200 million of gross proceeds through private placements, the majority of which will be used to repay existing debts, pending the use of such amount to partially fund the proposed acquisition of additional interest in Nex.

site_title: UK fell into technical recession in H2 2023
summary: The UK economy has slipped into a shallow recession in the second half of 2023, with GDP falling 0.3% in the fourth quarter. This marks the UK's first technical recession since 2020, contradicting Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's claim of economic growth before a general election. The recession is attributed to the cost-of-living crisis and rapid interest rate hikes. Economists define a technical recession as two consecutive quarters of falling output, which suggests stagnation rather than a full-blown downturn.

images.alt_text: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey says there were signs that Britain’s economy was gathering momentum.

epa10713638 A shopper at a supermarket in London, Britain, 27 June 2023. UK supermarket chiefs are set to face intense questioning from MP’s over food inflation at parliament in London 27 June. UK food inflation has fallen for the second month in a row as supermarkets cut the price of household staples. Food inflation however still remains high 8.4 percent.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Musk says SpaceX has moved its incorporation to Texas from Delaware
summary: SpaceX, led by CEO Elon Musk, has moved its incorporation from Delaware to Texas, according to Musk's post on X. This move follows Tesla's decision to change its incorporation to Texas, after a Delaware judge invalidated Musk's $56-billion pay package. Additionally, Musk's brain-chip implant company Neuralink changed its location of incorporation from Delaware to Nevada. The changes reflect Musk's preference for Texas, where SpaceX and Tesla have their headquarters.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, February 15, 2024 (Ep 2)
summary: Asian stocks rallied as Taiwan surged on AI demand, while Indonesia's Subianto leads election polls. The Singapore shares rose after GDP data, with the STI up 0.3%. Markets in Asia mostly followed Wall Street gains, tracking a strong US market.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.

site_title: 'She said yes': Aussie PM reveals Valentine's Day engagement
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese revealed his Valentine's Day engagement to girlfriend Jodie Haydon, with a morning message announcing their decision to wed. Albanese, who met Haydon in 2020, is the first Australian prime minister to get engaged while in office. The couple, who have been together for four years, expressed their gratitude for the warm congratulations they received from friends, family, and world leaders, including New Zealand's Christopher Luxon and English chef Nigella Lawson.

images.alt_text: Jirat Somprasung and Rawitsara Chotiwatpongsaton receive their marriage license from an officer while riding elephants during a Valentine's Day celebration, at the Nong Nooch Tropical Garden in Chonburi province, Thailand, February 14, 2024. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Indonesia’s presidential election, with more than 200 million of the 270 million population eligible to vote, is the world’s biggest single-day election.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Thursday after GDP data; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Thursday, driven by a 1.1% GDP growth in 2023 and an upgrade in non-oil domestic exports to 4-6% in 2024. The Straits Times Index gained 8.28 points to 3,147.35, with gainers outnumbering losers 70-43. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, also rose. The gains followed a softer-than-expected UK inflation report, which boosted chances of interest rate cuts by the Bank of England.

images.alt_text: Thai Beverage's sales revenue falls by 5.9 per cent after a 14 per cent decline in the group's beer segment revenue.

site_title: Private US moon lander launches half century after last Apollo lunar mission
summary: A privately funded US moon lander, Nova-C, developed by Intuitive Machines, successfully launched from Florida on February 15, 2024, aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket. The mission aims to conduct the first US lunar touchdown in over 50 years and the first by a privately owned spacecraft. The lander, dubbed Odysseus, is carrying six NASA payloads to gather data about the lunar environment ahead of NASA's planned return of astronauts to the moon later this decade. A successful landing is expected on February 22, marking the first controlled descent to the lunar surface by a US spacecraft since the final Apollo mission in 1972.

images.alt_text: Starlink’s network of low Earth orbit satellites can provide Internet to remote locations, or areas that have had normal communications infrastructure disabled.
Elon Musk’s brain-chip implant company, Neuralink also changed its location of incorporation from Delaware to Nevada last week.

site_title: Watch live stream of Budget 2024 statement from 3.30 pm, Feb 16
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver the Budget 2024 statement in Parliament on Feb 16 at 3:30 pm. The statement will be live-streamed on The Business Times YouTube page. This marks the Singapore government's budget announcement for the year.

site_title: Latest Singapore 6-month T-bill offers cut-off yield of 3.66%
summary: Singapore's six-month Treasury bills (T-bills) offered a cut-off yield of 3.66%, higher than the previous six-month auction's yield of 3.54%. The latest auction received S$13.5 billion in applications for S$6.6 billion on offer, a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.05. Experts attribute the higher cut-off to firm US data and expectations of a no-landing scenario where the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates later in the cycle.

images.alt_text: The Supplementary Retirement Scheme can be a great way to save while lowering your income tax bill.
The bills received a total of S$14.6 billion in applications for the S$6.3 billion on offer, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.32.

site_title: Indonesia posts smaller-than-expected US$2 billion trade surplus in January
summary: Indonesia posted a US$2 billion trade surplus in January, smaller than forecast, due to a 8.06% year-on-year decline in exports to US$20.5 billion. Exports of top commodities like coal and palm oil decreased, with palm oil shipments falling 11.54% year-on-year. Imports grew 0.36% to US$18.5 billion, beating expectations of a 1.3% rise. The trade surplus was also smaller than the previous month's US$3.3 billion.

site_title: Six things to look out for in Budget 2024
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver the 2024 Budget Statement in Parliament on Feb 16, with potential moves including skills-led support for employees and employers, amid high inflation and sluggish wage growth. The government is studying ways to provide additional support for households.

images.alt_text: One suggested move was to reintroduce estate duties or inheritance taxes, with rates varying by property value and type.

According to UOB's survey, 84 per cent of businesses said they were somewhat or highly affected by inflation, with its effects being most felt in the industrials, oil and gas as well as manufacturing and engineering sectors.
Broad-based handouts run the risk of demand-pull inflation, where consumer demand outpaces the supply of goods and services.

The seven key policy shifts outlined in the Forward Singapore report provide a roadmap for the government and "all of Singapore" to chart their way forward in an environment that will be more uncertain, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (fourth from left) during a press conference fronted by the fourth-generation leadership.

site_title: Germany's Commerzbank posts biggest net profit in 15 years
summary: Commerzbank, Germany's largest bank, reported its largest profit in 15 years, reaching 2.224 billion euros in 2023, a 55% increase from the previous year. The bank's net interest income rose 8.5% in the fourth quarter, driven by higher interest rates. Despite this, the bank warned that the sluggish economy will remain a challenge. CEO Manfred Knof stated that the bank aims for another profit rise in 2024, with net interest income expected to continue growing.

images.alt_text: Germany’s stake in Commerzbank dates back to the global financial crisis of 2008 and is still loss-making for the government.

site_title: Thailand sticking with handout plan to lift ‘fragile’ economy
summary: Thailand's government plans to proceed with its 500 billion baht ($18.7 billion) handout scheme, dubbed the "digital wallet", to stimulate the fragile economy. The scheme, which will give 10,000 baht to 50 million Thais, aims to spur growth despite concerns over funding and potential corruption. The plan, championed by Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin, has been met with criticism from economists, who call it fiscally irresponsible. The government has slashed its 2024 economic growth forecast to 2.8 per cent, citing high interest rates and household debt as major concerns.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s state borrowing is estimated at 2.4 trillion baht in the fiscal year that began on Oct 1.
Bangkok and the northern city of Chiang Mai have ranked among the most polluted cities in the world on a number of days last year.

site_title: Nvidia’s scorching shares drew hedge funds in Q4, filings show
summary: Hedge funds have been drawn to Nvidia's shares, with several well-known funds increasing their stakes, including Rokos Capital Management, Bridgewater Associates, and Arrowstreet Capital. The chipmaker's stock has risen nearly 50% in 2024, driven by its role in building artificial intelligence into products. Nvidia's market capitalization has surpassed Alphabet's, making it the third most valuable US company. The company is set to release its quarterly earnings results on February 21, with analysts predicting a significant revenue and profit increase.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: NVIDIA logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Mizuho in a client note raised its price target for Nvidia’s stock to US$825 from US$625 ahead of the Santa Clara, California, company’s quarterly results due on Feb 21.
Arm’s share price rise has made for massive gains for recent bullish options bets.
Nvidia is the last of the tech giants to report earnings, which are due on Feb 21.

site_title: East Ventures names new partner for South Korea fund
summary: East Ventures has appointed Sang Han, former managing director of Temasek Life Sciences Accelerator, as partner for its South Korean fund. Han will manage the fund operation in South Korea, bringing over two decades of experience in corporate development and investments. The fund, launched in partnership with SV Investment, aims to invest $100 million in startups and companies across key sectors, including biotech and healthcare, and media and content. East Ventures, an early backer of notable tech companies in the region, seeks to expand its presence in South Korea.

site_title: Russians use Chinese partner to produce Citroen cars at idled Stellantis plant
summary: Russian company Automotive Technologies has started assembling Citroen C5 Aircross cars at the idled Stellantis plant in Kaluga, Russia, with a Chinese partner. The production began after Stellantis halted operations in Russia in April 2022. At least 42 car kits were imported by Automotive Technologies in December, according to customs records. This move indicates Russian operators are finding ways to continue producing Citroen models despite the halt in production at the Kaluga plant, which is still majority-owned by Stellantis.

images.alt_text: The vehicle’s wings are made of walnut, its chassis is pear and apple tree wood, and cherry wood was used for the bonnet and boot.
As part of the partnership, Stellantis and CATL plan to build an LFP battery factory in Europe.

site_title: Indonesia president says rice prices will decrease soon on incoming supply
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo expects rice prices to decrease in one to two weeks due to incoming supplies. The country plans to import 2.44 million tons of rice in 2024, including a 445,000-ton quota from 2023. This comes amid a rice deficit of 1.63 million tons in January and 1.15 million tons in February, caused by disrupted distribution. The import quota is a quarter of the total 2024 allocation, with most expected to arrive by March. This move aims to alleviate the shortage and stabilize rice prices.

images.alt_text: Workers unload sacks of rice imported from Thailand from a cargo ship at Malahayati Port in Krueng Raya, Indonesia's Aceh province, on June 22, 2023. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)

site_title: Ford sees ‘colossal’ competitive threat in low-cost Chinese EVs
summary: Ford sees low-cost Chinese electric vehicles as a "colossal strategic threat" due to their advanced technology and affordable prices. The company is recalibrating its EV strategy to compete with Chinese automakers like BYD, which recently surpassed Tesla as the world's largest EV maker. Ford expects Chinese automakers to build factories in Mexico to evade US tariffs, and is working on low-cost EVs to take on the competition. The company's CEO, Jim Farley, emphasized the need for Ford to adapt to the changing EV market to ensure its future.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Ford logo is pictured at the 2019 Frankfurt Motor Show (IAA) in Frankfurt, Germany September 10, 2019. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Homes outside London increasingly going for more than £1 million
summary: Homes outside London are increasingly selling for over £1 million, with the average distance from the city centre to high-value postcodes reaching 106 km. Despite nationwide house price struggles since 2022, London suburbs continue to benefit from people seeking homes close to the city for commuting and raising families. Knight Frank reports 11 new areas in England and Wales selling a fifth of their homes for over £1 million, with areas like Woking and South Oxford making the list, and others in picturesque landscapes like the Lake District and Cotswold.

images.alt_text: The average price of a home in the UK rose to £284,691 in December, a 0.1 per cent rise compared to the previous month.

epa10498611 A row of houses in London, Britain, 02 March 2023. UK house prices in February dropped by the most in more than 10 years according to mortgage lender Nationwide showing signs of a slowdown in the housing market due to high inflation and rising borrowing costs.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL

site_title: Gold near two-month low as traders wary of US rate cut prospects
summary: Gold prices held near a two-month low on February 15, sliding 1.4% after the CPI data, its biggest daily decline since December 4. US Federal Reserve officials' mixed remarks on inflation data sparked concerns about early interest rate cuts. Chicago Fed president Austan Goolsbee said the central bank should be wary of waiting too long before cutting rates, despite hotter-than-expected inflation. Gold prices remain flat at $1,992.77 per ounce, with traders pricing in roughly 97 basis points of rate cuts for this year.

images.alt_text: Bullion fell about 1.4 per cent on Tuesday in its biggest daily decline since Dec 4.

site_title: Bangkok says work from home as pollution blankets city
summary: Bangkok's city employees have been ordered to work from home due to severe air pollution, with PM2.5 levels exceeding 15 times the World Health Organization's annual guideline. The pollution, caused by smoke and industrial emissions, affects over 60,000 people and is expected to last into Friday. The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration has implemented measures to mitigate the issue, with the government promising to tackle air pollution as a national agenda.

images.alt_text: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin makes a pitch to potential investors about the land bridge project during his visit to the US. PHOTO: X

The newly approved borrowing is part of a wider revised debt management plan for the fiscal year, which includes the restructuring of existing debt of 2 trillion baht and debt repayments of about 400 billion baht.

epa10883323 Chinese tourists and others visit the Emerald Buddha Temple inside of the Grand Palace in Bangkok, Thailand, 26 September 2023. Thailand started the five-month visa exemption scheme for Chinese and Kazakh visitors effective from 25 September 2023 to 29 February 2024, with the aim to generate tourism revenue.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Slow start to year for developers with lowest January new home sales in 15 years
summary: Singapore's private home sales in January fell to their lowest level in 15 years, with 281 units sold, a 28.5% decrease from the same month in 2023. The low sales figure, excluding executive condominiums, is attributed to tentative buyer sentiment and high unsold units, which rose to 7,936. The majority of sales (73%) fell within the S$1 million to less than S$2.5 million price range, with sales of executive condominiums also showing signs of stabilization.

images.alt_text: Generic image of private property in Singapore
One of two large sites awarded for over S$1 billion last year was a prime Marina Gardens Lane site.  The site is etched in red in this aerial view of Marina South.
The government plays a critical role in ensuring adequate private housing supply.

site_title: Starlink satellites approved for use in Israel and Gaza
summary: The Israeli government has approved the use of Elon Musk's Starlink satellite Internet services in both Israel and parts of the Gaza Strip. The deal will provide Internet access to a field hospital in Gaza's city of Rafah and may expand further with Israeli approval. The service will enable video conferencing and real-time remote diagnostics, potentially saving lives in Gaza's overwhelmed hospitals, which have been affected by four months of war.

images.alt_text: Starlink offers high-speed Internet connection for a monthly fee and a one-time charge for the ground receiver hardware needed to connect to its satellite constellation.
“Starlink is also now a majority of all active satellites and will have launched a a majority of all satellites cumulatively from Earth by next year,” says Elon Musk.

site_title: Some Chinese youth spurn corporate jobs for ‘me time’ as economy slows
summary: China's economy continues to struggle, with a record-high youth jobless rate of 21.3% in June 2023. Many young people, like 23-year-old Chu Yi, are opting out of corporate jobs to prioritize their own well-being and interests, a phenomenon known as "lying flat". This trend is driven by pessimism about the future, economic uncertainty, and the pressure of corporate work. As a result, Chu is choosing a part-time job to pursue her passion for tattooing, finding happiness in her newfound freedom.

images.alt_text: A dragon installation in Beijing, Feb 7, 2024.
China has been beset by falling prices for much of the last year as the nation struggles to revive domestic demand and consumer confidence.

site_title: Crypto market value climbs back above US$2 trillion in broad rally
summary: The cryptocurrency market has seen a significant rally, with Bitcoin's value climbing back above $2 trillion in market capitalization for the first time since April 2022. Bitcoin has tripled since the start of last year, driven by factors such as the debut of US exchange-traded funds and the upcoming Bitcoin halving, which is expected to curb supply and support prices. Other cryptocurrencies, including Ether, have also seen gains, with Ether reaching $2,785. Analysts attribute the rally to strong net inflows into US spot Bitcoin ETFs.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has risen around 20 per cent since the start of February, already set for its biggest monthly rise since October.
Bitcoin has tripled since the start of last year in a comeback from the 2022 digital-asset rout.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up, tracking Wall Street gains
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, following a rebound in Europe and New York, and positive remarks from a senior Federal Reserve official that inflation was headed in the right direction. The US consumer price index slowed less than expected in January, dealing a blow to hopes of an early interest rate cut. Strong earnings releases and expectations of reduced borrowing costs boosted investor sentiment. Key markets rose, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Singapore gaining, while Taipei hit an intraday record high, and Jakarta's stocks rallied after a general election result indicated policy continuity.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks were in retreat as the Hang Seng reopened after an extended break for the Lunar New Year.

site_title: Time to review planning to raise accommodation supply for senior living: Redas
summary: Singapore needs to review its approach to senior living amid an ageing population, with over 900,000 seniors aged 65 and above expected by 2030. Redas president Tan Swee Yiow called for separate zoning for senior living, with integrated units requiring adjusted unit sizes, layouts, and smart features. The association also urged the government to consider recalibrating the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) regime to promote property market stability. With a projected 1-3% economic growth in 2024, Tan emphasized the need for timely remuneration and risk-sharing in public-sector projects.

images.alt_text: For 2024, the Built Environment and Construction Authority (BCA) expects construction demand to fall between S$32 billion and S$38 billion, an increase from 2023 figures.

site_title: Chip giant TSMC helps power Taiwan’s stock index to record high
summary: Taiwan's stock index reached a record high on February 15, driven by a surge in tech titan Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) after it reported strong sales. TSMC's earnings showed a 7.9% on-year increase in January revenues, with the company's stock spiking 9.8% and the Taiex index jumping 3.5%. The gains were fueled by optimism for the sector and demand for chips used for artificial intelligence, with TSMC controlling over half of the world's silicon wafer output and powering everything from coffee machines to missiles.

images.alt_text: FILE — The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) headquarters in Hsinchu, Taiwan on Oct. 18, 2022. These days it seems impossible to have a conversation about geopolitics or economics without coming back to T.S.M.C., which makes about 90 percent of the world’s most advanced chips, as Nicholas Kristof writes. (Lam Yik Fei/The New York Times)
The company has faced resistance to plans to bring in technicians from Taiwan for the construction project.

“In today’s fractured globalisation environment, our strategy is to expand our global manufacturing footprint to increase our customers’ trust, expand our future growth potential, and reach for more global talents,” says TSMC Chairman Mark Liu.

site_title: South Korea prepares 75.9 trillion won corporate financial support programme
summary: South Korea has prepared a 75.9 trillion won financial support programme to help companies and small businesses affected by high interest rates. The programme includes 15 trillion won in cheap policy loans for key industries and 20 trillion won in support for small and medium-sized businesses. The Financial Services Commission aims to provide relief to companies facing liquidity trouble and support the growth of key sectors, including semiconductors and batteries. This move is seen as a response to evolving trade relations with China, technological advancements, and global supply chain fragmentation.

site_title: Japan chipmaker Renesas to buy software company Altium for A$9.1 billion
summary: Renesas Electronics has agreed to buy Australian-listed electronics design company Altium for A$9.1 billion, a 34% premium to Altium's closing price. The deal aims to streamline electronics design for customers by offering tools for designing circuit boards. Headquartered in California, Altium booked US$263 million in sales in the previous year. The acquisition has been approved by both companies' boards and will require shareholder and regulatory approval. This is Renesas' latest acquisition, following the purchase of power semiconductor company Transphorm in June.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of NEC Corp is pictured at the CEATEC JAPAN 2017 (Combined Exhibition of Advanced Technologies) at the Makuhari Messe in Chiba, Japan, October 2, 2017.   REUTERS/Toru Hanai
The view from the company itself is more sanguine, with one executive projecting strong sales in China continuing for the next year or two.

site_title: Genetic-testing firm Invitae, backed by SoftBank and Cathie Wood, files for bankruptcy
summary: Invitae, a genetic-testing company backed by SoftBank and Cathie Wood, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in New Jersey. The company listed assets of $500 million to $1 billion and liabilities of $1 billion to $10 billion. Invitae's market capitalization soared to over $10 billion during the pandemic but struggled to maintain profitability. The company plans to use its own cash to fund the bankruptcy process and has received interest from several potential buyers.

images.alt_text: The bank’s collapse almost a year ago represented the biggest US bank failure in more than a decade and marked the start of a crisis in the sector.
FILE PHOTO: People walk behind the logo of SoftBank Corp in Tokyo December 18, 2014.  REUTERS/Toru Hanai (JAPAN - Tags: BUSINESS TELECOMS LOGO)/File Photo

site_title: Google enables OS upgrades for older PCs post-Windows 10 support cut-off
summary: Google is enabling businesses to upgrade older PCs running Windows 10 with its Chrome operating system, allowing them to continue receiving security updates and features. This move comes after Microsoft's Windows 10 support ends on October 14, 2025, and users may struggle to find compatible devices. ChromeOS Flex will provide an auto-updating version, stream legacy applications, and support data encryption. The plan aims to extend the life of millions of PCs and prevent them from reaching landfills, although it may not address compatibility issues with legacy applications.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: NVIDIA logo is seen near computer motherboard in this illustration taken January 8, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Last month, Google has announced it would invest US$1 billion into building a data centre just outside of London.
A logo of Google is seen on its office building in Hyderabad, India, January 29, 2024. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas

site_title: Australia unemployment hits two-year high as jobs growth sputters
summary: Australia's jobless rate rose to 4.1% in January, the highest since January 2022, as employment growth slowed. The net employment increase was 500, lower than forecasted 30,000, and full-time employment added 11,100. The jobless rate surpassed expectations and the participation rate held steady at 66.8%. The Reserve Bank of Australia left its benchmark interest rate unchanged, citing a slowing labor market and subdued consumer demand. Markets now expect a rate cut in September, with the total easing expected to be 38 basis points this year.

images.alt_text: The RBA has lifted interest rates to a 12-year peak of 4.35 per cent in an effort to restrain inflation and continues to warn that another hike might be needed even as the economy slows.
Consumer price inflation slowed sharply to a two-year low of 4.1 per cent in the December quarter, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment.

site_title: Japan unexpectedly slips into recession, Germany now world’s third-biggest economy
summary: Japan unexpectedly slipped into recession at the end of last year, with its GDP falling 0.4% in the October-December period. The country lost its title as the world's third-largest economy to Germany, and weak demand in China, sluggish consumption, and production halts at a Toyota unit point to a challenging economic recovery. The Bank of Japan's exit from its decade-long ultra-loose monetary policy may be delayed, with some analysts warning of another contraction in the current quarter.

images.alt_text: Japan will need more people to produce goods and consume while paying taxes.
Young people in Japan are benefiting from a labour shortage that’s especially acute in their age group.
Japanese household spending in December fell 2.5 per cent from a year earlier, government data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: CICT’s lower DPU, higher gearing since pandemic may have some investors questioning its strategy
summary: CICT, a Singapore-based property trust, reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 10.75 cents for FY2023, lower than its pre-pandemic level of 11.97 cents in FY2019. The trust's higher gearing and debt costs may be contributing to the decline. Analysts point to the interest rate environment and CICT's improved operational performance, including an 8.2% rise in revenue and a 7% increase in net property income. Despite this, some investors may question CICT's strategy, and the trust's DPU is expected to be challenging to recover this year.

images.alt_text: FCT said it would acquire an additional 10% stake in Waterway Point.
FCT will hold an effective 50 per cent interest in Nex if its proposed acquisition of Fraser Property's 24.5 per cent stake goes through.
Proceeds from the placement will be used to partially fund FCT’s acquisition of Frasers Property’s 24.5 per cent stake in retail mall Nex.

krhls31 - Bukit Panjang Plaza

Artist's impression of IMM Building, one of CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust's three properties undergoing asset enhancement initiative works.
The manager attributes the improvement in performance to higher contributions from Raffles City Singapore and full-year contributions from the Reit’s 2022 acquisitions.

site_title: Some Volkswagen cars delayed in US ports over Chinese part
summary: Volkswagen expects to resolve delays in US port deliveries by the end of March due to a customs issue related to a Chinese subcomponent. Approximately 1,000 Porsche sports cars, several hundred Bentleys, and several thousand Audi vehicles were impounded at US ports due to anti-forced labor law breaches. Volkswagen takes allegations seriously and may end supplier relationships if serious violations are confirmed. The issue was discovered in mid-January, and individual customers may face delays until the end of March.

site_title: Blackstone aborts Canary Wharf sale as gloom hangs over area
summary: Blackstone has abandoned plans to sell its Canary Wharf office building, Cargo, after negotiations with an Asian investor collapsed due to concerns about the future of the district. The private equity firm, which purchased the building for £165 million in 2014, expects to hold on to the building until sentiment improves. Fears about the future of Canary Wharf, following major occupiers like HSBC and Clifford Chance moving to central locations, have discouraged investors from buying even long-leased buildings.

images.alt_text: Blackstone’s decision comes after a ramping up of protests against private equity involvement in the sport’s top league, the Bundesliga, at the weekend.
Crown Resorts has faced years of regulatory challenges, including a royal commission in Victoria around money-laundering charges.
L’Occitane’s enterprise value was about 10 times its estimated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation at Monday’s close.
The Blackstone headquarters in New York, US, on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024. Blackstone Inc. released earnings figures on January 25. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: Meta adds exec from key chip partner to board
summary: Meta Platforms added Broadcom CEO Tan Hock to its board of directors, bringing on a key partner in its chip development and data centre ambitions. The move comes as the technology to create chips that move and crunch data quickly becomes a key battleground for AI systems. Meta spent around $500 million on components and design services from Broadcom in 2023. Tan's appointment follows the addition of John Arnold, a former energy trading executive, to the board. The partnership highlights the growing importance of custom chips in AI development.

images.alt_text: The European Commission has said the Digital Services Act (DSA) levy applies to 20 very large online platforms, including Meta, Google, Apple and TikTok and two very large online search engines.
The approach builds off a template established over the past decade by some of the same companies to coordinate the removal of banned content across platforms.

site_title: Singtel Innov8 sells entire stake in Vizzio to embattled founder
summary: Singtel Innov8, a Singapore-based venture capital firm, has sold its entire 80 preference shares in Vizzio Technologies to the company's founder Jon Lee. This move removes the S$1 million in paid-up share capital injected by Singtel Innov8. The sale comes after a series of exposés on Lee's claims, including faking his doctorate degree. The transaction marks a significant development in the embattled AI firm's history, which has seen the resignation of a board member and the appointment of an interim CEO.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, Keppel, Kore, Civmec
summary: Thai Beverage's sales revenue fell 5.9% to 76.1 billion baht in the first quarter, driven by a 14% decline in beer segment revenue. Keppel was appointed to design and operate a solar PV system at Changi Airport, marking the largest single-site rooftop solar PV system in Singapore. Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posted a 10.1% fall in distributable income, while Civmec saw a 12.9% increase in net profit to A$31.9 million for the first half.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to cut several hundred jobs in wealth unit
summary: Morgan Stanley plans to cut several hundred jobs in its wealth-management business, affecting less than 1% of employees, as the firm aims to reduce expenses amid a slump in fees. The cuts come after the bank's shares have declined 10% this year and the company warned that it will take longer to achieve its profit-margin goals. The move is the first major restructuring under new CEO Ted Pick, who has vowed to grow the wealth segment.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley’s net income falls to US$1.5 billion, or 85 cents per diluted share, in the three months ended Dec 31.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit plunges nearly 40% to all-time low on shock distribution suspension
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (Kore) suspended distributions for two years following a significant decline in portfolio valuation and rising leverage. The Reit's units plummeted 39.2% to an all-time low, with the counter trading at US$0.154. To maintain performance and occupancy, the manager requires continued capital investments, and divestments or an equity fundraising may not be sufficient to address leverage concerns. The decision was made unanimously by the sponsors and board, and the manager expects capital expenditures of around US$60 million in 2024 and US$50 million in 2025.

site_title: Potential for insects not just as food for the table but also in supplements and feed
summary: The Singapore Food Agency has extended its deadline to approve 16 species of insects for human consumption to the first half of 2024. This move comes as the insect farming industry shifts focus to producing insect-derived ingredients for health supplements and animal feed, driven by increasing demand for alternative proteins. Companies like Insectta, which started as a black soldier fly farm in Singapore, are exploring these new markets. The extension allows for more time to develop and refine insect-based products, potentially paving the way for their use in various industries.

images.alt_text: With lagging consumer acceptance casting doubt on the viability of the industry, Insectta turned to extracting biomaterials from black soldier flies for use in pharmaceuticals and electronics.

site_title: Manulife beats profit estimates on strong Asia, Canada performance
summary: Manulife Financial, Canada's largest insurer, beat quarterly earnings estimates with strong performance in its Canadian and Asia units. The company's Asia segment rose 11% and Canada's premium equivalent increased 44%, driven by group insurance sales. Manulife also reshaped its portfolio, signing a $10 billion reinsurance deal last year, and announced a 9.6% dividend increase. Core earnings rose to $1.77 billion, beating analyst forecasts, and the company's total investment income increased to $7.2 billion.

images.alt_text: The transaction is expected to be completed in the first half of next year, subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: WeWork seeks fresh cash with bankruptcy at ‘critical juncture’
summary: WeWork, a struggling co-working giant, is seeking fresh financing to pay rent on office spaces used by its customers while exiting bankruptcy. The company needs funds mainly to pay rent, as it deliberates which buildings to keep and shed as part of its Chapter 11 reorganisation. WeWork has denied allegations of withholding rent from landlords, arguing they can be paid using letters of credit and surety bonds. The company has made progress in landlord negotiations, but holdouts refuse to compromise. WeWork's bankruptcy plan, which unveiled earlier this month, proposes senior lenders will own the company after it emerges from bankruptcy.

images.alt_text: Under Neumann, WeWork grew to be the most valuable US startup worth US$47 billion.
WeWork expanded at breakneck speed but racked up losses on its long-term lease obligations as more people began working from home during the pandemic and demand for office space plunged.
The deal with 1440 Broadway allows WeWork to maintain a foothold in a New York City building that’s in the heart of Times Square.

site_title: BOE governor encouraged by latest UK inflation data
summary: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey expressed encouragement over the latest UK inflation data, which showed consumer prices rose 4% in the 12 months to January, slightly smaller than the BOE's forecast. Bailey noted that the data left inflation broadly in line with expectations and pointed to early signs of a pick-up in the economy. However, he emphasized that services inflation remained too high to meet the BOE's 2% target, and rate-setters need more clear evidence of wage growth decline before cutting interest rates.

site_title: Renault posts lower-than-expected full-year profit, ups dividend
summary: Renault reported a slightly lower-than-expected full-year 2023 net profit of €2.315 billion, despite a 9% growth in global sales volumes. The company's operating margin rose to 7.9%, up from 5.5% in 2022, and it expects a margin of around 7.5% in 2024. Renault also increased its dividend to 1.85 euros, citing a stronger cash position and margin growth. The company's turnaround under CEO Luca de Meo appears to be bearing fruit, with plans to launch 10 new electric models this year.

The sale will be implemented as part of a share buyback programme announced by Nissan, and is to be executed on Wednesday, Renault says.

site_title: Y Combinator seeks startups in robotics, space and defence
summary: Y Combinator, a prominent Silicon Valley startup accelerator, has released a new list of 20 startup sectors it wants to join its program, including robotics, space, and defense technology. The list, which represents the biggest overhaul since 2018, highlights areas like machine learning in robotics, AI-powered simulations, and new space companies. Y Combinator believes robotics is close to its "GPT moment" with advancements in AI enabling human-level perception and judgment, and is also focusing on defense technology due to the US's increasing involvement in large-scale conflicts.

images.alt_text: While Indonesia has produced unicorns in the past, the startup ecosystem has its share of weaknesses, says the Asian Development Bank.
Avepoint chief executive Jiang Tianyi believes that a Spac offers more certainty around the amount of capital raised for the company, but more can be done to improve the Spac framework.

site_title: Nvidia outstrips Alphabet as third largest US company by market value
summary: Nvidia surpassed Alphabet as the third-largest US company by market value, with its stock rising 231% in the past 12 months to reach $1.812 trillion. Strong demand for its AI computing chips drove the surge, with Wall Street expecting $11.38 billion in fourth-quarter profit and revenue to surge three-fold. Nvidia now trades at 33.19 times its forward earnings estimates, indicating its stock may have priced in earnings potential, leaving little room for further growth.

site_title: Australia’s Telstra trims FY earnings view; first-half profit rises
summary: Telstra, Australia's top telecom firm, trimmed its FY earnings forecast due to weak performance in its network applications and services segment. Despite this, the company reported an 11% jump in first-half profit to A$964 million, driven by strong performance in its mobile, fixed line, and infrastructure segments. Telstra now expects underlying operating earnings of A$8.2-8.3 billion, down from the prior range of A$8.2-8.4 billion. The company also declared an interim dividend of 9 Australian cents per share. Telstra aims to achieve its cost-cutting ambitions by the end of FY25.

images.alt_text: Telstra chairman John Mullen will retire at the conclusion of this year’s annual meeting on Oct 17.

site_title: Uber unveils US$7 billion share buyback after first profitable year
summary: Uber has announced a US$7 billion share buyback program, marking its first-ever share repurchase initiative. The move comes after the company posted its first annual net profit in 2023, driven by strong recovery in ride-share and food delivery demand. Uber expects gross bookings growth of 15-20% and adjusted core profit growth of 33-40% over the next three years, with free cash flow projected to be 90% or higher annually. The company's shares rose 5% following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore upgrades 2024 NODX forecast to growth of 4 to 6%
summary: Singapore has upgraded its 2024 forecast for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) to modest growth of 4-6% year on year, compared to November's forecast of 2-4%. This follows a 2023 decline of 11.7% year on year, driven by drops in both oil and non-oil trade. The country maintains its forecast for total merchandise trade growth of 4-6% in 2024, with a projected global economic activity growth of 3.1% and higher world trade volume growth.

images.alt_text: EnterpriseSG expects trade performance to xxx in 2024.

site_title: Budget 2024 should keep cost-of-living handouts targeted to avoid fuelling inflation
summary: The government of Singapore is considering targeted cost-of-living handouts in the upcoming Budget 2024 to avoid fueling inflation. Indiscriminate handouts could exacerbate demand-pull inflation, where consumer demand outpaces supply. To mitigate this risk, the government should focus on providing help to lower-income groups and areas with inelastic demand, such as cash rebates for school fees and public transport vouchers. This targeted approach would help keep inflation in check while aligning with the government's commitment to fiscal prudence and progressivity.

site_title: Keppel to build 43 MWp solar PV system at Changi Airport
summary: Keppel has been appointed to design, build, and operate a 43 MWp solar PV system at Changi Airport for 25 years. The system, set to be completed in early 2025, will generate enough solar energy to power over 10,000 flats annually and reduce the airport's carbon emissions by 20,000 tonnes per year. The rooftop and airfield solar PV systems will be integrated with Keppel's operations center, allowing for real-time monitoring and maintenance.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah
solar, panels, solar energy
More than 160 automated lanes were installed in 2023, with another 230 lanes to be set up in 2024.

site_title: US 30-year mortgage rate climbs to a two-month high of 6.87%
summary: US 30-year mortgage rates have reached a two-month high of 6.87%, up 7 basis points from the previous week, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This increase reverses some of the momentum in the nation's housing recovery and is unwelcome news for the resale market, where low inventory and many homeowners are locked into low mortgage rates. Mortgage applications fell 2.5% last week, a five-week low, and borrowing costs are expected to remain elevated until further progress is made in bringing inflation closer to the Federal Reserve's goal.

images.alt_text: Mortgage rates that are down more than a percentage point from recent highs have perked up the housing market.

site_title: Singapore’s 2023 GDP growth revised down marginally to 1.1%; 2024 forecast kept at 1 to 3%
summary: Singapore's 2023 GDP growth has been revised down to 1.1% from the initial estimate of 1.2%, marking a marginal decrease. The fourth-quarter GDP growth was also revised down to 2.2% year-on-year, lower than the initial estimate of 2.8%. The forecast for 2024 remains unchanged at 1-3%. The downward revision is attributed to the moderation in fourth-quarter growth, but still indicates a stable economy.

images.alt_text: Singapore's economy is expected to grow by 1 to 3 per cent in 2024, according to MTI.
“Barring any further global shocks, the Singapore economy is expected to strengthen in 2024, with growth becoming more broad-based,” MAS says.

site_title: Total amount invested in Bitcoin back over US$1 trillion
summary: Bitcoin's market capitalization surpassed $1 trillion for the first time since November 2021, reaching $1.005 trillion, after a 20% rise since the start of February. The token's price reached $51,694, its 25-month high, driven by strong inflows to US spot Bitcoin ETFs, which increased to $1.64 billion in the week to February 14. Analysts predict further price rises if inflows continue, with one saying "large inflows will be met by further price rises for spot Bitcoin."

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has tripled since the start of last year in a comeback from the 2022 digital-asset rout.
Representation of Bitcoin cryptocurrency is seen in this illustration taken January 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Wall St opens higher after selloff as traders reassess rate bets
summary: Wall Street opened higher on February 14, 2024, after a selloff in the previous session, as traders reassessed rate bets following a hot inflation report. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.47% and 0.81%, respectively, while the Dow Jones rose 0.26%. The market recovery came ahead of the Federal Reserve's first interest-rate cut this year, with investors reevaluating their bets on rate changes.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce back after inflation report sell-off
summary: US stocks rebounded on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.4% at 38,424.27, the S&P 500 gaining 1.0% to 5,000.62, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.3% to 15,859.15. The rally followed a sell-off on Tuesday after inflation data showed a higher-than-expected rate, prompting analysts to push back interest rate cut expectations. Individual stocks such as Lyft and Uber also rose, while Kraft Heinz fell 5.5% due to declining revenues.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 1, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: US producer prices revised lower in December
summary: US producer prices dropped 0.2% in December, revised from the initial 0.1% decline. The revised data, released by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, was due to recalculating seasonal adjustment factors and updating weights in the Producer Price Index (PPI) basket. The annual data remained unrevised, showing a year-on-year decline. The revision resulted from a routine procedure to strip out seasonal fluctuations from the data, which is undertaken annually by the BLS.

site_title: That influencer tip? Probably an ad in disguise, EU finds
summary: The European Union has found that 97% of social media influencers publish posts with commercial content, but only 20% disclose it as advertising. The EU launched a probe into influencer marketing, which has generated a global total of around $29 billion last year, and found that 119 influencers promoted unhealthy or hazardous activities. The EU's justice commissioner calls on influencers to be more transparent, and the bloc is weighing its action, including considering an ethical code or label for influencers.

images.alt_text: TikTok's "election centres" are designed to better inform Europeans about the electoral process.

site_title: Cisco to lay off 5% of workforce, cuts annual revenue forecast
summary: Cisco Systems plans to cut 5% of its global workforce, approximately 4,250 employees, primarily in the third quarter of fiscal 2024. The company also lowered its annual revenue forecast to $51.5 billion to $52.5 billion, down from the previously estimated $53.8 billion to $55 billion. The job cuts and revenue reduction are aimed at focusing on high-growth areas such as artificial intelligence and software. Cisco's shares fell 5% in extended trading following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Cisco has in recent years grappled with supply chain issues and a post-pandemic slowdown in demand, which has hastened its push into software offerings such as cybersecurity.
Cisco’s report shows that slowing orders for networking hardware are taking their toll on growth.
Cisco offers US$157 in cash for each share of Splunk, representing a 31 per cent premium to the company’s last closing price.

site_title: Oil falls by more than US$1 a barrel on US crude build, security threat worries
summary: Oil prices fell by more than $1 a barrel on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures settling at $81.60 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures at $76.64 a barrel. The decline was driven by a 12 million-barrel increase in US crude inventories, exceeding analysts' expectations. Additionally, concerns about a possible security threat to the US, which could dampen oil demand, contributed to the price drop.

images.alt_text: An idled oil pumping unit in Cabimas, on the East coast of Lake Maracaibo, Venezuela, is illuminated by the morning light Friday January 3, 2002.
