site_title: Here’s how to name your AI chatbot
summary: Google has rebranded its AI-powered chatbot as Gemini, replacing Bard, in an effort to signal a departure from naming AI assistants after themselves. The name change comes after Microsoft integrated OpenAI's technology into its products and opted for the name Copilot. The article suggests that a good name for an AI should evoke a sense of sophistication, safety, and friendliness, while also being easy to pronounce and remember. Some experts propose names like Gary, which has a solid hard "G" and is associated with helpful and creative individuals.

images.alt_text: A logo of Google is seen on its office building in Hyderabad, India, January 29, 2024. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas

site_title: Doing business in Niseko
summary: Niseko, a popular ski resort town in Hokkaido, has become a hub for Singaporean entrepreneurs, with several familiar business names operating there, including SC Global and Nylon Coffee. This "Singapore wave" has led to the opening of new restaurants, such as Roketto by chef Willin Low, serving modern Singaporean cuisine. The town's high concentration of Singaporeans has also inspired other entrepreneurs to set up shop, capitalizing on the demand for Singaporean-style businesses in the resort town.

site_title: Greenback rises as hot US inflation cools Fed rate-cut bets
summary: The US dollar rose to a three-month high against major peers as traders pushed back bets for a Federal Reserve interest rate cut following hot US inflation figures. The US Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 3.1% in January, beating expectations, and money markets now price in no March Fed cut and a 53% chance of a June cut. This has made dollar strength more durable, and risks of rate cuts from the Swiss National Bank and European Central Bank ahead of the Fed could gain traction.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has risen around 20 per cent since the start of February, already set for its biggest monthly rise since October.
Derivatives traded volume in January 2023 reaches the highest since March 2022.

site_title: Volkswagen in talks with JV partner over future of Xinjiang site
summary: Volkswagen is in talks with its joint venture partner SAIC-Volkswagen over the future of its business activities in Xinjiang province after a German newspaper reported evidence of the carmaker's involvement in forced labor. Independent researcher Adrian Zenz found photos and statements indicating Uygur workers were employed to construct a test track under poverty alleviation programs. Volkswagen denied previous knowledge of human rights abuses and said it would consider different scenarios for its presence in Xinjiang.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen says to launch over 20 electric vehicle models in China

site_title: Visa halts intermediated commercial card payments in India after regulatory order
summary: Visa, the world's largest payments processor, has halted intermediated commercial card payments in India after receiving a directive from the Reserve Bank of India. The RBI directed Visa to stop domestic transactions for business payment solution providers, which facilitate business-to-business card payments made to non-card-accepting vendors. Visa did not disclose the reason behind the RBI's directive and is in discussions with the regulator and its partners to ensure compliance. This move affects only intermediated card payments, not all commercial card payments.

images.alt_text: Earlier in February, the Enforcement Directorate had started a probe into Paytm on suspicion of violation of foreign exchange rules.

site_title: Microsoft says it caught hackers from China, Russia and Iran using its AI tools
summary: Microsoft has announced a blanket ban on state-backed hacking groups using its AI products, following a report that tracked hackers from China, Russia, and Iran using Microsoft-backed OpenAI tools to hone their skills and trick targets. The hackers, affiliated with Russian military intelligence, Iran's Revolutionary Guard, and the Chinese and North Korean governments, used large language models to research military operations, generate spear-phishing campaigns, and write convincing emails. Microsoft Vice President for Customer Security Tom Burt stated that the company does not want threat actors to have access to the technology, citing concerns over its deployment and potential for abuse.

images.alt_text: According to the Washington Post, the companies will agree to develop ways to identify, label and control AI-generated images, videos and audio that aim to deceive voters.

site_title: UK house prices post first rise in four months
summary: UK house prices rose 0.1% to £284,691 in December, marking the first increase in four months, according to official data. Despite a 1.4% decline in the 12 months to December, the market is expected to rebound, driven by decreasing mortgage rates and increased buyer demand. Industry data suggests prices may have turned the corner after a cooling in mortgage rates and speculation over rate cuts in 2024.

site_title: German auto supplier Continental says to cut 7,150 jobs
summary: German auto supplier Continental plans to cut 7,150 jobs worldwide by 2025 due to the shift to electric vehicles. The company aims to save 400 million euros through cost-cutting measures, including shedding 1,750 research and development positions and 5,400 other roles. Continental currently employs around 200,000 people globally.

site_title: Third time’s the charm: Prabowo claims victory in Indonesia presidential election
summary: Indonesian Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto claimed victory in the country's presidential election, securing the top spot for the first time after two previous losses. With an unofficial "quick count" showing him ahead of rivals Anies Baswedan and Ganjar Pranowo, Prabowo declared victory in a packed arena in Jakarta, stating it was a win for all Indonesians. The results follow a third attempt by the 72-year-old politician.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s presidential election, with more than 200 million of the 270 million population eligible to vote, is the world’s biggest single-day election.

Officials unload ballot boxes in Jakarta, Indonesia, Feb 9, 2024. Nearly 259,000 candidates are contesting 20,600 posts across the archipelago of 17,000 islands in the world’s biggest single-day election.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, February 14, 2024 (Ep 1)
summary: Asian stocks fell on February 14, 2024, due to persistent US inflation, while investors watched Indonesia's polls. The Singapore shares declined 1.2% at the open, following a similar trend in the US, where stocks fell as inflation remained higher than expected.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 97 to 22 after 71.9 million securities worth S$108.7 million change hands.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished  1.4 per cent lower at 38,272.75 on Tuesday, retreating from Monday’s record.

site_title: Civmec H1 earnings up 12.9%, declares dividend of A$0.025 per share
summary: Civmec, an Australian engineering and construction company, reported a 12.9% increase in net profit to A$31.9 million for the first half of 2024, driven by higher revenue. The company completed key projects, including the Iron Bridge Magnetite Project and a maintenance facility, and strengthened its balance sheet. An interim dividend of A$0.025 per share was declared, up from A$0.02 per share. The company's order book remains above A$1 billion, demonstrating its ability to secure multiple contracts.

images.alt_text: Patrick Tallon, Civmec CEO.
Civmec highlighted that its order book remained healthy at over A$1.1 billion as at Sep 30, an increase of 17.9 per cent year-on-year.
Civmec said that the improved performance came on the back of increased gross margins in the period.

site_title: Boeing wins orders for at least 45 aircraft from Thai Airways
summary: Boeing secured an order for at least 45 aircraft from Thai Airways International, adding to its growing orderbook following a deal with Akasa Air for 150 Max jets. The order includes an option to purchase more and will be powered by General Electric engines. The deal comes as Boeing faces scrutiny over its manufacturing following an Alaska Airlines accident earlier this year. Thai Airways' order is seen as a boost for Boeing, which has recently locked in deals with Akasa Air and Airbus has secured deals with Delta and Ethiopian Airlines.

site_title: German investment in China rises to record high
summary: German direct investment in China rose to a record high of 11.9 billion euros (S$17.2 billion) in 2023, a 4.3% increase from the previous year. Despite government pleas to reduce exposure, German firms continue to invest heavily, with some withdrawing capital and others seeking to exit the Chinese market. The proportion of German firms exiting the Chinese market has more than doubled to 9% in the last four years. This poses a dilemma for Chancellor Olaf Scholz's coalition government, with politicians divided over how much to reduce the risk of exposure to China.

site_title: Shareholders, Sias raise concerns over Chemical Industries’ C-suite resignations, alleged ‘post-retirement perks’
summary: Shareholders of Chemical Industries (Far East) have raised concerns over the company's senior management resignations, including the CEO and COO, who both served for less than a year. The group also criticized the nomination of Lim Yew Nghee, the son of co-founder Lim Soo Peng, as deputy chairman. They alleged that the company spent money on "post-retirement perks" for Lim Soo Peng and requested disclosure of the amount spent. The minority shareholders also expressed disappointment at the company's bottom-line shrinking over the past two years, with a net loss of S$1.6 million in the first half of 2024.

site_title: ABN Amro announces 500 million euro buyback as profit jumps
summary: ABN Amro Bank has announced a 500 million euro share buyback, joining a string of European banks repurchasing billions of euros to boost low valuations. The Dutch state will receive 200 million euros from the buyback. Net income rose 54% to 545 million euros, beating analyst expectations, driven by falling credit provisions. However, costs are expected to rise to 5.3 billion euros in the current year, and the bank's return on equity target for 2026 is set at 9-10%, significantly lower than last year's rate.

site_title: Jennifer Lopez launches 'This Is Me...Now' with Affleck by her side
summary: Jennifer Lopez has launched her new movie "This Is Me...Now: A Love Story" and album of the same name, exploring her experiences of love and relationships. The musical film premiered in Hollywood, where Lopez walked the carpet with her husband, actor-director Ben Affleck. Lopez stated that she aims to grow as a person and artist by being more vulnerable and honest in her work, with the movie and album serving as a reflection of her personal journey.

site_title: UK inflation weaker than forecast in relief for BOE policymakers
summary: The UK's inflation rate came in lower than forecast in January, with consumer prices rising 4% compared to the previous year, matching December's pace. This is a relief for Bank of England policymakers, who had expected a higher rate. Services inflation accelerated to 6.5%, but officials are cautious about easing interest rates amid tight labor market and signs of a recovering economy. British finance minister Jeremy Hunt stated that the government has made "huge progress" in bringing down inflation from 11% to around 2% in a few months.

images.alt_text: The unemployment rate fell to 3.8 per cent from 3.9 per cent in the three months to the end of November.

Office workers cross London Bridge into The City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. site_title: Nokia unveils AI assistant for industrial workers
summary: Nokia has unveiled an AI-powered tool called "MX Workmate" to assist industrial workers. The tool generates human-like text to provide warnings about faulty machinery, recommended actions for repairs, and solutions to boost production quality. Compliant with operational technology regulations, the tool is designed to help workers make sense of data from machine sensors. Nokia plans to roll out the tool as manufacturers face a shortage of qualified staff, with initial implementations expected in a year or more.

site_title: Indonesian voters greeted with chocolates, candy on Valentine’s Day
summary: Indonesian voters were greeted with chocolates and candy on Valentine's Day as they cast ballots in the country's massive presidential election. With over 200 million eligible voters, the election is the world's largest single-day poll. Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto, a 72-year-old former special forces commander, is the frontrunner to succeed popular President Joko Widodo. The election will determine the future of Indonesia, the world's third-largest democracy and most populous Muslim-majority country, with nearly 259,000 candidates vying for 20,600 posts.

images.alt_text: Officials unload ballot boxes in Jakarta, Indonesia, Feb 9, 2024. Nearly 259,000 candidates are contesting 20,600 posts across the archipelago of 17,000 islands in the world’s biggest single-day election.
The three men looking to succeed Widodo for the next five years are (from left) Prabowo Subianto, Ganjar Pranowo and Anies Baswedan.
The US presidential elections, where former president Donald Trump is a likely candidate, will be the most consequential election for global investors this year.
Ahead of Indonesia’s Polling Day on February 14, a mandatory cooling-off period will be held from February 11 to 13.

site_title: Sony, Honda EV venture to roll out three models before 2030
summary: Sony Honda Mobility, a joint venture between Sony and Honda, plans to roll out three electric vehicle models by the end of the decade. The models include a sports utility vehicle in 2027, a compact in 2028 or later, and a sedan scheduled for launch in 2025. The venture aims to compete with Tesla, leveraging Honda's engineering expertise and Sony's software and gaming expertise. The company has already announced plans to start selling a sedan under the "Afeela" brand name in North America by early 2026.

images.alt_text: Sony Corp's Vision-S Prototype vehicle is displayed at its headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo

site_title: TikTok to ramp up fight against fake news, covert influence ahead of EU elections
summary: TikTok plans to increase efforts to combat fake news and covert influence ahead of the European Parliament elections in June. The company will launch local language "election centres" in all 27 EU countries, providing trusted information on the electoral process. TikTok also plans to expand its fact-checking network and introduce media literacy campaigns. The move comes as governments and politicians worldwide are concerned about the spread of misinformation and its impact on elections. The company aims to increase transparency and accountability.

images.alt_text: The video posted by the Biden-Harris HQ TikTok account shows US President Joe Biden answering rapid fire questions.
Team GB's commercial director Tim Ellerton says the deal with TikTok is “a valuable opportunity to introduce a new generation to the magic of the Olympic Games”.
More investigations are likely to be added as the EU has been quizzing all designated firms for more information over the last few months.

(FILES) This picture taken on April 26, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a screen displaying the Tiktok social media platform's logo and the European flag. Tech giants Meta and TikTok are contesting the scope of an EU law that from March will set new rules on competition in the digital marketplace. The European Commission has designated 22 big online companies as "core platform services" to be subject to additional scrutiny and obligations under the Digital Markets Act (DMA) aiming to crack down on anti-competitive practices. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)

site_title: UniCredit set to boost bonus pool by 16% after record year
summary: UniCredit is set to boost its bonus pool by 16% after posting a record profit and increasing shareholder returns. The average bonus gain per person will be higher, ranging from 9% to 27% depending on countries, businesses, and relative performance. Lower-ranking employees can expect larger gains than top executives as part of the bank's commitment to rewarding front-line staff.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Unicredit bank logo is seen on a banner downtown Milan, Italy, May 23, 2016. REUTERS/Stefano Rellandini/File Photo

site_title: ThaiBev Q1 Ebitda up 1.9% to 13.8 billion baht despite lower beer sales hitting revenue
summary: ThaiBev's Q1 revenue fell 5.9% to 76.1 billion baht due to lower beer sales, but its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) rose 1.9% to 13.8 billion baht. The company's beer segment revenue declined 14% to 32.6 billion baht, while its spirits business revenue inched up 0.5% to 33.9 billion baht. Non-alcoholic beverages and food business revenue also increased, with Ebitda growth in all segments despite the revenue decline, and the company's financial position remaining robust with strong free cash flow.

images.alt_text: FPL did not comment on news reports of a deal, or its surging share price, until the end of last week
Coca-Cola has been making acquisitions to help it diversify away from sugary drinks.

site_title: Central banks’ 2% inflation target is not the finish line
summary: Central banks' 2% inflation target is not the end goal, but rather a starting point to achieve a stable economy where workers and producers forget about inflation. Recent data shows that inflation has fallen in the US and eurozone, but the services sector remains plagued by inflationary pressures. Energy prices, which were initially attributed to supply chain disruptions and the pandemic, have declined, but services prices have continued to rise. This suggests that inflation is not solely caused by external factors, but also by underlying wage rigidity and rational inattention. Central banks must focus on keeping inflation stable, not just reaching the 2% target, to achieve their goal.

images.alt_text: The most commonly cited factor driving the recent surge in inflation is high energy prices. But by early 2023, crude oil prices had fallen back to pre-Ukraine war levels.
While the euro has delivered on some of its promises -- notably, maintaining price stability -- it has failed to facilitate the continent’s economic and political integration.

A vendor sells fruits and vegetables in New York on Dec 21, 2023. The US personal consumption expenditures index ticked up in December to 2.9 per cent, within distance of the Fed's comfort level of 2 per cent annual inflation.

site_title: Thai couples marry on elephants for Valentine's Day
summary: In Thailand, nine couples exchanged vows on Valentine's Day in a unique mass wedding featuring elephants. The ceremony took place at the Nong Nooch Tropical Garden in Chonburi province, where couples rode elephants while wearing traditional dress. The event reflects Thailand's long association with elephants, which are considered a symbol of national prosperity and good fortune. The couples signed their marriage licenses in front of a district official, also seated on an elephant, marking a special and memorable day for the newlyweds.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s presidential election, with more than 200 million of the 270 million population eligible to vote, is the world’s biggest single-day election.

site_title: India agency seeks overseas transaction details from Paytm Payments Bank: sources
summary: India's Enforcement Directorate is seeking overseas transaction details from Paytm Payments Bank, a unit of One 97 Communications, amid a probe into suspected foreign exchange rule violations. The agency had initiated an investigation earlier this month, following a central bank order to wind down the bank's business due to supervisory concerns. Paytm has lost nearly 55% of its market value since the order, with shares falling 10% on February 14. The investigation is described as a preliminary examination, with no immediate response from Paytm or the Enforcement Directorate.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall after US inflation dashes Fed rate-cut hopes; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% on Wednesday, closing at 3,139.07, as the US inflation rate for January surpassed expectations, dashing hopes of a Federal Reserve rate cut. The Straits Times Index (STI) declined despite gains from Singapore Airlines, which rose 0.7% to S$7.14. Banking stocks traded mixed, with DBS and UOB increasing, while Rex International fell 11.1% to S$0.128 due to a preliminary report of a net loss for FY2023.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks were in retreat as the Hang Seng reopened after an extended break for the Lunar New Year.

site_title: BlackRock’s ESG fund business soars despite attacks by US Republicans
summary: BlackRock's ESG fund business continues to expand despite US Republican attacks, posting net ESG inflows every quarter for two years. The asset manager's ESG-related assets under management grew 53% from 2022 to 2023, surpassing the wider ESG fund market's 8% growth. BlackRock now oversees $320 billion of ESG funds, more than any other firm globally. Despite ESG backlash in the US, BlackRock has seen significant inflows, with $4.7 billion in net inflows last quarter, driven by its European business and index-tracking strategies.

images.alt_text: Global ESG exchange-traded funds are slightly outperforming benchmark indexes this year, according to Bloomberg data.
The popularity asset pricing model incorporates different capital market expectations and individual preferences beyond risk tolerance.

site_title: Shell expects 50% rise in global LNG demand by 2040
summary: Shell expects a 50% rise in global liquefied natural gas (LNG) demand by 2040, driven by growing demand in China and Southeast Asia. The company attributes the tight supply and high prices to LNG, which is maintaining prices and price volatility above historic averages. China is expected to dominate LNG demand growth this decade, as the industry seeks to reduce carbon emissions by switching from coal to gas. The global LNG market is projected to reach 625-685 million tons per year in 2040, with a significant role for gas in reducing carbon emissions and local air pollution.

site_title: Alibaba seeks Middle East partners as Beijing deepens Gulf ties
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has sought partnerships with local firms in Saudi Arabia and the UAE, as China deepens ties with the Gulf region. Alibaba's president, Michael Evans, stated that partnering with local firms allows for tighter integration in the dialogue about market developments. This move comes after Alibaba faced years of government punishment and strategic missteps, prompting co-founder Jack Ma to urge the company to correct its course. The partnership is part of China's efforts to expand its global influence and diversify its economy away from hydrocarbons.

site_title: Every corporation needs a Marie Kondo
summary: A growing number of companies are adopting an annual "spring cleaning" ritual to prune bureaucratic clutter and improve employee morale. The practice, inspired by Marie Kondo's tidying philosophy, involves employees suggesting ways to reduce unnecessary tasks and meetings. While top-down initiatives have failed to sustain change, a ritualized approach that empowers employees to take the lead could lead to lasting improvements. Studies show that managerial clutter wastes time and degrades morale, with only a third of employees fully engaged in their work.

images.alt_text: Don't let a cluttered work desk mess up your career
Kondo eyes tidying up your work arena too

site_title: In Tokyo, world's first sovereign transition bonds make their debut
summary: Japan auctioned its first sovereign climate transition bonds, raising 800 billion yen (S$7.17 billion) in 10-year bonds to fund environmental shifts. The bonds, priced at 0.74% yield, were met with slightly weaker-than-expected demand. The proceeds will support projects like low-cost wind power generators and alternative fuel airplanes. This is part of Japan's plan to sell 20 trillion yen of climate bonds over the next decade to achieve its goal of cutting greenhouse gases to zero by 2050.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023. The expansion of Israel’s ground operations in Gaza added more pressure to global markets as investors prepare for a busy week packed with major central bank decisions and a high-stakes announcement of US bond sales. site_title: Amid funding crunch, smaller Indonesia startups face hard decision to sell or shut down
summary: Indonesian startups face a funding crunch, with smaller ones considering selling to larger tech companies or shutting down due to cash flow issues. Industry insiders report an increase in startups selling their businesses, with larger players like Bukalapak and GoTo acquiring them. However, available capital remains, with venture capital firms holding a record amount of dry powder but changing risk appetites, requiring startups to demonstrate monetization models and clear exit pathways. Analysts suggest that sectors like agritech and B2B startups may appeal to VCs as the market landscape shifts.

images.alt_text: Grab and GoTo have held on-and-off talks to combine without success in the past, after years of fierce competition in ride-hailing, food delivery and financial technology.
The acquisition of Singlife by Sumitomo Life is just one of many deals Japanese corporates in South-east Asia, with their banks looking to leverage their low cost of funds.
A shot of Jakarta's skyline. The total venture capital deal value for Indonesia is expected to decline by up to 80 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 14)
summary: Singapore's economy grew 4.4% in 2024, surpassing the advance estimate of 4%, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The country's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 0.2% in 2024, reversing from the 13.1% contraction in the previous year. The growth forecast for 2025 remains unchanged at 1 to 3%. Meanwhile, Malaysia's economy expanded 5.1% in 2024, exceeding the official forecast. Geopolitical concerns are affecting pre-IPO activity and M&As involving Chinese firms, citing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: India’s seven days of love sees young people spending millions on Valentine’s gifts
summary: India's "Valentine's Week" has seen a surge in spending among young adults, with millions spent on gifts, dining, and experiences. E-commerce platforms and dating sites are promoting romantic products, leading to record sales of roses, chocolates, and teddy bears. Indian gifting platforms and food delivery platforms report significant increases in sales, with FNP.com delivering 350 roses per minute and Zomato's Blinkit dispatching 406 chocolates per minute. The trend is driven by India's growing middle class, particularly young adults, who prioritize experiences over practical purchases.

site_title: Why Biden should talk up economic success
summary: US President Joe Biden should claim credit for the country's successful economy, despite some pundits advising against it. The US economy has experienced an extraordinary year, with inflation plummeting and real GDP rising 3.1%. Despite this, consumer sentiment remains somewhat depressed, with Republicans viewing the economy unfavorably and Democrats' perceptions being more responsive to economic conditions. However, surveys show that persuadable voters are aware of the economy's improvement, and President Biden should acknowledge this success to boost his credibility.

images.alt_text: The percentage of US adults in their prime working years participating in the labour force is now at its highest level in 20 years.
Traders previously betting on a rate cut at the Federal Reserve's Apr 30-May 1 meeting now see June as more likely.

site_title: Morningstar appoints South-east Asia managing director in newly created role
summary: Morningstar appoints Shihan Abeyguna as managing director, South-east Asia, a newly created role. Abeyguna will collaborate across the firm's business units to drive growth in the region, further strengthening Morningstar's presence. He has over 15 years of experience with the company, holding leadership roles in product, strategy, and sales. Abeyguna reports to Julie Willoughby, head of global sales, and holds degrees from Grinnell College and the University of Chicago Booth School of Business.

site_title: More firms look for inflation support, green incentives, SkillsFuture credits in Budget this year: UOB survey
summary: A survey by UOB found that 84% of businesses in Singapore are affected by inflation, with the industrials, oil and gas, manufacturing, and engineering sectors being the hardest hit. Businesses are seeking support for inflation, green incentives, and SkillsFuture credits in the upcoming Budget 2024. Specifically, 45% of respondents want government support to cope with high inflation, followed by higher SkillsFuture credits (42%) and incentives to adopt sustainable practices (29%). The survey also highlighted challenges such as increased operating and raw material costs, with smaller businesses facing greater difficulties in managing working capital needs.

images.alt_text: A cornerstone of Singapore’s policies is supporting families, and the government has pledged in the report to provide more assurance for Singaporeans that “they will be taken care of at every life stage as basic needs like education, retirement, healthcare and housing will be met”.

site_title: Seatrium renews ship repair contract for 43 LNG carriers docked in South-east Asia
summary: Seatrium has renewed a five-year contract with GasLog LNG Services and Shell International Trading and Shipping Company to repair, refurbish, and upgrade a combined fleet of 43 liquefied natural gas (LNG) carriers in South-east Asia. The contracts, valued at an undisclosed amount, will run from 2024 to 2029 and support joint planning and environmental sustainability targets. The renewals come weeks after Seatrium announced a similar contract win in Singapore.

site_title: Udders tailors its scoops of ‘Made-in-Singapore’ ice cream for markets abroad
summary: Udders, a Singapore-based ice cream maker, aims to generate 60% of its revenue from overseas sales in the next three to five years. The company, co-founded by husband-and-wife duo Wong Peck Lin and David Yim, currently has five outlets in Singapore and distributes its products through over 400 retail points islandwide. Udders plans to expand into Japan, with a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, following a partnership with Sojitz. The company's targeted approach to overseas expansion is part of its strategy to increase revenue.

images.alt_text: In the lead-up to the Mid-Autumn Festival in September, Golden Moments founder Josiah Seow (right) officially launched the Mao Shan Wang durian snowskin mooncakes in China last August at an offline event. Guangzhou-based Singapore consulate-general Loh Tuck Keat (left) was among the attendees at the event, held in Shenzhen.

site_title: Asia: Stocks tracks Wall Street retreat as US inflation dents rate cut hopes
summary: Asian stocks retreated on Wednesday as the US inflation report dented hopes for an early interest rate cut, tracking a sell-off on Wall Street. The US Dow and S&P 500 fell over 1%, with US Treasury yields jumping and the VIX rising at its fastest clip since October. Expectations for a rate cut have been doused, with the dollar surging against the yen and Japanese officials warning of potential intervention to support the currency.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished  1.4 per cent lower at 38,272.75 on Tuesday, retreating from Monday’s record.
Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 97 to 22 after 71.9 million securities worth S$108.7 million change hands.

site_title: PMO deputy secretary Cindy Khoo appointed new managing director of Enterprise Singapore
summary: Cindy Khoo, deputy secretary of the Prime Minister's Office (PMO), has been appointed as the new managing director of Enterprise Singapore, taking over from Jeffrey Siow on March 1. Khoo will relinquish her PMO role on April 1. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) praised Khoo's leadership experience and expertise in public sector governance, sustainability, and economic issues. Eight current EnterpriseSG board members will step down on March 31, and six new members will join the board on April 1.

images.alt_text: According to UOB's survey, 84 per cent of businesses said they were somewhat or highly affected by inflation, with its effects being most felt in the industrials, oil and gas as well as manufacturing and engineering sectors.

site_title: Wishes for Budget 2024
summary: Trade associations, chambers, and sector-specific observers have submitted suggestions for Singapore's Budget 2024, including new grants for SMEs, risk-sharing for internationalisation, and support for parenthood and caregivers. The labour movement and some observers also call for targeted financial help for seniors and jobless individuals. Property experts advocate for cutting the 15-month waiting period for 'downgraders', tweaking the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD), and reintroducing the estate tax. Prime Minister Lee expects stronger growth in 2024 and more support for parenthood, while PM Wong assures the government's full confidence in the Singapore Times' mission.

site_title: IHH Healthcare’s indirect subsidiary in India cancels IPO plans
summary: IHH Healthcare's indirect subsidiary in India, AGILUS Diagnostics, has cancelled its initial public offering (IPO) plans due to "commercial considerations". The decision was made in consultation with private-equity investors and the boards of directors of Fortis Healthcare and Agilus. The IPO draft red herring prospectus was filed with the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) in September 2023, but will be withdrawn. The company may re-file for an IPO in the future, subject to applicable laws.

site_title: London exhibition celebrates ‘unknown artist’ Yoko Ono
summary: A retrospective exhibition at the Tate Modern in London celebrates the impact of Yoko Ono, a conceptual artist often misunderstood as the wife of John Lennon rather than an artist in her own right. The "Music of the Mind" show runs until September 1 and features 200 works, including installations, videos, and photographs, showcasing Ono's artistic legacy over seven decades. The exhibition aims to vindicate Ono's contributions to contemporary art and culture, highlighting her activism and campaigns for peace.

images.alt_text: Michael Jackson, one of the top-selling artists in pop music, died in 2009, leaving an estate worth hundreds of millions of US dollars but large debts to work out.
Art and sports rarely mix in France. As a rule, the country’s artistic output leans toward intellectualism rather than the virtuosity embodied by high-level athletes.

site_title: Heineken forecasts single digit operating profit growth in 2024
summary: Heineken forecasts single-digit operating profit growth in 2024, ranging from low to high, due to declining beer consumption amid inflation and economic worries. The company expects revenue growth to be balanced between volume and value, with organic revenue growth of 5.3% and operating income of 4.9 billion euros. A wet summer in Europe and dismal conditions in Vietnam and Nigeria have hurt sales, with beer volumes falling 4.7% on an organic basis.

images.alt_text: Bottles of Carlsberg beer on the production line at a facility in Saint Petersburg, Russia. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: The brutal reality of plunging office values is here
summary: US commercial real estate market is experiencing a significant shakeup, with office values plummeting due to soaring interest rates and reduced demand. As of December, offices accounted for 41% of the value of distressed US properties, worth nearly $86 billion. The crisis is expected to spread globally, with potential losses estimated at nearly $1 trillion. Lenders are bracing for bad loans, and some are already trying to offload loan portfolios. The Federal Reserve's end of interest-rate hikes provides more clarity, but widespread concern remains.

site_title: They’re starting a New York ‘housing league’ to promote property development
summary: New York City officials are launching a "housing league" to promote property development, countering the perception that opposing development is a political win. The group, led by Brooklyn Borough President Antonio Reynoso and Manhattan Councilman Erik Bottcher, aims to change the narrative that resisting development drives up rents and home prices. The league's formation comes as the city faces a housing crisis, with Governor Kathy Hochul and Mayor Eric Adams pushing for more housing construction. The group plans to issue statements against anti-development politicians and support pro-development colleagues.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Apartment buildings under construction in the Mott Haven neighborhood of the Bronx on Oct. 7, 2021. More lawmakers have come to agree that more construction is sorely needed to solve a housing crisis.  (Karsten Moran/The New York Times)

site_title: China’s BYD plans new electric vehicle plant in Mexico: Nikkei
summary: China's BYD plans to establish a new electric vehicle factory in Mexico, aiming to become an export hub to the US. The move comes after BYD surpassed Tesla to become the world's top EV maker in sales. BYD is expanding globally, with plans for new plants overseas and expanded Chinese exports. The Mexican plant will be built in northeastern Brazil, where BYD will spend $817 million on an industrial complex. The move could pose a threat to US automakers, with some warning that Chinese cars could "spell doom" for their prospects.

images.alt_text: BYD’s sales, over 80 per cent of them in China, have grown by about one million cars in each of the past two years.
Chinese automobile maker BYD pipped American counterpart Tesla to be the top electric vehicle seller in Singapore in 2023.
China’s customs bureau puts the total exports number at 5.22 million, a huge year-on-year rise of 57 per cent, with one in three fully electric vehicles.

site_title: Zee Entertainment Q3 revenue falls on weak advertising demand
summary: India's Zee Entertainment reported a 3% decrease in third-quarter revenue to 20.5 billion Indian rupees, due to weak advertising demand. The company's expenses rose 5.4% and its profit more than doubled to 585 million rupees. This comes weeks after Sony scrapped its merger with Zee, citing regulatory issues.

images.alt_text: Sony's notice states that Zee "fails to take commercially reasonable" efforts to meet certain financial thresholds, including those related to cash availability.
The termination letter from Sony came after a 30-day grace period ended over the weekend when the two sides could not reach an agreement on a deadline set in late December.
Sony plans to file a termination notice before the extended Jan 20 deadline.
Sony plans to file the termination notice before a Jan 20 extended deadline for closing the deal, saying some of the conditions necessary for the merger have not been met.

site_title: Six government agencies to refund at least S$7.5 million in GST wrongly charged on regulatory fees
summary: Six Singapore government agencies will refund at least S$7.5 million in Goods and Services Tax (GST) to individuals and non-GST registered businesses, totaling about S$1.5 million annually. The agencies mistakenly charged GST on 18 regulatory fees, including administrative fees and application fees, from January 2019. The agencies will refund the GST, with interest of 5.5% per annum, and have already stopped charging GST on the fees as of February 14. The Ministry of Finance will also table legislative amendments to prescribe a list of regulatory fees where GST should not be charged.

images.alt_text: While corporate and personal income tax receipts are higher than in the past as a percentage of government projections, but GST is lagging, say UOB economists.
Analysts expect stamp duty collection and property tax takings to increase for Singapore's full financial year ended March 2024.

site_title: Coca-Cola is among suitors for healthy soda brand Poppi
summary: Coca-Cola is pursuing an acquisition of healthy soda brand Poppi, according to sources. The Atlanta-based beverage giant is among suitors for the company, but no transaction has been finalized and a deal is not imminent. Poppi, which offers a range of natural and organic flavors, would be a strategic acquisition for Coca-Cola as the company seeks to diversify away from sugary drinks. No terms could be learned, and a Coca-Cola representative declined to comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: Coca-Cola's average selling prices rose 9 per cent in the fourth quarter, while unit case volumes increased 2 per cent.
Kirsten van Zandwijk, director of sustainability and partnerships for Asean & South Pacific at The Coca-Cola Company, and SembWaste chief executive officer Kok Kin Lee.

site_title: Hong Kong’s top housing estates saw zero deals during holiday
summary: Hong Kong's top 10 private housing estates saw zero sales during the Chinese New Year holiday, marking the first time since 2010. The housing slump is expected to linger due to rising interest rates and an economic slowdown in China. Second-hand residential sales reached a 28-year low in 2023, with prices dropping to their lowest since 2017. Buyers are waiting for government measures to aid the property market, which will be announced in the upcoming budget. This adds to signs of a prolonged housing slump in Hong Kong.

site_title: GlobalFoundries forecasts hit as chip customers seek advanced processes, clear inventory
summary: GlobalFoundries has forecasted its first-quarter revenue below market estimates due to customers clearing excess chip inventory and opting for more advanced manufacturing processes. The company expects revenue in the range of $1.5 billion to $1.54 billion, down from analysts' average estimate of $1.76 billion. GlobalFoundries' CEO Thomas Caulfield attributed the weakness to the accelerated node migration of data centre and digital-centric customers to single-digit nanometres, weighing on demand for the company. The company expects automotive revenue growth in 2024, but remains cautious on the outlook for 2024.

site_title: SGX securities turnover up 8% to five-month high in January
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) securities market turnover reached a five-month high in January, increasing 8% to S$20.6 billion. Securities daily average value dropped 1.7% to S$935 million, while exchange-traded funds (ETFs) saw a 5% rise to S$291 million. Derivatives traded volume rose 27% to 24.6 million contracts, driven by strong increases in equities, foreign exchange, and commodities. Global investors leaned on SGX's platform to manage risk amid expectations for a rates cut and mixed views on Asian growth.

images.alt_text: Avepoint chief executive Jiang Tianyi believes that a Spac offers more certainty around the amount of capital raised for the company, but more can be done to improve the Spac framework.
Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks over the five trading sessions through to Feb 8.

site_title: CLI sets up new lodging private fund with US$600 million target in equity
summary: CapitaLand Investment has set up a new lodging private fund, CapitaLand Ascott Residence Asia Fund II (Clara II), with a target equity size of US$600 million. The fund, which will hold a 20% sponsor stake, will leverage Ascott's global operational expertise and sales network. Two lyf-branded properties in Singapore and Japan will be added to the fund as seed assets, with plans to launch them in mid-2024 and the fourth quarter of 2024, respectively. Investor interest in serviced residences and co-living properties has been on the rise, driven by their resilience during the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Sea Logistics Fund intends to develop its recently-acquired freehold site in Bangkok into an automated logistics campus.
CapitaLand is divesting a 95 per cent interest in Capital Square Beijing to AIA Life Insurance.
Ascott's Oakwood brand will see almost 18,000 units across 48 cities, including new markets such as Ha Long in Vietnam (pictured above).

site_title: Democrat flip seat of disgraced New York congressman
summary: Democrat Tom Suozzi won a special election to replace ousted New York Representative George Santos, flipping the affluent Long Island district back to Democrats and narrowing the GOP's razor-thin majority in the US House of Representatives. Suozzi, who previously held the seat for three terms, out-raised and out-spent Republican candidate Mazi Pilip, and his victory speech called for taking the country back from those who want to divide it. The election, seen as a bellwether for November's presidential and congressional elections, was marked by significant national interest and divisive ads on immigration, Israel, and abortion.

images.alt_text: WOODBURY, NEW YORK - FEBRUARY 13: Democratic U.S. House candidate Tom Suozzi celebrates with his family his victory in the special election to replace Republican Rep. George Santos on February 13, 2024 in Woodbury, New York. Suozzi defeated Republican Mazi Pilip in a race closely watched nationally as the presidential race heats up.   Stephanie Keith/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by STEPHANIE KEITH / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Israel faces growing pressure over Gaza ceasefire
summary: Israel faces growing international pressure to agree to a ceasefire with Hamas as it prepares for an incursion into Gaza's Rafah city, where over a million Palestinians are trapped. A Qatari-brokered plan aims to halt fighting in exchange for Hamas freeing hostages. The US and UN have warned Israel against a ground offensive into Rafah without a plan to protect civilians. Israel says it must eliminate Hamas's last battalions in the area to achieve a "complete victory". A ceasefire has been elusive, with over 1,160 people killed in Israel and 28,473 killed in Gaza since the Hamas attack on October 7.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled 77 cents higher or 0.94 per cent at US$82.77 a barrel at 2.30 pm EST on Tuesday.
Jordan's King Abdullah II speaks at a press conference, with US President Joe Biden, at the White House in Washington, United States, Feb 12, 2024.
IMF's Kristalina Georgieva says that if there are other “consequences in terms of where the fighting goes, it could be more problematic for the world as a whole”.
The Senate's vote breaks a procedural hold placed on the USS$95 foreign assistance bill which includes US$60 billion for Ukraine.

FILE PHOTO: The world's first methanol-fueled container vessel Laura Maersk, owned by shipping company Maersk, is seen in Copenhagen, Denmark September 14, 2023. REUTERS/Jacob Gronholt-Pedersen/File Photo

site_title: Apple’s longest-serving designer to depart company, adding to exodus
summary: Apple's longest-serving senior industrial designer, Bart Andre, is retiring after joining the company in 1992. Andre, who worked alongside Jony Ive, is one of the last remaining designers from the Ive era and helped create the aesthetic for Apple products over the past three decades. The departure is the latest in a series of exits for top designers, with multiple longtime designers planning to leave the company's software design team. The industrial-design team is now overseen by Jeff Williams, the company's chief operating officer, who has implemented cost-cutting measures that have contributed to the unrest among staff.

images.alt_text: The EU's decision is a win for Apple and Microsoft, as they would have been obliged to adapt their services to meet a swathe of new obligations and prohibitions.
Apple has sued “stealth” startup Rivos in 2022.
Apple’s main rival in the space is Meta Platforms, the leader in VR with its Quest goggles.

site_title: Hot stock: Rex International falls 10% on heavy volumes after profit guidance
summary: Rex International's shares dropped 10% on heavy trading after the company warned of a net loss for FY2023, mainly due to non-cash items related to impairment of oil and gas properties. The group is still finalizing its impairment assessment and will release FY2023 results by Feb 29. The stock reached a ten-month low of S$0.129, with 33.6 million shares traded.

site_title: Why fashion’s ‘recycling’ is not saving the planet
summary: Fashion brands' efforts to use recycled materials are not saving the planet, despite claims of reducing dependence on fossil fuels. Most recycled polyester comes from plastic bottles, not old clothes, and can only be recycled a few times. Textile waste is mainly dumped or burned in Europe, with only 22% recycled or reused. The industry's reliance on mixed fabrics and unrecyclable materials perpetuates a cycle of waste. Environmental groups demand the textile industry stop producing polyester entirely, citing its significant carbon footprint and pollution. The solution lies in reducing consumption and adopting repair, reuse, and upcycling practices.

images.alt_text: Kirsten van Zandwijk, director of sustainability and partnerships for Asean & South Pacific at The Coca-Cola Company, and SembWaste chief executive officer Kok Kin Lee.
US households recycle just a fraction of the items they could, according to new research.

Calendars from 1996 are being reused for 2024 as both are leap years that begin on a Monday. The quirk has sparked a flurry of interest on the internet, with 1990s nostalgia fans chasing down vintage calendars nearly 30 years old.
The most profitable EV batteries to recycle are made of lithium, nickel, cobalt and manganese.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday’s open; STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.2% at the opening bell on Wednesday, following overnight losses in global markets due to US consumer inflation slowing less than expected. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 38.53 points to 3,103.34, with losers outnumbering gainers 97 to 22. Key companies, including Singtel, Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, and local banks, declined. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts are now less likely, contributing to the market downturn.

site_title: Casino operator MGM beats fourth-quarter estimates on China travel rebound
summary: MGM Resorts International exceeded market expectations in its fourth-quarter earnings, driven by a travel rebound in China and Macau. The company's China business saw an 18% increase in adjusted property EBITDA compared to 2019 levels. MGM's total revenue rose 22% to $4.4 billion, beating analysts' estimates, and its adjusted profit per share of $1.06 also surpassed expectations. The company attributed its success to its "premium positioning and offerings" in Las Vegas, particularly during major events like the Formula 1 race and Super Bowl.

images.alt_text: The five-year agreement with the unions averts a strike at eight MGM properties.

site_title: Rakuten Bank shares surge 13% after raising profit forecast
summary: Rakuten Bank shares surged 13% after raising its annual profit forecast, the largest intraday gain in four months. The Japanese online lender cited rising interest income from loans and expanded business scale as reasons for the increase. The bank's fiscal third-quarter net income was in line with estimates, and it now expects a full-year profit of 33.5 billion yen. This boost comes as Rakuten Bank benefits from its reward point system and potential interest-rate increases by the Bank of Japan.

site_title: Waitrose cuts prices after losing out to rival supermarkets
summary: Waitrose, a British upmarket supermarket chain, has announced £30 million worth of price cuts to win back customers lost during the cost-of-living crisis. The price cuts include 200 own-brand items, with lamb shanks now 16% cheaper and chicken goujons down 10%. The move follows struggles to keep up with competitors, including Aldi and Lidl, and comes after the company raised £125 million from a sale and leaseback on 11 stores. Waitrose is also considering 11,000 job cuts over the next five years.

images.alt_text: epa10713638 A shopper at a supermarket in London, Britain, 27 June 2023. UK supermarket chiefs are set to face intense questioning from MP’s over food inflation at parliament in London 27 June. UK food inflation has fallen for the second month in a row as supermarkets cut the price of household staples. Food inflation however still remains high 8.4 percent.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Instacart cuts 250 jobs in push for higher-margin businesses
summary: Instacart is cutting 250 jobs, about 7% of its workforce, as it shifts focus to higher-margin businesses like advertising and enterprise products for grocery stores. The restructuring also sees three company executives leaving for personal reasons. Despite a slight revenue miss, Instacart's adjusted earnings beat estimates, and the company expects adjusted earnings of $150-160 million for the first quarter of 2024, beating expectations.

images.alt_text: The grocery delivery firm, whose stock has lost more than a third of its value since its debut, also announced a US$500 million share repurchase programme.
At least half of Instacart’s 20 IPO underwriters have initiated coverage with their top ratings after the quiet period ended.

site_title: Ueda mulls rate hike in rare case of BOJ facing scant opposition
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda is poised to raise interest rates for the first time since 2007, with no strong opposition from politicians or business leaders. The BOJ's decision to end the world's last negative rate regime is supported by the economy's rebound to 1.1% annualized growth in the fourth quarter and the yen's weakening against the US dollar. Most BOJ watchers expect the rate hike to be implemented by April, with some analysts framing it as a positive move to end an "abnormal policy" and a necessary step to address elevated inflation trends.

images.alt_text: The bank delivers its next policy decision on Mar 19.
Many market players expect the BOJ to end negative rates this year, with the most popular timing seen as April.
Young people in Japan are benefiting from a labour shortage that’s especially acute in their age group.

site_title: DBS obtains licence to underwrite non-financial corporate bonds in China
summary: DBS Bank has obtained a licence to underwrite non-financial corporate bonds in China's interbank bond market, marking the first time a South-east Asia headquartered bank has secured this licence. The licence allows non-financial enterprises outside of China to tap the world's second-largest bond market, leveraging DBS' experience in helping foreign governments and financial institutions. This expansion expands DBS China's capabilities and networks in accessing the attractive market, following its success in panda bond issuances in 2023.

images.alt_text: Piyush Gupta, CEO, DBS Group.
DBS has been keen to expand in Greater China.
The Singapore-based bank bought a 13 per cent stake in the Chinese bank for S$1.1 billion in 2021 as part of a long-standing goal of growing in large emerging markets.
DBS appoints veteran Ginger Cheng as new country CEO for China

site_title: Walmart in talks to buy Vizio for more than US$2 billion, WSJ reports
summary: Walmart is reportedly in talks to buy smart-television manufacturer Vizio for over $2 billion, according to The Wall Street Journal. The acquisition would give Walmart control of nearly a fifth of the US television market and bolster its advertising business. Vizio shares surged 24.6% on the news, while Walmart's shares fell about 1%. The reported offer price is nearly 30% higher than Vizio's current market cap. The deal comes as Walmart increasingly monetizes its shopper data to sell ads on its properties, including its website and store assets.

images.alt_text: Walmart, the world’s largest retailer, ships one quarter of its US imports from India between January and August this year.

site_title: US seeks about US$1.4 billion from collapsed SVB for taxes
summary: The US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is seeking approximately $1.4 billion in unpaid taxes from Silicon Valley Bank (SVB), which collapsed last year. The IRS claims the bank owes corporate income and employment taxes from 2020 to 2023. This comes after a similar lawsuit in New York City is trying to collect over $2.1 million in back taxes. The IRS estimates the amount sought, noting some employment taxes had been paid, but the exact amount is not specified.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as inflation stands higher than expected
summary: US stocks declined 1.4% on Tuesday, retreating from Monday's record high, as consumer inflation slowed less than expected in January. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 3.1% from last year, while core inflation rose 3.9%, above the Federal Reserve's 2% target. US Treasury bond yields jumped as investors shifted bets against interest rate cuts. Analysts downplayed the inflation report, with one describing it as a "blip," and the Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at 38,272.75.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A street sign for Wall Street is seen outside the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., July 19, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly//File Photo

site_title: Nvidia market cap threatens Alphabet after overtaking Amazon
summary: Nvidia surpassed Alphabet as the world's third most valuable company, with a market capitalization of over $1.78 trillion, surpassing Amazon's $1.75 trillion. Nvidia's dominance in the AI chip market has driven its stock up 46% this year. Analysts predict "substantial AI upside" for Nvidia and its competitors, further fueling the tech industry's rally. This marks a historic milestone, as Nvidia first surpassed Amazon's market value in 2002.

images.alt_text: Arm’s share price rise has made for massive gains for recent bullish options bets.
Arm is benefiting from a push beyond smartphone technology, helping fuel growth and profitability.
Nvidia is the last of the tech giants to report earnings, which are due on Feb 21.
Competition for homes is intensifying as the pandemic exodus from Northern California to cheaper locations around the country winds down.

site_title: Digital telco Circles names ex-Gojek, Coinbase exec as CFO in leadership shakeup
summary: Circles, a Singapore-based digital telco, has announced leadership changes with Justin Choi as new CFO, Bart Weijermars as Chief Customer Success Officer, and Luke Lu as Chief People Officer. Choi, previously at Gojek and Coinbase, will oversee corporate strategy, financial operations, and strategic acquisitions. Weijermars will lead the mobile virtual network enabler business unit, while Lu focuses on talent acquisition and retention for Circles' global expansion. The changes aim to drive innovation and agility in the company's telco technology platform, Circles-X, serving clients in 15 markets, including Japan and the Middle East.

site_title: Gold struggles below US$2,000 per ounce as US Fed cut bets trimmed
summary: Gold prices fell 1.4% on Tuesday, the largest daily decline since December 4, as the US Federal Reserve trimmed bets on rate cuts following a stronger-than-expected inflation report. Spot gold traded below $2,000 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.2%. The decline was attributed to reduced expectations of more than three quarter-point rate cuts from the US Fed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars from the vault of a bank are seen in this illustration picture taken in Zurich November 20, 2014. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Brexit, crisis ‘hangover’ keep UK bank shares undervalued, minister says
summary: UK bank shares remain undervalued due to lingering Brexit concerns and a negative political climate, according to Financial Secretary Bim Afolami. Despite stability and solid earnings, shares have struggled, prompting Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey to describe their valuations as a "puzzle." The government is working to change perceptions by being responsive to the sector's needs, with Afolami stating that the views on banks are "unfounded."

images.alt_text: epa10498611 A row of houses in London, Britain, 02 March 2023. UK house prices in February dropped by the most in more than 10 years according to mortgage lender Nationwide showing signs of a slowdown in the housing market due to high inflation and rising borrowing costs.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL
German Finance Minister Christian Lindner addresses the media about the government's budget plans, in Berlin, Germany, July 5, 2023. REUTERS/Lisi Niesner
Britain is reforming its financial sector in a bid to remain globally competitive as UK tech companies like chip designer Arm Holdings choose to list in New York.

Brussels wants EU regulators to have direct oversight of euro clearing for banks and asset managers based in the bloc, particularly since Britain’s departure from the EU and requirement to comply with its financial rules.

Former British Prime Minister Liz Truss spent just 49 days in office before she was ousted by her own party in October 2022 after her disastrous mini-budget spooked financial markets and sank the pound.

site_title: Robinhood posts surprise profit on interest income boost, trading rebound
summary: Robinhood Markets reported a surprise profit of 3 cents per share in the fourth quarter, driven by higher interest income from customers paying back loans and a rebound in trading. The company's net interest revenue rose to $236 million, and transaction-based revenues grew 8% year-over-year to $200 million. Robinhood's trading market share climbed 14% for equities and 19% for options, and the company aims to deliver margin expansion and expects headcount to be roughly flat to slightly up this year.

images.alt_text: The app will allow European investors to buy and sell more than 25 cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin, Ether and Solana’s SOL.
Robinhood’s transaction-based revenue decreased 11 per cent year-over-year to US$185 million amid a 13 per cent decline in equities and a 55 per cent decrease in cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Indonesian polling stations open in election
summary: Indonesia's presidential election began on Wednesday, with nearly 259,000 candidates contesting 20,600 posts across 17,000 islands. The election pits two former governors, Ganjar Pranowo and Anies Baswedan, against controversial frontrunner Prabowo Subianto. President Joko Widodo, who cannot run, is backing Prabowo, who is projected to win the majority of votes and avoid a second round. Voter turnout will be crucial, and undecided voters may decide the outcome, with a runoff possible in June if no candidate secures over 50% of the votes.

images.alt_text: The three men looking to succeed Widodo for the next five years are (from left) Prabowo Subianto, Ganjar Pranowo and Anies Baswedan.
The archipelago of more than 17,000 islands stretches across three times zones and a distance similar to across the United States.

Supporters during a Prabowo Subianto, presidential candidate and Indonesia's defense minister, campaign rally in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Feb. 10, 2024. Days before Indonesians vote for their first new president in a decade, opinion polls favor an ex-general bent on continuing an economic strategy anchored on business ties to China while vowing to sustain a more neutral foreign policy stance between Washington and Beijing. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
Surveys have consistently shown Prabowo is the candidate to beat.

Anies Baswedan has portrayed himself as the anti-establishment candidate in Indonesia’s presidential campaign, climbing to second place in polls on the back of a message that includes opposing a costly relocation of the capital to Borneo
Ganjar Pranowo, Central Java’s former governor, has called on people to vote for him to show “true resistance” against the use of state resources during campaigning, without naming any of his rivals.
This election marks the third presidential run for Prabowo Subianto, a controversial ex-soldier who was defeated by Joko Widodo in 2014 and 2019.

site_title: Bali’s 150,000 rupiah tourist e-tax comes into force
summary: Bali, Indonesia, has implemented a 150,000 rupiah (S$13.50) e-tax on arriving tourists to preserve the island's culture and environment. The move aims to boost the island's coffers and protect its tropical allure. With nearly 4.8 million tourists visiting between January and November last year, the tax is seen as a necessary measure to capitalize on the island's popularity. The tax will help protect Bali's natural resources and cultural heritage, according to the acting governor.

images.alt_text: Ahead of Indonesia’s Polling Day on February 14, a mandatory cooling-off period will be held from February 11 to 13.
Starting on 14 February this year, the provincial government of Bali will implement a 150,000 rupiah (S$12.8) tax for foreign tourists.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust posts 25.4% higher DPS of S$0.0217 for H2
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) posted a 25.4% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to S$0.0217 for the second half of 2023, driven by higher gross revenue and net property income (NPI) of 28.6% and 24.8% year-over-year, respectively. Revenue per available room (RevPAR) for hotels rose 19.9% to S$140, while average occupancy improved 2.6 percentage points to 81.7%. The stapled group is "well-positioned to ride on the further recovery of the hospitality sector," according to its CEO, Gerald Lee.

images.alt_text: Maybank Securities projects Far East Hospitality Trust to report a FY2023 distribution per stapled security of S$0.04.

Oasia Resort Sentosa, one of the assets in Far East Hospitality Trust's portfolio. The stapled group's third quarter revenue is up 42.5 per cent year-on-year due to strong contributions from the hotel segment.
FEHT intends to remain a "very Singapore-centric Reit", with a small proportion of overseas assets, said Gerald Lee, chief executive officer of the Reit manager.
FEHT's H1 DPS is up mainly due to higher net property income and the distribution of other gains from its recent divestment of Central Square.

site_title: NEC spurned private equity offers before selling discounted stake in iPhone supplier: sources
summary: NEC, a Japanese electronics conglomerate, received multiple buyout offers from global private equity funds for its 51% stake in iPhone supplier Japan Aviation Electronics Industry (JAE) before agreeing to sell back its stake at a 14% discount. The offers, which included one valued at 4,000 yen per share, were made by at least three global funds and could raise questions about NEC's decision-making process. Governance experts warn that the deal may have compromised the interests of NEC's shareholders.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of NEC Corp is pictured at the CEATEC JAPAN 2017 (Combined Exhibition of Advanced Technologies) at the Makuhari Messe in Chiba, Japan, October 2, 2017.   REUTERS/Toru Hanai

site_title: Blackstone drops out of bidding for German football media rights deal
summary: Blackstone has dropped out of bidding for a German football media rights deal, following protests from fans critical of foreign capital. The decision comes amid concerns about the deal's structuring and economic factors, and after some clubs expressed interest in a fresh vote. CVC Capital Partners, the sole remaining bidder, remains committed to pursuing the deal. The move follows a backlash against private equity involvement in the Bundesliga, with fans criticizing the firms for taking funds from Saudi Arabia.

images.alt_text: Crown Resorts has faced years of regulatory challenges, including a royal commission in Victoria around money-laundering charges.
L’Occitane’s enterprise value was about 10 times its estimated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation at Monday’s close.
The Blackstone headquarters in New York, US, on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024. Blackstone Inc. released earnings figures on January 25. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The acquisition of Rover is expected to close in the first quarter of 2024, according to a November statement.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CLI, FEHT, Centurion, Grand Banks Yachts
summary: CapitaLand Investment sets up a new lodging private fund with a target equity size of US$600 million. Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 25.4% increase in distribution per stapled security and a 28.6% year-on-year rise in gross revenue. Centurion expects a "substantial increase" in net profit for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2023, attributed to net fair value gains on investment properties.

site_title: Siemens to make transformers in US to meet rising power demand
summary: Siemens Energy is investing $150 million to expand its power manufacturing plant in Charlotte, North Carolina, to produce transformers in the US. The move aims to meet the growing demand for electricity, particularly from data centers powering artificial intelligence. Currently, 80% of US transformers are imported, and establishing a domestic supply chain is crucial. Production is expected to start in 2026, with a potential grant from North Carolina covering almost $7 million over 12 years. This investment will help Siemens Energy meet the increasing power demand in the US.

site_title: Firefox maker Mozilla is cutting 60 jobs after naming new CEO
summary: Mozilla, the maker of Firefox browser, is cutting about 60 jobs, approximately 5% of its workforce, as part of a shake-up under new CEO Laura Chambers. The cuts primarily affect the product development organization, with a focus on Firefox Mobile. Mozilla aims to re-prioritize resources on products with significant growth potential, such as Firefox Mobile. This move comes after the company's longtime CEO Mitchell Baker stepped down to become executive chairman. Mozilla's market share has been declining in recent years, leading to the restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: Cisco has in recent years grappled with supply chain issues and a post-pandemic slowdown in demand, which has hastened its push into software offerings such as cybersecurity.

site_title: AI giants to unveil pact to fight political deepfakes
summary: Tech giants Meta, Microsoft, Google, and OpenAI are working on a pact to combat AI-generated deepfakes and other deceptive content ahead of crucial elections this year. The companies will develop ways to identify, label, and control AI-generated images, videos, and audio that aim to deceive voters. They have already agreed to use a common watermarking standard to tag AI-generated images. The pact is set to be announced at the Munich Security conference on Friday.

site_title: Cost cuts to help Lyft turn cash flow positive in 2024; shares surge
summary: Lyft reported a beat on quarterly profit estimates, with total costs cut by 12% in 2023, and expects to generate positive free cash flow for the first time in 2024. The company's shares surged 18% in post-market trading. Lyft CEO David Risher has driven aggressive restructuring, cutting jobs and eliminating management layers. The company expects ridership to grow in the mid-teens this year, driven by a 26% rise in the December quarter, and gross bookings are expected to rise between $3.5 billion and $3.6 billion in the March quarter.

images.alt_text: Media reports previously said both the companies were in preliminary discussions related to a variety of scenarios about a potential deal.

A Doordash delivery person rides their bike on Church Avenue in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn on December 4, 2020 in New York City. site_title: Jeff Bezos sells US$4 billion of Amazon stock in four trading days
summary: Jeff Bezos, the world's second-richest person, has sold $4 billion worth of Amazon shares in four trading days, offloading 24 million shares. The sales follow a plan to dispose of up to 50 million shares, announced in November. Bezos' relocation to Miami from Seattle is believed to be the reason behind the sales, as Washington state's 7% capital gains tax would save him $288 million. Amazon shares were up 13% at the time of the sales.

images.alt_text: Bezos has adopted a trading plan to sell 50 million shares anytime before Jan 31, 2025.

Jeff Bezos owns homes in Washington, DC, New York City, Los Angeles and Maui, as well as a 300,000-acre ranch in Texas, the base of the launch site for Blue Origin’s New Shepard rocket.

site_title: BT Tech In Finance: How tech will shape tomorrow’s business (Ep 3)
summary: HSBC Singapore's head of commercial banking, Priya Kini, shares four key trends driving digital transformation for businesses in the banking industry. These trends include the use of digital tools to enhance customer experience, increased adoption of cloud computing, the growth of fintech, and the importance of cybersecurity. According to HSBC's Digital Horizons report, these trends will shape the future of the banking industry and drive business transformation.

images.alt_text: Serene Koh from OCBC believes digital first doesn’t mean digital only.
Jenita Soetanto from UOB, the largest commercial investor in Singapore’s first smart digital district.

site_title: Biden blasts Trump’s ‘dumb’ and ‘dangerous’ Nato threats
summary: US President Joe Biden strongly condemned Donald Trump's comments on Nato, calling them "dumb," "shameful," and "dangerous." Trump stated he would encourage Russia to attack Nato members who fail to meet financial commitments, prompting Biden to accuse him of bowing to Russian President Vladimir Putin. Biden also criticized Trump's history of praising Putin and his claims to settle the Ukraine war in 24 hours, labeling them "un-American." The comments sparked alarm among Washington's allies, fueling Biden's election attack line against Trump as a threat to democracy.

images.alt_text: Rather than focusing on candidates’ ages per se, we should consider whether they have the capabilities to do the job.
The US presidential elections, where former president Donald Trump is a likely candidate, will be the most consequential election for global investors this year.

The video posted by the Biden-Harris HQ TikTok account shows US President Joe Biden answering rapid fire questions.
Trump is close to winning the Republican nomination after back-to-back wins in Iowa and New Hampshire last month.

site_title: Oil up on geopolitical tension, gains capped by fading Federal Reserve rate-cut hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 0.94% on Tuesday, with Brent futures settling at $82.77 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $77.87 a barrel. Geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and eastern Europe, particularly the conflict in Ukraine and Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthis' attacks, contributed to the increase. However, gains were capped by fading hopes for US Federal Reserve rate cuts, which could dampen economic growth and oil demand.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's largest refinery, Nghi Son, is 35.1 per cent owned by Kuwait Petroleum, 25.1 per cent by Vietnam’s state oil firm PetroVietnam, and 4.7 per cent by Mitsui Chemicals.
Brent futures fell 19 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to settle at US$82.00 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: January global EV sales up 69% from a year ago, but down 26% vs December
summary: Global electric vehicle sales surged 69% in January compared to the same period last year, reaching 1.1 million units. However, sales declined 26% from December, largely due to subsidy cuts in Germany and France, as well as seasonally weaker sales in China.

images.alt_text: Daihatsu Motor Corporation's next president, Masahiro Inoue, speaks during a press conference in Tokyo on February 13, 2024. Japanese auto giant Toyota named Inoue the new head of its Daihatsu subsidiary on February 13 after an embarrassing scandal over faked safety tests dating back decades. (Photo by JIJI Press / AFP) / Japan OUT
