The loss-making British luxury carmaker is seeking to refinance at a tumultuous time in debt markets following the surge in interest rates and uncertainty around rate cuts.
BYD’s sales, over 80 per cent of them in China, have grown by about one million cars in each of the past two years.
At Budget 2023, the vehicle tax rate at the highest tier was cranked up to 320 per cent, from 220 per cent. This applies to the part of a vehicle’s basic cost exceeding S$80,000.
Daihatsu will resume production of 10 other models on Feb 26.

site_title: Airbnb gives optimistic outlook buoyed by international trips
summary: Airbnb reported a stronger-than-expected Q4 2023 with revenue surpassing analysts' estimates, driven by growth in international markets. The company expects $2.03-2.07 billion in revenue for Q1 2024, with guest demand remaining strong, particularly among first-time bookers. Despite a net loss of $349 million, Airbnb's shares jumped 8% in extended trading, and the company announced a new share repurchase program to buy back up to $6 billion of stock.

images.alt_text: Starting Apr 1, an additional fee of as much as 2 per cent will be charged to guests if they pay in a different currency from the listing.
Airbnb received more than 2,000 complaints from Australian customers over being charged in US dollars during this period.
The tax probe is related to Airbnb’s alleged failure to withhold 21 per cent of landlords’ rental income and pay it to Italian tax authorities.

site_title: US Fed might defer rate cuts as inflation stays elevated: analysts
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers may defer rate cuts due to elevated inflation, which remained above expectations in January, increasing the likelihood of a rate cut in June rather than April. The consumer price index rose 3.1% year-over-year, with core inflation at 3.9%, indicating that inflation is still above the Fed's 2% target. This decision may delay a rate cut, with economists predicting a possible cut in September if inflation remains high.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building in Washington, U.S., January 26, 2022. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo

site_title: India plans US$9 billion rooftop solar push as key elections loom
summary: India plans to invest $9 billion in rooftop solar panels to power 10 million homes, boosting its renewable industry. The scheme aims to increase the pace of solar-power rollout, with each household receiving 300 kilowatt-hours of free power per month. The initiative, unveiled ahead of national elections, echoes China's strategy to drive down energy prices by creating economies of scale. Despite research suggesting up to 637 gigawatts of solar capacity could be harnessed from Indian homes, high loan rates may still price out small households.

site_title: Canberra sets out to rebalance power in the workplace
summary: Australia's Senate has passed a Bill allowing workers to ignore calls and messages outside of working hours without fear of repercussions. This reform, part of a broader suite of industrial relations laws changes, aims to rebalance power in the workplace and ensure workers receive fair compensation for their work. The changes were made in response to the Australian Labor Party's election promises, which highlighted stagnant wages and soaring business profits. The reforms also made it easier for unions to negotiate pay deals for workers in similar industries.

images.alt_text: Under an amendment proposed by the Australian Greens, an employee would now have the right to “refuse to monitor, read or respond to contact, or attempted contact, from an employer outside of the employee’s working hours unless the refusal is unreasonable.”

site_title: Switzerland, US, Singapore offer best opportunities for building family wealth
summary: Switzerland, the US, and Singapore are the top countries for building family wealth, according to a new index by Henley & Partners. Switzerland's low 2% unemployment rate, top universities, and high earnings make it the best destination for families looking to create long-term wealth. The US and Singapore follow closely, offering strong career prospects and high earnings. This report highlights the importance of location in achieving financial success for families across generations.

images.alt_text: Investing in bonding will build the necessary trust and go a long way to stave off family conflicts.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop 1% after hot US inflation data, technology weighs
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index dropped 1.0% on Tuesday after US consumer prices increased more than expected in January, leading traders to trim bets on early interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve. Technology shares fell 2.7% from a 23-year high, while real estate shares dropped 2.5%. The European Central Bank is now pricing in a roughly 60% chance of a rate cut in April. Despite this, the ECB's dovish comments in the previous session had boosted European shares to a near two-year high.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished  1.4 per cent lower at 38,272.75 on Tuesday, retreating from Monday’s record.

site_title: Bitcoin snaps 7-day winning streak after breaching US$50,000 plateau
summary: Bitcoin fell 2.8% to $48,450, ending a 7-day winning streak, after speculators took profits following its recent rally past $50,000. The decline still leaves the cryptocurrency up 16% this year. The recent US approval of spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds is seen as a factor in the rally, with investors now waiting to see how ETF approvals will play out. Analysts expect a shallow correction and support around $45,000.

site_title: Property stamp duty collection up 1.7% to S$4.51 billion in first 9 months of FY2023
summary: Singapore's property stamp duty revenue rose 1.7% to S$4.51 billion in the first nine months of FY2023, driven by a 12.6% increase in property tax takings. Despite lower transaction volumes, higher duty rates and increased property annual values contributed to the revenue growth. Analysts expect a slight increase in stamp duty collections and a larger jump in property tax takings for the full year. The government's initial projections for stamp duty collections and property tax revenue were revised upwards, with revenue from residential property tax projected to grow by around S$600 million in 2024.

images.alt_text: Replacing the revenue generated through property taxes with higher corporate and individual tax rates could have a negative impact on Singapore’s attractiveness.
URA's overall price index was up XX per cent year on year, a notch higher/lower than earlier estimates of 2.7 per cent.
Tweaks to property taxes can be considered in the upcoming Budget 2024.

site_title: Middle managers the weak link in ethics and compliance, new study finds
summary: A new study by ethics and compliance advisory firm LRN found that middle managers in Singapore are the weakest link in ethics and compliance, with only a third reporting making difficult decisions consistent with their company's values and purpose. In contrast, senior and executive managers reported making such decisions at a rate of nine in 10. Singaporean organizations were found to be more proactive in modifying or abandoning business initiatives due to ethics and compliance concerns, with 72% of respondents taking such actions. This may be attributed to the incorporation of ethical behavior into executive and employee evaluations, a practice adopted by 80% of Singaporean companies.

images.alt_text: Generic image of office workers. The breakthrough of technologies such as AI , and wave of digitization and transformation will affect everyone and these changes will impact working lives on a daily basis.

site_title: Former Malaysia PM Mahathir hospitalised again
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 98, has been hospitalized again for an undisclosed infection. He was admitted to the National Heart Institute on January 26 and is receiving treatment. Mahathir had a court hearing scheduled for Tuesday but failed to appear, citing hospitalization. He has a history of heart problems and has undergone bypass surgeries. This is the latest in a series of hospitalizations for the nonagenarian leader who served as prime minister for 22 years.

site_title: Burger King owner’s Q4 sales outpace expectations
summary: Restaurant Brands International reported Q4 sales of US$1.82 billion, surpassing analyst estimates, with earnings per share at 75 US cents. Same-store sales rose 5.8% and digital sales jumped 20% from a year ago, accounting for over a third of system-wide sales. The company attributed its success to initiatives such as remodeling locations and advertising, despite a pullback in spending by peers like McDonald's and Taco Bell-owner Yum! Brands.

images.alt_text: Fast-food traffic worsened in the fourth quarter, with KFC and Pizza Hut seeing declines of 4.8 per cent and 2.6 per cent, respectively.
A McDonald’s fast food restaurant in New York, US, on Monday, Oct. 24, 2022. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: Australia’s biggest bank CEO cautions on risks to economy
summary: Australia's Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) CEO Matt Comyn warned of mounting risks to the economy, despite the bank's profit beating expectations. Cash profit for the six months ended December 31 reached A$5.02 billion, exceeding estimates. Comyn cited slowing demand, persistent inflation, and geopolitical tensions as concerns. The bank will pay an interim dividend of A$2.15 per share and targets a full-year payout ratio of 70-80%. Comyn expects "financial strain to continue" in 2024, with increased arrears and impairments, but remains well-provisioned and capitalized.

images.alt_text: Office workers in Sydney's central business district.  On Feb 8, 2024, Australia's Senate passed a bill giving workers the right to ignore calls and messages outside of working hours without fear of repercussion.
The RBA has lifted interest rates to a 12-year peak of 4.35 per cent in an effort to restrain inflation and continues to warn that another hike might be needed even as the economy slows.
Consumer price inflation slowed sharply to a two-year low of 4.1 per cent in the December quarter, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment.
The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates steady at a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent last week, having last hiked by a quarter point in November.

site_title: Standard Chartered weighs breaking up corporate, investment bank
summary: Standard Chartered is considering restructuring its institutional banking arm, separating its investment bank from corporate and commercial banking operations, in an effort to improve returns. The move, led by CEO Bill Winters, could result in job cuts. The bank's shares have fallen 40% under Winters' leadership since 2015, and rival HSBC has already achieved higher returns. Standard Chartered aims to boost its return on tangible equity above 11% by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: In August last year, Su Jianfeng was charged with possessing some S$17 million worth of in cash, which were benefits from unlawful remote gambling activities.

site_title: Thailand’s pitching US$28 billion land bridge to the world, but foreign investors not ready to bite
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has pitched a US$28 billion land bridge project to the world, aiming to cut travel time and increase trade between the Pacific and Indian Oceans. However, foreign investors remain skeptical due to the lack of a full-scale feasibility study, transparency, and concerns over profitability. Despite the Thai government's claims of strong interest, experts warn that it's premature to bid for the project, citing a preliminary study's methodological limitations and shipping lines' reluctance to adopt the new route. The project's hefty price tag and potential for strategic or political advantages also raise concerns.

site_title: Boeing deliveries shrink 29% in Jan amid pressure to increase safety
summary: Boeing delivered 27 aircraft in January, a 29% decrease from the same month last year, due to pressure from regulators and customers following a MAX 9 mid-air cabin panel blowout in January. The US planemaker booked its lowest total gross orders since 2019 and had customers cancel orders for two 737 MAX aircraft. The MAX 9 was grounded for several weeks after the incident, and Boeing has capped production while conducting an audit. Deliveries of the 737 MAX fell to 25 aircraft, and the company has a backlog of 5,599 aircraft.

Expedia's shares, which have gained over 60 per cent since November, slid more than 12 per cent in extended trading.
The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: The Body Shop tips into insolvency, risking 2,000 UK jobs
summary: The Body Shop's UK business has fallen into administration, putting over 2,000 jobs and 200 stores at risk. The retailer, owned by private equity firm Aurelius, appointed administrators after struggling with increasing competition from online rivals. The brand, founded in 1976 by Anita Roddick, was valued at £207 million in a deal with Brazilian conglomerate Natura & Co. The move comes after several major brands, including Wilko and Paperchase, have gone into administration in recent months, highlighting the decline of Britain's shopping districts.

images.alt_text: Hermes is defying a broader slump in the high-end goods market as its exposure to the ultra-rich shields it from the worst of the lull.

A woman passes Japanese cosmetics company Shiseido's counter at a department store in Tokyo January 15, 2010. site_title: Paramount to cut 800 jobs days after record Super Bowl
summary: Paramount Global, owner of CBS and Nickelodeon, is cutting 800 jobs days after the company's Super Bowl coverage set a record for most-watched US television program. The move is part of CEO Bob Bakish's restructuring efforts, aiming to boost profits amid declining cable and satellite TV viewership. Paramount+, the company's streaming service, is not profitable. The cuts follow previous asset sales and debt reduction measures, with options including a sale of the company to independent producer David Ellison or media mogul Byron Allen.

images.alt_text: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - JANUARY 31: The Paramount Pictures logo is displayed in front of Paramount Studios with the Hollywood sign visible beyond on January 31, 2024 in Los Angeles, California. site_title: Korean Air wins EU’s approval for US$1.4 billion Asiana deal
summary: Korean Air Lines has won EU approval for its $1.4 billion bid to acquire Asiana Airlines, with the European Commission stating that the airline's proposed remedies, including divesting cargo business and allowing competitors to operate on certain routes, address concerns over competition. The merger still requires US regulatory approval, but is expected to proceed without major issues. This approval brings the deal closer to completion, following recent approvals from Japanese and EU authorities.

images.alt_text: The plan includes selling Asiana’s cargo business to other South Korean carriers, removing the main obstacle to the merger.

site_title: US consumer prices rise more than expected in January
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.3% in January, exceeding expectations, driven by increases in shelter and healthcare costs. The annual inflation rate remained at 3.1%, down from a peak of 9.1% in June 2022. Despite the stronger-than-expected reading, financial markets expect the Federal Reserve to start cutting interest rates in May or June, citing a tight labor market and elevated services inflation. Policymakers remain cautious, seeking evidence of sustained inflation slowdown before lowering borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 6, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid
The greenback rose to an 11-week high of 149.695 yen, edging toward the closely-watched 150 level.

site_title: Interest costs weigh on S-Reit distributions, but not all is doom and gloom for long-term investors
summary: S-Reits' latest results show 17 out of 22 Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) reporting declines in distribution per unit (DPU) due to higher interest rates. However, despite the near-term challenges, S-Reit managers are expressing greater optimism over growth in the coming years as interest rate expectations improve and investor sentiment shifts. Some Reits are taking steps to tap potential growth opportunities, such as making acquisitions and raising equity. Long-term investors may find it compelling to buy on dips to gain exposure at less expensive valuations.

images.alt_text: FCT raised S$200 million of gross proceeds through private placements, the majority of which will be used to repay existing debts, pending the use of such amount to partially fund the proposed acquisition of additional interest in Nex.

site_title: Dollar hits 150 against yen after US inflation data
summary: The US dollar surged to a 7-month high against the yen, reaching 150.34 yen, after US inflation data showed a 0.3% monthly increase and 3.1% year-on-year growth, exceeding economists' expectations. The data reinforced expectations that the Federal Reserve will hold interest rates in March. The pound rose to a 6-month high against the euro, while the Swiss franc fell to multi-week lows after lower-than-forecast consumer prices spurred rate cut bets.

images.alt_text: Changing expectations of when and how quickly central banks will cut interest rates as inflation falls are a significant driver of currency markets at present.

site_title: Global order faces systemic breakdown two years after Ukraine invasion
summary: The global order is facing a systemic breakdown two years after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with growing tensions in the Asia-Pacific region and rising nationalism. The Munich Security Conference will address these concerns, with experts warning of a potential major power war. The world is experiencing a series of simultaneous crises, and additional shocks could amplify their effects, leading to a major systemic breakdown. Despite the risk, memories of World War I and II, the presence of nuclear weapons, and the resilience of international institutions may prevent a major power war in the foreseeable future.

images.alt_text: Many CEOs and executives foresee an upbeat US economy in 2024, but are concerned about China and Europe, and the impact of unexpected global shocks on inflation.
An automobile assembly line in China. As the centre of gravity of the world economy continues to shift towards Asia, political shifts are inevitable.
A core uncertainty regarding Europe’s future is whether it can boost its economic competitiveness and close its growth gap with the US.

site_title: Aztech Global reports ‘cybersecurity incident’, appoints forensic advisers to investigate
summary: Aztech Global reported a cybersecurity incident where cybercriminals gained unauthorized access to its IT network and deployed a ransomware attack. The incident did not have a material impact on the company's financials or operations. Measures were taken immediately, including shutting down servers and using cybersecurity screening software. Third-party forensic advisers have been appointed to investigate, and the company is seeking advice from industry experts to strengthen its cybersecurity. Financial results for the full year ended Dec 31 will be announced on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Small companies are particularly attractive to hackers as they often have inadequate cybersecurity, making them easier targets.
Maersk says the disruptions were due to a technical network issue and not a cybersecurity issue, adding that some of the networks were coming back online.

site_title: Shopify Q4 results beat estimates on holiday demand
summary: Shopify reported strong Q4 results, beating estimates with a 24% revenue increase to $2.14 billion, driven by holiday demand. The company's adjusted earnings per share exceeded expectations at 34 cents. Despite this, US-listed shares fell 8% in pre-market trading. Shopify has launched new tools and AI products to stay ahead in the competitive e-commerce space, and expects a low-20s percentage revenue growth rate in the first quarter, slightly below analyst expectations.

images.alt_text: Food delivery is facing growth challenges as it comes off heady times during the pandemic.

site_title: US proposes rule to boost investment advisor scrutiny
summary: The US Treasury Department proposes a new rule to increase scrutiny of investment advisors, aiming to address "illicit finance and national security risks" in the sector. The proposed rule would require SEC-registered investment advisors to report suspicious activity and maintain records on fund movements. The move is seen as a response to the fact that thousands of investment advisors overseeing trillions of dollars in US investments lack comprehensive anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism measures.

images.alt_text: A spot crypto ETF tracks the market price of the underlying digital asset, giving investors exposure to the token without having to buy the currency.

site_title: Macquarie banker who earns more than Jamie Dimon steps down
summary: Macquarie Group's commodities head Nick O'Kane, who earned over $50 million in 2023, is stepping down as head of commodities and global markets and from the executive committee on February 27. O'Kane, a 28-year veteran, will be replaced by Simon Wright, who has been with the company for 35 years. The move comes as Macquarie reported a "substantially down" profit for the nine months ended December 31, and O'Kane's departure is attributed to personal reasons.

images.alt_text: The bank says that net other operating income for the second half of 2024 is expected to be substantially down on last year.

site_title: Moody's posts Q4 profit below estimates as credit ratings unit disappoints; names new CFO
summary: Moody's reported Q4 profit below estimates, with its credit ratings segment posting revenue of US$684 million, missing the analyst average estimate of US$699 million. The company's analytics unit saw a 11.5% increase in revenue to US$796 million. Moody's named Noémie Heuland as its new CFO, succeeding Caroline Sullivan. The company's adjusted profit for the quarter was US$2.19 per share, missing the analyst average estimate of US$2.32 per share, but it forecast per share adjusted profit between US$10.25 and US$11.00 for the full year 2024.

site_title: Vietnam’s largest refinery to book over 10 billion yen net loss in 2023
summary: Vietnam's largest refinery, Nghi Son, is expected to book a net loss of at least 10 billion yen (S$90.1 million) for 2023 due to high interest rates. Despite running above 100% capacity, the refinery faces financial costs from rising US interest rates. Idemitsu, the Japanese oil refiner with a 35.1% stake in Nghi Son, is discussing financing options to turn the refinery profitable. The company remains committed to its full-year profit forecast of 180 billion yen.

A trader counts Indian rupee notes in Mumbai. The currency has remained largely stable against the US dollar over the past year, trading at around 83 rupees to the greenback.

site_title: Private credit returns beat buyout funds for a second straight quarter
summary: Private debt funds have beaten private equity funds for a second consecutive quarter, with 1.8% returns in the third quarter of 2023 compared to 0.35% for buyout funds. Higher interest rates have benefited private credit funds, which offer floating rate debt and provide regular interest payments, despite the riskier nature of private equity. This reversal of expected returns highlights the impact of high interest rates on the private credit market.

site_title: CK Hutchison cancels sale of 3.4 billion euro Italian network unit
summary: CK Hutchison has cancelled the sale of its majority stake in Italian network infrastructure portfolio Wind Tre SpA to private equity firm EQT AB due to unfulfilled conditions. The deal was valued at 3.4 billion euros. This move comes as Italy's competitive telecom market, led by Iliad, continues to influence the industry. The sale of Telecom Italia's landline network to US private equity firm KKR in 2023 also highlights the market's dynamics.

site_title: Ex-Amazon duo’s AI startup raises US$12.5 million in Series A funding
summary: AI startup Marqo raised US$12.5 million in Series A funding led by Lightspeed Venture Partners to develop its search platform for unstructured data. The platform, which harnesses data from emails, customer contracts, and other corporate systems, will help companies analyze and use the data for purposes like e-commerce personalization. Marqo, co-founded by ex-Amazon duo Tom Hamer and Jesse Clark, aims to tap into the world's biggest untapped information resource, with plans to commercialize its technology and relocate its headquarters to San Francisco.

images.alt_text: While Indonesia has produced unicorns in the past, the startup ecosystem has its share of weaknesses, says the Asian Development Bank.

site_title: Sailing around the Cape will boost container lines, for a while
summary: The Cape Route is gaining popularity among container shipping companies, with CMA CGM reportedly joining the switch to avoid the Red Sea. This shift has led to a spike in freight rates, with average rates per 40-foot equivalent unit (FEU) for China-to-Europe routes reaching over US$4,000. However, the lines' advantage is short-term, as the market is expected to revert to its usual low returns on investments due to factors such as restored navigation in the Red Sea, increased supply, and regulatory changes. Maersk's CEO Vincent Clerc stated that the current market will lead to price pressure and impact results, with ocean container shipping seeing poor returns.

site_title: Marriott’s 2024 profit forecast lags estimates as US demand moderates
summary: Marriott International forecasted 2024 profit between $9.18 and $9.52 per share, lower than analyst expectations of $9.69 per share. US room revenue has normalized after post-pandemic highs, while international markets, particularly China, are expected to drive growth. The company reported a 7.2% year-over-year increase in revenue per available room (RevPAR) in the fourth quarter, driven by higher room rates and occupancy levels in China. Full-year room revenue rose 14.9% compared to 2022.

site_title: Coca-Cola revenue tops estimates on resilient demand, higher prices
summary: Coca-Cola beat Wall Street estimates for fourth-quarter revenue, driven by a 9% rise in average selling prices and a 2% increase in unit case volumes. The company's net revenue rose to $11 billion, surpassing estimates of $10.7 billion. This resilient demand and pricing strategy contrasts with PepsiCo's weak annual organic revenue growth and sales decline, as consumers are willing to spend more on favorite drinks and snacks due to increased prices and experiences.

site_title: Centurion expects ‘substantial increase’ in net profit for FY2023
summary: Centurion Corp expects a "substantial increase" in its net profit for FY2023, driven by "net fair value gains on the group's investment properties" to be recognized in FY2023. The company's final results will be released on Feb 28. This announcement led to a 2.6% gain in shares, closing at S$0.40.

site_title: US: Wall St dives at open as hot inflation data drives rate-cut jitters
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 98.21 points, or 0.25%, to 38,699.17, amid hotter-than-expected consumer inflation data that drove US Treasury yields higher and squashed market speculation for imminent interest rate cuts. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 opening lower by 53.90 points, or 1.07%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 343.67 points, or 2.16%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A street sign for Wall Street is seen outside the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, New York, U.S., July 19, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly//File Photo

site_title: Britain’s tea supply facing disruption from Red Sea crisis
summary: Britain's tea supply may face disruption due to shipping delays in the Red Sea, which affects the country's tea imports from Kenya and India. The British Retail Consortium warned of temporary disruptions to some black tea lines, but retailers expect minimal impact. The disruption follows attacks on ships in the Red Sea by Iran-aligned Houthi militia, which has slowed trade between Asia and Europe. The alternative shipping route around South Africa's Cape of Good Hope may add 10-14 days to a journey, but disruptions are expected to be minimal for tea consumers.

site_title: Ride-hailing firm GoTo denies discussions of merger with Grab
summary: GoTo Group, a major ride-hailing company in South-east Asia, has denied media reports of discussions with Grab Holdings about a potential merger. In a statement, GoTo said it was not in any discussion with Grab about a deal. This comes after media reports suggested Grab could acquire GoTo using cash, stock, or a combination of both. GoTo's CEO, Patrick Walujo, took over last year, potentially leading to the company's openness to a deal.

site_title: Apple iMessage, Microsoft Bing dodge EU’s Big Tech crackdown
summary: The European Union's Digital Markets Act (DMA) has found that Apple's iMessage and Microsoft's Bing search engine, Edge web browser, and advertising service do not hold a dominant enough position to be regulated. This decision spares these services from strict new EU rules aimed at limiting Big Tech platforms' market power abuses. Despite being exempt, Microsoft and Apple will still face new obligations for their Windows operating system, iOS mobile operating system, App Store, and Safari browser. The new rules will come into effect on March 7.

A screen tracks Nvidia's stock price as a trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange. Nvidia is already worth as much as the entire Chinese stock market.

site_title: German investor morale improves, rate cut hopes have ‘doping effect’
summary: German investor morale improved in February, rising to 19.9 points from 15.2 points in January, beating expectations. Over two-thirds of respondents expect the European Central Bank to cut interest rates in the next six months, and nearly three-quarters anticipate imminent US rate cuts. However, the assessment of the economic situation remains dire, with a reading of -81.7 points, the lowest since June 2020, indicating that the German economy is in a bad place despite the pick-up in investor confidence.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 13)
summary: ComfortDelGro acquires UK-based transport management specialist CMAC Group for £80.2 million, expanding its point-to-point mobility services. Keppel DC Reit is set to receive S$13.3 million from DXC Technology Services due to a dispute over colocation services. The Indonesian government's consumer spending and populist policies are expected to boost food and beverage sectors. Listed equities face challenges due to ageing populations, higher interest rates, and taxes. Experienced CEOs may not be the best bet for boards in uncertain economies.

site_title: Experienced CEOs aren’t the safe bet boards think they are
summary: US companies are turning to more experienced CEOs, with the average age of incoming S&P 500 CEOs reaching 56.4 in 2023, the oldest on record. This trend reflects a desire for stability in an uncertain economy, but experts warn that experience alone may not be enough to navigate the challenges ahead. Research suggests that first-time CEOs outperformed repeat CEOs in the long term, producing higher total shareholder returns with less volatility, and that the learning curve isn't as steep for those who have done the job before.

site_title: China opposes ‘illegal sanctions’ after proposed EU trade curbs
summary: China has strongly opposed "illegal sanctions" proposed by the EU to impose trade restrictions on three Chinese firms and one Indian firm in an effort to disrupt Russia's war efforts in Ukraine. The EU plan, which includes companies in Hong Kong, Serbia, and Turkey, aims to block European firms from trading with listed entities. China's foreign ministry said it will take necessary measures to safeguard Chinese enterprises' rights and interests, indicating a potential escalation in tensions between the two nations.

images.alt_text: The SME Infocomm Commerce Conference (SMEICC) organised by SCCCI was attended by around 5,000 participants and Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat in 2023.  PHOTO: SCCCI
The German economy has contracted by 0.3 per cent in 2023, due to persistent inflation, high energy prices and weak foreign demand.

site_title: French wine and spirit exports fell last year on US hangover
summary: French wine and spirit exports fell 6% to 16.2 billion euros in 2023, the second-highest on record, due to inflation and distributors clearing existing US stocks. The US market, the largest export market, saw a 22% drop in imports to 3.6 billion euros. Despite this, some countries like China saw a slight increase in sales, particularly cognac, and the industry remains optimistic for 2024, with the US market's de-stocking phase ending and trade issues being addressed.

images.alt_text: NV JJ Vincent Cremant de Bourgogne Blanc Brut sparkling wine. More people are drinking sparkling wine.

site_title: Rising interest in China, South-east Asia among members of SCCCI
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) has seen rising interest in China and South-east Asia among its members, with the organization organizing four business missions to nine parts of China and receiving nearly 130 delegations from China in 2023. The SCCCI also co-organized the 2023 Conference on International Industrial Cooperation, which attracted over 2,000 participants. The chamber strengthened ties with Malaysia's business community, signing a memorandum of understanding with its counterpart. SCCCI president Kho Choon Keng expressed commitment to serving members and promoting bilateral business ties.

images.alt_text: Thirteen generative AI solutions identified by EnterpriseSG and IMDA will be progressively onboarded to the sandbox by end February.
The recommendations cover five areas: manpower; digitalisation; internationalisation; sustainability; and grants, incentives and schemes.
SCCCI hopes Budget 2024 will help SMEs with costs, financing and sustainability

site_title: Flight attendants join hands to picket outside 30 airports for better pay
summary: Flight attendants from 24 airlines, including Alaska Air, Southwest Airlines, and United Airlines, are picketing outside 30 airports in the US, UK, and Guam to demand new contracts with significant pay increases. The protests come as flight attendants have not received a pay raise in five years, unlike pilots who have secured better deals. The Association of Flight Attendants is pushing for compensation for boarding and waiting time, as well as better scheduling and benefits. The labor market is seen as a factor in the airlines' ability to offer higher wages to pilots.

images.alt_text: Eva, best known internationally for the Hello Kitty livery on some of its jets, operates flights to many destinations around Asia as well as to North America, Europe and Australia.

site_title: All foreigners can use automated lanes at checkpoints from second half of 2024: ICA
summary: Singapore will introduce automated lanes for all foreigners at air, land, and sea checkpoints in the second half of 2024, allowing them to clear immigration without registering beforehand and presenting their passports upon departure. The new Automated Border Control System will use multi-modal biometrics capturing iris, facial, and fingerprint details. This will be the first country in the world to implement this system. The move aims to provide seamless immigration clearance for all travelers.

site_title: BLACKPINK K-pop star Lisa to join cast of 'White Lotus'
summary: BLACKPINK singer Lisa is set to make her acting debut in season 3 of HBO's 'The White Lotus', with production scheduled to begin in Thailand this month. Lisa will be credited under her full name, Lalisa Manobal, but her role remains undisclosed. This marks her first acting appearance, and her involvement could boost her star profile with American audiences.

images.alt_text: Mattel Films is also developing projects based on other popular toy lines, including American Girl, Hot Wheels, Magic Ball, Barney and more.

site_title: Stability, continuity top concerns of investors as Indonesia picks Jokowi’s successor
summary: Indonesia is set to elect its next president, with investors prioritizing stability and continuity of economic policies. The three main candidates, Prabowo Subianto, Ganjar Pranowo, and Anies Baswedan, are vying for the top spot, following outgoing President Joko Widodo. Investors are seeking reassurance on sound fiscal policy, infrastructure spending, and economic growth, which has been a hallmark of Widodo's tenure. The election outcome is expected to have a significant impact on Indonesia's economy, with 204 million voters casting their ballots on February 14.

images.alt_text: The archipelago of more than 17,000 islands stretches across three times zones and a distance similar to across the United States.
The US presidential elections, where former president Donald Trump is a likely candidate, will be the most consequential election for global investors this year.
A trader counts Indian rupee notes in Mumbai. The currency has remained largely stable against the US dollar over the past year, trading at around 83 rupees to the greenback.

Anies Baswedan has portrayed himself as the anti-establishment candidate in Indonesia’s presidential campaign, climbing to second place in polls on the back of a message that includes opposing a costly relocation of the capital to Borneo

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves US$15.7 billion more in new borrowing for 2024 fiscal year
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved an additional $15.66 billion in new borrowing for the 2024 fiscal year, bringing total new borrowing to $21.10 billion. This is part of a revised debt management plan, which includes restructuring existing debt of 2 trillion baht and debt repayments of 400 billion baht. The plan aims to finance a budget deficit of 693 billion baht, with the 2024 fiscal budget projected to spend 3.48 trillion baht. The budget was delayed from its original start date due to a general election last year.

site_title: I’m a neuroscientist. We’re thinking about Biden’s memory and age in the wrong way
summary: A neuroscientist argues that the conversation about Joe Biden's cognitive abilities should be informed by science, not politics. Biden's age and memory issues are often exaggerated, as memory functions naturally decline with age starting in the 30s. Forgetting and retrieval failure are common, but Forgetting (with a capital F) is a different issue. Experts point out that age does not definitively predict cognitive status, citing examples of "super-agers" who remain sharp. The focus should be on whether candidates have the capabilities to do the job, rather than their age or memory.

images.alt_text: epa11148754 US President Joe Biden looks on during a press conference with King Abdullah II of Jordan (not pictured) following their meeting at the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 12 February 2024. US President Biden is hosting King Abdullah II of Jordan to discuss the ongoing situation in Gaza and Israel, and humanitarian assistance in the region.  EPA-EFE/CHRIS KLEPONIS / POOL
President Joe Biden's age has once again become a talking point in US national politics, after recent incidents where he confused the names of foreign leaders.

site_title: Migrant boats make music at Milan’s La Scala
summary: Migrant boats from the Mediterranean, destined for the scrapyard, were transformed into string instruments, dubbed the "violins of the sea," by prisoners at an Italian opera prison. The instruments, made from cracked and diesel-soaked wood, debuted at La Scala opera house in Milan, moving the audience with a performance of Bach and Vivaldi. The project aims to give voice to those who are often discarded, including migrants and prisoners, and hopes to inspire emotional connections through music.

images.alt_text: “The Stradivarius myth was born between these walls, and it was here that (Stradivari’s) vision of the violin’s perfect resonance began to germinate”, says violinist Fabrizio von Arx (above), who set up the foundation which restored the house in Cremona.

site_title: Year of elections: How should you invest?
summary: The 2024 elections, particularly in the US, Indonesia, and India, may impact global investors due to potential changes in domestic and external policies, and geopolitical alignment. Investors should prepare for uncertainties, including tariff changes, fiscal policies, and national security issues. The US presidential election between Biden and Trump could lead to inflation, reduced interest rates, and market volatility. Diversification and risk management are key, with a focus on Japanese equities, developed markets' bonds, and gold as a reliable diversifier.

images.alt_text: Trump is close to winning the Republican nomination after back-to-back wins in Iowa and New Hampshire last month.
The archipelago of more than 17,000 islands stretches across three times zones and a distance similar to across the United States.

site_title: Grand Banks Yachts H1 profit jumps 91.7% to S$6.9 million; declares interim dividend of S$0.005 a share
summary: Grand Banks Yachts reported a 91.7% increase in net profit to S$6.9 million for the first half of 2024, driven by increased boat-building activities and higher sales. The company's interim dividend per share was S$0.005. This represents a 33.9% increase from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: The acquisition comes as the group looks to expand its point-to-point mobility services and offerings in the region.

site_title: The road to investing wisdom begins with ‘I don’t know’
summary: Investors often fail due to overconfidence rather than a lack of knowledge. Admitting "I don't know" is crucial in investing, as it allows for humility and a willingness to learn. Knowing one's circle of competence, or the range of topics and fields where you have expertise, is essential. However, it's equally important to acknowledge what you don't know and avoid investing in areas outside your expertise. A discounted cash flow analysis can provide a target price, but it relies on guessing future cash flows. Investors should be cautious of Mr. Market's mood swings and instead focus on the underlying business's earnings growth over the long term.

images.alt_text: Do not be lured into timing your entry and exit into and out of the market. You cannot tell when the pendulum will change direction.

site_title: Paris-based IEA opens its first overseas office in Singapore; operations to begin in H2 2024
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) is opening its first overseas office in Singapore, dubbed the IEA Regional Cooperation Centre, set to begin operations in the second half of 2024. The office will focus on scaling up renewables, clean energy technologies, and cross-border power trading in the Asia-Pacific region. It aims to energize the region's decarbonization journey while providing advice on energy security and resilience. Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry and the IEA have expressed confidence in the hub's strategic importance for the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Overall gas consumption across the globe is seen increasing by 2.5 per cent in 2024, with the Asia-Pacific region adding 4 per cent, followed by gas-rich countries in Africa and the Middle East.

site_title: ‘Better than a real man’: young Chinese women turn to AI boyfriends
summary: In China, a growing number of young women are turning to artificial intelligence boyfriends, citing loneliness and difficulty finding compatible partners in real life. Apps like Glow and Wantalk offer customizable virtual companions, from pop stars to historical figures, which users can interact with for emotional support and companionship. Despite concerns over data privacy, users say the technology provides a sense of connection and comfort, with some even seeking out virtual relationships over real-life ones.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on February 2, 2024 shows user Wang Xiuting chatting with her virtual boyfriend on Wantalk - an artificial intelligence chatbot created by Chinese tech company Baidu, on her phone at a shopping mall in Beijing. Twenty-five-year-old Chinese office worker Tufei says her boyfriend has everything she could ask for in a romantic partner: he's kind, empathetic, and sometimes they talk for hours. Except he isn't real. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP) / To go with 'CHINA-INTERNET-AI-ROMANCE, FOCUS' by Ludovic Ehret and Qian Ye
The game features a cast of 10 relatives of varying degrees of disapproving, prying or caring.

site_title: Tiger Woods launches brand with TaylorMade after Nike split
summary: Tiger Woods has partnered with TaylorMade Golf to create an apparel line, debuting in May. The 48-year-old golfer, who already plays with TaylorMade clubs, will work with the company to develop a brand that will eventually expand into footwear and clothing for women and kids. This marks a new marketing partnership for Woods, following the end of his long-term endorsement deal with Nike earlier this year. Woods has signed a committed partnership with TaylorMade, with no financial terms disclosed.

images.alt_text: PACIFIC PALISADES, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 12: Tiger Woods speaks during the launch of Tiger Woods and TaylorMade Golf's new apparel and footwear brand "Sun Day Red" at Palisades Village on February 12, 2024 in Pacific Palisades, California. site_title: ESG investing and the popularity asset pricing model
summary: The popularity asset pricing model (PAPM) offers a framework to understand the impact of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) analysis on risk and expected return, allowing investors to build personalized portfolios that reflect their views and preferences. Unlike the capital asset pricing model (CAPM), PAPM incorporates individual preferences beyond risk tolerance, including ESG considerations, and can explain anomalies in long-term average returns. By considering both capital market expectations and investor tastes, PAPM provides a more nuanced approach to portfolio construction, enabling investors to capitalize on ESG-related returns and avoid those that are negatively impacted.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags fly outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, March 1, 2023.REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo

site_title: Toyota says president, chairman of scandal-hit Daihatsu unit to step down
summary: Toyota Motor has named Masahiro Inoue as the new head of Daihatsu Motor, amid the brand's scandal over rigged collision safety-tests. The president and chairman of Daihatsu will step down, marking drastic changes as Toyota seeks to return Daihatsu to its roots. The move comes as Toyota faces potential reputational damage and governance issues at other affiliates, including Hino Motors and Toyota Industries. The changes aim to address the safety certification lapses and governance concerns, but the impact on Toyota's reputation remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: At Budget 2023, the vehicle tax rate at the highest tier was cranked up to 320 per cent, from 220 per cent. This applies to the part of a vehicle’s basic cost exceeding S$80,000.

site_title: STI closes flat as traders await key US inflation data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Tuesday, awaiting key US inflation data, which will shape market expectations for rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve. Expectations are for a disinflationary trend in the US to remain intact. The STI rose 3.57 points or 0.11% to 3,141.87, with the Dow pushing to a fresh record ahead of the US' January headline consumer price index release.

site_title: UK unemployment dips to 3.8% at end of 2023
summary: The UK's unemployment rate dropped to 3.8% in the final quarter of 2023, a decrease from 3.9% in the previous quarter. Average regular earnings growth slowed to 6.2% in the final quarter, while inflation remains elevated. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) noted that growth in employment has slowed and the proportion of people neither working nor looking for work has risen, with historically high numbers of people citing long-term sickness. Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt emphasized the need to stick with tax cuts to support economic growth ahead of a general election this year.

images.alt_text: Office workers cross London Bridge into The City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. Average earnings excluding bonuses rose 7.3% in the year through June, only slightly less than the 7.9% rate of consumer-price inflation, Bloomberg Economics predicts ahead of official labor market data due to be published on Aug. 15. site_title: Indonesia’s Valentine’s vote; Asean’s rail ambitions face hitch
summary: Indonesia is set to hold its presidential and legislative elections on February 14, with a mandatory cooling-off period from February 11-13. Meanwhile, ASEAN's rail ambitions face a hitch, with countries like Vietnam and Thailand trailing behind in connecting the region by rail. The Malaysian ringgit hit a historical low against the Singapore dollar, depreciating by 10.5% in 2023. Vietnam seeks $492 million in tech investments, and the region continues to push for sustainable tourism with entry fees for foreign tourists.

images.alt_text: Delegates convened at the fourth Asean Digital Senior Officials Meeting in Singapore on Jan 30 in preparation for the Feb 1-2 Asean Digital Ministers Meeting.

A man walks past the entrance of Bank Negara Malaysia in Kuala Lumpur. The country’s central bank maintained its overnight policy rate at 3 per cent in January.

site_title: Nikkei 225 gains as much as 3% on strong tech earnings, weak yen
summary: The Nikkei 225 index rose 2.9% to 37,963.97, its largest gain since November 2022, driven by strong tech earnings and a weak yen. Tokyo Electron's boost in full-year revenue and profit guidance led the gains, while SoftBank Group's Arm Holdings also contributed to the rally. The Topix index rose 2.1% as exporters were supported by the yen's 0.1% decline to 149.52 to the dollar. The Nikkei is now about 2% away from a record close.

site_title: India narrows gap with China in key MSCI index with weight hitting new high
summary: India has narrowed the gap with China in the MSCI's Global Standard index, with its weightage rising to 18.2% after the February revision, surpassing China's 25.4%. The move could lead to $1.2 billion in passive foreign flows. MSCI added five Indian stocks and removed 66 Chinese stocks, while keeping Indian stocks unchanged. The revised index will take effect on February 29, and India could potentially surpass a 20% weight by early 2024.

The EU has so far listed more than 620 companies, with the near entirety from Russia.

site_title: Mizuho Bank invests US$145 million in Credit Saison’s India business
summary: Mizuho Bank has invested US$145 million in Credit Saison's India business, acquiring a 15% minority stake. Credit Saison India, a non-banking financial company (NBFC) licensed in 2019, focuses on wholesale lending and consumer lending through its 40 physical branches in India. The investment is seen as a strategic move to deepen its lending franchise in the market. This marks Mizuho's entry into the Indian market, following Japan's Credit Saison International's expansion into Brazil and Mexico in 2023.

images.alt_text: The acquisition of Singlife by Sumitomo Life is just one of many deals Japanese corporates in South-east Asia, with their banks looking to leverage their low cost of funds.
Japan's Credit Saison launches new Asia-focused fund for early-stage startups

site_title: Tata Motors cuts EV prices between 1%- 8%, first by an Indian carmaker
summary: Tata Motors, India's largest electric vehicle (EV) carmaker, has reduced the prices of its electric cars by up to 8%, with the top-selling Nexon.ev now priced at 1.45 million rupees, down 1.4% from its previous price. The company aims to have 10 electric cars in its portfolio over the next three to four years and increase EV sales to 25% of its total car sales by 2025. This move is seen as a proactive step to pass on benefits to customers, following a decline in battery cell prices.

site_title: Thailand declares extra holiday to sustain tourism recovery
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved an extra holiday for civil servants during the traditional new year festival in April to boost tourism, which has seen a 48% surge in foreign tourist arrivals to 4.4 million since the start of the year. The special holiday will extend the Songkran festival period to five days until April 16, aiming to sustain the tourism industry's recovery, which averages less than 2% growth per year. The move is part of the government's efforts to target 35 million foreign arrivals this year, with 8 million expected from China.

site_title: Enter the Dragon, exit Meta
summary: Meta, a tech giant, is exiting a prime office space in downtown Singapore, leaving 22% of the building's office space vacant. This follows the company's earlier announced job cuts and global layoffs. The move raises concerns about more vacancies in the Singapore office sector. Meanwhile, the government's current fiscal year saw the highest recorded land sales, with $8.15 billion in proceeds, and the Urban Redevelopment Authority rejected a state land tender bid due to low market appetite. These developments come as businesses await the upcoming Budget statement and property taxes have increased for the year.

Residential rents are starting to come off their highs., writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Market players are watching closely to see if the government will award the Marina Gardens Crescent site to GuocoLand-Hong Leong group, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Possibly, property players will hope that Budget 2024 is a non-event for the sector, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

Higher ABSD and tighter loan limits have thrown a spanner in the works for those eyeing Singapore residential property for their portfolios or retirement plans, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Even if US-China tensions are manageable, a rough ride may be in store for listed equities
summary: US-China tensions may not lead to a complete collapse of global equities, but a rough ride is expected due to factors such as ageing populations, higher interest rates, inflation, and taxes. The two powers' competition in technology and global supremacy may lead to intense conflict, but they can afford to be inward-looking as they have large domestic markets. Investors value certainty, and a decline in geopolitical risk is a plus for global equities. However, listed equities may face challenges from rising debt servicing costs, higher taxes, job destruction, and elevated interest rates, making a compelling investment case uncertain.

images.alt_text: The US presidential election this year is set to be the most consequential geopolitical event. But would be naïve to regard the 2016-2017 US elections as a template for how the markets would likely behave should Donald Trump win.
The talks underscore trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies.

site_title: Australia’s ANZ plans to cut 170 business banking jobs, union says
summary: ANZ Group, Australia's fourth-largest bank, plans to cut 170 jobs in its commercial banking operations, according to the Finance Sector Union. The job cuts are part of the bank's efforts to automate and re-engineer back-office operations using technology. ANZ remains committed to investing in data and technology, and many of the affected employees will be offered alternative roles within the group. The bank made a record annual profit of A$7 billion last year, leading union president Wendy Streets to criticize the decision, saying it prioritizes profits over staff.

site_title: Barclays team handed guidelines to ratchet up transition finance
summary: Barclays has pledged to provide $1 trillion in sustainable and transition finance by 2030. The bank has assembled a team to define transition finance and has set parameters for expanding the business without being accused of greenwashing. Transition finance aims to transform carbon-intensive assets into greener ones, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions from oil, gas, and aviation sectors. Barclays is also stepping up pressure on energy clients to adjust their business and adopt transition plans. The bank's move comes amid concerns over greenwashing and the need for a regulatory definition of transition finance.

images.alt_text: Barclays also expects “energy clients to produce transition plans or decarbonisation strategies” by 2025.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows signage on a branch of Barclays Bank in London, Britain, March 17, 2023.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo
Barclays has one of the lowest valuations among peers, with shares down by around 24 per cent in the last year, driven in part by a hefty disposal of stock by a top investor, Qatar Holding.

site_title: Britain’s chronic housing shortage has become an election issue
summary: The UK is facing a severe housing shortage, with a potential shortfall of almost 100,000 homes per year over the next parliament. Construction of new homes in London dropped to its lowest level since 2009 between July and September. The Labour Party's pledge to build 1.5 million homes over five years could help alleviate the issue, but the country needs to build almost 400,000 dwellings annually to meet population growth. The UK's housing crisis has led to devastating effects, including homelessness, with temperatures dropping in market towns and a man dying after sleeping rough.

images.alt_text: RICS' report adds to signs of strengthening momentum in Britain’s housing market after high inflation and rising interest rates crimped demand in 2023.
Easing mortgage costs and improving confidence in the outlook for the economy have boosted the number of buyers looking for property.

Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust appoints new CIO after firing previous executive demanding alleged outstandings
summary: Dasin Retail Trust appointed Chinese real estate veteran Wang Peng as its new chief investment officer (CIO) on February 13, replacing former CIO Lu Zhiqi after he demanded alleged outstandings of S$783,376. The move comes amid a leadership crisis, with unitholders requesting an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove the trust's manager and form a new board. The trustee-manager had previously received letters of demand from four individuals, including Lu, for unpaid salaries and a loan.

images.alt_text: Ocean Metro Mall is one of three malls that will be in Dasin Retail Trust’s initial portfolio.
The trust's legal adviser has said the requisition notice is not valid.
Dasin Retail Trust shareholders have requisitioned an EGM to vote for an internalisation of the manager.

Notice of the EGM, and details of the meeting, will be sent to unitholders once the trustee-manager has verified the unitholding of the requisitionists whose unitholdings are registered in the name of nominee companies.

site_title: ContextLogic nears US$173 million sale of Wish to Qoo10
summary: ContextLogic, the parent company of online retailer Wish, has agreed to sell its assets and liabilities to Singaporean e-commerce company Qoo10 for US$173 million, or US$6.50 per share in cash. ContextLogic will retain its tax assets, including a US$2.7 billion net operating loss carryforwards, and may seek a financial sponsor to monetize them. The deal follows a strategic review initiated by ContextLogic in November, amid pressure from activist investor Cannell Capital and a significant decline in market value.

images.alt_text: A Qoo10 delivery van at Chin Swee Road on 13 July 2017.

site_title: EU proposes curbs on three Chinese firms for aiding Russia
summary: The European Union has proposed new trade restrictions on about two dozen firms, including three based in China, accused of supporting Russia's war efforts in Ukraine. The list includes companies in Hong Kong, Serbia, India, and Turkey, and would ban European firms from trading with the listed firms to crack down on Russia's ability to obtain sanctioned goods. The proposal comes as the EU counts Beijing as one of its most important trade partners, particularly for Germany, which sees China as the biggest market for carmakers.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen during an EU China summit in 2022. The EU has released five new initiatives which indicate its more sceptical policy towards China.
Trade tensions have been rising since the EU opened its EV investigation and China this month announced an anti-dumping probe into brandy sales.
The EU’s recent trade actions towards China have extended beyond EVs.

site_title: Indonesia in final stretch ahead of world’s biggest single-day election
summary: Indonesia is set to hold its world's biggest single-day election on February 14, with around 25,000 police ensuring security. Outgoing President Joko Widodo is widely seen as a strong candidate, despite criticism over his perceived political meddling. Prabowo Subianto, a former special forces commander and Widodo's ally, is projected to secure over 50% of the votes, potentially winning in a single round. The election comes 25 years after the end of authoritarian rule in Indonesia, with Widodo's legacy being tested in the contest.

images.alt_text: Supporters during a Prabowo Subianto, presidential candidate and Indonesia's defense minister, campaign rally in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Feb. 10, 2024. Days before Indonesians vote for their first new president in a decade, opinion polls favor an ex-general bent on continuing an economic strategy anchored on business ties to China while vowing to sustain a more neutral foreign policy stance between Washington and Beijing. Ganjar Pranowo, Central Java’s former governor, has called on people to vote for him to show “true resistance” against the use of state resources during campaigning, without naming any of his rivals.
This election marks the third presidential run for Prabowo Subianto, a controversial ex-soldier who was defeated by Joko Widodo in 2014 and 2019.

Presidential candidate and Indonesia’s Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto speaks on the stage during the last presidential election debate at the Jakarta Convention Center (JCC) in Jakarta on February 4, 2024.

Joko Widodo, Indonesia's President, speaks during a ground breaking ceremony for projects funded by private investors at the new national capital Nusantara (IKN) in Penajam Paser Utara, Indonesia, on Thursday, Sept. 21, 2023. Indonesian tycoons are leading the way in investing in the country's new capital city, with a hotel starting construction on Thursday. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: UK wage growth stronger than expected, supporting BOE caution
summary: The UK's wage growth slowed less than expected in the fourth quarter, coming in at 6.2% year-over-year, down from 6.7% in the previous quarter. This suggests the labour market is not cooling down fast enough to satisfy policymakers worried about a wage-price spiral. The Bank of England is expected to hold interest rates at a 16-year high until at least June, as inflation is forecast to hit 2% in the spring. The data also showed a lower-than-forecast unemployment rate of 3.8%.

images.alt_text: Office workers cross London Bridge into The City of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. Average earnings excluding bonuses rose 7.3% in the year through June, only slightly less than the 7.9% rate of consumer-price inflation, Bloomberg Economics predicts ahead of official labor market data due to be published on Aug. 15. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
British employers expect to raise basic pay by an average of 4 per cent over the next 12 months, according to the survey.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit to receive S$13.3 million from DXC Technology Services on dispute resolution
summary: Keppel DC Reit has reached a settlement with DXC Technology Services, agreeing to a S$13.3 million payment by April 2024 to resolve a payment dispute. The dispute centered on DXC's partial default of payment related to colocation services at a Singapore data center. The Singapore High Court previously endorsed Keppel's interpretation of the agreement, and both parties will release and discharge each other from claims arising from the matter. The settlement will not affect Keppel's FY2023 pro forma distribution per unit.

images.alt_text: One of Mapletree Industrial Turst's assets, at 250 Williams Street NW, Atlanta. MIT’s portfolio occupancy for its data centre segment is at 91.0 per cent (as at Dec 31, 2023), 2.4 percentage points lower quarter on quarter.
CGS-CIMB analysts expect that Keppel DC Reit will take over two of the data centres in Guangdong from FY2025 before gradually leasing them out.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. Sabana Reit’s FY2023 gross revenue is up 17.9 per cent year on year to S$111.9 million.

site_title: Traders bet on policy error in New Zealand as rate paths rupture
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) is bracing for a possible interest-rate increase by a quarter point to 5.75% in the first half of the year, according to overnight indexed swap contracts. The move is expected to be rapidly unwound by August, with borrowing costs to be lowered to 5.25% at the final meeting of 2024. This follows a 50% chance of a rate hike, up from 60% prior to data showing a 2½-year low in New Zealand inflation expectations.

images.alt_text: New Zealand housing market Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg
The aggressive hiking has weighed on the economy and GDP unexpectedly contracted in the third quarter and early quarters were revised lower.
The RBNZ has raised its policy interest rate to 5.5 per cent in the middle of 2023 from a record low of 0.25 per cent in October 2021 to try to dampen inflationary pressures.

site_title: Indonesia’s Pertamina to slash capacity at second-biggest refinery due to upgrade
summary: Indonesia's state-owned energy company Pertamina will temporarily reduce production capacity at its Balikpapan refinery from 260,000 barrels per day (bpd) to 60,000 bpd starting in late February. The reduction is part of a two-month revamp to increase capacity to 360,000 bpd and enable the production of fuel with Euro V emission standards.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of state-owned oil giant Pertamina's refinery unit IV  in Cilacap, Central Java, Indonesia January 13, 2016. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo

site_title: Paytm hits fresh lows as Macquarie sees ‘arduous’ path for embattled payments firm
summary: Paytm shares dropped 10% to a new record low on Tuesday, after Macquarie downgraded the Indian payments firm to "underperform" due to an "arduous" task to shift customers to other banks by the end of February. The Reserve Bank of India ordered Paytm Payments Bank to shut most of its business by February 29, citing persistent non-compliance, resulting in a 50% loss of market value and $3 billion in shareholder wealth. Analysts predict prices could drop another 28% to Macquarie's price target of 275 rupees.

images.alt_text: The payments firm competes with the likes of Walmart’s PhonePe and Google, and is widely used for everything from buying groceries to household items.
SoftBank has been offloading Paytm shares regularly since at least November 2022 through last month, according to a Bloomberg analysis of company filings.

epa11131189 A sign indicates that paytm mobile phone payment technology is accepted to receive payment from customers at a local roadside shop in Mumbai, India, 06 February 2024. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) ordered the closure of Paytm Payments Bank due to non-compliance and supervisory concerns.  EPA-EFE/DIVYAKANT SOLANKI

site_title: Japan's first sovereign green bonds expected to attract healthy demand
summary: Japan is set to issue its first sovereign green bonds, selling 10-year climate transition bonds worth 800 billion yen and 5-year bonds later this month. Investors expect healthy demand due to the scarcity of yen-denominated green bonds, with prices commanding a premium over regular Japanese government bonds. The bonds aim to finance Japan's goal of becoming a carbon-neutral society by 2050 and cutting greenhouse gases to zero. The sale is part of Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's plan to sell 20 trillion yen of bonds to fund green energy projects.

images.alt_text: A screen displays the Nikkei 225 Stock Average figure at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), operated by Japan Exchange Group Inc. (JPX), in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, Oct. 30, 2023. The expansion of Israel’s ground operations in Gaza added more pressure to global markets as investors prepare for a busy week packed with major central bank decisions and a high-stakes announcement of US bond sales. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Franklin Templeton files for spot Ethereum ETF
summary: Franklin Templeton filed for a spot Ethereum exchange-traded fund (ETF), becoming the eighth provider to do so. The move comes after the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) approved 11 spot bitcoin ETFs in January. Franklin Templeton's registration, along with other new entrants, marks a significant development in the crypto industry's push for regulatory approval. Assets in the Franklin Bitcoin ETF total $77 million, significantly lower than competitors BlackRock and Fidelity, which have assets of $4.18 billion and $3.49 billion respectively.

images.alt_text: A spot crypto ETF tracks the market price of the underlying digital asset, giving investors exposure to the token without having to buy the currency.
BlackRock is proposing to convert the trust to a “spot” ETF, which means it will own ether instead of futures products tied to the crypto token.

site_title: Thailand’s January consumer confidence at 47-month high on support measures, tourism
summary: Thailand's consumer confidence rose to a 47-month high in January, reaching 62.9, driven by government stimulus measures and tourism. The country welcomed 4.39 million foreign tourists in the period, a 48% jump from the same time last year. Officials attribute the improvement to policies such as giving away 10,000 baht to 50 million people through a mobile app and waiving visas for Chinese nationals. Consumer confidence is expected to continue improving if the government's economic policies are successful.

images.alt_text: Former Thai prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra will be freed, possibly as soon as this weekend.
An employee counts Thai one-thousand baht banknotes at a bank in Bangkok, Thailand.Photographer: Luke Duggleby/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: Thailand's central bank is seen at the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand April 26, 2016.   REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo
PM Srettha Thavisin has repeatedly urged the central bank to ease monetary policy, saying small businesses and debtors are suffering at decade-high interest rates.
FILE PHOTO: Thailand's central bank is seen at the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand April 26, 2016.   REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo

site_title: Paris Olympics set for gold medal in luxury promotion
summary: French luxury goods giant LVMH is promoting its high-end brands at the Paris Olympics through various partnerships, including designing gold medals featuring a piece of iron from the Eiffel Tower. Chaumet, a lesser-known luxury jewelry house, won the design contract, while Berluti will dress French athletes during the opening ceremony. LVMH is also sponsoring sports ambassadors and will offer luxury drinks and hospitality suites. The company aims to add a touch of creativity to the Olympics and promote its brands to French people and a global audience.

images.alt_text: Team GB's commercial director Tim Ellerton says the deal with TikTok is “a valuable opportunity to introduce a new generation to the magic of the Olympic Games”.
The Eiffel Tower is one of the most popular monuments in the world, with 6.3 million tourists visiting last year.
Designed by jeweller Chaumet, the 18-gram hexagon tokens, representing the shape of France, are made of iron from past refurbishments of the Eiffel Tower.
The cost of getting into the most in-demand sports competitions has risen – sometimes by Olympian proportions.

site_title: Australian business conditions soften in January, costs a problem
summary: Australian business conditions softened in January, with a two-point decline in the National Australia Bank's index to +6, below its long-run average of +7. Business confidence rose one point to +1, while business sales eased three points to +11. Price pressures ticked up to +0.9% in January, despite the ongoing easing in activity measures. The Reserve Bank of Australia continues to warn of another interest rate hike, despite the economy slowing, to restrain inflation.

images.alt_text: Consumer price inflation slowed sharply to a two-year low of 4.1 per cent in the December quarter, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment.
The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates steady at a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent last week, having last hiked by a quarter point in November.
The Reserve Bank of Australia has left interest rates at a 12-year high.
FILE PHOTO: Office workers and shoppers walk through Sydney's central business district in Australia, September 7, 2016.   REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo

site_title: Tokyo Electron hits new high after China demand boosts outlook
summary: Tokyo Electron's shares surged to a record high after the company raised its operating income forecast by 11% to 445 billion yen (S$4 billion) due to strong sales in China, driven by Chinese semiconductor ventures buying legacy equipment amid US trade curbs. The company expects strong demand from China to continue or grow stronger still through 2025, despite potential risks being ignored. This follows a similar surge in Arm Holdings' market value and SoftBank Group's stock.

images.alt_text: Tokyo-based LSTC is working on designs that will enable AI applications on gadgets such as smartphones and electric vehicles.

site_title: Ueda says BOJ to keep policy easy in post-negative rate era
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the central bank will maintain easy financial conditions even after ending the world's last negative rate regime, citing a stable economic outlook. Despite expectations of a rate hike, officials assure market participants that policy stance will remain unchanged, emphasizing a gradual pace for rate hikes once inflation is confirmed durable. The International Monetary Fund supports the BOJ's cautious approach, recommending a gradual pace for rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Many market players expect the BOJ to end negative rates this year, with the most popular timing seen as April.
Young people in Japan are benefiting from a labour shortage that’s especially acute in their age group.
More than half of the economists surveyed by Bloomberg in January predicted an end to negative interest rates in Japan in April.
Markets widely expect the BOJ to maintain on Tuesday its short-term rate target at -0.1 per cent and that for the 10-year bond yield around 0 per cent.

site_title: Aston Martin is in talks to tackle US$1.4 billion debt pile
summary: Aston Martin Lagonda Global Holdings is in talks with bankers to address its US$1.4 billion debt pile, with near-term liabilities totaling US$1.1 billion. The company is seeking to refinance at a tumultuous time in debt markets following interest rate surges. Aston Martin's executive chairman, Lawrence Stroll, stated the company will address its debt in the "most appropriate manner possible" and in the best interests of its shareholders. The company has a revolving credit facility of £79 million and a US$121 million note to be repaid in 2026.

images.alt_text: The British luxury carmaker retains the rest of its 2023 outlook, however, saying demand remains strong as it plans to bolster cash and margins by rolling out next-generation sports cars and limited editions this year and next.
The move will allow Aston Martin to redeem its most expensive debt and become sustainably free-cash flow positive.

An Aston Martin DB12, which combines the British brand’s familiar curves with a twin-turbo V8 sourced from Mercedes-AMG that produces 671 horsepower, inside the automaker’s new dealership on Park Avenue in Manhattan, June 13, 2023. With Formula One making huge inroads in the U.S., the British automaker’s executive chair, and owner of its Formula 1 team, Lawrence Stroll, is ready to test the old racing adage: Win on Sunday, sell on Monday. (Victor Llorente/The New York Times)

site_title: Broker’s take: RHB downgrades Manulife US Reit to ‘trading buy’; cuts NPI forecasts
summary: RHB downgraded Manulife US Reit to "trading buy" and cut its target price to US$0.12, citing weak occupancy levels and lower-than-expected leasing momentum. The downgrade reflects a 10% decrease in net property income (NPI) forecasts for FY2024 and FY2025. Despite this, the analyst believes valuations are nearing bottom and have sufficiently priced in market weakness. The Reit's second-half results beat expectations, with revenue and NPI growing 6.2% and 6.7% year-over-year, respectively.

images.alt_text: Tripp Gantt, chief executive of Manulife US Reit's manager, says priorities for 2024 will focus on asset dispositions and maximising proceeds to further reduce indebtedness and fund capital expenditure.

Manulife US Reit's Centerpointe property. The three US office Reits listed in Singapore – Manulife US Reit, Prime US Reit and Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit – suffered steep declines through most of 2023, but rallied in November and December.
The four properties with the largest percentage valuation declines are namely Figueroa (pictured), Plaza, Penn, and Diablo.
The benchmark index, which measures the performance of Reits in Singapore, gained 9 per cent in December, the best monthly performance since the index’s inception in September 2010.
MUST has completed the divestment of the Park Place property in Arizona, US, as part of the master restructuring plan.
The first resolution, which was to approve the divestment of the Reit’s Park Place property to the sponsor for US$98.7 million, saw 97.7 per cent or 545.6 million votes in favour.
