site_title: Stocks to watch: ComfortDelGro, Keppel DC Reit, Food Empire, Straco, Hatten Land
summary: ComfortDelGro acquired CMAC Group, a UK-based ground transport management and accommodation network specialist, for £80.2 million (S$135.4 million). Keppel DC Reit received S$13.3 million from DXC Technology Services, potentially increasing its distribution per unit by 7%. Food Empire's subsidiary filed a police report after discovering false claims for cash advances, while Straco expects a substantial net profit for FY2023. Hatten Land posted a net loss of RM20.7 million for its second quarter, with revenue declining 21.3%.

site_title: Jailed former Thai leader Thaksin granted parole, PM says
summary: Former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra has been granted parole after serving six months in detention, Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin announced. Thaksin, a 74-year-old billionaire, had his eight-year jail term commuted to a year by the king and did not spend a single night in prison due to an undisclosed health condition. He is eligible for release after February 18, according to corrections department rules, although he could still be detained if public prosecutors charge him for insulting the monarchy.

images.alt_text: “Based on the criteria, Thaksin qualifies for a special parole,” Corrections Department says.

Thaksin Shinawatra, Thailand's former prime minister, arrives at Don Mueang airport after returning from self-exile in Bangkok, Thailand, on Tuesday, Aug. 22, 2023. Thaksin, who faced three guilty sentences for corruption cases handed down in absentia, was ordered by the Supreme Court today to serve a total of eight years in jail. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg
Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin made a pitch to potential investors about the Landbridge project during his recent visit to the US.

Thai politician Pita Limjaroenrat attends the TIME 100 Next Gala in New York City on October 24, 2023. TIME’s annual TIME100 Next list recognizes 100 individuals who are defining the next generation of leadership — Artists, Phenoms, Leaders, Advocates and Innovators — poised to make the climb and in doing so, make history. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)
Thai politician Pita Limjaroenrat said his reformist party Move Forward had to “restrategise”, acknowledging that election runners-up Pheu Thai had control over the electoral system.

Paetongtarn Shinawatra, prime ministerial candidate for the Pheu Thai party and daughter of former premier Thaksin Shinawatra, during a news conference at the Praram 9 Hospital in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, May 3, 2023. Paetongtarn Shinawatra gave birth to a baby boy during an election campaign that has seen her party amass a solid lead against ex-generals who are seeking to extend nearly a decade of army-backed rule. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: US Senate chair wants airline, credit card CEOs to testify on fees
summary: US Senate Chair Dick Durbin has asked CEOs of American Airlines, United Airlines, Visa, and Mastercard to testify at an April 9 hearing on credit card competition. The request comes amid scrutiny of the frequent flyer programmes of major US airlines for potential deceptive or unfair practices. Durbin claims the airlines and credit card companies have "aggressively opposed" efforts to bring competition to the credit card market, protecting billions of dollars in windfall profits. The CEOs must defend the status quo, which allowed Visa and Mastercard to collect $93 billion in credit card fees in 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An American Airlines Airbus A321-200 plane takes off from Los Angeles International airport (LAX) in Los Angeles, California, U.S. March 28, 2018. REUTERS/Mike Blake//File Photo

site_title: Soaring Sydney housing may lead to city ‘with no grandchildren’
summary: Sydney's soaring housing prices are driving young families away, with the city potentially becoming known as the "city with no grandchildren" if action isn't taken. The New South Wales state productivity commissioner warns that strong opposition to high apartment blocks and limited construction are exacerbating the issue. A Productivity Commission report suggests that increasing housing density could help, with Sydney potentially generating 45,000 additional dwellings if buildings were constructed at an average of 10 stories high instead of 7. This could lead to lower prices and rents, and an annual saving of A$1,800 for renters.

images.alt_text: The RBA has lifted interest rates to a 12-year peak of 4.35 per cent in an effort to restrain inflation and continues to warn that another hike might be needed even as the economy slows.
Consumer price inflation slowed sharply to a two-year low of 4.1 per cent in the December quarter, according to the Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment.
The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates steady at a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent last week, having last hiked by a quarter point in November.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as traders return, eyes on US data
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday as traders returned from the weekend, with Tokyo leading advances due to a near-10% surge in SoftBank. The surge was driven by another strong day for Arm, a US-listed unit of SoftBank. Traders are awaiting US inflation data, hoping for a continued downward trend that would support interest rate cuts. However, there is growing skepticism that a March rate cut is out of the question, with May now being tipped as the first month for a potential rate shift.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 38,797.38 on Monday, a new all-time record.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 80 to 47 after 41.2 million securities worth S$55.5 million change hands.

site_title: BlackBerry to lay off more staff in cost-cutting drive
summary: BlackBerry is targeting an additional $100 million in annual profit through cost-cutting measures, including 200 job cuts in the prior quarter. The company is also slashing costs in the cybersecurity business, with additional layoffs expected to provide yearly savings of about $27 million. BlackBerry scrapped its IPO plans for its IoT business in December and plans to split the IoT and cybersecurity businesses into fully standalone divisions. The company expects to achieve its cost reduction goals, despite further job cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Blackberry logo is shown on a office tower in Irvine, California, U.S., October 20, 2020.   REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% at the opening bell on Tuesday, driven by overnight gains in global markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 7.78 points to 3,146.08. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose, while Singtel fell 0.9%. The gains followed a mixed performance on Wall Street, where indices ended with mixed results.

site_title: Hunt for ‘next Nvidia’ draws options traders to Arm’s soaring stock
summary: Options traders are flocking to Arm Holdings, a chip designer, after its shares nearly doubled in price in less than a week, driven by better-than-expected quarterly results. The company's forecast of increased demand for its technology to design chips for AI features has sparked massive gains for bullish options bets, with volume soaring 10 times the average daily trading volume. Investors are positioning for the "next Nvidia," with Arm's shares rising 80% since Wednesday and call options on the shares rising above $185.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is the last of the tech giants to report earnings, which are due on Feb 21.
Nvidia’s H100 and A100 chips serve as a generalised, all-purpose AI processor for many of those major customers.
Nvidia has emerged as a poster child of the AI frenzy and saw a record monthly jump in its market value in January.
Nvidia has in recent weeks been pricing orders for H20 distributors in China in a range of US$12,000 to US$15,000 per card.

site_title: Gold trades in tight range ahead of key US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained stable in a tight range ahead of the US inflation report, with spot gold flat at $2,020.28 per ounce. Trading volume is expected to be thin due to Chinese New Year holidays. Economists predict a 2.9% year-on-year CPI rise, down from 3.4% in the previous month, and a 62% chance of a Federal Reserve rate cut in May.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: American gold bars stand on display during a preview of "Gold", a new exhibition dedicated to the highly prized mineral at the American Museum of Natural History in New York, November 15, 2006.   REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Great inflation hedge unwind sees Tips ETFs lose US$43 billion
summary: US inflation hedge funds, known as Tips ETFs, have lost $43 billion in assets, down from a peak of $99 billion in early 2022. The decline reflects investors' confidence that the Federal Reserve has controlled inflation, with economists predicting the consumer-price index will fall below 3% for the first time in three years. The pullback may also be due to the fact that Tips ETFs were not effective in shielding investors from the Fed's monetary policy tightening, which led to significant losses.

images.alt_text: Chinese leaders are under mounting pressure to act more resolutely to end a stock-market meltdown.
Beijing has restricted short selling and state funds stepped in to buy shares of big banks
Equities in India have been booming, thanks to a rapidly growing retail investor base and strong corporate earnings.

site_title: State land sale proceeds in FY2023 at S$8.15 billion so far, highest in 6 years
summary: Singapore's government land sales (GLS) for FY2023 have reached S$8.15 billion, the highest in six years since FY2017. This is a significant increase from FY2022's S$3.6 billion. The government has awarded 17 plots, including two sites valued over S$1 billion, and has set a goal to supply at least 5,450 private residential units in FY2024. Despite rising land prices, market watchers expect land values to remain stable or fall slightly, with GLS proceeds still expected to increase in FY2024.

images.alt_text: The government plays a critical role in ensuring adequate private housing supply.

site_title: US: Dow ends at record on mixed day for stocks
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at a record 38,797.38, up 0.3%, on a mixed day for US stocks. Investors await key inflation data, which may influence US monetary policy. Despite a slight decline in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index, major US indices have been on a tear since late October. The US central bank has signaled interest rate cuts in 2024, and individual companies like Diamondback Energy have seen significant gains following a solid earnings season.

images.alt_text: The latest milestone in a four-month rally among Wall Street’s main indexes was the S&P 500 closing above the psychological 5,000-point level on Friday.

site_title: ComfortDelGro acquires UK-based transport-management specialist for £80.2 million
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport management company, has acquired CMAC Group, a UK-based ground-transport management specialist, for £80.2 million (S$135.4 million). The deal aims to expand ComfortDelGro's point-to-point mobility services in the UK and Europe. CMAC provides emergency passenger-transport services to various sectors, including airlines, ground handlers, and healthcare companies. The acquisition is expected to contribute S$1.7 million to S$2 million to ComfortDelGro's net earnings for FY2024, with potential synergies in onboarding ComfortDelGro's existing private-hire fleet on CMAC's platform.

images.alt_text: The 11-year contract will be the transport group’s first rail contract in Sweden and its largest rail passenger operation outside Singapore.
COSCO SHIPPING has the best YTD total returns for 2024 among transportation stocks on the Singapore Exchange.
RHB believes the A2B acquisition and higher commission rates could lift FY2024 earnings by 2 to 4 per cent and by 4 to 5 per cent for FY2025.
The research house raises the earning forecast for ComfortDelGro up two per cent for FY2024, and up three per cent for FY2025.
Comfortdelgro will raise commissions for booked rides to 7 per cent, running counter  to what its ride-hailing rivals have done.

site_title: Japan GDP set to confirm slip to world’s fourth-largest economy
summary: Japan's economy is expected to confirm its slip to the world's fourth-largest economy in 2023, with its GDP in US dollar terms shrinking to around $4.2 trillion from $6.3 trillion in 2012. The decline is largely due to Japan's feeble currency and aging demographics. In contrast, India's economy is poised to overtake Japan in 2026 and Germany in 2027, driven by its large and growing population. Despite concerns about its trajectory, Japan's stable living standards and efforts to boost domestic industries, such as semiconductor production, are helping to mitigate the impact of its economic decline.

images.alt_text: Young people in Japan are benefiting from a labour shortage that’s especially acute in their age group.
Japanese household spending in December fell 2.5 per cent from a year earlier, government data showed on Tuesday.
The service sector has been a bright spot for the world’s third-largest economy, helping offset some of the drag on manufacturers from weak global demand.

site_title: SUVs help keep Michelin profits rolling in
summary: Michelin, the world's top tyre maker, reported record operating profits despite a 0.9% decline in sales to 28.3 billion euros in 2023. The company attributed the improvement to a focus on premium products, including SUV tyres, and a drop in raw material costs. Operational profits in the tyre segment hit a record 3.6 billion euros, while net profits dipped 1.3% to 1.98 billion euros. Michelin expects stable global markets and a 3.5 billion euro operating profit in 2024, and announced a share buyback programme worth up to 1 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Michelin will cease operations at its Karlsruhe, Trier and Homburg sites by the end of 2025, affecting 1,532 jobs.

site_title: Australia central bank says inflation slowdown requires productivity revival
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia reiterated that inflation is still too high, despite a slowdown, and will take time to return to target. Head of the economics unit Marion Kohler said inflation is expected to return to 2-3% by late 2025 and 2.5% by 2026, with a productivity revival necessary for this to happen. The central bank held interest rates steady at a 12-year high of 4.35%, leaving the door open for another hike if necessary.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia has left interest rates at a 12-year high.
FILE PHOTO: Office workers and shoppers walk through Sydney's central business district in Australia, September 7, 2016.   REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo

Under an amendment proposed by the Australian Greens, an employee would now have the right to “refuse to monitor, read or respond to contact, or attempted contact, from an employer outside of the employee’s working hours unless the refusal is unreasonable.”

site_title: Europe: Shares near two-year highs at start of data-packed week
summary: Europe's shares rose 0.5% on Monday, nearing two-year highs, driven by a strong rally on Wall Street and optimism about the potential timing of a US rate cut. The Stoxx 600 index reached levels not seen since 2001, with real estate and retailers leading gains. Investors also await key economic data from the euro zone and US January consumer price index (CPI) reading, which is expected to show slowing inflation. European stocks are also boosted by recent US market rallies, with the S&P 500 closing above 5,000 for the first time.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 38,797.38 on Monday, a new all-time record.

site_title: Satisfying end users is key part of digital transformation: OCBC’s Serene Koh
summary: OCBC's Serene Koh, head of group digital business and transformation, emphasizes the importance of understanding end-users' needs in digital transformation initiatives. She believes that if customers cannot feel the impact of changes, the initiative is unsuccessful. Koh stresses the need for seamless customer experiences and the potential for data to drive business decisions. Her team is exploring ways to harness data and AI to create value for customers and employees, and to embed AI models in digital journeys.

images.alt_text: Seren Koh, head, group digital business and digital transformation, OCBC

site_title: ‘Greenlash’ reshapes EU’s flagship sustainability deal
summary: The European Union's Green New Deal is facing a significant "greenlash" as farmer protests and discontent over green policies grow across Europe. The protests, driven by conservatives and eurosceptics, have led to the opposition of key elements of the Green Deal, including the Nature Restoration Law and the Sustainable Use Regulation. This may result in a shift towards decarbonisation targets, with less emphasis on biodiversity and nature conservation. The European Commission is doubling down on decarbonisation, with proposals for a 90% cut in greenhouse gas emissions by 2040, and is seeking a new approach to sustainability issues.

images.alt_text: Tuesday’s proposal will kick off political debate on the target, but it will be up to a new EU Commission and parliament, formed after EU elections in June, to pass the final target.
Israeli military bombarding the northern Gaza Strip on Nov 15. It remains to be seen whether the conflict will become wider or if it will offer a new chance for peace.
Ministers from European Union countries will meet this week to attempt to agree joint plans to fight climate change.
German farmers supporting the EU's Green Deal bill demonstrate in front of the European Parliament, in Strasbourg, eastern France, on July 11, 2023.

site_title: US defence chief treated under general anesthetic, cancels trip
summary: US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin underwent general anesthesia for bladder issues and was treated in a critical care ward, forcing him to cancel a trip to Brussels. The 70-year-old's health scare comes weeks after he kept recent hospital stays secret and didn't inform President Joe Biden of his prostate cancer diagnosis. Austin's cancer prognosis remains excellent, and he is expected to resume his normal duties tomorrow. His deputy, Kathleen Hicks, will take over his duties temporarily.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden's age has once again become a talking point in US national politics, after recent incidents where he confused the names of foreign leaders.
The video posted by the Biden-Harris HQ TikTok account shows US President Joe Biden answering rapid fire questions.
Lloyd Austin continues to retain the functions and duties of his office, says a Pentagon spokesman.
Jordan's King Abdullah II speaks at a press conference, with US President Joe Biden, at the White House in Washington, United States, Feb 12, 2024.

site_title: Macquarie profit ‘substantially’ down; commodities head resigns
summary: Macquarie Group reported a substantial decline in profit for the nine months ended December 31, 2024, due to reduced activity in its commodities and global markets business. The bank attributed the decline to exceptionally strong results in the prior period, including lower asset realisations in green investments and margin compression. Despite this, the company's underlying client franchises remained resilient, with continued customer growth and new business origination. The head of the commodities and global markets division, Tan Teck Long, will step down later this month.

site_title: Malaysia’s biggest port considers new investors for RM39.6 billion expansion
summary: Westports Holdings, Malaysia's largest port operator, is considering external strategic investors to fund a RM39.6 billion expansion, which will nearly double its capacity to 27 million twenty-foot equivalent units by 2082. The port's expansion echoes similar plans from neighboring countries, including Singapore's Tuas Port and Thailand's proposed land bridge. Westports' executive chairman, Ruben Emir Gnanalingam, is open to external investment and is also exploring a dividend reinvestment plan and borrowing to support the project.

images.alt_text: The crisis stemming from the diversions from the Red Sea to avoid rebel attacks has led to soaring freight rates as vessels route around Africa,

Generic photo of general scene at PSA (Singapore) at Pasir Panjang Terminal on Feb 9, 2023. Can use for stories on economy, shipping, ports, containers terminal, sailing, port hub, cranes, shipping vessels, harbour, transshipment, merchant, cargo ship.
Ships on their way to Israel will also be barred from loading cargo at any port in Malaysia with immediate effect.

site_title: Jordan’s king says Gaza needs ‘lasting ceasefire now’
summary: Jordan's King Abdullah II urged a full ceasefire in Gaza, calling for an end to the war, after meeting with US President Joe Biden. The US president, however, wants a six-week pause to allow Israel to defeat Hamas, sparking a discordant note. The two leaders warned against an Israeli ground incursion into Rafah, where over a million Palestinians are trapped, and emphasized the need to protect civilians. The meeting comes as the US works on a hostage deal between Israel and Hamas to bring in a sustained period of calm to Gaza.

images.alt_text: Huthi attacks have prompted some shipping companies to detour around southern Africa to avoid the Red Sea, a vital route that normally carries about 12 per cent of global trade
Barcelona port official says the delays affect ships carrying all kinds of products, including liquefied natural gas.

The Unrwa agency has become more essential since Israel sent troops into the territory to dislodge Hamas. That’s left more than two million people increasingly dependent on food, water and medical aid, according to the UN.

In a sweeping ruling, a large majority of the 17-judge panel of the ICJ ordered Israel to refrain from any acts that could fall under the genocide convention, and also ensure that its troops do not commit any genocidal acts in Gaza.
IMF's Kristalina Georgieva says that if there are other “consequences in terms of where the fighting goes, it could be more problematic for the world as a whole”.

epa11022569 Smoke rises from the Gaza Strip following Israeli airstrikes, as seen from an undisclosed location near the border between Gaza and southern Israel, in Israel, 11 December 2023. More than 18,000 Palestinians and at least 1,200 Israelis have been killed, according to the Palestinian Health Ministry and the Israel Defense Forces (IDF), since Hamas militants launched an attack against Israel from the Gaza Strip on 07 October, and the Israeli operations in Gaza and the West Bank which followed it.  EPA-EFE/ABIR SULTAN

site_title: Indonesia’s consumer companies to ride on election spending, populist policies
summary: Indonesia's consumer companies are expected to benefit from election spending and populist policies, with staples like food and beverages, fast-moving consumer goods, and clothing likely to see gains. Analysts predict stable demand for grocery, packaged food, and poultry sectors due to government handouts and social safety measures. Despite rising inflation, the election cycle is expected to support domestic demand, particularly in the first half of the year, with certain sub-sectors such as food and beverage, fast-moving consumer goods, and telecommunications benefiting.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Defence Minister and presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto  is the candidate to beat, with a 20-point lead in Indikator Politik’s most recent poll released last month, with 45.8 per cent support.

(FILES) This aerial picture taken on May 14, 2023 shows a general view of PT. Indonesia Morowali Industrial Park (IMIP), one of the biggest nickel producers in Konawe Utara. At least 13 people were killed and 38 injured in eastern Indonesia on December 24, 2023 in an explosion at a Chinese-funded nickel-processing plant owned by PT Indonesia Tsingshan Stainless Steel (ITSS) in the Morowali Industrial Park, the owner of the industrial park that hosts the facility said. (Photo by RIZA SALMAN / AFP)

site_title: Commercial-property loans coming due in US jump to US$929 billion
summary: US commercial property loans totaling $929 billion will mature this year, requiring refinancing or property sales. This represents a 40% increase from an earlier estimate, attributed to loan extensions and delays. With the Federal Reserve signaling interest rate hikes are done, more deals are expected to be completed this year. Commercial property values have plummeted 21% and office prices have declined 35% due to remote and hybrid work growth, causing concern among regulators and investors.

images.alt_text: From Chicago to San Francisco, office buildings in the US remain stuck in a slow-burning crisis.

An empty office space in a building in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2023. San Francisco's office vacancy rate reached a record 34% in the third quarter, according to the real estate brokerage CBRE Group. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

An empty office space in a building in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2023. San Francisco's office vacancy rate reached a record 34% in the third quarter, according to the real estate brokerage CBRE Group. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil settles little changed; demand concerns offset Middle East tensions
summary: Oil prices settled little changed on Monday, with Brent futures falling 19 cents to $82.00 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 8 cents to $76.92. Concerns about interest rates and global demand offset Middle East tensions, which had previously driven prices up 6% last week due to threats to shipping in the Red Sea and Ukrainian strikes on Russian refineries. The International Energy Agency predicts oil demand will peak by 2030, but others disagree, with some predicting continued growth.

images.alt_text: Oil is trading within a band of about US$10 for most of this year.
Oil remains in high demand globally despite efforts to transition away from it, with consumption expected to rise through 2030 – and perhaps beyond.

site_title: Bitcoin surges to US$50,000 for the first time since 2021 on ETF demand
summary: Bitcoin has surged to US$50,000 for the first time in over two years, driven by optimism over the approval of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) to own the cryptocurrency directly. The price has tripled in value since last year, with investors re-embracing risk amid expectations of easing monetary policy. The latest rally comes as the crypto industry faces fewer looming risks, with analysts attributing the price surge to "enthusiast buyers" and momentum.

images.alt_text: Representation of Bitcoin cryptocurrency is seen in this illustration taken January 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Global carbon markets value hit record 881 billion euros last year: LSEG
summary: Global carbon markets reached a record value of 881 billion euros in 2023, a 2% increase from the previous year. The EU's ETS was the world's most valuable carbon market, worth around 770 billion euros. Prices in several markets, including Europe and North America, hit record highs, but fell towards the end of 2023 amid weak demand. The UK's ETS value fell 22% to 36.4 billion euros, while North American markets were worth 71.4 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines have steadily increased, and strong winds have pushed up production of renewable energy.

site_title: Arm extends blistering rally as stock nearly triples since IPO
summary: Arm Holdings' shares rose 29% on Monday, extending a three-day rally that has driven its value up nearly 100%, after a blockbuster earnings report showed artificial intelligence spending is bolstering sales. The chip designer's stock has nearly tripled since its IPO and has a market value of over $150 billion, surpassing Boeing and AT&T. The rally is driven by a push beyond smartphone technology and AI-driven demand for computing power, with traders paying up for options and expecting further gains.

images.alt_text: The Arm US headquarters in San Jose, California, US, on Wednesday, Sept. 6, 2023. SoftBank Group Corp.'s Arm Holdings Ltd. is planning to raise as much as $4.87 billion in the chip designer's long-anticipated initial public offering, marking lowered ambitions for an IPO that was once expected to generate roughly twice that amount. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: The virtual loneliness of mixed reality
summary: The article discusses the Apple Vision Pro, a mixed-reality headset, and its potential impact on human interaction. While the device offers immersive experiences, some reviewers have noted its potential for loneliness and isolation. The author raises concerns that this technology could lead to a decline in human interaction and the loss of essential social skills. The article concludes that it's essential to consider the potential consequences of this technology and not blindly adopt it, as it could lead to a future where humans prefer virtual connections over real-life interactions.

images.alt_text: Apple’s main rival in the space is Meta Platforms, the leader in VR with its Quest goggles.
The Vision Pro vaults Apple into its first major new product category since 2015: a US$3,499 headset that melds virtual and augmented reality.
Apple only plans to sell the Vision Pro in the US, with launches in other markets coming in the months ahead.
"The Vision Pro is not ready for mass consumption” Morgan Stanley analysts say, pointing to a bulky external battery pack and the lack of a “killer app”, among other issues.
An Apple Vision Pro mixed reality (XR) headset is unveiled during the Apple Worldwide Developers Conference at Apple Park campus in Cupertino, California, US, June 5, 2023.

site_title: There are lessons from Russia’s GDP growth – but not those Putin thinks
summary: Russia's GDP growth has exceeded expectations, with the IMF estimating a 2.6% growth rate for 2024, but this does not indicate sanctions failure. Most of the growth is in war-related sectors, while the rest of industry has stagnated. The economy remains underperforming, with public utilities and residential infrastructure deteriorating due to sanctions-related deficits. Russia's experience shows that mobilizing resources for political goals is possible, but this approach can cannibalize its economic future. Liberal market democracies should take note of this and consider mobilizing resources for worthwhile investments, rather than emulating authoritarian regimes.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators in Warsaw demanding more restrictive sanctions against Russia and arms supplies for Ukraine, on Jan 8, 2024.
A former KFC restaurant in Moscow re-opened under the brand Rostic's, after American firm Yum!Brands Inc sold its fastfood chain KFC in Russia to a local operator; April 2023.

site_title: Creating a society where seniors can age well
summary: DBS and its partners are working to create a society where seniors can age well. Red Crowns, a care agency, offers assisted-living arrangements for seniors, providing a home-like environment with daily tasks and meaningful activities. GentleFoods, another BFI supported by DBS Foundation, creates soft, nutritious foods for seniors with dysphagia. DBS is also promoting digital literacy among seniors through initiatives such as Getai "edutainment" roadshows. These efforts aim to alleviate social isolation, provide care options, and empower seniors to age actively and independently, ultimately building a more inclusive society.

images.alt_text: The collaboration between DBS Foundation and SG Enable has allowed people with disabilities, such as Muhammad Sayfullah (centre), to pick up financial concepts.
DBS delivers care packages to hospitals, communities

site_title: US commercial real estate push backfires for German lender PBB
summary: German lender PBB's CEO Andreas Arndt is facing a reckoning after the firm's exposure to US commercial real estate loans reached US$5 billion. PBB cut its profit forecast in November, sparking investor concerns, and its bonds and shares plummeted to record lows after rising defaults in the US property market. Despite Arndt's statement that the firm would post a profit for last year, shares fell 5.7%. The crisis is seen as the worst since the financial crisis, and Arndt is stepping down as CEO soon.

images.alt_text: The US commercial buildings sector is facing financing difficulties amid high interest rates and lower office occupancy due to widespread adoption of remote work.

site_title: Nvidia overtakes Amazon in market value
summary: Nvidia briefly surpassed Amazon in market value on February 12, with a market value of about $1.8 trillion, before Amazon regained the lead. The tech giant's surge is attributed to soaring demand for its AI computing chips, which has fueled a stunning rally over the past year. Nvidia's valuation now sits below Alphabet's $1.8 trillion, Microsoft's $3.1 trillion, and Apple's $2.9 trillion.

site_title: Panic among Democrats: Biden described as a ‘well-meaning elderly man with poor memory’
summary: President Joe Biden's cognitive issues and memory problems have become a major concern among Democrats, with opinion polls suggesting a majority of voters believe he is too old to run for office. A special counsel's report on Biden's handling of classified documents found that he would not be prosecuted, but also described him as a "well-meaning elderly man with poor memory." The report's conclusion, made by a Republican special counsel, has sparked chaos in the White House, with Biden himself struggling to characterize the report's findings during a press conference. This has raised concerns about Biden's ability to win the presidential election against Republican nominee Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: Joe Biden gave the interviews that the special counsel report was based on Oct 8 and 9, as he organised the US response to the Oct 7 Hamas attack on Israel.

site_title: Singapore firms see silver lining as Q4 performance downturn eases: BT-SUSS poll
summary: Singapore firms are cautiously optimistic about their Q4 performance, with 64% expecting an improvement compared to the same period last year. More companies, 46%, plan to expand abroad, up from 39% in the previous year's survey. Despite a decline in retail sales and a slowdown in factory activity, economists predict Singapore's growth will improve in 2024, but uncertainty lingers over the pace of recovery.

site_title: X hopes to lure creators, take on YouTube with new ad targeting
summary: X, the social network formerly known as Twitter, is launching new ad targeting features to compete with YouTube. The platform will allow advertisers to run ads before videos from creators of their choice, starting later this month. X will share ad revenue with its 80,000 creators, offering them another way to monetize their content. The new feature aims to lure creators and advertisers back to the platform, which saw ad revenue decline by over 50% after Musk's takeover. X has previously paid out over $20 million to creators, with a revenue split to be disclosed.

site_title: NYCB gains as stake purchase by top executives lifts investor trust
summary: NYCB shares surged 9% on Monday after top executives disclosed a stake purchase worth over $850,000. The move aims to boost investor confidence following a surprise quarterly loss and dividend cut due to commercial real estate loans. The bank's stock is still down 50% this year, but the rally extends a previous session's 17% gain. The KBW Regional Banking Index has lost 10% this year, amid concerns over US office property defaults and the need to refinance $2 trillion of commercial real estate debt.

images.alt_text: More than half of NYCB's total multifamily loan portfolio is secured by properties in New York state.

site_title: Australia lagging peers on AI adoption, productivity chief says
summary: Australia lags international peers in adopting artificial intelligence and other advanced technologies, according to the Productivity Commission. Chair Danielle Wood stated the country is "pretty much towards the bottom of the pack" of Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development nations. The 2023 government report predicts a 1.2% annual productivity growth, down from 1.5% two years earlier, resulting in a 10% cut in estimated real GDP over 40 years. Wood is optimistic about AI's impact on productivity in fields like healthcare and education, but less concerned about negative workforce fallouts.

site_title: Spacs still have a place for fast-growing startups: AvePoint CEO
summary: AvePoint CEO Jiang Tianyi believes that special purpose acquisition companies (Spacs) can offer more certainty for startups, prioritizing the company's interests over traditional IPOs. Jiang, who led AvePoint's listing on the Nasdaq via a Spac, notes that Spacs provide a short-term solution and allow companies to focus on running their business. However, he also suggests that the Spac framework can be improved, particularly with better investor education and clearer targets. AvePoint's recent dual listing in Singapore is seen as a step towards raising its profile and attracting more premium investors.

images.alt_text: In addition to anchoring the development of new products and solutions for Singapore and the global market, AvePoint’s new hub will strengthen global cloud resilience for customers, support data sovereignty, strengthen multi-cloud security, and ensure regional businesses are supported at the local level, it says.
A Spac's cash management, expense fee and number of shareholders can affect its redemption price, say analysts.
Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition says it will announce details of the process to redeem its issued outstanding Class A shares in due course.
Pegasus Asia is reportedly expected to release its announcement by Dec 22, while Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition's will be released next week.

site_title: End of pandemic boom may push some food delivery firms into survival mode
summary: Food delivery firms in South-east Asia, which experienced rapid growth during the pandemic, are now facing a slowdown in growth and increasing competition. Grab dominates the market with 55% of the region's food delivery GMV, while foodpanda trails behind with 15.8%. As growth slows, some players are considering mergers or sales, with Grab potentially acquiring foodpanda. The industry faces challenges such as high operational costs and macroeconomic headwinds, and may need to diversify revenue streams to remain profitable.

images.alt_text: Grab and GoTo have held on-and-off talks to combine without success in the past, after years of fierce competition in ride-hailing, food delivery and financial technology.
South-east Asia’s food delivery expenditure topped US$17.1 billion, growing by 5 per cent year on year.
Grab Singapore managing director Yee Wee Tang says the firm has plans to improve its ride-sharing service GrabShare and carpooling service GrabHitch.

site_title: Futures muted as caution looms ahead of data-packed week
summary: US stock index futures remained subdued on Monday as investors awaited economic data points that could impact interest rate cuts. The S&P 500 closed above 5,000 points last week, with many expecting a potential market drop after scaling a prominent peak. Despite upbeat earnings forecasts and a strong economic outlook, concerns over rich valuations and potential rate cuts weighed on the market. The Federal Reserve is set to release more data, including the consumer price index, which may influence traders' expectations for monetary policy easing this year.

images.alt_text: The US’ share of the global stock market is now 64 per cent, up from around 40 per cent in 2010, and is at its most expensive level ever viewed next to the rest of the world.
A screen tracks Nvidia's stock price as a trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange. Nvidia is already worth as much as the entire Chinese stock market.

site_title: Saudi minister says energy transition behind Aramco capacity halt
summary: Saudi Arabia halted oil capacity expansion plans due to the energy transition, according to Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman. The kingdom has set a maximum sustained production capacity of 12 million barrels per day, 1 million bpd below its previous target. Saudi Arabia aims to reach net zero emissions by 2060, while Aramco plans to reach net zero emissions from its operations by 2050. The kingdom has a "huge cushion" of spare oil capacity to cushion the oil market, and Aramco expects oil demand to increase to 105 million bpd in 2025.

images.alt_text: “The JMMC reviewed the crude oil production data for the months of November and December 2023 and noted the high conformity for participating Opec and non-Opec countries,” Opec says.

site_title: Private credit market reports few ripples from Signa fallout
summary: Private credit market reports few ripples from Signa's insolvency, with demand remaining high despite increased scrutiny and lending rate hikes. Julius Baer's exit from private debt is unlikely to prompt similar moves, but market watchers expect greater caution and tougher regulations. The European Central Bank warns of years of struggle in the commercial property sector, while a BofA Securities report notes a 7.7% default rate for US high-yield bonds. Despite this, 57% of investment professionals polled by Natixis are bullish on private debt, with many firms planning to maintain or add to their holdings.

images.alt_text: Careful and diversified asset allocation is key to Yale's returns. An individual's asset allocation depends on their time horizon, expected return and liquidity tolerance of that individual's specific and unique goals.

An empty office space in a building in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, Dec. 5, 2023. San Francisco's office vacancy rate reached a record 34% in the third quarter, according to the real estate brokerage CBRE Group. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
A probe launched since the initial revelation in November showed that risk managers didn’t have a handle on the complex nature of the Benko loans, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Indonesia, India leading wave of strong growth momentum among Asia’s emerging markets: Pimco
summary: Pimco has expressed optimism on the economic growth prospects of Indonesia and India, two emerging markets in Asia. Indonesia's economy is forecast to grow by around 5% in 2024, driven by reforms and a shift towards higher-value metal exports. India is expected to grow by around 7% in 2024, driven by resilient domestic demand and strong growth in capital expenditure. Pimco notes that both countries have stable currencies, with the Indonesian rupiah trading at around 15,000 to the US dollar and the Indian rupee at around 83 to the greenback.

images.alt_text: After temporarily breaching the regulatory fiscal deficit limit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product in 2020 and 2021 due to Covid-related spending, the Indonesian government narrowed the shortfall to 2.38 per cent in 2022, one year earlier than projected.

site_title: Thailand to create asset management firm to tackle soaring household debt
summary: Thailand plans to establish an asset management firm to tackle its high household debt, which stands at 16.2 trillion baht (S$607 billion) or 90.9% of GDP. The firm, set to be launched in the first quarter, aims to help resolve debts, particularly among lower-income families trapped by high-interest loans. The government has only helped 12,000 people with a combined informal debt of 670 million baht since December, amid concerns over the debt problem's impact on the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has been outspoken about his differences with the Bank of Thailand (BOT) over the policy rate, which is at a decade high of 2.50 per cent.

site_title: India retail inflation eases to 3-month low but no rate cuts expected yet
summary: India's retail inflation rate fell to a 3-month low of 5.1% in January, easing from 5.69% in December. Despite this, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is unlikely to cut interest rates yet, aiming for a sustainable inflation rate of 4%. The RBI has signaled that rate cuts may be some time away, focusing on achieving this target rather than responding to the recent inflation drop.

images.alt_text: The payments firm competes with the likes of Walmart’s PhonePe and Google, and is widely used for everything from buying groceries to household items.
A trader counts Indian rupee notes in Mumbai. The currency has remained largely stable against the US dollar over the past year, trading at around 83 rupees to the greenback.

site_title: Spare UK taxpayers bill for QE losses, ex-BOE deputy says
summary: Former Bank of England deputy governor Charlie Bean suggests changing the operation of the Bank of England's quantitative easing (QE) program to save UK taxpayers billions of pounds. The program has cost taxpayers £38 billion in the last 16 months, with losses projected to rise to £200 billion over the coming decade. Bean proposes introducing a "tiering" system, where a lower interest rate is paid on a share of the £895 billion of commercial bank deposits created under QE, similar to the European Central Bank's policy. This could moderate fiscal risks and potentially save the government tens of billions of pounds.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian crosses the streets in front of The Bank of England illuminated by a ray of sunlight, in central London, on February 12, 2024. (Photo by HENRY NICHOLLS / AFP)

site_title: Australian firms face earnings test after RBA keeps rate at 12-year high
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has kept interest rates at a 12-year high, despite markets betting on easing. Australian firms, including Commonwealth Bank, Wesfarmers, and Telstra, will report earnings, which may be impacted by weak underlying profitability trends and higher impairment costs. Analysts predict further stock gains may be difficult given these challenges. In other markets, Japan's Sony Group Corp. reported higher earnings, while Thailand's Airports of Thailand PCL and Gulf Energy Development PCL are expected to benefit from the post-pandemic travel recovery.

site_title: Global minimum tax – what’s beyond the horizon?
summary: Singapore may need to reconsider its approach to attracting foreign direct investments (FDIs) as the global minimum tax (Pillar Two top-up tax) takes effect in 2024. The top-up tax aims to curb base erosion and profit shifting by requiring large multinational enterprises to pay at least 15% tax on profits earned in jurisdictions where they operate. As this tax is now in force in over 20 jurisdictions, Singapore's reliance on tax incentives to attract FDI may be diminished, forcing the country to explore alternative means to maintain its position as a preferred FDI location.

images.alt_text: Current incentives may need to be widened and future-proofed, both to entice companies evaluating Singapore as a potential investment destination, and to reassure those operating here that they will be supported.
With the rollout of BEPS 2.0, would Singapore have to rethink how it attracts foreign investment?

site_title: Real estate pain for US regional banks is piling up, say investors
summary: US regional banks are facing significant real estate pain, with many exposed to commercial mortgages and multifamily properties. The crisis began unfolding last year after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, and concerns have intensified due to high interest rates and declining property valuations. Investors are scrutinizing banks' CRE portfolios, with some expecting more pain for those with high concentrations of real estate loans. Nearly 1,900 smaller banks have CRE loans exceeding 300% of equity, and Fitch predicts losses could result in the failure of moderate-sized banks if property prices decline by 40%.

images.alt_text: The bank expects to post a net loss of 28 billion yen (S$255.9 million) for the fiscal year, compared with its previous forecast of a 24 billion yen profit.

site_title: IMF, World Bank warn Gaza war, Red Sea attacks imperil global economy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank warned that the ongoing Israel-Hamas war and Red Sea attacks pose threats to the global economy. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva stated that interest rates may rise by mid-year to combat inflation. The conflict's economic impact is expected to worsen with prolonged fighting, affecting the Middle East and North Africa region and potentially spilling over to the global economy.

images.alt_text: Red Sea attacks raise freight charges, but still manageable for businesses: MTI

site_title: Indonesia students protest alleged poll interference by Jokowi administration
summary: Hundreds of Indonesian students and activists protested against President Joko Widodo's alleged interference in the upcoming presidential election, claiming he has unfairly favored frontrunner Prabowo Subianto. Widodo has denied any wrongdoing, but his public appearances with Prabowo and his son's candidacy have sparked concerns about neutrality. Opinion surveys project Prabowo to secure over 50% of the votes, allowing him to win in a single round, and rival candidates are seen at a significant disadvantage. Protests are planned in Yogyakarta and Jakarta, with demonstrators calling for Widodo and his allies to be held accountable.

images.alt_text: Surveys have consistently shown Prabowo is the candidate to beat.

site_title: Greenback ticks up, US inflation data tops this week's bill
summary: The US dollar edged higher on Monday as investors await US inflation data, which could influence central bank interest rate cuts. The euro and pound fell, while the Japanese yen strengthened. Changing expectations of when and how quickly central banks will cut rates are driving currency markets. Strong jobs data has pushed back the timing of a March Fed rate cut, with May now seen as more likely. The US core CPI is expected to come in at 0.3% month on month in January, with the ECB potentially cutting rates soon, according to Bank of Italy governor Fabio Panetta.

images.alt_text: The dollar headed for a fourth week of gains while traders reduced their bets on how quickly the Bank of Japan might raise interest rates and how soon the Federal Reserve will cut them.
FILE PHOTO: An employee counts U.S dollar bills at a money exchange office in central Cairo, Egypt, March 20, 2019. REUTERS/Mohamed Abd El Ghany/File Photo

site_title: How China built BYD, its Tesla killer
summary: Chinese company BYD has surpassed Tesla in worldwide sales of fully electric cars, with a significant expansion of exports to Europe. BYD's sales have grown by about one million cars in each of the past two years, and the company is on the cusp of passing Volkswagen Group as the market leader in China. BYD's success is attributed to its low manufacturing costs, innovative battery chemistries, and strategic partnerships. The company has also made significant investments in autonomous driving technology, with 4,000 engineers working on the project.

images.alt_text: Vehicle sales in China, including those exported, totalled 2.44 million units, up 47.9 per cent from a year earlier but down 22.7 per cent from December, the first such slide since November.
HW 4.0 has already been deployed on Tesla’s premium S and X models, as well as some Model Ys outside China.

site_title: Taylor Swift celebrates nail-biting Super Bowl triumph for boyfriend Kelce’s Chiefs
summary: Taylor Swift attended the Super Bowl in Las Vegas, where her boyfriend Travis Kelce and the Kansas City Chiefs defeated the San Francisco 49ers 25-22 in overtime. Swift, who won a record fourth Album of the Year Grammy, arrived at the game in style, wearing a bespoke Chiefs jacket and gold necklace bearing Kelce's number 87. Her presence at the game drew attention and praise, with some fans criticizing her for drawing attention away from the game. Kelce praised Swift, saying she is "unbelievable" and "rewriting the history books."

images.alt_text: When Beyonce unveiled Renaissance in July 2022, she posted a statement on Instagram that explained it was merely part one of a “three act project” that she recorded during the pandemic.
The tour has been unleashed in China via some 7,000 screens raking in 95 million yuan at the box office – a boon for the industry even though it is not topping the chart.
Now, the famous couple is getting ready for a monumental weekend, with millions eager to follow along.

site_title: Eurozone yields fall after ECB official makes case for rate cuts
summary: Eurozone bond yields fell after ECB official Fabio Panetta suggested the time for a reversal of monetary policy stance is approaching, citing falling inflation. Germany's 10-year bond yield dropped 4 basis points to 2.339%, while Italy's yield fell 7 basis points to 3.897%. The comments are seen as dovish, supporting lower interest rates, although some strategists note other factors may be at play. US consumer price index figures are expected to show inflation slowed to 3% year-on-year in January.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1 per cent lower on Thursday after rising as much 0.3 per cent during the day.

site_title: Google pledges 25 million euros to boost AI skills in Europe
summary: Google has pledged 25 million euros (S$36.2 million) to support people in Europe in learning to use artificial intelligence (AI). The tech giant will run a series of "growth academies" to help companies scale their use of AI and expand its free online AI training courses to 18 languages. The program aims to address existing inequalities in economic security and employment. This investment follows Google's recent US$1 billion investment in a data centre outside London, aimed at meeting growing demand for internet services in the region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: HSBC logo is seen in this illustration taken December 22, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Some US commercial real estate assets may need recapitalising: BOA’s Mensah
summary: US commercial real estate assets may need recapitalizing or restructuring due to financing difficulties caused by high interest rates and lower office occupancy. Bank of America president Bernard Mensah stated that the market is efficient and not experiencing a systemic issue, but some assets will require recapitalization or restructuring. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed concerns about looming commercial real estate stresses on banks and property owners, but believes the situation is manageable with assistance from regulators.

site_title: German finance chief warns of ‘ruinous’ impact of leaving EU
summary: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner warns that leaving the EU would have a "ruinous" impact on Germany's economy, citing its reliance on the single market. He describes a potential "Dexit" as the worst possible scenario for export-dependent Germany. Leading politicians and business executives have echoed this warning, with the far-right Alternative for Germany party proposing a referendum on leaving the EU. The party's rise in opinion polls has put pressure on Chancellor Olaf Scholz's government, which is preparing proposals to boost Germany's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The 20 countries that share the euro barely avoided an outright recession in the final quarter of last year.

site_title: Diamondback to buy Endeavor for US$26 billion in oil megadeal
summary: Diamondback Energy has agreed to buy Endeavor Energy in a $26 billion deal, creating the largest pure-play operator in the Permian Basin. The combined company will have 838,000 net acres and 816,000 barrels of oil equivalent production. Diamondback will fund the deal with shares and $8 billion in cash, with Endeavor shareholders owning 39.5% and Diamondback shareholders owning 60.5%. The acquisition is seen as a maturing of the shale industry and a defensive move for Diamondback, positioning it for future growth and survival amidst a merger wave.

images.alt_text: The combined company will be the third largest oil and gas producer in the Permian Basin of West Texas and New Mexico.

site_title: Thai PM urges royal convoy debate in 'safe spaces' after violence
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has called for dialogue on the issue of royal family motorcades in "safe spaces" following weekend brawls between ultra-royalists and monarchy-reform activists. The incidents sparked a public row, with a 22-year-old activist live-streaming her confrontation with police blocking a royal motorcade. The monarchy is officially above politics and insulting it carries penalties of up to 15 years in prison. Thavisin prioritized the safety of the royal family, seeking to address the sensitive issue in a calm and respectful manner.

images.alt_text: An employee counts Thai one-thousand baht banknotes at a bank in Bangkok, Thailand.Photographer: Luke Duggleby/Bloomberg

site_title: How to ‘rightsize’ your risk-taking
summary: Investors often over-allocate to risky investments, failing to compensate for the additional risk. To maximize expected wealth without ruin, the optimal risk sizing is 20% of net worth, according to Victor Haghani's book "The Missing Billionaires." This is lower than the intuitive 10% or 30% risk sizing, and higher than betting the entire net worth. The correct allocation depends on individual risk tolerance, as measured by Constant Relative Risk Aversion utility (CRRA). Investors should adjust their risk sizing accordingly to maximize expected utility and avoid spectacular losses.

images.alt_text: When momentum is as strong as recently seen, median returns have been at least twice the long-term average up to a year later.
Argentina's new president Javier Milei (pictured above in an electoral campaign ad) wants to dollarise his country. A strengthening of Latin American assets is one possible surprise next year.

site_title: Novo’s top shareholder boosts investments with US$7 billion goal: report
summary: Novo Nordisk's largest shareholder plans to invest up to $7 billion annually by 2030, bolstered by the success of the Danish drugmaker's obesity and diabetes blockbusters. The investment will help Novo meet booming demand for its obesity drug Wegovy. With a market value of over $540 billion, Novo is now Europe's largest publicly traded company, following a 72% share price gain in the past 12 months. The investment will also support the acquisition of Catalent, a global drug-manufacturing company, worth $16.5 billion.

site_title: No-frills airline SpiceJet cuts jobs to ease financial troubles
summary: SpiceJet, an Indian low-cost carrier, is cutting 1,000 jobs, about 10% of its workforce, as part of its "turnaround and cost-cutting strategy" to boost its finances. The airline aims to save $16 million annually and has reported losses of nearly $55 billion in the past five years. SpiceJet's market share has slipped to 5.6% from 7% in 2023, and it has been struggling against rivals like Indigo and Air India. The airline has received a $22.5 billion capital infusion and is also resolving outstanding payments and legal disputes.

images.alt_text: Go has a fleet of 54 Airbus SE A320neos, all of which are grounded.

site_title: Unilever CEO pursuing strategic shift with Peltz's backing
summary: Unilever CEO Hein Schumacher is pursuing a strategic shift with the backing of billionaire activist Nelson Peltz, who is "fully behind" the plan to reinvigorate the company. The strategy involves a systematic marketing approach for top brands, streamlining the workforce, and improving operating discipline. Peltz's Trian Partners has a 1.45% stake in Unilever and has influenced the company's growth strategy, which includes investing in top brands and supporting innovation. Schumacher has also announced a 1.5 billion euro share buyback and overhauled the leadership team, with a focus on performance culture changes and a clearer roadmap for market development.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This photograph taken on August 3, 2007 in Rueil-Malmaison, shows the logo of Unilever at the headquarters of Unilever France. Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch maker of consumer goods and food products announced 02 August 2007 that it would cut 20.000 jobs worldwide, 11 percent of its total workforce, over the next four years. Two million for late payment to suppliers to Unilever France, a multinational company of consumer goods and food products, the Agency for the Repression of Frauds (DGCCRF) said on its website, in Paris, on December 18, 2023. (Photo by Eric Feferberg / AFP)

site_title: How will Indonesia’s presidential election play out?
summary: Indonesia will hold a presidential election on February 14, with Prabowo Subianto leading in opinion polls with a 28-point lead over his closest competitor, Anies Baswedan. A runoff scenario is possible if Prabowo fails to secure 50% of the vote, which would require him to contest a June 26 runoff with Anies. The election's outcome is uncertain due to Indonesia's complex election rules and the potential for shifting alliances among voters. The candidates have pledged to continue President Jokowi's initiatives, including economic growth and social welfare, but their campaign pledges lack specific details.

images.alt_text: Anies Baswedan has portrayed himself as the anti-establishment candidate in Indonesia’s presidential campaign, climbing to second place in polls on the back of a message that includes opposing a costly relocation of the capital to Borneo

site_title: Germany’s office property slump accelerates with record drop
summary: Germany's office property market experienced its largest decline in two decades, with a 13% drop in the fourth quarter and over 10% for the full year. Higher financing costs and sluggish return-to-office trends have soured investor appetite. The crisis is threatening to impact banks, with Deutsche Pfandbriefbank's stock hitting an all-time low. German Finance Minister Christian Lindner described the market as in an "adjustment period," but warned of further declines in 2024. The market is expected to remain weak due to buyers demanding deeper discounts than sellers are willing to offer.

images.alt_text: View of the construction site of the Elbtower building, owned by Rene Benko’s Signa and a Commerzbank subsidiary, in Hamburg, Germany, November 2, 2023. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer

site_title: Swedes turn more upbeat on housing with rate cuts on horizon
summary: Sweden's housing prices show signs of optimism, with households growing more confident in the market. The SEB housing price indicator rose 6 points to 25, with 45% of respondents expecting prices to rise compared to 20% who anticipate a decrease. The Swedish Riksbank may cut its benchmark rate if inflation rates continue to decline, potentially boosting the market. However, the direction of housing prices remains uncertain due to rising unemployment and a large supply of homes for sale. Respondents expect the benchmark Riksbank rate to remain unchanged at 3.77% in a year's time.

images.alt_text: Residential apartment blocks in Stockholm, Sweden, on Tuesday, June 13, 2023. Swedish households are becoming more optimistic about the development in the housing market, according to a survey from the country’s largest bank. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Don’t just wait for the lucky dragon
summary: The article advises investors to adopt a diversified foundation portfolio, rather than waiting for the "Lucky Dragon" to bring good fortune. By allocating a significant portion of their wealth to a long-term diversified portfolio, investors can benefit from historically high returns and beat cash returns and inflation. In contrast, investors who relied too heavily on short-term trades or cash deposits did worse, with the author citing examples of successful diversified portfolios outperforming average annual returns over the past century.

images.alt_text: The US presidential election this year is set to be the most consequential geopolitical event. But would be naïve to regard the 2016-2017 US elections as a template for how the markets would likely behave should Donald Trump win.

site_title: King Charles appears in public for first time since cancer announcement
summary: King Charles III, 75, made his first public appearance since announcing his cancer diagnosis, strolling into a church on the Sandringham estate. He waved and smiled at well-wishers, accompanied by his wife Queen Camilla, before attending an 11 am service. The king thanked the public for their support, saying kind thoughts were the greatest comfort and encouragement. He paused his public engagements to focus on cancer treatment, but expressed appreciation for the increased awareness and support for cancer patients.

images.alt_text: Britain's King Charles won plaudits last month for being open about his benign prostate condition, with doctors saying many more members of the public had come forward with symptoms.

site_title: Hatten Land’s Q2 loss widens to RM20.7 million on lower revenue
summary: Hatten Land, a Malaysian real estate developer, reported a net loss of RM20.7 million in its Q2 fiscal period, a significant increase from the RM4.3 million loss in the same period last year. Revenue declined 21.3% to RM3.8 million due to lower sales and marketing efforts. The company's total market value of development properties reached RM1.1 billion, with RM663 million being unsold completed properties. Despite the losses, Hatten Land remains optimistic about the Malaysian property market's gradual recovery and its ability to continue operating on a going-concern basis.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the Harbour City project in Melaka, which is to comprise a mall, theme park and three hotel blocks. PHOTO: HATTEN LAND

site_title: Argylle sees big drop but still tops North America box office
summary: Universal's spy thriller "Argylle" took in an estimated $6.5 million over the Friday-through-Sunday period, despite a $200 million budget and a sharp drop from its opening weekend. Variety has declared it the year's first big bomb. In contrast, "Lisa Frankenstein" earned $3.8 million and is expected to turn a profit due to its low budget. The weekend's total ticket sales were at a near all-time low, with $42 million, overshadowed by the Super Bowl championship game.

images.alt_text: Bryce Dallas Howard (left) and Sam Rockwell star in Argylle.
Deadpool 3 release date moved from May 2024 to July 2024.

site_title: Wanted: blended finance for smaller, riskier projects
summary: A report by the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA) and auctusESG found that commercial lenders are favoring utility-scale projects over smaller, riskier ones, such as solar-powered mini-grids in India. Blended finance, which combines grants, concessional loans, and commercial capital, may not be available to these smaller projects due to misallocation of capital. The report suggests that project risks can be mitigated through concessional debt and revenue shortfall guarantees, and that commercial lenders should approach blended finance as an incremental opportunity to gain market share.

images.alt_text:
Front (from left to right): Global Energy Alliance for People and Planet's (GEAPP) vice president Kitty Bu, Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) chief sustainability officer Gillian Tan and Asian Development Bank's (ADB) vice president for sectors and themes Fatima Yasmin

The partnership will deploy blended finance, crowding in both concessional capital from the philanthropic and public sectors, as well as private capital towards green and sustainable projects in Asia.
Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu stands in front of the Singapore Pavilion at the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP28 in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, Dec 11, 2023.
