site_title: Wee Cho Yaw’s business legacy may live on longer in property than in banking
summary: Singapore's late businessman Wee Cho Yaw, a 95-year-old banking giant, left his mark in various sectors, including property. His business acumen and visionary leadership led to the growth of United Overseas Bank (UOB) into one of Singapore's most successful banks. Wee's property legacy may live on longer than his banking one, with his sons Ee Cheong and Ee Lim holding key positions in UOB and Haw Par Corporation, respectively. The Wee family may step back from UOB's management team in the future, potentially leading to a third-party takeover or further consolidation in Singapore's banking sector.

images.alt_text: Wee receiving the Distinguished Service Order Medal from then president Tony Tan at the National Day awards in 2011.
PM Lee Hsien Loong with Wee Cho Yaw's  wife Chuang Yong Eng at the late banker's wake on Sunday (Feb 4).

site_title: Australia’s top bank CBA lures funds exiting China despite profit outlook
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has seen its stock price surge over 20% since November, driven by investors fleeing China's battered markets and seeking safe-haven assets. CBA's market capitalization is now roughly double its nearest rival, National Australia Bank, as investors pour into Australian equities. However, analysts warn that the bank's valuation may be at risk due to earnings headwinds, including a higher effective tax rate and shrinking interest margins. Despite this, CBA remains one of the world's most expensive banks, trading at 21 times forward earnings per share.

images.alt_text: Even though rate hikes since last year have boosted interest incomes and margins at Australian banks, the rising cost of repayments has intensified competition in the home loan market.
The move marks the latest blow for Hong Kong’s ambitions to keep growing as a primary Asian financial hub alongside places such as Singapore and Tokyo.

site_title: ANZ's Q1 revenue in line with year-ago average
summary: ANZ Group reported its first-quarter revenue in line with the average of its fiscal 2023 first half, driven by its institutional division's markets business. The bank's shares rose 1% to A$27.93, their highest level in 22 months, following a record annual profit in FY2023. ANZ's lending growth across its Australian retail and consumer franchises was robust, fueled by customer deposits, and boosted Australian home loan book profits. The bank's common equity tier 1 ratio fell to 13.1% at the end of December 2023.

images.alt_text: The firm is continuing with its efforts to acquire Suncorp Bank, with a tribunal decision expected in February.

FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian is reflected in the window of a branch of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ) in central Sydney, Australia, October 25, 2017. Picture taken October 25, 2017.     REUTERS/Steven Saphore/File Photo

Australia's competition regulator said on Friday it had denied authorisation for ANZ Group Holdings to proceed with its proposed A$4.9 billion (S$4.3 billion) acquisition of Suncorp Group’s banking arm.

site_title: Team GB sign deal with TikTok to boost athletes' online fanbase
summary: Team GB has signed a deal with TikTok to boost its athletes' online presence ahead of the 2024 Paris Olympics. The partnership aims to introduce a new generation to the Olympic Games and help athletes connect with new audiences. TikTok's short-form video platform is seen as key for reaching younger audiences, making it a valuable opportunity for Team GB to grow its fanbase. The deal is part of the loosening of Olympic rules on digital advertising for this year's Games.

images.alt_text: More investigations are likely to be added as the EU has been quizzing all designated firms for more information over the last few months.

(FILES) This picture taken on April 26, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a screen displaying the Tiktok social media platform's logo and the European flag. Tech giants Meta and TikTok are contesting the scope of an EU law that from March will set new rules on competition in the digital marketplace. The European Commission has designated 22 big online companies as "core platform services" to be subject to additional scrutiny and obligations under the Digital Markets Act (DMA) aiming to crack down on anti-competitive practices. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)
NHL has previously had players compete between 1998 and 2014, but no deal was put in place for Pyeongchang in 2018 or the Covid-impacted Beijing Games in 2022.

site_title: Australians get right to ignore office calls, emails after hours
summary: Australia is set to adopt a law allowing employees to ignore office calls and emails outside of working hours, unless the request is deemed unreasonable. Proposed by the Australian Greens, the amendment grants workers the right to disconnect from work-related contact after clocking out. The measure, part of a major industrial relations bill, could pass as soon as this week, and businesses that fail to respect employees' boundaries may face punitive consequences.

site_title: Gold takes pause in light trading; eyes on Fed in data-packed week
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,022.39 per ounce in holiday-thinned trading on Monday, awaiting US Federal Reserve officials' remarks in a data-packed week. Trading was expected to be thin due to holidays in Asia, with spot gold oscillating in a $5 range. US gold futures were also steady at $2,036.20 per ounce. Investors will closely watch the Fed's comments for guidance on interest rates and inflation.

images.alt_text: The price of one gram of silver more than doubled in a year but at about 47 Egyptian pounds, it remains far cheaper than the price of a gram of 21-carat gold which rose more than 120 per cent to 3,875 Egyptian pounds.
Lower rates decrease the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

site_title: Million-dollar car sales fall in 2023 for second year in a row
summary: Singapore saw a decline in million-dollar car sales for the second consecutive year in 2023, with 296 units registered, a 15.4% drop from 2022. The tax hike on high-end cars, introduced in Budget 2023, was a major factor, with dealers citing economic uncertainty and buyer concerns about conspicuous purchases amid a money laundering case as additional reasons. The tax rate increased to 320% for vehicles exceeding S$80,000, affecting priciest cars on the market. Dealers expect low demand for luxury cars in 2024, with some predicting a similar market to 2023 levels until 2025.

images.alt_text: Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for most categories fell in February's first round of bidding.

site_title: Toyota's Daihatsu resumes part of domestic production
summary: Toyota's Daihatsu resumed part of its domestic production on February 12, after suspending operations over a safety testing scandal. The factory in Kyoto resumed manufacturing of the Probox van and Mazda-branded Familia van. Daihatsu will resume production of 10 other models on February 26, after meeting safety regulations. The company had been manipulating safety tests since at least 1989 and had previously halted production in Japan and halted shipments of 10 models.

images.alt_text: The Daihatsu Motor Co. headquarters in Ikeda, Osaka Prefecture, Japan, on Thursday, Dec. 21, 2023. Daihatsu Motor offices were raided by the Japanese government after an inspection scandal forced the Toyota Motor Corp. subsidiary to suspend all car shipments indefinitely. Photographer: Buddhika Weerasinghe/Bloomberg

site_title: With tech stocks in a frenzy, the AI party is still picking up steam
summary: Tech stocks, particularly those related to artificial intelligence (AI), are experiencing a speculative boom. Nvidia's market cap reached $1.7 trillion, surpassing that of the entire Chinese stock market. The AI bubble is reminiscent of the 1999 dot-com frenzy, where companies like Amazon and Pets.com were overvalued due to their perceived potential. Analysts predict AI will revolutionize industries, with students already using AI to write term papers. However, some experts warn of a "parabolic" phase in Nvidia's stock price, where every session generates a bigger percentage gain than the last. The AI boom shows no signs of slowing down, with companies adding AI to their names to attract speculators.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A screen tracks NVIDIA Corp. as a trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., October 23, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Sales of iPhones hit US$69.70 billion, growing 6 per cent to beat analyst expectations of US$67.82 billion.
Nvidia’s H100 and A100 chips serve as a generalised, all-purpose AI processor for many of those major customers.
The Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) forecast a 13.1 per cent jump in global chip sales to US$595.3 billion, compared with a drop of about 8 per cent in sales in 2023.

site_title: UK employers plan smaller pay rises for 2024: survey
summary: UK employers expect an average 4% pay rise in 2024, down from 5% in 2023 and late 2022, reflecting less willingness to tolerate higher labor costs. This decrease in expected pay rise is the first drop in nearly four years. The change may ease domestic inflation pressures, increasing confidence among Bank of England policymakers that interest rates will decrease later this year.

images.alt_text: The central bank is watching pay figures carefully for signs that price pressures will stick around longer than they expect.

Two men speak together as they cross over a footbridge in London's central business district of Canary Wharf, on August 14, 2023. The British Office for National Statistics (ONS) will release new data on the job market on August 15 morning. The unemployment rate in the three months to the end of June 2023 is expected to remain unchanged at 4.0%, according to a consensus supplied by Pantheon Macroeconomics. But experts are expecting a considerable slowdown in employment growth. (Photo by HENRY NICHOLLS / AFP)
The Bank of England is watching carefully for signs of domestically generated inflation and is monitoring how much companies try to pass on rising costs to their customers through higher prices.

site_title: Tritax offers to buy UK Reit in US$1.2 billion all-share deal
summary: Tritax Big Box Reit has offered a US$1.2 billion all-share deal to buy UK Commercial Property Reit, valuing the latter at £924 million. The acquisition would create the UK's fourth-largest public property company with a combined portfolio worth over £6 billion. UKCM shareholders would own approximately 23.3% of the combined group. The deal represents a 10.8% premium to UKCM's closing price on February 9 and a 23% increase over its six-month volume weighted average.

images.alt_text: The largest warehouse in Europe, under construction in Dartford, UK, is owned and developed by Tritax Big Box Reit and is leased by Amazon.com.
Skyscrapers give way to warehouses as Covid-19 changes UK real estate

site_title: Judge orders Elon Musk to answer to regulators in Twitter/X probe
summary: US Judge Laurel Beeler orders Elon Musk to comply with a subpoena to answer questions from regulators about his Twitter purchases in 2022. Musk had failed to show up for a scheduled deposition in September and had previously testified twice, but his attorney claims the SEC is "harassing" him. The SEC investigation includes Musk's statements and filings with market regulators, and he has one week to agree on a time and place for testimony.

images.alt_text: Musk said last week that Neuralink had implanted its first brain chip in a human patient, who was recovering well after the procedure.
Gina Carano claims that she was not brought back for season three of The Mandalorian, and the new show was shelved.
Elon Musk's 10-year, US$55.8 billion stock compensation deal blew away all comparisons.

site_title: Biden campaign joins TikTok in push for young voters
summary: US President Joe Biden's reelection campaign has joined TikTok, a move aimed at reaching young voters ahead of the presidential election in November. The campaign launched its TikTok account during the Super Bowl, despite concerns over the app's ownership by Chinese tech giant ByteDance. This marks a notable shift for the Biden campaign, which has faced skepticism over TikTok's potential ties to the Chinese government. The campaign's move is seen as a strategic effort to connect with younger voters.

site_title: Xiaomi says India's scrutiny of Chinese firms unnerves suppliers
summary: China's Xiaomi has told India that scrutiny of Chinese firms is unnerving suppliers, prompting the company to request lower import tariffs and manufacturing incentives. Xiaomi, the largest smartphone market share holder in India, assembles phones with mostly local components and the rest imported from China and elsewhere. The company's letter to India's IT ministry says that "confidence building" measures are needed to encourage component suppliers to set up operations locally. Xiaomi also seeks reduced tariffs on sub-components used in batteries, USB cables, and phone covers.

images.alt_text: The SU7 is expected to make the most of its shared operating system with the company’s popular phones.
Xiaomi posts sales of 70.9 billion yuan (S$13.2 billion) for the September quarter, versus average projections for 70.5 billion.
Phone sales in China are up 11 per cent in the first four weeks of last month compared to the same period a year ago.
Xiaomi’s 14 series has received over one million orders since its late-October launch.

site_title: Fragile-five days long gone as funds pile into India, Indonesia
summary: India and Indonesia, once classified as part of Morgan Stanley's "Fragile Five", have seen their financial outlook brighten due to successful reforms and fiscal restraint. The two countries' credit default swaps have dropped significantly, indicating improved credit quality, and investors have poured $14 billion into their bonds last year. Despite upcoming elections in both countries, investors remain optimistic, citing strong near- and long-term fundamentals. The governments' commitment to reducing their budget deficits has reinforced this positive outlook.

images.alt_text: India, as part of a national manufacturing drive, is chipping away at that dominance, when many companies are looking to spread their work to countries other than China.

site_title: Sanli Environmental eyes opportunities in local coastal protection, climate change efforts
summary: Sanli Environmental, a Singapore-based environmental engineering company, is expanding its areas of operations to tap into the growing demand for coastal protection, climate change efforts, and renewable energy projects. Despite being a relatively small company with a market capitalization of S$27.1 million, Sanli is well-positioned to capitalize on the increasing awareness of environmental protection. The company plans to diversify its revenue streams, with a focus on green technologies, solar energy, and developing countries in Southeast Asia. Sanli's CEO, Sim Hock Heng, believes that the company can hold its own in the competitive market, with a strong focus on adapting to changing circumstances.

images.alt_text: Sanli says Myanmar unit's operations disrupted by political situation
Sanli bags sub-contract for Tuas Water Reclamation Plant
Sanli Environmental - a play on Asia's water story
Sanli Environmental secures S$54.3m in contracts, order book stands at S$134.4m

site_title: Beyonce announces new album in Super Bowl commercial
summary: Beyoncé announced her new album, Act II, in a Super Bowl commercial, set to be released on March 29. The album is the second part of her Renaissance project, with a country-rock theme, and features two new songs, Texas Hold 'Em and 16 Carriages. The announcement marks a shift in Beyoncé's communication style, as seen in her previous surprise album drops, including her 2013 album Beyoncé and 2016's Lemonade. This follows her previous album Renaissance, released in July 2022, which was also part of a three-act project.

images.alt_text: The tour has been unleashed in China via some 7,000 screens raking in 95 million yuan at the box office – a boon for the industry even though it is not topping the chart.

site_title: Oil falls after weekly gain as Iran signals Gaza talks progress
summary: Oil prices declined after Iran's foreign minister hinted at a diplomatic solution to the Israel-Hamas conflict, with Brent falling 0.8% to below $82 a barrel. West Texas Intermediate traded near $76. The decline follows a 6.3% gain last week. Iran's Hossein Amirabdollahian discussed potential hostage releases and a diplomatic solution, while Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu emphasized protecting civilians before military operations. Oil prices have traded within a $10 range for most of the year, influenced by global supply and demand, particularly in China.

images.alt_text: The combined company will be the third largest oil and gas producer in the Permian Basin of West Texas and New Mexico.
The renewed strength of the US dollar, driven by the Fed’s reluctance to risk deflation, is primarily magnifying headwinds on oil prices.
Brent crude futures settled up 56 US cents, or 0.7 per cent, at US$82.19 a barrel.

site_title: Beijing to host 2029 world swimming championships
summary: Beijing has been awarded the 2029 World Aquatics Championships, becoming the second Chinese city to host the event after Shanghai in 2011. China dominated the current World Aquatics Championships in Doha, taking 16 golds out of 29 events. The 2029 championships will feature over 2,500 world-class athletes from 200 countries, competing in six aquatic sports. China Swimming Association President Zhou Jihong praised the award, saying it fits with China's love of aquatic sports and will welcome top athletes to the country.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Paris 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games is seen on tiny Eiffel tower replicas inside an official Paris 2024 store at the Carrousel du Louvre in Paris, France, December 21, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier
Kaylee McKeown at the World Aquatics Championships in Fukuoka in July 2023; she is the first woman ever to hold world records in all three backstroke disciplines.
The Games will be staged at 54 venues – 14 newly constructed – mostly in Hangzhou but also extending to cities as far afield as Wenzhou, 300 kilometres south.

site_title: Hospitalised Pentagon chief transfers duties to deputy: spokesman
summary: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, battling prostate cancer, has transferred his duties to Deputy Secretary of Defense Kathleen Hicks due to an "emergent bladder issue." Austin, who was hospitalized, handed over functions and duties to Hicks, according to Pentagon spokesman Pat Ryder. Austin is still receiving treatment, and the White House and Congress have been informed of the change.

site_title: Biden calls on snack companies to stop ‘shrinkflation’
summary: US President Joe Biden has called on snack companies to stop "shrinkflation," a practice where businesses cut product sizes while keeping prices the same. Biden described the practice as "a rip-off" and urged companies to "do the right thing." Several major brands, including Gatorade, Doritos, and Breyers, were shown in a video posted by Biden. Industry representatives have welcomed the call for action, but no specific solutions have been offered.

images.alt_text: The soda and snacks giant forecast annual organic revenue growth of at least 4 per cent, compared to the 9.5 per cent growth reported for fiscal 2023.

A still from Season 4 of the television series, Stranger Things. Doritos partnered with Netflix to hold a concert of 80s music. For Doritos, the goal was to find interesting new ways to stay relevant in pop culture.
In recent years, dozens of studies have found that people who eat lots of ultra-processed foods have a higher risk of heart disease, cancer, asthma, depression and other illnesses.

site_title: Another shakedown for oil?
summary: US dollar strength, driven by the Fed's reluctance to risk deflation, is exacerbating headwinds on oil prices. China's ailing consumption and delayed US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts have reduced supply-side momentum, causing oil prices to remain stable. Despite a record demand forecast, investors are concerned about the brewing US banking crisis and its impact on oil prices, which have lost over 7% in January. The US dollar's renewed strength and geopolitical stress are expected to continue affecting oil markets, with Brent prices potentially testing the $70-$72 per barrel zone.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 56 US cents, or 0.7 per cent, at US$82.19 a barrel.

site_title: Bitcoin eyes longest winning run in a year as ETFs attract inflows
summary: Bitcoin is poised for a seventh straight daily gain, its longest such streak since January 2023, as record-breaking US exchange-traded funds (ETFs) for the token attract over $9 billion in investor inflows. The Grayscale Bitcoin Trust, the largest portfolio dedicated to Bitcoin, has seen a slowdown in outflows, and optimism about the upcoming Bitcoin halving in April is also lifting sentiment. The asset has risen about 1% to $48,436, bringing it closer to its 2021 record high of $50,000.

images.alt_text: The dollar headed for a fourth week of gains while traders reduced their bets on how quickly the Bank of Japan might raise interest rates and how soon the Federal Reserve will cut them.
Representation of Bitcoin cryptocurrency is seen in this illustration taken January 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Is this the end for Cordlife? (Ep 40)
summary: Cordlife Group's operations were suspended for 6 months by the Ministry of Health after significant issues with its cord blood storage system were found. The company's board failed investors and customers, and more problems may come to light. However, a stock analyst suggests that the stock may have bottomed for now, and the company may need to weigh its options to unlock value.

images.alt_text: While Cordlife is in good financial shape at the moment, it should begin weighing its strategic options before too much value is lost
Mainboard-listed Cordlife was in November slapped with a six-month suspension from collecting, processing and storing new cord blood and providing any new types of tests.
What would adjusting to the “new normal” of higher interest rates and slower growth look like for Singapore REITs?

site_title: AI boom reawakens Silicon Valley’s housing market
summary: The housing market in Silicon Valley and the San Francisco Bay Area is experiencing a boom due to the AI industry's resurgence. Open houses are packed, with million-dollar homes selling for hundreds of thousands over asking. The recent dip in mortgage rates and a year-long rally in Big Tech stocks have fueled the surge, with many first-time homebuyers taking advantage of the opportunity. Listings are flying off the market at the fastest rate in the US, indicating a highly competitive and rapidly changing market.

images.alt_text: From Chicago to San Francisco, office buildings in the US remain stuck in a slow-burning crisis.

site_title: Parenthood, caregiver support, ageing well among possible social priorities in Budget 2024
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 may include social programs to encourage parenthood, support caregivers, and promote healthy aging. The government aims to support families through various stages of life, including young couples, middle-aged parents, and families with persons with disabilities. Initiatives may include enhanced paid parental leave, stronger caregiving support, and increased support for seniors, including the Silver Support Scheme and Matched Retirement Savings Scheme. The budget also aims to uplift the vulnerable, including lower-income families, with enhancements to the ComLink+ program and increased support for early childhood education.

images.alt_text: NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng calls on stakeholders, including employers and the government, to support workers managing work and caregiving.
With significant headwinds ahead, both workers and businesses are feeling anxious about the economic outlook for 2024, said NTUC and SNEF.
Budget 2024 will bring details of moves to boost retirement adequacy, including enhancements to the Silver Support Scheme that provides up to S$900 each quarter to eligible residents.

site_title: Small to mid-cap listcos will struggle more with higher rates than larger counterparts
summary: Small- and mid-cap Singapore-listed companies with high debt ratios are feeling the strain of a higher interest rate environment, but may be more vulnerable to margin pressures than larger counterparts. Six mid-cap stocks have net debt to equity ratios above 100%, with Del Monte Pacific's at 707.1%. Analysts warn that highly geared companies are more susceptible to unexpected changes in market conditions and may struggle to repay loans. Investors should monitor debt levels, debt maturity, and other accounting measures when making investment decisions. Companies need to actively manage or scale down their borrowings to mitigate margin pressure.

images.alt_text: An oil pumping jack, also known as a 'nodding donkey,' stands in an oilfield operated by Bashneft PAO in the village of Otrada, 150kms from Ufa, Russia, on Saturday, March 5, 2016. Bashneft is an upstream and down stream oil & gas provider which explores, produces and refines its own oil and gas which it extracts from brownfield reserves in the Russian Federation. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg
Reit analysts are keeping a close eye on occupancy resilience and rental reversions in the upcoming earnings season.
Company executives have said a 100-basis-point interest rate cut will reduce its interest expense by anywhere from US$10 million to US$15 million.

site_title: S-Reits actively enhance funding measures
summary: S-Reits raised over S$1.8 billion in secondary fund-raising in 2023, with S$1.3 billion from placements and S$0.5 billion from rights issues. Despite a high interest rate environment, S-Reits are actively managing balance sheet health through divestments, capital recycling, and debt facilities. Since 2024, at least eight S-Reits have announced plans to tap debt facilities or raise funds via the secondary market, with notable deals including Frasers Centrepoint Trust's S$200 million private placement and Digital Core Reit's US$120 million private placement.

images.alt_text: One of Mapletree Industrial Turst's assets, at 250 Williams Street NW, Atlanta. MIT’s portfolio occupancy for its data centre segment is at 91.0 per cent (as at Dec 31, 2023), 2.4 percentage points lower quarter on quarter.

site_title: The S&P 500 just topped 5,000. Should you buy now?
summary: The S&P 500 has reached a record high of 5,000, prompting questions about whether investors should buy now. Financial advisers suggest not over-interpreting the milestone, as day-to-day market moves are random and long-term patterns are more important. Instead, consider your individual circumstances and focus on your overall investment strategy. Valuation concerns and market concentration in tech stocks may warrant diversification, while timing the market is not recommended. Experts advise dollar-cost averaging and rebalancing portfolios into cheaper areas, such as international, small caps, and value stocks.

images.alt_text: The current “Goldilocks” period in the US economy, where economic conditions are just right with moderate growth and low inflation, has helped uphold investor optimism.

site_title: Ukraine aid package clears key procedural vote in US Senate
summary: The US Senate voted 67-27 to break a procedural hold on a $95 billion foreign aid package, including $60 billion for Ukraine, allowing it to move forward to a final vote. The bill includes funding for Israel's fight against Hamas and Taiwan, but the majority of the aid will support Ukraine as it enters its third year of war against Russia. Despite opposition from right-wing Republicans, the Senate Majority Leader, Chuck Schumer, expressed optimism that the bill will pass, citing the urgent need for aid to Ukraine.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - A man installs a Ukrainian flag on a memorial for Ukrainian soldiers in Kramatorsk district, on January 19, 2024, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by Roman PILIPEY / AFP)
Unlike America's recent foreign-policy blunders, supporting Ukraine does not involve the loss of US soldiers and actually contributes to national security.
The short-term package is meant to give lawmakers time to complete negotiations on annual funding for the fiscal year that began Oct 1.

US House Speaker Mike Johnson (centre) at the Capitol in Washington, Jan 18, 2024. Despite the urgency, dozens of conservatives in the House voted against the stop-gap measure but Democrats provided Republican Speaker Johnson enough backing to smooth its passage.

site_title: Myanmar junta enforces mandatory military service for young people
summary: Myanmar's junta has enforced mandatory military service for all young men and women aged 18-35, with those aged 18-27 required to serve for up to two years and specialists up to 45 for three years. The move is part of the junta's efforts to contain armed rebel forces fighting for greater autonomy. Analysts have noted the Tatmadaw's struggles with recruitment and the forced deployment of non-combat personnel. Those who fail to comply with the draft face up to five years in prison under a 2010 law that has not been enforced until now.

images.alt_text: epa10779215 (FILE) - Myanmar State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi (R) waits for the arrival of Chinese President Xi at the presidential house in Naypyitaw, Myanmar, 17 January 2020 (reissued 01 August 2023). According to state media, Myanmar's Chairman of the State Administration Council granted amnesty on 01 August 2023 to ousted civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi for a number of offenses, more than two years after she was detained in the 2021 military coup.  EPA-EFE/NYEIN CHAN NAING

site_title: Diamondback, Endeavor Energy in talks to create US$50 billion company: sources
summary: US shale oil companies Diamondback Energy and Endeavor Energy Resources are close to a US$25 billion cash-and-stock deal, creating an oil and gas company valued at over US$50 billion. The combined company would be the third largest oil and gas producer in the Permian Basin, behind Exxon Mobil and Chevron. Analysts say the deal will put pressure on remaining firms to combine for greater efficiencies and scale. The deal, expected to be announced Monday, would give Diamondback's shareholders more than half of the combined company, with Endeavor founder Autry Stephens and family retaining a major role.

images.alt_text: The silhouette of pumpjacks is seen on the site of an oil well outside Williston, North Dakota, U.S., on Wednesday, Feb. 11, 2015. A plunge in global energy prices that has put some North Dakota oil rigs in a deep freeze has yet to chill the state's hiring climate. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg
Exxon results included a US$2.5 billion impairment charge for California properties that it has been trying to sell for more than a year.
The new reserve marks the birth of yet another sizeable tight gas field as the state oil and gas giant steps up drilling deep and hard-to-extract reservoirs, Sinopec says.
China's oil production for 2023 at around 4.18 million barrels per day (bpd) remains below the 2015 record of 4.3 million bpd.

The Chevron Corp. signage outside One The Esplanade office tower, which houses the company's office, in Perth, Australia, on Thursday, Sept. 14, 2023. Liquefied natural gas workers at key Chevron sites in Western Australia have begun ramping up a campaign of industrial action in a dispute that has roiled global energy markets. Photographer: Philip Gostelow/Bloomberg
ExxonMobil has been hunting for big acquisitions in the Permian for years, but the timing was never quite right.

site_title: Mass layoffs shouldn’t be routine
summary: Mass layoffs have become a routine business practice, with 58% of Fortune 100 companies announcing layoffs in 2023 and 5% already cutting jobs in 2024. This widespread practice is deeply corrosive, hurting people, companies, and society. Regular layoffs lead to psychological and financial distress for the affected, decreased morale and engagement among layoff survivors, and increased turnover. Downsizing rarely has the hoped-for financial effect, and it can lead to a decline in trust in the economy. The normalization of layoffs has broken the psychological contract between employers and employees, leading to a deep cynicism about the value of loyalty.

images.alt_text: After laying off more than 1,000 employees in January, Google warned workers that rolling layoffs could continue through the year.

site_title: Are prices soaring in the Year of the Dragon?
summary: Chinese New Year celebrations in Singapore may be dampened by soaring prices, as inflation remains elevated in 2024. The festive basket of goods has been affected, with food prices climbing. The article does not provide specific details on the impact of prices on CNY celebrations.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The week's tanker and dry bulk market saw increased activity, particularly in the LNG market, with several cargoes and tenders coming into play from the Atlantic. The capesize market experienced a boost in sentiment, driven by active engagement from miners in the Pacific and robust cargo lists. Panamax and ultramax markets remained mixed, while the handy sector continued to face general negativity. LR2 and MR freight lost value, while VLCCs saw gains across regions. The LPG market saw greater interest, with several ships fixed away and rates reacting positively, as the market begins to recover from early-week stagnation.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Feb 2, 2024).

site_title: China AI game trains young people to face nosy relatives during Chinese New Year
summary: China has developed an AI chatbot game, "Epic Showdown: New Year Reunion," to help young people prepare for the annual family dinner table interrogation during Chinese New Year. The game simulates nosy relatives asking intrusive questions and users must navigate through levels to appease them. The game gained over 3 million users in its first week, with some playing to vent frustrations and others to practice communication skills. The game's creators aimed to bring humanistic care to young people and facilitate cross-generational communication, with some users expressing emotional connections with the AI relatives.

images.alt_text: Baidu sign is seen at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Wee Cho Yaw was all the governance UOB needed
summary: Wee Cho Yaw's leadership at United Overseas Bank (UOB) for over three decades is cited as a key factor in the bank's success, with his reputation for shrewd management contributing to its status as a blue chip company. While regulators may assume that adding more provisions to the Corporate Governance Code will improve company performance, Wee's example suggests that it may not be a guarantee. His son, Wee Ee Cheong, has continued to lead the bank with success, but Wee's influence remains a notable factor in UOB's governance.

images.alt_text: Directors who do not share the views of a company’s controlling shareholders are unlikely to last long
The issuance of new guidelines follow some controversial independent financial advisor opinions in the past year.

Initiatives to boost the vibrancy of the Singapore market mooted during the recent Mark to Market 'Live' event could become a difficult and disagreeable business if they run up against the vested interests of a company's board and controlling shareholder
If you work for a listco your family controls, does pay incentivise you the way it would for an outsider?
Wee receiving the Distinguished Service Order Medal from then president Tony Tan at the National Day awards in 2011.
PM Lee Hsien Loong with Wee Cho Yaw's  wife Chuang Yong Eng at the late banker's wake on Sunday (Feb 4).

site_title: Active or passive investing? How choosing got so hard
summary: The debate over active versus passive investing has shifted, with active managers regaining ground after a decade of passive investing dominance. High inflation and rising interest rates in 2022 led to a resurgence of stock pickers, with 62% of active large-company funds beating the market in 2022. Active managers argue that passive distortions will create opportunities for those who can spot bargains, while hybrid styles are emerging that mix the two. The lines between active and passive investing are blurring, with index approaches becoming more active and active investing getting more passive.

images.alt_text: Regardless of whether you think a downturn is imminent or not, there will always be pockets of opportunity in the market.

site_title: What ‘friend-shoring’ means for the future of trade
summary: The US is pushing "friend-shoring," a policy to shift manufacturing away from authoritarian states like China and Russia, to create more robust and resilient supply chains. This involves encouraging companies to move production to free-market democracies, reducing dependence on countries that can disrupt the US economy through economic blackmail. While some companies, like Apple, have started shifting production to countries like India and Vietnam, it's a slow process, and the US remains dependent on China for 276 types of critical goods. A disintegration of the global economy into separate blocs could reduce global GDP by 5% over the long term, leading to a poorer and less productive planet.

images.alt_text: Listed equities in Singapore and elsewhere may be in for a rough ride even if the vital US-China relationship does not go badly awry

site_title: Make your company’s data accessible to all to create business impact
summary: Singapore businesses face challenges in productivity and profitability due to labor shortages and higher costs. Implementing "data democracy" can help alleviate these challenges by increasing access to company data, allowing users to perform their own analyses, and encouraging data curiosity through increased literacy. A 10% increase in data usability can boost revenue for a Fortune 1000 company by over $2 billion. To harness the power of data, companies can centralise data, use data visualizations, and standardise reporting, resulting in improved productivity and business performance.

images.alt_text: Beyond the boardroom, productivity may become more important as population growth in developed countries slows down, making it harder to rely on an expanding workforce for economic growth.

site_title: Cohen & Steers increases deemed interests in Parkway Life Reit and Digital Core Reit
summary: Cohen & Steers Capital Management increased its deemed interests in Parkway Life Reit (PLife Reit) and Digital Core Reit (DCReit) on Feb 5. For PLife Reit, Cohen & Steers acquired 2,355,900 units at an average price of S$3.48 per unit, bringing its substantial shareholding above the 6% threshold. For DCReit, Cohen & Steers acquired 825,000 units at an average price of US$0.646 per unit, increasing its deemed interest above the 5% threshold. These increases follow recent buyback activities by the companies, with Stamford Land Corporation and Jardine Matheson also conducting buybacks.

images.alt_text: Institutions are net sellers of Singapore stocks over the five trading sessions through to Feb 1, with S$329 million of net institutional outflow.

site_title: Amazon steers consumers to higher-priced items, lawsuit claims
summary: Amazon is being sued in a US class action for allegedly steering consumers to higher-priced items to earn extra fees. The lawsuit claims Amazon's algorithm in the "Buy Box" obscures lower-priced options with faster delivery times, leading shoppers to click "Buy Now" nearly 98% of the time, often believing Amazon has found the best prices. The case focuses on harm to consumers from deceptive practices, differing from other private litigation over the "Buy Box".

images.alt_text: Bezos has adopted a trading plan to sell 50 million shares anytime before Jan 31, 2025.
Amazon’s cuts add to what’s become nearly daily announcements from technology companies that they are eliminating positions.
Bezos has adopted a trading plan to sell 50 million shares anytime before Jan 31, 2025.

site_title: Amazon’s Prime Video to stream its first NFL playoff game next season: report
summary: Amazon's Prime Video will exclusively stream its first NFL playoff game next season, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. The announcement comes ahead of Sunday's Super Bowl game, which will be available for streaming on Paramount+ and broadcast live on CBS and Nickelodeon. The NFL has broadcast contracts with four companies: Paramount Global, Comcast, Fox, and Walt Disney's ESPN.

site_title: Everything you need to know about ESG investing and the backlash to it
summary: ESG investing, which focuses on environmental, social, and corporate governance factors, has grown significantly but faces a backlash from Republican politicians in the US. Efforts to rein in ESG are underway in about 20 states, while Democratic-led states and activists push back against what they see as ESG backsliding. The term ESG has become politicized, with some accusing Wall Street of being "woke" and others criticizing the label for being too broad. Despite this, global ESG assets stand at around $35 trillion, and some ESG funds argue that they help meet fiduciary duties and generate better long-term returns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags fly outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, March 1, 2023.REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo

site_title: India’s Paytm to form advisory panel on compliance, regulatory matters
summary: Paytm, India's largest payments firm, will form an advisory committee on compliance and regulatory matters. Led by former chairman of India's markets regulator M Damodaran, the panel will work closely with the board. The move comes after the Reserve Bank of India ordered Paytm affiliate Paytm Payments Bank to shut most of its business by February 29, citing "persistent non-compliance". The committee aims to address regulatory concerns and ensure compliance with Indian laws.

images.alt_text: SoftBank has been offloading Paytm shares regularly since at least November 2022 through last month, according to a Bloomberg analysis of company filings.

epa11131189 A sign indicates that paytm mobile phone payment technology is accepted to receive payment from customers at a local roadside shop in Mumbai, India, 06 February 2024. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) ordered the closure of Paytm Payments Bank due to non-compliance and supervisory concerns.  EPA-EFE/DIVYAKANT SOLANKI
Vijay Shekhar Sharma owns 51 per cent in the payments bank, which can take deposits of up to 200,000 rupees but is not allowed to lend.
The bank is important to the company’s app and wallet eco-system, which could be hit if Paytm cannot find banking partners to replace its payments bank.

site_title: Singapore banks bring festive cheer during Chinese New Year
summary: Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB are celebrating Chinese New Year by bringing festive cheer to various communities. DBS will engage 160 staff volunteers with 750 seniors, offering activities such as lo hei, bingo, and singing sessions. OCBC staff volunteers partnered with Willing Hearts to deliver meals to underprivileged families and also took 30 beneficiaries shopping. UOB brought 30 children from Lakeside Family Services to shop for new clothes, sponsored by the bank. These events aim to foster a stronger sense of community and belonging, especially for isolated seniors and underprivileged families.

images.alt_text: CNY shoppers at Floral Far East Pte Ltd
Nicholas Ionides, MBS’ vice-president of communications and corporate affairs, with a senior at the reunion lunch organised by MBS and Care Corner.

site_title: India’s quiet push to steal more of China’s iPhone business
summary: India is quietly gaining ground in manufacturing Apple's iPhones and other electronics, chipping away at China's dominance. The country's national manufacturing drive is attracting companies looking to diversify their production. In southern industrial areas, such as Sriperumbudur, Indian workers are assembling iPhones and other electronics on former farmland plots. This shift is seen as a significant development in the global electronics industry, as India seeks to reduce its dependence on China and other countries.

images.alt_text: Dormitories being built for workers at FoxconnÕs iPhone production complex in Sriperumbudur, India on Jan. 3, 2024. Tamil Nadu is home to 5 percent of IndiaÕs population but 43% of all Indian female factory employees. (Atul Loke/The New York Times)

site_title: Weaning ourselves from love for property
summary: Singapore's approach to taxing property as a proxy for a wealth tax suggests higher property taxes are unlikely to be rolled back. The city-state's property market has seen significant growth, with non-landed residential property prices doubling between 2000 and 2023. For seniors who are asset-rich and cash-poor, options like renting or investing in property trusts may be viable alternatives. The government's stance on property taxation may also impact the resale market, potentially making it more challenging for sellers to realize funds for retirement.

images.alt_text: Generic image of private property in Singapore
It is time to cut 15-month waiting period for ‘downgraders’, tweak ABSD, bring back estate tax, says PropertyGuru.
Replacing the revenue generated through property taxes with higher corporate and individual tax rates could have a negative impact on Singapore’s attractiveness.

site_title: China South City flags potential default on October 2024 notes payment
summary: China South City Holdings, a property developer, is at risk of defaulting on its 9% Senior Notes due October 2024 and April 2024 due to depressed sales and cash flow. The company is seeking financing and working to generate sufficient cash flow to prevent the default. If it defaults, it could have a significant material adverse effect on its business and financial condition, potentially leading to insolvency or restructuring.

site_title: A car-free Eiffel Tower zone? Paris mayor faces pushback
summary: Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo plans to remove cars from an area around the Eiffel Tower to create a green pathway, despite opposition from the police force. The proposal, which aims to reduce pollution and increase green areas in the densely populated city, has been met with resistance from residents and critics. The plan, which was initially rejected in 2022 and 2023, has been resubmitted as a "modified" plan ahead of the 2024 Summer Olympics. The proposal aims to create a "green" Trocadero, a "pedestrian-friendly" Iena bridge, and a "reforested" Champ-de-Mars, but faces opposition from the police chief and right-wing mayors.

images.alt_text: The largest contingent of Eiffel Tower visitors, at 18.9 per cent of the total, came from France, followed by North Americans at 18 per cent – with 13.2 per cent coming from the US alone.

site_title: Tesla rakes in US$9 billion from carmakers failing to sell enough EVs
summary: Tesla generated US$1.79 billion in regulatory credit revenue in 2023, bringing its cumulative total to nearly US$9 billion since 2009. The company earns credits by making electric vehicles and selling them to manufacturers whose new-vehicle fleets exceed emissions limits, with little to no incremental cost. This business model has proved lucrative, despite initial predictions that it would dissipate.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A flagstore shop of electric carmaker Tesla is pictured in Berlin, Germany, November 13, 2019.    REUTERS/Fabrizio Bensch/File Photo

site_title: Doom spending is not self-care
summary: A recent survey by Credit Karma found that 27% of Americans engage in "doom spending" - buying luxury goods to cope with economic and foreign affairs-related stress. The behavior is more common among men, with 33% admitting to it, but disproportionately affects young women, who already face financial challenges such as lower earning power and higher student debt. Experts warn that doom spending can lead to financial instability and is often fueled by marketing tactics targeting women's insecurities, rather than genuine self-care.

images.alt_text: In the current Year of the Dragon, rather than wait to tap on the mythical's luck, investors would do well to commit to a diversified foundation portfolio.

site_title: Hermes to raise prices again after Q4 sales boom
summary: Hermes plans to raise prices by 8-9% globally this year, following a 17.5% sales jump in Q4 2023 to €3.36 billion. The company's strong brand momentum and careful production management have helped maintain its exclusivity despite economic headwinds. The luxury label's sales growth was driven by all regions, with "dynamic" growth in China forecasted. Hermes will also pay a €4,000 bonus to its 22,000 employees worldwide.

images.alt_text: In the current Year of the Dragon, rather than wait to tap on the mythical's luck, investors would do well to commit to a diversified foundation portfolio.

site_title: Three-way race: Indonesia’s presidential candidates
summary: Indonesia's presidential election is set for February 14, with three candidates vying for the top spot: Prabowo Subianto, Anies Baswedan, and Ganjar Pranowo. Subianto, a 72-year-old retired military general, is the frontrunner, promising to eradicate childhood stunting and continue President Joko Widodo's policies. Baswedan, a 54-year-old former Jakarta governor, is polling in second place, opposing the relocation of the capital to Borneo and focusing on economic equality. Ganjar Pranowo, a 55-year-old former Central Java governor, prioritizes access to health, housing, and food, and is promising to carry on Widodo's policies.

images.alt_text: Presidential candidate Anies Baswedan reacts during his campaign rally at the Jakarta International Stadium in Jakarta, Indonesia, February 10, 2024. REUTERS/Ajeng Dinar Ulfiana
Presidential candidate and former Central Java governor Ganjar Pranowo speaks during his final election campaign in Semarang, Central Java, on February 10, 2024. (Photo by JUNI KRISWANTO / AFP)

Indonesia's Defence Minister and presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto gestures as he addresses his supporters during a campaign rally in Jakarta, Indonesia February 10, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
Ganjar Pranowo, Central Java’s former governor, has called on people to vote for him to show “true resistance” against the use of state resources during campaigning, without naming any of his rivals.

site_title: Musk’s Neuralink switches location of incorporation to Nevada
summary: Neuralink, Elon Musk's brain-chip implant company, has relocated its incorporation from Delaware to Nevada. This move comes a week after Musk mentioned the first human brain chip implantation, which is reportedly proceeding well. The change in incorporation state may face hurdles, particularly if seen as a response to a shareholder vote on Tesla's state of incorporation to Texas. Neuralink did not comment on the relocation.

site_title: Oil settles up, notches weekly gain on tight supply, Middle East conflict
summary: Oil prices rose 6% on a week-on-week basis, settling at $82.19 a barrel, amid worries about supply from the Middle East and tightened refined product markets. Brent crude futures rose 56 US cents, or 0.7%, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 62 US cents, or 0.8%, due to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's rejection of a Hamas ceasefire proposal and US energy firms adding rigs. US domestic production returned to a record 13.3 million barrels per day level, and refinery downtime tightened product markets.

images.alt_text: Brent futures closed US$2.42, or 3 per cent, higher at US$81.36 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Barclays bank to stop financing new oil, gas projects
summary: Barclays announced it will stop directly financing new oil and gas projects, but will still lend to existing clients that have transition plans or decarbonisation strategies by 2025. The bank will scale back lending for existing fossil fuel projects and impose restrictions on new and non-diversified oil and gas clients engaged in expansion. Critics say the move falls short, with some organizations calling for an end to financing fossil fuels altogether.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows signage on a branch of Barclays Bank in London, Britain, March 17, 2023.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo
Barclays has one of the lowest valuations among peers, with shares down by around 24 per cent in the last year, driven in part by a hefty disposal of stock by a top investor, Qatar Holding.
C.S. Venkatakrishnan Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Why some CEOs are more likely to engage in corporate downsizing
summary: A firm's decision to downsize its workforce may depend on its CEO's internal attribution tendency. When a company's performance falls short, it can consider growth-related strategies or corporate downsizing actions. Research suggests that CEOs who attribute performance shortfalls to internal factors, such as poor management or lack of talent, are more likely to engage in downsizing. This approach can provide a quick fix to stop organizational bleeding, but may not address underlying issues. The study highlights the importance of considering a CEO's internal attribution tendency when making strategic decisions.

images.alt_text: Alphabet says that it plans to invest in its “biggest priorities” as the Google parent laid off around a thousand employees across multiple divisions, including in its voice assistant unit and team responsible for Pixel and Fitbit.

site_title: Major rallies held in Indonesia as election campaign draws to close
summary: Tens of thousands of supporters of Indonesia's presidential contenders gathered in Jakarta and Central Java for final rallies ahead of the country's single-day election. Ganjar Pranowo and Anies Baswedan, backed by President Joko Widodo, are running against Prabowo Subianto, who has surged in opinion polls with the incumbent's tacit backing. The election, which will determine Indonesia's leadership for the next five years, is seen as crucial for the country's future economic prospects.

images.alt_text: This election marks the third presidential run for Prabowo Subianto, a controversial ex-soldier who was defeated by Joko Widodo in 2014 and 2019.

Presidential candidate and Indonesia’s Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto speaks on the stage during the last presidential election debate at the Jakarta Convention Center (JCC) in Jakarta on February 4, 2024.

Joko Widodo, Indonesia's President, speaks during a ground breaking ceremony for projects funded by private investors at the new national capital Nusantara (IKN) in Penajam Paser Utara, Indonesia, on Thursday, Sept. 21, 2023. Indonesian tycoons are leading the way in investing in the country's new capital city, with a hotel starting construction on Thursday. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: BASF to exit joint ventures in China’s Xinjiang amid rights record scrutiny
summary: BASF will sell its stakes in two joint ventures in China's Xinjiang region due to high carbon dioxide emissions and market pressure. The decision comes amid human rights concerns, including allegations of forced labor in detention camps, but BASF's audits found no evidence of rights violations. The move follows similar actions by other Western companies, including Volkswagen, which has faced pressure to ensure its supply chains comply with human rights laws. BASF's presence in China remains unchanged despite the divestment.

images.alt_text: BASF Investments this year would be cut to 5.7 billion euros (S$8.3 billion), down from 6.3 billion euros projected earlier this year.

site_title: Disney harnesses AI to drive streaming ad technology
summary: Disney is harnessing artificial intelligence to power a new advertising tool, "Disney's Magic Words", for its streaming services Disney+ and Hulu. The tool uses AI and machine learning to analyze scenes, identifying contents, brands, images, and mood, allowing brands to personalize messaging. This feature is part of a broader shift in advertising, as companies move away from traditional TV and focus on streaming. The tool is being tested with six global advertising companies, including Omnicom and Dentsu, and is seen as a game-changer in maximizing ad impact.

images.alt_text: Shares of Disney gained as much as 8.7 per cent to US$107.75 in extended trading after the results were announced, their highest in almost a year.
Disney and Epic have collaborated for years, including through Disney’s Accelerator programme, where company executives mentor smaller businesses.
The new app is a recognition that there is an increasingly large market for sports outside of traditional TV.

site_title: As China woes mount, investment banks brace for more Asia job cuts
summary: Investment banks in Asia are bracing for more job cuts amid China's economic and market turmoil. Revenue pressures have led to staff reductions, with some banks cutting up to 20% of their workforce in Asia last year. The decline in Chinese deals has seen global investment banks' income from equities business generated from Chinese clients slump to $4 billion in 2023, 30% lower than 2022. Despite a promising deals pipeline from India and Japan, fee income growth remains challenging in the near term.

site_title: Citi tells dealmakers to control their drinking at client events
summary: Citigroup has reminded investment bankers to be disciplined when consuming alcohol at client events, following complaints of unruly behavior. The bank's management is working to raise standards after years of underperformance, despite a 27% increase in investment banking revenue in the fourth quarter. The decision comes as Citigroup cuts 20,000 roles, with investment banking less affected than other divisions. The bank's CEO, Jane Fraser, aims to improve the firm's reputation, which has been impacted by excessive drinking at client events.

site_title: Taylor Swift wows Chinese women tired of Xi’s conservative era
summary: Taylor Swift's Eras tour concert movie has been a hit in China, attracting young, female audiences with its feminist lyrics and celebration of LGBTQ freedoms. The show's values contrast with President Xi Jinping's conservative vision for women, providing a rare outlet for young women rejecting social controls. The movie has raked in 95 million yuan at the box office, despite not topping the chart, and has sparked praise from fans and experts, who see Swift as a symbol of female empowerment and a rare voice in China's patriarchal society.

images.alt_text: Now, the famous couple is getting ready for a monumental weekend, with millions eager to follow along.
The Asia leg of Taylor Swift’s tour kicks off on Wednesday with the first of four planned shows, although it is the last, on Saturday, that’s causing the biggest stir.
Taylor Swift accepts the award for Album of the Year for "Midnights" during the 66th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles, California, Feb 4, 2024.

site_title: ‘Zombie offices’ spell trouble for some US banks
summary: US office buildings face a slow-burning crisis due to low occupancy rates, with many buildings in Chicago, San Francisco, and other cities experiencing occupancy rates as low as 17%. The pandemic's shift to remote work has not been reversed, and high interest rates have further reduced the value of office properties. Prices have tumbled 35% from their peak in early 2022, with some buildings selling for significantly less than their pre-pandemic values. This crisis is affecting major US cities, with many office buildings struggling to find tenants.

images.alt_text: CHICAGO, ILLINOIS - NOVEMBER 13: The Chicago skyline rises above the Chicago River on November 13, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. site_title: Special counsel report on Biden memory is wrong, White House says
summary: The White House has criticized a report from Special Counsel Robert Hur that suggested President Joe Biden was suffering from memory lapses, with Vice President Kamala Harris calling the report "clearly politically motivated." The report, which did not result in criminal charges against Biden, described him as a "well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory." White House spokesperson Ian Sams rejected the characterization, saying it was "really out of bounds," and Biden himself reacted furiously to the comment about his late son.

images.alt_text: The report removed a legal cloud hanging over Joe Biden as he seeks reelection in a contest expected to be against Donald Trump - who is facing a criminal trial for removing large amounts of secret documents after he lost the White House.

President Joe Biden at an event in August 2023. His accomplishments during his term in office amount to little short of an economic revolution for America -- one shaped by faith in government and a mistrust of markets.

site_title: TikTok faces fine as EU prepares probe over risks to minors
summary: The European Union is preparing a probe into TikTok over concerns it is not doing enough to protect minors under the bloc's new Digital Services Act. The investigation, which may result in fines of up to 6% of annual sales or even a ban from the EU, follows similar probes into other major tech companies such as Meta and X. EU regulators have been quizzing TikTok and other firms since December over their content moderation practices and potential breaches of the new regulation, which gives regulators unprecedented powers to take action against tech companies.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This picture taken on April 26, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a screen displaying the Tiktok social media platform's logo and the European flag. Tech giants Meta and TikTok are contesting the scope of an EU law that from March will set new rules on competition in the digital marketplace. The European Commission has designated 22 big online companies as "core platform services" to be subject to additional scrutiny and obligations under the Digital Markets Act (DMA) aiming to crack down on anti-competitive practices. site_title: Hermes overtakes L’Oreal to become France’s second most valuable firm
summary: Hermes International SCA has overtaken L'Oreal to become France's second most valuable firm, with a market capitalization of 230 billion euros, surpassing L'Oreal's 225 billion euros. Hermes' strong revenue report and exposure to the ultra-rich shielded it from the slump in the high-end goods market, resulting in a 6.3% increase in its stock to a record high. This marks the first time Hermes has surpassed L'Oreal in value.

site_title: Apple to settle trade secrets lawsuit against chip startup Rivos
summary: Apple has agreed to settle a trade secrets lawsuit against chip startup Rivos, according to a joint court filing. The agreement allows Apple to examine Rivos' systems and recover confidential information. The lawsuit, filed in 2022, accused Rivos of stealing Apple's trade secrets related to computer-chip technology. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed, but representatives for both companies declined to comment. The settlement brings an end to a lawsuit that began over two years ago.

images.alt_text: Apple’s main rival in the space is Meta Platforms, the leader in VR with its Quest goggles.

site_title: Sony buys Michael Jackson music for US$600 million: Billboard
summary: Sony Group is acquiring a half interest in Michael Jackson's music catalogue for at least $600 million, the largest such deal ever. The agreement includes master recordings and publishing rights for Jackson's songs, as well as the Mijac catalogue, which may also include songs from other artists. This deal follows Jackson's estate selling its half interest in Sony/ATV Music Publishing, a joint venture that included the Beatles songs.

site_title: ASML’s next chip challenge: rollout of its new US$350 million ‘High NA EUV’ machine
summary: ASML, the sole manufacturer of extreme ultraviolet photolithography, is gearing up to produce its new $350 million "High NA EUV" machine, aimed at Intel and other high-end semiconductor makers. The machine, which can shrink chip features by up to 40%, is expected to be shipped this year, with analysts questioning how many customers will adopt it due to its high cost. ASML expects to deliver 20 machines annually by 2028, with some customers, like Intel, already taking delivery of pilot devices. The technology's adoption is seen as crucial for ASML's dominant position in the market, but its high cost may limit its adoption.

images.alt_text: The surge has allowed ASML to overtake Swiss food group Nestle as Europe’s third-largest listed company.
ASML registers strong orders of more than nine billion euros in the fourth quarter – more than triple third-quarter levels.

site_title: Mixed US consumer price revisions leave slowing inflation trend intact
summary: US consumer prices rose less than initially thought in December, with the annual revision showing a 0.2% increase instead of 0.3%. However, the overall inflation trend remains intact, with core goods prices falling in the first half and the increase in services revised down for November and December. The revisions did not alter expectations for a potential interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve this year, with economists expecting inflation to cool considerably in the coming months.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Cranes wait to unload cargo shipping containers from ships at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California on June 7, 2023. The trade gap shrank to $58.3 billion, down nearly 10 percent from July's revised figure of $64.7 billion, said the Commerce Department. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: Cisco to cut thousands of jobs as it seeks to focus on high growth areas: sources
summary: Cisco plans to restructure its business, including laying off thousands of employees, to focus on high-growth areas. The company, with 84,900 employees as of fiscal 2023, is still deciding on the number of employees to be affected. This move comes after Cisco cut its full-year revenue and profit forecasts in its previous earnings call, citing a slowdown in orders. The restructuring announcement could come as early as next week, ahead of the company's earnings call on February 14.

images.alt_text: Cisco’s report shows that slowing orders for networking hardware are taking their toll on growth.

site_title: PepsiCo signals demand hit from price hikes with rare sales decline
summary: PepsiCo reported a surprise drop in quarterly sales and forecast a slowdown in organic revenue growth for 2024 due to multiple price hikes weighing on demand for its beverages and chips. The company attributed the decline to consumers baulking at higher prices in the US, where demand has started to wane. CEO Ramon Laguarta stated that both food and beverages slowed in the fourth quarter, partly due to pricing and tightening household budgets. The company forecast annual organic revenue growth of at least 4%, down from 9.5% in fiscal 2023.

images.alt_text: From Thursday (Jan 4), shelves with PepsiCo products at Carrefour stores in France will be accompanied by a note saying “We are no longer selling this brand due to unacceptable price increases”.

site_title: Hyundai picks JPMorgan, Citi to accelerate US$3 billion India IPO: sources
summary: Hyundai Motor has appointed investment bankers JPMorgan and Citi to advise on its planned at least US$3 billion initial public offering (IPO) in India. The company plans to file regulatory papers by May-June and is considering an IPO that could value its local operation at up to US$30 billion, making it India's largest. This move comes amid hopes for political stability after the upcoming elections, which is expected to boost IPO activity in the country.

site_title: Renault, Geely expect to finalise engines tie-up this month: sources
summary: Renault and Geely are expected to finalize a joint venture for combustion and hybrid engines by the end of February, with Saudi Aramco set to invest in the venture. The deal, valued at 15 billion euros, will supply engines to both Renault and Geely brands, as well as third-party manufacturers. Renault aims to bolster its legacy business and make headway with electric vehicles, while Geely seeks to expand its presence in the market. The partnership is a key strategy for Renault to stay competitive against larger rivals like Stellantis.

site_title: Preparing your portfolio for an economic slowdown in 2024
summary: Investors should consider preparing their portfolios for a potential economic slowdown in 2024, regardless of whether a recession is imminent. High-quality assets, such as investment-grade bonds, offer attractive yields and relatively low default risk. Investment-grade bonds, including Treasury bonds and corporate bonds, can provide a "soft landing" for investors, offering a buffer against potential economic downturns. Additionally, companies with investment-grade credit ratings may offer attractive alternatives to owning their stocks, with historically low default risk and the potential for outperforming stocks in recessions.

images.alt_text: america, the dollar, president
Moving into 2024, Asian currencies will likely be most affected by the US monetary policy and China’s growth.

site_title: SoftBank sees new-found caution as secret weapon in AI arms race
summary: SoftBank Group, led by founder Masayoshi Son, is adopting a new strategy in the AI arms race, relying on caution after splashing out billions on startups at near-peak valuations. This marks a turnaround for the company, which previously transformed the tech investing world with high-conviction bets on startups. The move is also a result of "defence mode" adopted after the pandemic, when higher interest rates eroded investor appetite for risk. SoftBank is now taking a more measured approach to investing in AI, seeking the next big thing without overpaying.

images.alt_text: SoftBank has been offloading Paytm shares regularly since at least November 2022 through last month, according to a Bloomberg analysis of company filings.

site_title: US: S&P 500 ends above 5,000 points for first time, extending rally
summary: The S&P 500 closed above 5,000 points for the first time, extending its rally, as solid earnings and economic data boosted investor confidence that the US economy can avoid a recession. The index finished at 5,026.61, up 0.6%, marking its 10th closing record of 2024. The Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.3%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 0.1%. The rally follows a period of easing inflation and the Federal Reserve's pivot away from aggressive interest rate increases.

site_title: For US$119,000 you can catch Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce in the same weekend
summary: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce are set to attend the Super Bowl and her Eras Tour in Japan, respectively, on the same weekend. Fans are eager to catch a glimpse of the couple, but attending both events is expensive, with ticket prices ranging from $231 to $78,000 for Swift's concert and $5,008 to $78,000 for Kelce's game. Flights from Japan to Las Vegas can cost $823 to $7,520, and lodging options vary from $350 to $4,000. The total cost for a luxury trip to see both events is estimated to be around $119,000, making it inaccessible to most fans, who may watch clips online instead.

site_title: Built to last: Why companies should be building more new businesses
summary: Companies in South-east Asia are prioritizing building new businesses, with almost half saying it's become a higher priority over the last year. Despite this, only a third of business leaders consider it a top five priority. The main reasons for hesitation include risk aversion, budget constraints, internal resistance, and a shortage of expertise. To improve success rates, companies should focus on existing capabilities, contain pressure on the budget, and explore external funding sources. By adopting resource-light strategies and establishing a separate business-building budget, companies can increase their chances of success and build new businesses that can drive growth and revenue.

site_title: The hongbao conundrum
summary: A Singaporean couple grapples with the dilemma of deciding how much to give in red packets during Chinese New Year. Despite researching online, they received vague and conflicting advice, with some suggesting it depends on the recipient's closeness to their spouse. The couple ultimately decides to give the same amount to everyone, citing that it's the thought that counts, and will factor in inflation and market rate adjustments annually. This approach aims to avoid perceived competition and promote equality, but its effectiveness remains to be seen.

site_title: Nvidia chases US$30 billion custom chip market with new unit: sources
summary: Nvidia is launching a new business unit to design bespoke chips for cloud computing firms and others, including advanced artificial intelligence (AI) processors. The move aims to capture a portion of the growing market for custom AI chips, which is estimated to reach $30 billion by 2025. Nvidia currently controls 80% of the high-end AI chip market, but companies like OpenAI, Microsoft, and Meta are developing their own internal chips to reduce energy consumption and costs. Nvidia's goal is to make its technology available to customers in various industries, including cloud, 5G wireless, video games, and automotives.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has emerged as a poster child of the AI frenzy and saw a record monthly jump in its market value in January.

site_title: After months of negotiation, a rare Russian compromise as Yandex changes hands
summary: A consortium of Russian investors has agreed to buy Yandex, Russia's largest search engine, for $5.2 billion, eliminating Western oversight and tightening Kremlin control over the internet. The deal, after 18 months of negotiations, marks a rare compromise for the Russian government, which had initially sought to seize Yandex's assets. The new ownership structure will see a group of Yandex managers hold a 35% stake, while oil major Lukoil and businessmen own the remaining 65%. The deal is seen as a relief for Yandex, which had faced expropriation risk, and a significant blow to Western investors.

summary: The Toyota Vellfire is a unique, Japanese take on overland luxury travel, offering a high-end experience despite not being a luxury car. The vehicle features armchairs fit for royalty, providing a comfortable ride for passengers. Its spacious interior and hybrid powertrain make it ideal for long trips, while its unconventional design sets it apart from traditional luxury vehicles.

site_title: Singapore’s growth ‘ought to be stronger’ in 2024; more support for parenthood to come: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the country's economic growth in 2024 is expected to be stronger than last year, despite uncertainties, with a growth forecast of 1-3%. The growth is driven by a recovering manufacturing sector, a strong construction pipeline, and continued recovery in services and tourism. PM Lee also hinted at additional support for parenthood in the upcoming Budget 2024, following previous initiatives such as preschool, flexible work arrangements, and baby bonuses.

site_title: Red packets that aren’t red? More demand for other colours this CNY
summary: Printers in Singapore have noticed an increase in orders for hongbao, or red packets, in non-traditional colors such as gold, pink, and cream. Despite overall demand for the slim envelopes falling, corporate buyers are cutting back on their orders, while individual consumers are opting for alternative colors. The traditional red hue remains the most popular, but gold and pink are gaining traction, offering a change from the traditional red packets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 9)
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong joined staff from Ng Teng Fong General Hospital for Chinese New Year celebrations on Friday, as part of his annual visit to workers. During a press conference, PM Lee expressed hopes for stronger growth in Singapore in 2024, but emphasized that this depends on US economic conditions and China's economic revival.

site_title: China January new bank loans hit record high on policy support
summary: China's banks extended a record 4.92 trillion yuan (S$921.18 billion) in new yuan loans in January, surpassing analysts' expectations and beating the previous record. The central bank's policy support and measures to shore up the economy amid a deep property crisis and prolonged stock market rout contributed to the surge. January lending more than quadrupled from December's 1.17 trillion yuan, with household loans and corporate loans also rising sharply.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China has rarely made such a broad easing move so close to the break.

site_title: The place of Michelin stars in the arc of the universe
summary: Michelin has announced its latest restaurant rankings, with several notable awards, including a third Michelin star for Noor in Cordoba and a first star for Chishuru, a West African restaurant in London, making Adejoke Bakare the first Black woman chef in the UK to receive the honor. The recognition is seen as a step towards justice in the culinary industry, where minority chefs often face challenges and biases. Ferran Adria, a legendary Spanish chef, has praised the impact of Michelin stars on the industry, while also acknowledging the artificial nature of the rankings.

site_title: Grab, GoTo to revive talks for ride-hailing mega-merger: sources
summary: Grab Holdings and GoTo Group, Southeast Asia's largest ride-hailing companies, have restarted talks for a potential merger, aiming to boost profitability after years of losses due to fierce competition. Discussions are in preliminary stages, with Grab potentially acquiring GoTo using cash, stock, or a combination of both. Major shareholders support the deal, and options include splitting markets or merging to raise rates and find synergies. However, valuation, deal structure, and governance remain key hurdles, and a merger would face intense scrutiny from regulators.
