site_title: Marubeni, Engie weigh exit from Singapore’s Senoko Energy: sources
summary: Majority shareholders of Singapore-based Senoko Energy are considering selling their stakes, valuing the company at up to $3 billion. Japan's Marubeni Corp and French utility Engie, each owning 30% of the firm, are working with financial advisers on the potential divestment. This could be the first of several power asset sales in Singapore, following Temasek Holdings and Shell's plans to sell assets. Senoko Energy has been a key energy provider in Singapore since 1977, supplying about 20% of the country's electricity needs.

summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman is in talks with investors, including the UAE, to raise up to $5 trillion to boost the world's chip-building capacity and expand its AI capabilities. The funds aim to address the scarcity of AI chips required for training large language models. Altman is pitching a partnership between OpenAI, investors, and chipmakers to build chip foundries. The discussions are in early stages, and the project's feasibility and funding details remain unclear.

site_title: Europe: Shares see off week lower as rising yields, L’Oreal losses weigh
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1% lower on Friday, despite a 0.2% weekly gain, as rising government bond yields and L'Oreal's 7.6% drop weighed on shares. Advances in Ubisoft and Hermes were offset by weak earnings reports, with healthcare stocks being the top gainers. The week's modest gain was largely driven by strong quarterly earnings updates, but concerns over elevated interest rates kept gains in check.

REUTERS/Staff/File Photo

site_title: New champions await coronation as Asian, African football finals loom
summary: The Asian Cup and Africa Cup of Nations finals are set to take place this weekend, with Qatar and Ivory Coast vying for the top spots. Qatar, favored to win the Asian Cup, will face Jordan in the final, while Ivory Coast will face Nigeria in the African Cup of Nations final. The finals are expected to be closely contested, with Jordan having pulled off surprise victories in the tournament, and Ivory Coast overcoming seemingly insurmountable odds under new coach Emerse Fae. Both teams are determined to bring home the trophy, with the winners being crowned the champions of their respective regions.

images.alt_text: Art and sports rarely mix in France. As a rule, the country’s artistic output leans toward intellectualism rather than the virtuosity embodied by high-level athletes.
Messi’s no-show at the highly anticipated match in Hong Kong on Sunday caused a furore that has shown no sign of waning, with fans still demanding answers and a refund three days on.
Top-flight clubs in England collectively spent about £100 million this January, a drop of around 88 per cent from the same time last year
Petronas has been a sponsor of the Mercedes team since 2010, with the partnership bearing eight constructors’ and seven drivers’ world championships.

site_title: What the next stage of Internet privacy means for business
summary: Google is eliminating third-party cookies to meet increasing demands for user privacy and safety online. Starting with 30 million Chrome users, the move aims to reduce data collection by businesses, keeping data within users' devices instead of sending it to advertisers. The initiative, part of Google's Privacy Sandbox, will eventually reach all users by Q3 this year. This change could reorient companies' data relationships with consumers and transform the entire Internet business model. The goal is to combat scams and phishing campaigns that misuse personal information.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This illustration photograph taken on October 30, 2023 in Mulhouse, eastern France, shows figurines next to a screen displaying a logo of Google, a US multinational technology company. The Canadian government and Google announced on November 29, 2023 a "historic" deal to support the country's media, heading off an imminent threat by the digital giant to block news on its platform. (Photo by SEBASTIEN BOZON / AFP)

site_title: China's consumer slump claims another victim as Shiseido profit slides
summary: Shiseido, a Japanese cosmetics maker, reported a 40% slide in annual earnings due to China's weak consumer spending. The company's operating profit dropped to 28.13 billion yen (S$253.5 million) in the 12 months ended in December, compared to 46.6 billion yen the prior year. This decline follows similar earnings drops at L'Oreal and Estee Lauder, which have been impacted by China's tightening purse strings and crackdown on foreign consumer goods.

images.alt_text: L’Oreal follows disappointing results last week at luxury group LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, whose perfume and cosmetics unit also missed estimates.
Estee Lauder says it would start the programme in the third quarter of fiscal 2024 and expects to take on restructuring and other charges of between US$500 million and US$700 million, before taxes.

site_title: Year of the Dragon: A time for reflection and setting goals
summary: The Year of the Dragon, a time associated with good fortune and nobility in Chinese culture, marks a significant year for families looking to start or expand their families. Research from the National University of Singapore estimates that Singaporean Chinese births increase by 9.3% in dragon years, but this year's challenges include rising costs of living and geopolitical uncertainty, making it more difficult to achieve financial goals. As families plan for the future, conversations around wealth transfer, previously considered taboo, are becoming more important for long-term financial stability.

images.alt_text: BT
A cash return threshold of 5% is less difficult to beat today. Most bond yields or income assets already offer yields higher than cash.

site_title: Hermes sales jump as Birkin bag maker weathers luxury slowdown
summary: Hermes' sales surged 17.5% in the fourth quarter, beating analysts' expectations, as the luxury brand weathered a slowdown in demand for high-end goods. The company's unique model, driven by scarcity, continues to attract wealthy customers willing to splurge on its handbags and silk scarves. Revenue rose to 5.65 billion euros, and the company plans an 8-9% price hike in 2024. Despite a mixed industry picture, Hermes' results demonstrate resilience, with all divisions growing by at least 10%.

site_title: From tobacco to banking, how Indonesia’s Hartono brothers amassed a US$48 billion fortune
summary: The Hartono brothers, Michael and Robert, are Indonesia's wealthiest individuals, with a combined net worth of US$48 billion. They inherited their US$48 billion fortune from their late father, who acquired a bankrupt cigarette company in 1950 and rebranded it as Djarum. The brothers expanded the company, producing kretek cigarettes, which became a staple in Indonesia. They also diversified into banking, real estate, and electronics, and have invested in digital ventures, including an e-commerce giant and a venture capital firm. Their wealth has enabled them to give back to society through education and sports scholarships, but they have faced challenges, including a loss in a two-year legal battle over their logo in athletes' uniforms.

images.alt_text: Michael Bambang Hartono, co-owner of Djarum Group, stands for a photograph following an interview in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Aug. 21, 2018. Hartono, the 78-year-old tycoon and professional bridge player, whose family fortune spans from tobacco to banking and telecom, is bidding to become Indonesia's oldest Asian Games medal winner. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan's steelworkers demand record pay hikes in spring talks
summary: Japanese steelworkers' labour unions are demanding a record pay hike of 30,000 yen (S$270) a month, equivalent to a 10% increase in base salaries, to outpace inflation. The proposal, made by the Japan Federation of Basic Industry Workers' Union, aims to stimulate private consumption and spread wage hikes across Japan. The labour talks, which started in February, will continue with blue-chip companies offering pay increases on March 13, followed by small firms later in the year. Policymakers see sustainable wage and price hikes as a prerequisite for the Bank of Japan to end negative interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida speaks during a news conference at the prime minister's office in Tokyo, Japan, 13 December 2023. Prime Minister Kishida said he will replace several ministers implicated in a political fundraising scandal.    FRANCK ROBICHON/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
The national flag flutters at the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo on January 23, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Japan allocates 45 billion yen to fire up domestic chip research
summary: Japan has allocated 45 billion yen (S$406.5 million) to support research on advanced chip technology through the Leading-edge Semiconductor Technology Center (LSTC). The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) approved the contract for up to five years, focusing on chip technology for 2 nanometers and AI-enabling chip design. The goal is to catch up in semiconductor manufacturing and bolster Japan's sustainable competitiveness. LSTC, in collaboration with Rapidus Corp, aims to develop cutting-edge fabrication technology for applications in AI and electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductor chips are seen on a printed circuit board in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: New highs for Nikkei, nervous new year break for China
summary: Japan's Nikkei index reached 34-year highs on February 9, driven by foreign inflows as investors fled China. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong fell 0.8% amid concerns over Chinese government support promises. Meanwhile, interest rate expectations led to a two-month low yen and opposing movements in the Australian and New Zealand dollars. SoftBank led Tokyo gains with a 10% rise, while Nissan shares plummeted 12% due to China sales concerns.

images.alt_text: Nissan has maintained its annual operating profit view as it expects a more profitable product mix to offset a downward revision to its sales outlook.

site_title: World's biggest flying lab comes to Asia on air pollution mission
summary: NASA has launched the world's biggest flying laboratory, the DC-8 airborne science laboratory, on a mission to improve air pollution forecasting and fight air pollution in Asia. The aircraft will fly for up to eight hours, collecting air particles for study, and provide direct measurements of pollution sources. The mission, called ASIA-AQ, aims to improve air quality forecasting models, which can lead to more accurate warning systems for the public. The study will be conducted over several countries in the region, including the Philippines, South Korea, Malaysia, and Thailand, and results will be shared with the public after a year.

images.alt_text: Ingenuity, resembling a box with four legs and parasol of rotor blades and solar panel, will live out its final days idle but emitting periodic blips of data before losing contact with the rover as Perseverance moves farther away.

site_title: Thai central bank open to easing if economic weakness drags
summary: Thailand's central bank is open to easing borrowing costs if the economy's weakness is deemed persistent, according to Bank of Thailand's assistant governor Piti Disyatat. The economy is experiencing a mixture of cyclical and structural factors, including disinflation and a slowdown in economic growth, exports, and tourism. The central bank is trying to disentangle these factors before making a decision, with a rate cut conditional on the economy's progress and the persistence of the softness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's central bank is seen at the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok, Thailand April 26, 2016.   REUTERS/Jorge Silva/File Photo

site_title: Baidu partners with Lenovo in third China AI smartphone deal
summary: Baidu has partnered with Lenovo to feature its Ernie large language model (LLM) on Lenovo's smartphones, marking the third collaboration with a phone manufacturer. The partnership aims to bring practical applications to Baidu's AI technology, similar to collaborations with Samsung and Honor. With 5% of smartphones expected to be AI-capable in 2024, the deal could help Baidu gain exposure to vast amounts of data and catch up with rival AI companies.

images.alt_text: Lenovo’s surge was part of a broader rally among its peers amid signs that a post-pandemic industry slump may have finally ended, helped by cyclical demand for PC replacement and upgrades.

site_title: Straco Corporation expects a ‘substantial’ net profit for FY2023
summary: Straco Corporation expects a "substantial" net profit for its FY2023, driven by increased revenue from the Singapore Flyer and China attractions. Visitor numbers rose as Covid-19 restrictions eased, while domestic tourism in China recovered strongly. The company reported lower exchange losses compared to FY2022. Despite this, shares fell 2.1% due to the market's overall downturn.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Flyer in the Marina Bay area.
Straco operates multiple tourist facilities in China, as well as the Singapore Flyer at Marina Bay (above).
Singapore Flyer also reported significantly higher revenues over the corresponding period, as international visitor arrivals gradually recovered.

the Singapore Flyer also reported “significantly higher revenues” compared to the same period in 2022.  Ride operations on the Singapore Flyer had been suspended due to a techincal issue between Jan 16 to April 14 last year.

site_title: Pinterest weak forecast signals intense competition for ad dollars, shares slump
summary: Pinterest shares plummeted over 14% in extended trading after the company forecast first-quarter revenue below Wall Street estimates. The digital advertising market is stabilizing, but Pinterest faces intense competition from larger social media players like TikTok and Meta Platforms-owned Facebook and Instagram. Despite a 11% rise in global monthly active users, Pinterest's revenue fell short of estimates, with ad spending in the shopping category growing less than 1% sequentially. The company's shares are now down for the second consecutive day.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This picture taken on April 26, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows a screen displaying the Tiktok social media platform's logo and the European flag. Tech giants Meta and TikTok are contesting the scope of an EU law that from March will set new rules on competition in the digital marketplace. The European Commission has designated 22 big online companies as "core platform services" to be subject to additional scrutiny and obligations under the Digital Markets Act (DMA) aiming to crack down on anti-competitive practices. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)
The European Commission has said the Digital Services Act (DSA) levy applies to 20 very large online platforms, including Meta, Google, Apple and TikTok and two very large online search engines.
Reddit is seeking to sell about 10 per cent of its shares in the IPO.
TikTok’s US expansion has already attracted the attention of politicians and regulators, who fret about the company’s growing influence over its audience.
Pinterest's monthly active user growth surpasses the pandemic surge to hit a record high of 482 million.

site_title: Blackstone-owned Crown Resorts clears CEO of law breach allegations
summary: Crown Resorts, owned by Blackstone, has cleared CEO Ciaran Carruthers of allegations that he overruled security officers for banning intoxicated customers. An internal investigation found no breach of regulations or laws. The decision comes after Crown Resorts began an investigation in December 2023, following a complaint filed against Carruthers. The company's chairman, William McBeath, stated that the investigation was completed and found Carruthers not to be at fault.

site_title: Japanese firms boosting pay for young workers is good news for Bank of Japan
summary: Japanese companies are boosting pay for young workers, a trend expected to boost overall wage growth and support the Bank of Japan's efforts to create a virtuous wage-price cycle. Firms such as Dai-Ichi Life Holdings and Nomura Holdings are raising starting salaries by 16% or more, with some companies like Tokyo Electron and Asics pledging significant increases. This development comes as Japan faces a labour shortage, particularly among young people, and the Bank of Japan may end its negative interest rate regime by April if wage growth momentum continues.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk behind the logo of SoftBank Corp in Tokyo December 18, 2014.  REUTERS/Toru Hanai (JAPAN - Tags: BUSINESS TELECOMS LOGO)/File Photo
More than half of the economists surveyed by Bloomberg in January predicted an end to negative interest rates in Japan in April.
Nintendo now expects to sell 15.5 million Switch units in the fiscal year ended March, up from 15 million, and it also raised its revenue, operating profit and net income guidance.
Japanese household spending in December fell 2.5 per cent from a year earlier, government data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Food Empire subsidiary files police report after uncovering false claims
summary: A subsidiary of Food Empire, Food Excellence Specialist, filed a police report in Malaysia after discovering a junior staff member made false claims for cash advances. The employee, who has been suspended, is under investigation. The company is working with external and internal auditors to review internal control processes and compliance. The incident has led to the engagement of a lawyer for legal assistance, and the outcome of the investigation is pending.

site_title: New York City’s housing crunch is the worst it has been in over 50 years
summary: New York City's housing crisis has reached its worst level in over 50 years, with a record-low 1.4% vacancy rate in 2023, according to city data. The crisis is forcing families and working-class people out of the city, with high housing costs and homelessness on the rise. Despite experts estimating that hundreds of thousands of new homes are needed, the city and state have not taken sufficient action to accelerate development. Mayor Eric Adams has proposed local solutions, but state lawmakers have failed to pass major housing proposals, leaving the crisis unresolved.

images.alt_text: The US housing market has sagged as the Fed began hiking its benchmark interest rate in 2022 to quash inflation.

site_title: Cat lover campaigns for animal rights in Indonesia elections
summary: Cat lover Francine Widjojo, a 44-year-old parliamentary candidate, campaigns in Indonesia's Jakarta elections, focusing on animal rights and welfare. She aims to make Jakarta a pet-friendly city by increasing sterilization and vaccination for pets. Widjojo, who rescued 27 cats, including a white cat named Yakult, urges people to join her in feeding strays and vows to "fight this together." The campaign highlights animal cruelty, particularly the consumption of dog and cat meat, which is still a pressing issue in Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Defence Minister and presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto  is the candidate to beat, with a 20-point lead in Indikator Politik’s most recent poll released last month, with 45.8 per cent support.

site_title: IMF urges Bank of Japan to end bond yield control, huge asset buying
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Bank of Japan (BOJ) to end its yield curve control and massive asset buying, and gradually raise short-term interest rates, as markets expect a near-term turn in the central bank's ultra-easy policy. Japan's economy is recovering, with domestic demand driving inflation, and the output gap is closing. The IMF expects core inflation to remain above the BOJ's 2% target until mid-2025. The central bank should consider exiting its complex stimulus program and tightening fiscal policy, while maintaining financial stability.

images.alt_text: Tokyo-based LSTC is working on designs that will enable AI applications on gadgets such as smartphones and electric vehicles.
Young people in Japan are benefiting from a labour shortage that’s especially acute in their age group.

site_title: US Supreme Court sceptical of keeping Trump off the ballot
summary: The US Supreme Court appears poised to reject a state court ruling that would bar Donald Trump from running for president due to his role in the January 6, 2021, US Capitol assault. The court, in a 2-hour hearing, expressed concerns about individual states deciding which candidates can be on the presidential ballot. Conservative justices, including Chief Justice John Roberts, warned that upholding the ruling could lead to "disqualification proceedings on the other side." Liberal justices, including Elena Kagan, questioned why a single state should decide who gets to be president. The court is expected to issue its ruling before Colorado's Super Tuesday primary on March 5.

The Trump administration began imposing tariffs aimed at curbing imports of Chinese goods in early 2018, eventually escalating to duties on goods ranging from seafood to chemicals by the fall of that year.

site_title: Expedia CEO resigns, shares slump on air travel softness
summary: Expedia CEO Peter Kern is stepping down, with Ariane Gorin, a company insider, taking his place. The company's shares slid 12% in extended trading after warning that air travel revenue would moderate due to falling ticket prices and the grounding of Boeing's 737 Max 9 fleet. Expedia expects low- to mid-single-digit gross bookings growth in the first quarter and mid-single-digit revenue growth. The company also beat earnings estimates for fourth-quarter profit and sales.

images.alt_text: Klook co-founder Eric Gnock Fah says one of the startup's growth pockets is helping millions of consumers in Asia book travel online for the first time.

Airbnb is conscious that the cost of stays plays a big part in its success – and its competition with hotels – and has introduced new tools to help hosts set appropriate pricing.

site_title: Police start process for DBS to sell shophouses linked to money laundering bust
summary: The Singapore Police Force has issued prohibition orders against several shophouses linked to a money laundering probe, paving the way for their sale to recover proceeds. The properties, valued at over S$100 million, were used as collateral for loans from DBS, which has appointed receivers to sell them. DBS aims to recover its S$100 million exposure to the case, with the sale proceeds to be seized by the police and dealt with by the courts.

images.alt_text: The row of shophouses (from left to right) at 55, 56, 57 and 58 Amoy Street on Jan 26, 2024. DBS placed several charges on the two firms and initiated the receivership process which included the selling of several shophouses.

site_title: Avant-garde watchmaker Urwerk plans new timepiece, codenamed ‘Moose’
summary: Urwerk, a Swiss watchmaker, plans to unveil a new timepiece codenamed "Moose" in October, featuring a high-powered mechanism and a unique complication. The watch will have a staff of 25 producing just over 200 watches annually, with 100 pieces shipped to retailers over three years. The company, founded in 1997 by Felix Baumgartner and Martin Frei, aims to cater to ultra-rich customers, including celebrities like Robert Downey Jr. and Michael Jordan. Urwerk has seen a surge in popularity in Asian markets, particularly in India, where it launched in 2020.

images.alt_text: The small ID Geneve start-up launched in 2020, vowing to make high-end watches with a climate- and environmentally-friendly circular production approach using non-traditional materials.
Swiss watch exports are boosted by sales in their largest market, the US, where they rise 35.1 per cent for the full year.

site_title: Huawei raided in France on suspicion of improper conduct: judicial source
summary: French authorities raided Huawei's offices on suspicion of improper behavior, including corruption and influence peddling, as part of a preliminary investigation by France's financial prosecution service. The telecoms giant, which has been at the center of a US-China stand-off over alleged state espionage, runs six research centers and a global design center in France. Huawei has around 20% of France's telecommunications market and is building a 5G factory in Alsace. The probe's outcome is unclear, but the raids follow similar investigations in the US and EU over security concerns.

images.alt_text: The complaint follows infringement lawsuits filed by Huawei against Netgear in Germany and China.

site_title: Empowering the unseen eco-warriors of South-east Asia
summary: Informal waste workers in South-east Asia, who collect and sort recyclables, face unstable incomes, social discrimination, and poor protections. Despite their critical role in the waste ecosystem, they lack recognition and rights. Efforts are underway to give them better tools and support, including funding from organizations like the Alliance to End Plastic Waste and the Ocean Conservancy. However, the most pressing issue is providing a stable and secure income, as recyclable plastic pellets trade at a low margin, and IWWs receive little of the already small sum. Formalization of the informal sector is also a challenge, as many IWWs value the independence and flexibility of the informal workforce.

images.alt_text: Kirsten van Zandwijk, director of sustainability and partnerships for Asean & South Pacific at The Coca-Cola Company, and SembWaste chief executive officer Kok Kin Lee.

Starting on 14 February this year, the provincial government of Bali will implement a 150,000 rupiah (S$12.8) tax for foreign tourists.
US households recycle just a fraction of the items they could, according to new research.

site_title: Uniqlo owner’s global strategy keeps equity investors bullish
summary: Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, has seen its global sales push keep equity investors bullish, with a 15% year-to-date gain making it the best-performing clothing company among those with a market value of over $10 billion. The company's operating profit for the first fiscal quarter topped analysts' average projections, driven by strong sales in North America and Europe. Fast Retailing aims to triple its current sales to 10 trillion yen and shift focus to overseas markets, with analysts predicting significant growth in overseas earnings, potentially leading to a 44% jump in operating profit by 2026.

site_title: Indonesia survey projects presidential hopeful Prabowo gaining majority votes
summary: Indonesia's presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto is projected to win the February 14 election with 51.8% of the vote, surpassing the 50% threshold needed for a single-round victory. This marks Prabowo's third presidential run, having lost to Joko Widodo in 2014 and 2019. A run-off will be held in June if no candidate reaches the 50% threshold. The poll, conducted by Indikator Politik Indonesia, shows Prabowo's ticket with a solid lead over rivals Anies Baswedan and Ganjar Pranowo.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Defence Minister and presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto  is the candidate to beat, with a 20-point lead in Indikator Politik’s most recent poll released last month, with 45.8 per cent support.

Presidential candidate and Indonesia’s Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto speaks on the stage during the last presidential election debate at the Jakarta Convention Center (JCC) in Jakarta on February 4, 2024.

site_title: GM appoints former Tesla executive as V-P of battery unit
summary: General Motors has appointed Kurt Kelty, former Tesla executive, as Vice-President of its battery unit. The move aims to boost battery manufacturing to support GM's target of producing one million electric vehicles in North America by 2025. Kelty, who led Tesla's battery development team for 11 years, will help address concerns about a slow ramp-up of GM's US battery plants, which could limit EV production.

site_title: Trump wins Nevada, Virgin Islands to close in on Republican nomination
summary: Donald Trump won Republican presidential nominating caucuses in Nevada and the US Virgin Islands, moving closer to securing the party's nomination. Trump won 182 votes in Nevada, and 4 in the US Virgin Islands, beating his last remaining rival Nikki Haley. Trump's victories in Iowa and New Hampshire last month have propelled him to the front of the nomination race. With Haley refusing to quit, Trump is expected to face a potential last stand in South Carolina's primary election on February 24.

images.alt_text: The question before the nine Supreme Court justices is whether Donald Trump is ineligible to appear on the Republican presidential primary ballot in Colorado because he engaged in an insurrection - the Jan 6, 2021 assault on the US Capitol by his supporters.

The report removed a legal cloud hanging over Joe Biden as he seeks reelection in a contest expected to be against Donald Trump - who is facing a criminal trial for removing large amounts of secret documents after he lost the White House.

The US presidential election this year is set to be the most consequential geopolitical event. But would be naïve to regard the 2016-2017 US elections as a template for how the markets would likely behave should Donald Trump win.

site_title: PM Lee in annual CNY message hopes Singaporeans will have more ‘dragon babies’
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong encouraged Singaporeans to have more children, particularly in the Year of the Dragon, citing the auspicious nature of the zodiac sign associated with power and good fortune. He assured the government's continued support for marriage and parenthood aspirations, acknowledging that the decision to have a child is a "very personal one."

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday’s open; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.5% at the opening bell on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 14.16 points to 3,128.75. Losers outnumbered gainers 64 to 41, and banking stocks traded mixed. The global market showed a mixed overnight performance, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average edging up, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced.

site_title: Time to review the code of corporate governance?
summary: Singapore's Code of Corporate Governance (Code) is being reviewed for its effectiveness in promoting good corporate culture, following global trends and developments in corporate governance. The review comes amid growing scrutiny of ethical business practices and the need for boards to establish purpose, values, and strategy. The Code should consider provisions for the alignment of culture with purpose and values, as well as the disclosure of ESG factors and sustainability reports. Additionally, the review may address diversity and inclusion, digitalization, and other board issues, to optimize board effectiveness and achieve cognitive diversity.

site_title: The global tremors from China’s real estate crisis are only just starting
summary: China's real estate crisis is spilling globally as investors and creditors sell off assets to raise cash. Office property values have dropped by over $1 trillion since borrowing-cost hikes triggered the slump. Completed commercial property deals fell to a decade low in 2023, with owners unwilling to sell at steep discounts. As Chinese developers restructure, overseas assets are hitting the market, bringing clarity to the market and potential wider impairments. The volume of sales is growing, with recent deals in London and Australia, and the market is expected to continue to thaw, improving transparency and price discovery.

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower on Chinese New Year’s Eve; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% to 3,138.3, with 251 losers outnumbering 212 gainers. The market was closed for the Chinese New Year, but some Asian markets, including Japan, were open and saw gains. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.7% after the central bank's deputy governor ruled out rapid interest rate hikes, leading to yen weakness. Local stocks, such as CapitaLand Ascendas, topped the STI, while Wilmar International was the index's biggest loser.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 64 to 41 after 56.6 million securities worth S$76.8 million change hands.
It appears that No Signboard is banking all its hopes on a memorandum of understanding for up to S$5 million in investments.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund sold down Paytm stake before shares plunged
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund sold a majority of its stake in Paytm before the Indian fintech firm's shares plummeted due to regulatory scrutiny. The sale occurred amid uncertainty over Paytm Payments Bank's licence and India's regulatory environment. SoftBank's executive managing partner Navneet Govil attributed the decision to start monetizing the stake, citing a "prudent" move before the recent stock correction. The sale comes after SoftBank reported its first profit in four quarters, following significant losses, and its Vision Fund logging a profit in the December quarter.

images.alt_text: epa11131189 A sign indicates that paytm mobile phone payment technology is accepted to receive payment from customers at a local roadside shop in Mumbai, India, 06 February 2024. site_title: Australia’s top central banker warns still some way to go to meet inflation target
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Michele Bullock warned that Australia's inflation challenge is not yet over, despite some encouraging signs. The central bank's inflation target range is 2-3%, and Bullock said there's still work to be done to meet the midpoint. Interest rates remain steady at 4.35% but the bank may need to tighten further if domestic inflation proves stubborn. Bullock also hinted that another interest rate rise is possible, neither ruling it in nor out.

site_title: Nissan shares plummet as Q3 earnings highlight China worries
summary: Nissan shares plummeted 11.7% on Friday, February 9, as the automaker trimmed its sales volume forecast for the year and expressed concerns about its business in China. Despite maintaining its annual operating profit view of 620 billion yen, Nissan revised its sales outlook to 3.55 million vehicles from 3.7 million. The company attributed the revision to intensifying competition and logistics issues in key markets, including China, where vehicle sales rose 12% last year. Nissan aims to remain in China and regain sales in cities where electrification is happening at a slower pace.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on December 8, 2023 shows the showroom in the guest house at the entrance to the Nissan Motor Tochigi plant, the company's largest in Japan, during a media tour in Kaminokawa, Tochigi prefecture, some 105 kms (65 miles) north of Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
China’s customs bureau puts the total exports number at 5.22 million, a huge year-on-year rise of 57 per cent, with one in three fully electric vehicles.

site_title: Why is my ice cream shrinking? Inflation by stealth
summary: Shrinkflation, or the practice of reducing product sizes while increasing prices, is becoming increasingly prevalent due to rising costs. This tactic, first identified in 1969, has seen a resurgence in recent years as companies seek to maintain profit margins. Affected products range from chocolate and crisps to dog food and washing detergent, with chocolate drawing the most complaints. Major brands such as Mondelez and Nestle have been criticized for shrinking product sizes, and consumers can take steps to avoid it by comparing prices online and opting for supermarket-branded goods.

images.alt_text: Resilient shoppers are a tailwind for retailers such as Amazon.com and Walmart.

US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell has pushed back on expectations of an interest rate cut in March, after the Federal Open Market Committee decided to leave interest rates at 5.25 to 5.5 per cent.

Hershey expects net sales to grow 2 to 3 per cent in 2024, mostly driven by higher prices the company has already planned.

site_title: Biden avoids documents charges, gets roasted on memory loss
summary: US President Joe Biden has been cleared of wrongdoing in his handling of classified documents, but a report has raised concerns about his mental capacity, with special counsel Robert Hur describing him as a "well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory." The report found no evidence of willful retention of classified materials, but Hur noted that a jury might struggle to convict Biden of a serious felony due to his age and memory issues. Republican leaders have criticized Biden's fitness for the presidency, while the White House has attacked the report's comments as "neither accurate nor appropriate."

images.alt_text: Some 27 per cent of traders surveyed see inflation as having the biggest impact, followed by 20 per cent for the November US presidential election, the survey by JPMorgan showed.
US officials say the new policy is part of a wider effort to shape the behaviour of foreign governments and individual companies that are involved in malicious digital espionage activities.
US regulators have been considering making AI-generated robocalls illegal, with the fake Joe Biden call giving the effort new impetus.

The Trump administration began imposing tariffs aimed at curbing imports of Chinese goods in early 2018, eventually escalating to duties on goods ranging from seafood to chemicals by the fall of that year.
Outside the US Steel Great Lakes Works plant in Ecorse, Michigan, Sep 24, 2019.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending rose 0.9 per cent.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall more than expected
summary: US jobless claims fell more than expected, dropping 9,000 to 218,000 for the week ended Feb 3. Despite recent layoffs, claims remain little changed compared to the same period last year. The labor market shows signs of underlying strength, with rising worker productivity and easing labor costs. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 3.7% and nonfarm payrolls increased by 353,000 jobs in January. This sustained labor market strength has led to reduced expectations for the first interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve, now expected in May instead of March.

images.alt_text: Initial claims increases by 9,000 to 224,000 in the week ending Jan 27, according to Labor Department.

site_title: Marcos says Duterte’s call to split Philippines ‘doomed to fail’
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. sharply rejected his predecessor Rodrigo Duterte's threat to secede the southern Mindanao island, calling it "doomed to fail" and a "grave constitutional travesty." Marcos stated that the call is anchored on a false premise and would undermine the country's unity. The move is seen as a deepening of the feud between the two leaders and could increase the risk of political instability. Marcos reiterated that his government is only introducing economic reforms to the constitution, not political ones.

images.alt_text: In an interview with a local broadcaster last month, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr expressed concern over the South-east Asian nation’s restrictive economic provisions and kept the door open to changes in politicians’ term limits.

site_title: Oil up 3% on Gaza ceasefire rejection and US fuel stocks data
summary: Oil prices rose 3% on Thursday due to concerns over a broadening conflict in the Middle East after Israel rejected a ceasefire offer from Hamas. Brent futures closed at $81.36 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $76.22 a barrel. The market is cautious about potential fallout from the conflict, with attacks on shipping by Iranian-backed Houthi rebels continuing to disrupt global oil trading. In contrast, a stronger-than-expected drawdown in US fuel stocks and rising crude stocks buoyed the oil market, driven by refinery maintenance and a shortage of diesel in Europe.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures gained 48 cents to US$79.07 a barrel as of 1.35 pm ET (1835 GMT), while US West Texas Intermediate crude climbed 42 cents to US$73.73 on Tuesday.

site_title: Bitcoin approaches US$45,000 with US spot ETFs showing steady inflows
summary: Bitcoin rose 1.6% to $44,872, approaching $45,000 for the first time in a month, amid steady inflows into US spot ETFs. The funds have seen net inflows for nine consecutive sessions, following a tapering of outflows from the Grayscale Bitcoin Trust. Analysts expect the upcoming Bitcoin halving event in April to drive a rally, with the event anticipated to reduce rewards for miners and cap the supply of Bitcoin at 21 million tokens.

images.alt_text: The SEC approved the listing of 11 spot Bitcoin ETFs, but caution is warranted.
Australian computer scientist Craig Wright says he is Satoshi Nakamoto, the pseudonym of bitcoin's creator and author of a white paper that introduced the cryptocurrency to the world in 2008.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MIT, SIAEC, StarHub, SingPost, Oxley, Marco Polo Marine
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust priced S$50 million notes with a 3.751% fixed coupon rate, set to refinance existing borrowings. SIA Engineering Company sold its entire stake in Additive Flight Solutions to Stratasys for US$90,000. StarHub posted a net profit of S$72.9 million for its second half, with revenue falling 0.1%. SingPost's group operating profit fell 18.2% to S$27.7 million, while Oxley posted a net loss of S$1.1 million. Marco Polo Marine's gross profit increased 75.8% to S$11.6 million.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index slid 0.4 per cent or 13.24 to 3,142.91.

site_title: Britain’s Hunt wants London Stock Exchange to become Europe’s Nasdaq
summary: British Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt aims to transform the London Stock Exchange into Europe's equivalent of the US Nasdaq, aiming to attract tech companies and create a "next Silicon Valley". This move is part of a broader effort to boost the UK's competitiveness, following the departure of UK tech companies like Arm Holdings listing in New York. Hunt believes the UK has the best universities and largest financial sector outside the US, and that a successful Silicon Valley in Britain could rival the impact of the 1980s' "Big Bang" reforms that established London as a top financial center.

images.alt_text: Activists at a rally in Indonesia. The key to defang identity politics is to transmit a fundamental message to voters: the government is working for you, not for elites of some kind or for friends in the party establishment.

Former British Prime Minister Liz Truss spent just 49 days in office before she was ousted by her own party in October 2022 after her disastrous mini-budget spooked financial markets and sank the pound.
Brexit was certain to go wrong, because it was based on false premises.
The state-run National Health Service (NHS) emerged from the Covid-19 pandemic in crisis, crippled by long waiting lists, ambulance delays and industrial action by staff over pay.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1 per cent lower on Thursday after rising as much 0.3 per cent during the day.

site_title: Shopee lawsuit loss sparks debate on non-competition clauses
summary: A Singaporean court dismissed a lawsuit by Shopee against a former employee, Lim Teck Yong, who joined ByteDance after leaving his executive director role at Shopee. The case highlighted the controversy surrounding non-competition clauses in employment contracts, with experts arguing that they can limit social mobility and stifle innovation. The court ruled that Shopee's prospects of success were too small to warrant an interim injunction, and the case has sparked debate on the ethics and effectiveness of such clauses.

images.alt_text: The court dismissed Shopee’s claims to seek interim injunctions to prevent the former employee from accepting employment with ByteDance.

site_title: New Oscar to be introduced for best casting
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has announced the introduction of a new Oscar for best casting, set to be added from 2026. This will be the first competitive new golden statuette added in over two decades. The new category recognizes the essential role of casting directors in filmmaking, who play a key part in shaping movies by hiring stars and performers for minor roles. The decision comes after a campaign by casting directors, who have been lobbying for their own Oscar category.

images.alt_text: Gina Carano claims that she was not brought back for season three of The Mandalorian, and the new show was shelved.
Bryce Dallas Howard (left) and Sam Rockwell star in Argylle.
Amazon has an unrivalled delivery network that can ship millions products to much of the US population in a day or less.
Mattel Films is also developing projects based on other popular toy lines, including American Girl, Hot Wheels, Magic Ball, Barney and more.

Although Netflix's executives said the deal with WWE did not signal a change to its focus on entertainment, it nevertheless sets Netflix on a collision course with traditional media as the streamer builds out its advertising business.

site_title: Harley-Davidson profit beats estimates despite lower sales
summary: Harley-Davidson reported a fourth-quarter profit of 18 cents per share, beating analyst estimates. Sales fell to $792 million, below the projected $879 million. The company attributed the result to higher borrowing costs and a challenging industry environment, despite efforts to boost incentives and invest in more profitable models. CEO Jochen Zeitz stated the company continues to make progress on its strategic plan, despite the current market conditions.

site_title: Muppets, military men and mental health
summary: Elmo's casual question about people's well-being on X sparked an unexpected response from users, sharing their mental health struggles and feelings of isolation. The conversation highlights the importance of normalizing mental health discussions and creating a safe space for individuals to share their thoughts and feelings. Regular check-ins can help detect subtle changes in behavior and provide support, and being candid and open can help break down stigma. The example of US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin's delayed disclosure of his prostate cancer diagnosis also underscores the challenges of revealing health challenges, particularly in positions of seniority or leadership.

simindset - Jeffery Tan, chief executive officer, MINDSET
Loneliness can occur despite being surrounded by people, and can affect anyone, regardless of age, gender, or socio-economic background.

site_title: US: S&P 500 finishes just shy of 5,000 points after latest push
summary: The S&P 500 ended at 4,997.91, up 0.1% on Thursday, narrowly missing a 5,000-point milestone. Solid earnings from Disney, including a 11.5% stock surge, and higher-than-expected profits from Mattel contributed to the gains. Analysts expect the S&P 500 to break the 5,000-point threshold in the near future, citing the upcoming consumer price index report.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 6, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: An arts festival about sports, for people who don’t like sports
summary: The Pompidou Centre's Hors Pistes festival, part of the Paris Cultural Olympiad, explores the intersection of art and sports. The festival features various performances, including Anna Chirescu and Gregoire Schaller's "Dirty Dancers," which contrasts the athleticism of gymnastics with everyday movements, and Rebecca Chaillon's "Where the Goat is Tied, It Must Graze," which critiques the exclusivity of women's sports. Meanwhile, a separate exhibition examines the sociopolitical history of the Olympics, including the 1936 Summer Olympics under the Nazi regime. The festival aims to question and subvert the rules of sport, sparking a nuanced conversation about the relationship between art, culture, and sports.

images.alt_text: Designed by jeweller Chaumet, the 18-gram hexagon tokens, representing the shape of France, are made of iron from past refurbishments of the Eiffel Tower.

site_title: Real estate turmoil leaves affected banks reliant on covered bonds
summary: US commercial real estate exposure is infecting banks worldwide, forcing them to mark down loan values as developers struggle with high debt and elevated interest rates. German banks, such as Deutsche Pfandbriefbank and Aareal Bank, are relying on covered bonds and deposits to access funding, as unsecured borrowing costs rise. Analysts warn that investors are becoming increasingly cautious around these lenders, potentially leading to spread differentiation in German covered bonds.

site_title: Paris 2024 medallists to take piece of Eiffel Tower home
summary: The Paris 2024 Olympics will reward medallists with a piece of the Eiffel Tower, unveiled as hexagon-shaped medals made of scrap metal from the monument. Designed by jeweller Chaumet, the 18-gram tokens represent the shape of France. Organisers aimed to link the Games with French symbols, with Thierry Reboul stating the Eiffel Tower is the "absolute symbol of Paris and France". Medallists will bring back a piece of Paris with them.

images.alt_text: The cost of getting into the most in-demand sports competitions has risen – sometimes by Olympian proportions.

site_title: Google rebrands Bard chatbot as Gemini, rolls out paid subscription
summary: Google has rebranded its Bard chatbot as Gemini, powered by a new AI model, and introduced a paid subscription service, Google One AI Premium, for US$19.99/month. The plan includes a more powerful Ultra 1.0 AI model, 2 terabytes of cloud storage, and access to Gemini in Gmail and Google's productivity suite. This move aims to compete with Microsoft's AI subscription service and OpenAI's ChatGPT Plus, with the goal of providing users with the most capable generative AI technology.

images.alt_text: Google’s outlook underscores ambitions for AI at its parent Alphabet, which to date has six products each attracting billions of users, among them its search engine and YouTube.

site_title: Barclays investors crave simpler bank as CEO Venkat prepares revamp
summary: Barclays' CEO Venkatakrishnan is under pressure to deliver a plan to win over restless shareholders clamoring for a streamlined business model and higher returns. The bank has one of the lowest valuations among peers, driven in part by a hefty disposal of stock by Qatar Holding. Shareholders favor shrinking its investment bank, offloading stakes in sub-scale businesses, or exiting non-core assets. Barclays aims to present a revival plan on Feb 20, but faces challenges in securing buyers for its UK payment business. Investors expect the bank to upgrade its annual return target to between 11% and 13%.

images.alt_text: A logo on a sign outside the headquarters of Deutsche Pfandbriefbank AG (PBB) in Garching, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 8, 2024. Bonds issued by real estate-focused German lenders slumped after Morgan Stanley analysts recommended clients sell senior bonds issued by Deutsche Pfandbriefbank AG because of its exposure to the CRE market in the US, according to people with knowledge of the matter who spoke on condition of anonymity. site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower as healthcare losses overpower earnings-fuelled rally
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1% lower on Thursday, despite strong earnings from consumer staples stocks like Unilever and Kering. Healthcare heavyweights, however, dragged the index down due to losses in AstraZeneca and Maersk. Oil and gas shares also took a hit from Neste's disappointing earnings. Despite this, some luxury stocks rose, with Kering up 4.9% and Unilever 3.2%. Analysts say the market is cautiously optimistic, but more evidence is needed for interest rate cuts from the European Central Bank.

images.alt_text: The S&P 500 ended at 4,997.91, up 0.1 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Europe’s banks under microscope with property worries swirling
summary: Europe's banks are under scrutiny due to concerns over property market troubles. Deutsche Pfandbriefbank, a specialized lender, continues its decline despite analysts at Barclays arguing it has set aside relatively small provisions. Other banks, such as Societe Generale and Intesa Sanpaolo, pushed back against concerns. The situation highlights the limited room for these lenders to absorb potential losses without raising concerns about their ability to raise investor payouts.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank’s loans on US offices represent about 1.5 per cent of its total lending book, with properties in cities including New York (top), Los Angeles and San Francisco.

site_title: China’s recovery road map in the Year of the Dragon
summary: China's equity market has struggled over the past year due to weakness in the real estate sector and slower consumer spending. To address this, a four-point policy plan has been developed, aiming for sustained recovery in China's economy and equity markets in the Year of the Dragon. The plan focuses on addressing market concerns and promoting growth.

images.alt_text: Innovations in electric vehicles bode well for China's technological future. China is transitioning from an economy driven by fixed assets and properties, towards one powered by high value-added manufacturing and innovation.

site_title: Oxley Holdings posts H1 loss of S$1.1 million on lower revenue, offset by lower finance costs, tower sale
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a H1 loss of S$1.1 million due to lower revenue, primarily from Singapore development projects. However, the company's finance costs decreased by 29% and the sale of a Grade-A office tower in Kuala Lumpur generated S$114 million. The group cites an optimistic macroeconomic outlook, with potential increases in global economic growth and tourism recovery, which could boost hotel rates and occupancy. Despite this, escalating operation costs and labour shortages may affect hotel performance.

images.alt_text: Oxley Towers KLCC, a freehold property, comprises two hotel towers with residences, an office tower and a retail podium linking all the three towers.
Oxley Holdings' Novotel Singapore and Mercure Singapore. The group's revenue has fallen by more than 50 per cent to S$202 million, from S$419.5 million in H2 FY2022.

site_title: Raiding development funding for climate
summary: The World Bank is shifting 45% of its funding towards climate change, diverting $40 billion annually away from poverty and hunger. Climate change is not the top priority for the world's poorest countries, where hunger, malaria, and tuberculosis are more pressing concerns. Investing in energy access and development projects can dramatically change lives and make countries more resilient against natural disasters. Research shows that spending on core development priorities is more effective per dollar spent than climate change mitigation efforts.

images.alt_text: Patients diagnosed with tuberculosis in Maputo, Mozambique. TB has been treatable for more than 50 years, yet still kills more than 1.4 million people annually.
COP28 in Dubai, UAE, Dec 6, 2023. Despite 27 previous conferences with iterations of ominous speeches and bold promises, global emissions have inexorably increased.

The second Sustainable Development Goals summit in New York. Progress on the goals is happening at less than a quarter of the pledged speed.

A Yemeni child waits for her mother receiving food aid, at a camp for Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) on the outskirts of Sana'a, Yemen, April 2022. Years of civil war have resulted in severe food insecurity, and hence a crisis of hunger and malnourishment, for millions of Yemenis.

site_title: Gucci sales fall as weakness persists at Kering’s top label
summary: Gucci's comparable revenue fell 4% in the fourth quarter, with Kering warning that group profit will decline this year. The Italian label, owned by Kering, struggled to attract wealthy shoppers to its luxury products. Kering's CEO Francois-Henri Pinault described 2023 as a trying year, and the company predicted a decline in recurring operating income this year, particularly in the first half. Gucci's new designer, Sabato De Sarno, was introduced last year to reinvigorate the brand.

images.alt_text: Kering’s performance has been lagging behind rivals as the luxury group controlled by the billionaire Pinault family navigates management and creative changes at Gucci.

site_title: Hershey says ‘historic’ cocoa inflation could push prices higher
summary: Hershey Co expects 2-3% net sales growth in 2024, driven by higher prices, as cocoa prices reach "historic" levels. New York cocoa futures hit a record, doubling in a year due to extreme weather affecting West African growers. The company plans to raise prices to manage costs, with higher prices expected to benefit earnings in the second half of 2024 and into 2025. Hershey shares rose 5.5% in response to the news, outpacing the S&P 500 consumer-staples index 2.7%.

images.alt_text: Hershey sued by California cookie maker in Hershey's Kisses dispute

site_title: Meta giving up 7 office floors totalling 115,000 sq ft at South Beach Tower
summary: Meta, the largest office tenant at South Beach Tower, will not renew its lease, which expires at the end of September this year. The landlord, South Beach Consortium, is in advanced negotiations with a replacement tenant for two floors, totaling 115,000 sq ft. The tech giant has consolidated its teams at Marina One, starting to move staff out of the building in the first half of last year. The company is expected to sign a deal with a new tenant, with asking rents ranging from S$12.50 to S$13.50 psf per month.

site_title: Is there room for me in the AI-driven future workplace?
summary: The future of work is expected to be shaped by AI, with 3.3 billion people in the workforce today and Gen Z making up 27% of the workforce by 2025. To address the challenges posed by AI, experts suggest focusing on leveraging AI to create a symbiotic relationship between humans and machines, rather than replacing humans. Key factors include building social capital, human capital, and technology capital, with Gen Z workers valued for their collaborative nature, strong communication skills, and ability to adapt to new technologies. AI tools can enhance capabilities, but humans must provide oversight, critical thinking, and empathy to ensure a beneficial relationship.

images.alt_text: Even employees in non-technical roles need to show they are equipped to handle the disruptions ahead.
AI raises mainy questions in a world of increasing economic complexity.
Feon Ang, Lee See Ting and Gautam Talwar.

site_title: Pakistan’s stormy politics laid bare in election
summary: Pakistan's election took place under the shadow of a military campaign against former Prime Minister Imran Khan, who was ousted in 2022. The Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PMLN) is expected to claim victory, led by Nawaz Sharif, who was also ousted by the military in 2017. The election was marred by human rights concerns, a mobile phone service outage, and allegations of vote tampering, which could spark protests. Analysts believe the military may try to elevate Sharif's brother, Shehbaz Sharif, or tamper with the vote count, further destabilizing the country's already tumultuous politics.

images.alt_text: Supporters of former Pakistan's Prime Minister, Imran Khan, gather at Zaman Park in Lahore. Khan’s ouster in April last year has galvanised support for the former international cricket star as the unsteady coalition that replaced him struggles to pull Pakistan back from the brink of default and control spiralling inflation.

site_title: No Signboard’s investor to provide additional capital via escrow arrangement
summary: No Signboard, a Singapore restaurant operator, has secured an additional capital injection of S$5 million from its investor Gazelle Ventures via an escrow arrangement. The funds will be used for general working capital and other purposes determined by the board. This move aims to ensure the company's continued operation as a going concern. Trading in No Signboard's shares has been suspended since Jan 24, 2022, and the company is also in the process of completing the acquisition of a 60% stake in Dining Haus.

images.alt_text: It appears that No Signboard is banking all its hopes on a memorandum of understanding for up to S$5 million in investments.
Facade of No Signboard Seafood restaurant.

No Signboard has entered into a share sale and purchase agreement with Chia Shu Sian and its investor Gazelle Ventures for the proposed acquisition of 60 per cent of the entire issued and paid-up capital of Dining Haus.

No Signboard has made three financial results announcements in seven days – with a Q2 earnings report on Nov 23 and a Q3 report on Nov 28. Shares of the company have also been suspended since January 2022.

site_title: Four arrested for involvement in concert ticket scams affecting at least 583 victims
summary: Four individuals, one man and three women, have been arrested in Singapore for their involvement in concert ticket scams affecting at least 583 victims, with total losses of at least S$223,000. The scammers posed as ticket sellers on e-commerce platforms and provided fake images or videos of tickets, promising to deliver them upon payment. The victims were duped when the sellers asked for additional payment, delayed delivery, or ceased communication. The scammers allegedly used stolen credentials to facilitate the scams, and seven others are assisting police with the investigations.

images.alt_text: Scammers targeting institutions such as hospitals, schools and government offices for ransom pocketed US$1.1 billion last year, compared with US$567 million in 2022.
