site_title: China's central bank to keep policy support for economy
summary: China's central bank has vowed to keep monetary policy flexible and precise to boost domestic demand while maintaining price stability amid a patchy economic recovery and rising deflationary risks. The People's Bank of China will strengthen policy coordination and support consumption, investment, and domestic demand, while keeping the money supply in line with economic growth and price levels. The bank will also promote deposit interest rate marketization and support the property market. China's consumer prices fell at their steepest pace in 14 years in January, prompting policymakers to take action to revive the economy.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China has rarely made such a broad easing move so close to the break.
Entrenched deflation and declining house prices are two of the most serious problems faced by the world’s second-largest economy this year as it tries to regain and sustain momentum.
The PBOC has increasingly leaned on tools that steer credit to specific sectors since 2020, when the pandemic hit economic growth.

site_title: BT Explains: How might Singapore stay competitive with tax changes under BEPS 2.0?
summary: Singapore is implementing a minimum effective tax rate of 15% for multinational enterprise groups starting January 2025, as part of the global tax pact BEPS 2.0. This move means the country will no longer offer traditional tax incentives to attract such companies. To stay competitive, Singapore may introduce new non-tax incentives, such as qualified refundable tax credits or expanded existing tax incentives. The government aims to review and update its industry development schemes to attract and retain investments. Non-tax factors, including its business environment and skilled labor force, will continue to play a role in Singapore's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Association for the Deaf will provide simultaneous sign language interpretation of Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong’s speech on Channel 5.
Butget 101 infographic
To be sure, revenue from carbon tax should be channeled towards climate mitigation measures as well as incentives to encourage both companies and consumers to go green.
Budget quiz thumbnail
BEPS 2.0 unlikely to hurt competitiveness, may net Singapore gains in tax revenue

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat with earnings, economic data in focus
summary: US stocks opened flat on February 8, 2024, as investors assessed earnings reports from Walt Disney and Spirit Airlines, as well as softer-than-expected jobs data and interest rate cut remarks from policymakers. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 42.09 points, or 0.1%, to 38,719.45, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, but by smaller margins. The flat opening was attributed to market uncertainty and ongoing economic data.

site_title: SIA Engineering to sell its entire stake in aerospace company for US$90,000
summary: SIA Engineering Company is selling its entire 60% stake in Additive Flight Solutions to Stratasys for US$90,000. The sale is based on the net book value of the company and has been completed. Additive Flight Solutions is no longer a subsidiary of SIAEC. The deal size was arrived at after arm's-length negotiations on a willing-buyer, willing-seller basis. SIAEC shares closed flat at S$2.29 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Generic image of SIA Engineering Company, for stories about aviation and SIA

site_title: 'Silver is the new gold' as Egyptians try to protect savings
summary: Egyptian women are shifting from traditional gold jewelry sets due to surging prices and a weakening currency, opting for silver instead. The price of one gram of silver has more than doubled in a year to 47 Egyptian pounds, while 21-carat gold has increased by over 120% to 3,875 Egyptian pounds. This trend reflects Egypt's economic crisis, marked by inflation over 30% and a 50% currency devaluation against the dollar.

images.alt_text: Lower rates decrease the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

site_title: Siemens investors call for further unbundling of group
summary: Two major investors in Siemens, Union Investment and Deka Investment, have called for the German engineering group to simplify its operations by reducing its stakes in Siemens Energy and Siemens Healthineers. Despite a strong operational performance, Siemens's total shareholder return has lagged rivals, and the investors believe the company's complexity weighs on its share price. They want Siemens to further unbundle the group, reducing its stakes in these businesses and streamlining operations.

images.alt_text: Siemens reported industrial profit increasing by 3 per cent to 2.72 billion euros (S$3.94 billion) for the three months to the end of December, beating forecasts of 2.64 billion euros in a company-gathered consensus of analysts.

site_title: Ralph Lauren rides on strong holiday demand, China rebound to post upbeat results
summary: Ralph Lauren reported a 6% jump in retail store sales and a 4% increase in e-commerce during the holiday season, driven by luxury spending from wealthy US shoppers. The company also beat Wall Street expectations for revenue for the 12th straight quarter, thanks to a strong rebound in China. Additionally, Ralph Lauren exited the holiday season with healthy inventory levels, indicating a positive outlook for the company.

images.alt_text: The media headlines have moved on from the metaverse, but the consumer has not, says Ralph Lauren CEO Patrice Louvet.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse urges swift introduction of EU rules to shift euro clearing from London
summary: Deutsche Boerse's Eurex Clearing arm in Frankfurt, leading euro IRS clearer, welcomes EU rules to shift euro derivatives clearing from London. The provisional deal requires banks and asset managers to have an "active account" with an EU-based clearing house. CEO Theodor Weimer wants "market-driven solutions" and praises the deal as a "good compromise." He urges swift implementation, but notes that more needs to be done to strengthen the EU's capital market union.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Boerse has named investment banker and former UBS executive Carsten Kengeter as its new CEO from next June, replacing Reto Francioni after nearly a decade at the helm.

Brussels wants EU regulators to have direct oversight of euro clearing for banks and asset managers based in the bloc, particularly since Britain’s departure from the EU and requirement to comply with its financial rules.

site_title: SingPost Q3 operating profit dips 18.2 per cent to S$27.7 million
summary: SingPost reported a 18.2% dip in Q3 operating profit to S$27.7 million, down from S$33.9 million in the previous quarter. Revenue fell 8% to S$455.4 million, while operating expenses narrowed 6.7%. The company expects a challenging business environment in 2024 due to global geopolitical and economic factors. A strategic review to transition into a logistics business is nearing completion, with a formal announcement expected before the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Exceptions include rates for aerogrammes to Malaysia and Brunei, which will remain at S$0.80 per piece.
SingPost Centre at 10 Eunos Road 8 near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 03, 2020. Can be used for stories on mail, postage, post, postman, courier, parcel, envelope, stamp and delivery.
SingPost says its proposed acquisition of Border Express aligns with the group's strategic ambition to expand its logistics network and foster synergy within its Australian operations.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust prices S$50 million notes at 3.751%
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust priced S$50 million notes at 3.751% per annum, with proceeds to be used for refinancing existing borrowings. The notes, due in February 2027, are expected to be assigned a rating of "BBB+" by Fitch Ratings. Units of the trust fell 1.2% to close at S$2.38 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Indian food delivery platform Zomato beats Q3 profit estimates on higher demand
summary: Indian food delivery platform Zomato reported a consolidated net profit of 1.4 billion rupees for the third quarter, beating market expectations, driven by increased demand during the men's Cricket World Cup and the festive period. Revenue jumped 69% to 32.88 billion rupees, with its mainstay food delivery business growing 27% and its grocery delivery business seeing a 100% increase in gross order value. Despite growth, the company's food delivery segment was below expectations due to "muted" demand.

images.alt_text: New Delhi-based Zomato says that reports about the company buying Shiprocket for US$2 billion were “incorrect news”, adding it had no plans for an acquisition.

site_title: Greenback picks up steam; yen falls past 149 per US dollar
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen, reaching a 12-week high, due to higher US Treasury yields. The dollar index was up 0.2% at 104.23, while the yen fell 0.7% to 149.18, its weakest level since November 27. The Federal Reserve's comments on policymakers suggesting rates would remain higher for longer also contributed to the dollar's rise. The euro and sterling also fell against the dollar, while the yuan remained steady despite a decline in China's consumer prices.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index – which measures the currency against six major peers, slips 0.1 per cent to 104.04, following Tuesday’s 0.29 per cent slide.

site_title: Pressure groups sue LME for allowing trade of 'polluting' Indonesian metal
summary: Pressure groups, the London Mining Network and the Global Legal Action Network, have filed a legal action against the London Metal Exchange (LME) for allowing the sale of 'polluting' Indonesian metal on its platform. The groups claim that metal produced in Indonesia's Grasberg copper mine is being dumped into local rivers, harming indigenous communities. The LME says it requires companies to undergo audits for sustainability and plans to suspend or delist 10% of its metals brands until producers provide responsible sourcing information.

images.alt_text: The appointments “will ensure that LME Clear is in a strong position as we drive forward our strategy” says LME CEO Michael Carty.
Hong Kong’s imports of industrial metals such as copper and aluminium are a small fraction of global supplies.

site_title: Maersk faces network issues, operations affected in some locations
summary: Maersk, a Danish shipping company, is experiencing technical network issues that are disrupting its operations in some locations, including the Americas. The disruptions are not related to a cybersecurity issue and some networks are coming back online. Maersk has initiated business continuity plans for affected vessels and cargo movements. This issue comes after the company reported fourth-quarter profits below expectations due to an oversupply of container vessels and uncertainty around Red Sea disruptions.

site_title: HSBC partners Google to hit US$1 billion climate tech finance goal
summary: HSBC has partnered with Google to finance fast-growing climate technology firms, aiming to reach a US$1 billion goal by 2030. The partnership will provide financing to companies chosen by Google to join its Google Cloud Ready-Sustainability programme, which assesses the quality and efficacy of climate technology solutions. HSBC will help these companies scale their businesses, while also facilitating introductions between existing customers and climate tech firms. The partnership is seen as a key step towards helping corporations transition to a low-carbon economy.

images.alt_text: HSBC has said it was not barred from hiring the former SVB employees.

site_title: Iswaran allowed to leave Singapore to help son settle in at university; case transferred to High Court
summary: Former Singapore Transport Minister S Iswaran's application to leave the country was conditionally approved to help his son settle into an Australian university. He faces 27 charges, including corruption, obtaining items from a business associate, and obstructing justice. Conditions for his travel include a cash bail of S$500,000 and providing his itinerary and contact information to the investigating officer. His court case will be transferred to the High Court, with the prosecution citing strong public interest.

images.alt_text: Former transport minister S Iswaran with his legal counsel Davinder Singh.
Lavish gifts and entertainment should be regarded as the proverbial Trojan horse that compromises one's integrity from the inside.
Tycoon Ong Beng Seng is alleged to have offered benefits worth over S$384,000 to former transport minister S Iswaran.
While the government will review its contracts to safeguard Singapore's interest, it remains committed to the F1 Singapore Grand Prix, said Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations Grace Fu.

site_title: Temasek teams with Norinchukin on US$173 million agri-food fund
summary: Temasek and Japan's Norinchukin Bank are partnering on a $173 million fund to invest in agriculture and food technology startups across the Asia-Pacific region, focusing on decarbonizing the food and agriculture industries. The Seviora T3F Strategy aims to address the growing concern of the carbon footprint of farming, which accounts for about a third of global greenhouse gas emissions. With several institutional backers, the fund has already started investing, with a $17 million investment in an Indian startup.

images.alt_text: India's was among the five best performing stock markets in Asia last year.

site_title: EU delays new ESG reporting demands amid industry pushback
summary: The European Union has agreed to delay new ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) reporting requirements by two years, pushing the deadline from June 30 to June 30, 2026. This decision comes after industry leaders expressed concerns about the weight of regulations, with the Belgian presidency citing the need to reduce administrative burdens on companies. The delay affects sector-specific reporting requirements, while general ESG data points will still be required from June this year. The move is seen as a compromise, with EU lawmakers and member states agreeing to limit reporting requirements to the minimum.

images.alt_text: The new requirements mark the first in what is set to be a continuous reworking of the capital framework within which European banks must operate.

site_title: This Valentine’s Day, say it with wine
summary: For Valentine's Day, consider adding sweet wines to your celebrations. Sweet wines, such as Sauternes and Tokaji, offer balanced flavors and can pair well with desserts and strong cheeses. They are labor-intensive and expensive to produce due to the risk of botrytis cinerea, a fungus that concentrates sweetness. Recommended sweet wines include Clot de L'Origine Maury, Clos Larrouyat Jurançon Moelleux, and Chateau Climens Barsac. These wines can be found in stores, but their distribution is limited. Adding sweet wines to your Valentine's Day celebrations can enhance the pleasure of the occasion and provide a unique and refreshing pairing experience.

images.alt_text: Angela Fronti at her family vineyards in Radda-in-Chianti in the Tuscany region of Italy on Jan. 9, 2024. Fronti used her familyÕs vineyards to create Istine, now an excellent Chianti Classico estate. (Clara Vannucci/The New York Times)

site_title: RBI’s clampdown on Paytm Payments Bank follows persistent non-compliance
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has taken action against Paytm Payments Bank (PPB) for persistent non-compliance with regulations, ordering it to stop accepting new deposits in its accounts or digital wallets from March. The RBI had found hundreds of thousands of PPB accounts created without proper identification. The clampdown led to a 35% decline in Paytm's stock price, erasing $2 billion in investor wealth. The central bank has given the company ample time to comply, but since it failed, the RBI has imposed supervisory restrictions.

images.alt_text: Vijay Shekhar Sharma owns 51 per cent in the payments bank, which can take deposits of up to 200,000 rupees but is not allowed to lend.

site_title: Bombardier forecasts strong 2024 revenue on higher deliveries of business jets
summary: Bombardier forecasts strong 2024 revenue with expected deliveries of 150-155 business jets, driven by sustained demand for private flying. Revenue is forecast at $8.4-$8.6 billion, surpassing analysts' expectations, and free cash flow is expected to be $100-$400 million. The company reported a lower fourth-quarter adjusted net income of $135 million, amid lingering supply snags that raised costs. This beats estimates, but free cash flow falls below expectations.

images.alt_text: Bombardier chief executive Eric Martel says the company is planning for more deliveries in 2024, without disclosing a specific figure, compared with this year’s target of more than 138 aircraft.
Bombardier reported a second-quarter profit of US$10 million from continuing operations, compared with a loss of US$109 million in the year-earlier period.

site_title: India’s Dynamatic Tech inks deal to make all Airbus A220 door variants
summary: Dynamatic Technologies, an Indian aviation parts maker, has inked a deal with Airbus to manufacture all door variants for its A220 planes in India, marking the largest contract for doors by the French planemaker. The deal is expected to boost Airbus' sourcing of parts from India, with plans to double the total value of parts sourced to $1.5 billion in the coming years. The first doors are set to be delivered early next year, with Dynamatic's shares reaching a record high of 7,780 rupees following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Tata-controlled Air India last month agreed record orders for 470 jetliners from Airbus and Boeing and sources have said India’s largest airline, IndiGo, is in talks for another 500.

site_title: China sets pricing rule for electricity stabilising services
summary: China's National Development and Reform Council has set a pricing rule for electricity stabilizing services, aiming to promote the development of an ancillary services market. The rule focuses on optimizing pricing mechanisms for standby capacity, frequency modulation, and peak shaving, essential services for maintaining reliable electricity supply. This step is part of China's efforts to create a national electricity market by 2030, with a focus on integrating wind and solar power into the grid.

site_title: Lawyers of OK Lim, daughter say witness exaggerated and lied in court testimony
summary: Lawyers for OK Lim and his daughter, Lim Huey Ching, claim that a witness, Serene Seng, exaggerated and lied in her testimony during a civil trial. Seng, a former Hin Leong employee, testified that OK Lim controlled all matters in the company, but other employees contradicted her, stating they had no work dealings with Lim. The lawyers also questioned Seng's statement about a conversation with Lim Huey Ching, noting discrepancies between her testimony and a prior statement to PwC. The civil trial, which aims to recover US$3.5 billion, will continue on February 13.

images.alt_text: In April last year, Hin Leong former employee Serene Seng admitted in court that she had lied to the CAD on some instances in a bid to protect her children.

Liquidators are alleging in the civil suit that Hin Leong concealed losses of more than US$800 million over the past few years through the creation of fictitious gains, forgery of documents, improper accounting entries and the overstatement of its inventory.

In response to a question from Navin Thevar of Davinder Singh Chambers – one of Lim’s lawyers –, Dr Yeo said he knew Lim was suffering from depression as soon as he had walked into the clinic’s consultation room.
OK Lim’s health has been deteriorating since the collapse of Hin Leong; he has also said he has depression and anxiety.

DPP Ong suggested that Lim had been untruthful when responding to certain questions in the interview, and that he was trying to distance himself from being involved in the likes of approving Hin Leong’s trades, as well as managing the company’s cash situation and financing matters.
The prosecution says OK Lim was trying to use his medical conditions as “an excuse to undermine the value” of his statements that were recorded during his interviews with the CAD.

Resuming his cross examination of Lim, deputy public prosecutor Christopher Ong had asked Lim about his involvement in Hin Leong’s day-to-day operations right up to the time he had stepped down as the company’s managing director in April 2020.
Prosecutors led by DPP Christopher Ong on Friday (Nov 3) began their cross-examination of OK Lim.
The court heard that there were occasions when OK Lim had attended interviews with the CAD while he was unwell.

Lim, who is represented by lawyers of Davinder Singh Chambers, disagreed with statements that were provided by Hin Leong accounts executive Katherine Ong and Freddy Tan – a contracts executive at Hin Leong that were read in court by one of the firm’s lawyers Navin Thevar.

site_title: DoorDash aims to boost presence abroad while rivals struggle
summary: DoorDash aims to expand its international presence, particularly in sparsely populated European countries, where it currently has a limited market share. The company, which operates in 28 countries, is seeking to boost its penetration levels and match the success of its US marketplace. CEO Tony Xu stated that while growth is present, DoorDash has a long way to go to achieve the same level of recognition as it has in the US. The company's overseas expansion is seen as a strategic move to counter its US-based rivals.

images.alt_text: A Doordash delivery person rides their bike on Church Avenue in the Flatbush neighborhood of Brooklyn on December 4, 2020 in New York City. A rule issued January 9, 2024, by the US Labor Department making it tougher for companies to classify workers as "independent contractors" could take a toll on the gig economy -- and is likely to face challenges. This includes drivers of ride-hailing services such as Uber and Lyft, or delivery workers for companies like DoorDash. (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)
The grocery delivery business has doubled in gross order value in the third quarter compared to a year ago, chief financial officer Ravi Inukonda says.

site_title: General Atlantic to buy a stake in asset manager Partners Capital
summary: General Atlantic is investing in Partners Capital, a US$50 billion asset manager, through its core growth equity funds. Partners Capital will operate independently from General Atlantic, with founding executives selling equity but remaining shareholders. The deal aims to provide incentives for talent retention and expand General Atlantic's wealth management presence. The investment marks another claim for General Atlantic in the sector, following successful early investments in tech firms like Facebook and Uber.

images.alt_text: General Atlantic chairman and CEO Bill Ford told the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos that he saw a “multi-decade opportunity” in energy transition, adding the world needed more renewable energy to power itself.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine Q1 gross profit rises 75.8% to S$11.6 million
summary: Marco Polo Marine has reported a 75.8% increase in gross profit to S$11.6 million for the first quarter ended Dec 31, 2023. The shipyard and marine logistics company attributed this to an uptick in its ship chartering business and a 9 percentage point year-on-year increase in average utilisation rates. Revenue rose 22.8% to S$29.1 million, and the gross profit margin was 39.9%, up from 27.8% previously. The company expects continued demand and higher utilisation rates for offshore supply vessels in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: COSCO SHIPPING has the best YTD total returns for 2024 among transportation stocks on the Singapore Exchange.
Marco Polo Marine gross profit margin for H2 is up to 39.3 per cent from 33 per cent in the same period a year ago.
Both the marine logistics company’s ship chartering and shipyard segments record improvements in operational performance.

site_title: TikTok sues EU over content law levy
summary: TikTok is challenging a European Union fee to enforce a content moderation law under the Digital Services Act. The video-sharing app, on the EU's list of "very large" online platforms, opposed the calculation method for the fee, citing flawed estimates of its monthly active user numbers. TikTok confirmed it had paid the fee last year, but disputes the amount. The EU's Digital Services Act compels platforms to police content and protect online shoppers from fraud, with the fee calculated in proportion to the size of the service.

images.alt_text: The European Commission has said the Digital Services Act (DSA) levy applies to 20 very large online platforms, including Meta, Google, Apple and TikTok and two very large online search engines.

site_title: Boeing 'undoubtedly' making progress on quality issues, Avolon CEO says
summary: Boeing is making significant progress in addressing quality issues, according to Avolon CEO Andy Cronin. Preliminary findings from a US regulatory investigation into a recent incident involving a 737 MAX 9 jet found no design implications or systemic production issues. This positive outcome suggests Boeing is on track to resolving quality concerns, with Cronin describing the progress as "undoubtedly" positive.

images.alt_text: The Boeing Co. logo is displayed outside of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)
The defect follows a string of manufacturing lapses at Boeing, including a near-catastrophic panel blowout on an Alaska Airlines 737 Max last month.

site_title: Swedish central bank official says rate cut more likely in May or June than March
summary: Sweden's central bank may lower its key policy rate in the first six months of 2024, with a cut in May or June more likely than in March, according to Riksbank deputy governor Per Jansson. For a cut in March, inflation needs to slow down and major central banks' rate-cutting plans should be clearer. The central bank held its policy rate unchanged at 4% in February, but now expects rate cuts could come earlier than previously forecast.

site_title: For China's new globetrotters, group tours are out and Northern Lights are in
summary: Chinese travelers are shifting away from group tours and shopping holidays, opting for more adventurous and experience-based trips, industry experts say. As the Chinese New Year holiday approaches, record-high numbers are choosing to travel abroad, with a focus on independent travelers, particularly younger generations. Northern Lights sightings and unique experiences, such as safaris and cultural holidays, are popular destinations. Flight schedules and visa processing times are returning to pre-pandemic levels, contributing to the growth in international travel.

images.alt_text: AOT, who operates six airports in Thailand including the main Suvarnabhumi gateway, says it was prepared for the sharp increase in flights and passengers.

site_title: Israeli lawmakers approve amended war budget for 2024 in initial vote
summary: Israeli lawmakers have approved an amended 2024 state budget worth 584 billion shekels, with higher defense spending and compensation for households and businesses affected by the conflict with Hamas, in a 57-50 vote. The budget, which includes debt repayment, now heads to the finance committee for potential adjustments before its second and third votes later this month.

images.alt_text: epa11022569 Smoke rises from the Gaza Strip following Israeli airstrikes, as seen from an undisclosed location near the border between Gaza and southern Israel, in Israel, 11 December 2023. More than 18,000 Palestinians and at least 1,200 Israelis have been killed, according to the Palestinian Health Ministry and the Israel Defense Forces (IDF), since Hamas militants launched an attack against Israel from the Gaza Strip on 07 October, and the Israeli operations in Gaza and the West Bank which followed it.  EPA-EFE/ABIR SULTAN

site_title: Singapore stocks decline on news of higher-than-expected drop in China’s CPI
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.4% on Thursday, February 8, as investors reacted to China's 0.8% year-on-year drop in consumer prices, the fastest since the global financial crisis. The Straits Times Index fell 13.24 points to 3,142.91. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index slid 1.3%, despite a rally in China's CSI 300, which ended 0.6% higher. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 2.1% on interest rate comments, while local stocks CapitaLand and DFI Retail Group made significant gains.

images.alt_text:
ST20231129-202342522839-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
SGX Centre 1 at Shenton Way in the Central Business District on Nov 29, 2023.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: StarHub’s move to substitute capex with opex bears fruit; higher dividend declared for FY23
summary: StarHub reported a net profit of S$72.9 million for the second half of FY23, up from S$1.3 million in the same period a year earlier, driven by growth in high-margin mobile services. Revenue fell 0.1% to S$1.3 billion, while service Ebitda rose 32.6% to S$219.3 million. The company declared a final dividend of S$0.042 per share, higher than the previous year's S$0.05 per share, and expects to increase net margin efficiency and reduce net debt. StarHub plans to explore mergers and acquisitions and expand its regional enterprise business.

images.alt_text: The move aligns with ST Engineering’s strategy to grow its cyber business and will allow StarHub to optimise its resources on other businesses which will elevate the execution of its 3C strategy.
Launched in 2021, StarHub’s Dare+ initiative builds the telco’s 5G network and other IT expenditures as part of its five-year growth map.

site_title: Valentine’s Day: The changing face of love
summary: Dating apps have dramatically shifted dating and mating patterns, offering unprecedented access to potential partners but also increasing the ease of losing one. Experts say the speed of coupling up has led to new labels for relationship structures, such as "situationships," and a greater emphasis on finding compatibility on emotional, intellectual, and lifestyle levels. Despite technological conveniences, some singles still struggle to find and keep love, with experts advising self-reflection, inner-work, and being clear with intentions and expectations. To keep the love alive, couples must prioritize intimacy, communication, and collaboration, and make a conscious effort to create and nurture their relationship.

images.alt_text: “Real” plant-based foods that are less processed, are making a comeback, says a wellbeing practitioner.

site_title: Architects Neri & Hu find inspiration in Shanghai
summary: Architects Lyndon Neri and Rossana Hu, founders of Neri&Hu Design & Research Office, reflect on their 20-year journey in Shanghai, where they found inspiration in the city's Chinese New Year and Asian heritage. The couple, who met at a young age, started their firm in 2004 and have since designed notable projects such as The Waterhouse at South Bund and Yangzhou Tsingpu Retreat. With a unique blend of Western and Asian influences, Neri&Hu has become one of the most progressive firms in the world, contributing to Shanghai's urban regeneration and showcasing the city's vibrant culture.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB upgrades DBS to ‘buy’ as clarity on dividend commitment improves
summary: DBS Group Holdings has been upgraded to "buy" by RHB, following clearer guidance on dividend commitments. The bank proposed a higher dividend payout and bonus shares to increase capital returns to shareholders. RHB expects DBS to maintain its focus on absolute dividend per share, offering investors "bond-like coupons" with yields too good to ignore. The research team has raised its target price to S$36.10, implying a 10.8% potential upside. DBS' Q4 results aligned with expectations, with a 3% drop in net profit to S$2.27 billion.

images.alt_text: The cut in variable pay likely means that DBS CEO Piyush Gupta will lose his bragging rights as the highest-paid executive among the three local banks.
An IG market analyst says DBS' higher Q4 dividend "may signal some confidence" for the bank's longer-term prospects.
DBS posts 3% drop in Q4 profit to S$2.27b; full-year earnings hit record S$10.06b

site_title: Shipping giant Maersk's profit sinks, warns of Red Sea risk
summary: Maersk, a shipping giant, reported a net profit of $3.8 billion in 2023, down from $29.2 billion in 2022. The company attributed the decline to an oversupply of container shipping, which led to a drop in prices after soaring in 2022 due to capacity shortages. Maersk warned of "uncertainty" in 2024 due to Yemeni rebel attacks on vessels in the Red Sea, which may disrupt global maritime trade. The company lowered its 2024 forecast for core profit to $1-6 billion, citing high uncertainty around the Red Sea disruption.

images.alt_text: “It’s hard to see that there can possibly be any winners, there will only be losers in the end,” Maersk CEO Vincent Clerc says.

site_title: Indonesia metals giant seeks bids for US$2 billion loan
summary: Indonesia's state-owned mineral-resources holding company, Mind ID, is seeking bids for a US$2 billion loan to repay existing debt and fund investments in downstream processing projects. The company plans to consider loan and bond options, depending on pricing. Mind ID has stakes in several Indonesian companies with interests in commodities such as nickel, copper, and gold, and is working to boost Indonesia's economy through mineral downstreaming. The loan is part of Mind ID's business plan, which includes third-party funding in 2024.

site_title: Nissan posts 6% rise in Q3 profit, missing estimates
summary: Nissan reported a 6.4% rise in operating profit to 141.6 billion yen in the December quarter, missing analyst estimates. The company maintained its annual operating profit forecast of 620 billion yen and revised its retail sales outlook down to 3.55 million vehicles due to lower forecasted sales across markets. Nissan cited intensifying competition and logistics issues in key markets, including China, as the reasons for the revised outlook. Despite the lower sales forecast, Nissan's global sales grew 4.6% to 3.3 million vehicles in 2023, driven by stronger performance in North America and Europe.

images.alt_text: Nissan says it is working with suppliers in an effort to meet changing requirements “and regain tax credit eligibility for the Nissan Leaf in the future”.

site_title: Unilever launches US$1.6 billion buyback as CEO demands improvements
summary: Unilever launched a US$1.6 billion share buyback after its full-year underlying operating profit rose 2.6% to 9.9 billion euros, but missed analyst expectations. CEO Hein Schumacher stated that the company's performance needs improvement, citing disappointing market share growth and increased costs. Despite this, the company reported a 5% rise in fourth-quarter underlying sales and a modest improvement in underlying operating margin. Unilever aims to transform into a consistently higher-performing business through increased brand and marketing investment.

images.alt_text: Unilever sales disappoint as emerging markets dampen growth

site_title: Foreign relations: An ambassador’s CNY
summary: EU Ambassador Iwona Piorko is celebrating her third Chinese New Year in Singapore, a festive season she has grown to appreciate for its cultural diversity and harmony. Piorko, who has been in her post since 2021, finds the celebrations fascinating and feels like part of the community. She shares her enthusiasm with friends and family, including a traditional yu sheng toss and decorating her home with a pussy willow arrangement, a practice she enjoyed as a child in Poland. The EU ambassador sees her role in fostering trust and cooperation between Singapore and the EU, particularly through the digital trade agreement.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Uchida says hard to see sharp hiking pace after liftoff
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Shinichi Uchida stated that it's challenging to envision a sharp increase in policy rates even after the negative interest rate policy ends. He expects financial market conditions to remain easy, with any subsequent policy moves occurring at a gradual pace. This contradicts predictions by over half of economists surveyed in January that the negative rate policy would end in April. The yen weakened, and Japanese bond yields erased gains as Uchida spoke, indicating potential market reaction to his comments. Annual wage negotiations will be a key factor in determining the policy trajectory.

images.alt_text: Manufacturers’ confidence remained strong, staying above the series average led by hopes for improved demand in markets such as semiconductors, though optimism slightly dipped from December
Japanese household spending in December fell 2.5 per cent from a year earlier, government data showed on Tuesday.
The service sector has been a bright spot for the world’s third-largest economy, helping offset some of the drag on manufacturers from weak global demand.
The acquisition of Singlife by Sumitomo Life is just one of many deals Japanese corporates in South-east Asia, with their banks looking to leverage their low cost of funds.

site_title: India central bank proposes steps to widen usage of its digital currency
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has proposed additional features to popularize its central bank digital currency, the e-rupee. The features include allowing digital rupee transactions when a customer is offline, introducing programmability, and adding a validity period or geographical ring-fencing. This will enable government agencies and companies to program expenditures and ensure secure digital payments. The RBI also plans to introduce offline solutions for remote areas with poor internet connectivity, building on the success of pilot projects that helped disburse employee benefits through the digital rupee.

images.alt_text: India's annual retail inflation rose to 5.69 per cent in December from November’s 5.55 per cent, well above the central bank's 4 per cent target.

site_title: Philippines finance secretary not expecting future rate hike
summary: Finance Secretary Ralph Recto does not expect future interest rate hikes in the Philippines due to easing inflation, which is within the central bank's 2-4% target range. The country's annual inflation rate stood at 2.8% in January, its slowest pace in over three years. Recto also mentioned that the Philippine economy's growth target may need to be adjusted to "something more realistic" after missing its 6-7% growth goal in 2023. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas will hold its first rate-setting meeting on February 15.

images.alt_text: Eli Remolona, Governor of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, speaks at an event at the Central Bank in Manila, Philippines, on Friday, July 28, 2023. Remolona said upside risks to inflation persist, in comments that indicate the monetary authority is open to further tightening. Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

site_title: AstraZeneca targets 2024 growth as portfolio booms
summary: AstraZeneca expects to boost revenue and profit in 2024 due to resilient demand for its cancer and rare disease drugs, driven by blockbusters such as Tagrisso, Calquence, and Farxiga. The company reported slightly lower-than-expected fourth-quarter profit, but its pipeline has been rebuilt under CEO Pascal Soriot's leadership. AstraZeneca expects 10-15% revenue growth and core earnings per share increase in 2024, with a strong presence in China contributing to its growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Test tubes are seen in front of a displayed AstraZeneca logo in this illustration taken, May 21, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration//File Photo

site_title: China’s consumer prices drop at fastest pace since 2009
summary: China's consumer prices dropped 0.8% in January, the largest decline since 2009, amid a struggle to revive domestic demand and consumer confidence. The producer price index fell 2.5%, further indicating deflationary pressure. Economists urge China to stimulate the economy and reverse a stock market slide, citing a risk of entrenched deflationary expectations. Deflation poses a significant threat, potentially leading to a downward spiral in consumption and business sales if not addressed.

site_title: Malaysia has recovered RM23 million in 1MDB assets since January 2023
summary: Malaysia has recovered RM23 million in 1MDB assets since January 2023, bringing the total recovered assets to RM29.03 billion. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission attributed the recovery to cooperation with the 1MDB asset recovery task force and foreign agencies. This follows a 10-year prison sentence deferral for ex-Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng to assist in the investigation. Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's sentence was halved to 12 years, while his fine was reduced to RM50 million.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Ex-Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng and his lawyer Marc Agnifilo leave the federal court in New York, U.S., May 6, 2019. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: Thai central bank ready to cut rates if private consumption falls sharply
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) is prepared to cut interest rates if private consumption falls sharply, according to senior director Sakkapop Panyanukul. The central bank kept key rates at 2.50% on Wednesday amid pressure from the government to ease monetary policy. Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has urged the bank to cut rates due to decade-high interest rates affecting small businesses and debtors. Any rate cuts would be small, with a long-term negative impact, and would only benefit debtors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Bank of Thailand logo is pictured in Bangkok, Thailand, August 5, 2016. Picture taken August 5, 2016.  Reuters/Chaiwat Subprasom/File Photo

site_title: Money laundering accused charged with submitting forged documents to cheat StanChart, Bank of Singapore
summary: Su Jianfeng, a Vanuatu passport holder, has been charged with submitting forged documents to Standard Chartered and Bank of Singapore to cheat them. He allegedly submitted false annual reports to show his wife, Chen Qiuyan, had legitimate wealth. Su faces six charges, including possessing S$17 million in cash from unlawful remote gambling activities. He has had over S$160 million of assets seized, including 13 properties, four vehicles, and S$20 million in bank accounts. Su will appear in court on Feb 15 for a pre-trial conference.

images.alt_text: Singapore is seeing its biggest money laundering case play out with more than S$3 billion of assets confiscated from ethnic Chinese so far.
The 10 accused in the case.
Suspects in the money laundering case have ties to dozens of companies, including two with a registered office address at Telok Ayer (above).

site_title: Sabana Reit investors ask to withdraw, modify upcoming EGM resolutions
summary: A group of Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) unitholders, led by Quarz Capital, have requested to withdraw and modify some of the resolutions proposed for an upcoming Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM). The unitholders are seeking to reduce costs and minimize issues related to the Reit's internalization process. They propose withdrawing two ordinary resolutions and amending another to provide bi-weekly written updates on the internalization process. The unitholders are also seeking clarification on how the trustee's spending of S$3.2 million on internalization is being utilized.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
Reit analysts are keeping a close eye on occupancy resilience and rental reversions in the upcoming earnings season.
A group of unitholders led by activist investor Quarz are looking to pass 12 resolutions at the EGM.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
Sabana Reit's manager has filed a defence to clarify its tenant's mischaracterisation of its obligations under lease.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.

site_title: January was world’s warmest on record, say EU scientists
summary: The European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) announced that January 2024 was the world's warmest January on record, surpassing the previous record set in 2020. This is part of a 12-month period where global temperatures have exceeded 1.5 degrees Celsius above the pre-industrial reference period. Scientists warn that rapid reductions in greenhouse gas emissions are necessary to stop global temperatures from increasing, and 2024 has a one-in-three chance of being even hotter than 2023.

images.alt_text: A man drinks water during a heat wave, in Santiago, Chile January 31, 2024. REUTERS/ Sofia Yanjari

A campaign volunteer places signs in a snow bank for Former South Carolina Governor and Republican presidential candidate Nikki Haley before the start of a campaign event at Jethro’s BBQ in Ames, Iowa, Jan 14, 2024.
People with umbrellas walk through heavy rain in New York, Jan 9, 2024. A major storm system was battering parts of the United States on Tuesday.
“Very hot” days, where daily maximum temperatures exceed 35 degrees Celsius, are set to become a new normal.

site_title: SoftBank posts first profit in five quarters with US$6.6 billion net income
summary: SoftBank Group posted its first profit in five quarters, with a net income of $6.6 billion in the three months to December, compared to a loss of $6.73 billion in the same period last year. The company's portfolio companies, including ride-hailing company Didi Global and robotics firm AutoStore Holdings, drove the increase. SoftBank's Vision Fund arm also booked an investment profit of $600.73 billion, with valuations for some holdings rising during the quarter. The company's shares jumped 11% on the news, and investors are now looking for potential returns on shareholder capital.

images.alt_text: SoftBank has loosened its hold on Paytm over the past few years, trimming its stake through various open market deals.

site_title: Once disgraced, military man Prabowo eyes Indonesia presidency after makeover
summary: Indonesian Defence Minister and presidential candidate Prabowo Subianto has emerged as the front-runner with a 20-point lead in the latest poll, garnering 45.8% support. Once disgraced and exiled, Prabowo has undergone a transformation since becoming defence minister in 2019, cultivating a more charismatic image. With the backing of incumbent President Joko Widodo and his son as a running mate, Prabowo is seeking to overcome his troubled past, including allegations of human rights abuses. The Feb 14 vote is approaching, with Prabowo's rebranding seemingly working to win over undecided voters.

images.alt_text: Despite the 2023 modest performance, economists and government forecast that Indonesia’s growth will slow down this year due to external headwinds.

Third-time candidate and current defence minister Prabowo Subianto (pictured) is ahead in opinion polls, widening the gap since choosing Joko Widodo’s eldest son Gibran Rakabuming Raka as his running mate last year.

Presidential candidate and Indonesia’s Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto speaks on the stage during the last presidential election debate at the Jakarta Convention Center (JCC) in Jakarta on February 4, 2024.

Joko Widodo, Indonesia's President, speaks during a ground breaking ceremony for projects funded by private investors at the new national capital Nusantara (IKN) in Penajam Paser Utara, Indonesia, on Thursday, Sept. 21, 2023. Indonesian tycoons are leading the way in investing in the country's new capital city, with a hotel starting construction on Thursday. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Siemens beats Q1 forecast despite digital industry weakness
summary: Siemens reported a 3% increase in industrial profit to €2.72 billion for the first quarter, beating analyst forecasts. Despite a slowdown at its digital industries unit, which saw new orders fall 33%, the company's train-making Mobility and building automation basis Smart Infrastructure reported strong performances. Revenue rose 2% to €18.41 billion, below forecast due to currency translation effects. The company's results are seen as a proxy for the global economy, with a stronger performance in Mobility offsetting the downturn.

images.alt_text: Siemens Energy has had repeated setbacks at its Siemens Gamesa wind turbine business which led to questions over its strategy of trying to serve broad swathes of the utility sector.

site_title: Rejecting the ‘too-low’ bid for the Marina Gardens Crescent site risks missing the big picture
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has rejected the sole bid for the 99-year leasehold Marina Gardens Crescent site due to a bid price deemed too low. The site, with a maximum gross floor area of nearly 783,000 square feet, can generate about 775 private homes. It will now be made available on the reserve list for the H1 2024 GLS Programme, allowing developers to submit applications with a minimum price acceptable to the government. The decision aims to ensure adequate private housing supply.

images.alt_text: The Marina Gardens Crescent site (in orange and dark grey) drew just one bid at a URA tender that closed on Jan 18, 2024. In contrast, the nearby Marina Gardens Lane plot (in purple) received four bids at a URA tender In June 2023.,

The Marina Gardens Crescent site (in orange and dark grey) fetched just one bid at a URA tender that closed on Jan 18, 2024. In contrast, the nearby Marina Gardens Lane plot (in purple) drew at a URA tender closing In June 2023.

site_title: Digital Core Reit’s private placement closes at  US$0.625, upsizes to raise US$120 million
summary: Digital Core Reit has closed its private placement, issuing 192 million new units at US$0.625 per unit, up to US$120 million. The enlarged unit base will be approximately 1.32 billion units. The proceeds will be used to fund potential acquisitions (62.5%), repay debt (35.4%), and pay fees and expenses (2.1%). The issue price represents a 5% discount to the market price, resulting in a pro forma FY2023 distribution per unit increase to US$0.0358.

images.alt_text: About 75 per cent of the gross proceeds raised will be used to fund potential acquisitions, says the manager.

One of Mapletree Industrial Turst's assets, at 250 Williams Street NW, Atlanta. MIT’s portfolio occupancy for its data centre segment is at 91.0 per cent (as at Dec 31, 2023), 2.4 percentage points lower quarter on quarter.
John Stewart, the Reit manager’s chief executive, said a perceived peak in the US interest rate tightening cycle has spurred a recovery in the prices of Reit units.

site_title: Generative AI faces major test as Indonesia holds largest election since boom
summary: Indonesia's general election on February 14 will test the impact of generative AI on large-scale political campaigning. Candidates, including former special forces commander Prabowo Subianto, are using AI tools to create campaign art, track social media sentiment, and target voters. The use of AI is widespread, with many campaigns powered by OpenAI, and some experts see it as a game-changer in the electoral landscape. However, concerns about AI interference and voter manipulation have been raised, with some campaign materials being labeled as "deepfakes." Despite this, election watchers say disinformation has been limited compared to the 2019 election. The outcome of the election will provide insights into the role of generative AI in politics.

images.alt_text: Bottom-up approaches based on the inclusion and empowerment of “smart” citizens may well be the missing ingredient in building trusted and responsible AI governance systems.

site_title: OpenAI developing software that operates devices, automates tasks: report
summary: OpenAI is developing software that can automate complex tasks on devices, including web-based tasks such as data gathering and itinerary creation, without requiring close supervision. The agent software, backed by Microsoft, will handle tasks like booking flight tickets and creating itineraries. This development comes after OpenAI's successful ChatGPT chatbot, which demonstrated generative artificial intelligence capabilities. The company has not commented on the new project.

site_title: India’s central bank leaves rates unchanged, as expected
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), left interest rates unchanged for the sixth consecutive meeting, maintaining the key repo rate at 6.50%. The decision comes despite annual retail inflation rising to 5.69% in December, exceeding the RBI's 4% target. RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das emphasized the need for an actively disinflationary monetary policy, but a sustained fall in core inflation and a fiscally prudent budget may lead to a possible policy pivot in the future.

site_title: Gold gains as US dollar, yields slip ahead of US weekly jobs report
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,037.80 per ounce ahead of the US weekly jobless claims report, driven by a softer US dollar and lower Treasury yields. The US dollar index fell 0.1% and 10-year Treasury yields slipped to 4.0921%, making non-yielding bullion more appealing. Investors await the jobless claims report, which could impact interest rate decisions, while the regional banking sector remains a concern.

images.alt_text: High interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion, decreasing its appeal among other assets.

site_title: Singaporeans flock to Malaysia for bargains as dollar hits record high
summary: Singaporeans are flocking to Malaysia to take advantage of the country's low ringgit currency, which has fallen 3.5% against the US dollar this year, making goods and services cheaper for those from Singapore. The Singapore dollar has reached a record RM3.55 against the ringgit, allowing locals to buy more goods and services at a lower cost. Many residents are stocking up on festive treats and gifts, with prices being significantly cheaper across the border, with some items costing up to two times less in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Most Malaysian business owners have felt the pinch of the rising cost due to weakening ringgit.
The son of Sarawak’s first governor, Abang Johari has had a role in every administration since 1982.
Malaysia's central reiterated that at the interest rate of 3%,  the monetary policy stance remains supportive of the economy.
With inflation unlikey to fall towards policymakers' target of 2 per cent and as recession risk fades, the US Federal Reserve may not be motivated to cut rates within the year.
Bank Negara believed that most domestic businesses is able to withstand potential new shocks amid improvements in business leverage, healthy cash buffers and more agile business models.
The ringgit has slid more than 1 per cent in January, adding to losses from the previous three years.

site_title: SocGen’s Q4 earnings slide but retail bank helps it beat forecasts
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) reported a 60% drop in Q4 net income to 430 million euros, beating analyst expectations due to a recovery in its domestic retail business and stable investment bank trading revenue. Group revenue dropped 10% to 6 billion euros, with sales from trading in its investment bank slipping 0.8%. The bank aims to slash costs, sell non-performing assets, and achieve a 6% return on tangible equity by 2026. Despite a challenging "year of transition", SocGen announced a proposed dividend and share buyback, with CEO Slawomir Krupa promising the "meticulous execution" of its strategic plan.

images.alt_text: The logo of French bank Societe Generale is seen outside a bank building in Paris, France, February 5, 2024. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier

site_title: UK job recruiters report sharp slowdown in pay for new hires
summary: UK job recruiters report a sharp slowdown in pay for new hires, with starting salaries climbing at the slowest pace in 34 months. Employers are hiring fewer permanent staff and restraining pay increases due to economic uncertainty and pressure on spending budgets. The Recruitment & Employment Confederation (REC) found fewer job vacancies and an increase in candidates seeking work, making firms reluctant to give new hires big pay bumps. The Bank of England is watching pay figures closely, forecasting CPI inflation to drop to 2% and potentially cutting interest rates.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global/CIPS UK Purchasing Managers’ Index’s headline measure of the construction industry improves to 48.8 in January from 46.8 in December, its highest since August 2023 although still in no-growth territory.
With Brits staying at home during two winter storms, grocery volumes saw their “largest year-on-year growth in over 12 months”, Sarah Bradbury says.

Two men speak together as they cross over a footbridge in London's central business district of Canary Wharf, on August 14, 2023. The British Office for National Statistics (ONS) will release new data on the job market on August 15 morning. The unemployment rate in the three months to the end of June 2023 is expected to remain unchanged at 4.0%, according to a consensus supplied by Pantheon Macroeconomics. But experts are expecting a considerable slowdown in employment growth. (Photo by HENRY NICHOLLS / AFP)

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts raise CICT targets after strong H2 showing
summary: Brokerages have raised their price target estimates for CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) after the real estate investment trust reported a 1.7% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second half ended December. Maybank Securities and RHB Research increased their target prices by S$0.20 each, with Maybank now setting a target price of S$2.10. Analysts have also raised their FY2025 estimates by 1.8% and introduced lower discount rates, reiterating their "buy" calls for the trust.

krhls31 - Bukit Panjang Plaza

The manager attributes the improvement in performance to higher contributions from Raffles City Singapore and full-year contributions from the Reit’s 2022 acquisitions.
For the quarter, CICT also registered a steady growth in portfolio committed occupancy at 97.3 per cent.
Proceeds raised will be used to finance or refinance the eligible green projects undertaken by CICT and its subsidiaries under the trust’s green finance framework.

site_title: Arm soars after expansion into new markets buoys forecast
summary: ARM Holdings rose 26% in late trading after CEO Rene Haas provided a bullish forecast, citing expansion into new markets, including server chips, as a key factor in the company's growth and profitability. Revenue is expected to be $850-900 million for the March quarter, exceeding analyst estimates, and the company now expects $3.16 billion in sales for fiscal 2024. This marks a significant shift from the smartphone market, which now accounts for less than a third of Arm's sales.

images.alt_text: Arm is still recovering from the turmoil of an extended dispute with the ousted head of Arm China, a joint venture owned by SoftBank and a group of Chinese investors.

site_title: Asia: Most markets track Wall Street record, Shanghai extends rally
summary: Asia's markets rose on Thursday, following Wall Street's record high, as investors cheered Chinese pledges to boost the markets and strong earnings reports from US firms. Despite fading hopes for an early Federal Reserve interest rate cut, traders now focus on inflation coming down and US growth remaining on track. Shanghai stocks surged, building on near five percent gains over the previous two days, while Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul also saw gains. However, Singapore and Wellington dropped, and Hong Kong was dragged lower by a decline in Alibaba's shares.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.4 per cent higher at 38,677.36 on Tuesday.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 63 to 48 after 67.2 million securities worth S$94.8 million change hands.

site_title: Everything China’s doing to rescue its battered stock market
summary: Chinese authorities are intensifying rescue efforts to stabilize the stock market, which has plummeted by $7 trillion, with the benchmark CSI 300 Index gaining 5.2% this week. The government has replaced the head of the securities regulator, announced a plan to brief President Xi Jinping on markets, and implemented various measures to support developers, listed firms, and consumers. The central bank has also cut the reserve requirement ratio and provided low-cost funds for lending to housing and infrastructure projects. The national team, a group of Chinese state funds, has bought onshore shares, and regulators are cracking down on illegal activities such as short selling and insider trading.

images.alt_text: Anticipation of more fulsome efforts to end the rout had been mounting for days, after Bloomberg News reported that regulators led by the CSRC planned to brief President Xi on the markets as soon as Tuesday.
Yi Huiman's removal comes as Chinese markets are on a knife edge as institutional and retail investors scramble to cut their losses.
Chinese shares sank to a five-year low on Friday (Feb 2), prompting regulators to tighten trading restrictions to stem the prolonged rout.
Xi Jinping has shown signs of becoming increasingly involved in the nation’s financial and economy policies.

site_title: Xi’s markets shakeup surprised insiders, showing alarm over rout
summary: China's securities regulator has ousted its head, Yi Huiman, amid a $5 trillion sell-off that's undermined confidence in the nation's fragile economy. The move signals growing alarm within President Xi Jinping's government over the market meltdown, now entering its fourth year. Wu Qing, a close ally of Premier Li Qiang, is taking over as chairman of the regulator. Analysts say the change may signal additional measures to revive China's world's second-largest stock market, but reforms and policy consistency are required to address structural macro headwinds.

images.alt_text: Yi Huiman's removal comes as Chinese markets are on a knife edge as institutional and retail investors scramble to cut their losses.
Xi Jinping has shown signs of becoming increasingly involved in the nation’s financial and economy policies.
China is trying to stabilise markets after shares sank to a five-year low in chaotic trading on Friday.
The watchdog’s vow to stabilise the market comes amid growing concerns that slumping share prices could trigger more selling in a vicious spiral.

site_title: Apple’s Vision Pro headset is being resold for US$5,000 overseas
summary: Apple's Vision Pro headset, priced at $3,500, is being resold for up to $8,500 on various online marketplaces due to its limited release and exclusive setup process. The device, a virtual reality (VR) gadget, is drawing interest from overseas buyers, including dedicated fans, software developers, and industry players. Analysts attribute the inflated prices to the device's exclusivity and the potential for future growth in the extended reality (XR) market.

images.alt_text: Apple put the Vision Pro on sale in a limited number of stores in the US at the start of this month. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Fullerton Health’s three co-founders slapped with corruption charges
summary: Three co-founders of Fullerton Health Corporation, including former majority owner David Sin, have been charged with corruption and falsifying nearly half a million dollars in entertainment claims. Sin faces five counts, while Tan faces four and Chan faces one, for conspiring to give gratification totaling S$668,000 to Collin Chiew, a former Aon Risk Solutions executive, between 2015 and 2019.

images.alt_text: Fullerton Health could turn to courts for rescue as woes mount and white knight seems elusive

While the government will review its contracts to safeguard Singapore's interest, it remains committed to the F1 Singapore Grand Prix, said Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations Grace Fu.
Tycoon Ong Beng Seng is alleged to have offered benefits worth over S$384,000 to former transport minister S Iswaran.
Former Transport Minister S Iswaran faces 27 charges in total, including two charges of corruption.

site_title: Marina Gardens Crescent site bid ‘too low’, plot not awarded: URA
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) rejected the sole bid for a 99-year leasehold plot in Marina Gardens Crescent as "too low", resulting in the site not being awarded. The bid, submitted by GuocoLand, Intrepid Investments, and TID Residential, was nearly 30% lower than the S$1,402 psf ppr paid for a neighboring plot in Marina Gardens Lane. The URA has put the site on the reserve list for future tendering, and market experts expect the site may not be triggered soon due to the increasing supply of new homes in the city.

images.alt_text: The government plays a critical role in ensuring adequate private housing supply.

The Marina Gardens Crescent site (in orange and dark grey) fetched just one bid at a URA tender that closed on Jan 18, 2024. In contrast, the nearby Marina Gardens Lane plot (in purple) drew at a URA tender closing In June 2023.
The Media Circle site in one-north can yield an estimated 355 residential units.

site_title: Time to cut 15-month waiting period for ‘downgraders’, tweak ABSD, bring back estate tax: PropertyGuru
summary: PropertyGuru Singapore has proposed three recommendations to alleviate challenges faced by home buyers and owners in Singapore ahead of the Budget 2024 statement. These include reducing the 15-month waiting period for private home "downgraders" to buy HDB flats, withholding Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) for Singaporeans buying a second property, and reintroducing estate tax. The proposals aim to address concerns about price appreciation, rental market volatility, and wealth inequality. Experts suggest implementing measures such as raising minimum occupation periods or imposing capital gains tax to prevent speculative behavior, and adjusting estate tax rates according to property values.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Association for the Deaf will provide simultaneous sign language interpretation of Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong’s speech on Channel 5.
Non-owner-occupied residential properties account for around two-thirs of the tax revenue increase, said Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat on Tuesday.
Budget 2024 could bring further top-ups to the Assurance Package, which was introduced in 2020 to cushion the impact of GST hikes.

site_title: Worldline to lay off 8% of its workforce
summary: French digital payments company Worldline confirmed it will cut its global workforce by around 8% as part of a cost reduction plan initiated in October. The move follows the company's previous announcement of cutting full-year targets and ties with some merchants to reduce crime risks. Worldline initiated social processes with employee representative bodies within the group.

site_title: Chinese Bitcoin miners find a new crypto haven in Ethiopia
summary: Chinese Bitcoin miners have found a new haven in Ethiopia, drawn by the country's low electricity costs and increasingly friendly government. Ethiopia, which allowed Bitcoin mining in 2022, has bolstered ties with China, with several Chinese companies helping build the $4.8 billion Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam. The country's ability to supply electricity for Bitcoin mining may rival that of Texas, with the potential to become a major hub. However, the industry faces risks, including the possibility of a backlash from the government and environmental concerns. Ethiopian officials are cautious, with the government permitting Bitcoin mining mainly due to the companies' payment in foreign currency.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin mining is an energy-intensive process in which miners use specialised computers to validate transactions on the Bitcoin blockchain and earn rewards in the token.

site_title: Disney earnings top views on cost cuts, parks; shares climb
summary: Disney reported better-than-expected earnings for its fiscal first quarter, with earnings rising to $1.22 a share and revenue at $23.5 billion, despite a struggling TV business and two theatrical misses. The company cited cost-cutting benefits and strong international theme park performance as key drivers. Disney also announced a 50% increase in dividend and a $3 billion stock repurchase program, and acquired a $1.5 billion stake in Epic Games. The company expects a 20% profit rise this year, beating estimates, and predicts its streaming operation will reach profitability by the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: The Disney store in New York.Photographer: Angus Mordant/Bloomberg

site_title: China is oversupplied with commodities as deflation persists
summary: China's commodities markets enter the Chinese New Year break on a deflationary note, with weak aggregate demand and oversupply issues persisting. Energy markets are under pressure due to warmer weather and tepid industrial demand, while grain and pork markets face ample supply. However, metals like copper are showing resilience, with the global market tightening and green demand booming. The government's response to the economy's woes, including a crisis of confidence in the stock market, will be crucial, with a potential reset on fiscal stimulus expected at the annual policy-setting meeting in early March.

site_title: Manhattan apartment leases surge, keeping rents from sliding
summary: Manhattan apartment leasing surged in January, with 3,922 rental agreements signed, a 14% increase from last year, and median rent rising 1.3% to $4,150. This marks the first year-over-year rent increase since October. Despite Manhattan's median rent being below the all-time high of $4,440, it remains above pre-pandemic levels. Outer boroughs, such as Brooklyn and northwest Queens, also saw robust demand, with lease signings nearly doubling in Brooklyn and increasing 31% in northwest Queens. Experts predict rent declines may occur as mortgage rates decrease, easing competition for rentals.

images.alt_text: usa, manhattan, contrasts

site_title: UK housing market recovers further in January: RICS
summary: The UK housing market continued its recovery in January, with new buyer enquiries reaching their strongest level in almost two years, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Survey (RICS). The gauge of new buyer enquiries rose to +7% from -3% in December, while house prices rose to -18% from -29% in December, the highest since October 2022. Expectations of interest rate cuts are boosting sentiment, and building firms are optimistic about the market's outlook.

images.alt_text: An artist impression of Yardhouse, an upcoming UK private rented sector development spanning 17-storeys.
Hilton has generally focused on developing new brands internally, while its competitors Marriott International and Hyatt Hotels have used deals to expand their portfolios.
London’s luxury real estate market has remained relatively strong even as global central banks have increased interest rates.

site_title: ‘Long and tedious journey’: companies sour on China outlook
summary: Global companies, including Starbucks, Pandora, and Carlsberg, have expressed concerns about Chinese demand, citing a decline in consumer spending and uncertain employment prospects. The comments come ahead of China's Chinese New Year holiday, which typically boosts consumer spending. Companies warn that the challenges will be a "long and tedious journey" for China's economy, with some predicting a mild recovery through the first half of the year. Investors are re-evaluating their exposure to companies reliant on China, with some seeing an emerging preference for domestic brands over global brands.

images.alt_text: Yi Huiman's removal comes as Chinese markets are on a knife edge as institutional and retail investors scramble to cut their losses.
Sales of gold, silver and jewellery have been brisk for months, defying wobbles in the Chinese economy centred around the protracted crisis in the property market.
Travellers wait for their trains at Shanghai Hongqiao railway station, during the Spring Festival travel rush ahead of the Chinese New Year.

site_title: Yoma posts 36.4% rise in revenue for quarter ended December
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a 36.4% increase in revenue to US$49.8 million for the three months ended Dec 31, 2023, driven by growth in most segments. The real estate business contributed 9.4% to revenue, while unrecognised revenue from ongoing projects rose to US$173.4 million. The company's mobile financial services business and food and beverage business also saw significant growth. CEO Melvyn Pun cited the increase in unrecognised revenue as providing clear visibility for the group's performance over the next 18-24 months.

images.alt_text: According to rules under SGX’s listing manual, companies will be placed on the watchlist if they record pre-tax losses for the three latest consecutive financial years, and have an average daily market cap of less than S$40 million over the last six months.
Yoma F&B, meanwhile, rose 47.3 per cent to US$16.7 million from US$11.3 million, supported by businesses from the group’s KFC (above) and YKKO restaurants.

site_title: HSBC bosses were aware of plan to steal SVB secrets, First Citizens alleges
summary: HSBC executives, including CEO Noel Quinn and Michael Roberts, were aware of a plan by a US unit to poach SVB employees and steal trade secrets, according to a revised lawsuit filed by First Citizens Bank & Trust. The plan, called "Project Colony," was allegedly spearheaded by former SVB executive David Sabow, who later joined HSBC. Despite this, HSBC claimed it was not barred from hiring the former SVB employees, and Sabow told HSBC UK's senior leadership about the plan before First Citizens acquired SVB in March 2023.

images.alt_text: An HSBC bank branch in North Vancouver, British Columbia. Photographer: Taehoon Kim/Bloomberg

(FILES) A sign is pictured above a branch of a HSBC bank in central London on April 26, 2022. The British banking giant HSBC announced on Monday, October 30, net profit almost tripled in the third quarter over one year to 5.6 billion dollars (5.3 billion euros), boosted in particular by "the positive impact of high interest rates". (Photo by Niklas HALLE'N / AFP)

The BOE’s Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) said HSBC fails to accurately identify deposits eligible for Britain’s Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS) – which protects customer cash up to £85,000.
“Our ability to transition relies on decarbonisation in the real economy – both the supply and demand side – happening at the necessary pace,” HSBC says.
Mark Tucker says HSBC is “strongly confident in its investment in China” and will actively support Hong Kong to be an international financial hub, and Britain-China cooperations.

site_title: Is time running out for DBS’ Piyush Gupta?
summary: DBS Group Holdings' CEO Piyush Gupta is facing pressure to deliver on his vision to transform the bank into a technology powerhouse. Despite a 30% cut in variable pay, Gupta's ambition remains unfulfilled. The bank's recent struggles with operational snafus and tech disruptions have raised concerns about its ability to meet its goals. With succession looming, Gupta must act quickly to eliminate single points of failure and strengthen its technology infrastructure. If he fails, investors may forgive minor setbacks, but DBS' reputation as the world's best digital bank will be at stake.

images.alt_text: The cut in variable pay likely means that DBS CEO Piyush Gupta will lose his bragging rights as the highest-paid executive among the three local banks.
An IG market analyst says DBS' higher Q4 dividend "may signal some confidence" for the bank's longer-term prospects.
DBS posts 3% drop in Q4 profit to S$2.27b; full-year earnings hit record S$10.06b
Analysts say the trio of local banks are likely to continue to post attractive dividend yields in Q4, which should provide support for their share prices.
DBS Asia Hub at 2 Changi Business Park Crescent, shot on Dec 9, 2023. Can be used for stories about DBS bank, banking, etc

site_title: North Korea scraps all economic cooperation with South Korea: KCNA
summary: North Korea has scrapped all economic cooperation agreements with South Korea, considering the South as an enemy at war. The decision follows the scrapping of a 2018 military pact aimed at de-escalating tension near the military border. The move marks a significant deterioration in relations between the two Koreas, which had previously engaged in economic cooperation, including the Mount Kumgang tourism project, attracting nearly 2 million South Korean visitors. The North's Supreme People's Assembly voted to abolish laws governing economic ties with Seoul.

site_title: PayPal forecasts flat 2024 earnings amid streamlining process
summary: PayPal forecasts flat 2024 earnings, unchanged from last year, with adjusted earnings of US$5.10 a share. The company reported a 15% increase in total payments volume to US$409.8 billion in the fourth quarter, beating estimates. PayPal plans to cut 9% of its workforce as part of efforts to streamline its businesses and become more efficient, with a focus on reducing expenses beyond headcount. The company's transaction margin was little changed from last year, and it will continue to review its operations to achieve profitable growth.

images.alt_text: The company’s low-margin business products have risen strongly, while growth in its branded products has slowed due to increased pressure from competitors such as Apple.
Merchants will also be able to use a separate AI-based tool called “smart receipts” to recommend personalised items to shoppers in their e-mail receipts, along with a cashback reward.
PayPal had become the first major fintech company to embrace digital currencies for payments and transfers when it launched its US dollar-backed stablecoin in August.
PayPal said it expects adjusted profit for the full year to be about US$4.98 per share from US$4.95 earlier. Analysts on average had expected US$4.92, according to LSEG data.

site_title: MSCI launches platform for private companies’ sustainability, climate data
summary: MSCI has launched a platform, MSCI Private Company Data Connect, allowing private companies to self-report their sustainability and climate disclosures to investors. The platform enables companies to retain ownership of their data, which will be based on the ESG Integrated Disclosure Project template. Investors can use the platform for due diligence, engage with portfolio companies, and set targets. MSCI will provide access to Persefoni Pro, a carbon measurement tool. The platform aims to increase transparency in private investments, giving investors similar insights into private companies' sustainability practices as they have with public corporations.
