images.alt_text: Investors who don't factor in climate risks may be caught off-guard by the long-term underperformance of their portfolios.
Cybersecurity is a vital factor in ensuring that data collected and processed from various sources for ESG reporting, for example, are reliable and protected.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher as the good earnings continue
summary: US stocks closed higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.4% at 38,677.36, and the S&P 500 rising 0.8% to 4,995.06. Strong earnings from companies like Ford, Chipotle, and Disney drove the gains, with Chipotle's shares surging over 7% and Disney's share price surging in after-hours trading. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.0% to 15,756.64, as investors continued to favor stocks amid an improving economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 6, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% at the opening bell on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,154.02. Despite overnight gains on Wall Street, the market was impacted by a decline in European shares and mixed banking stocks. Seatrium rose 1.1%, while DBS increased 0.3% after releasing its latest financials. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4% and the S&P 500 rose 0.8% on Wall Street, with investors weighing market outlook and tariffs.

site_title: Meta challenges supervisory fee for EU online content rules
summary: Meta has challenged a 0.05% supervisory fee imposed by the European Commission to cover EU regulators' costs of monitoring compliance with the Digital Services Act. The fee, based on average monthly active users and profit/loss, is aimed at 20 large online platforms, including Meta, Google, and TikTok. Meta disagrees with the methodology, citing that companies with losses pay nothing, while others pay disproportionately. The company has challenged the levy at the Luxembourg-based General Court, Europe's second-highest court.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HPH Trust, Thomson Medical, Digital Core Reit, Geo Energy
summary: Stocks to watch on Feb 8, 2024, include Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's 3.8% decline in distribution per unit, Thomson Medical Group's 91.1% year-on-year drop in net profit, and Digital Core Reit's issuance of 192 million new units at US$0.625 per unit. Geo Energy Resources received a US$35 million investment from ResInvest, while Pan-United posted a 107% increase in net profit. Other companies reported flat trading and results announcements, with Jumbo Group opening its first outlet in Nanjing, China, and Yoma Strategic's revenue rising 36.4% for the three months ended Dec 31, 2023.

images.alt_text: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's Hong Kong terminals

site_title: Manulife US Reit H2 distributable income falls 13.3%
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 13.3% decline in distributable income for the second half of FY2023, mainly due to higher finance expenses and lower rental and recoveries income. Revenue grew 6.2% to US$108.5 million, while net property income (NPI) improved by 6.7% year on year. The Reit's priorities for 2024 will focus on asset dispositions and maximising proceeds to reduce indebtedness and fund capital expenditure, with a target of US$100 million in asset disposals by Q2 or Q3 2024.

images.alt_text: The four properties with the largest percentage valuation declines are namely Figueroa (pictured), Plaza, Penn, and Diablo.
MUST has completed the divestment of the Park Place property in Arizona, US, as part of the master restructuring plan.
The first resolution, which was to approve the divestment of the Reit’s Park Place property to the sponsor for US$98.7 million, saw 97.7 per cent or 545.6 million votes in favour.
The Reit will obtain around US$235 million in funding from its sponsor, comprising the sale of its Park Place property to the sponsor and a sponsor-lender loan.

site_title: Sun Life Financial beats estimates on Asia growth, insurance sales
summary: Sun Life Financial beat analyst estimates for fourth-quarter profit, driven by 10% growth in underlying net income to C$983 million. The increase was fueled by strong sales of individual and group insurance policies, particularly in its Asia business. CEO Kevin Strain attributed "exceptional sales" for individual protection and good momentum in group health and protection businesses to the growth. This marks a positive turn for the company's US business, which has been under pressure due to a change in Medicaid dental policies.

images.alt_text: Incoming Sun Life Singapore chief Christopher Albrecht will be tasked with leading the strategic and operational aspects of Sun Life’s Singapore business

site_title: MCST of Woodlands industrial property initiates civil lawsuit against owners Wee Hur
summary: The managing body of Mega@Woodlands industrial property, a subsidiary of Wee Hur Holdings, has initiated a civil lawsuit against Wee Hur's subsidiaries, Wee Hur (Woodlands 12) and Wee Hur Construction, over alleged defects in the property. The MCST is seeking damages, interests, and other relief. Wee Hur has engaged legal counsel to defend the claims and will consult its auditor to assess the potential financial impact. The lawsuit was filed in the High Court's general division.

images.alt_text: Analysts say they do not view the recent profit warnings from property companies as potential red flags about their financial health.

site_title: Disney to invest US$1.5 billion in Fortnite maker Epic Games
summary: Disney is investing $1.5 billion in Epic Games, the maker of Fortnite, as part of a collaboration involving Disney properties such as Star Wars, Marvel, and Avatar. The deal will allow fans to watch, shop, and play with Disney characters in the game, and will also involve new titles and a collaboration with Disney's theme parks. This marks Disney's biggest entry into the gaming industry, following a 2016 shutdown of its in-house game operations. The new project will span several years, with Epic developing the experiences internally.

images.alt_text: Gina Carano claims that she was not brought back for season three of The Mandalorian, and the new show was shelved.
The new app is a recognition that there is an increasingly large market for sports outside of traditional TV.
TikTok is first app to surpass US$10 billion in user spending.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as declining banks, energy stocks weigh
summary: European stocks declined 0.3% on Wednesday, weighed down by declining banking shares and energy heavyweights Equinor and TotalEnergies. Equinor fell 7.8% after cutting its cash returns to shareholders, while TotalEnergies slipped 3.2% after reporting a bigger-than-expected decline in adjusted income. The Bank sector dipped 0.9%, with UBS losing 2.7% after reduced price targets. Technology and automobile sectors were among the top gainers, with technology advancing 0.7% and Stellantis jumping 1.1%. The European Central Bank expressed caution on cutting interest rates due to potential inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.4 per cent higher at 38,677.36 on Tuesday.

site_title: Navigating the hyperconnected era for business success
summary: The hyperconnected economy, driven by convergence of frontier technologies like AI, blockchain, and platform technologies, is transforming the way businesses operate. This trend is expected to revolutionize daily tasks and business operations, extending beyond information collection and service delivery to governance of access to knowledge. Companies must adapt by harnessing data to craft personalized experiences, fostering direct connections between producers and end consumers, and embracing a direct-to-consumer (D2C) shift, which will bring benefits such as lower prices and higher profit margins, but also poses a significant challenge for those accustomed to traditional B2B transactions.

images.alt_text: To build a smart nation, Singapore must be hyperconnected

site_title: Geo Energy Resources secures US$35 million investment
summary: Geo Energy Resources secures a US$35 million investment from ResInvest, a private commodities investment company, for at least 5.5% of its equity. The investment includes US$25 million for ordinary shares and US$10 million for treasury shares, with a three-year moratorium on ResInvest and Geo Energy's largest shareholders. The deal also includes a life-of-mine coal offtake agreement with EP Resources, with TRA coal mine supplying 75-85% of its export volumes.

images.alt_text: Geo Energy's chairman and chief executive Charles Antonny Melati said that the winter season and a strong rise in electricity demand to sustain economic growth in China and India will further fuel coal demand.

Ship to shore container cranes stand on the quayside over the MSC Freeport freight container ship at Liverpool2 deep-water port, at the Port of Liverpool, pictured across the River Mersey from New Brighton, in northwest England on January 15, 2024. (Photo by Paul ELLIS / AFP)

An oil pumping jack, also known as a 'nodding donkey,' stands in an oilfield operated by Bashneft PAO in the village of Otrada, 150kms from Ufa, Russia, on Saturday, March 5, 2016. Bashneft is an upstream and down stream oil & gas provider which explores, produces and refines its own oil and gas which it extracts from brownfield reserves in the Russian Federation. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Creative Technology narrows H1 loss to US$4.1 million
summary: Creative Technology narrowed its half-year net loss to US$4.1 million, up from US$10.6 million the previous year, driven by a 13% increase in revenue to US$31.8 million. The company attributed the growth to new product launches. Despite the challenging business environment, Creative Technology plans to grow revenue and margins, with new headphone and speaker products in the pipeline.

images.alt_text: Homegrown electronics brand Creative is known for products such as the SXFI Air Bluetooth headphones (pictured).

site_title: Ackman launches cheaper hedge fund aimed at wider investor pool
summary: Billionaire hedge fund manager William Ackman is launching a new investment portfolio, Pershing Square USA, on the New York Stock Exchange. The fund will offer lower fees and quicker access to capital, making it available to a wider pool of investors, including pension funds, endowments, and retail investors. Ackman's existing 1.2 million followers on social media platform X and smaller endowments could contribute to the fund's capital. The move aims to expand the hedge fund's investor base and provide more opportunities for diverse investors.

images.alt_text: The billionaire pitched the idea roughly two years and had been waiting for the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve it since, which finally came in on Friday.

WatchBox, that previously won backing from Pershing Square Capital Management founder Bill Ackman and NBA great Michael Jordan, is buying two watch and jewellery companies in the US and will be renamed The 1916 Company.

site_title: Gautam Adani’s fortune hits US$100 billion again
summary: Gautam Adani's net worth has reached $100.7 billion, surpassing the elite club of individuals with fortunes above $100 billion. This marks a significant rebound for Adani after a short-seller attack led to a $20 billion loss in 2023. His flagship Adani Enterprises shares rose for an eighth consecutive day following an earnings report showing a 130% surge in profit. Adani is now the 12th-richest person in the world, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

images.alt_text: The flagship firm of billionaire Gautam Adani’s empire posted net income of 18.9 billion rupees (S$305 million) for the quarter through December

Indian billionaire Gautam Adani in  an inauguration ceremony after India's the Adani Group completed the purchase of Haifa Port in Haifa port, Haifa, Israel on January 31, 2023 photographer : Kobi Wolf for Bloomberg

Indian billionaire Gautam Adani in  an inauguration ceremony after India's the Adani Group completed the purchase of Haifa Port in Haifa port, Haifa, Israel on January 31, 2023 photographer : Kobi Wolf for Bloomberg

site_title: Messi plays in Inter Miami match in Tokyo, Hong Kong seethes
summary: Lionel Messi played in Inter Miami's friendly match in Tokyo on Wednesday, but skipped the highly anticipated match in Hong Kong on Sunday, causing widespread disappointment among fans who demanded answers and a refund. The sold-out Hong Kong match drew 40,000 fans, but the Japan National Stadium was less than half full with just 28,614 in attendance. Messi appeared in the Tokyo match, playing 30 minutes, and received a positive reception from fans, but his no-show in Hong Kong has yet to be explained.

images.alt_text: Lionel Messi’s (third from left) non-appearance will add to the problems Hong Kong faces in trying to restore its reputation as a world-class centre, in the wake of a crackdown on dissent and strict pandemic curbs.
Inter Miami’s visit is part of a series of efforts by Hong Kong officials to create a buzz in the city and boost spending.

site_title: UBS US$1 billion AT1 sale rakes in nearly US$12 billion of orders
summary: UBS sold US$1 billion of Additional Tier 1 (AT1) notes at a yield of 7.75% to receive nearly US$12 billion of orders, following a record-breaking deal in November that pulled in US$36 billion for US$3.5 billion of AT1s. European banks, including BNP Paribas and Deutsche Bank, also plan significant AT1 issuance this year. The market for new AT1s has recovered since the worst day of trading in March, with spreads near their lowest level since February.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at a branch of Swiss bank UBS in Zurich, Switzerland February 2, 2016. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann
The bank is due to present its fourth-quarter earnings and results for all of 2023.
John McDonald, group chief marketing officer, UBS
The scale of the retrenchment in private banking is one of the biggest seen in Asia and comes as wealth from the Greater China region has tumbled amid a property crisis and the faltering economy.

site_title: US trade deficit widens slightly in December
summary: The US trade deficit widened slightly in December, increasing to $62.2 billion, but contracted 18.7% in 2023 to $773.4 billion. This represents 2.8% of GDP, down from 3.7% in 2022. The contraction in the trade deficit contributed to a 3.3% annualized growth rate in the fourth quarter, up 0.43 percentage points.

site_title: Apple is developing foldable clamshell iPhones: The Information
summary: Apple is developing foldable clamshell iPhones in early stages, but they are not planned for mass production until after 2025. The company has approached Asian manufacturers for components related to at least two different foldable iPhone models. This move suggests Apple is exploring the technology, but it does not indicate a near-term release.

site_title: Pan-United H2 net profit up 107% to S$20.4 million
summary: Pan-United Corporation, a Singapore-based ready-mix concrete producer, reported a net profit of S$20.4 million for the second half of 2023, a 107% increase from the previous year. Revenue rose 13% to S$414 million, and basic earnings per share increased 58% to 2.94 cents. The company attributed the growth to increased demand for its products.

images.alt_text: solar, panels, solar energy

site_title: US seeks to crack down on real estate money laundering
summary: The US Treasury Department's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) proposed a plan to crack down on real estate money laundering. The plan requires real estate professionals involved in cash transactions for residential real estate to flag suspicious activity. This move aims to curb illicit funds flowing through residential real estate, with an estimated $2.3 billion laundered through US real estate between 2015 and 2020. The plan's implementation is expected to help prevent anonymous hiding of ill-gotten gains in real estate.

site_title: Oil rises on US fuel stocks draw, Israel-Hamas tensions grow
summary: Oil prices rose for a third consecutive day, boosted by a larger-than-expected fall in US fuel stocks and rising tensions in the Middle East. Brent crude futures gained 48 cents to $79.07 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude climbed 42 cents to $73.73. A larger-than-expected build in crude stocks and a smaller-than-expected draw in distillate stocks contributed to the price increase. Meanwhile, tensions in the Middle East, including Israeli-Hamas tensions and Iranian-backed Houthi rebel attacks, continue to influence market sentiment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The sun is seen behind a crude oil pump jack in the Permian Basin in Loving County, Texas, U.S., November 22, 2019. REUTERS/Angus Mordant/File Photo

“India will become the largest source of global oil demand growth between now and 2030, while growth in developed economies and China initially slows and then subsequently goes into reverse in our outlook,” says IEA.
Brent crude futures settled at US$78.59 a barrel, up 60 US cents.

site_title: Economic policies and identity politics
summary: Centrist reformers seeking to combat nativist populism must adopt a strategy that targets innovation-driven economic growth and fair income distribution. However, simply focusing on these goals is insufficient, as the clash of identities threatens to undermine democratic societies. Instead, policymakers should convey a fundamental message to voters: the government is working for them, not just elites or party interests. This can be achieved through revamped social insurance, government as an insurer of last resort, and active labor market policies that promote job creation and social cohesion. Effective policies must also address regional disparities and migration, making intuitive sense to voters to avoid populist rhetoric.

images.alt_text: American democracy and soft power
Populism is now going mainstream
Populism run amok is no answer to globalisation's challenges
Pushing the inclusive global prosperity envelope in an age of nativism

site_title: Last hurrah from Keppel’s former O&M business
summary: Keppel, a Singaporean conglomerate, has reported a record FY2023 profit of S$4.1 billion, driven primarily by gains from the divestment of its offshore and marine (O&M) unit. The company's infrastructure segment saw its net profit more than double to nearly S$700 million. CEO Loh Chin Hua emphasized the importance of the transformation efforts over the past few years, which have shifted the company from a multi-business model to an asset-light integrated business. Keppel's recurring income from continuing operations rose 54% year on year, and the company aims to reach S$200 billion in funds under management by end-2030.

images.alt_text:
“The first six months of 2023 were
transformational and productive for Keppel", said CEO Loh Chin Hua (centre) at a results briefing on Thursday
Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua with his senior management team at the company's results briefing on Thursday

site_title: Will US policy deter Teheran?
summary: The US and Iran are locked in a delicate balance of power in the Middle East, with the Biden administration seeking to deter Iranian proxies from attacking American targets while de-escalating tensions with the Islamic republic. Recent strikes by Iran-backed groups, including the Houthis in Yemen and Hamas in Gaza, have raised concerns about a regional military confrontation between Israel and Iran. The US has responded with air strikes, but it's unclear if this has had the desired effect, with tensions continuing to escalate. Iran's nuclear ambitions and its support for proxies also pose a significant threat to US strategic interests in the region.

images.alt_text: Houthi followers participate in a parade as part of a 'popular army' mobilization campaign by the movement, in Sanaa, Yemen, February 7, 2024. REUTERS/Khaled Abdullah
Anti-war activists protesting in the Capitol Building in Washington on Dec 19. Some Democratic lawmakers have been calling for a ceasefire in Gaza, but the idea has been rejected by the Israel.
US President Joe Biden has been putting pressure on the Israeli government to delay and moderate its ground invasion of the Gaza Strip.
Members of the Israeli army build a bomb shelter for residents of the Arara Bedouin community in Israel's southern Negev Desert, Oct 14, 2023.
As officials in the Biden administration see it, reviving the JCPOA is a “mission impossible”, politically speaking.

site_title: No one can be sure what amount is ‘enough’ when it comes to Singapore’s reserves: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that there is no amount of national reserves that can be considered "enough," as future crises and investments cannot be predicted. The government's focus on accumulating reserves may lead to insufficient use of funds for present-day needs. The government passed a motion to ensure its budget and reserve policies remain fiscally responsible and sustainable, but with amendments that removed calls for reviewing current policies. Opposition MPs urged the government to increase transparency and explore alternative revenue sources.

images.alt_text: “We want to help Singaporeans tackle cost of living pressures, but we must be careful not to inadvertently generate more demand and worsen inflation,” said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong in Parliament.

Addressing concerns that the government has shifted from a “pro-growth” approach, DPM Lawrence Wong reiterated its commitment to “growing the economic pie”, as only then would Singapore have the resources to “redistribute, strengthen its social compact and progress as one people”.

site_title: Crypto ransom attack payments hit record US$1 billion in 2023: Chainalysis
summary: Crypto ransom attack payments reached a record $1.1 billion in 2023, nearly doubling from $567 million in 2022, according to blockchain analytics firm Chainalysis. Scammers targeted institutions such as hospitals, schools, and government offices, with a dominant share of ransom revenue made up of payments of $1 million or more. Other crypto-related crimes, such as scamming and hacking, fell in 2023, while cryptocurrency theft via cyberheists and ransomware attacks also funded North Korea.

images.alt_text: The startup plans to allow payments to and from external e-wallets, be it crypto or non-crypto, to bridge Web3 and real-world spending.
Tether’s USDT token is on the verge of surpassing US$100 billion in circulation for the first time.
The largest digital asset has risen about 2 per cent in January.

site_title: China developer to sell London project for HK$1 plus dollar debt
summary: Guangzhou R&F Properties, a Chinese developer, plans to sell its London project, Market Towers, for £1.34 billion, with buyers receiving some of its dollar bonds and HK$1 in cash. The deal, valued at HK$1 plus dollar debt, is part of the developer's efforts to pay off debts amid a government crackdown on excess leverage. R&F has US$8.6 billion in outstanding dollar bonds and is among dozens of Chinese developers to have defaulted on their debts, threatening global real estate markets.

images.alt_text: Sunac says that more than 90 of its projects had been added included to whitelists from cities including Beijing, Tianjin, Chengdu and Chongqing.

site_title: Uber expects strong core profit as ride share, food delivery pick up pace
summary: Uber reported its first annual net profit as a public company, driven by strong growth in its core ride-share and food delivery businesses. Revenue rose 15% to $9.9 billion and gross bookings increased 22% to $37.6 billion, exceeding expectations. The company expects adjusted earnings of $1.26 billion to $1.34 billion in the next quarter. Uber's user retention improved, with initiatives like memberships and corporate travel contributing to the results. Despite strong earnings, shares fell 1% due to delayed capital allocation plans.

images.alt_text: Uber is offering its drivers exclusive purchase incentives of up to US$2,000 for Tesla’s Model 3 and Model Y, apart from existing federal tax credits.

Kia President and CEO Song Ho Sung speaks during a briefing at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nevada, Jan 8, 2024. Uber and Kia announced on Wednesday the signing of an agreement on producing electric vehicles.
Uber operates taxi services in 33 countries and regions, including an “Uber Green” service in North America and Europe.
The stocks will replace Sealed Air Corp, Alaska Air Group and SolarEdge Technologies in the benchmark S&P 500.
The new service offered by Uber, which will be rolled out in early 2024, will enable black cab drivers to sign up to the app to take booked journeys.

site_title: Ant Group quarterly profit falls 92% on year to 24.5 million yuan
summary: China's Ant Group reported a net profit of 24.5 million yuan (S$4.6 million) in the three months to Sep 31, down 92% from the previous year. This is the first quarter Ant has reported a profit. The decline comes after Chinese authorities fined Ant Group 7.12 billion yuan in July for violating consumer protection and corporate governance laws. The fintech company, co-founded by billionaire Jack Ma, received a 33% stake from Alibaba Group Holding.

site_title: Tesla asks which jobs are critical, stoking layoff fears
summary: Tesla has asked US managers to identify critical jobs, sparking layoff fears amid a slowdown in sales growth and a significant increase in spending on growth initiatives. The company has roughly doubled its workforce since 2020, but has faced criticism for high costs and underperformance. Following a 26% slump in shares this year, Tesla is taking a cost-cutting approach, with CEO Elon Musk emphasizing the need to "chase down every penny possible." The company has terminated employees in the past for low performance and has hundreds of job listings on its website.

images.alt_text: US safety regulators have upgraded their probe into Tesla vehicles over power steering loss to the status of an engineering analysis – a required step before the agency could demand a recall.
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) says the investigation covers about 334,000 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles from the 2023 model year.
HW 4.0 has already been deployed on Tesla’s premium S and X models, as well as some Model Ys outside China.
Tesla’s arrangement appears to be a departure from CATL’s deal with Ford Motor, which aims to license the Chinese company’s technology to build batteries at a Michigan plant owned by the automaker.

site_title: KFC-parent Yum Brands sales miss estimates amid cautious consumer spending
summary: Yum Brands, parent company of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell, reported weaker sales growth in the fourth quarter, missing Wall Street estimates, amid a cautious consumer spending environment in the US. Fast-food traffic declined 4.8% at KFC and 2.6% at Pizza Hut, while Taco Bell saw a 3.5% drop. Operating margins rose due to easing commodity costs, but the company still missed profit expectations due to tax rate fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The acquisition will add to Devyani’s 500 KFC outlets in India, Nepal and Nigeria.
The Egyptian McDonald's October and November sales fell by at least 70 per cent compared to the same months last year.
Quarterly comparable sales at KFC jump 13 per cent and top estimates for an 8.29 per cent growth.
Yum intends to stay at a pace of 1,100 to 1,300 new outlets this year, while overall capital spending will be between US$700 million to US$900 million.

site_title: New York Times misses revenue expectations as advertising spends weaken
summary: The New York Times missed revenue expectations for the fourth quarter, reporting $676.2 million in revenue, 1.2% below analysts' estimates of $679.24 million. Advertising revenue fell 8.4% to $164.1 million, and the company added 300,000 digital-only subscribers in the quarter. Despite this, the company beat earnings per share estimates on an adjusted basis, earning 70 cents per share. The publisher attributed the slowdown to an uncertain economy and advertisers reducing marketing budgets, with some expecting a boost in advertising spend ahead of the US presidential election.

images.alt_text: The fate of Sports Illustrated, long the pinnacle of sports writing in the US, is up in the air after its publisher, Arena Group, defaulted on a licensing payment to Authentic Brands Group, which owns the name.

site_title: A final farewell to banking tycoon and former UOB chairman Wee Cho Yaw
summary: Singapore's banking tycoon and former UOB chairman Wee Cho Yaw, who led the bank for over six decades, has died at the age of 95. A memorial service was held at Raffles Place, attended by hundreds of UOB employees and members of the public, followed by a private funeral. Wee was known for spearheading several bank acquisitions across South-east Asia and was praised for his contributions to the corporate world and community, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and President Tharman Shanmugaratnam paying tribute to his legacy.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of UOB employees and members of the public show up at Wee Cho Yaw's final memorial service on Wednesday.

site_title: Stolen Van Gogh returned in Ikea bag displayed again
summary: A stolen Vincent van Gogh painting, "Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring," worth up to $6.8 million, was returned to the Groningen Museum in the Netherlands after being held by an art sleuth for three and a half years. The painting, stolen in 2020, showed damage from the theft, including a deep white scratch, and was displayed to media for the first time since its return. Restorer Marjan de Visser is conducting a thorough investigation to restore the painting, which is set to be publicly displayed on March 29.

images.alt_text: In an undated image provided via Calvary Hospital, among the 1,400 Torah scrolls on loan from a London trust is this one held by Calvary Hospital, a Catholic institution in the Bronx. The hospital raised $58,000 to have it repaired. (via Calvary Hospital via The New York Times) Ñ NO SALES; FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY WITH NYT STORY RESCUED TORAH SCROLLS BY MILTON ESTEROW FOR FEB. 5, 2024. ALL OTHER USE PROHIBITED. Ñ

site_title: GIC makes senior leadership changes, appoints new COO
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has made senior leadership changes, appointing Sam Kim as new COO and Bryan Yeo as deputy group CIO. Kim will also join the group executive committee, replacing Tay Lim Hock. The changes aim to continue excellence in operating and investment capabilities, with the new appointments effective April 1.

images.alt_text: Hotels in Japan have been among the most popular real estate investments in the Asia-Pacific region in the past year.

site_title: Jeweller Pandora sees ‘healthy’ sales so far this year
summary: Pandora, the world's largest jeweller, reported strong sales of silver charms and bracelets, leading to a "healthy" performance since the start of the year. The company aims for organic revenue growth of 6 to 9% in 2024, driven by its affordable luxury items. Its share price has more than doubled since the start of last year, and it has announced a share buyback program. Pandora's sales growth is a rare bright spot among retailers targeting aspirational consumers.

images.alt_text: Pandora produces jewellery in two factories in Thailand and is building a third in Vietnam.

site_title: US commercial real estate contagion moving to Europe
summary: US commercial real estate losses have spread to Europe, particularly in Germany, with Deutsche Pfandbriefbank seeing its bonds slump due to concerns over exposure to the sector. The crisis is attributed to rising interest rates eroding building values worldwide, with analysts predicting a further 15% writedown in office values this year. Smaller German banks, such as Deutsche Pfandbriefbank and Aareal Bank, are taking increasing provisions on debt extended to property owners and developers, raising concerns of a broader contagion that could echo the 2008 global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank’s loans on US offices represent about 1.5 per cent of its total lending book, with properties in cities including New York (top), Los Angeles and San Francisco.
The bank expects to post a net loss of 28 billion yen (S$255.9 million) for the fiscal year, compared with its previous forecast of a 24 billion yen profit.

Janet Yellen, US Treasury secretary, speaks during a meeting of the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) at the Treasury Department in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Dec. 14, 2023. The US Treasury secretary this week said it would make sense for the Federal Reserve to consider lowering interest rates as inflation eases to keep the economy on an even keel. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

site_title: US dollar edges lower in pullback from nearly 3-month peak
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.1% to 104.04, its lowest level since November 14, amid a pullback from a nearly three-month high. The decline was driven by technical factors, including a two-day rally of 1.4% against the euro, and a rise in US bond yields. Analysts point to the US jobs data and Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's hawkish rhetoric as contributing to the dollar's decline, which is expected to continue as traders wait for next week's inflation data.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the US currency against six others, rises 0.1 per cent to 104.58, having touched 104.60 on Monday, its highest since Nov 14.
The US dollar index, which tracks the greenback against six other major currencies, rises to 104.3, its highest since Nov 17.

site_title: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust H2 DPU declines 3.75% to HK$0.077
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust reported a 3.75% decline in its second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to HK$0.077, down from HK$0.08 a year ago. The trust's full-year DPU was HK$0.132, lower than HK$0.132 in 2022. Distribution income for the second half fell to HK$670.8 million, down from HK$696.9 million a year ago. Net profit for the full year was HK$233.5 million, a 79% drop from the previous year.

images.alt_text: HPH Trust noted that 2022 full year throughput of its ports was 7 per cent below the previous year.  It also said it experienced “challenging business conditions” in the second half of 2022.
SHARES of HPH Trust were trading in hefty volumes on Wednesday (Jul 27), as price slipped roughly 2.1 per cent or US$0.005 to US$0.235 as at 9.19am. Some 2.1 million shares changed hands at the time.

In a bourse filing on Tuesday (Jul 26), HPH Trust reported a 6.8 per cent dip in profit attributable to unitholders of the trust to HK$716.3 million (S$126.5 million) in H1 2022 ended Jun 30, from HK$768.3 million a year ago.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher; earnings, policy outlook in spotlight
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 hitting a fresh record high due to gains in megacap and chip stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 92.53 points, or 0.24%, to 38,613.89, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 81.36 points, or 0.52%, to 15,690.35. Investors are assessing major corporate earnings and awaiting policy clues from policymakers on interest-rate cuts, which may impact market outlook.

site_title: China's new energy vehicle sales drop for first time since Aug
summary: China's new energy vehicle (NEV) sales dropped 38.8% in January, the first decline since August 2023, amid faltering demand in the world's largest auto market. Total vehicle sales, including exports, reached 2.44 million units, up 47.9% from the previous year but down 22.7% from December. Despite Tesla's discounted prices, NEV sales accounted for only 29.9% of total sales, with BYD seeing the lowest sales since March 2023. The decline highlights tepid consumer demand in China amid a protracted housing downturn and market meltdown.

images.alt_text: China is estimated to have overtaken Japan as the world’s largest auto exporter in 2023.

site_title: India will be the world’s biggest driver of oil demand growth through 2030: IEA
summary: India is expected to become the world's largest driver of oil demand growth between 2023 and 2030, surpassing China, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). India's oil demand is projected to increase by 1.2 million barrels per day, accounting for one-third of the global increase, with diesel fuel being the single largest basis of consumption. The country's oil demand is expected to reach 6.6 million barrels per day by 2030, driven by transportation fuels and petrochemical demand.

images.alt_text: “The consensus economic outlook has improved somewhat over the last few months in the wake of the recent dovish pivot in central bank policy,” the IEA says.
Oil and gas use would fall by 75 per cent by 2050 if governments successfully pursued the 1.5 deg C target and emissions from the energy sector reached net zero by then.

(FILES) The sun sets behind smoke rising from the LyondellBasell-Houston Refining plant in Houston, Texas, on April 20, 2020. An escalation of the war between Israel and Hamas could further strain global oil and gas supplies, already disrupted by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, experts warn. (Photo by Mark Felix / AFP)
Oil has slid to around US$82 a barrel for Brent crude from a 2023 high in September of near US$98.

site_title: Jumbo Group opens first Nanjing outlet, two franchised outlets in Hainan
summary: Jumbo Group has opened its first outlet in Nanjing, China, located in the Nanjing International Finance Centre, spanning 668 square metres. The company also recently opened two franchised outlets in Sanya, Hainan province, on January 27 and February 4. This move comes after shares of Jumbo Group slipped 1.9% to close at S$0.26 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Alibaba misses revenue estimates; boosts buyback by US$25 billion
summary: Alibaba Group Holding reported revenue of 260.35 billion yuan (S$48.9 billion) for the third quarter, missing analysts' estimates due to softness in the retail market and a sagging economic recovery in China. The company's net income decreased 77% to 10.7 million yuan. In response, Alibaba increased its share repurchase program by US$25 billion through the end of March 2027, while CEO Eddie Wu emphasized the need to reignite growth in core businesses like e-commerce and cloud computing.

images.alt_text: Alibaba’s revenue for the three months to December is expected to have risen 5.6 per cent from a year ago.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Alibaba Group is seen at the company's headquarters in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province, China July 20, 2018. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
James Dong, who heads Alibaba’s South-east Asian arm Lazada Group, will replace Daraz founder Bjarke Mikkelsen as acting CEO with immediate effect.

site_title: China replaces head of securities regulator amid market turmoil
summary: China has replaced the head of its securities regulator, Yi Huiman, amid market turmoil, with Wu Qing taking over as chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC). The move comes as Chinese markets face a sell-off, with institutional and retail investors cutting losses due to economic concerns and lack of government stimulus measures. The change is seen as a signal that leaders are willing to address market issues, but analysts question whether it will be effective in stabilizing the market, which has fallen to a five-year low.

images.alt_text: Wall Street giants are endorsing India as the prime investment destination for the coming decade.
Chinese shares sank to a five-year low on Friday (Feb 2), prompting regulators to tighten trading restrictions to stem the prolonged rout.
Xi Jinping has shown signs of becoming increasingly involved in the nation’s financial and economy policies.
China's securities regulator will also ban securities lending to investors who sell stocks on the same day of purchase.
China is trying to stabilise markets after shares sank to a five-year low in chaotic trading on Friday.
The watchdog’s vow to stabilise the market comes amid growing concerns that slumping share prices could trigger more selling in a vicious spiral.

site_title: Sainsbury’s pledges £1 billion savings and share buyback
summary: Sainsbury's has pledged to cut costs by £1 billion and buy back £200 million of shares over the next three years as part of its updated strategy to sharpen its focus on food sales. The supermarket chain plans to dedicate more store space to selling food, rather than clothing or general merchandise, and expects retail operating profit to grow. Sainsbury's also announced plans to lift capital spending to £850 million per year and open 75 new local stores.

images.alt_text: epa10713638 A shopper at a supermarket in London, Britain, 27 June 2023. UK supermarket chiefs are set to face intense questioning from MP’s over food inflation at parliament in London 27 June. UK food inflation has fallen for the second month in a row as supermarkets cut the price of household staples. Food inflation however still remains high 8.4 percent.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Wooing FDI into Singapore
summary: Singapore is recalibrating its tax incentives to maintain its status as a global investment destination. The country has a toolkit of incentives to drive foreign direct investment into target growth sectors such as sustainability, advanced manufacturing, and innovation through AI. Ahead of the Singapore Budget 2024, the government is implementing the OECD's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting Pillar Two initiative, which aims to compel multinational enterprises to pay their fair share of tax. Recalibrated tax incentives will continue to play a vital role in keeping Singapore buoyant as a global investment destination.

images.alt_text: 新加坡鸟瞰图、天际线。滨海湾一带的建筑物、金融区、中央商业区高楼大厦。

site_title: Ringgit continues downward spiral to hit fresh low of RM3.55 to Sing dollar
summary: The Malaysian ringgit hit a fresh low of RM3.55 to the Singapore dollar on February 7, 2024, due to the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance, Malaysia's ongoing political uncertainty, and less attractive yields. The currency has depreciated by 10.5% against the Singapore dollar and 60% over the past 20 years. Analysts predict a rebound in the second half of the year, with the ringgit potentially trading at RM4.50 against the US dollar. However, rising costs and concerns over political stability may weigh on business owners, with a recent survey showing over half of respondents experiencing shrinking profits due to rising costs.

images.alt_text: Anwar told civil servants he could not be faulted for the royal leniency granted to Najib last week, as the Federal Constitution empowers Malay rulers to pardon convicts.
Malaysia's central reiterated that at the interest rate of 3%,  the monetary policy stance remains supportive of the economy.

site_title: Asme hopes for new and expanded grants, risk-sharing for internationalisation in Budget 2024
summary: The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (Asme) has submitted recommendations to the Singapore government for Budget 2024, focusing on five areas: manpower, digitalisation, internationalisation, sustainability, and grants, incentives, and schemes. Asme hopes for new and expanded grants, risk-sharing for internationalisation, and tax incentives for buying green goods from local suppliers. The recommendations aim to support smaller companies through tough times.

images.alt_text: With significant headwinds ahead, both workers and businesses are feeling anxious about the economic outlook for 2024, said NTUC and SNEF.
Some watchers believe it may be time for the government to consider a review of Singapore's tax-free threshold of S$20,000, which has not changed since 2003,
SGTech called for the formation of a public-private sustainability communication office.
The Progressive Wage Credit Scheme, which boosts the incomes of lower-wage workers , is being reviewed for improved support, according to Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad.
Even if sustainability may not always bring immediate revenue gains, it is nonetheless important, says OCBC head of global commercial banking Linus Goh.
One recommendation was for employers to be given additional salary support when employees aged 45 and above attend training courses.
Butget 101 infographic
SCCCI hopes Budget 2024 will help SMEs with costs, financing and sustainability
SBF chief executive officer Kok Ping Soon (left), and Lee Sze Yeng, managing partner of KPMG in Singapore, at the release of a joint Budget 2024 wish list on Monday (Jan 8).

“More so than ever, tax measures and policies are critical enablers in supporting Singapore’s economic objectives and charting the nation’s next lap of growth," said EY's Singapore head of tax Soh Pui Ming.

site_title: The changing face of love
summary: Singapore's concept of love and romance has undergone significant changes over the past decade, influenced by societal, cultural, and technological factors. The rise of dating apps has revolutionized the way people date and mate, with many opting for casual relationships over traditional courtship. Experts attribute this shift to increased accessibility and anonymity. Meanwhile, Asian heritage and cultural traditions continue to shape the city-state's dating scene, with couples like Neri & Hu incorporating their Chinese roots into their architecture and design work. Valentine's Day is approaching, with lovebirds expected to mark the occasion with roses.

site_title: Thomson Medical H1 earnings fall 91.1% to S$2 million
summary: Thomson Medical Group's net profit plummeted 91.1% to S$2 million in the half-year ended Dec 31, down from S$22.8 million the previous year. Revenue fell 8.6% to S$168.1 million, with a 18.2% decline in Singapore and a 20.8% increase in Malaysia. The company attributed the decline to the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and changes in market conditions.

images.alt_text: This is the third time Thomson Medical has submitted an application to SGX seeking a grace period to restore its public float.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 7)
summary: DBS reported a net profit of S$2.27 billion for the fourth quarter, 3% lower than the previous year. The bank's CEO Piyush Gupta took a 30% variable pay cut due to the bank's digital disruptions in 2023. Singapore's median household income grew 2.8% in real terms in 2023. COE prices fell for most categories except commercial vehicles, with a 8.6% drop in large car category. Ng Yu Zhi, a nickel trading fraudster, was slapped with two further counts of forgery and money laundering. DBS led the STI up 1% on Wednesday.

site_title: 🧹 Spring clean your finances
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article "Spring clean your finances" by Daryl Choo advises readers to review and organize their financial situation. However, it does not directly relate to the provided content. The provided articles discuss various financial topics, including investing in CPF, buying life insurance, avoiding GenAI financial advisers, budgeting for graduate trips, and investing in a tariff-fying world. The articles target Gen Z, emphasizing the importance of financial literacy and awareness in making informed decisions about their financial futures. The content aims to educate and empower young adults to take control of their financial well-being.

site_title: Sri Lanka targets debt restructuring framework in first 6 months of 2024, says President
summary: Sri Lanka aims to implement a debt restructuring framework within the first six months of 2024, with President Ranil Wickremesinghe expressing confidence in the country's recovery from its worst financial crisis in decades. The nation is expected to grow its GDP by up to 3% this year, with a central bank projecting a 3% growth rate. Sri Lanka's overall debt is estimated at $91 billion, and the country has made progress on $11 billion of bilateral debt restructuring.

images.alt_text: epa11022753 A vendor counts Sri Lankan rupee banknotes in the commercial hub of Colombo, Sri Lanka, 11 December 2023. The International Monetary Fund's executive board is slated to vote on 12 December regarding the release of approximately 330 million US dollars as the second tranche of the Extended Fund Facility program to Sri Lanka. In the preceding year, the IMF approved a three-billion-dollar Extended Fund Facility (EFF) to bolster Sri Lanka's economic strategies and reforms. Meanwhile, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) recently approved a 200 million US dollars concessional loan to Sri Lanka's government aimed at stabilizing the nation's financial sector in response to the economic crisis that arose in 2022 due to the suspension of external debt payments. Sri Lanka is experiencing its worst economic crisis in over seven decades as a result of a lack of foreign reserves.  EPA-EFE/CHAMILA KARUNARATHNE

“We are looking at, within the next 12 to 24 months, somewhere in the region of about US$5 billion worth of foreign currency infusion into the country in terms of projects and also from the sale of some state-owned enterprises,” says Sabry said in an interview.

site_title: UBS offers US$1 billion AT1s in fast start to its funding plan
summary: UBS is offering US$1 billion of Additional Tier 1 notes with an initial yield of 8.375% due April 2031. The move comes after the bank outlined plans to raise up to US$2 billion of subordinated debt this year. European banks, including BNP Paribas and Deutsche Bank, also plan to issue similar-sized AT1s. The market for new AT1s has been active, with other banks such as ING Groep and Swedbank recently selling new debt.

images.alt_text: The bank is due to present its fourth-quarter earnings and results for all of 2023.
John McDonald, group chief marketing officer, UBS
The scale of the retrenchment in private banking is one of the biggest seen in Asia and comes as wealth from the Greater China region has tumbled amid a property crisis and the faltering economy.

site_title: Shanghai plans faster offshore data transfer approvals for foreign firms: sources
summary: The Shanghai government plans to introduce a faster approval process for foreign firms wanting to transfer their local data offshore, separate from the Cyberspace Administration of China's (CAC) existing approval system. This move aims to attract foreign investors, particularly western banks and asset managers, as China's economy recovers from post-pandemic challenges. The fast-track approval initiative is expected to relax China's stringent data rules, which were introduced over a year ago.

images.alt_text: Stock markets in Hong Kong and Shanghai tumbled on Monday (Jan 22) – the Shanghai index marking its worst day since April 2022 – as investors retreated from what was a ‘must have’ country in global portfolios just a year ago.
Overseas companies last year invest 1.13 trillion yuan (S$209 billion) in the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: DBS chief Piyush Gupta takes 30% variable pay cut over banking outages
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta will take a 30% cut in variable pay, reducing his earnings to around S$11.16 million for 2023, despite the bank's record-breaking FY2023 performance. The cut is attributed to the bank's digital disruptions in 2023, but Gupta emphasized the bank's strong earnings and transformation agenda. DBS has also set aside S$25 million to enhance system resiliency and S$15 million for a one-time bonus for junior employees.

images.alt_text: An IG market analyst says DBS' higher Q4 dividend "may signal some confidence" for the bank's longer-term prospects.
DBS posts 3% drop in Q4 profit to S$2.27b; full-year earnings hit record S$10.06b
DBS Asia Hub at 2 Changi Business Park Crescent, shot on Dec 9, 2023. Can be used for stories about DBS bank, banking, etc
Analysts say the trio of local banks are likely to continue to post attractive dividend yields in Q4, which should provide support for their share prices.

site_title: ‘Are you serious?’ OK Lim’s lawyer Davinder Singh squares off with Hin Leong ex-employee
summary: Senior Counsel Davinder Singh questioned a former Hin Leong employee, Serene Seng, about inconsistencies in her statements and court testimonies during a civil trial. The cross-examination focused on a 2020 statement regarding a discounting application related to a Unipec Singapore transaction, one of two central transactions to the three charges against Lim Oon Kuin in a criminal case. Singh aimed to "nail down several 'lies'" in Seng's statements, representing Lim in both the criminal case and the civil trial.

images.alt_text: Liquidators are alleging in the civil suit that Hin Leong concealed losses of more than US$800 million over the past few years through the creation of fictitious gains, forgery of documents, improper accounting entries and the overstatement of its inventory.

In response to a question from Navin Thevar of Davinder Singh Chambers – one of Lim’s lawyers –, Dr Yeo said he knew Lim was suffering from depression as soon as he had walked into the clinic’s consultation room.
OK Lim’s health has been deteriorating since the collapse of Hin Leong; he has also said he has depression and anxiety.

DPP Ong suggested that Lim had been untruthful when responding to certain questions in the interview, and that he was trying to distance himself from being involved in the likes of approving Hin Leong’s trades, as well as managing the company’s cash situation and financing matters.
The prosecution says OK Lim was trying to use his medical conditions as “an excuse to undermine the value” of his statements that were recorded during his interviews with the CAD.
OK Lim's GCB in Third Avenue was sold for just below S$26.5 million to a Singapore family.

Resuming his cross examination of Lim, deputy public prosecutor Christopher Ong had asked Lim about his involvement in Hin Leong’s day-to-day operations right up to the time he had stepped down as the company’s managing director in April 2020.
Prosecutors led by DPP Christopher Ong on Friday (Nov 3) began their cross-examination of OK Lim.
The court heard that there were occasions when OK Lim had attended interviews with the CAD while he was unwell.

Lim, who is represented by lawyers of Davinder Singh Chambers, disagreed with statements that were provided by Hin Leong accounts executive Katherine Ong and Freddy Tan – a contracts executive at Hin Leong that were read in court by one of the firm’s lawyers Navin Thevar.

site_title: Microsoft in talks to end trade body's cloud computing complaint
summary: Microsoft is in talks with CISPE, a trade group representing European cloud providers, to resolve a complaint alleging the company's cloud computing licensing practices harm the EU ecosystem. CISPE filed a complaint in 2022, and Microsoft amended its terms after rivals in several EU countries complained. The talks aim to resolve issues and avoid a possible EU investigation and fine. CISPE and Microsoft are exploring potential remedies, with CISPE seeking "substantive progress" by the first quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: A Microsoft logo is seen on an office building in New York City, July 28, 2015. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

Through these collaborations, Microsoft will help the organisations to identify and refine the procedures and policies to use artificial intelligence (AI) responsibly in newsgathering and business practices.

Investors are watching Microsoft’s Azure and Office revenues to see what kind of sales flow comes from the tens of billions of US dollars the company plans to pour into data centres this year to deliver generative AI.

site_title: Swee Heng targets nine more stores in 2024, to invest in new production facility
summary: Swee Heng, a Singaporean bakery chain, plans to open nine new stores in 2024, expanding its offerings to include modern bakes such as stuffed croissants. The company, founded in 1989, will invest S$13-15 million in a new 40,000 sq ft facility to increase production capacity by 30-40%. Swee Heng aims to diversify its products and reach new customers, including those looking for healthier options, and will consider increasing business-to-business sales. The company's revenue reached S$75 million in 2023, with Swee Heng Bakery still accounting for half of the total.

images.alt_text: OCBC’s SME sustainable financing loan book doubled to over S$7 billion in 2023

Far East Organization’s project Baker X @ Orchard Central, fully equipped with a baking studio and café, was set up to give home bakers the chance to trial and sell their bakes to the public in a brick-and-mortar setup at no cost for up to six weeks.
Located at Esplanade MRT station, Hive 2.0 showcases innovative technology and retail concepts.

site_title: UK house prices jump the quickest since 2022: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 1.3% in January, the strongest monthly pace since 2022, driven by easing mortgage costs and improved economic confidence. This marks a 2.5% annual increase, the strongest in a year. Falling mortgage rates and a still-resilient labour market have boosted buyer confidence, contributing to a positive start to 2024's housing market.

images.alt_text: An artist impression of Yardhouse, an upcoming UK private rented sector development spanning 17-storeys.

The S&P Global/CIPS UK Purchasing Managers’ Index’s headline measure of the construction industry improves to 48.8 in January from 46.8 in December, its highest since August 2023 although still in no-growth territory.

site_title: Bank of Thailand holds key rate as expected, PM disagrees
summary: The Bank of Thailand held its key interest rate at 2.50% for the second consecutive meeting, defying government pressure to cut rates to revive growth. The decision was in line with market expectations. The central bank cited structural challenges and deteriorating competitiveness as reasons for maintaining the rate. The government, led by Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin, had called for a rate cut to boost growth, which was rejected by the central bank. The decision was seen as a disappointment for the government, which had forecast a rate cut earlier than expected.

images.alt_text: Despite lower inflation and government pressure on the Bank of Thailand to ease monetary policy, it is expected to leave its policy rate unchanged at a more than record high of 2.50 per cent on Wednesday, a Reuters poll showed.

site_title: EU agrees new rules to move euro derivatives clearing from London
summary: The European Union has agreed on new rules to move euro derivatives clearing from London to mainland Europe, aiming to deepen the bloc's capital market. The deal, which requires banks and asset managers to have an EU-based clearing account, will help reduce reliance on London and enhance EU strategic autonomy. However, international banks have criticized the move, citing potential damage to their international competitiveness. The new rules will take effect after formal approval from EU states and the full European parliament.

images.alt_text: While the euro has delivered on some of its promises -- notably, maintaining price stability -- it has failed to facilitate the continent’s economic and political integration.

Launched by 11 countries at the start of 1999, the euro stayed an electronic currency for its first three years. The euro area now includes 20 countries, making it the payment method for some 350 million people.
The EU wants to modernise payments so that money can be transferred from one account to another in seconds, at any time of the day or night.

site_title: Germany cuts stake in DHL in privatisation push
summary: Germany's state-owned KfW bank sold 50 million shares of its stake in DHL for 2.17 billion euros, reducing its holding to about 16.5% of the company. The sale is part of a government plan to privatize stakes in companies to invest in the rail network, with the proceeds to be used to strengthen Deutsche Bahn's equity and expand railway infrastructure. The move follows a string of large stock sales at European companies, with KfW remaining DHL's largest shareholder.

images.alt_text: DHL Group does not operate ships but it uses them to transport containers.
DHL Express expects the strike to garner “sympathy support” at various pickup and delivery locations across the US and that it is prepared to deploy replacement staff.
FILE PHOTO: A DHL logo is seen on a DHL Boeing 757 aircraft during a charity fundraising event at the Safi Aviation Park in Safi, Malta May 1, 2019.  REUTERS/Darrin Zammit Lupi

site_title: COE prices for most categories fall; large-car category drops by 8.6%
summary: COE prices for most categories fell in February's first round of bidding, with Category B experiencing the largest drop of 8.6% to S$102,338. This decrease is attributed to a decrease in demand for larger, more powerful passenger cars. The price drop is a relief for car buyers in Singapore, but it's worth noting that commercial vehicle categories remained unchanged.

images.alt_text: The total number of Certificates of Entitlement available for the period February to April 2024 is 14,707, a 2.2 per cent increase.
Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD went from 12th to fifth in passenger car registrations for 2023.
There are now more similarities than differences between private hire cars and taxis, which is why the former should not compete or bid for passenger car COEs.
Industry watchers expect Certificate of Entitlement (COE) supply to increase in 2024, which should lead to lower prices.

site_title: Jailed ex-Malaysia PM Najib considering new request for full pardon
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is considering a new petition for a full pardon, less than a week after a special panel agreed to halve his 12-year prison sentence linked to the 1MDB scandal. Najib's lawyer claims his client did not receive a fair trial and questions the pardons process led by King Al-Sultan Abdullah Ahmad Shah. Najib is expected to be released in August 2028, six years after his sentence began. The decision has sparked uproar in Malaysia, with critics saying it undermines anti-corruption efforts.

images.alt_text: Anwar told civil servants he could not be faulted for the royal leniency granted to Najib last week, as the Federal Constitution empowers Malay rulers to pardon convicts.
FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak speaks to journalists outside the Federal Court during a court break, in Putrajaya, Malaysia August 23, 2022. REUTERS/Lai Seng Sin/File Photo

site_title: DBS leads STI up 1% as Singapore shares end Wednesday higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1% on Wednesday, driven by DBS's record full-year earnings of S$10.06 billion, a 23% year-over-year increase. DBS led the pack, with shares rising 2.5% to S$32.45, followed by OCBC and UOB. Wilmar International also gained 1.8% as the benchmark index ended at 3,156.15. Regional markets were mixed, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 down 0.3% and 0.1%, respectively.

images.alt_text: A series of announcements out of Beijing has lit a fire under equities in Hong Kong and Shanghai this week.
The cut in variable pay likely means that DBS CEO Piyush Gupta will lose his bragging rights as the highest-paid executive among the three local banks.
DBS posts 3% drop in Q4 profit to S$2.27b; full-year earnings hit record S$10.06b
An IG market analyst says DBS' higher Q4 dividend "may signal some confidence" for the bank's longer-term prospects.

site_title: China’s Jan new yuan loans seen surging on policy support
summary: China's new yuan loans likely surged in January, with banks issuing an estimated 4.5 trillion yuan, tripling December's 1.17 trillion yuan. The move is seen as a response to the economy's patchy recovery, with a deepening property crisis and mounting deflationary risks. The central bank's decision to cut the reserve requirement ratio by 50-basis points on February 5 also helped prop up the economy. This is lower than the record 4.9 trillion yuan issued in January last year, but higher than the official target of 10.4% annual outstanding yuan loans growth.

images.alt_text: The state bank action effectively put a floor under the onshore yuan, which last traded at 7.1813 per US dollar.
Offshore yuan tomorrow-next forwards jumps to a more than two-month high of 4.25 points, reflecting signs of tighter liquidity conditions.

The People’s Bank of China has left interest rates unchanged when rolling over maturing medium-term policy loans, defying market expectations for a cut to shore up China’s bumpy post-pandemic economic recovery.

site_title: Qantas gouges customers on fares, unfair-pricing report says
summary: Qantas Airways has been accused of "price gouging" by exploiting its dominance in the Australian air travel market, according to a report by former antitrust chief Allan Fels. The airline's fare increases in 2022 led to a quarter of Australia's inflation, and Fels criticized the government's decision to block more Qatar Airways flights into Australia as being in Qantas' interests. Fels recommends introducing legislation to allow the government to break up big businesses for severe competition abuses, citing similar laws in the US and other countries.

site_title: Farewell Wee Cho Yaw; property prospects in the Dragon Year
summary: Tycoon Wee Cho Yaw, chairman of UOL Group and chairman emeritus of Singapore Land Group, passed away recently, leaving behind a legacy in banking and property. He successfully navigated the property market, with his private company Kheng Leong active in development. A joint UOL-SingLand venture secured a prime Orchard Boulevard plot at a state tender, but the bid came in below expectations. High Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) for foreigners may be affecting demand in the Orchard area. Analysts expect interest rates to impact the property market, with Reits showing signs of high interest rates' adverse effects.

images.alt_text: Residential rents are starting to come off their highs., writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Market players are watching closely to see if the government will award the Marina Gardens Crescent site to GuocoLand-Hong Leong group, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Possibly, property players will hope that Budget 2024 is a non-event for the sector, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.

Higher ABSD and tighter loan limits have thrown a spanner in the works for those eyeing Singapore residential property for their portfolios or retirement plans, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Sales at two new launches in particular pushed prices upwards in 2023's low-volume fourth quarter, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Singapore’s debt situation ‘manageable’; bankruptcy, winding-up below pre-Covid levels: Alvin Tan
summary: Singapore's overall debt situation remains manageable, with individual bankruptcy and corporate winding-up orders below pre-pandemic levels, according to Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan. Despite a 2023 increase in individual bankruptcy applications, most corporates and households were able to service their loans, and actual winding-up numbers were lower than pre-Covid levels. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's stress tests show that most borrowers have adequate buffers to manage shocks, with no significant uptick in non-performing loans.

images.alt_text: With significant headwinds ahead, both workers and businesses are feeling anxious about the economic outlook for 2024, said NTUC and SNEF.
In nominal terms, median monthly household income from work rose by 7.6 per cent in 2023.
Singapore dollar notes in 2, 5, 10 and 50 denomination.

site_title: Carlsberg estimates operating profit growth of up to 5% in 2024
summary: Danish brewer Carlsberg expects organic operating profit growth of 1-5% in 2024, driven by higher revenue per hectolitre and tight cost controls. Despite a higher cost base, the company plans to increase sales and marketing investments by over 10%. CEO Jacob Aarup-Andersen attributes the growth to the success of its premium portfolio and key Asian markets. The company reported a 4.7% revenue rise in 2023, narrowly beating analyst expectations.

images.alt_text: AB Inbev, Carlsberg and Heineken all grow revenues in the third quarter even as consumers bought less beer, boosted by price increases and drinkers opting for more expensive brews.
Bottles of Carlsberg beer on the production line at a facility in Saint Petersburg, Russia. Source: Bloomberg
Carlsberg says it now expects organic operating profit growth this year of between 4 per cent and 7 per cent.

site_title: Yellen says commercial property is a worry, but regulators are on it
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed concern over losses in commercial real estate, citing factors such as rising interest rates, higher vacancy rates, and maturing commercial real estate loans. Yellen stated that regulators are working to ensure loan-loss reserves and liquidity levels are adequate to cope with the issue, but acknowledged that some institutions may be stressed. Yellen declined to comment on specific lenders, including New York Community Bancorp, which has seen its stock drop 50% since announcing surprise losses and a dividend cut.

images.alt_text: The concern reflects the ongoing slide in US commercial property values coupled with the difficulty predicting which specific loans might unravel.
The bank expects to post a net loss of 28 billion yen (S$255.9 million) for the fiscal year, compared with its previous forecast of a 24 billion yen profit.

site_title: Former IPP director Goh Jin Hian liable for US$146 million losses suffered by company: High Court
summary: A High Court in Singapore has found former Inter-Pacific Petroleum (IPP) director Goh Jin Hian liable for US$146 million losses suffered by the company due to his breach of director's duties and statutory duties. Goh, the son of former prime minister Goh Chok Tong, served as a director from 2011 to 2019 and failed to monitor the company's financial issues, including sham transactions and trade financing. The court ruled that Goh had breached his fiduciary duty to the company and its creditors, and he is now facing a claim for the losses.

images.alt_text: Goh Jin Hian, the former chief executive officer of New Silkroutes Group, is charged for false trading.

site_title: Douyin CEO Zhang resigns to take new role at ByteDance
summary: Kelly Zhang, CEO of Douyin, the Chinese sister app of TikTok, is resigning to focus on the video-editing app CapCut within parent company ByteDance. Zhang will not seek a successor and will shift her focus away from Douyin. ByteDance CEO Liang Rubo previously stated the company needs to address organisational problems and catch up in the artificial intelligence race. Zhang joined ByteDance in 2014 and took the Douyin CEO role in 2020, becoming one of few women in leadership posts among China's biggest tech firms.

site_title: Germany’s industrial downturn stretches into a seventh month
summary: Germany's industrial output fell 1.6% from November, extending a slump to a seventh month, with production at its lowest level since June 2020. The decline was worse than predicted by analysts and highlights the struggles in Europe's largest economy. The country faces a potential recession amid weak global demand, high interest rates, and the energy crisis. Despite mixed news on factory orders and exports, Finance Minister Christian Lindner warned that Germany's failure to boost output is making it less competitive, leading to economic decline.

images.alt_text: For 2023 as a whole, factory orders decline 5.9 per cent.
German's gross domestic product contracted by 0.3 per cent in the fourth quarter compared to the previous quarter.

site_title: Crucial for investors to price in climate risks
summary: Investors are not adequately addressing climate risks, despite growing awareness of their importance. A recent survey found that 84% of investment professionals are concerned about climate change, but only 57% consider it a high or very high influence on their investment decisions. Climate risks can significantly impact investment returns, with a 2021 report showing that limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius could result in 10% lower returns over 40 years. To bridge the gap, investors need better education and access to data on climate-risk modelling.

images.alt_text: Being modest about green disclosures makes sense. Yet, there is a danger that companies may quiet-quit on their climate goals.
ESG funds in the United States bled more than a net US$5 billion in the final three months of 2023.

site_title: Zoom cuts DEI-focused team as corporate America retreats on diversity initiatives
summary: Zoom Video Communications has fired its diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) team, shifting its focus to external consultants to promote "inclusion" among employees. The move comes as corporate America retreats on DEI initiatives amid conservative attacks. Despite the change, Zoom remains committed to DEI, with some internal staff still working on the issue. This decision follows a broader trend of companies reevaluating their DEI policies, including Pfizer and BlackRock, amidst controversy surrounding the topic.

images.alt_text: After vaulting into public consciousness during the pandemic, Zoom has struggled to maintain high revenue growth.
Zoom lifted its full-year revenue forecast to between US$4.506 billion and US$4.511 billion, from US$4.485 billion to US$4.495 billion earlier.
To some experts, the so-called “Zoom wave” emerged due to our need to recreate the social connections that the pandemic ruptured.

site_title: EnterpriseSG, IMDA launch generative AI sandbox for SMEs
summary: EnterpriseSG and IMDA have launched a generative AI sandbox for Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), aiming to help them capture opportunities in AI, such as improving productivity and customer experiences. The sandbox will onboard 13 generative AI solutions by end-February, allowing SMEs to adopt solutions for marketing, sales, and customer engagement. The program will provide grant support and grant for a three-month trial of one solution, with applications closing by end-May or once capacity is reached.

images.alt_text: The guide covers the use of GenAI in business solutions, technology talent profiles and GenAI skills required for employees.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment acquires 3 properties in South-east Asia
summary: CapitaLand Investment has acquired three properties in South-east Asia, including two industrial assets in Singapore and a 20-hectare freehold site in Bangkok, Thailand. The Bangkok site will be developed into an automated logistics campus with a gross floor area of 2.5 million square feet, set to become Thailand's largest standalone warehouse. The acquisitions are expected to boost CapitaLand's funds under management to S$1.2 billion, fueling the next stage of growth for its managed funds.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand is divesting a 95 per cent interest in Capital Square Beijing to AIA Life Insurance.
The Fed sparked a big global market rally in December, before news of CapitaLand Investment's fair value losses really sank in

CapitaLand Investment had, in its third-quarter business updates published in November, pointed out the dampening macro-economic together with persistently higher interest rates and geo-political tensions.

site_title: China’s top chipmaker SMIC cautious on recovery expectations; shares dip
summary: China's top chipmaker SMIC expressed cautious optimism on the global semiconductor industry's recovery, citing mild growth due to insufficient demand. The company expects a gross margin of 9-11% in the first quarter, down from 16.4% in the previous quarter. SMIC's co-CEO, Zhao Haijun, warned that the current surge in orders may be unsustainable, likening it to "eating away next year's food in advance." The company's shares dipped following the announcement.

images.alt_text: SMIC's net income reaches US$174.7 million in the three months ended in December, compared to the average analyst estimate of US$139.1 million.
The US has restricted shipments of advanced chips and chipmaking equipment to China for national security.

site_title: China to help NEV industry respond to foreign trade restrictions
summary: China's commerce ministry has issued guidelines to encourage the new energy vehicle (NEV) industry to respond to foreign trade restrictions and cooperate with overseas firms. The move comes amid a European probe into Chinese subsidies for the sector and amid China's growing clout as a vehicle exporter. The guidelines also encourage automakers to set up R&D and after-sales service centers abroad and work more closely with shipping companies on transportation logistics. This effort aims to mitigate frictions abroad and protect China's position as the world's largest auto exporter.

images.alt_text: A billboard displays an advertisement for a BYD Dolphin car along a highway from downtown Bangkok to Suvarnabhumi International Airport.
China’s customs bureau puts the total exports number at 5.22 million, a huge year-on-year rise of 57 per cent, with one in three fully electric vehicles.

site_title: Digital Core Reit proposes private placement to raise US$100 million
summary: Digital Core Reit has proposed a private placement to raise at least US$100 million. About 75% of the funds will be used to fund potential acquisitions, including a data centre in Japan and a 24.9% stake in a Frankfurt facility. The manager expects the acquisitions to enhance the Reit's portfolio, diversification, and credit quality. The proposed issue price ranges from US$0.60 to US$0.625 per unit, with the future acquisitions pending final negotiations and unitholders' approval.

images.alt_text: One of Mapletree Industrial Turst's assets, at 250 Williams Street NW, Atlanta. MIT’s portfolio occupancy for its data centre segment is at 91.0 per cent (as at Dec 31, 2023), 2.4 percentage points lower quarter on quarter.
John Stewart, the Reit manager’s chief executive, said a perceived peak in the US interest rate tightening cycle has spurred a recovery in the prices of Reit units.
The peaking of interest rates could be positive for S-Reits in 2024.
John Stewart, CEO of Digital Core Reit's manager, expects the Reit's prospects to be brighter next year after resolving matters relating to a customer bankruptcy.

site_title: Taylor Swift kicks off Asia tour with 34 billion yen Japan impact
summary: Taylor Swift's economic impact in Japan is estimated to be around 34 billion yen ($309 million) from her recent tour, surpassing other visiting artists and most Japanese acts. This figure, calculated by Mitsumasa Etoh, is comparable to the economic impact generated by Swifties in Denver. However, Swift is unlikely to receive a high reception in Japan due to the country's mature music industry dominated by domestic artists, with fans focusing on hit songs rather than foreign artists.

images.alt_text: (FILES) US singer-songwriter Taylor Swift performs during her Eras Tour at Sofi stadium in Inglewood, California, August 7, 2023.
