French rapper SCH's July 22, 2023, concert at Marseille's Velodrome stadium, filmed with some 70 cameras, will be programmed as a single screening on November 23, 2023, in 200 cinemas in France, Switzerland and Belgium. The screenings follow in the footsteps of artists OrelSan, Taylor Swift, - M - and Beyonce, who have carried out similar events. (Photo by Michael Tran / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE
Taylor Swift accepts the award for Album of the Year for "Midnights" during the 66th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles, California, Feb 4, 2024.
Inter Miami’s visit is part of a series of efforts by Hong Kong officials to create a buzz in the city and boost spending.
TikTok has begun muting short videos featuring the label’s artists.
Searches for Taylor Swift’s name on Sunday afternoon on the social media platform formerly known as Twitter yielded the error message, 'Something went wrong. Try reloading.'

site_title: Meta to start labelling AI-generated images from companies like OpenAI, Google
summary: Meta will begin labelling AI-generated images from companies like OpenAI, Google, and others in the coming months, using invisible markers built into the files. The move aims to signal to users that the images, which can resemble real photos, are digital creations. Meta already labels its own AI-generated content, and this new system builds on a decade-old template to coordinate content removal across platforms. The company will also require users to label their own altered audio and video content, with penalties for non-compliance.

images.alt_text: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen attends a session as part of the G20 Leaders' Summit at the Bharat Mandapam in New Delhi on September 9, 2023. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / POOL / AFP)
Grok is being trained using data collected by X – a marketing point for xAI, which says that will make its chatbot more up to date on new information.

site_title: Scores of NY public housing workers charged in record corruption case
summary: Federal prosecutors charged 70 current and former New York City Housing Authority employees with bribery and extortion in a record corruption case. The employees, including superintendents and assistant superintendents, took over $2 million in bribes from contractors seeking work at apartment buildings across the city's five boroughs. This is the largest number of federal bribery charges handed out in a single day, according to US Attorney Damian Williams.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Real estate signs advertise new homes for sale in multiple new developments in York County, South Carolina, U.S., February 29, 2020. REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo
The US housing market has sagged as the Fed began hiking its benchmark interest rate in 2022 to quash inflation.

site_title: CDL buys private rented sector development in London for £88 million
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) acquired a 17-storey private rented sector development, Yardhouse, in central London for £88 million. The project, set to be completed in 2026, will feature 209 co-living studio units and a seven-storey block for a non-profit organization. The acquisition boosts CDL's UK portfolio to 4,771 operational and pipeline units, with CEO Sherman Kwek stating the UK PRS has proven resilient despite challenges.

images.alt_text: All unit types were well received, with three-bedroom premium and four-bedroom units being most popular, said CDL.
Along with 315 other organisations, the five Singapore-based companies will publish TNFD-aligned disclosures as part of their annual corporate reporting for FY2023, FY2024 or FY2025.
CDL paid S$336 million or S$626 psf per plot ratio for the EC plot in September 2022.
CDL said the lack of significant divestment gains was intensified by higher financing costs.
City Developments is the first corporate to obtain the OCBC 1.5°C loan.
City Developments will buy back 33.1 million of its preference shares at S$0.78 apiece on Dec 1.

site_title: China expresses concerns to US over tariffs, sanctions in Beijing talks
summary: China expressed concerns to US Treasury officials about US tariffs, investment restrictions, and sanctions during Beijing talks, citing these measures as a threat to Chinese companies. The talks also focused on macroeconomic issues and debt, with both sides agreeing to maintain communications. China's Vice Premier He Lifeng urged cooperation to stabilize the China-US economic relationship, while China's Vice Minister of Commerce Wang Shouwen raised concerns about semiconductor restrictions and fair treatment of Chinese companies in the US.

images.alt_text: China is estimated to have overtaken Japan as the world’s largest auto exporter in 2023.
US companies are restricted by Washington from providing technology to SMIC without a special license.
RISC-V is an instruction set architecture, a computer language used to design anything from smartphone chips to advanced processors for artificial intelligence.

site_title: Fresh charges, US$15 million in secret funds emerge at Ng Yu Zhi’s latest court appearance
summary: Ng Yu Zhi, a 36-year-old alleged nickel-trading fraudster, has had two new charges filed against him, including forgery and money laundering, related to his attempts to sell a shophouse allegedly bought with criminal proceeds. He is suspected of having a secret fund of approximately US$15 million stashed away in an HSBC account. If convicted, Ng could face up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to S$500,000. His bail was revoked due to his flight risk, and his case is set for a pre-trial conference on March 8.

images.alt_text: Ng Yu Zhi faces 107 charges related to a nickel trading investment scheme offered by his companies, Envy Asset Management and Envy Global Trading.
Ng Yu Zhi leaving the State Courts on 28 Mar 2022. The Singaporean businessman is at the centre of an alleged US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam.
Ng Yu Zhi was declared bankrupt last month on the application of the liquidators of his companies.
Ng Yu Zhi is facing over 100 criminal charges for his alleged involvement in the US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam.

site_title: Expect more opportunities for capital returns, even after 1-for-10 bonus issue: DBS CEO
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has proposed a higher Q4 dividend of 54 cents per share and a bonus issue of one bonus share for every 10 ordinary shares held, marking a second dividend increase in a year. CEO Piyush Gupta expects more opportunities for capital returns, citing the bank's strong balance sheet and capital position. The move may signal confidence in the bank's longer-term prospects, with shares rising 2.8% post-announcement. DBS aims to increase dividend payouts by 24% and targets a step-up of 24 cents per share per year.

images.alt_text: DBS posts 3% drop in Q4 profit to S$2.27b; full-year earnings hit record S$10.06b
DBS Asia Hub at 2 Changi Business Park Crescent, shot on Dec 9, 2023. Can be used for stories about DBS bank, banking, etc
Chief executives of the trio of local banks have been increasingly cautious, as growth in NIM and loans will likely be hit by the macro and geopolitical environment.
On Monday, DBS posted a 16 per cent increase in net profit to S$2.59 billion for the third quarter ended September.
DBS Q3 profit rises 16% to S$2.59 billion; declares S$0.48 per share dividend

site_title: Singapore’s median household income up 2.8% in real terms in 2023
summary: Singapore's median household income from work rose 2.8% in real terms in 2023, with median monthly income from work increasing to S$10,869. This growth rate is lower than the 7.6% nominal growth. Household income inequality continued to fall, with the Gini coefficient dipping to 0.433. However, after accounting for government transfers and taxes, the Gini coefficient decreased to 0.371. The median household income per household member rose to S$3,500, with growth rates varying across income deciles.

images.alt_text: Real incomes at the 20th percentile was S$2,826 in 2023, representing a 1.7 per cent increase from S$2,779 in 2022 – though this was also lower than the increase of 4.1 per cent per annum from 2013 to 2023.
Industry watches expect labour demand to cool further in 2024 – especially earlier in the year – amid softer economic activity.

site_title: Apple defeats Khosla-backed AliveCor suit over watch tech
summary: A US federal judge ruled in favor of Apple, dismissing a lawsuit alleging its smartwatch copied heart-monitoring technology from AliveCor, a Khosla Ventures-backed startup. The dispute centered on a 2015 meeting between AliveCor co-founder David Albert and Apple executives, where AliveCor claims Apple intended to collaborate on the technology. Apple denied the allegations, stating that the meeting was a standard meeting with developers. AliveCor plans to appeal the decision, which confirms Apple's ability to improve the Apple Watch's capabilities without being anti-competitive.

images.alt_text: The Vision Pro vaults Apple into its first major new product category since 2015: a US$3,499 headset that melds virtual and augmented reality.
The judge also rejects Apple's bid to exclude testimony it considered unreliable from two expert witnesses.
Sales of iPhones hit US$69.70 billion, growing 6 per cent to beat analyst expectations of US$67.82 billion.

site_title: China’s New Year buyers look to gold as stocks and property crash
summary: China's New Year buyers are prioritizing gold as a store of value amidst the country's economic crisis, with sales of gold, silver, and jewelry reaching a six-year high in December. Despite a stock market crash, consumers are flocking to gold due to its perceived investment value, with younger buyers driving interest in edgy gold jewelry designs. The country's economic woes, including a property market crisis, are contributing to a loss of confidence in consumer spending, making gold a more attractive option for preserving wealth.

images.alt_text: Travellers wait for their trains at Shanghai Hongqiao railway station, during the Spring Festival travel rush ahead of the Chinese New Year.

China has been funnelling financial resources into the manufacturing sector, rather than consumers, exacerbating overcapacity and deflation concerns, even in booming higher-end sectors, such as electric vehicles.
China’s economy is struggling to regain momentum, facing multiple challenges including persistent deflationary pressures, a prolonged housing downturn and mounting local government debt.

site_title: Gold prices flat as traders await remarks from Fed officials
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $2,035.12 per ounce as traders await comments from Federal Reserve officials on interest rate cuts. The Fed said the fight against inflation is not yet done, and it may take time before deciding to lower rates. High interest rates decrease the appeal of gold among other assets. Market focus shifted to comments from Fed officials this week and the upcoming inflation report, which may provide further clues on Fed policy.

images.alt_text: US gold futures edged 0.1 per cent lower to US$2,041.30 per ounce.

site_title: Adoption of tripartite standards should not be an ESG disclosure requirement for SGX-listed firms: Alvin Tan
summary: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan stated that the adoption of tripartite standards should not be an ESG disclosure requirement for Singapore Exchange (SGX)-listed firms. Tripartite standards, developed by the Ministry of Manpower, National Trades Union Congress, and Singapore National Employers Federation, set out good employment practices. Companies must assess which factors have a material impact on their business performance and prospects, and disclose them voluntarily. Tan emphasized that SGX's disclosure requirements aim to promote the availability and quality of information on company performance, not prescribe how companies should be run.

images.alt_text:
pixparl10 Parliament in Session Jan 10 2024.
Mr Alvin Tan, Minister of State, Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth & Ministry of Trade and Industry.
The requirements of upcoming workplace fairness legislation will be achievable by most employers, and companies need not worry about running afoul of the law.
SGX chief regulatory officer Tan Boon Gin.

site_title: Chinese ships get cheaper insurance to navigate Red Sea
summary: Chinese merchant ships are receiving cheaper insurance rates to navigate the Red Sea due to Houthi attacks, which have targeted vessels with Western ties. The discounts range from 0.35% to 0.75% of hull and machinery value, with some vessels paying as little as 0.35%. The attacks have led to a multi-tiered insurance market, with underwriters differentiating between covered carriers. This trend is causing hundreds of ships to avoid the area, instead sailing thousands of miles around Africa. The incidents are further exacerbating the economic impact of the conflict in Yemen.

images.alt_text: Red Sea attacks raise freight charges, but still manageable for businesses: MTI
Huthi attacks have prompted some shipping companies to detour around southern Africa to avoid the Red Sea, a vital route that normally carries about 12 per cent of global trade
Hapag-Lloyd, the world’s fifth biggest container liner, has joined other shippers in taking longer, costlier journeys around Africa, after one of its ships was attacked on Dec 15.
The Red Sea lies on the key Suez Canal trade route for Europe-bound Asia factory goods and the east coast of the Americas.

site_title: Embracing change: Future-proofing family businesses in S-E Asia
summary: Family businesses in South-east Asia, comprising over 60% of publicly listed companies, face challenges as they transition to subsequent generations. Effective family governance is crucial to prevent conflicts among family members, who often have differing perspectives and aspirations. Investing in bonding and building trust can help stave off family conflicts. Companies must address internal issues such as disagreements over remuneration and leadership roles to ensure long-term success. Implementing strategies for maintaining family harmony is essential for the continued growth and continuity of family businesses in the region.

images.alt_text: Banyan Tree Group founder and executive chairman Ho Kwon Ping, who turns 71 in August, takes the approach of “leaving nothing unresolved by the time you die”
Family-run listcos: A smart investment decision, or 'clusters of long-term insiders'?
Dual governance methods, more independent director involvement crucial for family businesses: panel

site_title: Amazon is laying off hundreds in its healthcare operation
summary: Amazon is laying off hundreds of employees in its healthcare division, including roles at One Medical and its online pharmacy operation. The job cuts follow the company's ongoing cost-cutting efforts, which have already resulted in over 27,000 employee reductions since 2022. Amazon's healthcare businesses are seeing growth, but the company aims to reposition resources to invest in customer-facing experiences. The layoffs are part of Amazon's broader efforts to trim costs, joining other tech companies that have announced mass workforce reductions this year.

images.alt_text: amazon Photographer: Stephanie Foden/Bloomberg
Bezos has adopted a trading plan to sell 50 million shares anytime before Jan 31, 2025.
Meta unveiled plans for a US$50 billion stock buyback, and even announced its first ever quarterly dividend – a sign to investors that it has money to spare and a reason for them to stick around.
The company says users can ask the software what they’d need to start an indoor garden or ask for Valentine’s Day recommendations, among other questions.
The company forecast current-quarter revenue of US$138 billion to US$143.5 billion.

site_title: Ford slows EVs, sends a truckload of cash to investors
summary: Ford plans to slow investment in new electric vehicle (EV) capacity due to slower demand and reduced pricing. The company expects a wider pretax loss of $5 billion to $5.5 billion this year from its EV operations. Ford will instead focus on its commercial vehicle business, Ford Pro, which is forecast to earn $8 billion to $9 billion this year. The automaker will return 40% to 50% of free cash flow to investors and has committed to return to investors 40% to 50% of free cash flow.

images.alt_text: The recall includes 1.89 million SUVs in the US and covers 2011 through 2019 model year vehicles because the trim could detach.
Ford's rise in sales was fuelled by demand for its SUVs (top) and pickup trucks.

Ford Motor Company's electric F-150 Lightning on the production line at their Rouge Electric Vehicle Center in Dearborn, Michigan on September 8, 2022. (Photo by JEFF KOWALSKY / AFP) (Photo by JEFF KOWALSKY/AFP via Getty Images)

site_title: HSBC bank sells Armenian business to Ardshinbank
summary: HSBC has agreed to sell its Armenian operation to Ardshinbank, the country's largest banking group, as part of its efforts to redeploy capital from non-core businesses to higher-growth opportunities globally. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, will see HSBC Armenia's total assets of $963.2 million, customer loans of $185 billion, and customer deposits of $200 billion transferred to Ardshinbank. The sale is expected to be completed within the next 12 months, with all HSBC Armenia staff and customer relationships transferring to Ardshinbank.

images.alt_text: India has become a favourite market for Wall Street investors, attracted by one of the world’s fastest rates of economic growth and as it positions itself as an alternative to China.
“Our ability to transition relies on decarbonisation in the real economy – both the supply and demand side – happening at the necessary pace,” HSBC says.

site_title: Toyota to invest US$1.3 billion in Kentucky facility for new electric SUV
summary: Toyota plans to invest US$1.3 billion in its Kentucky facility to assemble a new three-row battery electric SUV and add a battery pack assembly line, supporting its previously announced battery electric vehicle production. The investment brings the plant's total to nearly US$10 billion and comes as legacy automakers focus on higher-margin models. The Kentucky plant employs 9,400 workers and assembles 550,000 vehicles annually. Toyota's move aims to strengthen its electric vehicle offerings in the US market.

images.alt_text: Toyota raised its profit forecast for the current year to 4.9 trillion yen (S$44.36 billion), versus 4.5 trillion expected previously.
Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD went from 12th to fifth in passenger car registrations for 2023.
Toyota chief executive officer Koji Sato has promised the automaker will be able to sell 1.5 million battery EVs annually by 2026, and 3.5 million by 2030.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street higher as Hong Kong extends rally
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks continued their rally on Wednesday, driven by hopes for additional Chinese support measures for battered markets. Despite Federal Reserve officials' comments downplaying interest rate cut hopes, investors remain optimistic. Companies have spent over $4 billion on buybacks following Beijing's calls to boost markets. Markets tracked Wall Street's advances, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: 5 Questions with MoneySmart founder Vinod Nair
summary: Vinod Nair, founder and CEO of MoneySmart, shares valuable lessons from his entrepreneurial journey. Nair's first venture, HomeSpace, taught him to prioritize a sound business model and sustainable growth. He also learned to distinguish between difficult and uncomfortable decisions, embracing a growth mindset and seeking feedback. Notable setbacks include navigating the Covid-19 crisis, where his company's revenue plummeted and employees took salary cuts. Nair now leans towards a direct listing for MoneySmart, prioritizing control and timing. His experiences have shaped his approach to decision-making and business strategy.

images.alt_text: Willis Wee founded Tech in Asia in 2009 during the social media boom.
Caroline Yap took an unconventional journey to becoming the managing director of Google Cloud's AI business, which included running away from home at 18.
Minette Navarrete, president of Kickstart Ventures, gives us a crash course on the Philippines' startup ecosystem.

site_title: CSA works with Google to block sideloading of potentially risky Android apps
summary: Google has partnered with the Cyber Security Agency of Singapore (CSA) to block sideloading of potentially risky Android apps, starting in Singapore. The feature aims to protect users from downloading malicious apps from unofficial sources. Google will assist CSA with malware detection and analysis, share malware insights, and create user education resources. The pilot is set to be rolled out over the next few weeks, with the goal of protecting Singaporean Android users from sideloading risky apps.

site_title: Disney, Fox, Warner Bros Discovery to create joint sports streaming platform
summary: Disney, Fox, and Warner Bros Discovery are launching a joint sports streaming platform later this year. The platform aims to capture younger audiences and reduce costs by offering a range of sports content, including rights to the FIFA World Cup, Formula 1, and the National Football League. The collaboration has been in the works for some time, with the CEOs discussing a partnership. The move recognizes the growing market for sports streaming outside traditional TV, and the companies are expected to release the platform in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Amazon has an unrivalled delivery network that can ship millions products to much of the US population in a day or less.

Although Netflix's executives said the deal with WWE did not signal a change to its focus on entertainment, it nevertheless sets Netflix on a collision course with traditional media as the streamer builds out its advertising business.
Comcast's revenue rises 2.3 per cent to US$31.25 billion in the fourth quarter, beating analysts’ estimates of US$30.51 billion

site_title: Brent, US crude futures give up some gains on talk of Gaza ceasefire
summary: US crude futures initially rose over $1 a barrel on Tuesday after the Energy Department said crude oil production would grow less than forecast, but then gave up gains on talk of a possible lengthy cease-fire in the Gaza War. Brent crude futures settled at $78.59 a barrel, up 60 US cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 53 US cents to settle at $73.51. A potential cease-fire is being reviewed by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, but some analysts remain skeptical.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled higher by 66 cents, or 0.9 per cent, at US$78.22 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Snap misses revenue estimate, shares plunge 30%
summary: Snapchat's parent company missed Wall Street estimates for quarterly revenue, falling short of expectations with a revenue of $1.36 billion. The company's shares plummeted 30% to $12.05, following the release of disappointing earnings. Despite a 4% increase in daily active users to 414 million, revenue growth was hindered by increased competition from larger tech giants such as Meta and Alphabet. Snap plans to shift focus to growing its user base and investing in high-revenue markets, including North America and Europe.

images.alt_text: “In order to best position our business to execute on our highest priorities, and to ensure we have the capacity to invest incrementally to support our growth over time, we have made the difficult decision to restructure our team,” Snap says.
Snap has been using the service to roll out early access to new features and improve them based on user feedback.
People will be able to link their Snapchat and Amazon accounts to take advantage of the in-app shopping feature, according to Amazon.

site_title: DBS posts 3% drop in Q4 profit to S$2.27b; full-year earnings hit record S$10.06b
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 3% drop in Q4 net profit to S$2.27 billion, missing a consensus forecast of S$2.39 billion. Total income for the quarter rose 9% to S$5.01 billion, driven by a higher net interest margin and fee income growth. The bank declared a higher dividend of S$0.54 per share and proposed a 1-for-10 bonus issue. Full-year net profit reached a record S$10.06 billion, with total income and return on equity also at record highs. CEO Piyush Gupta expects the bank to sustain underlying profits despite interest rate headwinds and forecasts double-digit fee income growth.

site_title: Musk backs lawsuit against Disney over ‘Mandalorian’ firing
summary: Gina Carano, fired from Disney's 'The Mandalorian' in 2021, has filed a lawsuit against Disney and Lucasfilm, alleging they terminated her for her social media posts deemed antisemitic and transphobic. Carano claims the company discriminated against her, as her male co-stars were not punished for similar statements. Elon Musk, who recently offered to provide legal representation to people fired for X posts, is backing her suit.

images.alt_text: The new app is a recognition that there is an increasingly large market for sports outside of traditional TV.
The agreement with ValueAc bodes well for Disney ahead of what is expected to a be a bitter proxy battle with another activist investor, Nelson Peltz.
Steamboat Willie, the first Disney movie to feature Mickey Mouse, has entered the public domain under US law.
Under the merger Reliance would own 51 per cent through a combination of shares and cash, with Disney holding the remaining 49 per cent.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust to sell Tanglin Halt factories for S$50.6 million
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) will sell a cluster of two factories at Tanglin Halt for S$50.6 million, 3.9% above the independent valuation of S$48.7 million. The sale price also represents an 8.4% premium above the book value of S$46.7 million. The proceeds will be used to fund committed investments, reduce debt, or distribute to unitholders, providing greater financial flexibility for the trust. The sale is expected to be completed in the first half of 2024, allowing MIT to rebalance its portfolio through divestments of non-core assets.

images.alt_text: As at end-December, MIT has a total of 142 properties across Singapore, North America and Japan with a total value of S$9.2 billion.
Six of the tenant's eight data centre leases will be assumed with no change to the terms, conditions, or rental rates under the existing lease agreements.

site_title: Seniors, jobless likely to get targeted financial help in Budget 2024
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 aims to balance short-term and long-term financial support for specific groups, including seniors and jobless individuals. The budget will include enhancements to the Silver Support Scheme, providing up to S$900 per quarter, and the Majulah Package, a S$7 billion package supporting lower-income "young seniors" born before 1974. Short-term targeted measures, such as bonus cash for retirees, will also be included to help them cope with inflation. Long-term support for the involuntarily unemployed is also expected, with benefits potentially tied to training and career counselling.

images.alt_text: The seven key policy shifts outlined in the Forward Singapore report provide a roadmap for the government and "all of Singapore" to chart their way forward in an environment that will be more uncertain, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (fourth from left) during a press conference fronted by the fourth-generation leadership.
Chee Hong Tat, Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Finance, says that MOF will consider the MPs' suggestions in designing the Majulah Package.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, MIT, Digital Core Reit, F&N, Wing Tai, BRC Asia, NoonTalk
summary: DBS declared a dividend of S$0.54 per share for the fourth quarter, with shares closing down 0.6% on Tuesday. Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) sold two factories for S$50.6 million, while Digital Core Reit proposed a private placement to raise US$100 million. Fraser and Neave reported a 52.9% jump in net profit to S$43.8 million for the first quarter, and Wing Tai's net profit dropped 68% to S$20.5 million for the first half of the year. BRC Asia saw a 46.5% increase in net profit to S$17.1 million for the first quarter. NoonTalk Media reported a reduced net loss of S$1.3 million for the first six months of FY2024.

site_title: Neumann Kaffee to expand in Indonesia as coffee market grows
summary: Neumann Kaffee Gruppe, a global coffee company, plans to expand its operations in Indonesia, the world's third-largest coffee producer, by opening integrated warehouses, a cupping lab, and an import office in Jakarta. This move aims to complement the company's existing coffee-exporting business in the country. The expansion is seen as a response to Indonesia's growing coffee market, which is expected to continue expanding due to the country's significant production of both arabica and robusta beans.

site_title: Yellen says regulators, institutions should deepen AI awareness
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged financial institutions, regulators, and market participants to deepen their expertise and monitoring capacity in artificial intelligence, citing potential benefits and risks. The increasing use of AI in finance can bring benefits such as reducing costs and improving efficiencies, but also poses risks like cyber and model risk. Yellen's comments were made in prepared remarks at a US House hearing, highlighting the need for greater awareness and oversight in the field of AI.

images.alt_text: Some AI tools can be hugely technical and opaque, making it hard for institutions to explain or properly monitor them for shortcomings.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% to 3,153.46 on Wednesday, driven by a global equities rally overnight. The STI gained 27.78 points after 73.5 million securities worth S$88.5 million changed hands. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also rose, while Seatrium and construction company Ley Choon gained 1% and 5.4% respectively. The rally follows a strong close on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4% and the S&P 500 rose 0.2%.

site_title: Transatlantic ties bolstered by Biden and Scholz
summary: US President Joe Biden and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz are set to meet at the White House, bolstering transatlantic ties. Despite past differences, the two leaders share similar centre-left views and agree on key challenges like climate change and international security. Germany has backed US strikes against the Houthis, and Berlin is pushing for a European Union mission in the Red Sea to protect commercial shipping. However, differences remain, including disagreements over Ukraine and Germany's stance on China, which has sparked criticism both domestically and abroad.

images.alt_text: EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen (second, from left), European Council President Charles Michel (third, from left) and US President Joe Biden (right) during the EU-US summit at the White House in Washington, DC on Oct 20.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy. site_title: Europe: Energy heavyweights push shares higher; Germany’s DAX hits fresh record high
summary: European stocks rose 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by energy giants, with the Stoxx 600 index reaching a fresh record high. BP's 5.5% gain after reporting better-than-expected earnings and accelerating share repurchases led the charge. Higher crude oil prices also boosted energy stocks. The energy index rose 2.1% as investors took comfort from fresh stimulus for China's battered financial markets.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index ended 0.1 per cent lower on Monday after closing the previous week flat.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher after more strong quarterly earnings
summary: US stocks closed higher on Tuesday, reversing some of Monday's declines, driven by strong quarterly earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also gained, with Palantir and Spotify seeing significant price increases after beating earnings expectations. The market's performance was attributed to a mix of profit-taking in mega-cap stocks and strong earnings, with the broader market performing well despite some drag from profit-taking in tech-rich stocks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rises 12.78 points, or 0.03 per cent at the open, to 38,392.90.

site_title: Star China banker’s disappearance makes his firm a buyout target
summary: China Renaissance Holdings, a boutique Chinese investment bank, is shrinking and being considered for a buyout after its chairman and CEO, Bao Fan, disappeared from public view a year ago. Almost a third of the bank's staff in Hong Kong have resigned or lost their jobs, and the firm has received interest from a Hong Kong-based financial group and small Chinese brokerages. Bao's resignation and potential release from detention may clear the way for a takeover, but talks have been difficult due to the ongoing investigation. The bank's stock has been suspended for almost a year, and its financial statements have been delayed.

images.alt_text: Fan Bao, chairman and chief executive officer of China Renaissance Group, stands for a photograph after a Bloomberg West television interview in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Wednesday, June 15, 2016. site_title: Britain, France lead 35 nation agreement on controlling spyware, mercenary hackers
summary: Britain, France, and the US, along with tech firms like Google and Microsoft, have signed a joint statement with 35 nations to tackle the growing use of spyware, which raises concerns over national security and human rights. The agreement calls for responsible use of spyware tools, increased oversight, and transparency with commercial vendors. Signatories warned that lax controls increase the risk of malicious actors using spyware for espionage. This comes after the US announced a new visa restriction policy for those misusing commercial spyware.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow open muted; focus on earnings, rate expectations
summary: US stocks opened muted on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 12.78 points, or 0.03%, to 38,392.90, and the S&P 500 opening higher by 7.35 points, or 0.15%, to 4,950.16. Investors focused on big-ticket earnings and Federal Reserve commentary, while tech-heavy Nasdaq gained 40.52 points, or 0.26%, to 15,638.19.

site_title: IMO’s Arsenio Dominguez is comfortable talking the talk
summary: The newly appointed IMO secretary-general, Arsenio Dominguez, has signaled a shift in the organization's approach, emphasizing transparency and engagement with stakeholders. In a press conference, he outlined four key areas: the regulatory process, de-escalating the Red Sea crisis, people and stakeholder engagement, and improving the public image of shipping. Dominguez demonstrated his ability to communicate effectively, fielding questions from the general and environmental press on topics such as decarbonization, piracy, and ship recycling. He also highlighted the importance of seafarers and pledged to review the Carbon Intensity Indicator (CII) by 2026.

images.alt_text: The Red Sea crisis may mean fewer ships have to run the gauntlet of the Somali pirates as, at least for now, many are heading for the Cape of Good Hope, rather than the Suez Canal.
Things have moved on rapidly since the first onboard carbon-capture methods were proposed, with numerous projects to lock away CO2 underground now.

site_title: US FAA chief boosting oversight of Boeing after MAX 9 emergency
summary: US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) administrator Mike Whitaker announced the agency is intensifying oversight of Boeing following a 737 MAX 9 mid-air emergency. The FAA is increasing floor presence at all Boeing facilities and will take "appropriate and necessary action" based on data. The agency barred Boeing from expanding 737 MAX production until quality issues are addressed. An audit of Boeing's production is underway, and inspectors have been deployed to facilities in Renton and Kansas. The FAA previously grounded 171 MAX 9 jets and lifted the grounding after 94% returned to service.

site_title: Noontalk Media’s H1 loss narrows 40% to S$1.3 million
summary: Noontalk Media, a Singaporean entertainment company co-founded by Dasmond Koh, reported a 40% reduction in its net loss for the first six months of its financial year to S$1.3 million, from S$2.1 million in the previous period. Revenue rose 16% to S$2.3 million, driven by an increase in engagements of affiliated artistes and a concert. However, the company's cost of sales and administrative expenses increased, and it faces intense market competition and content saturation. To solidify its market position, Noontalk will focus on producing innovative content and expanding its reach to overseas markets.

images.alt_text: NoonTalk Media’s net loss in the six months ended Jun 30, 2023 stood at S$1.1 million, reversing from a net profit of S$734,377 posted the same period a year ago.
Lissa, one of the three Thai artistes signed on by NoonTalk Media.
Singaporean actor, TV host and radio DJ Dasmond Koh is Noontalk's largest shareholder, with a direct interest of 62.55 per cent in the company.
Post-IPO, NoonTalk chief executive officer Dasmond Koh will hold a 62.6 per cent stake in the company.

site_title: What is the Fed thinking?
summary: The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady at 5.25 to 5.5% in its January meeting, citing an uncertain economic outlook and inflation risks. Despite a balanced macroeconomy with low unemployment and falling inflation, the Fed remains cautious, citing the zero lower bound constraint and the need to maintain a neutral monetary policy. Experts argue that current policy rates are too restrictive and that the Fed should adjust its stance to align with the presumed value of the neutral rate r-star. This decision has sparked concern about the Fed's thinking on inflation pressures and the distribution of future supply and demand shocks.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell has pushed back on expectations of an interest rate cut in March, after the Federal Open Market Committee decided to leave interest rates at 5.25 to 5.5 per cent.

site_title: US SEC set to adopt Treasury market dealer rule as part of market overhaul
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is set to adopt a rule requiring proprietary traders and firms dealing in US government bonds to register as broker-dealers, subjecting them to stricter oversight. This rule is part of a broader effort to address liquidity problems in the $26 trillion Treasury market. The changes, which include pushing more trades through clearing houses, represent the biggest overhaul of the Treasury market in decades. The rule applies to about 43 companies and aims to create more transparency, level the playing field for market participants, and improve market stability.

images.alt_text: A spot crypto ETF tracks the market price of the underlying digital asset, giving investors exposure to the token without having to buy the currency.

The new rules adpoted by SEC target deals involving “special-purpose acquisition companies” (SPACs), shell companies that raise funds through a listing with the intention of acquiring a private company and taking it public.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi in 'strong spirits', says son
summary: Myanmar democracy figurehead Aung San Suu Kyi, 78, is in "strong spirits" according to her son Kim Aris, who received a letter from her thanking him for a care package sent to her late last year. Suu Kyi has been jailed for over 20 years since her detention in the 2021 coup, which ended a 10-year experiment with democracy in the country. Despite being largely hidden from view, she remains popular and continues to suffer from dental problems, according to her son.

images.alt_text: The facade of Myanmar's opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi's house. Ms Suu Kyi was placed under house arrest in this house during the rule of the junta.

site_title: Pricing and quality matter for all new listings
summary: Singapore's market for new listings has shifted its focus to home-grown companies, with the past year seeing six local firms list on the Catalist board. However, post-IPO performance has been disappointing, with four of the companies falling below their offer prices and daily trading being largely non-existent. The issue lies in the companies being overpriced or in early growth stages, lacking quality to attract investor interest. To revive the market, more mature companies with decent profit histories and better pricing are needed to attract investor interest.

images.alt_text: While regulators and experts in the field often focus on the minutiae of rules and controls that guide the behaviour of companies, ordinary investors often react to the behaviour itself.

site_title: Cost of living may prompt more top-ups, transfers for families in Budget 2024
summary: Singapore's Budget 2024 is expected to include cost-of-living relief measures, with economists predicting $1-2 billion in handouts to households. The government may introduce targeted support for low-income households and enhance the Assurance Package, which was introduced in 2020 to cushion the impact of GST hikes. The budget aims to ease inflation, which remains above long-term historical averages, and job market conditions. Economists also expect a slight expansionary budget for FY2024, with a projected overall fiscal deficit of $3 billion or 0.4% of GDP.

images.alt_text: While corporate and personal income tax receipts are higher than in the past as a percentage of government projections, but GST is lagging, say UOB economists.
The January 2024 CDC vouchers will be disbursed to about 1.27 million Singaporean households and cost the Government $635 million.

site_title: AstraZeneca to invest US$300 million in US facility for cell therapies
summary: AstraZeneca is investing US$300 million in a Rockville, Maryland facility for cell therapy development and manufacturing. The facility, which will create over 150 jobs, will initially focus on manufacturing cell therapies for clinical trials. This investment follows the company's acquisition of Neogene Therapeutics and agreements with other cell therapy developers. AstraZeneca is advancing early-stage trials of cell therapies for various types of cancer, including liver and prostate cancer.

site_title: BRC Asia’s Q1 profit up 46.5% to S$17.1 million
summary: BRC Asia, a steel mesh and reinforcement company, reported a 46.5% increase in net profit to S$17.1 million for its first quarter ended Dec 31, 2023, from S$11.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 17% to S$399.2 million. The company's order book stood at around S$1.3 billion, with upbeat forecasts for construction demand in Singapore. Construction demand in 2023 reached S$33.8 billion, exceeding the Building and Construction Authority's estimate.

images.alt_text: BRC Asia stated the compensation to an associate of its controlling shareholder did not prejudice the interest of minority shareholders.
The 1.7 million ordinary shares to be disposed by BRC Asia represent 17 per cent of the total issued share capital.

site_title: Wing Tai H1 net profit tumbles 68% to S$20.5 million
summary: Wing Tai, the Singapore-based property and retail company, recorded a net profit of S$20.5 million for the first half of its financial year ended Dec 31, 2023, a 68% drop from the same period last year. Revenue fell 63% to S$97.7 million due to lower contributions from development properties. The company expects heightened geopolitical uncertainties to weigh on the global economy and remains cautious on the Singapore private residential property market until greater confidence returns.

site_title: WeWork founder Adam Neumann trying to buy back company
summary: WeWork founder Adam Neumann is attempting to buy back the company after it filed for bankruptcy in November. Neumann's real estate company, Flow Global, has sought to acquire WeWork or its assets, and provide bankruptcy financing to keep it afloat. The move comes after WeWork's slower-than-expected progress on rent negotiations, which may require a new bankruptcy loan. Neumann's ouster and the company's decline under his leadership, marked by losses and a failed initial public offering in 2019, led to its current financial struggles.

site_title: Billionaire Cheng family seeks to oust Giordano CEO after failed buyout
summary: The Cheng family, led by Henry Cheng, is attempting to oust Giordano CEO Peter Lau after a failed buyout attempt two years ago. The family, which owns 24.1% of the company, wants to appoint Colin Currie as CEO and two of Henry Cheng's children, Sonia and Christopher, as non-executive directors. The move comes after the family's failed bid to acquire the company for HK$2.6 billion in 2022. Giordano's shares have fallen 7.4% following the news, with the company seeking legal advice on the situation.
