site_title: Taxing our love of property
summary: Singapore property owners have seen their property tax bills increase due to rising property values and tax rates. The government's decision to replace property tax revenue with higher corporate and individual tax rates could negatively impact the country's attractiveness and property values. However, for owners who have experienced significant capital appreciation, the increased taxes may be seen as a reasonable price to pay for the stability and infrastructure provided by the government. The author argues that property taxes should be viewed as a wealth tax, with a rate of 0.2% on assets worth S$11.5 million.

images.alt_text: Non-owner-occupied residential properties account for around two-thirs of the tax revenue increase, said Second Minister for Finance Chee Hong Tat on Tuesday.
The Business Times' Property Insights newsletter (Feb 21, 2023)

site_title: SMIC’s profit beats estimates on strong demand for Huawei phones
summary: SMIC, China's top contract chipmaker, posted a quarterly profit of US$174.7 million, beating analyst estimates, driven by strong demand for Huawei smartphones. Revenue reached US$1.68 billion, surpassing projections. Huawei's shipments surged 36% in the December quarter, making it the No 4 smartphone vendor in China. However, SMIC's shares have declined 25% amid stagnant demand for mature node chips and a sluggish consumer electronics market.

images.alt_text: SMIC reports a 15-per cent fall in revenue to US$1.62 billion, versus an average projection for US$1.64 billion.
The US has restricted shipments of advanced chips and chipmaking equipment to China for national security.

site_title: Singapore widens legal net to counter financing of weapons of mass destruction
summary: Singapore has strengthened its legal framework to counter the financing of weapons of mass destruction. A Bill passed in February 2024 requires non-financial institutions, including jewellery dealers, pawnbrokers, and law practitioners, to implement internal controls and procedures to prevent proliferation financing, in addition to money laundering and terror financing. The businesses must perform risk assessments and develop policies to counter proliferation financing, bringing Singapore's regulations in line with international standards. The move aims to prevent the financing of nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons.

images.alt_text: Singapore amends hijacking and aviation security laws amid high terrorism threat
Singapore is seeing its biggest money laundering case play out with more than S$3 billion of assets confiscated from ethnic Chinese so far.

site_title: EU recommends ambitious 2040 climate target, goes light on farming
summary: The European Commission recommended a 90% reduction in net greenhouse gas emissions by 2040, but watered down a previous agriculture target due to farmer protests. The revised proposal aims to cut non-CO2 emissions from 2015 levels, rather than 30%, to achieve the overall climate goal. The final target will be set by the new EU Commission and parliament, formed after EU elections in June, sparking a potential political debate.

images.alt_text: Emission allowance prices are expected to rise this year as tighter regulations help to limit a surplus.
Climate impacts are now part of the cost-benefit analysis of new regulations, factored into economic growth projections and reflected in budget forecasts.
The green shift in the 27-nation bloc will affect every corner of the economy, requiring more sustainable consumer lifestyles and more effort from businesses and agriculture.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 6)
summary: Singapore attracted S$13.5 billion in fixed asset investment in 2024, with over half of it in electronics. The country's Economic Development Board (EDB) secured several precision medicine projects, including AstraZeneca's planned new facility for antibody drug conjugates. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported improved momentum in its IPO pipeline, with hopes for exceeding last year's listings. Malaysia introduced tax incentives for the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone, targeting high-tech and talent investments, while the EDB expressed caution on the impact of US tariffs on Singapore's investment decisions.

site_title: Boeing latest to apply for Saudi HQ under government’s new rules
summary: Boeing has submitted a formal application to establish its Middle Eastern headquarters in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, under the government's new rules requiring global firms to shift regional headquarters to the kingdom by January 1. The US commercial aircraft manufacturer is working with the Ministry of Investment for approval, amid concerns about how officials will enforce the new rules. Other companies, including Airbus, Oracle, and Pfizer, have also received licenses for regional hubs in Saudi Arabia, with some suggesting there is still confusion around the rules and how regional headquarters should operate.

images.alt_text: A sign for Lockheed Martin on the X-59 aircraft during a media preview at Lockheed Martin Skunk Works in Palmdale, California, US, on Friday, Jan. 12, 2024. Lockheed Martin Corp. and NASA unveiled the X-59, a supersonic jet designed to fly faster than the speed of sound (about 760 mph at sea level) with much less noise. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

site_title: Estée Lauder CEO ‘not going anywhere’ despite 40% drop in shares
summary: Estée Lauder CEO Fabrizio Freda has defended his tenure, stating he's committed to turning the company around. Following a 40% drop in shares, Estée Lauder announced it's cutting 3,000 positions, or 5% of its global staff, to trim costs and boost profit. The company's shares rose 12% in New York, the largest gain since August 2019, amid Freda's turnaround plan. Freda expressed his commitment to taking the company through recovery, dismissing speculation about his departure.

site_title: Asti issues profit warning for FY2023
summary: Asti Holdings, a semiconductor company, has issued a profit warning for its FY2023 financial year, expecting a net loss due to reduced revenue and a provision for impairment on certain assets. The company's financial results will be released on or before Feb 29, 2024. Asti has been affected by shareholder disputes, with the board being replaced in January 2024. Trading in the company's shares has been suspended since July 2022.

images.alt_text: Ng Yew Nam and Soh Pock Kheng have been appointed as directors of Asti Holdings.
The semiconductor company reveals its chairman stepdown after the announcement of adjourned AGM.
Semiconductor company Asti will reconvene its long delayed annual general meeting (AGM) in the next few weeks.
Asti says a fresh notice of meeting will be issued shortly to shareholders.

site_title: Spotify’s monthly user growth, subscribers beat expectations
summary: Spotify reported fourth-quarter monthly active users and subscribers ahead of expectations, with 602 million monthly active users and 236 million premium subscribers. The company's revenue and profitability trends looked favorable, with revenue rising 16% to 3.67 billion euros. However, the first-quarter forecast was below Wall Street expectations, and the company expects revenue to reach 3.6 billion euros. Spotify also posted a fourth-quarter operating loss of 75 million euros, despite raising prices and laying off thousands of employees to boost profits and increase efficiency.

images.alt_text: “The DMA (Digital Markets Act) means that we’ll finally be able to share details about deals, promotions, and better-value payment options in the EU,” Spotify says.
Spotify began offering complimentary audiobooks to millions of customers in October as part of their monthly subscriptions.
A tech platform should not be allowed to use its market power to steadily decrease payments to content creators, to sell user data and to price gouge advertisers.

site_title: Brace for a volatile ride in the Year of the Dragon
summary: The Year of the Wood Dragon, a highly auspicious year in Chinese astrology, is expected to be a volatile and dynamic time, with significant geopolitical and economic events. The US presidential election is considered the most consequential event of the year, with the outcome likely to have far-reaching implications. Meanwhile, asset diversification and dollar-denominated investments are expected to gain traction in Asia, with stablecoins and cryptocurrencies gaining attention. The NFT market continues to decline, while retail investors are expected to drive growth in the ETF market.

images.alt_text: Armed tribesmen loyal to Houthis at an anti-USA and anti-Israel rally, in Sana'a, Yemen, January 29, 2024. A world that gives way to non-state and anti-state forces has dire implications for much of humankind.

Confidence is no easy fix, with more geopolitical headwinds expected in 2024, executives at exchange operators and asset managers say during panel discussions at the Asian Financial Forum in Hong Kong.

site_title: Qatar hits major LNG growth market India with sales blitz
summary: Qatar extends a 20-year, 7.5 million-ton-per-year LNG supply contract with Petronet LNG until 2048, covering shipping costs. The move aims to meet India's growing demand for LNG, with imports expected to double to 40 million tons by 2030. Qatar Energy Minister Saad Sherida Al-Kaabi is in high-level talks with Gail India and Indian Oil to secure new deals. The deal is seen as a bid to serve India's expanding economy and reduce reliance on dirtier fossil fuels, with the goal of increasing natural gas share to 15% by 2030.

images.alt_text: This year, two new LNG projects in the US are due to start production, a joint venture between ExxonMobil and QatarEnergy.

site_title: KKR profit beats estimates on record fees, insurance unit
summary: KKR & Co. reported a fourth-quarter profit that beat Wall Street estimates, driven by record fee-related earnings and a strong Global Atlantic insurance business. After-tax distributable earnings rose 4% to $888 million, surpassing the $0.93 average estimate. Fee-related earnings increased 21% to $675 million, fueled by growth in management fees and a capital markets unit. Despite a downturn in the private equity industry, KKR's asset management, insurance, and strategic holdings segments are expected to drive long-term growth, according to co-CEOs Joe Bae and Scott Nuttall.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: No hope, no way out for No Signboard’s investors short of exit offer or winding up company
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Singapore-based restaurant operator, is facing financial difficulties, with a net loss of S$4.7 million in FY2022 and total liabilities exceeding total assets by S$7.1 million. The company's auditor has flagged uncertainty about its ability to continue operating as a going concern. No Signboard is relying on a memorandum of understanding with Gazelle Ventures for up to S$5 million in investments, but minority shareholders have no way out of the situation. The company's majority shareholder, GuGong, may need to make an offer to acquire all shares to provide shareholder reprieve and protect minority interests.

images.alt_text: No Signboard outlet at Esplanade.

site_title: F&N net profit for Q1 jumps 52.9% to S$43.8 million
summary: Beverage maker F&N reported a net profit of S$43.8 million for Q1 2024, a 52.9% jump from the same period last year. Revenue declined 0.2% to S$531.6 million due to unfavourable foreign exchange translation. The company's dairy segment saw a 0.2% increase in revenue, while its printing and publishing segment fell 15%. The group's profit before interest and taxes rose 41.9% to S$80.6 million, driven by higher revenue from the dairy segment.

images.alt_text: Singapore retail sales down 0.4% in December, reversing November’s gain
Shares of ThaiBev, which owns Chang Beer, see heavy trading on Wednesday.
Revolver’s interiors are done up in shiny silver, black and copper tones. The restaurant is located at Tras Street.
A look at Singapore's F&B industry.
Bar and restaurant chain Harry’s International has 19 outlets in Singapore.
Though more Singapore residents have been heading abroad, restaurants and hotels foresee demand ramping up towards year-end.

site_title: Infineon lowers guidance amid broader slump in chip demand
summary: Infineon Technologies lowered its revenue guidance due to a broader slump in semiconductor demand from industrial customers, citing a "noticeable decline" in sales for power and sensor chips in the second quarter. The company expects revenue of 15.5-16.5 billion euros, below previous guidance and analyst estimates. Despite strong demand for automotive chips, Infineon anticipates a noticeable recovery in demand only in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Infineon Technologies AG logo is seen during German Economy Minister Robert Habeck and Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock's visit, in Dresden, Germany July 13, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: Infineon Technologies AG logo is seen during German Economy Minister Robert Habeck and Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock's visit, in Dresden, Germany July 13, 2023. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse/File Photo

site_title: JPMorgan to open more than 500 new bank branches over next three years
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to open over 500 new US bank branches by 2027, expanding its presence in areas where it is under-represented. The multi-billion dollar investment will see the bank open new locations in Boston, Charlotte, and other cities. This aggressive expansion strategy comes as other lenders have been shrinking their presence, with JPMorgan having the largest network in the US with 4,897 branches at the end of 2023. The bank aims to renovate nearly 1,700 existing branches and hire 3,500 more employees for its branch network.

images.alt_text: Some 27 per cent of traders surveyed see inflation as having the biggest impact, followed by 20 per cent for the November US presidential election, the survey by JPMorgan showed.
FILE PHOTO: A sign of JP Morgan Chase Bank is seen in front of their headquarters tower in Manhattan, New York, U.S., November 13, 2017. REUTERS/Amr Alfiky

Under Mark Leung's leadership since 2018, JPMorgan’s China revenue doubled and the bank became the first foreign firm to fully own a securities business and a futures company after the nation opened its financial markets.
The goal is to monetise biodiversity through financial innovation, while navigating new regulations designed to protect the natural environment.

site_title: TSMC to build second Japan chip factory, raising investment to US$20 billion
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, plans to build a second fabrication plant in Kumamoto, Japan, with a total investment of over US$20 billion. The new factory, which will begin construction by the end of this year, is expected to increase total monthly capacity to over 100,000 12-inch wafers for automotive, industrial, consumer, and high-performance computing applications. The move is in response to rising customer demand, with the first Japanese factory set to open in February and begin volume production in the fourth quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: As the biggest maker of advanced chips, TSMC must navigate an uncertain industry outlook and a US-China chip spat that could make it vulnerable.

site_title: China aims to boost chip production despite US restrictions
summary: China's top chipmaker, SMIC, is set to mass produce next-generation smartphone processors as early as this year, despite US restrictions on providing technology to the company. SMIC will use existing US and Dutch-made equipment to produce 5-nanometre chips. The move comes as China invests heavily in developing a self-reliant semiconductor supply chain due to US concerns over its alleged work with China's military.

images.alt_text: circuitry, microchip, close-up

site_title: Why is Big Tech still cutting jobs?
summary: Big Tech companies, including Google, Amazon, Meta, Microsoft, and Apple, are continuing to cut jobs despite strong sales and profits, as they shift focus to investing in artificial intelligence (AI) technology. The companies, which added over 900,000 jobs during the pandemic, are now spending billions to build AI capabilities they believe could be worth trillions. This shift has led to layoffs, with Meta laying off nearly 20,000 people last year and Google warning workers of potential further cuts. The industry is also experiencing a cycle of boom and bust, with employment growth rebounding in January after a year of layoffs.

images.alt_text: With significant headwinds ahead, both workers and businesses are feeling anxious about the economic outlook for 2024, said NTUC and SNEF.
Even as the industry sheds some jobs, it is also hiring aggressively in others.

site_title: Top Chinese hedge fund Banxia slashes stocks for ‘survival’ in rout
summary: Chinese hedge fund Banxia Investment Management Center significantly reduced its equity assets in January to cut losses, citing "must lose an arm for survival" to avoid further declines. The fund, led by founder Li Bei, acknowledged mistakes in betting on rapid economic recovery and shifted to safer high-dividend stocks and bigger companies. Chinese shares sank to a five-year low, prompting regulators to tighten trading restrictions. Banxia's January losses were 7.8%, after a 14.7% decline last year, and it was previously ranked the best performer among multi-asset funds.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping has shown signs of becoming increasingly involved in the nation’s financial and economy policies.
China's securities regulator will also ban securities lending to investors who sell stocks on the same day of purchase.
Alibaba’s revenue for the three months to December is expected to have risen 5.6 per cent from a year ago.
China is trying to stabilise markets after shares sank to a five-year low in chaotic trading on Friday.

site_title: Philippines to tap retail bond market to repay debts
summary: The Philippine government plans to tap the retail bond market to repay debts, with an initial auction set for Feb 13 to raise at least 30 billion pesos. The move is part of the government's "strategic financing programme" to raise 2.46 trillion pesos this year. Retail bonds, typically offered in small denominations, are a significant source of financing for the government, used to plug budget deficits and repay debts. The auction comes amid easing inflation and signs the central bank is nearing the end of its monetary tightening cycle.

site_title: NetLink 9-month profit up 4% at S$85 million
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 4% increase in profit after taxes to S$85.1 million for the first nine months of its 2024 financial year, driven by improved earnings from higher revenue and a one-off reversal of operating costs. The company's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation rose 3.9% to S$228.5 million. Revenue increased 3.2% to S$309.4 million, with residential connections making up 59.9% of the revenue. NetLink aims to improve network reach, densification, and capability, while increasing competitiveness in the enterprise and government segments.

images.alt_text: NetLink NBN Trust's Tong Yew Heng, acquired 100,000 units of NetLink NBN Trust at S$0.835 per unit.
NetLink Trust saw a 3.1 per cent decline in profit to S$52.9 million, even as revenue rose 2.9 per cent to S$205.3 million.
NetLink Trust's company vehicle. NetLink Trust has become the fibre network operator of the Next Gen NBN, in place of OpenNet Pte Ltd, since 1 October 2014.
Directors who do not share the views of a company’s controlling shareholders are unlikely to last long
Generic shots of SGX

site_title: Singapore has not yet convened Electoral Boundaries Review Committee for next election
summary: Singapore's Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) has not been convened for the next election, despite being last convened in August 2019 ahead of the 2020 general election. Minister for Education Chan Chun Sing stated that there will be sufficient time for the committee to make its recommendations, allowing candidates and parties to prepare. The committee's work is expected to be carried out professionally, without media attention or public pressure, and its recommendations will be based on expert analysis of population shifts and housing developments.

images.alt_text: Transport Minister S Iswaran leaves the CPIB headquarters in July 2023.
PM Lee Hsien Loong and DPM Lawrence Wong mingling with party members after the PAP’s convention on Nov 5.

site_title: Scenario planning helps Income Insurance add resilience to life fund
summary: Income Insurance is using scenario-based planning to add resilience to its life fund, which tends to outperform in poor market environments. Chief investment officer David Chua is examining climate transition risks and opportunities, including climate-themed investments. The insurer aims to have zero coal-related exposure and net-zero emissions by 2050. Chua is setting interim targets to measure portfolio performance and engaging with fund managers to invest in impact investments. The company's life fund is managed by over 10 external fund managers, with a focus on identifying managers with sustainable outperformance. Income Insurance's goal is to deliver consistent returns while preserving capital in down markets.

images.alt_text: A recent survey of 1,200 Singapore residents found 42 per cent (or about four in ten) of respondents saying they would not be financially prepared to manage the costs of cancer treatment.
Income Insurance was corporatised in 2022. The liquidity program by Alta and PhillipCapital creates an avenue for shareholders to buy and sell their shares on Alta's digital securities exchange.

site_title: US dollar steadies near 11-week high, Fed policy path in focus
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.1% to 104.58, its highest level in almost three months, as investors became more optimistic about the Federal Reserve's policy path. Robust US economic data and remarks from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell have reduced speculation of early interest rate cuts, with traders now pricing in only a 16% chance of a cut in March. The Australian dollar rose 0.05% to US$0.6492, while the euro was down 0.1% at US$1.0732, amid mixed signals from European economic data.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The US dollar index, which tracks the greenback against six other major currencies, rises to 104.3, its highest since Nov 17.

site_title: Novartis to acquire cancer-focused MorphoSys for 2.7 billion euros
summary: Novartis is acquiring MorphoSys, a cancer treatment developer, for 2.7 billion euros. The deal includes MorphoSys' promising rare bone-marrow cancer treatment candidate, pelabresib. Novartis will offer shareholders 68 euros per share in cash and take MorphoSys private after the deal, contingent on certain conditions. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the first half of 2024 and will add to Novartis' portfolio of cancer treatments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Flags with the Novo Nordisk logo flutter outside their Danish company's offices in Copenhagen, Denmark, September 26, 2023. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo
A recent survey of 1,200 Singapore residents found 42 per cent (or about four in ten) of respondents saying they would not be financially prepared to manage the costs of cancer treatment.

site_title: VinFast recalls nearly 6,000 units in Vietnam to replace switch
summary: VinFast is recalling nearly 6,000 VF 5 electric vehicles in Vietnam due to a combination switch error that causes the front lights to turn off when the ignition is turned on. The issue was caused by a design error from a component supplier. Only one vehicle sold on the market was affected, and no incidents have occurred. The recall affects vehicles manufactured between March and December 2023.

site_title: UK builders most optimistic in two years on rate cut hopes: PMI
summary: UK construction firms turned most optimistic in two years due to hopes of interest rate cuts, which raised expectations of a turnaround in the sector. The S&P Global/CIPS UK Purchasing Managers' Index improved to 48.8 in January from 46.8 in December, its highest since August 2023, despite still being in no-growth territory. Economists expect a smaller rise, while construction firms cited higher shipping costs and improved customer demand as reasons for optimism.

images.alt_text: CBRE data shows total investment in the City of London slumped to £3.6 billion in 2023, a shadow of the pre-pandemic £12 billion annually.
House prices in January increased by 0.7 per cent from the month before after being flat in December, beating economists’ forecast in a Reuters poll for a 0.1 per cent rise.

Residential properties in Guildford, UK, on Monday, Sept. 4, 2023. The downturn gripping the UK housing market steepened in August as the cost-of-borrowing squeeze sapped demand, according to a major mortgage lender. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
The property market in London has been hit by a tax clampdown aimed at investors and foreign buyers along with Brexit and changing working patterns after the pandemic.
Prime residential mortgage-backed securities in the UK deliver over 6 per cent last year, the most since 2009.
The cautious outlook is shared across the homebuilding sector, though some companies are more optimistic.

site_title: With ‘tough year’ ahead, NTUC calls for support for displaced workers, caregivers in Budget 2024
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) is calling for greater support for displaced workers and caregivers in Budget 2024, amid concerns about a tough economic outlook. With significant headwinds ahead, NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng expects more retrenchments this year and is pushing for greater support for caregivers, including statutory paid leave. The union is also calling for more flexible work arrangements and top-ups to the SkillsFuture Credit to support workers' upskilling.

images.alt_text: NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng calls on stakeholders, including employers and the government, to support workers managing work and caregiving.
SkillsFuture credit utilisation was higher among younger age groups, says Minister of State for Education Gan Siow Huang.

site_title: Thailand orders close watch on cheap ‘elephant pant’ imports
summary: Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister Phumtham Wechayachai has ordered a close watch on imports of cheap "elephant pant" trousers, citing copyright concerns over the pachyderm print design. The popular pants have become a hit among young Thais and European backpackers, but a surge in cheap Chinese-made imports has raised concerns about foreign products edging out local manufacturers. Wechayachai warned that imported products may be of inferior quality, impacting Thailand's standardized products. The move aims to protect local manufacturers and maintain the quality of Thai-made products.

images.alt_text: AOT, who operates six airports in Thailand including the main Suvarnabhumi gateway, says it was prepared for the sharp increase in flights and passengers.

site_title: Downside of investing in the new spot Bitcoin ETFs
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has approved the listing of 11 spot Bitcoin exchange-traded funds (ETFs), but experts caution investors against investing in the new ETFs due to Bitcoin's lack of intrinsic value, volatility, and susceptibility to fraud and money laundering. Bitcoin's fundamental value is difficult to determine, and its prices are driven by sentiment, making it a highly speculative and risky asset. The high expense ratios and lack of transparency in some ETFs also raise concerns. As a result, the article advises investors to stay away from new spot Bitcoin ETFs.

images.alt_text: The largest digital asset has risen about 2 per cent in January.
Going mainstream has revealed Bitcoin's true value. Now it is just another asset class, about as exciting as a bond fund, but much more volatile and with far less ability to diversify its risk.
FILE PHOTO: Representation of Bitcoin cryptocurrency is seen in this illustration taken January 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
A spot crypto ETF tracks the market price of the underlying digital asset, giving investors exposure to the token without having to buy the currency.

site_title: RBA keeps rate at 12-year high, signals higher bar for rate hikes
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) maintained its cash rate at a 12-year high of 4.35% and signaled further tightening, contradicting market expectations for near-term easing. Governor Michele Bullock emphasized that inflation remains "too high," and the board is not ruling out further interest rate hikes. The Australian dollar rose, and bond yields increased, with swaps traders now seeing a 42% chance of a June rate cut. The RBA's hawkish stance suggests Australia may be one of the last dollar-bloc economies to begin easing interest rates.

images.alt_text: Growth has slowed in recent months, with Sydney prices just rising 0.2 per cent in January.

Michele Bullock  is concerned about the stickiness of services prices in Australia and has warned that the central bank’s willingness to take a bit longer to return inflation to target to preserve job gains has its limits.

Australia's housing price momentum has eased in recent months amid rate hikes, persistent cost-of-living pressures, worsening affordability, rising advertised stock levels and poor consumer sentiment.
The central bank will likely await fourth quarter figures due later this month, which include an expanded coverage of prices to inform its policy decision at its Feb 5 to 6 meeting.

site_title: Singapore shares retreat on US stock slump; STI sheds 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,125.68, tracking US stock losses amid concerns over interest rate cuts. The US non-manufacturing PMI rose to 53.4, beating expectations, and Treasury yields increased. In contrast, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index climbed 4% after China's securities regulator announced plans to curb short-selling. The STI's top performer was Venture Corporation, while Sembcorp Industries was the biggest loser.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping has shown signs of becoming increasingly involved in the nation’s financial and economy policies.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7 per cent to 38,380.12 while the broad-based S&P 500 retreated 0.3 per cent to 4,942.81 on Monday.
Losers outnumber gainers 59 to 57, after 112.0 million securities worth S$70.5 million change hands.

site_title: Eurozone consumers trim near-term inflation expectations: ECB
summary: Eurozone consumers have reduced their inflation expectations, with the median household forecasting a 3.2% price rise in the next 12 months, down from 3.5% in the previous month. This suggests the European Central Bank's (ECB) credit-tightening efforts are having an impact, potentially leading to a decrease in inflation to the ECB's 2% goal. The Consumer Expectations Survey, conducted in December, was expanded to 11 countries and showed a decline in inflation expectations, indicating a possible shift in household attitudes towards inflation.

images.alt_text: Sentix’s index for the eurozone rises to -12.9 points in February from -15.8 in January, above a reading of -15 estimated in a Reuters poll of analysts.
HCOB’s composite PMI for the bloc, compiled by S&P Global, rose to 47.9 in January from December’s 47.6, matching a preliminary estimate.

site_title: McDonald’s looks to boost China presence with 1,000 new outlets
summary: McDonald's plans to open 1,000 new outlets in China this year, aiming to boost its presence in lower-tier cities and reach 10,000 mainland restaurants by 2028. The company's CEO, Chris Kempczinski, stated that the company is "very much on track" with its development aspirations, despite economic woes in the country leading shoppers to pull back. McDonald's is competing with other global chains to establish a bigger foothold in lesser-known Chinese cities, with promotions and discounts becoming increasingly reliant on sales.

images.alt_text: A McDonald’s fast food restaurant in New York, US, on Monday, Oct. 24, 2022. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
The expansion plans would take its restaurant count to about 50,000 in over 100 countries, according to McDonald’s.

site_title: What’s behind markets that refuse to rise
summary: The Shanghai Composite Index is struggling to lift itself off the floor, offering better investment opportunities due to its long-term downtrend. Oil prices have also retreated from a high of around $79 to $74, driven by tensions in the Middle East and Strait of Hormuz. The Shanghai index shows a weak divergence pattern, suggesting a weaker uptrend breakout, with resistance levels near 2,925 and 3,075. In contrast, the oil market remains unperturbed, trading within a well-defined band between $65 and $95, with a 45% profit potential.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled higher by 66 cents, or 0.9 per cent, at US$78.22 a barrel on Monday.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows an oil pump jack outside Almetyevsk in the Republic of Tatarstan, Russia June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk//File Photo
China's securities regulator will also ban securities lending to investors who sell stocks on the same day of purchase.

site_title: Indian central bank's liquidity drain signals tight cash conditions may stay
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has signaled that it is not loosening its grip on liquidity, conducting an overnight variable rate reverse repo (VRRR) auction for the first time in seven months. Despite a tepid response, the central bank announced a follow-up auction, indicating a desire to keep overnight rates above the standing deposit facility rate. The RBI's liquidity deficit has eased, but the central bank is not expected to announce fresh measures on liquidity in its policy decision due on Thursday, with economists suggesting a review of the situation may come in April.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) head office in Mumbai, India, on Thursday, April 6, 2023. The Reserve Bank of India’s six-member Monetary Policy Committee unanimously voted on Thursday to keep the repurchase rate at 6.50%, a move expected by only six of 33 economists surveyed by Bloomberg. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg

site_title: Undeterred ex-PM Truss to launch new UK Tory grouping
summary: Former UK Prime Minister Liz Truss is launching a new conservative movement, "Popular Conservatism," with the goal of pushing the ruling Conservatives rightwards. The movement has secured support from several prominent Tories, including Lee Anderson and Jacob Rees-Mogg, and aims to shape the party's manifesto on issues like immigration and tax. Despite being ousted from office just 49 days ago, Truss remains a thorn in the side of her successor Rishi Sunak, who faces a general election later this year that polls indicate he is likely to lose.

images.alt_text: Britain's King Charles won plaudits last month for being open about his benign prostate condition, with doctors saying many more members of the public had come forward with symptoms.
Traders are currently betting on about four quarter-point rate cuts in the UK this year, compared to five in the euro area and the US.
“No final decision has been made to pursue a digital pound – also called a central bank digital currency,” the BOE and finance ministry say.
Investors took Wednesday’s PMI as a sign that the BOE would be in no hurry to lower borrowing costs.
The state-run National Health Service (NHS) emerged from the Covid-19 pandemic in crisis, crippled by long waiting lists, ambulance delays and industrial action by staff over pay.

Record migration, despite the supply-side benefits, has triggered a political storm after pro-Brexit campaigners promised to control the country’s borders.

site_title: Boeing labour strife poses next big risk to plane production
summary: Boeing faces a potential labour crisis as its largest union, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, demands a 40% pay raise over three or four years. This comes amid a resurgent US labour movement, a shortage of qualified aerospace workers, and pressure on the company to stabilize work in its factories. Union leaders are seeking a new contract, which they say they must accept, and are willing to go on strike if necessary.

site_title: Gold subdued as US dollar holds firm on fading rate cut hopes
summary: Gold prices fell to nearly two-week lows due to a firm US dollar and rising Treasury yields, as traders reduced expectations for early US Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. The US dollar index hovered near a three-month high, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. Spot gold was flat at $2,025.24 per ounce, while US gold futures edged 0.1% lower to $2,041.30 per ounce. The US services sector growth picked up in January, but suppliers fell behind, leading to a measure of input prices rising to an 11-month high.

images.alt_text: Comex gold speculators cut their net long position by 4,639 contracts to 71,976 in the week ended Jan 30, data showed on Friday.

site_title: German factory orders unexpectedly advanced at year end
summary: German factory orders unexpectedly rose 8.9% in December, defying economists' estimates of a 0.2% decline. This rebound signals a small improvement in the country's industrial downturn, which has been caused by the energy crisis and weak global demand. Despite this, Germany's economy is expected to "stagnate at best" in the first quarter of 2024, with the Bundesbank citing a continued decline in foreign orders and cautious consumers. The country's GDP contracted 0.3% in the final quarter of 2023, narrowly avoiding a recession.

images.alt_text: On average, only 56 per cent of the available money is drawn down from the climate fund each year, offering the potential for some room to manoeuvre.

The 20 countries that share the euro barely avoided an outright recession in the final quarter of last year.
German's gross domestic product contracted by 0.3 per cent in the fourth quarter compared to the previous quarter.
While narrowly escaping two straight quarters of contraction last year, Germany continues to suffer from weak global demand and the aftermath of the energy crisis.

site_title: BP beats Q4 profit forecast, increases share buybacks
summary: BP reported fourth-quarter earnings of US$3 billion, exceeding forecasts, and lifted its 2023 profit to US$13.8 billion, a 50% drop from the previous year due to cooling oil and gas prices and weakening refining margins. The company maintained its dividend and increased its share buyback program to US$1.75 billion. This follows strong gas trading results and higher oil and gas prices, which were offset by lower refining margins and exploration impairments.

images.alt_text: Despite the nearly 40 per cent fall in annual profit, Chevron announces it would increase its dividend by 8 per cent in a sign of confidence.
Exxon results included a US$2.5 billion impairment charge for California properties that it has been trying to sell for more than a year.

site_title: Singapore AI fintech investment surges in H2 despite global funding winter: KPMG
summary: Singapore's AI fintech sector saw a 77% surge in funding to $333.1 million in the second half of 2023, despite a global decline in fintech investments. The full-year total was $481.2 million, with 24 deals. The sector's total fintech funding declined 64% to $747 million in the second half, and 68% to $2.2 billion for the full year. A cautious investor sentiment and geopolitical conflicts contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: Cybersecurity is a vital factor in ensuring that data collected and processed from various sources for ESG reporting, for example, are reliable and protected.
Some watchers believe it may be time for the government to consider a review of Singapore's tax-free threshold of S$20,000, which has not changed since 2003,
Being modest about green disclosures makes sense. Yet, there is a danger that companies may quiet-quit on their climate goals.

site_title: China regulator unveils more curbs on short-selling
summary: China's Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has unveiled new measures to curb short-selling, including capping the size of securities refinancing business and banning securities lending to investors who sell stocks on the same day of purchase. The regulator also vowed to crack down on illegal securities lending practices. These moves aim to prevent market volatility and protect investors.

site_title: Nintendo lifts profit and Switch outlook after beating estimates
summary: Nintendo raised its forecast for Switch console sales and profit for the year after reporting better-than-expected earnings for the holiday quarter. The company now expects to sell 15.5 million Switch units, up from 15 million, and raised its revenue, operating profit, and net income guidance. This beat analyst estimates and follows a 6% decline in sales compared to the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Nintendo’s seven-year-old Switch has sold over 132 million units and is approaching the end of its life cycle.
YFO, connected to Nintendo’s founder, seeks to buy out Toyo but the company repeatedly resists the offer.
“The Switch will enter its eighth year from March 2024 but we will continue to develop new titles without being bound by previous platform lifecycles,” says Nintendo president Shuntaro Furukawa.
The upcoming "Zelda" film will be directed by Wes Ball, whose movies including the upcoming Kingdom of the Planet of the Apes.

site_title: Sri Lanka approves lifting some limits on rupee conversion for outward remittances
summary: Sri Lanka has approved lifting some limits on converting rupees to foreign exchange for outward remittances, with Cabinet spokesperson Bandula Gunawardane stating that the country's reserves have improved and limits will be increased under the central bank's guidance. The move aims to support the country's economy, which has been recovering from its worst financial crisis in decades. The official reserves stood at $4.4 billion at the end of 2023, an increase of 22% from the previous year.

site_title: Xi set to discuss China stock market with financial regulators
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to receive a briefing from financial regulators on the nation's plunging stocks, amid mounting pressure to prop up the market. The CSRC plans to update top leadership on market conditions and policy initiatives, with no new support measures confirmed. China's stocks have lost about $7 trillion in value since 2021, and regulators have implemented various measures, including curbs on short selling and state buying of shares. The meeting highlights Xi's increasing involvement in financial policies, following an unprecedented visit to the central bank last year.

images.alt_text: China's securities regulator will also ban securities lending to investors who sell stocks on the same day of purchase.
China is trying to stabilise markets after shares sank to a five-year low in chaotic trading on Friday.
The watchdog’s vow to stabilise the market comes amid growing concerns that slumping share prices could trigger more selling in a vicious spiral.

In a sign of how exasperated some investors have become, thousands flocked to a social media account of the US embassy in Beijing to vent their frustrations over the economy and slumping share prices.

Authorities will actively work with relevant parties and coordinate the implementation of various measures to stabilise the market and boost confidence, according to the China Securities Regulatory Commission.

site_title: The elusive restaurant group redefining Korean dining in New York
summary: Korean dining in New York has become increasingly diverse and dynamic, thanks to Hand Hospitality, a company that owns or co-owns 17 restaurants in the city. The company, founded by Kiro Lee, focuses on serving traditional Korean cuisine to young Koreans and Korean Americans, rather than trying to appeal to a broader audience. Despite limited English proficiency among staff and some dishes being only listed in Korean, non-Koreans flock to Hand's establishments, which reflect the globalized shape of South Korean culture, known as hallyu. The company's influence extends beyond its own restaurants, inspiring other Korean chefs to develop unique fusion cuisine.

images.alt_text: DailyBeer's agreement with Katrina Group will be the first time the South Korean craft beer and chicken restaurant operator has gone beyond its home market.

site_title: Tesla falls on SAP snub report, Piper Sandler price target cut
summary: Tesla shares fell 4% to $180.46 after a report by German publication Handelsblatt stated SAP would no longer source company cars from the US automaker due to delays and price fluctuations. Piper Sandler cut its price target, citing lower delivery expectations. The stock has lost $193 billion since the company forecast "notably lower" growth for deliveries in 2024. This adds to the potential loss of nearly $24 billion in market capitalization if losses hold. Tesla's shares hit their lowest since May 2023.

images.alt_text: Chinese automobile maker BYD pipped American counterpart Tesla to be the top electric vehicle seller in Singapore in 2023.
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) says the investigation covers about 334,000 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles from the 2023 model year.
HW 4.0 has already been deployed on Tesla’s premium S and X models, as well as some Model Ys outside China.

site_title: SK Innovation projects slower growth in global EV demand
summary: SK Innovation forecasts slower growth in global electric vehicle (EV) demand, joining other automakers and suppliers expressing concerns about the EV market. The company reported an operating profit of 73 billion won for the fourth quarter, below analyst expectations, and a capital spending budget of 9 trillion won for this year, with 80% allocated for its battery business. Despite this, SK On's battery unit expects an increase in shipments in the second half of the year due to new EV launches and lower interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of SK Innovation is seen in front of its headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, February 3, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo
The company is boosting its exposure to the EV battery market as it bets on a faster-than-expected electrification of cars.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after Wall Street losses, Shanghai and Hong Kong rally
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday after a drop on Wall Street, with Shanghai and Hong Kong rallying after a pledge by authorities to boost investment in stocks. The US interest rate outlook remains uncertain, despite a jobs report showing the economy's momentum. Analysts warn that long-standing economic problems, particularly in the property sector, need to be addressed to restore confidence.

images.alt_text: Losers outnumber gainers 59 to 57, after 112.0 million securities worth S$70.5 million change hands.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7 per cent to 38,380.12 while the broad-based S&P 500 retreated 0.3 per cent to 4,942.81 on Monday.

site_title: Wall Street snubs China for India in a historic markets shift
summary: Wall Street giants are shifting their focus from China to India as a prime investment destination for the next decade. Investors are pulling billions of US dollars from China's sputtering economy, with much of that cash heading to India. The US$62 billion hedge fund Marshall Wace has positioned India as its biggest net long bet after the US, while Morgan Stanley predicts India's stock market will become the third-largest by 2030. India's strong growth, relative political stability, and vast ecosystem of technologies are attracting investors, despite the country's expensive valuations and potential risks. Despite these challenges, many investors believe India's long-term growth potential makes it an attractive investment opportunity.

images.alt_text: The bull figure outside the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai, India, on Monday, Aug. 11, 2023. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

site_title: 2024 property tax revenue to rise by S$600 million, more than government’s projected S$380 million
summary: Singapore's residential property tax revenue is projected to rise by S$600 million this year, exceeding the government's initial estimate of S$380 million. Non-owner-occupied homes account for two-thirds of the increase, driven by higher annual values, which rose 8.7% year on year in the fourth quarter of 2023. The government has implemented a one-off rebate of up to 100% for owner-occupied HDB flats and a 15% rebate for private homeowners, capped at S$1,000, to soften the impact of the tax hike.

images.alt_text: Monies that go into buying and sprucing up houses in GCB Areas can be productively used in many other areas.

site_title: Torah scrolls that survived the Nazis now fuel faith around the world
summary: The Memorial Scrolls Trust, a London-based organization, has been lending Torah scrolls to synagogues and institutions worldwide for 60 years, after rescuing them from the Nazis during World War II. The scrolls, which numbered 1,564, were originally confiscated from Czech synagogues and stored in a warehouse, where they deteriorated. The trust was founded by Ralph Yablon, who purchased the collection for $30,000 and donated it to the Westminster Synagogue in London. Today, the trust lends scrolls to over 25 countries, including the US, and has become a symbol of Jewish resilience and unity.

images.alt_text: The site, about 35 km southwest of Bethlehem, has been known for generations as the Cave of Salome.

site_title: Alibaba’s 80% loss may extend on competition worries
summary: Alibaba's revenue for the three months to December is expected to have risen 5.6% from a year ago, the slowest growth in three quarters, amid difficult economic conditions and steep discounting. The stock's nearly 80% tumble from its 2020 record high has driven its valuation to an all-time low, comparable to upstart rival PDD Holdings. Investors may face further pain ahead of the company's earnings report, with increased bearishness in options trading and a put contract betting on a 14% drop by the end of April.

site_title: Cybersecurity – more than just a tech issue, it’s an ESG concern
summary: Cybersecurity is becoming increasingly intertwined with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns, particularly in ESG reporting. Despite economic uncertainties, businesses prioritize both cybersecurity and ESG, with the government proposing a model AI governance framework to enhance the ecosystem. However, most businesses view these priorities in isolation, and the ESG regulatory environment remains nascent. To build trust, businesses should integrate cybersecurity and ESG approaches, leveraging synergies to gain a competitive advantage and mitigate risks.

site_title: Inflation, US election to drive 2024 markets: JPMorgan trader survey
summary: A JPMorgan survey found that inflation and the US presidential election are expected to be the biggest drivers of global markets in 2024, with 27% and 20% of traders citing these factors, respectively. The survey also noted that liquidity challenges, including access to liquidity and market structure, are a growing concern. Recession fears have decreased to third place, with war in Europe and the Middle East also being significant factors. The survey highlights the potential for short-term volatility in markets, particularly with the release of US monthly jobs and inflation numbers.

site_title: China tightens some trading restrictions for domestic and offshore investors
summary: China has tightened trading restrictions on domestic and offshore investors to combat a deepening stock rout. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has imposed caps on brokerages' cross-border total return swaps and banned quantitative hedge funds from placing sell orders. The measures aim to prevent a "negative loop" of technical selling pressure triggered by margin calls and worsen market downturn. The CSRC has also vowed to crack down on illegal activities, including insider trading, and guide more funds into the market. However, experts say the measures may be insufficient to turn the market around, and China may need to consider large-scale stock purchases.

images.alt_text: The watchdog’s vow to stabilise the market comes amid growing concerns that slumping share prices could trigger more selling in a vicious spiral.

In a sign of how exasperated some investors have become, thousands flocked to a social media account of the US embassy in Beijing to vent their frustrations over the economy and slumping share prices.

The CSRC (top) is seeking opinion on the proposal to “reasonably” reduce transaction fees, and plans to strengthen supervision of the distribution of commissions for securities trading of public funds.

site_title: Musk’s track record, OpenAI success are xAI’s biggest investor pitches
summary: Elon Musk's new AI startup, xAI, is focusing on its access to Musk's "Muskonomy" of companies and the early success of rival OpenAI as key selling points to investors. The startup's presentation highlights Musk's entrepreneurial track record, strategic partnerships with companies like Tesla and X, and the rapid growth of OpenAI. xAI aims to raise up to $1 billion in equity and has secured at least $500 million in financing. The company's chatbot assistant, Grok, is available to paying subscribers and is being trained using data from X, positioning it as an edgier alternative to OpenAI's ChatGPT.

Elon Musk, 52, oversees six companies: Tesla, SpaceX, X, Neuralink, Boring and xAI.

site_title: Room for central bank to cut rates: Thai PM
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin urged the Bank of Thailand to cut interest rates, citing a need for monetary policy easing despite lower inflation. The central bank is expected to maintain its record-high policy rate of 2.50% on Wednesday, despite government pressure. Thavisin argued that there is "a lot of room" for rate cuts, even after reducing the rate from 2.50% to 2.25%. BOT Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput recently stated the current policy rate was "broadly neutral," and the economy was not in crisis.

site_title: The protectionist impulse in Washington
summary: US lawmakers from both parties have expressed concerns over Japan's planned acquisition of US Steel, citing national security implications and exacerbating national trade imbalances. Despite President Joe Biden's encouragement of foreign investment in US factories, lawmakers have pushed for a review of the deal, putting Biden in a tight spot in an election year. The proposed acquisition would be a collaborative effort with Japan, both facing the challenge of Chinese dominance in the global steel industry.

images.alt_text: Citing several unnamed sources, Bloomberg said the three Japanese megabanks had extended a commitment letter to Nippon Steel for the dollar-denominated loans.

site_title: Toyota hikes annual profit forecast after Q3 beats expectations
summary: Toyota raised its annual profit forecast to 4.9 trillion yen ($44.36 billion), a 9% increase, after beating Q3 expectations with higher sales volumes and a weaker yen. The company's operating profit for the third quarter totaled 1.68 trillion yen, up 75.7% from last year. Toyota's robust demand for hybrid vehicles, which it pioneered, is seen as a key factor in its outperformance this year, despite rivals warning of slowing sales growth and high interest rates.

Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD went from 12th to fifth in passenger car registrations for 2023.
Toyota chief executive officer Koji Sato has promised the automaker will be able to sell 1.5 million battery EVs annually by 2026, and 3.5 million by 2030.

More than 30 deaths worldwide and hundreds of injuries in various automakers’ vehicles since 2009 are linked to Takata airbag inflators that can explode, unleashing metal shrapnel inside cars and trucks.

site_title: Thailand’s sugar outlook worsens as yields slide after dry spell
summary: Thailand's sugar production is expected to be lower than initially forecast due to a dry spell impacting plant growth, leading to a global supply squeeze. The country's sugar millers have trimmed their production estimate to 7.5 million tonnes, a third lower than the previous season. This will strain the market further, contributing to the lowest yield from crushed cane in at least 13 years. Climate change is cited as a factor in the reduced yields.

images.alt_text: Palm oil is one of the only agri commodities that has booked a fall in price so far this year, which has pressured the margins of companies in the palm oil production sector.

site_title: India’s HDFC Bank gets central bank nod to buy 9.5% stake each in six banks
summary: HDFC Bank, India's largest private lender by market capitalization, has received approval from the Reserve Bank of India to acquire up to 9.5% stakes in six private lenders: ICICI Bank, IndusInd Bank, Yes Bank, Axis Bank, Bandhan Bank, and Suryoday Small Finance Bank. The approval, valid for one year, also mandates the group to acquire major shareholdings in all the banks. This move comes after HDFC Asset Management Company already holds stakes in ICICI Bank, IndusInd Bank, Yes Bank, Axis Bank, and Bandhan Bank.

images.alt_text: The banking giant is seeking a bigger presence abroad to tap the Indian diaspora for savings and term deposits, as well as to cross-sell more products, say sources.

site_title: UBS restarts share buybacks, targets more cost cuts from Credit Suisse takeover
summary: UBS has restarted its share buyback program, targeting more cost cuts from its acquisition of Credit Suisse. The Swiss bank reported a net loss of US$279 million in the fourth quarter due to higher expenses from integrating Credit Suisse. UBS has lifted its cost-cutting target to US$13 billion by 2026, with a focus on driving sustainable long-term growth and higher returns. Analysts welcomed the proposed 27% increase in its 2023 dividend but expressed lukewarm response to the underwhelming fourth-quarter results.

images.alt_text: John McDonald, group chief marketing officer, UBS
The scale of the retrenchment in private banking is one of the biggest seen in Asia and comes as wealth from the Greater China region has tumbled amid a property crisis and the faltering economy.
UBS is making progress on a complex integration and restructuring of Credit Suisse, which it acquired in an emergency rescue.
UBS will use the slogan “Banking is our craft” as it seeks to attract new customers to its wealth management, asset management, and investment banking franchises.

site_title: Hilton is in talks to buy campus-focused Graduate Hotels brand
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings is in talks to acquire the Graduate Hotels brand, which operates over 30 locations in the US and UK, without taking on the real estate. The deal, if finalized, would mark Hilton's first acquisition of a brand. This move comes as Hilton focuses on expanding its portfolio through acquisitions, following its competitors Marriott International and Hyatt Hotels. The deal could be completed this year, but talks may fall apart or another buyer may emerge.

site_title: China declines comment on Singapore’s foreign interference case, says it’s another country’s internal affairs
summary: China's Foreign Ministry declined to comment on Singapore's designation of businessman Philip Chan as a politically significant person under the country's foreign interference laws. Chan, 59, was served a notice on Feb 2 due to his involvement with the Hong Kong Singapore Business Association and his past attendance at the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. China stated it refrains from interfering in other countries' internal affairs and has no intention of commenting on the matter, citing Chan's contributions to promoting cooperation between Hong Kong and Singapore.

images.alt_text: Naturalised Singaporean Philip Chan, who was born in Hong Kong, believed in uniting overseas Chinese to tell China’s story.

Philip Chan Man Ping, a Hong Kong-born businessman and president of the Kowloon Club helping new immigrants to Singapore, has been assessed to have shown susceptibility to being influenced by foreign actors, MHA said.

site_title: Philippine annual inflation at 2.8% in January
summary: The Philippines' consumer price index in January fell to 2.8%, the lowest since October 2020, below the 3.1% forecast. This decrease was driven by lower food prices. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food and energy costs, was at 3.8%. The rate is below the central bank's projection of 2.8-3.6%.

site_title: OK Lim was in ‘complete control, made all decisions’ for company: Hin Leong ex-employee
summary: A former employee of failed oil trader Hin Leong testified in court that founder OK Lim was "in complete control" and made all decisions for the company, contradicting Lim's claim of not being involved in day-to-day activities. The employee, Serene Seng, said Lim oversaw the company's trading and bunkers departments, and his children were involved in the accounts department. Liquidators allege Hin Leong concealed losses of over $800 million through fictitious gains, forged documents, and improper accounting. The trial continues, with Lim and his children facing a $3.5 billion lawsuit from liquidators and top creditor HSBC.

site_title: UK retail sales slow as shoppers tighten belts
summary: UK retail sales slowed in January, increasing 1.2% compared to a 3-month average of 1.9%. This decline was attributed to consumers tightening their belts due to tepid economic demand. Food sales, however, saw a "largest year-on-year growth in over 12 months" as Brits stayed home during winter storms, with grocery volumes rising 5.2% at supermarkets. Overall, spending growth on UK credit and debit cards rose just 3.1%.

site_title: Abu Dhabi wealth fund is said to weigh stake in Wanda mall unit
summary: The Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (Adia) is considering purchasing a minority stake in Dalian Wanda Group's mall operator, Zhuhai Wanda Commercial Management Group. This comes after billionaire Wang Jianlin relinquished control in December as part of a deal to avoid repaying pre-IPO investors. Private equity firm PAG and other investors hold 60% of the company, with Wang holding 40%. Adia may buy shares from existing holders, contingent on securing $30 billion in financing from banks.

site_title: Google to face US antitrust trial over digital ads in September
summary: A US federal judge has set a September 9, 2024, date for the start of a jury trial in a lawsuit against Google, alleging the company has monopolized the digital advertising market and undermined competition. The US Justice Department and a coalition of states filed the lawsuit in January 2023, seeking Google to sell its ad manager suite. Google denies the claims, stating it would slow innovation and harm small businesses if forced to sell. This trial is one of several ongoing cases against Google in the US.

images.alt_text: Alphabet has faced tough competition for ad budgets from other online platforms such as Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and Amazon.com, and economic signals in the US have been mixed.

Investors are watching Microsoft’s Azure and Office revenues to see what kind of sales flow comes from the tens of billions of US dollars the company plans to pour into data centres this year to deliver generative AI.
Meta has already proven that its work in AI can produce results for its advertisers.

At the launch event at Google Singapore's office on Monday (Jan 29) were (from left):  Google Singapore managing director Ben King, country director for Singapore at Google Cloud Serene Sia, managing director (South-east Asia) at Google Cloud Mark Micallef, Minister for Communications and Information  Josephine Teo,  Permanent Secretary at Smart Nation Joseph Leong, Permanent Secretary at the Ministry of Trade and Industry Gabriel Lim, and Jacqueline Poh, managing director at the Singapore Economic Development Board.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,128.97. The decline was attributed to overnight losses in global equity markets. Losers outnumbered gainers 59 to 57, with 112 million securities worth S$70.5 million changing hands. Banking stocks were trading mixed, while shares on Wall Street ended lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.7% and the S&P 500 down 0.3%.

images.alt_text: CICT rises in gross revenue and net property income for the second half ended December.

site_title: US appeals court to weigh fate of US$12 billion bank collusion case
summary: A US appeals court has agreed to hear a challenge to a judge's order allowing cities to band together in a $12 billion class action against eight major banks, accused of artificially inflating interest rates on municipal bonds from 2008 to 2016. The cities claim the banks' collusion reduced available funding for hospitals, schools, and other outlets. The 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals will decide whether the case was properly certified as a class action before proceeding.

images.alt_text: A visitor arrives at the Societe Generale SA bank headquarters in the La Defense business district of Paris, France, on Wednesday, Aug. 2, 2023. SocGen reports earnings on August 3. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a signboard of Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and MUFG Bank at its headquarters in Tokyo, Japan April 3, 2018. REUTERS/Toru Hanai/File Photo

The logo of the Saudi National Bank (SNB) can be seen at the banks' headquarters in Riyadh on March 27, 2023, after the chairman of SNB, the main shareholder of troubled lender Credit Suisse which was bought out this month, resigned. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)
Australia’s labour market remains solid and the economy has shown resilience to higher borrowing costs, suggesting there’s no urgency to shift quickly to easing.

site_title: Snap to lay off 10% of its workforce as spate of job cuts continue
summary: Snapchat is laying off 528 employees, or 10% of its global workforce, as part of a restructuring effort to position the business for growth. The move, which is expected to incur pre-tax charges of $55-75 million, is the latest in a spate of job cuts in the tech industry. This brings the total number of layoffs in 122 tech companies to over 32,000 workers since the start of the year, with the tech sector accounting for the highest number of layoffs in 2023.

images.alt_text: Snap has been using the service to roll out early access to new features and improve them based on user feedback.
People will be able to link their Snapchat and Amazon accounts to take advantage of the in-app shopping feature, according to Amazon.

The court decision covers hundreds of lawsuits filed on behalf of individual children who allegedly suffered negative physical, mental and emotional health effects from social media use including anxiety, depression, and occasionally suicide.
Snap's revenue for the third quarter ended September rose 5 per cent to US$1.19 billion, beating analysts’ expectations of US$1.11 billion.

site_title: HDB approves 25% of appeals to waive 15-month waiting period for condo downgraders
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has approved 25% of appeals to waive the 15-month waiting period for condo downgraders, with 850 out of 3,470 appeals filed between Sep 30, 2022 and Dec 31, 2023 approved. The 15-month wait period was introduced in Sep 2022 to moderate demand for HDB resale flats and keep them affordable. The approval was mostly granted to individuals in financial difficulties or those who had committed to sell their private residential property, or those buying an HDB resale flat before the new wait-out period was announced.

images.alt_text: While buying a new executive condominium home is a good way to get into private homeownership, such homes can be fairly unaffordable these days.
Singapore's private rental market continues to face downward pressure.
XXX
Both Huttons and OrangeTee & Tie are projecting HDB resale price growth to range between 3 and 5 per cent for 2024.
National Development Minister Desmond Lee says a range of measures are in place to manage supply and demand to stabilise the property market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Treasury yields climb; earnings in focus
summary: Wall Street opened lower on Monday, Feb 5, as Treasury yields rose after Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments on potential rate cuts. The Dow Jones fell 107.65 points, or 0.28%, to 38,546.77, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Investors assessed corporate earnings, with companies like NTT DC Reit and Creative Technology reporting mixed results. The market's focus shifted from rate cut speculation to earnings reports, leading to a lower opening.

site_title: Oobit to expand crypto payments app’s global reach with US$25 million boost
summary: Oobit, a Singapore-based mobile crypto payment app, has secured US$25 million in series A funding to expand its global reach. The funding, led by Solana Labs co-founder Anatoly Yakovenko and stablecoin issuer Tether Limited, aims to take the platform to Asia Pacific, Latin America, and the UAE. Oobit's "tap and pay" feature allows users to make payments at over 100 million merchants worldwide, mirroring contactless transactions. The app plans to enable direct payments while maintaining user control over funds, aligning with its user-centric financial vision.

site_title: US lenders, business groups sue bank regulators over updated fair lending rules
summary: US banking and business groups have sued three bank regulators over updated fair lending rules, arguing they exceed statutory authority, are too complex, and could disincentivize lending. The lawsuit, filed by the American Bankers Association and others, seeks to vacate new rules enforcing the Community Reinvestment Act, which aims to ensure banks lend in local communities. The regulators say the updated rules modernize lending practices for the digital age. The lawsuit is the latest in a wave of challenges to Democratic President Joe Biden's regulators by lenders and industry groups.

images.alt_text: US officials say the new policy is part of a wider effort to shape the behaviour of foreign governments and individual companies that are involved in malicious digital espionage activities.

site_title: Japan’s December real wages, household spending fall again
summary: Japan's real wages fell for a 21st straight month, with a 1.9% decline in December from a year earlier, slowing from a revised 2.5% drop in November. Household spending also declined for a tenth consecutive month, falling 2.5% from a year earlier. The decline in real wages and household spending was driven by inflation outpacing wage recovery, with the Bank of Japan closely monitoring these indicators as it prepares to phase out its stimulus policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a signboard of Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and MUFG Bank at its headquarters in Tokyo, Japan April 3, 2018. REUTERS/Toru Hanai/File Photo
The service sector has been a bright spot for the world’s third-largest economy, helping offset some of the drag on manufacturers from weak global demand.
The acquisition of Singlife by Sumitomo Life is just one of many deals Japanese corporates in South-east Asia, with their banks looking to leverage their low cost of funds.
Marubeni posts a profit of 371.5 billion yen (S$3.4 billion) in the nine months through Dec 31 compared with 463.5 billion yen a year earlier.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Mizuho Financial Group logo is seen at the company's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan August 20, 2018. Picture taken August 20, 2018.  REUTERS/Toru Hana/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: CICT posts 1.7% rise in H2 DPU to S$0.0545
summary: CICT, a Singaporean real estate investment trust (Reit), reported a 1.7% increase in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0545, driven by higher contributions from Raffles City Singapore and full-year contributions from 2022 acquisitions. Gross revenue rose 4.1% to S$785.2 million, while net property income (NPI) grew 4% to S$563.6 million. The Reit's manager attributed the improvement to conservative portfolio management and cost management. CICT plans to undertake asset enhancement initiatives and pare down its gearing, with aggregate leverage expected to be around 37-38%.

krhls31 - Bukit Panjang Plaza
