the upgrade comes after CICT reported its Q3 business updates on Thursday
For the quarter, CICT also registered a steady growth in portfolio committed occupancy at 97.3 per cent.

site_title: Paragon Reit posts 1.9% lower H2 DPU of S$0.026
summary: Paragon Reit posted a 1.9% lower second-half distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.026, despite a 3% increase in gross revenue to S$145.8 million. The Reit's net property income rose 3.3% to S$109 million. The lower DPU was attributed to rising interest costs, but the Reit's manager expects a continued recovery in tenant leasing sentiments and improved performances in FY2024, driven by robust demand and labor market conditions.

images.alt_text: The Paragon, a luxury shopping complex located in the Orchard Road area of Singapore.
The Metro Trim Shoppe at the atrium on the ground floor of Paragon shopping mall on Dec 7, 2022.
Paragon Reit's distribution per unit fell 15.7 per cent to S$0.0242 for the first half of its financial year ended Jun 30.

For Paragon Reit's Singapore properties – which includes Paragon, The Clementi Mall and The Rail Mall – tenant sales rose 12 per cent on year in the first quarter, while footfall was up 37 per cent on year.

site_title: UK trial opens into bitcoin ‘inventor’ claims
summary: A UK trial began on Monday to determine whether Australian computer scientist Craig Wright, 53, is the true creator of bitcoin, claiming to be Satoshi Nakamoto. Wright has been accused of lying about his identity and forging documents to prove his claims. The Crypto Open Patent Alliance (Copa) is suing Wright, backed by industry heavyweights Coinbase and Block, and the trial is expected to last until mid-March. If Wright is found not to be Satoshi, it could impact another case pitting him against 26 developers for allegedly infringing on his intellectual property rights.

images.alt_text: Tether’s USDT token is on the verge of surpassing US$100 billion in circulation for the first time.
The Reserve Bank of India aims to widen the use of its central bank digital currency. It reportedly met its goal of one million daily transaction of the digital rupee in 2023.
The largest digital asset has risen about 2 per cent in January.

The fraud-tainted crypto firm’s four largest affiliates – including FTX Trading and Alameda Research – together nearly doubled the group’s cash pile to US$4.4 billion at the end of 2023 from about US$2.3 billion in late October, according to Chapter 11 monthly operating reports.
Going mainstream has revealed Bitcoin's true value. Now it is just another asset class, about as exciting as a bond fund, but much more volatile and with far less ability to diversify its risk.
A spot crypto ETF tracks the market price of the underlying digital asset, giving investors exposure to the token without having to buy the currency.
Bitcoin has surged past US$49,000 for the first time since December 2021 with trading commencing on the first US exchange-traded funds that invest directly in the cryptocurrency.
The entrance of the world’s largest cryptocurrency into the world’s largest stock market “marks the end of the beginning of Bitcoin’s maturation and growing-up phase.

site_title: Having raced past rivals to become the world’s top EV seller, BYD’s challenge is to stay ahead
summary: BYD surpassed Tesla as the top electric vehicle seller in Singapore in 2023. The Chinese automaker posted a 74.4-86.5% year-on-year profit improvement, estimating 29-31 billion yuan (S$5.4-6.4 billion) in net profit for 2023. This success comes as the industry faces slowing demand for electric vehicles. BYD's achievement has investors wondering if the company is at a crossroads, but the company's strong financial performance suggests it is well-positioned to stay ahead.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Volkswagen logo is seen on a Volkswagen ID.5 electric car on display at a showroom of a car dealer in Reze near Nantes, France, November 13, 2023. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo
Trade tensions have been rising since the EU opened its EV investigation and China this month announced an anti-dumping probe into brandy sales.

site_title: HDB resale prices jump 1.5% in January amid strong volumes: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore rose 1.5% in January 2024, driven by strong volumes and demand for larger flats. The highest transacted price was S$1.57 million for a five-room flat in Toa Payoh. Year-on-year, prices increased 5.7%, with five-room units rising 6.4% and four-roomers increasing 5.5%. The number of million-dollar flats sold in January 2024 was 37% higher than the previous all-time high, with 74 such transactions. Experts predict more million-dollar flats in 2024, with some estimating over 500 million-dollar flats.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of public housing in the Bishan district taken on Jan 5, 2024.
There are 56 million-dollar flat transactions as of Jan 26, says Huttons Asia.
The number of resale transactions ease 2.2 per cent in the fourth quarter to 6,547 cases – the lowest fourth-quarter volume since 2020.
Both Huttons and OrangeTee & Tie are projecting HDB resale price growth to range between 3 and 5 per cent for 2024.

site_title: Plans afoot to make SimplyGo card also work for motoring payments
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat plans to extend the SimplyGo card-based ticketing system for adult transport cards until 2030, with a $40 million investment. The system will be integrated with motoring payments, similar to older ez-link cards. To address usability issues, more card readers will be added to MRT stations and bus interchanges. The government will also extend the concession card-based system until 2030. Chee acknowledged that SimplyGo's delay in displaying fare information has caused delays, but believes a solution can be found over time.

site_title: US to restrict visas for those who misuse commercial spyware
summary: The US has announced a new visa restriction policy targeting individuals and companies involved in misusing commercial spyware. The policy, part of a broader effort to combat malicious digital espionage, will allow the State Department to impose visa restrictions on those believed to have abused spyware, facilitated such actions, or benefited from them. This move aims to shape the behavior of foreign governments and companies involved in such activities, particularly those accused of hacking human rights activists, journalists, and opposition politicians in the developing world.

images.alt_text: Cybersecurity is a vital factor in ensuring that data collected and processed from various sources for ESG reporting, for example, are reliable and protected.
Communications and Information Minister Josephine Teo addressing the media in a press conference after the closing of the fourth Asean Digital Ministers Meeting at Shangri-La Hotel on Feb 2 (Friday).

The region's digital ministers convene in Singapore for the fourth Asean Digital Ministers Meeting.

site_title: Strata office deals inch up 1.8% to S$1.2 billion, average price climbs 15% in 2023: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's strata office market recorded flat growth in 2023, with transaction value increasing 1.8% to S$1.2 billion and average price rising 14.7% to S$2,929 per square foot. The market is expected to be held up by displaced occupiers and steady demand for limited freehold strata office units, with Knight Frank projecting a total transaction value of S$1 billion in 2024.

images.alt_text: In 2022, Midpoint Orchard attempted a third collective sale at around S$350 million.
Interest in Orchard Road malls has revived, with Far East Shopping Centre changing hands at S$908 million.
Shenton House's purchase price translates into S$1,889 psf ppr., says JLL.

site_title: Australia set to pass contentious tax cuts bill as parliament resumes
summary: Australia's parliament is set to pass a reshaped tax cuts bill, which would give low-income earners more breaks and reduce benefits to the wealthy. The bill, unveiled last month, aims to benefit more Australians amid high inflation. The conservative opposition initially criticized the government's shift in policy, but later pledged support. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese defended the proposal, citing financial pressure on families from inflation. The bill is expected to pass after the opposition's change of stance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese speaks at the Sydney Energy Forum in Sydney, Australia July 12, 2022. Brook Mitchell/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Australia’s labour market remains solid and the economy has shown resilience to higher borrowing costs, suggesting there’s no urgency to shift quickly to easing.

The new policy, recently announced, will see people earning up to A$135,000 (S$118,183) fall into lower tax brackets from Jul 1. For some high-income earners, tax breaks will nearly halve, with the savings redirected to those on low incomes.
Australia’s property market surprisingly recovered last year despite the central bank’s 4.25 percentage points of policy tightening since May 2022.
Growth has slowed in recent months, with Sydney prices just rising 0.2 per cent in January.

site_title: US services sector growth picks up in January: ISM survey
summary: The US services sector experienced growth in January, with a non-manufacturing PMI increasing to 53.4 from 50.5 in December. New orders rose to 55.0, employment rebounded to 50.5, and input prices increased to an 11-month-high of 64.0. Despite this, the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, citing that rates had peaked, and the economic growth momentum from the fourth quarter continued into the new year, diminishing the chances of an interest rate cut in March.

images.alt_text: Shoppers outside of the Ralph Lauren store in the Magnificent Mile shopping district of Chicago, Illinois, US, on Saturday, Dec. 2, 2023. A burnt-out consumer, weighed down by high interest rates and dwindling savings, is the surest sign that economic growth is gliding lower heading into 2024. Photographer: Taylor Glascock/Bloomberg

site_title: Blackstone said to consider bid for skin-care company L’Occitane
summary: Private equity firm Blackstone is considering a bid for skin-care company L’Occitane International, potentially teaming up with billionaire chairman Reinold Geiger. Blackstone has conducted preliminary due diligence and is evaluating a potential offer. L’Occitane shares rose 0.8% following the news. Geiger had previously considered taking the company private, but abandoned the idea last year. If a proposal is made, L’Occitane could attract interest from other suitors, and the company's enterprise value is currently about 10 times its estimated earnings.

site_title: King Charles III diagnosed with cancer
summary: King Charles III, 75, has been diagnosed with cancer and is undergoing treatment, Buckingham Palace announced on Monday. The diagnosis was made during his recent hospital procedure for benign prostate enlargement, and the palace did not specify the type or severity of the cancer. The king remains positive and looks forward to returning to full public duty as soon as possible. Prince Harry and Prince William have offered support, with Prince Harry stating he will visit his father and Prince William expected to return to royal duties this week.

images.alt_text: The Princess of Wales during a walkabout meeting members of the public on the Long Walk near Windsor Castle, Berkshire, where the Coronation Concert to celebrate the coronation of King Charles III and Queen Camilla is being held. Picture date: Sunday May 7, 2023.  Andrew Matthews/Pool via REUTERS

(FILES) Sarah, Duchess of York smiles outside after attending the Royal Family's traditional Christmas Day service at St Mary Magdalene Church on the Sandringham Estate in eastern England, on December 25, 2023. Prince Andrew's ex-wife, Sarah Ferguson, who recently underwent breast cancer surgery, is suffering from "malignant melanoma", a skin cancer, her spokesperson announced on Sunday, January 21. (Photo by Adrian DENNIS / AFP)

The Princess of Wales during a walkabout meeting members of the public on the Long Walk near Windsor Castle, Berkshire, where the Coronation Concert to celebrate the coronation of King Charles III and Queen Camilla is being held. Picture date: Sunday May 7, 2023.  Andrew Matthews/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Real estate most distressed sector in Europe in 2023
summary: Real estate in Europe was the most distressed sector in 2023, driven by high interest rates, falling valuations, and expensive financing. This is the fourth consecutive quarter that real estate tops the Weil European Distress Index report. Healthcare, retail, and consumer goods followed as the second, third, and fourth most distressed sectors, respectively. The report aggregates data from over 3,750 listed European firms, highlighting a challenging outlook for highly leveraged companies facing debt repayment and refinancing difficulties.

images.alt_text: Fewer qualifying buyers upgrading from HDB public flats is a factor that may dampen Singapore home prices this year.

site_title: China’s 1% is watching the other 99%
summary: China's surveillance capabilities, though bolstered by advanced technologies, are largely dependent on the country's extensive organisational presence and sophisticated intelligence network. The Chinese Communist Party's recruitment of millions of informants, estimated at 1% of the population, provides a vast network of "ears and eyes" to gather intelligence. While technology plays a role, it is the CCP's unique system that allows for effective surveillance, making exportation of such capabilities challenging. China's surveillance state is a product of its deep social and economic reach, rather than just technology.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration’s previous moves to restrain sensitive economic relationships have taken a toll.
Police checks and patriotic flowers: Beijing leaves nothing to chance ahead of Party centenary

site_title: US: Stocks slump after earnings while yields rise
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.7% to 38,380.12 and the S&P 500 down 0.3% to 4,942.81, amid concerns over interest rate cuts. Treasury yields rose, with two-year and 10-year yields surging, as investors expect the Federal Reserve to maintain its stance. Earnings reports from Caterpillar and McDonald's also influenced the market, with Caterpillar's shares rising 1.9% and McDonald's falling 3.7%. Fed Chair Jerome Powell reiterated that a rate cut is unlikely in March, fueling concerns about the timing of interest rate cuts this year.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 1, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Europe: Shares ease as dashed rate-cut hopes push yields higher
summary: European shares closed 0.1% lower on Monday, following lower expectations of interest rate cuts by major central banks. The Stoxx 600 index ended flat for the week. Bond yields rose, with the German government bond yield at 2.318%, amid concerns of higher interest rates for longer. The US jobs data and Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments also contributed to the subdued sentiment. Despite some upbeat corporate reports, shares of European miners and healthcare companies fell, while retail shares dropped 2.2%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7 per cent to 38,380.12 while the broad-based S&P 500 retreated 0.3 per cent to 4,942.81 on Monday.

site_title: Reddit revenue rises 20% ahead of IPO, but it isn’t profitable yet
summary: Reddit has reported a 20% rise in revenue to over $800 million in 2023, ahead of its potential initial public offering (IPO). Despite this growth, the company remains unprofitable, with a loss of $69 million in adjusted earnings. Reddit is preparing for its IPO, with banks including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs working on the deal, which is expected to be filed as early as this month. The company is targeting a valuation of at least $5 billion in the IPO.

images.alt_text: The valuations under consideration demonstrate the extent of tech’s retreat from the heady days of the private funding boom that peaked in 2021.
Reddit is seeking to sell about 10 per cent of its shares in the IPO.

Companies planning first-time share sales in the US have been stymied for months by volatile markets and a relatively weak showing for four closely watched debuts in September and October, which all but slammed the door on big-ticket IPOs in 2023.
Reddit, the social media platform that helped fuel the stock meme frenzy two years ago, filed confidentially for an initial public offering in late 2021.
Reddit tapping Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley for IPO: Bloomberg News

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, Paragon Reit, Hong Lai Huat
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) posted a 1.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the second half ended December 2023, driven by higher rental and occupancy rates. In contrast, Paragon Real Estate Investment Trust's DPU decreased 1.9% due to rising interest costs. Meanwhile, Hong Lai Huat announced plans to sell two loss-making subsidiaries in Cambodia for $37.5 million, marking the group's exit from its agricultural business. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

site_title: Nickel extends slump on Indonesian glut as metals hit by US Fed
summary: Nickel prices continue to slump due to a surge in Indonesian supply, expected to remain in surplus for the rest of the decade. The market has been affected by rising Indonesian supplies, prompting miners to close operations and seek state bailouts. Prices have almost halved over the past year, with the London Metal Exchange seeing a decline in risk appetite for the metal. The US Federal Reserve's decision to wait beyond March to cut interest rates has also contributed to the slump, with other base metals declining in response.

images.alt_text: A huge Indonesian expansion of low-grade production led to a surplus, but processing innovations have allowed that glut to be refined into a high-quality product that’s hitting the battery market.
Indonesia has emerged as a global nickel hub after billions of US dollars of investment in efficient plants that benefit from inexpensive labour, cheap power and readily available raw materials.

site_title: China targets margin loans, short selling to help stabilise stocks
summary: China's securities regulator has vowed to stabilize the market by tightening scrutiny of margin financing, malicious short selling, and pledged shares. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) aims to guide brokerages to give investors more time to answer margin calls, easing downward market pressure. The watchdog has set "zero tolerance" for ill-intended short sellers, warning they will face severe penalties, including fines and imprisonment. So far, risks are manageable, with total forced selling of roughly 900 million yuan (S$169.2 million) in January.

images.alt_text: In a sign of how exasperated some investors have become, thousands flocked to a social media account of the US embassy in Beijing to vent their frustrations over the economy and slumping share prices.

Authorities will actively work with relevant parties and coordinate the implementation of various measures to stabilise the market and boost confidence, according to the China Securities Regulatory Commission.

site_title: Noel Gifts posts S$1.2 million H1 loss but expects full-year profit on proceeds of collective sale
summary: Noel Gifts International reported a net loss of S$1.2 million for the first half of 2024, a 84.1% year-on-year increase, due to lower sales and "ever-changing consumer demand". However, the company expects to be profitable for the full year of 2024, thanks to the proceeds of the collective sale of its 50 Playfair Road property, valued at S$81.2 million.

images.alt_text: Alfred Wong, the managing director of Noel Gifts International.
Noel Gifts expects to book S$30.6 million from the sale of 10 units it owns at the freehold industrial property.
The 8-storey development has been sold for S$81 million and will be use as a food factory, says Edmund Tie.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands to stage Singapore’s largest drone show as part of Year of the Dragon festivities
summary: Marina Bay Sands will host Singapore's largest drone show as part of the Year of the Dragon festivities. The 10-minute show, featuring 1,500 synchronised drones, will take place on six evenings starting February 10, telling the mythical tale of a koi's transformation into the Dragon King against Singapore's city skyline. The event marks a collaboration between Marina Bay Sands, the Singapore Tourism Board, and local bank UOB to introduce "world-class programming" in the precinct.

images.alt_text: Nicholas Ionides, MBS’ vice-president of communications and corporate affairs, with a senior at the reunion lunch organised by MBS and Care Corner.
An artist's impression of Marina Bay Sands' fourth tower.
Over 40 companies – which include Standard Chartered Singapore (above) – and individuals have been mobilised to donate, pack and distribute the items to the recipients.
The Sands Innovative Arts Fund is part of MBS’ community engagement programme, Sands Cares, of which support for the arts is a key pillar.

site_title: Microsoft partners with Semafor for AI-assisted news content
summary: Microsoft is partnering with Semafor and other news organizations to help journalists work with generative AI in content production. The collaboration aims to identify and refine procedures for using AI responsibly in newsgathering and business practices. Semafor is launching a breaking news feed called "Signals" using tools from OpenAI and Microsoft. This comes as Microsoft faces a lawsuit over its use of copyrighted content to train AI technologies, with the company claiming it falls under fair use. The partnership also includes collaborations with other news organizations to explore AI integration.

site_title: US bill poses risk to Wuxi AppTec and its Western drugmaker partners
summary: A US congressional committee has introduced a bill restricting federally funded medical providers from sharing genetic information with China's BGI Group, Wuxi AppTec, and other biotech firms. The bill could impact Wuxi AppTec, a leading China-based biotech firm, and its Western partners, including Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and GlaxoSmithKline, which rely on the company for research and manufacturing. Wuxi AppTec's shares have tumbled nearly 50% amid concerns about the bill's potential impact, with analysts warning that investor confidence could remain under pressure.

images.alt_text: AstraZeneca will also acquire Gracell’s cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments of US$234.1 million as of Sept 30 2023 and the deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2024.

site_title: Tech layoffs continue to roil industry with 32,000 jobs cut
summary: The tech industry has started 2024 with another wave of job cuts, with 32,000 tech workers losing their jobs so far this year, according to Layoffs.fyi. Companies such as Snap, Okta, Amazon, Salesforce, and Meta Platforms are cutting jobs, citing economic factors and a shift in resources to focus on artificial intelligence (AI). Despite these layoffs, the industry is also hiring aggressively, with 33,727 active job postings in January, the largest month-over-month increase in 12 months.

images.alt_text: home office, program, programmer

“In order to best position our business to execute on our highest priorities, and to ensure we have the capacity to invest incrementally to support our growth over time, we have made the difficult decision to restructure our team,” Snap says.
Lazada and the FDAWU have settled on a better support package and training fund for laid off union members.
After vaulting into public consciousness during the pandemic, Zoom has struggled to maintain high revenue growth.
Okta estimates it will incur about US$24 million in severance and benefits costs during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2024 as a result of the job cuts.
This photograph taken on January 19, 2024 shows a sign of American corporation Microsoft displayed during the World Economic Forum (WEF) annual meeting in Davos. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)
Google has been working on AI for years, and recent seismic events in the market has reaffirmed the need for dominance as its core search product faces an existential threat.

site_title: WeWork explores bankruptcy loan options amid landlord dispute
summary: WeWork may explore a new bankruptcy loan to cover its financial shortfall due to slower-than-expected progress in rent negotiations with landlords. The company's post-bankruptcy business plan relies on significant rent reductions, but WeWork has shown "painfully little progress" in discussions, according to creditors. WeWork's initial cash reserves of $164 million are now deemed insufficient, and the company is considering taking on a new loan that could be converted into equity after bankruptcy. Landlords have criticized WeWork's "hardball tactics" and accused the company of "taking hostages" by withholding rent.

images.alt_text: epa11053156 People cross the street beneath a large screen showing the latest stock exchange and economy data in Shanghai, China, 02 January 2024. On Tuesday 02 January 2024, most Asian markets were down following the release of data that indicated further weakness in Chinese property and manufacturing sectors.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI

epa10647830 Workers at Canary Wharf in London, Britain, 23 May 2023. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has upgraded its forecast for the UK economy. The IMF has stated it expects the UK growth domestic product to grow by 0.4 percent in 2023, rising to two percent in 2024/25. The IMF also noted that it expects Britain’s high inflation to fall back to five percent by the end of 2023. The International Monetary Fund previously announced in April that it had expected the UK to fall into recession this year.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
The deal with 1440 Broadway allows WeWork to maintain a foothold in a New York City building that’s in the heart of Times Square.

Blackstone’s platform, which it originally bought as The Office Group but has today re-branded following a merger with Brockton Capital’s Fora last year, now boasts more locations in London’s zones one and two travel districts than any other flexible office brand.

site_title: McDonald's records first sales miss in nearly 4 years
summary: McDonald's reported its first quarterly sales miss in nearly four years, with comparable sales in its International Developmental Licensed Markets segment rising only 0.7% in the fourth quarter, missing estimates of 5.5% growth. The company's overall net profit rose 7% due to higher menu pricing and lower raw material costs. Weak sales in China and the Middle East, as well as protests and boycott campaigns over perceived pro-Israeli stance, contributed to the miss.

images.alt_text: The expansion plans would take its restaurant count to about 50,000 in over 100 countries, according to McDonald’s.

site_title: Oil rises nearly 1% as traders assess worsening geopolitical situation
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 1% on Monday as traders assessed the worsening geopolitical situation, particularly in the Middle East and Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine. Brent crude futures settled at $78.22 a barrel, up 66 cents, or 0.9%, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 50 cents, or 0.7%, to $72.78 a barrel. The gains were the first in four sessions, driven by concerns that tensions in the region could curb global supplies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows an oil pump jack outside Almetyevsk in the Republic of Tatarstan, Russia June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk//File Photo

site_title: Oil steady as rate cut caution overshadows Mideast strikes
summary: Oil prices remained steady on Monday, gaining 10 US cents, or 0.1%, to US$77.43 a barrel for Brent Crude futures and flat at US$72.28 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate futures. The stability was due to a strong US job report, which reduced hopes for swift interest rate cuts. However, ongoing air strikes in the Middle East by the US maintained geopolitical tensions, keeping oil prices high.

images.alt_text: High interest rates tend to dampen economic growth and oil demand.

site_title: Nvidia hits record high as Goldman Sachs boosts PT on AI prospects
summary: Nvidia's shares hit a record high after Goldman Sachs raised its price target to $800, citing robust AI server demand and improving GPU supply. The stock rose 4% to $689.21, adding $70 billion to the company's market capitalization. Analysts expect Nvidia to report fourth-quarter earnings of $4.51 per share, with shares trading at 31.4 times forward earnings, compared to the industry average of 22.9. The company is seen as a leader in the AI market, with a 21% upside potential from current levels, according to LSEG data.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: NVIDIA HGX AI Supercomputer on display during the annual Foxconn Tech Day in Taipei, Taiwan October 18, 2023. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia presidential rivals tackle thorny labour issues in final election debate
summary: Indonesia's presidential candidates debated key issues in the final election debate, focusing on labour, healthcare, and digitalisation. Former Central Java governor Ganjar Pranowo promised to review the country's job creation laws, while Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto vowed to build modern health facilities and increase medical schools. Ganjar also pledged to restore Indonesia's 5% national budget for healthcare. The frontrunner, Prabowo, emphasized improving human resources and providing sufficient nutrition for children and pregnant women. The candidates' election pledges will be scrutinized ahead of the Valentine's Day polling day, with over 204 million eligible voters set to elect Indonesia's next President.

images.alt_text: Thousands of Indonesians at an election campaign rally in South Sulawesi on Jan 17, 2024. The three presidential candidates have each promised to roll out many policies to improve the lives of the people if they are successful at the Feb 14 poll.

site_title: Sri Lanka eyes US$5 billion in foreign funds after debt restructure
summary: Sri Lanka aims to attract around $5 billion in foreign funds within the next 12-24 months following the restructuring of its overseas debt. The country has made progress on $11 billion of bilateral debt restructuring and hopes to finalize agreements with key creditors by May. This influx of funds will be used for major infrastructure projects, including a highway, airport expansion, and a $2 billion light railway project with Japan, and from the sale of state-owned enterprises.

images.alt_text: Helped by a US$2.9 billion bailout by the IMF, Sri Lanka is on the path to recovery from its worst financial crisis in seven decades.
The central bank expects the VAT increase to add 2 percentage points to the inflation rate, while analysts predict it will add up to 4 percentage points.

site_title: MeGroup enters EV market with MG dealership in Malaysia
summary: MeGroup, a CATALIST-listed company, has been appointed as a dealer of MG cars in Malaysia, marking its entry into the electric vehicle (EV) market. Menang Nusantara, a subsidiary of MeGroup, will open the dealership in Setia Alam, Selangor. This move comes after MeGroup wound up its Hyundai dealership. The appointment signifies MeGroup's expansion into the EV market, following its transition from a traditional automotive dealership.

images.alt_text: Honda Malaysia appoints MeGroup as used car dealer
MeGroup to lease unsold cars to car subscription service Flux
MeGroup inks deal with Mitsubishi Motors to operate a dealership

site_title: US dollar hits 11-week high as Fed rate-cut bets recede
summary: The US dollar index reached its highest level in almost three months, surpassing 104.3, as traders reduced bets on aggressive Federal Reserve rate cuts this year. The dollar's rise followed the strong US jobs report and the Fed chair Jerome Powell's comments indicating the central bank could be patient in cutting interest rates. The euro fell to its lowest level since December 11, while the yen fell to its lowest since early December.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was last at 103.98, the highest since Dec 13 and up 0.9 per cent on the day.

site_title: OECD raises global growth outlook on US strength
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has raised its global growth outlook, expecting 2.9% growth in 2024, better than the 2.7% forecasted in November. The US economy is expected to grow 2.1% in 2024 and 1.7% in 2025, driven by lower inflation and interest rate cuts. Eurozone growth, however, remains weak, with Germany's economy expected to grow 0.6% in 2024. The OECD left its 2025 global estimate unchanged at 3% due to expected rate cuts by major central banks.

images.alt_text: BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda has stressed the bank’s resolve to keep ultra-loose policy settings intact until sustained achievement of 2 per cent inflation, accompanied by durable wage rises, comes into sight.

While about 36 per cent of corporate profits are currently estimated to be taxed at less than 15 per cent, only 7 per cent is expected to be below that threshold after the global minimum is in place, the OECD says.
Flags are pictured during the first working session of G-7 foreign ministers in Muenster, Germany, November 3, 2022.  REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/Pool

The Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) logo is seen at the company's headquarters in Paris, France, on Friday, May 28, 2010. Slovenia, along with Israel and Estonia, are joining the Paris-based organization of 31 of the world's most developed economies. Photographer: Antoine Antoniol/Bloomberg

site_title: Novartis in the lead to acquire cancer drug developer MorphoSys: sources
summary: Novartis is in advanced talks to acquire MorphoSys, a cancer drug developer, for 1.6 billion euros. The deal comes after MorphoSys missed key goals in clinical trials for its myelofibrosis drug Pelabresib, but still plans to apply for US and European approval in 2024. Novartis has outbid rival Incyte, and the deal's outcome is uncertain. MorphoSys' main revenue generator is its lymphoma drug Monjuvi, which it sells in a profit-sharing agreement with Incyte, generating US$92 million in 2023 sales.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company's logo is seen at the new cell and gene therapy factory of Swiss drugmaker Novartis in Stein, Switzerland, November 28, 2019. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Saudi Arabia to manufacture parts of Lockheed missile defence system
summary: Saudi Arabia has signed sub-contracts with US defense company Lockheed Martin to manufacture parts of its Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) missile defense system, enhancing manufacturing capabilities and transferring expertise to the country's defense industry. The deal was announced at the World Defence Show in Riyadh, amid rising tensions in the region, including US and British attacks on Iran-backed groups in Yemen and Iraq. The Biden administration has maintained support for Saudi Arabia's receipt of the Thaad system, approved in 2017 to counter ballistic missile threats.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The Airbus logo pictured at the company's headquarters in Blagnac near Toulouse, France, March 20, 2019.  REUTERS/Regis Duvignau/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Estee Lauder to cut jobs on skittish China demand
summary: Estee Lauder plans to cut 3-5% of its global workforce to shore up margins amid Chinese customers cutting back on luxury products, citing a "small reduction in market share" in the second quarter. The company expects incremental operating profit of $1.1-1.4 billion from 2025-2026, with charges of $500-700 million. This move comes as the company faces a sluggish luxury demand, with organic net sales in the Asia-Pacific region falling 7% and overall margins dipping 60 basis points.

images.alt_text: Estee Lauder makes about 36 per cent of its annual revenue from the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Asean property stocks: Positioning for falling interest rates in 2024
summary: Asean property stocks are poised for a recovery in 2024, driven by falling interest rates and improved sentiment among institutional investors. Singapore Reits are expected to perform better this year, with industrial Reits being favored due to stronger balance sheets and growth opportunities. In contrast, Singapore developers face a challenging outlook due to a potential downcycle in the housing market, while Thai developers will benefit from an ongoing recovery in visitor arrivals. Philippine property developers are expected to deliver double-digit growth in residential sales, driven by robust economic growth.

images.alt_text: Analysts say they do not view the recent profit warnings from property companies as potential red flags about their financial health.
While buying a new executive condominium home is a good way to get into private homeownership, such homes can be fairly unaffordable these days.

site_title: Indonesia economy grows 5.05% in 2023 amid falling exports, slowing consumption
summary: Indonesia's economy grew 5.05% in 2023, slightly above projections but lower than 5.3% in 2022. Weaker exports, driven by lower commodity prices, and slower consumption contributed to the slowdown. Household consumption, accounting for over half of GDP, grew 4.82%, while exports increased 1.32% and imports declined 1.65%. Economists warn of a continued slowdown in growth due to tightening monetary policy and weak commodity demand, with forecasts of 4.8-4.9% growth in 2024.

images.alt_text: Third-time candidate and current defence minister Prabowo Subianto (pictured) is ahead in opinion polls, widening the gap since choosing Joko Widodo’s eldest son Gibran Rakabuming Raka as his running mate last year.

site_title: Novo Nordisk parent to buy Catalent for US$11.5 billion to boost Wegovy supply
summary: Novo Holdings, parent of Novo Nordisk, agreed to buy contract drugmaker Catalent for $11.5 billion in an all-cash transaction. The deal values Catalent at $63.50 per share, a 16.5% premium to its last trading price. Catalent supplies the main syringes and injection pens for Novo Nordisk's weight-loss drug Wegovy. The acquisition is expected to expand Novo's filling capacity, with the deal also including the assumption of Catalent's debt.

site_title: Lufthansa ground staff to add to Germany's strike woes
summary: Ground staff at Lufthansa will go on strike on Feb 7, affecting over 100,000 passengers across Germany's major airports. The 25,000-staff walkout, lasting around 27 hours, seeks a 12.5% pay increase and one-off bonuses to combat inflation. Lufthansa had previously offered a 13% pay increase over three years, but the Verdi union deemed it "totally unacceptable." The strike comes amidst growing social unrest in Germany's transport sector, following recent walkouts by pilots, airport security staff, and train drivers.

images.alt_text: Union members march through the terminal, during a strike by airport security workers, at Frankfurt Airport in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 1, 2024. Verdi, Germany's main services union, called security workers at major airports to stage a one-day strike this week, threatening to bring chaos to flight traffic in Frankfurt and regional hubs. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Red Sea attacks raise freight charges, but still manageable for businesses: MTI
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong notes that the government's economic projections account for current Red Sea attacks, but businesses find the impact manageable. Shipping lines have re-routed vessels via the Cape of Good Hope, adding 10-15 days to transit, affecting imports of petrochemicals, speciality chemicals, and machinery. Despite this, the proportion of goods shipped from Europe to Singapore by sea is small, and overall import delays are manageable.

images.alt_text: The impact of the Red Sea attacks is feeding through to oil prices via higher transport costs, which is encouraging refiners to go local where they can.
Huthi attacks have prompted some shipping companies to detour around southern Africa to avoid the Red Sea, a vital route that normally carries about 12 per cent of global trade

site_title: Atos cancels 720 million euros rights offering ahead of debt wall
summary: Atos has cancelled its 720 million euros rights offering due to unapplicable conditions, amid pressure to negotiate a restructuring with creditors ahead of debt maturities. The company has 1.25 billion euros of bonds due by May 2025 and 2.4 billion euros of bank debt maturing next year. Shares plummeted 30% to a record low, and Atos has requested a court-appointed mediator to aid refinancing negotiations with banks. Talks with potential buyers, including EPEI and Airbus, continue.

images.alt_text: Atos’ big data and security unit  could help to speed up Airbus' digital transformation and enhance its defence and security portfolio.

site_title: Japan's top bank Mitsubishi UFJ says Q3 profit triples
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Finance Group, Japan's largest lender by assets, reported a tripled net profit of 370.64 billion yen (S$3.35 billion) for the October-December period, compared to 112.08 billion yen a year earlier. The bank maintained its annual profit forecast at 1.3 trillion yen, a fresh record. This follows a robust showing from its largest rivals, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group and Mizuho Financial Group, whose lending businesses benefited from increased growth investment by Japanese companies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Mizuho Financial Group logo is seen at the company's headquarters in Tokyo, Japan August 20, 2018. Picture taken August 20, 2018.  REUTERS/Toru Hana/File Photo/File Photo
The Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group headquarters building in Tokyo, Japan. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Swiss watchmaker says it's time to make luxury sustainable
summary: ID Geneve, a Swiss watchmaker, is pioneering a sustainable luxury watch brand using non-traditional materials such as vegetal leather, recycled stainless steel, and compostable packaging made from algae. The company, launched in 2020, has already gained attention with US actor Leonardo DiCaprio as an investor. ID Geneve's innovative approach to circular production has resonated with consumers seeking eco-friendly luxury products, and analysts predict the company may carve out a niche in the established industry.

images.alt_text: Swiss watch exports are boosted by sales in their largest market, the US, where they rise 35.1 per cent for the full year.
These watches from the collection will be on offer at Centurion New York.

site_title: Singapore to review F1 contracts, audit 2022 race in light of graft allegations against Iswaran
summary: Singapore will review its contract with the F1 Singapore Grand Prix and conduct an audit of the 2022 race following corruption allegations against former transport minister S Iswaran. The review will be led by the Ministry of Trade and Industry, while the audit will be conducted by the Singapore Tourism Board. Despite the review, the government remains committed to the F1 Singapore Grand Prix, with preparations for the 2024 race already underway. The contract review and audit are aimed at safeguarding Singapore's interests and ensuring transparency.

images.alt_text: Most of the offences former transport minister S Iswaran face involve Ong Beng Seng, who brought F1 to Singapore in 2008.
Former Transport Minister S Iswaran faces 27 charges in total, including two charges of corruption.
Tycoon Ong Beng Seng is alleged to have offered benefits worth over S$384,000 to former transport minister S Iswaran.

site_title: Malaysia property deals up 8.8% to RM142 billion in first three quarters of 2023
summary: Malaysia's property market saw a 8.8% increase in transactions worth RM142.5 billion in the first nine months of 2023, driven by robust tourism activities. The market's commercial real estate sector is expected to remain stable and optimistic in 2024, with a focus on industrial and logistics sub-sectors. A survey by Knight Frank Malaysia found that 68% of respondents believe foreign direct investment will be more favorable in 2024, driven by improved economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Kuala Lumpur commanded the highest rental growth for the high-rise home segment in Q4 last year, with an average monthly rental of RM1,975.

site_title: It’s time to celebrate the nanny state, not apologise for it
summary: The UK government should take a more active role in addressing public health issues, such as obesity, by implementing measures like banning fast-food ads before 9 pm, increasing taxes on sugary drinks and processed food, and launching a national exercise campaign. This approach is not about restricting individual freedom but about recognizing that people's choices can have unintended consequences on others, particularly when influenced by powerful corporations. By embracing the "nanny state," the government can improve lives, free individuals from the grip of big companies, and address the country's growing health crisis.

images.alt_text: The measures are part of the government’s response to its consultation on smoking and vaping, launched in October last year.
Meta employees making use of the games-room facilities in the company's Singapore office in May 2022.  Employers now routinely offer their staff perks such as free food, gym membership and flu  jabs.

site_title: Job worries sour mood for Chinese heading home for holidays
summary: Chinese workers are heading home for the Chinese New Year holidays with concerns about their jobs amidst a stuttering economy. A record 9 billion journeys are expected, but many are worried about their employers calling them back due to declining sales and profit margins. Factories are locked in a price war, with producer prices falling for 15 months, crushing profit margins and endangering workers' incomes and jobs. The economy grew 5.2% last year, but many feel it's shrinking, and unemployment and declining wages are becoming increasingly common.

images.alt_text: China has been funnelling financial resources into the manufacturing sector, rather than consumers, exacerbating overcapacity and deflation concerns, even in booming higher-end sectors, such as electric vehicles.
China’s economy is struggling to regain momentum, facing multiple challenges including persistent deflationary pressures, a prolonged housing downturn and mounting local government debt.
The People’s Bank of China has rarely made such a broad easing move so close to the break.

Outstanding PSL loans totalled 3.4022 trillion yuan at the end of January, compared with 3.2522 trillion yuan at end-December, the central bank says.
China will run a budget deficit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product in 2024.
The export index may have been affected by the Lunar New Year which will fall on Feb 10 this year, as factories and workers geared up for the pre-holiday shipment of goods.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 5)
summary: Singapore's government will review its contracts with the F1 Singapore Grand Prix to safeguard its interest amid corruption allegations against former transport minister S Iswaran. Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations Grace Fu stated that the government remains committed to the event. The review and audit of the 2022 race will be conducted to ensure transparency and accountability.

images.alt_text: Ferrari's Spanish driver Carlos Sainz Jr (bottom centre) drives in front of the field during the start of the Singapore Formula One Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on Sep 17, 2023.

site_title: OCBC’s SME sustainable financing loan book doubled to over S$7 billion in 2023
summary: OCBC has more than doubled its sustainable financing for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to over S$7 billion, up from S$3.3 billion in 2022. Over 1,200 SMEs, mostly in the built environment and clean transportation sectors, have taken up sustainable financing with the bank. OCBC aims to double sustainability-linked loans to regional enterprises, from 24 in 2023 to at least 48 by 2028.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of OCBC new signage / logo

site_title: Thai PM wants fiscal, monetary policies to work in tandem
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin has called for coordinated fiscal and monetary policy moves to address the country's economic woes, citing a fourth straight month of negative inflation in January. Thavisin, who is also finance minister, believes that if different policies are implemented, it would be difficult to solve the economic problems. He emphasized the need for fiscal and monetary policies to work in tandem to stabilize the economy.

images.alt_text: The core CPI increases 0.52 per cent year-on-year in January, versus a forecast rise of 0.57 per cent.

site_title: Global chip sales forecast to jump 13% this year after rocky 2023: industry group
summary: The Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA) forecasts a 13.1% jump in global chip sales to $595.3 billion in 2024, reversing a 8% decline in 2023. A surge in demand for artificial intelligence (AI) and automotive chips will drive the rebound. AI applications require large quantities of chips, including GPUs, memory, and networking processors. The industry expects a 6% growth in automotive chip sales, despite a slow start to the year. The forecast is based on industry trends and a strong market for AI-driven technologies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductor chips are seen on a printed circuit board in this illustration picture taken February 17, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China bets on open-source chips as US export controls mount
summary: China is investing in open-source RISC-V chips to reduce dependence on Western technology amid US export controls. The People's Liberation Army's Academy of Military Sciences has used RISC-V to develop high-performance chips for cloud computing and smart cars. Beijing's Science and Technology Commission sees RISC-V as a geopolitically neutral alternative, with Chinese tech giants Alibaba and Huawei investing heavily in the standard. While RISC-V has yet to break the dominance of x86 and Arm, its low cost, ease of customization, and energy efficiency make it attractive to some chipmakers.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration began imposing tariffs aimed at curbing imports of Chinese goods in early 2018, eventually escalating to duties on goods ranging from seafood to chemicals by the fall of that year.

US officials have long warned that China poses a particular threat in that area, and the new measures could affect a wide array of industries.
Many US companies have been trying to reduce their reliance on China in recent years as the US-China tech battle ramps up and regulators limit trade in sensitive technologies like chip making.

site_title: Singapore shares sink on Monday after Powell signals slower-than-expected rate cuts; STI down 1.4%
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.4% on Monday after US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell signaled slower-than-expected rate cuts, citing a need for data on inflation moving sustainably below 2%. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 3,134.29, with losers outnumbering gainers 351 to 241. Regional indices also fell, except for Japan's Nikkei 225, which rose 0.5%.

images.alt_text: All three major US stock indexes are on track for their fourth consecutive weekly gains.

site_title: AI chip demand forces Huawei to slow smartphone production: sources
summary: Huawei is slowing smartphone production for its premium Mate 60 phones due to soaring demand for its artificial intelligence (AI) chips, which are in high demand amid a Sino-US technological standoff. The company is prioritizing production of its Ascend AI chips, which are considered the most competitive non-Nvidia AI chip available in China. This move comes as Huawei tops Chinese smartphone sales for the first time in over three years, despite US sanctions that have crippled its smartphone unit since 2019.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has in recent weeks been pricing orders for H20 distributors in China in a range of US$12,000 to US$15,000 per card.
The complaint follows infringement lawsuits filed by Huawei against Netgear in Germany and China.
The company expects 2023 revenue to exceed 700 billion yuan, amounting to 9 per cent year-on-year growth, according to an internal message last month.
The company spent more than US$13 million lobbying in the past ten years.
Huawei has since sunk billions into chip research and stockpiling in past years, while also building a domestic network of suppliers and manufacturing partners, in some cases with government backing.

site_title: Thai former PM hopeful hit with more legal trouble
summary: Thai former Prime Minister hopeful Pita Limjaroenrat was sentenced to a four-month suspended prison term and a fine of 11,200 baht for leading an unlawful 2019 rally. The ruling adds to the legal troubles of the opposition Move Forward Party, which faces potential dissolution and executive bans after a Constitutional Court ruled the party undermined the monarchy and national security. The party's liberal agenda and popularity among young voters pose a threat to the status quo in Thailand, and its attempts to form a government were blocked by the appointed senate.

images.alt_text: Move Forward Party leader and prime ministerial candidate, Pita Limjaroenrat, celebrate the party's election results in Bangkok, Thailand, May 15, 2023. REUTERS/Jorge Silva

Thai politician Pita Limjaroenrat attends the TIME 100 Next Gala in New York City on October 24, 2023. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: QAF expects ‘significant improvement’ in net profit for H2 2023
summary: QAF expects a "significant improvement" in its net profit for the second half of 2023, driven by better business performance and improved foreign exchange movements. The company's full-year result is also expected to see the same improvement, despite a non-cash impairment of S$9.2 million on a joint venture investment and exceptional insurance claims. This marks a reversal from a 66.2% decline in net profit in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: OCBC led the share buyback consideration tally, buying back 1.2 million shares at an average price of S$12.67 per share.
Singapore Exchange Centre at 2 Shenton Way, taken on 15 Feb 2019.
Between Aug 18 and Aug 23, JEP Holdings executive chairman and CEO Andy Luong acquired 2,021,900 shares at an average price of S$0.302 per share.
QAF says it was impacted by higher key raw material commodity, electricity and labour costs.
Sponge and dough: The busy art of loaving at Gardenia STEP 4 - End of the Line- Freshly baked loafs are mechanically packaged in polybags and are now ready to be delivered to retail outlets.

site_title: Nokia signs 5G patent deal with China's Vivo
summary: Nokia has signed a multi-year 5G patent licence agreement with Chinese smartphone vendor Vivo, resolving all pending patent litigation between the parties. The deal, Nokia's 6th major smartphone licensing agreement in 13 months, follows previous deals with Apple, Samsung, OPPO, Honor, and Huawei. The agreement is expected to generate significant operating profit for Nokia Technologies, with a minimum of 1.4 billion euros (S$2 billion) in 2024, according to the company's previous statement.

site_title: Airbus in talks with Saudi Arabia for military air tanker order
summary: Airbus is in talks with Saudi Arabia to sell more A330 tanker military planes as the nation seeks to boost its air force capabilities. The talks are led by Airbus's 49% joint venture with Saudi Arabian Military Industries. Saudi Arabia already owns six A330 MRTTs and is considering purchasing the A400M military transport aircraft. The country is also poised to order more Eurofighter jets and has resumed talks with the US about forging closer defense ties. This comes as Saudi Arabia aims to diversify its economy and reduce its dependence on oil.

images.alt_text: Tata and Airbus are already cooperating to make the C-295 transport aircraft in Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s home state of Gujarat.

site_title: Eurozone economy showing some signs of recovery
summary: The eurozone economy showed signs of recovery in January, with the composite PMI rising to 47.9, its best reading since July. Rising inflationary pressures bolstered the European Central Bank's case for keeping interest rates at record highs. The services sector saw a dip in PMI to 48.4, but optimism about the year ahead was at an eight-month high, with firms increasing headcount at the fastest rate since September. The downturn in factory activity eased for a third month.

images.alt_text: Inflation remains above the European Central Bank’s 2 per cent target, but well below the peak of 10.6 per cent recorded in October 2022 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent energy prices soaring.
HCOB’s final eurozone manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI),  climbed to 46.6 in January from December’s 44.4.

site_title: Eurozone investor morale rises in February: survey
summary: Eurozone investor morale rose to -12.9 points in February, its highest level since April, after four consecutive monthly improvements. This surpasses analysts' estimated reading of -15. However, economic weakness in Germany, the region's largest economy, casts doubt on the recovery. Sentix's index for the eurozone showed an improvement in expectations and current situation, with the expectations index rising to -5.5 points and the current situation index rising to -20 points. Despite this, Germany's economic crisis remains a concern, making it too early to declare a full recovery.

images.alt_text: HCOB’s composite PMI for the bloc, compiled by S&P Global, rose to 47.9 in January from December’s 47.6, matching a preliminary estimate.
Inflation remains above the European Central Bank’s 2 per cent target, but well below the peak of 10.6 per cent recorded in October 2022 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent energy prices soaring.
HCOB’s final eurozone manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI),  climbed to 46.6 in January from December’s 44.4.
The 20 countries that share the euro barely avoided an outright recession in the final quarter of last year.

site_title: Banker extraordinaire and takeover artist: Milestones from Wee Cho Yaw’s career
summary: Singapore's prominent banking personality Wee Cho Yaw, who led United Overseas Bank (UOB) for over 60 years, died at 95. Wee built UOB into a domestic and regional financial powerhouse, expanding its network from 75 to over 500 branches globally and assets from S$2.8 billion to S$253 billion. He made headlines for high-profile M&A deals, including the S$10 billion acquisition of OUB in 2001, and was named Singapore's Businessman of the Year twice. Wee stepped down as CEO in 2007 and as chairman in 2013, passing the baton to his son Wee Ee Cheong.

images.alt_text: Wee Cho Yaw, who played a pivotal role in the growth of UOB, has passed away at the age of 95.
PM Lee Hsien Loong with Wee Cho Yaw's  wife Chuang Yong Eng at the late banker's wake on Sunday (Feb 4).

site_title: Gold inches lower as traders rethink early rate cut bets
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $2,036.96 per ounce on Monday, following a strong US jobs report that dashed hopes for early interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve. The US dollar and Treasury yields rose, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. Traders are now betting on fewer interest rate cuts in 2024, reducing gold's appeal. Spot silver and platinum also fell, while palladium dropped 0.8%.

images.alt_text: US gold futures were flat at US$2,070.30 per ounce.

site_title: China property developers Sunac, Cifi say projects get local government support
summary: Chinese property developers Sunac and Cifi Holdings reported that over 90 and 18 of their projects, respectively, have been added to local government whitelists, making them eligible for loans. This move aims to inject liquidity into the crisis-hit sector. More than 30 projects from Country Garden, which defaulted on its offshore debt last year, have also been whitelisted. The "project whitelist" mechanism, launched by 35 cities, is expected to ease cash flow pressure for developers and support "home delivery" in various cities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of property developer Sunac is seen outside a residential compound in Beijing, China September 19, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: How much should you invest in private equity, private debt, hedge funds?
summary: Yale's endowment achieved an annualized return of 13.7% from 1985 to 2021, growing from $1 billion to over $40 billion. To replicate this return, investors need to carefully consider their life goals, time horizon, expected return, and liquidity tolerance when mapping out their asset allocation. Sophisticated investors are shifting towards less liquid, higher-cost asset classes, while others may be missing out on potential returns. A diversified asset allocation is key to achieving such high returns, but individual goals and circumstances should be taken into account.

images.alt_text: hand, finger, keep

site_title: Shanghai INE to expand trading limits for shipping, oil and copper contracts
summary: SHANGHAI International Energy Exchange (INE) has announced plans to expand trading limits and adjust margin requirements for its listed products, including European container shipping, oil, copper, and rubber contracts. The trading band for the European container shipping index will be widened to 25% from 20%, while the margin ratio will be raised to 25% from 22%. The move aims to increase market liquidity and efficiency.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 0.4% in December, reversing November’s gain
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 0.4% year-on-year in December, reversing the 2.4% gain in November. Total sales reached S$4.7 billion, with online sales accounting for 13.1% of this, down from 15.3% in November. Most industries recorded declines, with 10 out of 14 categories experiencing year-on-year declines. Factors contributing to the reversal include higher outbound travel, front-loaded purchases, and prudence in consumer discretionary spending.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s retail sales up 2.5% in November, reversing October’s fall

site_title: Corporates make their moves
summary: Grab's proposed commitments to address concerns over its potential monopolistic powers on Trans-cab drivers have been rejected by Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS), citing insufficient measures to address a "permanent change in market structure". Meanwhile, GoTo announced the completion of its 75.01% stake sale in Tokopedia to TikTok, and the Indonesian tech conglomerate reported positive adjusted Ebitda for the fourth quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: VCs, too, have raised money for their funds, but it isn’t all cheery there, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
The rise of fintech in the region has partly been driven by the opportunity to serve the "underbanked" population, writes Garage correspondent Claudia Chong.
Lazada's recent layoffs suggest its plans to IPO may not be on the cards any time soon, writes Garage journalist Daphne Yow.

According to impacted staff, the layoffs were part of a “change of direction” by Lazada, with the former employees noting that such a move came as no surprise, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.
Funding taps appear to be opening up again, writes Garage correspondent Benjamin Cher.

site_title: Retrenchment rules must be kept flexible for businesses while protecting workers: Tan See Leng
summary: Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng emphasized the need to balance flexibility for businesses with protection for workers during retrenchments. Despite calls for stronger action, around 9 in 10 eligible employees received retrenchment benefits from 2019 to 2023. Tan defended Singapore's approach, citing its success in facilitating discussions between companies and unions, such as with Lazada after its initial lapse. He stressed the importance of preserving flexibility for businesses to create and sustain good jobs for Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Lazada and the FDAWU have settled on a better support package and training fund for laid off union members.

site_title: Malaysia’s Anwar urges calm after Najib’s 1MDB jail term halved
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim urged calm amid criticism over former leader Najib Razak's 12-year prison sentence being halved and fines slashed for crimes related to 1MDB. Anwar stated that the royal leniency granted to Najib was within the Federal Constitution's powers, which empowers Malay rulers to pardon convicts. This decision was made by the Pardons Board, chaired by Malaysia's previous king. Anwar defended his role, saying he could not be blamed for the royal decision, and that the constitution is the jurisdiction provided for since independence.

site_title: Real estate veteran Chris Fossick steps down from top JLL role, joins board of UK firm Native Land
summary: Real estate veteran Chris Fossick has stepped down as JLL's chief executive of JLL South-east Asia and joined UK firm Native Land as a non-executive director. Fossick will support Native Land in Asia, focusing on building relationships and the brand in the region. Native Land, a property development and investment company, has co-invested in properties with several major companies, including Singapore's Temasek and Malaysia's Amcorp Properties Berhad.

images.alt_text: JLL names Singapore, Thailand country heads as it eyes regional growth
JLL hires ex-CBRE veteran as head of valuation and advisory services for S-E Asia

site_title: China’s tumbling prices push some exporters to the brink
summary: China's export sector is facing a crisis, with 15 consecutive months of deflationary pressure threatening the survival of smaller exporters. Factory owners, like Kris Lin, are forced to cut production and staff due to shrinking orders, while profit margins have fallen to unsustainable levels. Policymakers must now focus on stimulating household consumption to meet the country's growth target, as interest rates abroad and rising trade protectionism squeeze demand. Experts warn of a vicious cycle of price cuts, staff salary reductions, and reduced consumer spending, with China's central bank struggling to find a solution.

images.alt_text: China’s economy is struggling to regain momentum, facing multiple challenges including persistent deflationary pressures, a prolonged housing downturn and mounting local government debt.
FILE PHOTO: Buildings are seen in Beijing, July 3, 2013. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
China will run a budget deficit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product in 2024.
The export index may have been affected by the Lunar New Year which will fall on Feb 10 this year, as factories and workers geared up for the pre-holiday shipment of goods.

site_title: UniCredit boosts investor returns as profit triples estimates
summary: UniCredit, Italy's second-largest lender, has posted a stated net income of about 2.81 billion euros in the final quarter of last year, nearly tripling analyst forecasts. The bank's profit beat estimates, allowing it to boost shareholder returns to 8.6 billion euros. UniCredit will distribute 100% of adjusted net profit for 2023, meeting its goal a year ahead of schedule. CEO Andrea Orcel attributes the success to rising European interest rates and efficiency drives. The bank expects an adjusted full-year profit in line with 2023 and plans to distribute at least 90% of its net adjusted profit starting this year.

site_title: American greatness and decline
summary: US President Donald Trump's promise to "Make America Great Again" is based on a flawed premise, as America has never had the power it is perceived to have. Despite its resources, the US has often failed to achieve its goals, as seen in events like the Soviet repression of the 1956 Hungarian revolt and the failed Suez invasion. Populist nationalism, rather than the rise of China, poses a greater threat to US power, and Trump's remedies may exacerbate this issue.

images.alt_text: America’s liberal political culture made a huge difference to the liberal international order that has existed since WWII.
Chinese President Xi Jinping meeting with then US Vice President Joe Biden in Beijing, Dec 2013. On balance, the Biden team is correct about being unable to force fundamental changes in China.

A virtual meeting between United States President Joe Biden and China President  Xi Jinping in November 2021. If America avoids ideological demonisation, shuns misleading Cold War analogies, and maintains its alliances, it can successfully manage the China challenge.
An Electric Multiple Unit high-speed train for a rail link project, part of China's Belt and Road Initiative, at the Tegalluar train depot in Bandung, West Java, Indonesia, October 2022.
American democracy and soft power

site_title: Asia: Markets take a hit as blockbuster US jobs batter rate cut hopes
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Monday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai extending a sell-off fueled by growing concerns over the Chinese economy. The US jobs report, which showed a robust labor market and world's largest economy, dashed hopes for a March interest rate cut. Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's comments, citing a need for more data, further reduced expectations for a rate cut, with the chances now at 20%. Most Asian markets fell, while Tokyo rose as the dollar rallied against the yen.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index sank 1.27 per cent, or 196.70 points, to 15,336.86 on Monday morning.

site_title: UK jobless rate in late-2023 much lower than earlier estimates
summary: The UK's unemployment rate has been revised downward, from 4.2% to 3.9% in the three months to November, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). This change may influence the Bank of England's decision on interest rates, as it considers whether inflation pressures have cooled enough to warrant a rate cut. The ONS also reported an inactivity rate of 21.9% and a re-weighted employment rate of 75.0%. The revised estimates use updated population data and are part of the ONS's improved Labour Force Survey, set to launch later this year.

images.alt_text: Huw Pill, chief European economist at Goldman Sachs Group Inc., Goldman Sachs, Frankfurt, 25.06.2015 speaks during a panel session at the IIF Europe Summit in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 25, 2015. If Greece were to leave the euro it "wouldn't be the end of the euro zone" although it would present a tough test for the region, said Commerzbank AG Chief Executive Officer Martin Blessing. Photographer: Martin Leissl/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Huw Pill

site_title: Foxconn reiterates guidance for Q1 revenue drop off high base
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, reiterated that it expects a year-over-year drop in first-quarter revenue due to a high base from the previous quarter. The company's overall operations are entering the traditional off-peak season, with seasonal performance expected to be similar to the past three years. Revenue last month reached NT$522.1 billion, up 13.5% month-over-month but down 20.9% year-over-year. Foxconn chairman Liu Young-way expects the company's business to be "slightly better" this year but faces a shortage of AI chip supplies.

images.alt_text: Foxconn chairman Liu Young-way says that production capacity for chips for servers is limited, even with strong demand.
Foxconn says revenue last month reaches NT$460.1 billion (S$19.8 billion), which is better than expected even though that is down 26.9 per cent year on year.
Foxconn has rapidly expanded its presence in India over the past year by investing heavily in manufacturing facilities in the south of the country.

site_title: Japan’s January service activity surges on strong demand, weak yen
summary: Japan's service sector activity surged in January, expanding at its strongest pace since September, driven by robust demand and a weak yen. The final au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers' index (PMI) rose to 53.1, marking the 17th consecutive month of growth. This helped offset weak global demand and a modest decline in manufacturing activity. Solid demand and the weak currency contributed to a four-month high in new business growth, while input price inflation rose to a three-month high due to high fuel and labor costs.

images.alt_text: Manufacturers’ confidence remained strong, staying above the series average led by hopes for improved demand in markets such as semiconductors, though optimism slightly dipped from December
The return to growth in production will offer support for the economy, pointing to the likelihood that it rebounded in the fourth quarter after a sharp contraction in summer.
The Bank of Japan is watching the labour market closely as it seeks evidence of a virtuous cycle linking rising wages with demand-led price gains.

site_title: South Korean court acquits Samsung chief over 2015 merger case
summary: A South Korean court has acquitted Samsung Electronics chief Lee Jae-yong of crimes linked to a 2015 merger, ruling that he did not intend to harm shareholders. The court found that the merger was not solely for succession purposes, but rather to solidify Lee's control. Lee was cleared of charges including stock price rigging, breach of trust, and accounting fraud. The verdict comes after over 100 hearings and nearly three years of deliberation, following Lee's previous 18-month jail sentence for a separate conviction.

images.alt_text: Jay Y Lee has denied any wrongdoing.

site_title: China’s Jan services activity expands at slower pace: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector expanded at a slower pace in January, with the Caixin/S&P Global services PMI falling to 52.7 from 52.9 in December, below the 50-mark that separates expansion from contraction. The sector's business confidence for the year ahead was the lowest in three months, and new orders declined. The economy faces multiple challenges, including deflationary pressures, a housing downturn, and mounting local government debt, with the government drawing on government debt to fund infrastructure to boost growth.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China has rarely made such a broad easing move so close to the break.

In a sign of how exasperated some investors have become, thousands flocked to a social media account of the US embassy in Beijing to vent their frustrations over the economy and slumping share prices.

The Trump administration began imposing tariffs aimed at curbing imports of Chinese goods in early 2018, eventually escalating to duties on goods ranging from seafood to chemicals by the fall of that year.
The flows are part of a broader shift away from China as domestic investors lose faith in the local share market.

site_title: IndiGo’s profit surges 53% as India air travel demand grows
summary: IndiGo, India's largest airline, reported a 53% surge in profit to 30 billion rupees (S$488 million) in the third quarter, exceeding estimates. Revenue rose 30% to 194.5 billion rupees, driven by a 26.8% increase in seat capacity. The airline is expanding its capacity to capture a larger share of the world's fastest-growing aviation market, where it currently holds 62% market share. Despite a capacity shortage, IndiGo aims to increase seat capacity by 12% in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: “This is just the beginning, there’s more going forward. With the growth of India (and) the growth of the Indian aviation market ... this is the right time for us to place this order,” said IndiGo's chief executive Pieter Elbers.

site_title: Taylor Swift wins Album of the Year Grammy, breaking record
summary: Taylor Swift won the Grammy Award for Album of the Year for her album "Midnights," breaking the record for the most Album of the Year wins by any artist with her fourth win. Swift also won the award for Best Pop Vocal Album. Other notable winners included Billie Eilish for Song of the Year and Miley Cyrus for Record of the Year. The ceremony also honored late musicians and industry executives, with performances by Joni Mitchell and Stevie Wonder. The event marked a milestone for women in music, with several female artists winning major awards, including Swift, Eilish, and Cyrus.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift accepts the award for Album of the Year for Midnights during the 66th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles, California, U.S., February 4, 2024. REUTERS/Mike Blake

site_title: Thai inflation lowest in nearly three years, but central bank may hold rates
summary: Thailand's annual headline consumer inflation rate fell to its lowest in 35 months in January, reaching 1.11%, driven by government energy subsidies, lower food prices, and a high base effect. The core CPI, which excludes fresh food and energy, rose 0.52% year-on-year. Despite lower inflation, the Bank of Thailand is expected to hold its policy rate steady at 2.5% due to concerns about negative headline inflation not being a concern or deflation. The commerce ministry predicts headline CPI will fall 0.7% year-on-year in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Street vendors sell food ahead of Chinese New Year celebrations in Chinatown, Bangkok, Thailand, on Saturday, Feb. 3, 2024. Thailand is scheduled to release consumer price index (CPI) figures on Feb. 5. Photographer: Andre Malerba/Bloomberg

site_title: Biden robocall: Audio deepfake fuels election disinformation fears
summary: US regulators consider making AI-generated robocalls illegal after a fake Joe Biden call sparked alarm over audio deepfakes, potentially fueling election disinformation. The robocall, digitally spoofing Biden's voice, urged New Hampshire residents not to cast ballots in the Democratic primary. Disinformation researchers fear widespread misuse of AI-powered applications in the pivotal election year, citing proliferating voice cloning tools and the ease of creating and disseminating fake audio content. Experts recommend building audio watermarks and digital signatures into tools, as well as regulation to prevent misuse.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration began imposing tariffs aimed at curbing imports of Chinese goods in early 2018, eventually escalating to duties on goods ranging from seafood to chemicals by the fall of that year.
Grocery giants Walmart, Kroger and Albertsons are booking 20-plus per cent gross profit margins, roughly in line with where they were before the Covid-19 pandemic spiked inflation.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending rose 0.9 per cent.
