Republican presidential hopeful and former UN ambassador Nikki Haley speaks at a rally on Jan 28, 2024 in Conway, South Carolina.
China’s development of AI and other next-generation technologies is a top concern for the administration, which sees Beijing as its primary global strategic competitor.

site_title: Boycott boost: Malaysian coffee chains gain as locals shun US brands over Gaza war
summary: Malaysian coffee chains have seen a surge in sales following a nationwide boycott of international brands perceived as supporting Israel in its war against Hamas. Local brands such as Gigi Coffee, ZUS Coffee, and Eight Ounce Coffee have gained popularity, with some outlets experiencing a 15-30% increase in sales. Consumers, many of whom are Muslim-majority, have been protesting against US brands like Starbucks, KFC, and McDonald's, opting instead for domestic brands that align with their values. This shift is seen as a significant boost to local coffee chains, with some reporting steady growth since the boycott began in October 2023.

images.alt_text: India – famous as a tea producer – is also the world’s eighth-largest coffee grower, mainly churning out the robusta beans used to make instant coffee.
Local prices are up more than 40 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Indonesia presidential front-runner draws fire in final debate
summary: Indonesia's presidential front-runner Prabowo Subianto faced criticism in his final debate, with opponents questioning his stance on women's rights and voter intelligence. Subianto, who is ahead in opinion polls, suggested people wanting free internet instead of free lunches are not intelligent, but later clarified his stance. Former Jakarta governor Anies Baswedan criticized the government for increasing social aid before the election. The debate comes ahead of the Feb 14 vote to determine the successor to President Joko Widodo, who is barred from running again.

images.alt_text: Thousands of Indonesians at an election campaign rally in South Sulawesi on Jan 17, 2024. The three presidential candidates have each promised to roll out many policies to improve the lives of the people if they are successful at the Feb 14 poll.

Three vice presidential candidates, Muhaimin Iskandar (L), Gibran Rakabuming Raka (C) and Mahfud MD take part in the vice presidential election debate at the Jakarta Convention Center in Jakarta on December 22, 2023.

Bank Indonesia targets inflation within a range of 1.5 to 3.5 per cent this year.

site_title: Hyundai mulls US$3 billion India IPO: sources
summary: Hyundai Motor India is reportedly exploring an initial public offering (IPO) that could value the company at $25-$30 billion. The IPO, which could raise at least $3 billion, is part of the company's plan to "unlock value" for its Indian business. Hyundai Motor India, the Indian arm of South Korea's Hyundai Motor, has been investing $2.45 billion in the country for its electrification push. The company has a 15% share of the Indian car market and competes with Maruti Suzuki and Tata Motors.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen Group’s focus on EVs comes down to their favourable taxation structure in India.
Chinese mainstream electric vehicle (EV) brand BYD went from 12th to fifth in passenger car registrations for 2023.
Honda will use fuel cells in a version of its popular CR-V sport utility vehicle due to be unveiled in March.
Hyundai Motor has reported a net profit of 2.2 trillion won for the October to December period versus a profit of 1.7 trillion won a year earlier.

site_title: South Korea watchdog warns financial firms against careless risk management
summary: South Korea's financial watchdog has warned financial firms against careless risk management, citing practices such as investing in real estate projects without proper risk assessment and making excessive earnings through incomplete sales of equity-linked securities. Governor Lee Bok Hyun stated that authorities will not tolerate practices that pass on risks to consumers and society, and firms that fail to make proper provisions for losses could face market expulsion and severe punishments. The regulator will prioritize household debt management, supervision of short sales of stocks and virtual assets, and cracking down on financial crimes.

site_title: China set to skirt Chinese New Year cash crunch on PBOC injection
summary: China is set to inject 1 trillion yuan ($189 billion) into the financial system ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday, reducing the likelihood of a cash squeeze and alleviating concerns about liquidity. The move is seen as a broad easing measure, with the central bank aiming to bolster the economy and encourage spending. Despite this, market sentiment remains cautious, and policymakers may face challenges in repairing confidence amid a stock-market slump.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Buildings are seen in Beijing, July 3, 2013. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
China will run a budget deficit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product in 2024.
The export index may have been affected by the Lunar New Year which will fall on Feb 10 this year, as factories and workers geared up for the pre-holiday shipment of goods.
China will not release its 2024 growth target till March, but policy insiders expect Beijing to maintain a similar growth target to last year of around 5 per cent.

site_title: Rare earths prices seen rebounding in second half of 2024: analysts
summary: Rare earth prices are expected to rebound in the second half of 2024 due to increasing demand from electric vehicles and wind power, and China's planned reduction in output quotas. After surging in 2022 and plummeting in 2023, prices have likely bottomed out, with neodymium-praseodymium oxide prices near production cost levels. A global deficit of 800 metric tons is predicted for 2024, driven by growing electric vehicle sales and wind turbine production. China's quotas are expected to increase at a slower rate this year, around 10-15%.

images.alt_text: Lynas has been upgrading its Malaysian processing facilities to increase separation capacity to 10,500 tonnes per year for neodymium and praseodymium, used in magnets in sectors from electrified transport to defence.

While it’s unclear what materials, if any, can be exploited, the claims come as Washington seeks to boost access to so-called critical minerals that are necessary for electric vehicle batteries and renewable energy projects.
China put technology for making rare-earth metals and rare-earth magnets on a list of items cannot be transfered overseas.
China, the world’s largest producer and consumer of rare earths, sets its third batch of quotas for rare earth smelting and separation at 13,850 tonnes.

site_title: China EV drive into Thailand galvanised by smog and subsidies
summary: Thailand is experiencing a surge in electric vehicle (EV) imports from China, driven by the country's air pollution crisis and government subsidies. The Thai government has made vehicle electrification a key goal, offering subsidies and incentives to encourage local production. Chinese carmakers, including BYD, SAIC, and Great Wall Motor, are taking advantage of the opportunities, with several establishing production facilities in Thailand. The move is seen as a way to upgrade local EV capacity, reduce reliance on imports, and skirt US and European export restrictions on Chinese technology. However, the influx of Chinese EVs may lead to a price war with established Japanese brands, which dominate the Southeast Asian market.

images.alt_text: Establishing lithium mines would put Thailand in a unique position compared to other major producers because it is also developing an EV production industry.

site_title: Hong Lai Huat to exit agricultural business in proposed US$37.5 million disposal
summary: Hong Lai Huat plans to sell two loss-making subsidiaries in Cambodia for US$37.5 million, marking its exit from the agricultural business. One subsidiary, owning 509.54 hectares of land, will be sold for US$1.5 million. The group's agricultural business has never been profitable since its inception in 2008. The sale is part of the property developer's efforts to restructure and focus on other business ventures.

images.alt_text: Hong Lai Huat to dual-list on Frankfurt bourse

Hong Lai Huat enters JV to explore, mine mineral resources in Cambodia

Hong Lai Huat Group unit disposes Singapore farm resort business to focus on Cambodia operations

site_title: Boeing needs to fix faulty rivet holes on 50 undelivered 737s
summary: Boeing must fix faulty rivet holes on 50 undelivered 737 jets, following a quality-control issue discovered at a supplier. The defect, which affects the plane's fuselage, could delay deliveries and has raised concerns about Boeing's manufacturing processes. The company's CEO, Stan Deal, stated that the issue is not an immediate safety concern, but the repairs will improve overall quality and stability. The incident follows a series of manufacturing lapses, including a near-catastrophic panel blowout on an Alaska Airlines 737 Max last month.

images.alt_text: “We will not rush the system, and we will take our time to do it right,” says Dave Calhoun in a letter to employees.
United is a leading operator of the MAX 9, which was partially grounded for three weeks following the blowout.
Ryanair says it will happily add 737 MAX 10 jets to its fleet in 2026, a year earlier than scheduled, should unhappy customers delay or cancel their orders.
China’s green light is a boost to the US planemaker, which has been hit by the fallout from a mid-air blowout of a cabin panel on a 737 MAX 9 jet operated by Alaska Airlines.

site_title: Canada extends ban on home purchases by foreigners to 2026
summary: Canada has extended its ban on foreign home purchases by two years, until January 1, 2027, as the housing market begins to show signs of a rebound. The ban, introduced in 2022, aims to prevent non-Canadians from buying residential real estate, which is seen as a speculative financial asset class. The government has carved out exemptions for foreign students and those on work permits, but the measure is intended to maintain affordability in cities such as Toronto and Vancouver.

images.alt_text: The number of foreign students in Canada has tripled in a decade to more than one million in 2023.
Receipts for retailers jump 0.8 per cent in December, the biggest increase since April.
The number of homes trading hands rises 8.7 per cent from the previous month – the first gain since June.

site_title: China tightens rules on polluters before carbon market expansion
summary: China has tightened rules for industrial polluters participating in its national carbon market, including larger fines for entities found to be falsifying data on emissions reductions. The regulations, set to come into force in May, give greater powers to the Ministry of Ecology and Environment and are aimed at reducing the supply of free allowances. The move is part of China's efforts to meet President Xi Jinping's pledge to hit net zero by 2060 and cover 70% of the nation's emissions by 2030. Emission allowance prices are expected to rise this year due to the tighter regulations.

While chewing coca leaves, Colombian Indigenous Fabio Valencia consults the jungle and his ancestors about a lawsuit against a company's green imposture. He denounces million-dollar transactions in exchange for supposed environmental services without the authorization of the community. Very far from the COP28 in Dubai, where carbon credits are discussed as a solution to the climate crisis, Valencia complains: the sales of these "green" bonds to polluting companies that aspire to offset the use of fossil fuels "are worse" for indigenous traditions than mining and oil exploitation. Climate Impact X chief executive officer Mikkel Larsen said COP28 was as a pivotal moment for carbon markets, and there was clear recognition of the markets’ necessity if the world was to make a “material dent” in climate change.

site_title: New York to host 2026 World Cup final
summary: The 2026 FIFA World Cup final will be held at MetLife Stadium in New York/New Jersey on July 19, with the US, Canada, and Mexico co-hosting the tournament. The stadium, which has previously hosted the 2016 Copa America final, will host 16 games, with the majority being held in the US. The competition will feature 48 teams, an expansion from the previous 32, and will kick off with the opening game at Mexico City's Azteca Stadium on June 11.

Real Madrid's Joselu has scored in his last two games against Atletico Madrid, and he will be hoping to continue that hot streak this weekend.

site_title: Most UK firms need to hike prices further after energy crisis
summary: Most UK firms plan to raise prices in the next two years due to high energy bills, with 81% of companies expecting to increase prices, according to a PricewaterhouseCoopers survey. Energy prices remain volatile and are twice as expensive as they were three years ago, forcing businesses to continue suffering from the effects of volatile prices. The Bank of England is watching for signs of domestically generated inflation and monitoring how companies pass on rising costs to customers.

site_title: Japanese capital pours into South-east Asia, seeking growth
summary: Japanese investors are pouring into South-east Asia, drawn by the region's favourable demographics and growing appetite for financing. Major banks such as Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Life have invested heavily in the region, with a focus on Indonesia and Singapore. The low cost of funds in Japan, due to negative interest rates, gives Japanese financial institutions an edge over international competitors. As the region's fintech landscape continues to evolve, venture capital firms are seeing increased interest from Japanese tech companies looking to gain a foothold. However, navigating the region's complex regulatory landscape and local market nuances remains a challenge for Japanese investors.

images.alt_text: Gregory Van, co-founder and chief executive officer of Endowus says that the fintech will hone in on personalisation as its next stage or growth.
MUFG considers Indonesia to be particularly important because it boasts the largest gross domestic product in South-east Asia, with high growth expected in future.
The transactions, subject to regulatory approvals in Japan and Singapore, are expected to complete in Q1 of 2024.

site_title: American consumers to forge ahead through credit strains and layoff threats
summary: US consumers remain resilient despite mounting credit-card bills and layoff threats, with over half saying spending will stay strong or increase in 2024. A Bloomberg Markets Live (MLIV) Pulse survey found that 63% of respondents plan to continue spending on experiences like travel and concerts. However, some 45% expect a slowdown, citing changing shopping patterns and debt repayment issues. Economists warn that credit card delinquency rates are above pre-pandemic levels, with nearly 3.2% of card balances past due.

images.alt_text: Factory orders gain 0.2 per cent after rebounding 2.6 per cent in November, the Commerce Department’s Census Bureau says.
The University of Michigan’s final sentiment index for the month rises 9.3 points from December to 79.
Employment gains remain well above the roughly 100,000 jobs per month needed to keep up with growth in the working age population.
The Commerce Department says that construction spending rose 0.9 per cent.

site_title: CapitaLand’s The Work Project ties up with Dexus to expand in Australia flex-office sector
summary: CapitaLand's flexible-working space operator, The Work Project (TWP), has partnered with Australian property giant Dexus to form a 50:50 joint venture, The Work Project Sydney. This venture will represent 14,000 sq m of flex space across Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, and Perth, with both TWP and Dexus retaining their brands. The joint venture aims to capitalize on Australia's growing premium flex co-working market, with TWP viewing it as a "mature flex market with encouraging growth potential".

images.alt_text: Since WeWork’s bankruptcy filing, TEC has been approached by 17 WeWork landlords across TEC’s 33 markets,  says founder and chief executive officer Paul Salnikow. TEC operates eight centres in Singapore

Singapore office landlords embrace flexibility and tech as they spruce up properties

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks shares plunge 1.27% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.27% at the open on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 196.70 points to 15,336.86. The decline was attributed to Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's warning that interest rates are unlikely to be cut in March and data showing a forecast-busting jump in US jobs creation. This is the second consecutive day of losses for Hong Kong stocks.

site_title: SRS contributions are great for tax savings but may not be for everyone
summary: Singapore's Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) can help lower personal income tax bills, but it may not be suitable for everyone. The maximum yearly contribution eligible for tax relief is S$15,300 for Singaporeans and permanent residents, and S$35,700 for foreigners. Contributions are meant to be withdrawn at 63, but premature withdrawals incur a 5% penalty and personal income tax. Experts advise individuals to consider their near-term cash needs and invest their SRS funds in a diversified portfolio to maximize returns, rather than solely relying on tax savings.

images.alt_text: The banks have flagged that the framework could raise competition concerns as they would be horizontal competitors in both the upstream and downstream markets for SRS products.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to acquire majority stake in Australian bus business for S$570.6 million
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has agreed to acquire a 98.6% stake in Australian bus-service business Ventura Motors for S$570.6 million. The deal is expected to support KIT's distribution per unit (DPU) accretion of 3.4% and increase its assets under management to S$8.7 billion. Ventura Motors is the largest bus-service business in Victoria, Australia. The acquisition is subject to completion adjustments and is expected to be completed soon.

images.alt_text: Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua with his senior management team at the company's results briefing on Thursday
KIT's FY2023 revenue sees greater contributions from City Energy.

Given that the solar solutions are bundled and leased to households under 20-year lease agreements, the acquisition will bring some “highly predictable cash flows” to KIT, the trustee-manager highlighted.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Monday’s open; STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 1.2% on Monday, led by declines from banking stocks, with DBS, OCBC, and UOB falling 1.3%, 1.5%, and 0.8% respectively. Losers outnumbered gainers 89 to 46, with 53.6 million securities worth S$91.9 million changing hands. The decline follows strong earnings outlooks and a US employment report on Wall Street, where stocks rose on Friday.

site_title: Messi fails to play in hyped Hong Kong match, drawing ire
summary: Lionel Messi failed to play in a highly anticipated friendly match in Hong Kong, drawing ire from the disappointed crowd. The Argentinian World Cup winner was on the bench for the entire match, which Inter Miami won 4-1. The event was meant to boost Hong Kong's reputation as a world-class center, but Messi's absence added to the city's problems, including a crackdown on dissent and strict pandemic curbs. The Hong Kong government expressed disappointment and may deduct its sponsorship due to Messi's failure to play, following other high-profile acts like Coldplay and Taylor Swift skipping the city.

images.alt_text: Lionel Messi, a soccer player for the Inter Miami, center, on the bench during a match between Inter Miami and the Hong Kong XI in Hong Kong, China, on Sunday, Feb. 4, 2024. The much-hyped Lionel Messi appearance in Hong Kong intended to lift the citys spirits ended with boos and jeers on Sunday as the Argentinian World Cup winner sat out his teams friendly with a local team. site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Property, KIT, Clint, Hiap Hoe, Pan-United, Keppel, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: Frasers Property's net gearing ratio increased to 78% in Q1 FY2024, while Keppel Infrastructure Trust acquired a 98.6% stake in Ventura Motors for A$600 million. Clint, an Indian property trust, bought three industrial facilities in India for S$43.2 million. Hiap Hoe sold its Melbourne Docklands hotel for A$96 million, and Pan-United Corporation partnered with Cleantech Solar for a solar panel project. Dasin Retail Trust received letters of demand from four individuals regarding alleged outstandings.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 325 to 257, after 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changed hands.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust to acquire 3 industrial facilities for 2.7 billion rupees
summary: CapitaLand India Trust has agreed to acquire three industrial facilities in OneHub Chennai, India, on a forward-purchase basis for 2.7 billion rupees (S$43.2 million). The acquisition is expected to diversify the trust's portfolio and grow its industrial presence in the city. The facilities will be developed in three phases over four years, with each phase spanning approximately 150,000 square feet. The acquisition is expected to increase the trust's floor area of industrial, logistics, and data centre asset classes to 14% of its committed pipeline, and is priced attractively considering current market capitalisation rates.

images.alt_text: Capitaland India Trust expects the full year contribution from the International Tech Park Hyderabad to positively impact FY2024 results.
CapitaLand India Trust's captive solar plant in Tamil Nadu will generate over 30 million kilowatt-hours of electricity annually.

The acquisition of Casa Grande - Phase 2 marks Clint’s second forward purchase transition with the Casa Grande Group, after it completed its first forward purchase transaction of a fully leased industrial facility known as Casa Grande - Phase 1 (pictured) in May 2022.

site_title: ‘Argylle’ takes top North American box office spot
summary: Universal's comedy adventure film 'Argylle' took the top spot at the North American box office, earning an estimated $18 million over the weekend. The movie, starring Bryce Dallas Howard, Sam Rockwell, and Dua Lipa, has received lackluster reviews despite its star-studded cast. Directed by Matthew Vaughn, 'Argylle' recounts the misadventures of a successful spy novelist.

images.alt_text: Amazon has an unrivalled delivery network that can ship millions products to much of the US population in a day or less.

site_title: RBA set to hold rate at 12-year high as bank overhaul begins
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is expected to hold its interest rate at a 12-year high of 4.35% at its first meeting of the year, amid a solid labour market and resilient economy. Economists anticipate the RBA will maintain a hawkish stance due to elevated inflation, which is still above the 2-3% target. While some predict a rate cut in early 2025, the RBA may resist easing due to domestic inflation concerns and a cautious rate-hike campaign.

images.alt_text: Michele Bullock  is concerned about the stickiness of services prices in Australia and has warned that the central bank’s willingness to take a bit longer to return inflation to target to preserve job gains has its limits.
The central bank will likely await fourth quarter figures due later this month, which include an expanded coverage of prices to inform its policy decision at its Feb 5 to 6 meeting.

site_title: Shell, Keppel-backed venture to install solar panels for Pan-United
summary: Pan-United, a ready-mix concrete company, is partnering with Cleantech Solar, backed by Shell Singapore and Keppel, to install 900 solar panels on its operational headquarters in Singapore and Malaysia. The project aims to bring Pan-United closer to its goal of becoming a carbon-neutral company by 2050. The installation is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2024, marking a significant step towards reducing the company's environmental impact.

images.alt_text: Pan-United's mixer trucks

As cement accounts for 7-8 per cent of carbon dioxide emissions globally, Pan-United chief executive May Ng said ready-mix concrete companies can have an impact if they reduce the amount of cement used in their products.

site_title: China vows to stabilise markets after rout, offers no detail
summary: China pledged to stabilize markets after shares hit a five-year low, erasing over $6 trillion in value, amid weak economic data, geopolitical tensions with the US, and a worsening property crisis. The China Securities Regulatory Commission vowed to prevent abnormal fluctuations and guide more funds into the market. No specific measures were announced, fueling frustration among individual investors.

China will run a budget deficit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product in 2024.

site_title: Hiap Hoe to sell Melbourne hotel for A$96 million
summary: Hiap Hoe is selling its Melbourne Docklands hotel for A$96 million (S$83.9 million) to WFM Financial, a subsidiary of MA Financial. The 273-key hotel, currently branded as Four Points by Sheraton, will be rebranded as Vibe Docklands under TFE Hotels. The sale will help Hiap Hoe repay bank borrowings and for working capital use. The hotel features conference space, a bar and restaurant, and guest amenities like a gym and outdoor swimming pool.

images.alt_text: The property is Great Eastern Motor Lodge, which is situated along the Great Eastern Highway, the main road linking the domestic and international terminals at Perth Airport to the Western Australian capital’s central business district.

site_title: ValueMax eyes Malaysia expansion, wants to cash in on demand for sustainable jewellery
summary: ValueMax Group, a mainboard-listed pawnbroker, plans to expand into Malaysia to capitalize on growing demand for sustainable jewelry. The company, which has 47 pawnbroking and retail outlets in Singapore, aims to grow northwards and expand into the Malaysian market. ValueMax's sustainability focus is driven by its roots in jewelry manufacturing, with its founder having previously run a gold jewelry manufacturing business. The company's associated company, Well Chip, is set to list on Bursa Malaysia's main stock exchange in the second quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: The amounts to be raised will be determined by ValueMax’s board after taking into account demand from investors.

site_title: Top aircraft lessors sow doubts over green fuel silver bullet
summary: Top aircraft lessors express doubts over the feasibility of achieving "net zero" emissions by 2050 through sustainable aviation fuel, citing the need for significant investment and the high cost of production. The industry estimates it will require $1.45-3.2 trillion in capital development, which may not be a "poor use of a scarce resource" according to AerCap CEO Aengus Kelly. Lessors emphasize the need for government incentives and policy intervention to support the development of sustainable aviation fuel infrastructure.

site_title: Ukraine’s Zelensky says considering replacing several officials, not just military
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is considering replacing several senior officials, including military commander Valery Zaluzhnyi, amid disagreements over the conduct of the Russian invasion. Zelensky stated that a "reset" is necessary, suggesting a broader leadership overhaul. He emphasized the need for unity and positive energy to win the war, following a Ukrainian counteroffensive's limited gains against Russian forces. The move comes as tensions between Zelensky and Zaluzhnyi have escalated.

site_title: Blinken heads back to Middle East to press hostage deal
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is on a crisis tour of the Middle East, visiting Israel, Egypt, and Qatar, to push for a proposal to halt the devastating conflict in exchange for the release of hostages. The proposal, which involves a six-week ceasefire, was drafted in Paris and involves Hamas freeing hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners. Blinken has expressed "real hope" for success, but faces opposition from hawks in Israel and division within Hamas. The visit comes amid escalating tensions in the region, including retaliatory strikes against Iranian-linked targets in Iraq and Syria.

site_title: Bond market rate-cut bets rattled by Powell pushback, job surge
summary: US bond market traders are re-evaluating their bets on interest-rate cuts after Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments, citing the economy's strong job growth and inflation surge. Despite a surge in hiring in January, Powell indicated the central bank is in a "risk management mode" and will start loosening monetary policy as inflation subsides. Traders now expect 3-4 rate cuts this year, with some predicting a potential fall in 10-year Treasury yields to 3%. The Fed's wait-and-see approach has sparked uncertainty, but a record $6 trillion in money-market funds may shift towards bonds once short-term rates come down.

site_title: Parisians vote in anti-SUV parking price referendum
summary: Parisians voted 54.55% in favour of charging SUVs weighing 1.6 tonnes or more 18 euros/hour for city centre parking or 12 euros further out. The proposal, from socialist mayor Anne Hidalgo, aims to reduce traffic congestion and generate revenue. Only 78,000 (5.7%) of 1.3 million eligible voters cast ballots, indicating low voter turnout.

site_title: German top ministers weigh corporate tax reform
summary: Germany's economy and finance ministers are considering corporate tax reform to make the country's companies more competitive, amid high energy costs and red tape. Economy Minister Robert Habeck said lowering the corporate tax rate to 25% would cost around 30 billion euros annually. Finance Minister Christian Lindner called for increased flexibility in the labor market, less red tape, and tax incentives as part of the reform. The goal is to boost the country's weakening economy and ensure prosperity, with the ministers urging swift action to produce results.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen’s Audi brand is paring down its EV lineup, and VW is taking a step back from plans to sell stakes in its battery unit.
On average, only 56 per cent of the available money is drawn down from the climate fund each year, offering the potential for some room to manoeuvre.

site_title: Endowus and foodpanda team up to provide financial literacy courses for riders
summary: Endowus, a personal finance platform, has partnered with foodpanda to provide financial literacy courses for delivery partners in Singapore. The courses, conducted by Endowus' Chiam Sheng Shi, aim to educate riders on managing their finances, especially with regards to Central Provident Fund (CPF) and housing loans. Over 40 delivery partners attended the first course, with plans for more sessions to reach over 300 riders. The partnership aims to provide unbiased guidance and lower-cost access to financial tools and education for platform workers.

site_title: China's Country Garden says over 30 projects have local government support
summary: Country Garden, China's largest private property developer, says over 30 of its projects have received local government support through the "project white list" mechanism, which aims to inject liquidity into the crisis-hit real estate sector. The projects, listed in provinces such as Heinan, Hubei, and Shandong, can receive financing support, helping to ease liquidity pressure and complete homes. This move follows China's efforts to support struggling developers, but banks' reluctance to lend remains a major obstacle.

site_title: More Asia-Pacific buyers on the prowl for London commercial properties
summary: Buyers from Asia-Pacific countries, particularly Singapore, dominated London's commercial property market in 2023, with total investment in the City of London slumping to £3.6 billion, a 70% decline from pre-pandemic levels. Asian investors, led by Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, acquired £1.1 billion worth of properties, including a 75% stake in a life-sciences development. Despite a decline in property values, rental yields in the City of London have increased, attracting Asian investors. Experts predict a boost in rental demand, driven by the UK's tight labor market and growing jobs growth.

images.alt_text: Skyscraper office blocks in the City of London, UK, on Tuesday, Jan. 23, 2024. site_title: Silchester takes ComfortDelGro stake above 7%
summary: Institutional investors net-sold Singapore stocks by S$329 million between Feb 1 and Feb 4, with S$15.2 million spent on 11 buybacks. CapitaLand Investment led the buybacks, buying back 5 million shares. In contrast, ComfortDelGro Corporation saw a significant increase in its stake above 7%, with substantial shareholder Silchester International Investors emerging as a major investor. Other notable transactions included CosmoSteel Holdings' CEO acquiring 2.75 million shares and China Kunda Technology Holdings' executive chairman increasing his stake to 1.95%.

site_title: Trump floats Chinese goods tariff of more than 60% if elected
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has suggested imposing a tariff of over 60% on Chinese goods if elected, despite criticism that it could start a trade war. Trump claims he "did great with China" during his presidency and wants to get along with China, but believes they've taken advantage of the US. This move comes as some US lawmakers support curbing economic ties with China, and follows a recent report that sparked currency hedges among traders.

images.alt_text: Republican presidential hopeful and former UN ambassador Nikki Haley speaks at a rally on Jan 28, 2024 in Conway, South Carolina.

Trump’s New Hampshire triumph comes after a decisive win in Iowa and delivers a setback to Haley, ahead of the Feb 24 primary in her home state of South Carolina.

site_title: Rail talk: Are South-east Asia’s high-speed rail ambitions on track or running out of steam?
summary: South-east Asia's high-speed rail ambitions are facing challenges, despite Indonesia's successful launch of the US$7.3 billion Whoosh project. Several countries, including Thailand and Malaysia, are working on HSR projects but have faced delays and funding issues. Experts say the region's vision of seamless integration requires regional coordination, which is difficult due to differing national agendas. Conflicts over national interests and high project costs are also major stumbling blocks. However, some experts believe that with active dialogue and cooperation, it is possible to connect several Asean cities via HSR, and the benefits of HSR links in urban agglomeration and clean energy should not be understated.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Cashing in on Lunar New Year (Ep 162)
summary: The Business Times podcast "BT Money Hacks" discusses making the most of Lunar New Year earnings. Host Howie Lim advises planning finances, saving, and distinguishing needs from wants. Mey Wong, head of client experience at StashAway, provides a step-by-step guide to using ang-bao money, emphasizing the need for a balance between saving, spending, and investing. The podcast aims to help listeners make the most of their ang-bao money and start investing as a beginner.

site_title: Foxconn sees 'slightly better' 2024, warns on AI chip shortage
summary: Foxconn, Apple's largest iPhone assembler, expects its 2024 business to be "slightly better" than last year, but faces a shortage of AI chip supplies. Chairman Liu Young-way attributed this to limited production capacity for server chips, despite strong demand. The company also noted that global economic uncertainty and geopolitical problems will impact consumer product demand, particularly in the Asian market. Foxconn will report fourth-quarter earnings next month, when it will update its 2024 outlook.

images.alt_text: An estimated 13 per cent of the world’s iPhones were assembled in India last year, and about three-quarters of those were made in Tamil Nadu.

site_title: Why stocks will soar in 2024
summary: Ken Fisher, a financial expert, predicts the young bull market will continue in 2024 despite bears' concerns over higher interest rates and global economic malaise. He expects moderate double-digit gains for the Straits Times Index and world stocks, driven by economic resilience and political tailwinds. Tech and big growth stocks are expected to lead early, with a mid-year value shift bringing a bounce to bank-heavy Singapore, potentially making it a good-to-great year.

images.alt_text: Singapore property stocks, hit hard by rising rates, would have greater upside in a recovery.

site_title: S&P 500’s current rally likely to stall
summary: The S&P 500's recent rally, driven by the US economy's "Goldilocks" period of moderate growth and low inflation, is expected to stall at the 5,000 level. The US economy grew 3.3% in the fourth quarter, beating estimates, and inflation moderated further in December. However, investors should exercise caution, as the rally may not be sustainable. The current market optimism is likely to continue, but the potential for a correction or stall is increasing.

images.alt_text: All three major US stock indexes are on track for their fourth consecutive weekly gains.

site_title: Ho Chi Minh City seeks US$492 million of investments in high-tech sector
summary: Ho Chi Minh City is seeking US$492 million in investments in the high-tech sector, including US$190 million for electronics and semiconductors, and US$302 million for a data centre project. The city aims to boost green development and follows recent investments of over US$12 billion in the Saigon Hi-tech Park. The city has seen a surge in foreign investment, with Singapore being the top source, and has expressed interest in courting global players to build its first wafer fab.

site_title: Inside Julius Baer’s failed gamble on Signa real estate empire
summary: Swiss bank Julius Baer wrote off $700 million from its exposure to Austrian property magnate Rene Benko's collapsed empire, following a probe that found risk managers didn't grasp the complexity of the Benko loans. The bank sacked CEO Philipp Rickenbacher and exited the private credit business. Chairman Romeo Lacher attributed the misjudged risk to a "misjudged the risk" and acknowledged the bank's poor risk control. Julius Baer's shares rose 1% after the announcements, and the bank is now reworking its risk control structures.

site_title: Attractive dividend yields to prop up DBS, OCBC, UOB shares as earnings soften in Q4
summary: Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB are expected to post softer earnings in Q4 due to weaker net interest margins and seasonally weaker fee income. However, analysts predict attractive dividend yields of around 7% to support their share prices. High capital levels and a strong CET-1 ratio may encourage special dividends, particularly for DBS and UOB. Analysts expect the banks to adjust down their 2024 NIM outlook due to rate expectations and will closely watch for guidance on outlook and interest rates.

summary: The capesize market experienced mixed conditions across different regions, starting with a marginal decline in rates due to uncertainty in North China. However, a positive turn was observed in the Pacific and South Atlantic, with the BCI 5TC increasing due to a longer cargo list and resurgence of coal. Despite this, the Pacific's C5 rates continued to decline. Volumes increased, including coal enquiries from East Coast Australia to China, adding complexity to the market.

Canadian dollar gives up weekly gain 
as US jobs data boost greenback
summary: The Canadian dollar weakened to a one-week low against the US dollar, trading 0.6% lower at 1.3460, following strong US jobs data that boosted the greenback. The data reduced prospects of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates, increasing Treasury yields and the dollar. This move also led to a correction in the Canadian dollar, which had been seen as overvalued. Preliminary data showed Canada's economy expanding at an annualized rate of 1.2% in Q4, but the price of oil, a major export, fell 2% to US$72.35 a barrel.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was last at 103.98, the highest since Dec 13 and up 0.9 per cent on the day.

site_title: Data centre S-Reits positive about riding AI wave
summary: Data centre-focused Specialised Real Estate Investment Trusts (S-Reits) are optimistic about the growing demand for data centres driven by the exponential progress of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning. Despite challenges such as economic slowdown and higher property expenses, portfolio occupancy levels remained resilient above 95% on average. S-Reits like Digital Core Reit, Keppel DC Reit, and Mapletree Industrial Trust reported strong revenue and net property income growth, with some securing new leases and expansion contracts. The demand for data centres is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 18.5% from 2023 to 2027.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. Sabana Reit’s FY2023 gross revenue is up 17.9 per cent year on year to S$111.9 million.

site_title: UBS launches biggest ad campaign in 7 years to ‘drive business’
summary: UBS is launching its largest ad campaign in 7 years to drive business growth, with a reported investment of double-digit millions. The campaign aims to reassure clients and employees that the recent acquisition of Credit Suisse won't lead to indigestion. John McDonald, UBS' group chief marketing officer, hopes to generate buy-in from both groups. The campaign's success will be crucial for UBS as it navigates the post-acquisition period.

images.alt_text: The scale of the retrenchment in private banking is one of the biggest seen in Asia and comes as wealth from the Greater China region has tumbled amid a property crisis and the faltering economy.
UBS will use the slogan “Banking is our craft” as it seeks to attract new customers to its wealth management, asset management, and investment banking franchises.
UBS is also struggling to offload the investment-banking franchise it inherited from Credit Suisse in China.

site_title: Philippines to use ‘forces’ to quell secession attempts: official
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has stated that the government will use "authority and forces" to quell any attempt to separate the country, following a threat by former leader Rodrigo Duterte to split Mindanao from the rest of the nation. Duterte warned that Mindanao will become independent if Marcos amends the constitution, while Marcos has backed efforts to revise the economic provisions of the 1987 Constitution. The comments highlight deepening cracks in the alliance between the two powerful political families.

images.alt_text: Even as inflation in December has slowed to within the central bank’s 2 to 4 per cent target band after 21 months, rate hikes are not fully off the table amid rising food prices.

site_title: Singapore arbitrator denies relief to Sony in Zee merger case
summary: Singapore's emergency arbitrator denied Sony Group's request for interim relief in a dispute over the scrapped $10 billion merger with Zee Entertainment Enterprises. The arbitrator ruled that the matter falls within the jurisdiction of India's National Company Law Tribunal, allowing Zee to pursue its case against Sony's Indian units before the Indian court. Zee is seeking to implement the merger plan, which Sony attempted to block. The decision comes as Zee's shares have plunged 37% this year amid the deal's failure and fallout concerns.

site_title: Tributes pour in for visionary banker Wee Cho Yaw
summary: Tributes pour in for visionary banker Wee Cho Yaw, who died at 95. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong hailed him as "a titan of Singapore's banking industry" for his business acumen and visionary leadership behind UOB's growth. Wee's significant contributions also included promoting Chinese language, culture, and values. President Tharman Shanmugaratnam described Wee's "insatiable appetite for work and shrewd eye for opportunities" as unmatched in local banking.

images.alt_text: Wee Cho Yaw, who played a pivotal role in the growth of UOB, has passed away at the age of 95.

site_title: Welcome to ‘Dalifornia’, an oasis for China’s drifters and dreamers
summary: China's megacities have drawn young people to Dali, a city in southwestern China, in search of a more relaxed lifestyle. The city, known as "Dalifornia," has long been a hub for backpackers and artists but has recently become a haven for those seeking an alternative to the high cost of living and suffocating political environment. With its idyllic old town, ancient city gates, and white-walled courtyard homes, Dali has become a destination for China's disaffected, drifting, or curious. While some newcomers plan to stay forever, others aim to try out an alternative lifestyle before returning to the city.

images.alt_text: Feature on  luxe red packets and cookbooks

site_title: Red Sea danger is spurring global oil buyers to go local
summary: The global oil market is shifting towards local supply due to Red Sea attacks, which have led to higher transport costs and encouraged refiners to diversify their sources. This trend is evident in reduced tanker traffic through the Suez Canal and increased demand for Middle Eastern and North Sea crude. The fragmentation may not be permanent, but it's making it harder for import-dependent nations like India and South Korea to diversify their oil supply, limiting their flexibility and potentially eating into margins.

images.alt_text: Oil markets remain fragile, with prices holding near US$80 a barrel in London even as conflict rages in the Middle East and shipping in the Red Sea comes under attack

site_title: Singapore companies may be falling behind on green skills development
summary: Singapore companies are falling behind in providing green skills training and development for employees, despite the increasing importance of green skills in the next five years. Only 12% of executives believe they are "completely ready" to provide green skills training, lower than the global average. The lack of preparedness has negative implications for companies in a competitive environment for green talent. SMEs are cited as a major obstacle, with limited resources and support structures. The government and industry can consider initiatives such as education, training, and support for renewable energy startups to address the shortage of green skills in Singapore.

images.alt_text:
ST20231121-202363285462-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
Workers installing solar panels on the rooftop of Block 850 Tampines Street 82 as part of HDB's SolarNova Programme on Nov 17, 2023.
The SolarNova programme is a Whole-of-Government effort led by the Economic Development Board and HDB intended to prompt demand for solar photovoltaic systems to achieve economies of scale and to drive growth in Singapore's solar industry. It appeals to public sector demand for the installation of solar panels across 1198 HDB blocks and 57 government sites with a solar capacity of 70 megawatt-peak.
(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)
SGTech called for the formation of a public-private sustainability communication office.
Chia Der Jiun, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, speaking at the launch of the Singapore Sustainable Finance Association on January 24, 2024.
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan was the guest of honour at the Singapore Manufacturing Federation's inaugural Manufacturing Day Summit 2024.
Even if sustainability may not always bring immediate revenue gains, it is nonetheless important, says OCBC head of global commercial banking Linus Goh.

site_title: China to prevent abnormal market fluctuations: regulator
summary: China's securities regulator vows to prevent abnormal market fluctuations and maintain capital market stability. Following a record sixth consecutive month of losses, the CSI 300 Index fell 6.3% in January, prompting a 2 trillion yuan rescue package and reserve requirement ratio cut. The regulator will crack down on market manipulation, short selling, and insider trading, while guiding more medium and long-term funds into the market to boost confidence. Authorities will actively coordinate measures to stabilize the market and support the stock markets.

site_title: Germany’s budget chaos leaves green-energy projects in limbo
summary: Germany's climate and transformation fund is facing a potential shortfall of up to 10 billion euros for 2025, casting doubt on the country's goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 65% by 2030. The fund, which has a projected total of 49 billion euros this year, is expected to draw down only 56% of its available money each year, leaving room for maneuver. Key solar and hydrogen projects are at risk due to the funding gap, and the government is struggling to find consensus on how to address the issue, despite Economy Minister Robert Habeck's promises of subsidies to support decarbonization.

images.alt_text: Inflation remains above the European Central Bank’s 2 per cent target, but well below the peak of 10.6 per cent recorded in October 2022 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent energy prices soaring.
The Federal Labour Office says the number of people out of work decreased by 2,000 in seasonally adjusted terms from December to 2.694 million.

site_title: Lazada’s laid off union members get training fund, better support package
summary: Lazada has agreed to a support package and training fund for laid-off union members, facilitated by the Ministry of Manpower. The package includes a training fund set up by Lazada in collaboration with NTUC's Employment and Employability Institute. While details of the support package remain confidential, the union has expressed satisfaction with the settlement, which comes a month after NTUC voiced its disappointment over the layoffs.

images.alt_text: Lazada's layoffs is unlikely a signal of preparation for an IPO in the near-future.
The Lazada building on Bras Basah Road on 9 January 2023.
As layoffs rip through Lazada, communication between the company the those that remain have been non-existent.
Lazada laid off an undisclosed number of employees in Singapore on Jan 3 without informing the union.
E-commerce company Lazada on Jan 3 laid off an undisclosed number of its Singapore staff, amid speculation of an upcoming IPO.

site_title: Germany’s dream of 15 million electric vehicles is fading away
summary: Germany's goal of having 15 million electric vehicles by 2030 appears to be fading away due to slowing EV demand in Europe's largest car market. Policymakers and manufacturers, including BMW's Oliver Zipse, have been advocating for a more flexible approach, including production lines for combustion, hybrid, and hydrogen-powered cars. EV adoption is being hindered by infrastructure and price concerns, with the upper-end market becoming saturated and lower-end models lacking options. The government's decision to end subsidies has led to a 14% drop in EV sales in Germany this year, and market watchers have trimmed forecasts due to the vehicles' high price compared to combustion-engine cars.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen Group’s focus on EVs comes down to their favourable taxation structure in India.
FILE PHOTO: A Volkswagen logo is seen on a Volkswagen ID.5 electric car on display at a showroom of a car dealer in Reze near Nantes, France, November 13, 2023. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo

site_title: Apple fans line up to spend US$3,499 on the Vision Pro headset
summary: Apple has launched its Vision Pro headset, priced at $3,499, marking its entry into the virtual and augmented reality market. The device, which relies on eye movement and hand gestures, was unveiled with a relatively subdued launch, drawing smaller crowds than previous Apple product launches. Despite this, CEO Tim Cook believes the Vision Pro has the potential to be a groundbreaking product, with analysts estimating $600 million in revenue from its preorder period. The headset's shipments are expected to be in the hundreds of thousands this year, positioning Apple to become a major player in the mixed-reality market.

images.alt_text: Sales of iPhones hit US$69.70 billion, growing 6 per cent to beat analyst expectations of US$67.82 billion.
The judge also rejects Apple's bid to exclude testimony it considered unreliable from two expert witnesses.

site_title: Why February is the best month for resolutions
summary: Psychologists recommend starting February as a time to reassess and adjust New Year's resolutions, rather than giving up. It's essential to reflect on progress, identify what's working and what's not, and set achievable milestones. Experts suggest starting with "almost embarrassingly manageable" goals, allowing for flexibility and a margin of error. Finding an accountability buddy and scheduling regular check-ins can also help stay on track. Lastly, practicing self-compassion and celebrating small wins can help maintain motivation and momentum throughout the year.

images.alt_text: The productivity-enhancing effect of dance is stronger in activities involving high levels of teamwork.

site_title: Driverless cars covered 5 times more test miles in California in 2023
summary: California saw nearly 3.3 million miles of test miles for driverless cars in 2023, more than five times the previous year. Alphabet's Waymo and General Motors' Cruise accounted for 36% and 63% of miles recorded without a safety driver, respectively. Despite concerns over a Cruise robotaxi accident, autonomous tests with a safety driver increased to 5.7 million miles. The state's DMV suspended testing permits for Cruise in October due to safety concerns and investigations.

images.alt_text: General Motors' Cruise pulled all its vehicles from testing in the United States to conduct a safety review after an Oct 2 incident in which a woman was struck and dragged by a Cruise vehicle in San Francisco.
General Motors is facing fallout over Cruise losing its license in October to operate on public roads in California.

Kia President and CEO Song Ho Sung speaks during a briefing at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nevada, Jan 8, 2024. Uber and Kia announced on Wednesday the signing of an agreement on producing electric vehicles.

site_title: Australia PM to introduce bill to reshape tax cuts on Tuesday
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese plans to introduce a bill on Tuesday that will reshape tax cuts, reducing benefits to the wealthy while increasing breaks for low-income earners. The policy, announced recently, will see those earning up to A$135,000 (S$118,183) move into lower tax brackets from July 1. For high-income earners, tax breaks will nearly halve, with the savings redirected to those on low incomes. The move aims to address high living costs, which have been exacerbated by inflation.

images.alt_text: Australia’s property market surprisingly recovered last year despite the central bank’s 4.25 percentage points of policy tightening since May 2022.

site_title: From green hype to bailouts, the nickel industry has imploded
summary: The nickel industry has imploded due to a massive Indonesian expansion of low-grade production, leading to a surplus and subsequent crash in prices by over 40% from a year ago. Despite processing innovations refining the glut into high-quality product for battery markets, the market remains volatile, with weak demand and concerns about China's economy. Many mines are at risk of closing, and some companies are seeking state bailouts or struggling to stay afloat, raising questions about the future of the industry outside of Indonesia.

images.alt_text: The appointments “will ensure that LME Clear is in a strong position as we drive forward our strategy” says LME CEO Michael Carty.

site_title: Gaming billionaire buys another London mansion for £24 million
summary: Billionaire Igor Bukhman, co-founder of gaming giant Playrix, has purchased a £24 million London mansion next to one of his existing luxury homes in Kensington. This is the second instalment in Bukhman's plan to renovate the two properties. Despite global interest rate increases, London's luxury real estate market remains relatively strong, with £100 million+ deals made in 2023. The market is expected to grow, with 28% more super-rich individuals projected by 2026, according to a report by Beauchamp Estates.

images.alt_text: Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Strong CNY dining demand at Singapore’s hotels, restaurants despite cost-of-living woes
summary: Singapore's hotels and restaurants have seen stronger Chinese New Year (CNY) dining demand from families and corporates, despite cost-of-living concerns. Reunion dinner slots are filling up faster and corporates are spending more, marking the second CNY since Covid-19 group-size restrictions were lifted. This is a significant improvement from last year's muted demand due to travel restrictions.

images.alt_text: Steven Lau and his wife Wong Lai Quen in front of the CNY dragon display at Gardens by the Bay. Lau was diagnosed with early-onset dementia at the age of 57.
Interest has been rising since both countries announced that the arrangement was in the works – though without a start date –  early last December, say industry players.
Quenino's plush yet patio-like interiors.

site_title: Exxon pursues lawsuit despite activist investor climb-down
summary: ExxonMobil will continue to pursue a lawsuit against two activist investors, Arjuna Capital and Follow This, despite their withdrawal of a shareholder proposal on climate change. The lawsuit, filed in January, questions the motivations of the investors and seeks to block the resolution from being voted on. Exxon claims there are still important issues for the court to resolve, and the suit is continuing. The case has raised concerns about the potential for other companies to block shareholder resolutions in court, rather than through regulatory appeals.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s lack of preparedness to provide green skills training and development for employees has potentially negative implications for companies amid an increasingly competitive environment for such talent.

site_title: CEO bake-offs are stale. Levi Strauss took a fresh approach
summary: Levi Strauss has taken a fresh approach to CEO succession by naming Michelle Gass, the current president, as the new CEO after a year-long transition period. This approach is a departure from the traditional "CEO bake-off" model, where internal candidates compete against each other. Gass's path to the top was unusual, as she was initially announced as president before being named CEO. The company's board used this transition period to turn an outsider into an insider, giving Gass a deep understanding of the company while also bringing in fresh thinking. This approach aims to mitigate the risks associated with internal candidates and provide a more thorough evaluation of leadership potential.

images.alt_text: Levi will continue to sell other products at the retailer.

site_title: Investors withdraw Exxon climate proposal after court complaint
summary: ExxonMobil has withdrawn a climate proposal aimed at reducing emissions produced by the burning of its products after a Texas court complaint from activist shareholders. The proposal, filed by Arjuna Capital and Follow This, sought to set targets for reducing Scope 3 emissions. Exxon had argued that the proposal was driven by an "extreme agenda" and that the court should block the move. The withdrawal comes after a court case assigned to a conservative judge, which could set a precedent for similar investors' claims. Exxon plans to continue the suit despite the withdrawal.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ExxonMobil logo is seen in this illustration taken, October 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Exxon results included a US$2.5 billion impairment charge for California properties that it has been trying to sell for more than a year.

site_title: How jobseekers can show they are ready for an AI-driven world
summary: In an AI-driven world, jobseekers must demonstrate a winning mindset by showcasing adaptability, innovation, and intellectual curiosity. Leading organizations are seeking candidates who can navigate change and leverage new technologies. Jobseekers can do this by sharing stories of embracing uncertainty, exploring new tools, and applying a growth mindset in previous work experiences. They should also be prepared to ask informed questions and demonstrate a baseline understanding of AI. By adopting this mindset, jobseekers can stand out in the job market and thrive in the AI-driven world.

images.alt_text: At the launch event at Google Singapore's office on Monday (Jan 29) were (from left):  Google Singapore managing director Ben King, country director for Singapore at Google Cloud Serene Sia, managing director (South-east Asia) at Google Cloud Mark Micallef, Minister for Communications and Information  Josephine Teo,  Permanent Secretary at Smart Nation Joseph Leong, Permanent Secretary at the Ministry of Trade and Industry Gabriel Lim, and Jacqueline Poh, managing director at the Singapore Economic Development Board.

As it becomes easier to generate historical disinfo and as the sheer volume of digital fakes explodes, the opportunity will become available to reshape history or at least to call our current understanding of it into question.
Samsung is making a push to expand its small share in China, the world’s largest smartphone market.

site_title: Oil posts weekly losses as US data dents hopes for near-term rate cuts
summary: Oil prices fell by 2% on Friday, posting weekly losses, after US jobs data reduced the chances of near-term interest rate cuts, dampening crude demand. High interest rates, faltering growth in China, and reduced tensions in the Middle East contributed to the decline. Brent crude futures settled at $77.33 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at $72.28 a barrel, both losing 7% on the week. The US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates high appears to be a long-term trend, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Opec+ currently has 2.2 million bpd of voluntary oil production cuts, announced in November.
Oil markets remain fragile, with prices holding near US$80 a barrel in London even as conflict rages in the Middle East and shipping in the Red Sea comes under attack

site_title: China’s Lunar New Year pork gloom exposes deep economic trouble
summary: China's Lunar New Year is typically a peak season for pork consumption, but this year's sluggish demand exposes deep economic trouble. Despite falling pork prices by about 20% compared to last year, vendors are selling a third less than usual. This weak demand sends a message about oversupply and declining consumer prices due to wage declines. The trend highlights China's economic struggles, which may lead to pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

images.alt_text: The Food and Agriculture Organization’s (FAO) price index, which tracks the most globally traded food commodities, averages 118.0 points in January, down from 119.1 the previous month.
Three straight years of losses have wiped more than US$6 trillion from the market value of Chinese and Hong Kong equities since a peak reached in 2021.
FILE PHOTO: A staff counts Chinese Renminbi currency at a bank in Baokang, central China's Hubei province, November 11, 2007. REUTERS/Stringer (CHINA) CHINA OUT/File Photo

site_title: AI can write, but is it any good at picking stocks?
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is being explored for its potential to improve stock market investing, but its effectiveness remains uncertain. Generative AI can analyze large amounts of financial data, identify patterns, and make predictions, similar to human experts. However, its ability to consistently beat the market is still unproven, with some studies showing underperformance over the past five years. Predictive AI, which focuses on identifying complex relationships between variables, is also being used in quantitative trading. While AI has the potential to boost productivity and efficiency, it is unlikely to replace human traders and market strategists entirely, as markets are subject to constant changes and noise.

images.alt_text: The company says users can ask the software what they’d need to start an indoor garden or ask for Valentine’s Day recommendations, among other questions.

site_title: NHL to return to Olympics for 2026, 2030 Winter Games
summary: The National Hockey League (NHL) has reached a deal with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and the International Ice Hockey Federation (IIHF) to have its players compete in the 2026 Milan-Cortina Winter Games and the 2030 Winter Games. This marks the first time NHL players will participate in the Olympics since 2014. The deal has been backed by the NHL Players' Association (NHLPA) and IIHF, and will feature NHL-sized courts for competition. The agreement is seen as a major boost for the sport, with IIHF president Luc Tardif calling it a "turning point" for ice hockey globally.

images.alt_text: The cost of getting into the most in-demand sports competitions has risen – sometimes by Olympian proportions.

site_title: UK bonds pare worst start to year as rate-cut hopes run high
summary: UK government bonds posted their first weekly advance in over a month, driven by expectations of rate cuts and a slowdown in inflation. Traders are betting on four quarter-point rate cuts in the UK this year, compared to five in the euro area and the US. A benign inflation outlook could prompt the market to bring forward the expected start-date for cuts, potentially leading to a "full rally mode" in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: “We have had good news on inflation over the past few months. It has fallen a long way,” says Andrew Bailey after the decision to leave the key rate unchanged at 5.25 per cent.

site_title: Zuckerberg’s wealth surges by US$28 billion as Meta rallies
summary: Mark Zuckerberg's net worth surged by $28.1 billion after Meta's quarterly results exceeded Wall Street's expectations, sending its shares up 20%. His net worth now stands at $170.5 billion, surpassing Bill Gates to become the fourth richest person on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. This marks a significant comeback from his net worth falling below $35 billion in 2022 due to tech stocks collapsing.

images.alt_text: Meta forecast first quarter revenue of US$34.5 billion to US$37 billion, above Wall Street expectations of US$33.8 billion.
Meta unveiled plans for a US$50 billion stock buyback, and even announced its first ever quarterly dividend – a sign to investors that it has money to spare and a reason for them to stick around.

site_title: Grocery stores should cut prices as costs ease, Biden administration says
summary: The Biden administration is urging grocery giants like Walmart, Kroger, and Albertsons to lower prices as costs ease, citing elevated profit margins and a lack of pass-through to consumers. The administration's message comes ahead of the president's re-election bid, following concerns about high costs and inflation. A White House analysis shows food-and-beverage retailers' revenues as a share of their costs have risen sharply since the pandemic, and consumer confidence is improving despite low approval ratings for Biden.

images.alt_text: Businesses are holding back on inventory accumulation in anticipation of slower demand this year.

site_title: US: Wall Street climbs, S&P 500 powers to record high on solid earnings, robust data
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, driven by strong earnings from Meta Platforms and Amazon.com, and a blowout January employment report. The S&P 500 index reached a record high, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite also gaining. Despite expectations of a potential interest rate cut, the Federal Reserve's rate decision was delayed, and investors are now focused on upcoming earnings and economic reports. The US economy added 353,000 jobs in January, with wage growth unexpectedly heating up, and analysts now expect year-on-year S&P 500 earnings growth of 7.8% for the October-to-December period.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 1.0 per cent at 38,519.84.

site_title: China gloom spurs record US$2 billion rush into foreign stock ETFs
summary: Chinese investors are rushing into foreign stock ETFs, with a record $2 billion flowing into US and Japanese markets in January, amid growing concerns over the domestic share market. This trend is part of a broader shift away from China, with domestic investors losing faith in the local market. Despite risks, investors are undeterred, seeking a way out of the sagging local stock market, with prices in some ETFs rising 40% above underlying assets.

images.alt_text: Three straight years of losses have wiped more than US$6 trillion from the market value of Chinese and Hong Kong equities since a peak reached in 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong pins revival hopes on Messi after Coldplay, Taylor Swift misses
summary: Hong Kong is hoping Lionel Messi's visit will boost the city's reputation, which has been damaged by a crackdown on dissent and strict pandemic curbs. Despite Coldplay and Taylor Swift skipping Hong Kong for their Asian tours, Inter Miami's arrival is seen as a attempt to create "Messi mania." The city's economy, which grew 3.2% last year, is struggling with a lack of facilities to host major global acts and high borrowing costs. The visit is part of efforts by Hong Kong officials to create a buzz and boost spending, but the city faces an uphill struggle with visitor numbers from mainland China down one-third since before Covid.

images.alt_text: Sales increases 7.8 per cent year on year to HK$36.3 billion (S$6.2 billion) in December, the Hong Kong government says.

site_title: Beware the Trojan Horse of lavish gifts and entertainment
summary: Lavish gifts and entertainment can compromise corporate and individual integrity, posing a risk of conflict of interest. In Singapore, businesses often give and receive gifts and entertainment during festive occasions, but this can blur the lines between personal and professional relationships. Former transport minister S Iswaran's 27 criminal charges highlight the need for clear policies and controls on gifts and hospitality. Companies should review their practices and require adequate payment for gifts and entertainment received personally to minimize the risk of influence peddling and actualized conflicts of interest, lest they become the proverbial "Trojan horse" that undermines their integrity and reputation.

images.alt_text: Most SMEs do not have guidelines on corporate gifting.

site_title: Singapore banking titan Wee Cho Yaw of UOB dies at 95
summary: Wee Cho Yaw, the 95-year-old billionaire businessman and chairman emeritus of UOB, has passed away. He played a pivotal role in the growth of the bank, expanding its network from 75 to over 500 branches globally and increasing its assets from S$2.8 billion to over S$253 billion. Wee was also a successful entrepreneur, winning Singapore's Businessman of the Year award twice, and was known for his transformative leadership and commitment to serving the community. He will be remembered for his contributions to Singapore's financial centre and his values of honour, enterprise, and unity.

images.alt_text: Resilient, visionary, charitable
Difficult to grow through acquisitions today: UOB's Wee Cho Yaw

site_title: Reddit picks New York Stock Exchange for IPO in win over Nasdaq
summary: Reddit has chosen the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) for its initial public offering (IPO), beating out Nasdaq. The San Francisco-based social media company is expected to file its IPO paperwork later this month, with a possible listing as soon as March. Reddit is considering a valuation of at least $5 billion and is gathering feedback from potential investors. This marks a win for the NYSE in its competition for high-profile IPOs, as reported earlier by The Wall Street Journal.

site_title: Companies need a better read on what their workers actually do
summary: Companies are struggling to measure productivity in a post-pandemic world where remote work and AI dominate. Traditional metrics, such as hours worked and pay, are flawed and can be misleading. Experts recommend looking beyond quarterly and yearly fluctuations, and exploring alternative methods, such as analyzing the European debt crisis and the introduction of the 35-hour week in France. Productivity growth is crucial for economic growth, as population growth slows and societies age. Companies are investing time and resources into finding better ways to measure and improve productivity, with some arguing that "feeling good" is a key indicator of efficiency.

images.alt_text: Minister of State for Manpower, Ms Gan Siow Huang, interacts with employee of AsiaOne Online Pte Ltd, Lim Ke Wei, (left) 21, Editorial Strategist, during her company visit on Jan 31, 2024. With her are; Ms Yeo Wan Ling (second from right) Director, Women and Family (WAF) / U SME; Mr Edwin Ng,(right) SNEF Honorary Secretary.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust receives letters of demand from executives
summary: Dasin Retail Trust received letters of demand from four individuals, including executives, totaling S$1,055,376, alleging outstandings for monthly salaries, loan repayments, and payments made on behalf of the trustee-manager. The trustee-manager is seeking legal advice and has confirmed it will continue to receive financial support from its major shareholder. The letters come after the trust received an invalid requisition notice for an extraordinary general meeting from unitholders.

site_title: Lower profits at US oil giants still mighty enough for big investor payouts
summary: US oil giants ExxonMobil and Chevron reported lower but still strong profits in the fourth quarter, with ExxonMobil's US$7.6 billion and Chevron's US$2.3 billion. Despite lower commodity prices, particularly for natural gas, both companies still scored significant increases in dividends and share buybacks. ExxonMobil returned US$32.4 billion to shareholders in 2023, while Chevron's payout jumped 18% to US$26 billion. The companies' profits were also boosted by production increases in targeted prospects and acquisitions, including ExxonMobil's planned takeover of Pioneer Natural Resources.

images.alt_text: High interest rates tend to dampen economic growth and oil demand.

site_title: Chinese billionaire’s carmaker adds satellites in Musk territory
summary: Chinese carmaker Geespace, a subsidiary of Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, launched 11 satellites into low-Earth orbit, aiming to provide satellite communications for driverless cars and consumer electronics. The launch marks the company's second attempt to deploy a satellite network, with a goal of 72 satellites by next year. Geespace's CEO, Tony Wang, believes satellite communications will become a key feature in vehicles, and the company plans to offer its service globally. This move aims to compete with Elon Musk's SpaceX, which dominates the low-Earth orbit space.

images.alt_text: Spiral galaxy NGC 1512, located 30 million light-years away from Earth, is seen in an undated image from the James Webb Space Telescope.
