site_title: Tackling costs of cancer treatment
summary: A recent survey of 1,200 Singapore residents found that nearly four in 10 respondents are unprepared to manage the costs of cancer treatment, with the main reason being unaffordable premiums. Only 5% of those with health and/or critical illness insurance were confident that their policies could fully cover the cost of cancer treatment. Experts emphasize the need for financial literacy and adequate insurance protection to minimize financial toxicity. Policymakers, clinicians, and financial professionals are urged to work together to better support cancer patients and their families.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of the National Cancer Centre Singapore showing the sign

site_title: Even at 100, Malaysia billionaire Robert Kuok is still leaving his mark on the business world
summary: Malaysia's richest man, Robert Kuok, turned 100 and remains the country's wealthiest individual with a net worth of US$11.8 billion, according to Forbes. Kuok, a self-made billionaire, has held the top spot in Malaysia for over 20 years, despite retiring from most of his companies in the 1990s. His vast wealth has allowed him to retain his position as the 112th richest person in the world.

images.alt_text: CP Group senior chairman Dhanin Chearavont set a long term direction three decades ago when he pinpointed retail and telecoms as growth sectors of the future.
Henry Sy Jr, chairman of property giant SM Prime. attends a shareholders' meeting in Manila on April 14, 2015.
Vingroup Chairman Pham Nhat Vuong at the ceremony marking VinFast’s first shipment of electric SUVs to the US in November, 2022.

site_title: Foodpanda parent denies collapse in talks to sell South-east Asian units
summary: Delivery Hero has denied rumors of the collapse of talks to sell foodpanda units in selected South-east Asian markets. The company stated that negotiations for the potential sale are ongoing, contradicting reports suggesting a failed bid by Grab to acquire foodpanda due to a pricing dispute. The talks are expected to continue, with foodpanda Singapore and units in six other markets in the region potentially being sold.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia’s food delivery expenditure topped US$17.1 billion, growing by 5 per cent year on year.
Grab and Food Panda delivery riders at Bishan Junction 8 shopping mall on Aug 18, 2022.

site_title: Judge certifies Apple app store class action
summary: A federal judge certified a class action lawsuit against Apple, allowing tens of millions of customers to pursue a claim that the company's App Store monopoly led to higher prices. The lawsuit, which includes Apple account holders who spent $10 or more on app or in-app content, was initially denied certification in 2022 but was re-approved after the class was narrowed. The judge rejected Apple's bid to exclude testimony from two expert witnesses, including Nobel Prize-winning economist Daniel McFadden. The case, which has been ongoing for 12 years, is estimated to have incurred billions of dollars in damages.

images.alt_text: Sales of iPhones hit US$69.70 billion, growing 6 per cent to beat analyst expectations of US$67.82 billion.
The outages came the same week that Apple announced sweeping changes to the App Store in the European Union.

site_title: Bezos discloses plan to sell up to 50 million Amazon shares as stock surges
summary: Jeff Bezos plans to sell up to 50 million Amazon shares over the next 12 months, potentially cashing in on the stock surge that has narrowed his wealth gap with Elon Musk to $8.1 billion. The disclosure comes after Amazon reported its best online sales growth since the pandemic, sending its shares up 8% to $172. Bezos' wealth jumped $12.1 billion, putting him within reach of becoming the world's richest person. The planned sales, worth about $8.6 billion, are part of a trading plan adopted by Bezos, which complies with new Securities and Exchange Commission rules.

images.alt_text: After her divorce from Jeff Bezos in 2019, MacKenzie Scott ended up with roughly 4 per cent of the tech giant, a stake that was then worth around US$37 billion.

site_title: Europe: Shares stuck below 2-year highs as US data dashes rate optimism
summary: European shares remained near two-year highs, closing flat on Friday, as upbeat corporate earnings offset hotter-than-expected US jobs data that dashed hopes of an imminent US Federal Reserve rate cut. Germany's DAX 40 index hit a record high, while Danske Bank jumped 8.1% after reporting strong fourth-quarter results and announcing a share buyback program. Despite the positive earnings, the pan-European Stoxx 600 index hovered near its recent highs, weighed down by concerns over US economic data.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index has closed 0.5 per cent lower.

site_title: China’s investors take shots at state media spin
summary: China's state media attempted to boost investor sentiment with a report claiming the government's efforts have significantly improved people's livelihoods and well-being, but the move was met with skepticism, as stocks tumbled and internet users responded with sarcasm. The article came amid three years of losses that have wiped over $6 trillion from Chinese and Hong Kong equities since 2021, sparking concerns about the economy and stock market. The move was seen as a desperate attempt to counter growing gloom ahead of the Spring Festival.

images.alt_text: Elderly investors monitor price movements and make trades at a stocks exchange house in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, 30 May 2018.

site_title: Foreign interference law invoked for the first time against naturalised Singaporean businessman
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Home Affairs has served a notice to Philip Chan Man Ping, a 59-year-old naturalised Singaporean businessman, under the country's foreign interference laws. Chan, who is also the president of the Kowloon Club, has been assessed to be susceptible to foreign influence and willing to advance their interests. He is the first person to be dealt with under the Foreign Interference (Countermeasures) Act, a law that empowers authorities to deal with foreign interference in domestic politics.

images.alt_text: Naturalised Singaporean Philip Chan, who was born in Hong Kong, believed in uniting overseas Chinese to tell China’s story.
House passes foreign interference law after 10-hour debate

site_title: Son guides South Korea to Asian Cup semis with extra time against Australia
summary: South Korea advanced to the Asian Cup semis with a 2-1 comeback win over Australia in extra time, thanks to a late goal from Son Heung-min in stoppage time. The match forced extra time after a late equalizer by South Korea in the group stage against Jordan. South Korea will face Jordan in the first semi-final on Tuesday.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - International Friendly - South Korea v Vietnam - Suwon World Cup Stadium, Suwon, South Korea - October 17, 2023
South Korea's Son Heung-min REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Meritocracy and its discontents
summary: Singaporeans, particularly its younger generation, overwhelmingly support meritocracy, believing it to be a key factor in the nation's economic success. A survey of NUS students from 2020 to 2023 found that 81% of respondents approved of the concept, indicating a strong affinity for meritocracy. This positive view is attributed to meritocracy's ability to allocate resources based on talent and effort, rather than nepotism and patronage.

images.alt_text: If we keep an open mind in our talent recruitment, cast our net deep and wide enough and commit to a rigorous interview and selection process, we will naturally increase the diversity of our talent pool.
If meritocracy necessarily results in unequal outcomes, the question is: Can we rely on such a system to deliver good outcomes for everyone?

The government will invest in Singaporeans “throughout life”, said Education Minister Chan Chun Sing, ith plans to make training more accessible for working adults with competing commitments and support more targeted for mid-career workers, including SkillsFuture Credit top-ups.
Broaden and enhance meritocracy to give Singaporeans hope and opportunity: Ravi Menon
Rebooting meritocracy - change needed across the rungs

site_title: US auto safety agency upgrades probe into Tesla power steering loss
summary: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has upgraded its investigation into Tesla vehicles over power steering loss to an engineering analysis, covering about 334,000 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles from the 2023 model year. The agency has identified 2,388 complaints and linked one crash to the issue. Tesla has addressed some other issues with remote software fixes, but a potential recall could be more expensive if physical parts need to be replaced. This investigation follows a Reuters investigation that found premature failures of suspension and steering parts in Tesla vehicles.

images.alt_text: HW 4.0 has already been deployed on Tesla’s premium S and X models, as well as some Model Ys outside China.
Tesla’s arrangement appears to be a departure from CATL’s deal with Ford Motor, which aims to license the Chinese company’s technology to build batteries at a Michigan plant owned by the automaker.
Elon Musk testified during the compensation trial in November 2022 that the money would be used to finance interplanetary travel.

site_title: Who is Philip Chan, the man against whom Singapore has invoked its foreign interference law?
summary: Singapore has invoked its foreign interference law against 59-year-old naturalised citizen Philip Chan, a Hong Kong-born businessman, due to his perceived susceptibility to foreign influence and willingness to advance their interests. Chan, who has lived in Singapore for over 30 years, has been involved in various community organizations and has spoken out on China's behalf, stating it's his duty as an overseas Chinese to tell China's story and promote its culture. He faces a 14-day deadline to submit representations against the designation.

site_title: US dollar jumps, traders pare rate cut bets after strong jobs report
summary: The US dollar index jumped to a seven-week high, reaching 103.98, after strong jobs data showed a 353,000 increase in nonfarm payrolls in January, beating expectations. This reduced the chances of near-term Federal Reserve interest rate cuts, with traders now pricing in a 22% chance of a rate cut in March, down from 38% previously. The euro fell 0.8%, and the Australian dollar reached a 10-week low.

images.alt_text: Employment gains remain well above the roughly 100,000 jobs per month needed to keep up with growth in the working age population.

site_title: Singapore to host, fund Asean computer emergency response team to boost cybersecurity
summary: Singapore will fund and host the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) regional computer emergency response team (Cert) with a budget of S$10 million over the next decade. The team aims to facilitate the sharing of information on cyber incidents, foster capacity-building initiatives, and promote the exchange of best practices on protecting critical information infrastructure. The team will be co-located within the Asean-Singapore Cybersecurity Centre of Excellence. This move is expected to boost cybersecurity in the region and enhance the bloc's ability to respond to cyber threats.

images.alt_text:
(From left) Mira Tayyiba, Secretary General, Ministry of Communications and Informatics, Indonesia; Santisouk Simmalavong, Deputy Minister, Ministry of Technology and Communications, Laos); Gobind Singh Deo, Minister, Ministry of Digital, Malaysia; Ivan John E Uy, Secretary, Department of Information and Communications Technology, the Philippines); Phan Tam, Deputy Minister, Ministry of Information and Communications, Vietnam; Josephine Teo, Minister, Ministry of Communications and Information Singapore; Prasert Jantararuangtong, Minister, Ministry of Digital Economy and Society, Thailand; Pengiran Dato Shamhary Mustapha, Minister, Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications, Brunei; Chea Vandeth, Minister, Ministry of Post and Telecommunications, Cambodia; Miguel Marques Gonçalves Manetelu, Minister, Ministry of Transport and Communication, Timor-Leste; and Satvinder Singh, Deputy Secretary-General of Asean for Asean Economic Community

The region's digital ministers convene in Singapore for the fourth Asean Digital Ministers Meeting.

site_title: India's Tata Motors smashes Q3 profit estimates
summary: Tata Motors, India's most valuable carmaker, reported a two-fold increase in third-quarter profit, exceeding expectations, driven by strong sales of luxury cars from its Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) unit. Revenue rose 25% to 1.11 trillion rupees, with JLR accounting for two-thirds of the company's revenue. Despite sluggish demand in the domestic market, Tata Motors expanded its margins to 14.3%. The company's stock price surged, surpassing Maruti Suzuki to claim the title of India's most valuable carmaker.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Tata Motors logo is pictured outside the company showroom in Mumbai, India February 5, 2018. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

site_title: Frasers Property posts pre-sold revenue of S$2.4 billion as at Dec 2023; net gearing ratio up to 78%
summary: Frasers Property has reported pre-sold revenue of S$2.4 billion as of December 2023, with a net gearing ratio of 78% due to capital expenditure. The group remains focused on proactive debt management and is well-positioned to repay and/or refinance its debt. Strong sales were recorded in Australia, with 286 units sold in Q1, while Singapore's residential business remains resilient. The company expects housing demand to remain resilient in Singapore, driven by homeowners, and is focused on achieving better risk-adjusted returns and visibility of earnings and cash flows.

images.alt_text: InterContinental Singapore is one of the hotels under FHT's portfolio.

site_title: The unspoken conflict of interest at the heart of investment consulting
summary: Investment consultants claim their advice is conflict-free, but a bias exists due to their own self-interest. The industry's business model, which emphasizes asset allocation, active managers, and alternative asset classes, is often driven by the consultant's own interests rather than the client's needs. This can lead to complex and costly portfolios that may not add value. A growing community of academics and investment professionals is calling for a simpler and less expensive approach, where clients prioritize low-cost index funds and avoid alternative asset classes. Trustees must recognize the conflict of interest and open their minds to alternative strategies, while consultants must let go of their obsession with complexity and focus on providing trusted advice.

images.alt_text: Developing ongoing good investing habits may be the most important thing we can do this year and the only certain way to better prepare for a future that will always be uncertain.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 open higher on tech earnings cheer; strong jobs data weighs
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gaining 0.20% and 0.27% respectively, driven by strong quarterly reports from Meta Platforms and Amazon.com. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.19% to 38,448.10. A strong jobs report also contributed to the upbeat sentiment.

site_title:
China’s property financing measures to be tested 
by banks’ cautious approach
summary: China aims to boost financing for home projects through a "project whitelist" mechanism, recommending to banks residential projects in crisis-hit areas. However, banks are cautious due to concerns about asset quality and the impact on their balance sheets. The mechanism is part of Beijing's efforts to ease a liquidity squeeze and boost homebuyer confidence. Despite the initiative, many developers face significant funding shortfalls, with 20 million unconstructed homes and a total shortfall of 3.2 trillion yuan. Banks prioritize risk controls and may not extend fresh credit to struggling developers, limiting the effectiveness of the support measure.

site_title: English Premier League January transfer spending falls 88%: Deloitte
summary: English Premier League clubs spent £100 million in January, a 88% drop from last year, due to a more prudent approach after heavy spending in the close season and concerns over potential sanctions for failing to comply with the league's profit and sustainability rules. This is the lowest January transfer spending in three years. Despite the drop, clubs still spent £2.5 billion across the two transfer windows, making it the second-highest season on record.

images.alt_text: Real Madrid's Joselu has scored in his last two games against Atletico Madrid, and he will be hoping to continue that hot streak this weekend.

site_title: Alibaba considers sale of consumer assets including Freshippo, RT-Mart: sources
summary: Alibaba Group is considering the sale of its consumer assets, including Freshippo, RT-Mart, and shopping mall operator Intime, as it shifts focus to its core profitable e-commerce business model. The sale plan is part of Alibaba's strategy to divest non-core, loss-making units. The company has been in talks with strategic and financial investors about the assets, which are reportedly loss-making and not aligned with Alibaba's core business. The sale is seen as a move to optimize the company's portfolio and improve its profitability.

images.alt_text: James Dong, who heads Alibaba’s South-east Asian arm Lazada Group, will replace Daraz founder Bjarke Mikkelsen as acting CEO with immediate effect.

site_title: China criticizes IMF’s growth outlook, calls to boost confidence
summary: China criticized the International Monetary Fund's forecast of decelerating growth in the country, citing a deep property slump and weak external demand. The IMF predicts China's GDP will grow 4.6% this year and 3.5% in 2028, but China's economy is experiencing a deep property crisis and geopolitical tensions. The IMF recommended continued monetary policy accommodation and fiscal policies to boost confidence, but China disputed the report's findings, saying it was making "continued progress with data provision."

site_title: India’s quiet push to steal more of China’s iPhone business
summary: India is quietly gaining ground in manufacturing iPhones, with 13% of global production estimated to be assembled in the country last year, primarily in Tamil Nadu. Foxconn, a Taiwanese company, has played a significant role in this shift, with the Indian factory expected to double in volume by next year. Despite India's "Make in India" initiative, manufacturing as a share of the economy remains stagnant at around 16%. Tamil Nadu's state government has subsidized electronics manufacturing, attracting companies like Apple and Samsung, and is now focusing on high-end goods, including non-leather footwear.

images.alt_text: Apple is exploring ways to reduce its reliance on China as tensions between Washington and Beijing continue to escalate.

site_title: JPMorgan’s trades threaten to take privacy out of private credit
summary: JPMorgan's foray into private credit trading has raised concerns about the privacy of information about debt, a key selling point in the $1.7 trillion market. The bank's strategy involves market making, which could force lenders to value assets on a marked-to-market basis, potentially introducing volatility. Smaller fund managers and investors support trading for increased access and ability to exit assets, while larger lenders worry about the impact on their advantage. The move could undermine the private credit market's unique selling point and lead to changes in how assets are valued.

site_title: LME clearing house reshuffles management
summary: The London Metal Exchange's (LME) clearing house has reshuffled its management team with the appointment of new chief operating officer, chief risk officer, and head of clearing risk. The appointments, made by LME CEO Michael Carty, aim to ensure the clearing house's strong position as it drives forward its strategy. Chris Jones becomes operations chief, Matt Wade takes on chief risk officer duties, and Paul Kirkwood replaces Jones as head of clearing risk. The moves come after the LME recovered from a 2022 nickel crisis that sparked a legal battle and regulatory investigation.

site_title: US consumer sentiment increases sharply at start of 2024
summary: US consumer sentiment surged in January, rising 9.3 points to 79, the most since 2005, as retreating inflation boosted views on the economy and household finances. Americans expect prices to climb 2.9% over the next year and 2.9% over the next 5-10 years. The increase in confidence could sustain household demand and keep the economy on an expansion path, while declining inflation expectations may reassure Federal Reserve policymakers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 2)
summary: DBS Group is merging its treasury markets, equity capital markets, brokerage, and digital exchange into a single entity called Global Financial Markets. The move comes after the retirement of Eng-Kwok Seat Moey, group head of capital markets, after 36 years. CapitaLand Ascott Trust is selling Citadines Mount Sophia Singapore for S$148 million. Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition will pay a redemption price of S$5.18 for Class-A shares. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is seeking to reduce client information collected by financial institutions for certain insurance policies.

site_title: Singapore’s PMI rises further in January, echoing region’s improved factory activity
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed further improvement in January, with the PMI rising to 50.7, a 0.2-point gain from the previous month. The electronics sector expanded for the third consecutive month, with a 0.4-point gain to 50.6. This marks the fifth straight month of expansion and the highest reading since December 2021. Economists attribute the growth to the ongoing recovery in the electronics sector and a projected upturn for the year. However, external factors such as elevated interest rates and ongoing geopolitical risks may continue to weigh on the sector's growth.

images.alt_text: Excluding the biomedical cluster, factory output grew 0.5 per cent in December.
The export index may have been affected by the Lunar New Year which will fall on Feb 10 this year, as factories and workers geared up for the pre-holiday shipment of goods.

site_title: World food price index falls near 3-year lows in January: FAO
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization's (FAO) world food price index fell to 118.0 points in January, its lowest level in nearly three years, due to declines in cereals and meat prices. Global wheat export prices declined due to strong competition among exporters, while maize prices dropped as improved crop conditions and larger supplies in the US contributed to the decrease. The meat price index declined for the seventh consecutive month due to abundant supplies from leading exporting countries.

images.alt_text: Starbucks, which once accounted for more than half of China’s coffee market, lost its crown as the biggest chain last year to local rival Luckin.
Traders and officials expect Asian rice production in the first half of 2024 to drop, as dry planting conditions and shrinking reservoirs are likely to cut yields.
After retreating for most of September and October, rice price gains quickened again in November.
The Food and Agriculture Organization’s (FAO) price index averages 120.4 points in November, around October’s levels which were the lowest since March 2021.

site_title: Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine Holdings to raise S$26.2 million in Catalist listing
summary: Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine Holdings (SIAMH) is raising S$26.2 million through a Catalist listing, offering 114 million shares at S$0.23 apiece. The company, which focuses on diagnosing and treating various diseases, including cancer, aims to become a "one-stop ambulatory treatment centre" for cancer patients. SIAMH will use the funds to repay bank borrowings, working capital, and acquire new equipment and facilities. The company's market capitalization will be S$231.8 million after listing.

images.alt_text: Incorporated in 2011 and founded by Dr Djeng Shih Kien, SIAMH focuses on diagnosing and treating various diseases and health conditions.

site_title: China regulator urges banks to improve credit management
summary: China's financial regulator has issued measures urging commercial banks to improve credit management and better serve the real economy. The measures, effective July 1, 2024, include simplifying loan approval processes for small and micro enterprises and personal loans under 200,000 yuan. Banks must also reasonably determine internal performance evaluation targets and avoid "vicious competition" and unreasonable lending targets. The regulator aims to improve the quality and efficiency of the financial industry serving the economy.

site_title: MBS partners Care Corner to ring in Chinese New Year with seniors
summary: MARINA Bay Sands (MBS) partnered non-profit organisation Care Corner Singapore to celebrate Chinese New Year with seniors at a reunion lunch. Over 40 MBS volunteers and nearly 80 seniors participated in activities, games, and performances. This event marks the continuation of the partnership between Care Corner and Sands Cares, MBS' community engagement programme, supporting seniors who are socially isolated or have limited access to support. Since 2021, over 350 seniors have been supported through the Neighbour Cares programme.

site_title: Missing China banker Bao Fan resurfaces after a year to resign
summary: Chinese banker Bao Fan, who disappeared in February 2023 and was placed under detention, has resigned as chairman and CEO of China Renaissance Holdings, effective February 2. He cited "health reasons" and a desire to spend more time with his family. Bao, a former banker at Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse, co-founded China Renaissance in 2005 and was known for brokering deals that led to the formation of Didi Global and Meituan. His resignation comes amid a broader graft crackdown on the financial sector.

site_title: Exxon beats estimates, ends 2023 with a US$36 billion profit
summary: ExxonMobil reported a record-breaking $36 billion profit for 2023, exceeding estimates, driven by fuels trading and higher oil and gas production. The company's earnings were also boosted by a 4% increase in capital spending and the planned acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources, set to close in the second quarter. Exxon's annual income fell 35% to $38.57 billion, excluding a $2.5 billion impairment charge for California properties. The company's shares were down less than 1% in pre-market trading, but CEO Darren Woods signaled optimism about the coming year.

site_title: US factory orders rise moderately in December
summary: US factory orders rose 0.2% in December, rebounding from a 2.6% increase in November, according to the Commerce Department's Census Bureau. This modest gain was in line with economists' expectations and marked an increase of 0.8% on a year-on-year basis. The moderate rise is attributed to the ongoing constraint of high interest rates on manufacturing, which accounts for 10.3% of the economy. Despite this, the outlook is promising, suggesting a potential pick-up in orders in the months ahead due to unfilled orders.

site_title: China stocks swing wildly in chaotic end to worst week in years
summary: China's key stock benchmarks plummeted over 3% on Friday, before rebounding, marking the worst week since 2018. The CSI 300 Index closed down 1.2%, as investor confidence remains shattered due to economic and geopolitical risks. Forced stock sales, margin calls, and technical selloffs are contributing to the market's distress. Chinese authorities have introduced monetary stimulus, but it has failed to restore confidence, leaving investors with little faith in the market's prospects.

images.alt_text: Disappointment over the Federal Reserve’s warning this week that borrowing costs would not likely be cut in March was tempered by the knowledge they are all but certain to come down this year.

site_title: Temasek takes profit on insurance portal Policybazaar as India’s tech stocks rally
summary: Temasek, a Singapore state investor, has sold a 5.4% stake in Indian-listed PB Fintech, owner of online insurance platform Policybazaar, generating a 40% internal rate of return. This sale follows a 129.4% gain in PB Fintech shares over the past year, as India's tech stocks rallied. The sale price was 24.25 billion Indian rupees (S$391 million), equivalent to 14 times invested capital. Temasek continues to own an indirect stake in the company.

images.alt_text: Investments will range from outright acquisitions to greenfield projects and partnerships, Citi’s India investment banking head Rahul Saraf says.
The instrument will be rated Aaa by ratings agency Moody’s, said Temasek.

site_title: Chevron beats Q4 estimates, but annual profits fall nearly 40%
summary: Chevron reported a 40% decline in annual profit to $21.3 billion, but beat Q4 earnings estimates. Despite the loss, the company plans to increase its dividend by 8% as a sign of confidence. Oil and gas production rose 10% in the Permian basin, but lower prices and foreign currency hits offset gains. Chevron's cash flow from operations fell due to lower commodity prices and refined product margins, and its return on capital employed fell to 5.1%. The company has increased its project spending budget for 2024 and acquired oil production and reserves.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chevron logo is seen in this illustration taken, October 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Chevron expects total capital expenditures to rise to between US$19 billion and US$22 billion following the proposed acquisition of US rival Hess Corp closes next year.

To access funding from the programme, companies will need to commit to cutting methane intensity by below 0.2 per cent, halting routine flaring of natural gas by 2030 and measuring and reporting emissions.

site_title: JAL expects US$14 million in lost revenue due to Haneda jet crash
summary: Japan Airlines (JAL) expects to incur a revenue loss of around $13.6 million due to the fatal jet crash at Tokyo Haneda airport in January, which killed 5 crew members and injured 1. The incident also forced JAL to take the A350 out of service. Despite this, the airline's third-quarter income beat average analyst estimates, with net income reaching 24.2 billion yen and sales totaling 428.4 billion yen. JAL plans to compensate for the A350's loss with other planes and has not seen significant impact on forward bookings.

images.alt_text: All 379 people aboard the JAL airliner managed to evacuate the burning plane after the collision with the Coast Guard aircraft at Tokyo’s Haneda airport on Jan 2, 2024.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after tech-fuelled Wall Street surge
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday, tracking a surge on Wall Street fueled by bargain-buying from the previous day's sell-off. Strong earnings from tech titans and a softening US labor market boosted optimism about interest rate cuts this year. Despite the Federal Reserve's warning that borrowing costs won't be cut in March, traders expect a rate cut by the end of 2024. The non-farm payrolls report later Friday will be closely watched, with some predicting a rate cut if the jobs report shows a jump in unemployment.

images.alt_text: After a broadly disappointing January for the region’s markets, the news meant February got off to an inauspicious start with Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta all down.

site_title: Birth of luxury post-partum confinement services
summary: Singapore's luxury post-partum confinement services have seen a surge in demand, with parents willing to pay up to twice their combined monthly income for 28-day packages that offer round-the-clock care, nutritious meals, and lactation experts. The centres, which have been popping up in the past three years, cater to the growing affluence and changing cultural norms among the working class. Despite the high cost, many parents opt for these services, citing the perceived higher quality of care and the ability to stay worry-free during work hours. With the Year of the Dragon believed to be an auspicious time for childbirth, demand for such services is expected to rise, with operators already exploring ways to enter the market catered to the rich and setting up facilities in neighboring Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The reluctance to tie the knot is worrying policymakers in China, who are grappling with a decline in births and a rapidly ageing population in what was once the world’s most populous country.

It is necessary to “actively cultivate a new culture of marriage and childbearing and strengthen guidance on young people’s view on marriage, childbirth and family,” says Chinese President Xi Jinping.
Egg freezing typically run from around 300,000 to 600,000 yen but can reach into the millions.

site_title: Hong Kong insurer FWD Group cuts around 50 jobs: sources
summary: Hong Kong insurer FWD Group has cut around 50 jobs in its head offices, mainly in Hong Kong and Singapore. The job cuts were part of a routine review and adjustment to ensure a skilled and sized team to support its fast-growing pan-Asian business. The move was not made public, with only two sources confirming the information.

images.alt_text: Richard Li's PCG has hired JPMorgan to run the sales process and has held preliminary discussions with a number of financial institutions.

site_title: Sentence halved for Malaysia’s ex-PM Najib jailed in 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak, serving a 12-year jail term for his role in the 1MDB scandal, had his sentence halved by a pardons board, allowing him to be released by August 2028. The decision sparked criticism from critics and investors, who view it as a setback for the country's anti-corruption efforts. Najib's reduced sentence comes amid accusations that the current Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is backsliding on his promised reforms.

images.alt_text: epa10134267 Malaysia's former prime minister Najib Razak (C) speaks to his supporters during a break in his final appeal trial outside the Federal Court in Putrajaya, Malaysia, 23 August 2022. The Malaysia highest court has scheduled hearings through 26 August 2022 to hear Najib's appeal of his convictions for criminal breach of trust, abuse of power and money laundering over the alleged theft of 4.4 billion Euro from 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a state fund he co-founded as premier in 2009.  EPA-EFE/AHMAD LUQMAN ISMAIL

site_title: Issue 86: The profusion of fusion interest; Thailand’s ESG tax breaks
summary: Singapore considers fusion as a regional hub due to its nascent green-energy technologies. The country could be a hub for fusion research, but it faces challenges in making an economic or business case for investing in a high-risk endeavor. Despite the risks, interest in fusion technology has increased, with cumulative funding growing 29% to US$6.2 billion in 2022. Thailand, on the other hand, has seen a surge in ESG fund flows, with investors putting US$2.5 billion into the region in the fourth quarter of 2023. Thailand has introduced a tax break scheme to boost investor interest in ESG funds, with 22 new funds launched in the fourth quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: Chinese car maker BYD has clinched the top electric vehicle seller from Tesla globally.
Kirsten van Zandwijk, director of sustainability and partnerships for Asean & South Pacific at The Coca-Cola Company, and SembWaste chief executive officer Kok Kin Lee.
Indonesia’s state energy firm Pertamina has agreed with US oil majors ExxonMobil and Chevron to discuss investment of CCS projects in Indonesia.
Climate adaptation investments remain a fraction of what is required, noted the ADB.
While there ought to be transparency, some corporate decisions are best made in private, and some facts (for example about relative pay) are best kept secret.

site_title: BT Explains: Why do Singapore-listed Spacs have vastly different redemption prices?
summary: Two Singapore-listed Spacs, Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition (NTAA) and Pegasus Asia, have differing redemption prices despite having the same initial public offering (IPO) price of S$5 per unit. NTAA's redemption price of S$5.18 per share is higher than Pegasus Asia's S$5.03 per share, influenced by factors such as initial capital raised, cash-management strategies, and the number of redeemable shares. Analysts advise investors to consider a Spac's fees, costs, and cash-management plans when evaluating its potential redemption price, rather than solely focusing on the redemption price itself.

images.alt_text: NTAA is one of three Spacs listed on the Singapore Exchange in January 2022, alongside Pegasus Asia and Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation.
The payment of the redemption amount will be made on or about Feb 13, Pegasus said in a bourse filing.
Pegasus Asia is reportedly expected to release its announcement by Dec 22, while Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition's will be released next week.
Since the business combination was completed on Dec 8, 17Live has been in the red every day. The sell-off had already started earlier in December, when it was still trading as VTAC.

Left: Ng Jing Shen, chief technology officer of 17Live. The live-streaming platform listed on the Singapore Exchange after completing a business combination with Vertex Technology Acquisition Company.

The number of outstanding shares to calculate redepmtion price includes the shares held by Venezio and the sponsor Vertex Venture Holdings, but excludes the promote shares, says VTAC.

The Spac’s shareholders are due to meet at 2 pm on Friday to vote on the business combination with e-commerce streaming company 17Live.  If the proposed combination does not pass, the redemption requests will be cancelled.
VTAC, led by non-executive chairman Chua Kee Lock,  has endorsed the merger, citing 17Live’s strong management, the potential for scale, and its alignment with Vertex Holdings’ areas of expertise.
Phillip Securities says VTAC shareholders should redeem their shares at the price range of S$5 to S$5.02 apiece.

site_title: Europe’s football titans collide in top-of-the-table showdowns
summary: Top-of-the-table showdowns are expected in Europe's football leagues this weekend. In the English Premier League, Arsenal faces Liverpool in a crucial match to keep their EPL title hopes alive. Meanwhile, Inter Milan and Juventus clash in the Serie A, with both teams vying for the league title. In La Liga, Real Madrid hosts Atletico Madrid in a highly anticipated derby, with Real seeking revenge after losing to Atletico in their previous match. These matches promise to be exciting and goal-filled, with many teams battling for crucial points.

images.alt_text: Sheffield United's Oli McBurnie (second from right, wearing #9) celebrates with his teammates after netting a penalty in the 103rd minute against West Ham4.
“Sorry, I am aware that this missed penalty led to our elimination from this Cup of Nations,” he posted on X, formerly Twitter.
Jude Bellingham’s move to Real Madrid is one of the top transfers in 2023.

site_title: MAS seeks to reduce client information collected by financial institutions for some insurance products
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is seeking feedback on proposals to reduce the amount of client information collected by financial institutions for term life insurance and standard critical illness policies. These policies, recommended based on the Basic Financial Planning Guide, will be affected by the proposals. The MAS aims to simplify the process and enhance clients' financial well-being. The proposals are part of an effort to help Singaporeans take proactive steps to address their savings, insurance, and investment needs.

images.alt_text: The changes proposed include extending the scheme to cover mandatory third-party liability insurance that businesses purchase for specified mobility devices such as bicycle, personal mobility device, power-assisted bicycle, motorised wheelchair or mobility scooter.
Given the rising numbers, insurers in Singapore have increasingly been looking to extend their services to reach the growing segment of individuals.
The transactions, subject to regulatory approvals in Japan and Singapore, are expected to complete in Q1 of 2024.
The newly issued best practices include cooperation among industry players to mitigate “rolling bad apples” – that is, to prevent individuals with prior misconduct from re-entering the industry.

site_title: McLaren 750S review: The one with the waggly tail
summary: McLaren's 750S is a high-performance sportscar that delivers scintillating performance with 750 horsepower, taking a classic approach by focusing on pure combustion power and minimizing weight. The car's design allows it to be both violently intense when needed and civilized for everyday driving, making it a more practical choice for those who want the thrill of a Formula 1 racing car without the hassle. The 750S is a great alternative for those seeking a high-performance vehicle that balances power and practicality.

images.alt_text: Mercedes’ GLC 300 4Matic Coupe wraps its mechanical bits inside a stylish take on the SUV format.
Alfa Romeo Stelvio

site_title: Japan's Mizuho reports 8.2% rise in Q3 profit on strong lending business
summary: Mizuho Financial Group, Japan's third-largest lender by assets, reported an 8.2% increase in quarterly net profit to 226.57 billion yen (S$2.06 billion) in the October-December period, driven by strong lending business and subdued loan-loss provisions. The bank maintained its full-year profit forecast at 640 billion yen, beating analysts' estimates. This solid performance follows similar results from larger domestic rival Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, as Japanese companies invest in growth opportunities.

site_title: Stablecoin Tether’s market dominance may jeopardise crypto, JPMorgan says
summary: JPMorgan warns that Tether's growing market dominance as the largest stablecoin could be a risk for the cryptocurrency market, citing a lack of regulatory compliance and transparency. Tether's USDT token is on the verge of surpassing $100 billion in circulation, and stablecoins may face increased regulation in the US and Europe. JPMorgan analysts suggest that stablecoin issuers aligned with existing regulations may benefit from the regulatory crackdown and gain market share.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins are typically pegged 1-1 to fiat currencies and backed by reserves of cash and bonds.
Stablecoins are a form of cryptocurrency backed by an asset or fiat currency.
Paxos is also looking to partner with enterprise clients to issue the USD-backed stablecoin in Singapore once it receives full approval from the regulator.
Circle has raised money from investors including Goldman Sachs Group, General Catalyst Partners, BlackRock, Fidelity Management and Research and Marshall Wace.

site_title: Lessons from the euro’s first 25 years
summary: The euro has delivered on maintaining price stability but failed to facilitate economic and political integration in the 25 years since its introduction. The eurozone's incomplete institutional framework has proven costly and dangerous, with significant imbalances emerging between member states. To address these issues, the European Union must finalize the banking union and push forward the capital market union. EU leaders must strike a balance between risk sharing and risk reduction, and formulate a cohesive European industrial policy to safeguard the single market. Completing the euro is crucial for safeguarding the EU's greatest achievement.

images.alt_text: A potential second term as European Commission chief for Ursula von der Leyen will have a huge role in defining the EU’s longer-term political and economic character.

Launched by 11 countries at the start of 1999, the euro stayed an electronic currency for its first three years. The euro area now includes 20 countries, making it the payment method for some 350 million people.

site_title: Indonesia's Jokowi insists 'no problem' in Cabinet amid rumbles of discontent
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo (Jokowi) has dismissed rumors of discontent among his Cabinet members, stating "the Cabinet has no problem" amidst speculation of potential resignations, including Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati. Critics have accused Jokowi of political interference and bias ahead of the February 14 election, with his son joining the campaign of rival candidate Prabowo Subianto. Jokowi is nearing the end of his second term, which is the maximum allowed for an Indonesian president, and his actions have raised concerns about the country's democratic process.

images.alt_text: (From left) Presidential candidates along with their running mates Ganjar Pranowo, Mahfud MD, Prabowo Subianto, Gibran Rakabuming Raka, Anies Baswedan and Muhaimin Iskandar, pose for a group photo after delivering their anti-corruption policies during a dialogue held by the country's anti-graft agency Corruption Eradication Commission, Jakarta, Indonesia, Jan 17, 2024.

site_title: Gold heads for best week in seven ahead of US jobs data
summary: Gold prices are poised for their best week in seven ahead of US jobs data, with spot gold flat at $2,053.09 per ounce. The US dollar and Treasury yields retreated, supporting gold prices, while concerns over the regional banking sector in the US increased demand for safe-haven assets. The US Federal Reserve expressed confidence in inflation moving towards the 2% range, but traders remain optimistic about a potential rate cut in May.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall St gains to end higher on Friday; STI up 1.2%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week higher, up 1.2% or 36.71 points to 3,179.77, tracking gains on Wall Street. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 325 to 257, with 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changing hands. Most regional indices also ended the day higher, while the Hang Seng Index fell 0.2%.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's DPU falls 6.1 per cent year on year to 7.441 Singapore cents for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 81 to 25.

site_title: New Zealand home building consents drop to five-year low
summary: New Zealand's residential building consents dropped to a five-year low in 2023, with a 25% decline from the previous year to 37,239. The decline is attributed to increasing construction costs and high interest rates discouraging homebuyers and developers. Standalone house approvals fell 27% to 15,675, while multi-unit homes dropped 23% to 21,564. The slowdown may cool economic growth, but record immigration could boost house prices.

site_title: Amazon adds AI shopping companion named Rufus to retail store
summary: Amazon has introduced Rufus, an AI shopping companion, to help customers comparison shop and answer complex queries. Rufus can assist with tasks such as starting an indoor garden or finding Valentine's Day gift ideas. The AI-powered tool is available to a small subset of Amazon mobile app users and is seen as a response to the rise of generative AI tools like OpenAI's ChatGPT. This move comes as Amazon prepares to report fourth-quarter earnings results, following similar expansions by Walmart and other tech companies.

site_title: Japan’s Marubeni posts 20% drop in 9-month profit on lower resource prices
summary: Japan's trading house Marubeni reported a 20% drop in 9-month profit to 371.5 billion yen (S$3.4 billion) due to lower resource prices and a one-off gain from last year's sale of a US grain business. The company stuck to its full-year profit forecast of 450 billion yen. This decline is attributed to lower coking coal and energy prices, affecting Marubeni's revenue.

images.alt_text: Marubeni, which plans to invest around £1 billion (S$1.67 billion) on its own, expects various support from the UK government, including helping the offshore wind power project to ensure stable revenue from selling power.

site_title: Tencent, Nexon soar after approval for marquee game
summary: Chinese regulators approved Mobile DnF, a marquee game developed by Tencent and Nexon, boosting the companies' stock prices. Tencent gained 5.9% in Hong Kong, while Nexon traded limit-up in Tokyo, with a record daily gain of over 20%. The approval is a significant boost for Tencent's 2024 pipeline, which relies on years-old titles and is seeking new blockbusters. The game had been delayed since 2020 due to regulatory restrictions aimed at curbing addiction among Chinese minors.

images.alt_text: Pony Ma says that the new games that Tencent has launched, have not performed as well as the company had hoped.
Tencent Holdings' Riot Games, whose popular titles include League of Legends, said teams outside of core development will see the largest impact from layoffs.
Tencent, the largest Chinese company by market value, is considered crucial to reviving the world’s No 2 economy.

site_title: Indonesia’s January drought points to lower rice harvest, higher imports
summary: Indonesia's January drought is expected to lead to a lower-than-expected rice harvest, potentially tightening global supplies and driving up prices. The country's rice output is forecast to drop 46% from last year, with the government expecting a delay in the March-April peak harvest due to below-normal precipitation. This could lead to higher imports, particularly from top exporters Thailand, Vietnam, and India, which are also experiencing lower output. Indonesian rice prices have already risen 15.6% year-over-year, and the country's initial forecast of 32 million tonnes of rice output has been undercut.

images.alt_text: Vietnam and the Philippines have competing claims over some parts of the South China Sea, a conduit for US$3 trillion of annual ship-borne trade that China claims almost in its entirety.

India’s rice output is expected to drop this fiscal year for the first time in eight years, raising the prospect of New Delhi extending curbs on exports of the grain to control food prices in the lead-up to elections.
India is expected to keep its export restrictions in place until at least a general election in April or May.

site_title: Mercedes reports strong cash flow on lower working capital
summary: Mercedes-Benz Group reported strong industrial cash flow of €11.3 billion in 2023, exceeding analyst estimates of €9.5 billion. The company benefited from lower working capital levels and a favorable cash conversion rate. This improvement helped offset global economic headwinds and allowed Mercedes to direct resources to electric vehicles and high-end models. The company did not disclose full-year earnings, which will be reported on February 22.

site_title: Swedish home prices resume climb in first month of the year
summary: Sweden's home prices rose 3% in January, breaking a declining trend, according to data from state-owned lender SBAB. This increase may be attributed to a pent-up need to change homes after a long period of low turnover. However, SBAB chief economist Robert Boije cautioned that the data should be viewed with caution, citing factors such as high supply, long transaction times, and low bidder numbers, which don't indicate a significant rise in housing prices.

site_title: SK Hynix favours Indiana over Arizona for US$15 billion chip site
summary: SK Hynix, a South Korean chipmaker, is set to choose Indiana over Arizona for a $15 billion advanced packaging facility, marking a major US investment. The firm first announced the project in 2022 and has been weighing its options since. Although Indiana is the preferred choice, SK Hynix still considers Arizona as a second option. The project is seen as a win for the Midwest and a step towards building a full US semiconductor supply chain, following other firms' investments totaling over $230 billion since President Biden's 2022 Chips Act.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix is expected to begin mass production of the next version of HBM, called HBM3E, in the first half of the year.
SK Hynix is expected to report holiday-quarter earnings later this month.
Investors have placed orders worth more than US$1.5 billion on Monday, according to a message sent by the deal’s bookrunners.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday’s open; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% at the market open on Friday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index reached 3,158.38, with gainers outnumbering losers 81 to 25. Key gainers included DBS, UOB, and OCBC banking stocks, while Seatrium and Thai Beverage also saw gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 1.0% and 1.3%, respectively, following a pullback on European shares.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's DPU falls 6.1 per cent year on year to 7.441 Singapore cents for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023.

site_title: Facebook parent Meta declares first dividend, shares soar
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, declared its first dividend and reported strong quarterly revenue and profit, beating Wall Street expectations. The company's shares soared 14% and its stock market valuation surged by over $140 billion. Revenue rose 25% to $40.1 billion, and earnings per share increased over 200% to $14 billion. Meta also announced plans to authorise an additional $50 billion in share repurchases and invest in its metaverse and AI technologies, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg saying the company is making progress on its vision for advancing AI and the metaverse.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Woman holds smartphone with Facebook logo in front of a displayed Facebook's new rebrand logo Meta in this illustration picture taken October 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Meta has already proven that its work in AI can produce results for its advertisers.

site_title: Singapore’s corporate tax takings in first 9 months of FY23 almost at full-year estimate
summary: Singapore's corporate income tax receipts for the first nine months of FY23 are ahead of the historical pace, reaching almost the full-year estimate. Personal income tax receipts have also surpassed 80% of the target, while goods and services tax (GST) takings are lagging. Overall operating revenue is ahead of the pace, despite an uncertain economic environment, according to DBS economist Chua Han Teng.

images.alt_text: Some watchers believe it may be time for the government to consider a review of Singapore's tax-free threshold of S$20,000, which has not changed since 2003,

Despite global uncertainties and China's challenging restructuring, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat believes that a global recession is unlikely in 2024, and the ASEAN economy will continue to grow. PHOTO: JASON QUAH, ST

site_title: DBS to merge treasury markets, equity capital markets, brokerage and digital exchange
summary: DBS is merging its treasury markets, equity capital markets, brokerage, and digital exchange businesses, renaming the enlarged group Global Financial Markets (GFM) starting March 1. The move follows the retirement of veteran banker Eng-Kwok Seat Moey, who led the bank's treasury market expansion in the region. The merger aims to improve synergy and efficiency, with Andrew Ng overseeing the group as head of GFM. The changes are seen as a positive move for DBS, allowing it to grow internally and continue innovation without acquiring new business ventures.

images.alt_text: DBS customers can soon enable the digiVault function on their existing bank accounts, without needing to open a separate account.
The weekly hawker meal subsidies, first launched in February 2023, will be extended for six months.
DBS will up its stake in Shenzhen Rural Commercial Bank to 16.6 per cent after gaining regulatory approvals.

site_title: Citi expects big year for India M&As with capital flowing from far and wide
summary: Citi's India investment banking head Rahul Saraf expects a big year for mergers and acquisitions (M&As) in India, driven by capital from sovereign wealth funds, the Middle East, and elsewhere. Investments will range from outright acquisitions to greenfield projects and partnerships, particularly in industrials, manufacturing, IT services, and insurance. Deal volume is expected to increase as financial sponsors and pension funds invest in Indian infrastructure, real estate, and green energy, fueled by the country's economic growth and a booming stock market.

images.alt_text: Citigroup last week said it would cut 20,000 jobs over the next two years, after a fourth quarter marred by one-off charges that resulted in a US$1.8 billion loss.
Citigroup
The cuts are going to make a small dent in the Citi’s regional research workforce where it has several hundred employees based in multiple markets.

site_title: Okta to cut 400 jobs following tech peers in reducing costs
summary: Okta, a software company, is cutting 400 employees, approximately 7% of its staff, to reduce costs. The job cuts are part of a trend among tech firms, following Amazon, Alphabet's Google, and Salesforce. The company estimates a $24 million severance and benefits cost in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2024. Despite the layoffs, Okta reaffirmed its quarterly guidance and announced financial results on February 28. The company's shares rose 2.6% after the announcement.

site_title: Japan’s Aozora loses 33% of its value in two-day stock meltdown
summary: Japan's Aozora Bank reported its first loss in 15 years due to bad loans tied to US commercial property. The bank's stock value plummeted 33% over two days, wiping out $1.2 billion in market capitalization. Aozora had loaned aggressively in the US, betting on stable office market returns, but prices cratered when Covid-19 led to widespread remote work. The bank's small size and lack of geographic strength made it vulnerable to the market downturn, with analysts citing poor risk management as a major contributor to the loss.

images.alt_text: The Aozora Bank Ltd. headquarters in Tokyo Japan, on Thursday, Feb. 1, 2024. Japan's Aozora Bank became the second lender in a span of hours to surprise investors with losses tied to US commercial property, sending shares down by the limit and heightening concern over global banks' exposure to souring real estate bets. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Paytm stock crashes for second day on RBI order, CEO seeks to reassure
summary: Paytm's shares plummeted 36% for the second consecutive day after the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) ordered its banking arm to stop accepting fresh deposits and credit transactions. The RBI cited non-compliance with rules and supervisory concerns that spanned years. Despite CEO Vijay Shekhar Sharma's reassurances, Paytm's shares are near record lows, valuing the company at $3.7 billion. The RBI's order prohibits Paytm Payments Bank from further deposits, credit transactions, or wallet uploads, potentially limiting its services on the app unless it finds a new banking partner.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with the Paytm logo is placed on a laptop in this illustration taken on July 14, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: South Korea consumer inflation softens to six-month low
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation slowed to a six-month low in January, with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 2.8% year-over-year, the lowest since July 2023. The slowdown was driven by a fall in oil prices, with petroleum products down 2.5% over the month. The central bank has indicated it's done raising interest rates, but inflation may rebound to around 3% in February and March due to rising oil prices. Core CPI, excluding volatile items, rose 2.5%, its weakest since December 2021.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust to sell Citadines Mount Sophia Singapore for S$148 million
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust is selling Citadines Mount Sophia Singapore for S$148 million, 19.4% above its book value as of 2023. The sale is expected to result in a net gain of S$14.6 million and net proceeds of S$138.6 million. The divestment is part of the trust's strategy to reduce debt and increase financial flexibility, with plans to redeploy capital into higher-yielding investments. The sale also follows news of a potential acquisition by Weave Living, which has acquired a property at the same address through a joint venture with BlackRock.

images.alt_text: Citadines City Centre Frankfurt is one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s (CLAS) properties. As at the end of September, the stapled group’s net asset value per stapled security stood at S$1.12.
The Cavendish London, one of the three lodging assets CapitaLand Ascott Trust will acquire from sponsor The Ascott.
Citadines City Centre Lille is one of the four properties divested in regional France.
Serena Teo, chief executive officer of CapitaLand Ascott Trust's managers

site_title: Mortgage rates in the US slip to 6.63% while Fed holds the line
summary: US mortgage rates fell to 6.63%, down from 6.69% last week, providing support to the housing market. However, relief for homebuyers may be delayed as the Federal Reserve holds the line on interest rates, citing concerns about inflation rebounding. Despite this, the economy is expected to continue outperforming due to solid job and income growth, and favourable factors such as increasing household formation. Affordability remains a challenge, with inventory still tight and many homeowners reluctant to move due to more expensive loans.

images.alt_text: Buyers have been sidelined by high mortgage rates, which hit a recent peak in October at 7.79 per cent.
High borrowing costs have caused sales of previously owned homes to slide to the lowest level in nearly three decades.

site_title: Meta, Amazon stocks surge by US$270 billion as cost cuts cheer investors
summary: Meta Platforms and Amazon.com reported better-than-expected earnings, with Meta unveiling a $50 billion stock buyback and its first-ever quarterly dividend. The companies' cost-cutting strategies, which included layoffs, appear to have paid off for investors, with combined stock prices surging $270 billion. Meta's shares rose 15% and Amazon's stock increased 7% in extended trading. The strong business results raise questions about whether the companies should invest heavily again, with Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg expressing a desire to maintain a "leaner company" and Amazon's CEO Andy Jassy vowing to continue reducing costs.

images.alt_text: Meta forecast first quarter revenue of US$34.5 billion to US$37 billion, above Wall Street expectations of US$33.8 billion.
The company forecast current-quarter revenue of US$138 billion to US$143.5 billion.

site_title: EC chief seeks era-defining economic legacy
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is seeking a second term, which could define the EU's economic legacy. As the bloc marks the 25th anniversary of the euro, von der Leyen aims to leave a lasting impact, similar to her predecessor Jacques Delors. Despite facing criticism and multiple crises, including the pandemic and Ukraine war, von der Leyen's period in office has seen significant achievements, such as the Green Deal and debt-raising powers. However, some argue that her legacy will be defined by the challenges she faces, including euroscepticism and domestic and external risks, in her potential second term.

images.alt_text: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen speaks during a press conference as part of the 29th EU-Japan Summit at The European Union Building in Brussels on July 13, 2023. (Photo by JOHN THYS / AFP)
EU reaches 'historic' 750b euro deal on post-pandemic recovery after marathon summit
Jacques Delors headed the European Commission from 1985 to 1995, a decade that saw major steps in the bloc’s integration.

site_title: US manufacturing sector on cusp of recovery in January: ISM
summary: The US manufacturing sector is on the cusp of recovery, according to the Institute for Supply Management (ISM), with its manufacturing PMI increasing to 49.1 in January from 47.1 in December. The sector has contracted for 15 consecutive months, the longest stretch since 2000-2002. New orders rebounded to 52.5, while production and supplier deliveries improved slightly. However, inflation at the factory gate picked up, and factory employment remained subdued. The ISM's forward-looking new orders sub-index indicates a potential turnaround in the sector.

site_title: Novo Tellus to pay redemption price of around S$5.184 for Class-A shares
summary: Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition (NTAA) will pay a redemption price of around S$5.18 per Class-A share, with the payment to be made on Feb 21. The Spac, backed by Novo Tellus Capital Partners, initially stated it would not conclude a business combination due to market conditions. This decision follows Pegasus Asia's similar announcement. NTAA will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on Feb 22, after its trading suspension from Feb 9.

images.alt_text: The payment of the redemption amount will be made on or about Feb 13, Pegasus said in a bourse filing.

On Dec 20, 2023, Pegasus said it would not conclude a business combination after considering market conditions and would wind up.

site_title: Apple China sales lag overshadows quarterly profit, revenue beats
summary: Apple reported a fiscal first-quarter revenue of $119.58 billion, beating analyst expectations, but China sales missed targets at $20.82 billion, down from analyst estimates of $23.53 billion. Despite this, iPhone sales grew 6% to $69.70 billion, driven by strong demand in emerging markets. The company's services business rose 11% to $23.12 billion, while Mac sales were in line with expectations. However, iPad sales fell 25% and wearables segment declined due to weak demand, overshadowing the company's overall profit of $2.18 per share.

images.alt_text: The outages came the same week that Apple announced sweeping changes to the App Store in the European Union.
Critics have said the changes do not go far enough, arguing Apple’s fee structure remains unfair, and that the changes may be in violation of the DMA.
Starting in March, developers will be able to offer alternative app stores on iPhones and opt out of using Apple’s in-app payment system, which charges commissions of up to 30 per cent
The iPhone 15 family of products is facing headwinds in sustaining demand in China, where analysts forecast sales will continue to weaken.

site_title: Fare affordability and service reliability key focuses for Grab in 2024: Singapore MD
summary: Grab Singapore plans to focus on improving affordability, driver income, and service reliability in 2024. Managing director Yee Wee Tang stated that the company has found a "good balance" between fare prices and driver income, addressing concerns of high fares and low driver earnings in 2023. Grab aims to enhance its ride-sharing service GrabShare and carpooling service GrabHitch to meet customer needs.

images.alt_text: Grab's acquisition of Trans-Cab includes about 2,200 cabs and more than 300 private-hire vehicles.
South-east Asia’s food delivery expenditure topped US$17.1 billion, growing by 5 per cent year on year.
Grab and Singtel have laid out plans for a further capital injection in the third quarter of this year.

summary:

Several Singaporean stocks experienced changes in trading on Friday. CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's DPU fell 6.1% year-over-year, while Parkway Life Reit's DPU rose 2.1%. DBS announced a merger of its equity capital markets and treasury markets business, and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit's DPU fell 14.5%. Frasers Hospitality Trust reported an increase in revenue per available room. Novo Tellus Alpha Acquisition's redemption price for its Class-A Shares was set at S$5.18. These developments may affect trading of the mentioned companies' securities.

site_title: Zoom cuts jobs in latest move by tech industry to shed workers
summary: Zoom Video Communications cut approximately 150 jobs, less than 2% of its workforce, as part of a broader trend of workforce reductions in the tech industry. The company, known for its videoconferencing software, has struggled to maintain high revenue growth since its pandemic-era rise. Despite this, Zoom plans to continue hiring in areas like artificial intelligence, sales, and engineering. The move is part of a 15% headcount reduction announced in February, and follows similar job cuts by other tech companies such as Microsoft, Alphabet's Google, and Amazon.com.

site_title: TikTok users lose access to Taylor Swift, Billie Eilish songs
summary: TikTok users have lost access to music from Taylor Swift, Billie Eilish, and other Universal Music Group artists, following the collapse of contract negotiations between the two companies. The dispute centers on Universal's demands for fair compensation, protection of human artists from AI-generated content, and addressing online safety issues. TikTok has begun muting videos featuring the label's artists, and Universal has accused the platform of not valuing artists and songwriters. The move has sparked shock among young users and may prompt them to turn to rival platforms like Instagram Reels.

site_title: US job cuts more than double in January
summary: US job cuts surged 136% in January, reaching 82,307 announced layoffs, the highest level in 10 months. This marks a significant increase from December's 34,817 layoffs. On a yearly basis, job cuts overall fell 20% from January 2023. The surge in layoffs is attributed to restructuring efforts in the financial and technology sectors.

images.alt_text: People queue outside a newly reopened career center for in-person appointments in Louisville, Kentucky, U.S., April 15, 2021.  REUTERS/Amira Karaoud

The overall labour market remains solid as employers hoard workers after struggling to find labour during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, drop 34,000 to 9.582 million on the last day of June, the lowest level since April 2021.

site_title: Bank of England signals rate cuts possible once inflation eases
summary: The Bank of England has signaled the possibility of interest-rate reductions as inflation eases, with a majority of its nine-member Monetary Policy Committee opting to leave the key rate unchanged at 5.25%. Governor Andrew Bailey stated that cuts are under consideration, but the decision will be based on evidence that inflation is set to fall to the 2% target. The central bank's more dovish stance reflects a shift in its guidance, with a greater emphasis on adjusting monetary policy as warranted by economic data.

images.alt_text: epa11116557 US Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell is seen in a camera viewfinder as he speaks to reporters after the Fed once again refrained from raising interest rates following its two-day conference at the Federal Reserve in Washington, DC, USA, 31 January  2024. Policymakers are widely expected to begin cutting interest rates later in 2024.  EPA-EFE/JIM LO SCALZO

site_title: Opec cuts oil production as coalition begins new supply pact
summary: Opec, a coalition of oil-producing countries, has cut oil production by 490,000 barrels a day, reducing output to 26.7 million barrels per day. The cut, which began last month, aims to prevent a global surplus and stabilize prices. However, the actual reduction is lower than expected due to disruptions in Libya, which is not part of the planned cutbacks. Opec and its allies have pledged to make additional production curbs this quarter to address slowing global demand growth and rising rival supplies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OPEC logo is seen in this illustration taken, October 8, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Oil prices drop 2% on unsubstantiated ceasefire reports, refinery shutdown
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% on Thursday, February 1, following unsubstantiated reports of a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas and a US refinery shutdown. Brent crude futures fell to $78.70 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell to $73.82. Opec+ has 2.2 million barrels per day of voluntary oil production cuts, announced in November.

images.alt_text: Major forecasters, including the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, see oil demand growth in 2024 driven primarily by Chinese consumption.

site_title: The audacity of E Jean Carroll
summary: A New York jury has awarded E Jean Carroll US$83.3 million in her civil trial against Donald Trump, finding him liable for defamation and emotional harm. The verdict is a significant victory for Carroll, 80, who had faced years of being a target of Trump's false statements. The case was not about re-litigating the 1990s assault, but about Trump's continued defamation of Carroll, which the jury deemed with malice. The award is also notable for Carroll's age, as she is one of the oldest women to come forward with a sexual assault claim. The verdict has been hailed as a victory for women's rights and a demonstration of the value of a woman's reputation, particularly at an advanced age.

images.alt_text: In a 59-page decision, US district judge in Manhattan  dismisses Trump’s arguments for reducing damages to less than US$1 million.

E. Jean Carroll leaves a federal court house after the jury found that former US president Donald J. Trump was liable for sexually abusing and defaming her but not liable for raping her, New York, May 9, 2023.
Trump on rape accuser: 'She's not my type'

site_title: Fed stays put on rates, sending strong message that inflation remains a clear and present danger
summary: The US Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged at 5.25-5.5% in a surprise move, sending a strong message that inflation remains a pressing concern. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the balance between growth and inflation has improved, and the committee is unlikely to cut rates in March. This decision was a departure from market expectations and caused US stocks to tumble. Powell expressed caution, citing the need for more data to confirm the easing of inflation pressures, and warned that premature rate cuts could lead to economic instability.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell has pushed back on expectations of an interest rate cut in March, after the Federal Open Market Committee decided to leave interest rates at 5.25 to 5.5 per cent.

site_title: US worker productivity strong in Q4
summary: US worker productivity increased at a 3.2% annualized rate in Q4, outpacing expectations and containing unit labour costs. This boost to productivity, combined with the recent decline in compensation costs, may help curb wage inflation and support the Federal Reserve's efforts to combat inflation. The Fed has raised interest rates by 525 basis points since March 2022, and Chair Jerome Powell suggests the rate may peak and begin to decrease this year if the economy evolves as expected.

site_title: Sabana Reit to hold requisitioned EGM; date to be fixed
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) will convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) at the request of activist investors led by Quarz Capital. The EGM, which was initially rejected by the Reit's manager in January, was submitted again on January 11. The meeting will consider 12 resolutions related to the internalisation of the Reit's management function, following previous votes in August last year that removed the Reit's manager and directed the trustee to implement internalisation. The date and details of the EGM will be announced separately.

site_title: China vows to keep up spending in 2024 after stimulus cut
summary: China plans to maintain fiscal spending at a "necessary intensity" in 2024 despite a property market slump, aiming to support a slowing economy. The government will keep spending at a reasonable size and increase infrastructure investments, with the central budget deficit potentially set at 3.5% of GDP. China will also increase transfer payments to local authorities and consider issuing special sovereign bonds to boost the economy, but economists expect a more conservative fiscal stance to balance debt risks.

images.alt_text: Outstanding PSL loans totalled 3.4022 trillion yuan at the end of January, compared with 3.2522 trillion yuan at end-December, the central bank says.

site_title: Amazon Q4 sales beats estimates on cloud and e-commerce strength, shares rise
summary: Amazon reported Q4 sales beating estimates with a 14% increase to $170 billion, driven by strong cloud business growth and e-commerce sales. The company forecast current-quarter revenue of $138 billion to $143.5 billion. Amazon Web Services (AWS) posted revenue of $24.2 billion, with CEO Andy Jassy citing efforts to incorporate generative AI into services. Shares rose 5% after the market close, with Amazon's year-to-date gain climbing over 6%. Analysts forecast Amazon expanding its US e-commerce market share this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Woman with smartphone is seen in front of displayed Amazon logo in this illustration taken, July 30, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Tengah EC parcel draws fewer-than-expected bids, topped by Hoi Hup-Sunway’s S$701 psf ppr
summary: A Tengah EC land parcel drew fewer-than-expected bids, with Hoi Hup-Sunway's S$701 psf ppr top bid. The site attracted four bids, lower than the anticipated eight, amid competition from nearby projects. Developers cited the oncoming EC supply at the adjacent plot and the desire to play safe in the market as reasons for the moderation in bids. Despite the relatively large project size, developers showed confidence in its saleability, with some predicting the project's launch in the fourth quarter of 2025.
