site_title: Thailand’s Move Forward Party faces dissolution threat after court order
summary: Thailand's Move Forward Party, which won the most seats in last year's election, faces a dissolution threat after a court order. Two fresh petitions urge the Election Commission to seek the Constitutional Court to dissolve the party and possibly ban its leaders from politics for 10 years. The court ruled the party covertly pushed an agenda to "destroy" the constitutional monarchy and ordered them to stop all activities related to changing a law protecting the monarchy from defamation. The party's leader, Chaithawat Tulathon, says his group is now at a "high risk" of dissolution, which could lead to a ban on its leaders and potentially unleash more political unrest.

images.alt_text: The Constitutional Court ordered Move Forward Party to abandon the plan, which amounts to an attempt to “overthrow the democratic regime of government with the king as a head of state” and therefore in violation of the constitution.

site_title: Evergrande EV unit suspends talks with Dubai’s NWTN on redrafting deal
summary: Evergrande New Energy Vehicle (NEV) has suspended talks with Dubai-based mobility firm NWTN on a HK$3.89-billion share subscription agreement. The deal, which would have given NWTN a 27.50% stake in NEV, was part of China Evergrande's restructuring plan. The parties are still considering whether the transaction will proceed, with no definitive view yet. The agreement was initially made in August to issue 6.18 billion new shares to NWTN.

site_title: Opec+ committee meeting keeps oil output policy unchanged
summary: Opec+ committee members agreed to keep oil output policy unchanged during a meeting on February 1, 2024. The Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee reviewed crude oil production data for November and December 2023, noting high conformity among participating countries. The voluntary 2.2 million barrels per day output cuts, led by Saudi Arabia, will expire at the end of March, with discussions on extending or unwinding them yet to begin.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Aramco is seen as security personnel walk before the start of a press conference by Aramco at the Plaza Conference Center in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia November 3, 2019. REUTERS/Hamad I Mohammed

FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) sits outside its headquarters ahead of the OPEC and NON-OPEC meeting, Austria December 6, 2019. REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger
Brent March crude futures settled at US$80.06 a barrel, up US$1.50, or 1.9 per cent, on Monday.
Brent crude fell 41 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to US$78.15 a barrel by 0105 GMT on Monday after settling down 54 cents on Friday.
The International Energy Agency this week raises its 2024 global demand forecast, but its projection is half that of producer group Opec.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after Fed-driven sell-off
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Thursday, February 1, 2024, after a sell-off in the previous session. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 25.04 points, or 0.07%, to 38,175.34, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. The move followed a disappointing Federal Reserve statement that dashed hopes for early interest rate cuts, with investors now focusing on upcoming economic data and Big Tech earnings.

site_title: China’s ‘urban village’ drive gets policy bank loan support
summary: China's central bank has granted 150 billion yuan (S$28.1 billion) in loans to policy banks through its pledged supplementary lending (PSL) facility in January, supporting its "urban village" plan. The loans were made to state-owned policy banks to fund the renovation of "urban villages" in Guangzhou, China's Cabinet outlined plans in July to transform these areas to support its troubled property sector and aid the economy. Outstanding PSL loans totalled 3.4022 trillion yuan at the end of January, a 3.15% increase from December.

images.alt_text: The export index may have been affected by the Lunar New Year which will fall on Feb 10 this year, as factories and workers geared up for the pre-holiday shipment of goods.
The PBOC has increasingly leaned on tools that steer credit to specific sectors since 2020, when the pandemic hit economic growth.
The People’s Bank of China and the National Financial Regulatory Administration will allow bank loans pledged by developers’ commercial properties to be used to repay other loans and bonds.
Governor Pan Gongsheng says the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) would cut the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for all banks by 50 basis points (bps).
While cutting rates can boost dwindling confidence, Beijing has to balance any easing with the need to guardrail the nation’s massive banking system and safeguard the yuan.
The LPR normally charged to banks’ best clients is calculated each month after the designated commercial banks submit proposed rates to the People’s Bank of China (PBOC).

site_title: VW Group’s India unit eyes entry-level electric SUV
summary: Volkswagen Group's India unit plans to introduce an entry-level electric SUV by the second-half of this decade, with CEO Piyush Arora stating the vehicle would need significant volumes to justify a $3 million investment. The company is evaluating its platform options and considering exporting the product to southeast Asia, the Gulf Cooperation Council, and North Africa to offset lower demand in India, where EVs currently account for just 2% of total car sales, with a target of 30% by 2030.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Volkswagen logo is seen on a Volkswagen ID.5 electric car on display at a showroom of a car dealer in Reze near Nantes, France, November 13, 2023. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo
The move added two weeks to delivery times, Volkswagen says.
The brand plans to optimise material and product costs, reduce fixed and production costs, and increase its revenues to achieve its target, according to Volkswagen.
Volkswagen's November deliveries in China, dampened by lockdowns last year, grow 32.4 per cent, beating the average growth in the market of 26.6 per cent.

site_title: Nursing home acquisitions lift Parkway Life Reit’s H2 DPU by 2.1%
summary: Parkway Life Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) increased 2.1% to 7.48 cents for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023, driven by acquisitions of nursing homes in Singapore and Japan. The Reit's gross revenue rose 4.7% to S$73.1 million, boosted by higher rents from its Singapore properties under new master lease agreements. The acquisition of nursing homes helped boost the Reit's healthcare assets, contributing to the revenue growth.

images.alt_text: The Mount Elizabeth Novena hospital has become “an ideal target for capital recycling” for the sponsor IHH Healthcare, says SAC analyst Matthias Chan.

site_title: Deutsche Bank warns of potential US property losses
summary: Deutsche Bank has warned of potential losses in the US property market, citing refinancing as the main risk. The bank's provisions for US commercial real estate losses rose 473% to 488 million euros in the last quarter, driven by refinancing risks. Properties in cities like New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco make up 1.5% of the bank's total lending book. Higher interest rates and lower occupancy rates have increased pressure on the sector, which accounts for 23% of the bank's stress-tested portfolio.

site_title: A US$560 billion property warning hits banks from NY to Tokyo
summary: US commercial property values continue to decline, prompting banks to slash dividends and stockpile reserves. New York Community Bancorp and Japan's Aozora Bank warned of losses tied to US commercial property investments, while Deutsche Bank quadrupled its US real estate loss provisions to $133 million. The US commercial real estate market has been in turmoil since the Covid-19 pandemic, with banks facing $560 billion in commercial property maturities by 2025. The market's uncertainty and potential defaults pose a risk to regional lenders, with some experts warning of a "tail risk" for 2024.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank’s loans on US offices represent about 1.5 per cent of its total lending book, with properties in cities including New York (top), Los Angeles and San Francisco.
The bank expects to post a net loss of 28 billion yen (S$255.9 million) for the fiscal year, compared with its previous forecast of a 24 billion yen profit.

site_title: New fine arts club for the C-suite
summary: The Eureka Griffin Club, a new fine arts club for business leaders, has opened on Cluny Hill in Singapore. The club features private dining rooms, a cigar room, whisky room, jewellery room, swimming pool, and a large exhibition space. Conceived by club director Li Yi Cheng, the space aims to foster a deep appreciation for culture and aesthetics, with changing exhibitions and permanent artworks on display. The club is housed in a well-appointed, two-storey Good Class Bungalow on 22,000 square feet land, offering a warm and inviting atmosphere surrounded by greenery.

site_title: Adani Enterprises’ profit jumps 130% bouyed by newer businesses
summary: Adani Enterprises, the flagship firm of billionaire Gautam Adani's empire, reported a 130% profit jump to 18.9 billion rupees (S$305 million) for the quarter through December, boosted by higher earnings from its newer businesses. Revenue increased 6.5% to 283.4 billion rupees, driven by double-digit growth in airports and new energy ecosystem business units. The company has rebounded from a brutal short seller attack early last year and has trimmed debt, secured new backers, and begun communicating extensively with investors.

images.alt_text: Adani Green says its consolidated profit rises to 2.56 billion rupees (S$41.3 million) in the quarter ended Dec 31 from 1.03 billion rupees in the year-earlier period.
FILE PHOTO: A logo of the Adani Group is seen on a commercial complex in Mumbai, India, February 7, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

Signage atop the Adani Group headquarters in Ahmedabad, India, on Wednesday, June 21, 2023. US authorities are looking into what representations Adani Group made to its American investors following a scathing short seller’s report that accused the company of using offshore companies to secretly manipulate its share prices. Photographer: Prakash Singh/Bloomberg

Indian billionaire Gautam Adani in  an inauguration ceremony after India's the Adani Group completed the purchase of Haifa Port in Haifa port, Haifa, Israel on January 31, 2023 photographer : Kobi Wolf for Bloomberg

site_title: Cut-off yield on 6-month T-bill drops to 3.54%; SSB 10-year return at 2.88%
summary: Singapore's six-month Treasury bills (T-bills) offer a cut-off yield of 3.54% in the latest auction, down from 3.7% in the previous auction. Demand remains strong, with a total of S$14.6 billion in applications for the S$6.3 billion on offer. Experts attribute the low yield to investors' preference for locking in returns at current levels, expecting rates to go lower. The six-month T-bill cut-off yield has now fallen to 3.54%, continuing a trend of lower yields.

images.alt_text: The total amount applied for in this round's T-bill was the same as last month’s, at S$12.8 billion.
The latest one-year T-bills received a total of S$11.9 billion in applications for the S$4.5 billion on offer, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.65.
The latest issuances have received S$13.6 billion for the S$6.4 billion on offer.

site_title: Nvidia’s new China-focused AI chip set to be sold at similar price to Huawei product
summary: Nvidia has started taking pre-orders for its new China-specific AI chip, the H20, priced between $12,000 to $15,000 per card, comparable to a rival Huawei product. The move comes as the US expanded bans on high-end chip exports to hamper China's AI and computer development for its military. The H20 will deliver less computing power than Nvidia's flagship H100 AI chip and the H800, which was also banned in October.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is up another 20 per cent this year as investors bet on its sector leadership.
Sales by largely unknown Chinese suppliers highlight the difficulties Washington faces, despite its bans, in completely cutting off China’s access to advanced US chips.
Nvidia is betting on the chips to help preserve its market share in China after tightening US export restrictions barred it from shipping products including its advanced A800 and H800 AI chips.
The GeForce RTX 4090 D, which Nvidia says offers a “quantum leap in performance, efficiency and artificial intelligence-driven graphics”, will be available to Chinese customers starting in January.
Tencent has been pushing services that use the AI inference chip Zixiao it developed with deep learning startup Enflame, touting performance comparable to some Nvidia chips.
Nvidia will deliver a new set of products for the Chinese market that’s in line with the latest rules coming from Washington, Jensen Huang says.

site_title: Nio delivers 10,055 vehicles in January, up 18% from year-ago period
summary: Nio delivered 10,055 vehicles in January, a 18% increase from the previous year. The company has cumulatively delivered 459,649 vehicles as of Jan 31, 2024. Nio also announced the expansion of its power swap network to the entire industry and established Zhongan Energy to build 1,000 battery swap stations in China. Despite a 2.9% decline in shares, the company expects to join forces with more partners to develop the power network and battery swapping.

images.alt_text: BYD has met its ambitious three million target, selling 3.01 million cars in 2023 – in the process overtaking Tesla as the world’s top-selling EV maker.
Nio completed placing 294 million new shares at US$7.50 apiece, raising a further US$2.2 billion from Abu Dhabi-backed fund CYVN Holdings last week.

site_title: UOL-SingLand JV tops bids for prime Orchard site at lower-than-expected S$1,617 psf ppr
summary: A joint venture between UOL Group and Singapore Land topped bids for a prime Orchard Boulevard site, with a S$428.3 million bid that valued the site at S$1,616.75 psf ppr. The tender saw subdued bids, with offers ranging from S$1,600 to S$2,000 psf ppr, reflecting cautious developer sentiment due to the current market challenges, including increased stamp duties and higher interest rates. The site can yield an estimated 280 residential units and is expected to be developed into a high-rise luxury development.

images.alt_text: Two land parcels in the prime central areas of Orchard and River Valley will be up for sale in H2 2023 Government Land Sales Programme.

site_title: The EU and Indo-Pacific: Partners for a more stable and prosperous world
summary: The European Union aims to strengthen its cooperation with the Indo-Pacific region, driven by the region's growing economic and security importance. The EU has become a strategic partner of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and has launched its Indo-Pacific strategy. To counter rising tensions, the EU will accelerate its path in 2024, focusing on multilateral solutions and regional approaches. The EU will also intensify its economic ties with Indo-Pacific countries, diversify supply chains, and cooperate on sustainable development and climate resilience.

images.alt_text: There is growing recognition among European nations that the Asia-Pacific will continue to be one of the most dynamic areas of the globe in the decades ahead.

Blast furnaces of Tata Steel in IJmuiden, the Netherlands. The EU's new carbon border adjustment mechanism (CBAM) complements its EU Emissions Trading System (ETS) designed to reduce emissions from power and industry plants.

german3p16sgc - Shirley Qi 

Credit: Singaporean-German Chamber of Industry and Commerce (SGC)
Despite the elevation to a “strategic partnership”, the relationship between Asean and the EU is often rocky with several irritants at play.

site_title: Eurozone factory downturn eased for third month in January
summary: The eurozone factory downturn eased for a third month in January, with the manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 46.6 from 44.4 in December. This marked a third consecutive month of increase, and most sub-indices showed a positive trend, with inflationary pressures weakening. The outlook for the year ahead appears optimistic, with the future output index rising to 57.1. This could be welcomed by policymakers at the European Central Bank, who aim to fight inflation.

images.alt_text: The 20 countries that share the euro barely avoided an outright recession in the final quarter of last year.

site_title: Eurozone inflation slows to 2.8% in January
summary: Eurozone inflation slowed to 2.8% in January, below the European Central Bank's 2% target but above the peak of 10.6% in October 2022. The slowdown was attributed to a decrease in food price increases. Analysts had forecast a 2.7% rate, and the drop in energy prices, at 6.3%, also contributed to the decrease. However, core inflation, which excludes volatile energy and food prices, remained at 3.3%, above the ECB's target, and some officials worry that inflation risks persist.

images.alt_text: HCOB’s final eurozone manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI),  climbed to 46.6 in January from December’s 44.4.
The 20 countries that share the euro barely avoided an outright recession in the final quarter of last year.
A key ECB survey now sees inflation at 2.4 per cent this year, down from 2.7 per cent seen three months ago and well below the 2.7 per cent projected by ECB staff.
Eurozone services PMI has fallen to a three-month low of 48.4.
In the European Union as a whole, consumer sentiment falls by 0.2 points to -16.2.

A person walks past the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building on September 14, 2023 ahead of the meeting of the governing council of the ECB in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: Evergrande’s unsold Tower, Hui’s mansion bode ill for creditors
summary: China Evergrande Group's liquidators face a challenging task in selling the company's assets, including a prime office tower and a luxury mansion, due to Hong Kong's worst property slump. The sale of Evergrande's former Hong Kong headquarters building has been unsuccessful despite rebranding and roadshows, and the luxury house formerly owned by founder Hui Ka Yan remains on the market. Creditors are likely to have to offer discounts to meet expectations in a market where values are expected to continue falling, according to Colliers International Group.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The Evergrande logo is seen on residential buildings in Nanjing, in China’s eastern Jiangsu province on August 18, 2023. Troubled Chinese real estate giant Evergrande was issued a winding-up order on January 29, 2024, after failing to convince a Hong Kong court that it had a working restructuring plan. (Photo by STRINGER / AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Adidas shares slide after cautious 2024 outlook
summary: Adidas shares fell 8% after the company delivered a forecast for 2024 operating profit of around 500 million euros (S$723 million), below analysts' estimate of 1.294 billion euros. The forecast assumes selling off remaining Yeezy shoe inventory at cost, but CEO Bjorn Gulden left room for possible upgrades. The company cited a "severe impact" from the devaluation of the Argentine peso and consumer sentiment. Adidas reported an operating profit of 268 million euros for 2023, down from 669 million euros a year earlier.

images.alt_text: Adidas’ gross margin for the quarter is up 0.2 percentage points at 49.3 per cent, supported by reduced freight costs and fewer discounts.
Adidas has been selling its remaining stock of Yeezy shoes since the end of May, helping narrow an expected loss, which was initially forecast as 700 million euros in March.
Ethiopia's Tigist Assefa celebrates after winning the women's Berlin Marathon. She was wearing Adidas' newest running shoes, the Adizero Adios Pro Evo 1.

site_title: Dutch bank ING sees lower total income in 2024, shares drop
summary: ING, the largest Dutch bank by assets, reported lower-than-expected net interest income in the fourth quarter, citing a peak in rising interest rates. The bank forecasts lower total income for 2024, with shares down over 8% and expected to be the bank's worst day in almost a year. Despite this, net profit jumped 43.1% in the October-December period, and the bank expects total income to remain strong but lower than 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a Deutsche Bank office in London, Britain July 8, 2019. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li seeks to sell asset manager PineBridge: sources
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li is seeking to sell his majority stake in asset manager PineBridge Investments, which managed $157 billion in assets at the end of 2023. PCG, Li's investment firm, has hired JPMorgan to run the sales process and held preliminary discussions with financial institutions. The divestment comes amid heightened market volatility and intense competition in the asset management business, contributing to PineBridge's recent losses. If successful, PCG will exit a money-losing fund house and potentially exit a profitable China joint venture.

images.alt_text: The expansion is part of WeLab’s ambitions to grow in the Asia region, after starting a digital bank in Hong Kong in 2020.
While ETF purchases have been a preferred tool to prop up the market by state funds, their buying was unlikely the defining factor for the inflows.

site_title: Shell's 2023 profit falls 30% to US$28 billion, dividend boosted
summary: Shell reported a 2023 profit of US$28 billion, down 30% from the previous year, due to cooling oil and gas prices. Despite the decline, Shell exceeded analysts' expectations and increased its dividend by 4% to US$0.344 per share. The company also announced a share repurchase of US$3.5 billion over the next three months. Shell's share distributions in 2023 reached nearly US$23 billion, representing over 10% of its market value. CEO Wael Sawan emphasized the company's focus on delivering value with less emissions.

site_title: India's finance minister promises reforms to drive growth
summary: India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has promised economic reforms to drive growth, stating the next five years will be years of unprecedented development towards achieving a developed India by 2047. The interim budget, seen as an economic manifesto, outlines plans for fiscal consolidation, borrowings, and future taxation policy. The government aims to build 20 million affordable houses and launch a scheme for middle-class housing. Despite the country's fastest-growing economy, consumption remains weak, with growth in wages and high inflation hurting lower-income earners.

images.alt_text: “The robustness seen in domestic demand, namely, private consumption and investment, traces its origin to the reforms and measures implemented by the government over the last ten years,” the review says.

site_title: Digital Core Reit posts 7.3% fall in H2 DPU to US$0.0178
summary: Digital Core Reit reported a 7.3% decline in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0178 for the six months ended Dec 31, 2023. Its gross revenue fell 10.4% and net property income (NPI) dropped 17.9%. CEO John Stewart attributed the decline to a perceived peak in the US interest rate tightening cycle, which has spurred a recovery in Reit unit prices.

images.alt_text: John Stewart, CEO of Digital Core Reit's manager, expects the Reit's prospects to be brighter next year after resolving matters relating to a customer bankruptcy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 1)
summary: Singapore's tourism performance in 2024 is forecast to remain below pre-Covid levels, with 15-16 million visitors expected, despite better-than-expected tourist spending in 2023. The US Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, boosting analyst confidence in Asian markets. Economic ties between Singapore and China are strengthening, with plans to advance cooperation. Keppel's H2 profit rose 2.5% and the company posted record full-year profits. The cut-off yield on Singapore's 6-month T-bill slid to 3.54%.

site_title: 🔊 Let’s get loud (about our finances)
summary: A recent newsletter from Thrive highlights the financial literacy gap among Gen Z, emphasizing the need for young adults to take control of their finances. The newsletter offers advice on investing CPF, buying life insurance, and navigating GenAI financial advisers. Additionally, it shares budgeting tips, such as planning two graduate trips on a student budget. The article concludes that Gen Z has no excuse for financial illiteracy and encourages readers to stay informed and proactive in managing their finances.

images.alt_text: When budgeting goes wrong
Money thoughts for a lifetime

site_title: India plans subsidy for offshore wind in pursuit of net zero
summary: India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced support for offshore wind as part of the country's net zero ambitions. The government aims to install 1 gigawatt of offshore wind capacity, with Suzlon Energy seeing a 5.1% gain following the announcement. However, critics say the plan lacks detail on funding and fails to provide a roadmap for reaching the target. The government also reiterated plans to install rooftop solar panels over 10 million homes and support electric vehicles, but observers argue more needs to be done to achieve India's net zero goals.

site_title: Julius Baer to exit private debt after Benko saga claims CEO
summary: Julius Baer, a Swiss wealth manager, will exit its private debt business after writing down $909.4 million in loans to bankrupt Signa companies. CEO Philipp Rickenbacher is stepping down, and the bank will refocus on traditional areas like Lombard and mortgage lending. The move comes after a tumultuous period, including a money-laundering probe and a downgrade by Moody's. Net income for 2023 slumped 52% due to the losses. Deputy CEO Nic Dreckmann will take over until a permanent appointment is made.

images.alt_text: A Julius Baer branch in Zurich. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia's factories struggle for momentum amid soft Chinese demand
summary: Asia's factories experienced a patchy performance in January, with China's private-sector PMI remaining steady at 50.8, contrasting with an official survey showing manufacturing activity contracting for the fourth straight month. The region's economies are still underperforming, with some countries like South Korea benefiting from improved demand, while others like Taiwan and Malaysia saw factory activity shrink. The International Monetary Fund expects Asia's growth to expand 4.5% this year, but with divergent performances across economies, with Japan expected to see growth slow to 0.9% and China's economy to expand 4.6%.

images.alt_text: The export index may have been affected by the Lunar New Year which will fall on Feb 10 this year, as factories and workers geared up for the pre-holiday shipment of goods.

site_title: Hong Kong December retail sales up 7.8% as tourism recovers
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 7.8% year-over-year to HK$36.3 billion in December, driven by a 4.8% increase in volume. Tourism continued to recover, with 3.93 million visitor arrivals in December, up from 160,578 in 2022. The growth is attributed to rising household income and government efforts to promote mega events. This marks the 13th consecutive month of retail sales growth, with the year-end total of 34 million visitors exceeding 2022's 160,578.

images.alt_text: HKMA says the city’s financial and monetary markets continue to operate in a smooth and orderly manner.
Hong Kong GDP expands 3.2 per cent in 2023, according to advanced estimates announced by the Census and Statistics Department.
Tougher penalties against sedition, a colonial-era law which currently carries a two-year sentence, are also expected in the package.
A security guard walks past a directory board of Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) in Hong Kong December 20, 2012. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Singapore, China reaffirm trade, investment ties; pledge to advance economic cooperation
summary: Singapore and China reaffirmed their commitment to advancing economic cooperation through five agreements at the Singapore-China Economic Partnership Conference. The agreements include renewing business activities, enhancing intellectual property protection, and providing mediation and arbitration support. The conference aims to foster bilateral trade and investment, with China welcoming Singapore businesses to break into the South-east Asian market through existing free trade agreements. The agreements are expected to promote commercial and industrial relations between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling (left) in conversation with CEO Singapore Business Federation Kok Ping Soon. Low shared insights on how Singapore and China can forge stronger economic ties in areas of sustainability, digital economy and e-commerce. PHOTO: SINGAPORE BUSINESS FEDERATION

site_title: New law mandating retail leases comply with code of conduct takes effect
summary: A new law in Singapore requires all retail leases with a tenure of at least one year to comply with an industry-wide code of conduct, taking effect on February 1, 2024. The code includes 13 principles, such as prohibiting landlords from pre-terminating leases and imposing a gross turnover rent component when rent exceeds a specific amount. The law applies to all qualifying retail leases and sets out a dispute resolution framework for non-compliance. The Fair Tenancy Industry Committee, which maintains the code, has been updated with new members and will monitor and promote compliance.

images.alt_text: Tenant group Singapore Tenants United for Fairness (SGTuff) has proposed that landlords should have to provide tenants with data on the footfall and average rental per square foot (psf) in their retail premises.
Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling said legislation will take effect in early February 2024, “to provide additional time for other landlords to come on board."

site_title: US property losses trigger 20% drop in Japanese Bank Aozora
summary: Aozora Bank, Japan's 16th largest bank by market value, reported a 28 billion yen (S$255.9 million) net loss for the fiscal year due to US commercial property losses, exceeding its previous forecast of a 24 billion yen profit. The bank's shares plummeted over 20% in Tokyo. Aozora's woes echo those of New York Community Bancorp, and concerns over global banks' exposure to souring real estate bets are growing. The bank's large exposure to overseas property loans, particularly US office loans, is seen as a major contributor to its losses.

images.alt_text: Aozora to raise 50b yen from Japan banks for real estate funds

site_title: Singapore businesses could gain from China’s restructuring: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat believes Singapore businesses can gain from China's economic restructuring, citing clear government priorities to promote innovation and new industries. Despite global uncertainties, Heng expects a global recession in 2024 to be unlikely and Asean's economy to continue growing. UOB forecasts 4.5% growth for China's economy in 2024, with opportunities for businesses to align with China's policy priorities. Heng emphasizes the need for businesses to boost productivity, go digital, and go green to mitigate rising costs.

images.alt_text: (From left) CCPIT Chairman Ren Hongbin; Zong Changqing, Economic and Commercial Minister Counsellor, Embassy of the People’s Republic of China; Low Yen Ling, Minister of State for Trade and Industry; SBF Chairman Lim Ming Yan. SBF and CCPIT renew their commitment to the mutual facilitation of business activities.
Demand for technology has picked up in recent months, boosting economies in Asia, says IMF.
The linchpin electronics sector gained 0.1 point from the previous month to post a slightly faster expansion at 50.2 in December.
Sun Xiao, secretary general of CCOIC, an affiliated body of CCPIT, highlights hat Asean remains an attractive destination for Chinese companies. PHOTO: UOB

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid mixed regional trading; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,143.06, as the local market was weighed down by a broader regional market trend. Losers outnumbered gainers 267 to 258 in trading of 1.4 billion securities worth S$1 billion. This mixed performance was influenced by regional markets, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.5% and the Kospi Composite Index rising 1.8%, while the Nikkei 225 lost 0.8%.

images.alt_text: Stocks to watch: Keppel, SGX, ESR-Logos Reit, IReit Global, Noel Gifts, Keong Hong
Singapore stocks track Wall Street retreat at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.8%

site_title: Tech CEOs told ‘you have blood on your hands’ at US Senate child safety hearing
summary: US senators grilled top executives from major social media companies, accusing them of having "blood on their hands" for failing to protect children from online threats. The hearing, led by Senator Lindsey Graham, highlighted growing concerns about child safety on platforms such as Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, and Snapchat. CEOs testified that they would work to prevent abuse, but stopped short of taking responsibility. The hearing comes amid calls for legislation to hold tech companies accountable for child sexual abuse material and to restrict data collection on children.

images.alt_text: ByteDance, nicknamed “App Factory” due to its aggressive iteration of mobile applications, has been slow to the AI race that is disrupting the technology sector.
ByteDance’s relationship with Tencent in gaming has warmed after a rancorous period of competition.

site_title: Gold climbs on hopes for sizeable Fed rate cuts this year
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $2,045.65 per ounce on February 1, reaching a two-week high of $2,055.89, amid hopes of significant Federal Reserve interest rate cuts this year. The Fed left interest rates unchanged, but traders now expect 142 basis points of rate cuts for 2024, up from 130 basis points previously. This optimism is driven by the expectation of a rate cut in May, following a drop in bets for a March cut.

images.alt_text: Spot prices have dropped 1.3 per cent so far this month.

site_title: ‘No real surprise’ as US Fed funds rate stays unchanged; analysts remain bullish on Asian markets
summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged for the fourth consecutive time, with the Federal Open Market Committee deciding to leave the funds rate at 5.25 to 5.5%. Analysts, including JP Morgan and Abrdn, remain bullish on Asian markets, citing a "soft landing" for the US economy and expectations of rate cuts in mid-2024. Despite the potentially longer wait for rate cuts, analysts expect US and Asian markets to perform well, driven by the Fed's focus on inflation and the narrowing rate differential between the US and Asia.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An eagle tops the U.S. Federal Reserve building's facade in Washington, July 31, 2013. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst/File Photo
After a broadly disappointing January for the region’s markets, the news meant February got off to an inauspicious start with Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta all down.
The employment cost index, which measures wages and benefits, increases 0.9 per cent in the fourth quarter, the smallest advance since 2021, after rising 1.1 per cent in the prior three-month period.

site_title: The Elon Musk pay dilemma
summary: A Delaware chancery court judge has ruled that Elon Musk's 2018 $55.8 billion stock compensation deal at Tesla should be rescinded due to a lack of fairness and independence in the board's process. The judge criticized the board for being "starry eyed" by Musk's appeal and failing to consider whether the plan was necessary for Tesla to retain him. The decision could significantly reduce Musk's personal stake in the company, potentially forcing him to reconsider his commitment to Tesla if his desired 25% ownership stake is not met.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk testified during the compensation trial in November 2022 that the money would be used to finance interplanetary travel.

site_title: Japan's SMFG reports 10.7% rise in Q3 profit on brisk lending in Japan
summary: Japan's SMFG, the country's second-largest bank, reported a 10.7% increase in Q3 profit to 266.37 billion yen (S$2.43 billion) due to brisk loan demand in Japan. The bank maintained its full-year profit forecast at 920 billion yen, exceeding its previous record set a decade ago. Despite hopes for a wider spread between deposit and lending rates, uncertainties over the US economy may weigh on Japanese banks' profits.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to cut 3,500 jobs, buy back shares as profit falls
summary: Deutsche Bank announced plans to cut 3,500 backoffice jobs as part of a restructuring effort. The move comes after the bank posted a 30% drop in fourth-quarter profit. In addition, the bank will buy back 1.6 billion euros in shares and pay dividends during the first half of the year. The bank also raised its outlook for revenue growth. The job cuts are part of a broader effort to reduce costs and improve efficiency.

images.alt_text: The demand for a 15.5 per cent pay rise for around 12,000 employees affects Deutsche Bank staff at its Postbank arm.

site_title: Foreign grip on London’s luxury homes tightens as UK buyers wait
summary: International buyers purchased 45% of homes sold in central London's most affluent postcodes in 2023, up from 39% in the previous year. This increase was driven by a larger share of buyers from Asia and the European Union, with Asia making up almost a third of overseas home purchases. The trend suggests that foreign buyers have tightened their grip on London's luxury housing market, while domestic demand dwindled.

images.alt_text: Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: ‘No, Senator, I’m Singaporean’: TikTok CEO Chew Shou Zi grilled by US lawmakers on Chinese links
summary: TikTok CEO Chew Shou Zi faced intense questioning from US lawmakers at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on January 31, regarding the app's Chinese ownership and alleged censorship of political topics. Senators criticized TikTok for promoting self-harm videos and anti-Israel propaganda to American children, while Chinese content was deemed beneficial and educational for children in China. Chew denied the allegations, stating that TikTok's algorithm does not suppress content based on the question and that the app has taken steps to protect user data. The hearing comes amid growing concerns about the spread of child sexual abuse material on social media platforms and the need for stricter regulations.

images.alt_text: CEOS (from left) Jason Citron of Discord, Evan Spiegel of Snap, Chew Shou Zi of TikTok, Linda Yaccarino of X, and Meta's Mark Zuckerberg are sworn in.
TikTok has completed a deal agreed in December to buy 75.01 per cent of Tokopedia for US$840 million.
ByteDance, nicknamed “App Factory” due to its aggressive iteration of mobile applications, has been slow to the AI race that is disrupting the technology sector.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street retreat at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.8% on Thursday, following overnight losses on Wall Street amid earnings releases. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 25.95 points to 3,127.06. Losers outnumbered gainers 94 to 33, with Seatrium being the most active counter by volume, losing 1%. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Stocks to watch: Keppel, SGX, ESR-Logos Reit, IReit Global, Noel Gifts, Keong Hong

site_title: The world’s last wave of oil refining bets is all about India
summary: India is set to embark on a significant capacity expansion of its oil refineries, with plans to increase production by over 20% over the next five years, reaching 6.2 million barrels a day by 2028. The country's refining capacity is projected to increase by 56 million tonnes by 2028, driven by growing demand for transport fuels. The expansion is expected to cost around US$60 billion, with state-run refiners accounting for most of the capacity additions. India's growing transport demand and slower adoption of electric vehicles will keep the appetite for petrol and diesel higher for longer.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco’s move to boost its downstream footprint comes as its competitor in neighbouring United Arab Emirates is also chasing mega deals.
The repairs at Thai Oil's crude distillation unit will likely take around two weeks, says a source.

site_title: Asia: Most markets retreat as Fed crushes March rate cut hope
summary: Asian markets retreated on February 1, following a sell-off on Wall Street after the Federal Reserve indicated it won't cut interest rates until it gains confidence that inflation is moving sustainably towards its 2% target. The Fed's comments, despite acknowledging inflation is going in the right direction, were seen as less dovish than expected, leading to a decline in Tokyo, Shanghai, and other markets. However, Hong Kong rose, and Seoul and Wellington also gained, as investors await the release of US jobs data and await guidance from the Fed on its plans at the March meeting.

images.alt_text: Seoul, Wellington and Taipei also fell, though Sydney, Singapore, Manila and Jakarta rose.

site_title: Amer Sports discounts IPO as investors fret about its reliance on China
summary: Amer Sports, owner of Arc'teryx and Wilson, raised $1.37 billion in a discounted US IPO, valuing the company at $6.3 billion. The IPO priced at $13 per share, below its indicated range, amid concerns about the company's growing reliance on China for revenue. Amer Sports generated 19.4% of its sales in China in the first nine months of 2023, up from 8.3% in 2022, and warned that escalating trade tensions could impact its ability to sell goods in the US. The IPO's poor performance may discourage other IPO hopefuls.

images.alt_text: Iconic Wilson tennis rackets maker Amer Sports has a revenue of US$3.05 billion in the nine months ended Sep 30.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank leaves interest rate unchanged, tracks US Fed
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) left its base rate unchanged at 5.75% on February 1, in line with the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady. The US Fed chair Jerome Powell stated interest rates had peaked and would move lower, citing falling inflation and sustained economic growth. The HKMA noted the city's financial markets operate smoothly, with a stable Hong Kong dollar exchange rate, but high interbank rates may persist. The decision reflects the city's monetary policy moving in lock-step with the US, as its currency is pegged to the US dollar.

site_title: Governments must ensure digital does not divide, says Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo emphasized the need for governments to ensure digital developments are built on a foundation of trust. An EU-Asean joint guide on model contractual clauses will be launched to help businesses manage cross-border data flows, addressing concerns over data protection and security. The launch follows a meeting of Asean digital ministers in Singapore, which discussed topics such as AI governance, cybersecurity, and scams.

images.alt_text: The Asean guide advises companies to put in place an AI risk assessment structure and AI governance training, but leaves specifics to companies and local regulators.

site_title: China’s factory activity expands on export order boost: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity expanded in January due to stable output, quicker logistics, and a rise in new export orders since June, boosting business confidence to a nine-month high. This contrasts with an official survey showing manufacturing activity contracted in the same month. The mixed signals suggest China's economy remains underperforming and may require further policy support.

images.alt_text: China will not release its 2024 growth target till March, but policy insiders expect Beijing to maintain a similar growth target to last year of around 5 per cent.
Banks in India are facing a "liquidity drought".
Entrenched deflation and declining house prices are two of the most serious problems faced by the world’s second-largest economy this year as it tries to regain and sustain momentum.

site_title: China’s fiscal revenue growth picks up in 2023
summary: China's fiscal revenue rose 6.4% in 2023, a significant improvement from the 0.6% increase in 2022. The country's Vice Finance Minister, Wang Dongwei, attributed the growth to economic improvement and low base effects from tax cuts in 2022. Fiscal expenditures rose 5.4% in 2023, with the government pledging to maintain a certain intensity in fiscal spending this year. Despite this, the economy remains uneven and deflationary pressures persist, with calls for more policy support. China is expected to run a budget deficit of 3% of GDP in 2024.

images.alt_text: An electronic ticker displays stock figures in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Monday, Jan. 29, 2024. China will halt the lending of certain shares for short selling from Monday, the securities regulator announced Sunday, in a move to support the country’s slumping stock markets. Photographer: Raul Ariano/Bloomberg
The export index may have been affected by the Lunar New Year which will fall on Feb 10 this year, as factories and workers geared up for the pre-holiday shipment of goods.
Banks in India are facing a "liquidity drought".
Entrenched deflation and declining house prices are two of the most serious problems faced by the world’s second-largest economy this year as it tries to regain and sustain momentum.

site_title: Pentagon calls out Chinese companies it says are helping Beijing’s military
summary: The US Department of Defense added over a dozen Chinese companies to a list of firms allegedly working with Beijing's military, including memory chip maker YMTC and artificial intelligence company Megvii. The move is part of Washington's efforts to restrict Chinese companies that may strengthen Beijing's military. China opposes the move, calling it an abuse of state power and an attack on market competition. The additions to the list can pose reputational risks to designated companies and may lead to sanctions.

images.alt_text: US officials have long warned that China poses a particular threat in that area, and the new measures could affect a wide array of industries.
South Korea’s economy is heavily reliant on the semiconductor sector to drive growth.
An expanded ban on the ASML’s sales of certain high-end equipment to China took effect this month.

site_title: China new home prices rise at fastest pace in nearly 2½ years: private survey
summary: China's new home prices rose at the fastest monthly pace in nearly 2½ years, increasing by 0.15% in January, according to a private survey. This is the fifth consecutive month of growth, surpassing the 0.1% increase in December. The number of cities with month-on-month price growth increased to 49, up from 47 in December. The surge in prices is attributed to government support measures and expectations of further relaxation in home buying policies. However, total sales of surveyed real estate enterprises dropped 33.3% year-on-year in January, indicating weak home-buying sentiment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Buildings are seen in Beijing, July 3, 2013. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
The value of negative-equity loans has jumped to HK$131.3 billion (S$22.5 billion) as of the end of December, rising from HK$59.3 billion in September and reaching the highest level since 2003.
The rapid rollout of financial assistance is being closely watched by the market amid a debt crisis that has roiled the sector since mid-2021 and resulted in many unfinished homes and defaults.

site_title: Tesla upgrades Model Y self-driving hardware to lift China sales
summary: Tesla has upgraded the self-driving hardware on its Model Y sports utility vehicles in China, providing a longer detection range, stronger perception ability, and better computing power. The upgrade, known as HW 4.0, is available at no added cost and includes upgraded cameras and on-board computers. The move aims to boost sales in the world's largest auto market, where Tesla faces competition from BYD, Li Auto, and Geely Automobile Holdings. The Model Y now offers three new colors and has been available outside China with HW 4.0 hardware since last year.

site_title: KKR closes Apac infrastructure fund at US$6.4 billion
summary: KKR has closed its Asia-Pacific (Apac) Infrastructure Investors II Fund at US$6.4 billion, the largest pan-regional infrastructure fund raised for the region. The fund, with a broad investment mandate, focuses on low-volatility infrastructure investments across sectors such as renewables, power, and digital infrastructure. KKR has already invested or committed over half of its capital across 10 investments, with its Apac platform growing to US$13 billion in assets under management since 2019. The fund was backed by a diverse group of global investors, including public and corporate pensions, sovereign wealth funds, and asset managers.

site_title: Dubai office landlord to bolster portfolio as city defies slump
summary: Dubai's largest office landlord, Tecom Group, plans to expand its portfolio by considering new developments and acquisitions to boost its commercial real estate. The company, which reported a 49% increase in annual profit, aims to buy more land and bolster its portfolio as the city's business hub defies a global slump in commercial real estate. Dubai's office occupancy rates are at an all-time high of 89%, contrasting with major cities worldwide where office landlords face challenges due to higher borrowing costs and lower occupancy.

images.alt_text: A digital rendering of the Mercedes-Benz Places.

Developers, investors and brokers are privately asking how quickly one of last year’s hottest real estate markets could turn and whether a painful correction akin to the slump that rocked the emirate in 2008 can be ruled out.

A growing number of wealth managers and family offices based in Hong Kong and Singapore are also setting up offices in Dubai, as investors look for safe havens, neutral political stance and favourable policies.
Dubai's uptick in GDP follows tHe launch of its 10-year economic plan in January 2023.

site_title: Accountancy body to offer mandatory training programme for new board directors
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (Isca) will offer a mandatory training programme for new board directors of Singapore-listed companies starting April 2024. The Board of Directors Masterclass Programme, developed in collaboration with SAC Capital, will cover corporate governance and teach directors how to corporatise their companies. The programme will include a mandatory learning course, an optional mentoring scheme, and a board-appointment service. This initiative aims to enhance corporate governance and compliance among Singapore's listed companies.

images.alt_text: Teo Ser Luck, President, Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA)

site_title: Shopee Singapore fails in court bid to stop former senior exec from joining TikTok parent company
summary: Shopee Singapore's court bid to stop its former senior executive Lim Teck Yong from joining TikTok parent company ByteDance was dismissed. The judge ruled that Shopee failed to prove Lim breached non-competition terms of his employment, and the claim was deemed not frivolous. The decision allows Lim to accept employment with ByteDance and prevent him from soliciting clients and employees.

images.alt_text: The exterior Shopee's regional headquarters in Singapore, pictured on December 20, 2022. Can be used for stories on Shopee, delivery, business, retail, job loss, economy, jobs, population, and Singapore.

site_title: Bain Capital plans to invest US$7 billion in India, boost hiring
summary: Bain Capital plans to invest US$7 billion in India over the next three to five years, driven by the country's relatively stable politics and economic growth. The investment will be made across various sectors, including IT services, financial services, pharmaceuticals, and industrials, with a focus on consumer retail and manufacturing. Bain also plans to expand its team of private equity professionals by 15-20% and explore investments from its global real estate, tech opportunities, and life sciences funds. This investment is part of a growing trend of global firms deploying billions of dollars in India, lured by the country's strong economic growth and political stability.

images.alt_text: Societe Generale, Goldman Sachs, UBS and Morgan Stanley were among the buyers of Axis Bank shares on Wednesday as Bain sold its stake.

site_title: DPM Wong to deliver Budget 2024 speech on Feb 16 at 3.30 pm
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver Singapore's Budget 2024 statement in Parliament on Feb 16 at 3:30 pm, with simultaneous sign language interpretation provided by the Singapore Association for the Deaf on Channel 5. The Budget Statement will also be broadcast live on Channel News Asia, the 8 World News website, and meWatch, with live radio coverage on CNA938 and Capital 958.

images.alt_text: Butget 101 infographic

site_title: Indonesia January inflation eases to 2.57%, in line with forecast
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate eased to 2.57% in January, in line with forecasts, as prices of chilli and transportation decreased. This marks the 13th consecutive month of slowing inflation, the lowest since December 2021. Analysts expect the central bank to maintain its policy rate at 6% in the first half of 2024 and implement a cumulative 125 basis point cut in the second half. The country aims to keep inflation within 1.5-3.5% in 2024, a lower target than last year's 2-4%.

images.alt_text: Thousands of Indonesians at an election campaign rally in South Sulawesi on Jan 17, 2024. The three presidential candidates have each promised to roll out many policies to improve the lives of the people if they are successful at the Feb 14 poll.
Indonesia’s state energy firm Pertamina has agreed with US oil majors ExxonMobil and Chevron to discuss investment of CCS projects in Indonesia.
Sri Mulyani expects Indonesia’s growth domestic product last year to be around 5 per cent.

site_title: ESR-Logos Reit eyes acquisitions for growth in 2024 as it looks to deploy S$700 million of capital
summary: ESR-Logos Reit plans to deploy S$700 million in 2024 to drive growth, focusing on acquisitions, redevelopment, and asset enhancements. The Reit posted a 3.1% decline in gross revenue and 6.5% drop in net property income to S$189.5 million and S$132.3 million, respectively, for the half-year period. Despite a 23% decline in DPU, the Reit's gearing fell to 35.7% and its five properties are valued at over S$1.7 billion. The Reit aims to deploy the bulk of its capital in Singapore and Japan, with acquisitions likely to occur in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: ESR-Reit owns general industrial property at 120 Pioneer Road (above).

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, SGX, ESR-Logos Reit, IReit Global, Noel Gifts, Keong Hong
summary: Keppel posted a 2.5% rise in net profit to S$439.9 million for the second half ended Dec 31, 2023. Singapore Exchange's net profit dipped 1% to S$281.6 million for the first half. ESR-Logos Reit's distribution per unit fell 23% to S$0.01186. IReit Global secured two new leases in France and Germany. Noel Gifts International received approval for the collective sale of its units. Keong Hong Holdings reported a net loss of S$49.5 million for the year ended Sep 30.

images.alt_text: CMG20231215-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Hotel landlord who wanted to raise rent beyond cap stated in contract loses court fight
summary: A Singapore court ruled in favor of the hotel operator, dismissing a lawsuit by landlord Hoon Kee Meng, who sought to increase rent beyond a cap stated in the tenancy agreement. The agreement did not specify the duration of the renewed lease, leading to the dispute. Meng is the sole shareholder and director of Kim San Leng Realty, a family-owned company. The court's decision upholds the cap on rent increases, preventing Meng from raising the rent beyond the specified limit.

images.alt_text: Under current rules, ABSD is refundable if the first property is sold within six months, but needs to be paid upfront in cash at the point of purchase of the second property.
There are 99 auction listings in 2023 Q4, down 2.9 per cent on the quarter.
An artist's impression of Marina Bay Sands' fourth tower.

site_title: Singapore expects to see 15 million to 16 million visitors in 2024, below pre-Covid levels
summary: Singapore expects 15-16 million international visitors in 2024, below pre-Covid levels, with forecasted tourist spending of $26-27.5 billion. This recovery is driven by improved global flight connectivity and the mutual 30-day visa exemption with China. The Singapore Tourism Board attributes 2023's tourism performance to its "robust leisure and sporting events calendar," which included the Singapore Grand Prix.

images.alt_text: Interest has been rising since both countries announced that the arrangement was in the works – though without a start date –  early last December, say industry players.
International tourism is expected to fully recover pre-pandemic levels in 2024, with initial estimates pointing to 2 per cent growth above 2019 levels, UNWTO says.

site_title: India orders Paytm payments bank to stop conducting business
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) ordered Paytm Payments Bank to stop its mobile wallet business and other banking activities due to persistent non-compliance and supervisory concerns. The bank must cease taking new deposits and conducting credit transactions after February 29, but existing customers can withdraw funds and use up balances in prepaid cards or wallets without restrictions. This decision comes nearly two years after the RBI barred the bank from taking on new customers due to rule violations.

images.alt_text: SoftBank has loosened its hold on Paytm over the past few years, trimming its stake through various open market deals.
Paytm is overhauling its operations in an attempt to achieve its first net profit since listing in November 2021.
Berkshire’s exit comes after a string of selldowns for Paytm, including stake cuts by Japanese conglomerate SoftBank Group and the exit of China’s Alibaba Group.

site_title: Japan January factory activity shrinks modestly on softer demand: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank for an eighth straight month in January, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) at 48.0, below the 50 threshold. Output and new orders declined due to subsiding economic conditions at home and overseas. Manufacturers cited cost pressures, supply disruptions, and weak demand from China as concerns. Despite this, confidence remained strong, driven by hopes for improved demand in markets such as semiconductors. The slowdown is expected to continue, with outstanding business showing the sharpest depletion since August 2020.

images.alt_text: The return to growth in production will offer support for the economy, pointing to the likelihood that it rebounded in the fourth quarter after a sharp contraction in summer.
The Bank of Japan is watching the labour market closely as it seeks evidence of a virtuous cycle linking rising wages with demand-led price gains.
The BOJ has pledged to keep ultra-loose policy until the recent cost-push inflation is replaced by price rises driven by robust domestic demand, accompanied by higher wages.

site_title: UBS weighs cutting about 90 jobs at Asia wealth, bank teams
summary: UBS Group is considering cutting approximately 90 jobs in its Asia private wealth and investment banking divisions in March, amid a deal drought and revenue erosion. The planned cuts, which have not been finalized, would affect around 70 jobs at the private bank and 20 at the global banking division. The jobs to be eliminated include relationship managers and supporting roles in Greater China and Singapore, with the bank expecting more voluntary departures following bonus payouts.

images.alt_text: UBS is making progress on a complex integration and restructuring of Credit Suisse, which it acquired in an emergency rescue.
UBS will use the slogan “Banking is our craft” as it seeks to attract new customers to its wealth management, asset management, and investment banking franchises.
The Swiss government and regulator opted not to put Credit Suisse into a wind-down procedure as it faced a collapse in confidence last year, instead brokering the takeover by UBS.

site_title: EC World Reit seeks legal action against sponsor in China as illegal mortgages not removed by deadline
summary: EC World Reit is seeking legal action against its sponsor, Forchn, in China for the discharge of illegal mortgages imposed over Fuzhou E-Commerce and Fuheng Warehouse. The mortgages, worth 268.6 million yuan (S$51.3 million), were not removed by the deadline of Wednesday, and the Reit's lenders have given Forchn until February 1 to discharge the remaining two mortgages. The Reit's manager is also evaluating options for the group.

images.alt_text: Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou is one of the properties still illegally mortgaged by EC World Reit's sponsor.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou owned by EC World Reit
Forchn Holdings, the sponsor of EC World Reit, is said to be working on solutions to discharge the remaining two illegal mortgages on Fuzhou E-Commerce (above) and Fu Heng Warehouse.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou owned by EC World Reit
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou is one of the three  EC World Reit properties that have been mortgaged by the Reit's sponsor.
The properties – Fuzhou E-Commerce, Fu Heng Warehouse (above) and Hengde Logistics – have been mortgaged without approval from EC World Reit.

site_title: Keppel H2 profit rises 2.5%, posts record full-year profits on O&M unit sale
summary: Keppel, a global asset manager and operator, reported a record full-year profit of S$4.1 billion, up 4 times from last year, driven by gains from the sale of its Keppel Offshore & Marine unit to Seatrium. Net profit from continuing operations rose 2.5% to S$439.9 million in the second half, and revenue from continuing operations was nearly flat at S$3.3 billion. The company's infrastructure segment saw significant growth, with full-year net profit more than doubling to S$699 million.

images.alt_text: Keppel wants to improve on its sustainability performance with its latest revolving credit facilities with DBS and UOB.

The LCT-IC will accelerate the development of cost-effective carbon capture, utilisation and sequestration (CCUS), as well as the production, transportation, distribution and utilisation of lower carbon hydrogen and its derivatives at scale, the parties said in a media statement.
Keppel signs deal to provide electricity for GlobalFoundries’ Singapore operations
Both Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Industries have continued to pursue renewable energy solutions, notes SGX.

site_title: Hatten Land receives notice of default for US$20 million convertible loan
summary: Hatten Land, a Malaysian property developer, has received a notice of default for a US$20 million convertible loan from lender Haitong International Financial Products (Singapore). The notice demands repayment of US$21.5 million, including principal and interest, within five business days. Hatten Land has been negotiating a settlement agreement with Haitong, which has agreed to withhold recovery actions until March 31, 2024. The loan was obtained in 2017 to finance the completion of the Hatten City project and other development projects.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Harbour City, Hatten Land's project in Melaka.
An artist impression of the Harbour City project in Melaka.
Hatten Land said it has in Q3 prioritised securing anchor tenants to its malls.

site_title: PSA said to show interest in port operator Wilson Sons
summary: PSA International, owned by Singapore's Temasek Holdings, has shown interest in acquiring Brazilian port and logistics company Wilson Sons. Potential buyers in China have also expressed interest. Wilson Sons' controlling shareholder, Ocean Wilsons Holdings, initiated a strategic review in June, and received non-binding offers for its stake in November. This move comes as the company conducts a review of its investment.

site_title: China sets deadline for cities to set up financing coordination mechanism for property projects
summary: China's housing and financial regulators have set a deadline of March 15 for prefecture-level and above cities to establish a financing coordination mechanism to support the country's struggling property sector. The mechanism, known as "Project Whitelist," aims to prevent loan misappropriation and safeguard credit funds. As of February 28, 276 cities in 31 provinces have set up such mechanisms, with over 6,000 real estate projects proposed and commercial banks approving over 200 billion yuan (S$37.4 billion) in loans for eligible projects.

site_title: Why investors should be wary of ‘mergers of equals’
summary: Investors should exercise caution when considering mergers of equals, where two companies of similar size combine. Research shows that the stock price of the combined company tends to underperform industry peers by over seven percentage points over the following two years. In fact, investors may be better off selling the shares of the acquirer on the day of the announcement. High-quality companies, financial health, and profitability are key considerations when evaluating mergers of equals, with poor performance often resulting from mismanaged companies.

images.alt_text: VivoCity, an asset under merged entity Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust. The Securities Industries Council says advisers to the deal leading up to its formation have breached the Singapore Code on Take-overs and Mergers.
Grab and GoTo are reportedly discussing a range of scenarios under which both companies could merge.

site_title: South Korea January exports rise for fourth month, chip sales surge
summary: South Korea's exports rose 18% year-over-year to $54.7 billion in January, driven by a surge in chip sales, the largest gain since May 2022. This marks the fourth consecutive month of growth, following a year-long downturn. Semiconductor exports jumped 56.2% and exports to the US and EU also increased. The preliminary trade balance showed a surplus of $0.3 billion, the largest in three years. The growth is expected to continue this year, contributing to economic growth.

images.alt_text: A man looks on cranes and shipping containers from an observation platform at Pyeongtaek port in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, July 9, 2020.    REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: SGX posts 1% lower H1 profit at S$281.6 million
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 1% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$281.6 million for the first half of FY2024, driven by lower contributions from cash equities and derivatives equities segments. Revenue grew 3.6% to S$592.2 million, mainly due to higher revenues from the currencies and commodities segment. Despite muted global economic growth and geopolitical uncertainties, the company remains cautious but expects to capitalize on conditions across cycles through its multi-asset strategy.

images.alt_text: The payment of the redemption amount will be made on or about Feb 13, Pegasus said in a bourse filing.
SINGAPORE Exchange (SGX) is looking to reduce its dependency on trading volumes by partnering with Clearstream to begin a new collateral management service in 12 to 18 months - PHOTO: REUTERS
SGX will collaborate with regional bourses to increase market connectivity, says SGX president Michael Syn.

site_title: Bank of America’s Merrill, Wells Fargo offer Bitcoin ETF products for clients
summary: Bank of America's Merrill and Wells Fargo are now offering Bitcoin ETF products to some wealth management clients, following the successful debut of the products by nearly a dozen firms in January. The move comes as Bitcoin has jumped over 40% this year, with the approval of Bitcoin ETFs by US regulators sparking a surge in demand. Several other firms, including Charles Schwab and Robinhood Markets, have already started offering the products, while Vanguard Group has expressed hesitation, citing that crypto is more of a speculation than an investment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A bitcoin logo is pictured on a door in an illustration picture taken at La Maison du Bitcoin in Paris May 27, 2015. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo
With Franklin’s registration, there are now eight ETF providers competing to introduce spot ether ETFs, all of whom rolled out spot bitcoin products in January.
The pullback underscores how confident investors are that the Federal Reserve has brought inflation back under control.

site_title: Haleon sees sluggish Q1 growth on tepid flu season, China demand
summary: British consumer healthcare giant Haleon expects its first-quarter organic revenue growth to be just below 4% due to a tepid cold and flu season and cooling China demand. Despite price increases, cheaper private-label competition has allowed rivals to catch up. The company forecasts organic revenue growth of 4-6% for 2024, below analyst expectations of 4.5%. CEO Brian McNamara expressed confidence in delivering on guidance, citing the company's well-positioned position in a challenging operating environment.

images.alt_text: Haleon has more than 24,000 staff globally.

site_title: Salesforce outlook disappoints as AI fails to spark growth
summary: Salesforce's annual sales outlook fell short of estimates, with revenue projected to increase 9% to $38 billion in 2025, below the average analyst estimate of $38.6 billion. The company attributed the disappointing result to its focus on cost-cutting and improving profitability, with AI-based features yet to spark significant growth. Adjusted operating margin is expected to be 32.5%, beating Wall Street estimates. Salesforce also announced a 4% decline in its shares and a $10 billion increase in its share repurchase program.

images.alt_text: Salesforce is betting that interest in artificial intelligence will fuel a new cycle of tech investment.
Salesforce had 70,456 full-time employees at the end of the fiscal second quarter on Jul 31.
Salesforce’s plans for reducing headcount by about 8,000 people by the end of fiscal 2024 are the company’s largest ever.

site_title: Changes to SGX restructuring framework are an upgrade – for judicial managers
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has proposed changes to its restructuring framework to aid company restructuring, aligning with Singapore's Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act 2018. The proposed enhancements aim to speed up the process and increase the chances of white knight rescues and trading resumptions, benefiting shareholders. Key changes include removing shareholder approval requirements for selling major assets and providing relief for shareholders if judicial managers act unfairly. Industry players have generally responded positively, but some have expressed concern about a potential power shift from shareholders to creditors.

images.alt_text: Public consultation on changes proposed by SGX RegCo will run until March 22.

The intention behind the writers' study of the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act is to obtain qualitative insights into views and perceptions as to the law in practice, from an empirical perspective.
In the Zipmex restructuring case, the Singapore High Court had to consider whether the unregistered foreign Zipmex entities have a “substantial connection” to Singapore as a threshold issue.

Amid the rise of restructuring, other tools have also emerged that help struggling debtors find a way forward. These are important as a complete liquidation may be more beneficial in some circumstances.

Corporate lawyers agreed that temporary relief measures and government financial support for businesses during the pandemic provided a reprieve from the commencement of winding up applications in 2020 and 2021.

site_title: Goldman Sachs CEO says firm to raise ninth private equity fund
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon announced plans to raise the firm's ninth private equity fund this year, with the goal of achieving mid-teen percentage returns for its global banking and markets business in the medium-term. The firm's asset and wealth management business is expected to project strong margins. Solomon also noted improvements in the investment banking business, but stated it still lags behind its 10-year average. Despite a 24% drop in net profit last year, Solomon received a 24% pay bump to $31 million.

images.alt_text: Goldman’s 5,200 price target for the S&P 500 in 2024 is now among the highest on Wall Street.

site_title: Investing in the Dragon year: No room for complacency
summary: US equities have started a new bullish phase since bottoming out in October 2022, driven by expectations of early and sustained rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The surge in equities, marked by a 24% gain in three months, has been fueled by institutional investors' increasing participation and corporate earnings growth. However, market sentiment has become too bullish, and investors should be cautious, as the Fed's rate cut path is conditional on disinflation and a robust labour market. With supply-driven disinflation expected to continue, investors should be prepared for a volatile market and consider outsourcing decisions to professional investment managers.

images.alt_text: Despite middling economic growth and the Covid-19 pandemic, stock markets have offered annual returns, after inflation, of more than 8 per cent a year since 2010, including dividends and capital gains.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished  0.2 per cent lower at 39,069.23 on Monday, pulling back from an all-time high.

site_title: Massimo Bottura lends star power to pizza and pasta at Torno Subito
summary: Massimo Bottura's Torno Subito, a modern Italian eatery in Dempsey, Singapore, offers a comfortingly stylish dining experience with a playful, beach-inspired interior. The menu features creative twists on Italian classics, such as smoked hamachi and pressed melon, comforting ragu tagliatelle, and succulent poached cod. Standout desserts include a revivified tiramisu and tre cioccolati. Chef Alessio Pirozzo's focus on quality and technique shines through, making Torno Subito a standout in the dining scene, with a rating of 7 out of 10.

images.alt_text: Air's dining room is furnished with sustainable tables and chairs.

site_title: Swedish property giants write down billions as prices crash
summary: Two major Swedish property companies, SBB and Heimstaden, announced significant writedowns in their 2023 results, with SBB writing down property value by 13 billion Swedish crowns (S$1.69 billion) and Heimstaden by 31 billion crowns, resulting in significant losses. Despite expressing cautious optimism, shares of both companies fell. The property market in Europe, particularly Germany and Sweden, has been impacted by a sharp rise in interest rates, leading to a bubble bursting. Experts warn of potential further falls in the market, with Sweden's central bank chief highlighting the commercial real estate sector as a key concern.

images.alt_text: Attention has been focused on the commercial property market, but the biggest effect so far has been in housing construction.
Oscar Properties has been hit with two separate bankruptcy claims from creditors in recent weeks.

site_title: Pan-United pivots to becoming a solutions provider by selling IP in sustainable concrete
summary: Pan-United Corporation, a ready-mix concrete producer, is pivoting to become a solutions provider by selling intellectual property in sustainable concrete. The company aims to expand its positive impact beyond its geographical footprint by sharing its knowledge and expertise with other like-minded companies. Pan-United will offer various capabilities, including technological solutions, product licensing, and technical management. The company has over 300 low-carbon concrete solutions in its portfolio, with a goal to sell only low-carbon concrete by 2030, reducing emissions by 58% on average. Despite higher costs, Pan-United posted a 107% net profit increase for the second half of 2023.

Pan-United's concrete mixer trucks at one of its batching plants. The company reported an increase in revenue for the second half of its 2023 financial year.

The LCT-IC will accelerate the development of cost-effective carbon capture, utilisation and sequestration (CCUS), as well as the production, transportation, distribution and utilisation of lower carbon hydrogen and its derivatives at scale, the parties said in a media statement.

site_title: The upside of geopolitical uncertainty
summary: Investors should consider the potential benefits of geopolitical uncertainty, as risk in one part of the world can create opportunities in another. Europe may benefit from US-China tensions, with China investing in strategic sectors such as battery production and electric vehicle manufacturing, providing cheaper goods and new manufacturing jobs. In the Global South, countries like Malaysia, Vietnam, and Indonesia are emerging as winners, diversifying away from China and Russia, and elevating their position in the value chain. Meanwhile, countries like Japan and South Korea are benefiting from China's divestment, and India is gaining global influence through new agreements with the US.

images.alt_text: While many investors do focus on anticipating cyclical turning points, most are focused on making returns over the longer term.

site_title: How Trump defeated Nikki Haley in her home state of South Carolina
summary: US President Donald Trump won the South Carolina primary by a 20-point margin, defeating Nikki Haley, his former governor and a potential presidential rival. Trump's campaign successfully isolated Haley by securing endorsements from 158 current and former South Carolina Republican officials, including lawmakers and mayors, while Haley received endorsements from only one member of the US House of Representatives and two mayors. Trump's data-driven campaign and aggressive outreach efforts, led by state operatives and governor Henry McMaster, played a significant role in his victory. Haley vowed to continue her presidential campaign despite the loss.
