site_title: The art of cyberdefence
summary: A global firm, "Victim Co," headquartered in Singapore, was breached by a cybermercenary army wielding ransomware, encrypting its data and exfiltrating hundreds of gigabytes of corporate information. The attackers, operating as a "Ransomware as a Service" (RaaS) gang, targeted the firm's 2,000 servers and end points. This incident highlights the need for preparedness and self-knowledge in the age of cyberwarfare, as passive defense is a losing game. The firm's data is now being held hostage, emphasizing the importance of effective cybersecurity measures to prevent such incidents.

images.alt_text: The law enforcement from more than 20 countries in October, which led to hundreds of arrests, demonstrated the “expanding geographical footprint” of the crime, the Interpol says.

site_title: ASML reaches ‘first light’ milestone on first High NA EUV tool
summary: ASML, a Dutch semiconductor equipment maker, has reached "first light" on its massive High NA EUV lithography system, a milestone marking the tool's functionality despite not being at full performance. The system, costing over $350 million each, is expected to enable new generations of smaller, faster chips for companies like Intel, TSMC, and Samsung. The first High NA tool is at ASML's laboratory in the Netherlands, and the second is under assembly at an Intel plant in Oregon, with Intel planning to use the tool in production for its 14A generation of chips.

images.alt_text: ASML is the only maker of a key technology – extreme ultraviolet photolithography – needed to manufacture the most advanced chips.
The surge has allowed ASML to overtake Swiss food group Nestle as Europe’s third-largest listed company.
ASML registers strong orders of more than nine billion euros in the fourth quarter – more than triple third-quarter levels.

site_title: Sony plans financial unit IPO in 2025 after PS5 sales falter
summary: Sony plans to list its financial arm in October 2025, aiming for a major capital infusion after cutting its forecast for its core gaming division. The move comes after the company reported disappointing hardware sales of the PS5, with only 8.2 million consoles sold in the December quarter, down from a projected 9.2 million. Sony now expects 12.3 trillion yen in sales for the year, down from 12.4 trillion yen previously. The listing will reverse a $3.7 billion take-private deal concluded in 2020, as the company seeks to balance profitability and sales.

images.alt_text: The results come weeks after Sony scrapped its merger with Zee.

site_title: StanChart suspends new investments from clients via China’s outbound channel
summary: Standard Chartered has suspended new investments by its clients in China into offshore products via a quota-based channel, citing "commercial reasons". The move comes amid Beijing's efforts to stem capital outflows as the yuan weakens and the economy slows. The Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor (QDII) programme, China's largest outbound investment channel, is capped by a quota set by the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. This suspension follows a surge in demand for overseas investments due to weakness in the local market and currency.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Standard Chartered bank logo is seen at their headquarters in London, Britain, July 26, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: Eating air in Matt Orlando and Will Goldfarb’s new eco-restaurant in Dempsey
summary: Singapore's new eco-restaurant, AIR, has opened in Dempsey, showcasing a 40,000 sq ft space made from recycled materials. The restaurant serves dishes made from kitchen scraps, including fermented cassava bread, papaya panna cotta, and seared lion's mane mushroom. While the dining room's lofty ideals score high, the food quality is hit-or-miss, with some dishes, like the papaya panna cotta, standing out as highlights. AIR aims to reduce food waste and promote sustainability, but its culinary offerings still need improvement.

images.alt_text: Tribal's tasteful interiors.

site_title: Roblox game developers earned a record US$741 million last year
summary: Roblox game developers earned a record US$741 million last year, a 19% increase from 2022. Since its launch in 2006, developers have created millions of games for the platform, with nearly 100 titles generating over US$1 million in sales each. The platform's 68 million average daily active users generated US$3.5 billion in bookings, with top 10 games absorbing 30% of players' time.

images.alt_text: The company’s popularity among young adults delivers Roblox US$81.1 million in adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation, also exceeding expectations.
Roblox gets 66 million daily users and is available on mobile devices, desktops, and Microsoft’s Xbox.

site_title: Thai central bank head rejects PM’s call for urgent rate cut
summary: Thai Central Bank Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput rejected Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's call for an urgent interest rate cut, citing a risk to financial stability. The governor said a premature rate cut won't solve the economy's structural problems and that household debt is above 90% of GDP. Despite weak growth, Thailand's recovery continues, and the central bank will weigh growth data before making decisions. The tension between the central bank and the prime minister is attributed to their different roles, with the governor describing their relationship as professional and cordial.

site_title: Hong Kong is over unless China fixes its own economy, Roach says
summary: Former Morgan Stanley Asia chair Stephen Roach says Hong Kong's economic success is over due to Beijing's tightening grip and rising US-China tensions. Roach, a Yale University senior lecturer, blames China's stringent Covid curbs, property crisis, and crackdowns on the private sector for eroding Hong Kong's growth prospects. He urges Beijing to fix its own economy and let Hong Kong run itself to ensure a better future for the financial hub.

site_title: Wildcard candidates threaten to tip scales in US election
summary: Wildcard candidates are gaining traction in the 2024 US presidential election, with voters open to alternatives to Joe Biden and Donald Trump. Despite having little chance of winning, some independent or third-party candidates could sway a close election. Analysts note that Green Party's Jill Stein's 2016 performance in swing states demonstrates the potential impact of such candidates. Voters are increasingly disenchanted with the two-party system, and a public survey shows they don't want a rematch between Biden and Trump.

site_title: 1MDB-linked firms put into Chapter 15 as liquidators seek assets
summary: Liquidators of companies linked to the 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) scandal have filed for Chapter 15 under the US bankruptcy code in an effort to recover assets. The petition, dated February 15, involves five firms in the British Virgin Islands, including 1MDB Energy Holdings and Platinum Global Luxury Services. The companies allegedly acted as conduits for funds from 1MDB to other entities and individuals. The move is part of ongoing investigations into deal-making, election spending, and political patronage under former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover on soft UK inflation data, upbeat earnings
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 ended up 0.5% on Wednesday, following a 1% drop in the previous session, as a softer-than-expected UK inflation report boosted hopes of imminent interest rate cuts by the Bank of England. Upbeat corporate earnings, including BT's 19.6% gain, added to the recovery. The UK's FTSE 100 advanced 0.8% after domestic inflation held steady in January, defying forecasts. Global equities steadied after a sell-off following hotter-than-expected US inflation data, with European markets in a "buy the dip" mindset.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index ended 1.0 per cent lower on Tuesday after data showed US consumer prices increased more than expected in January amid rising shelter and healthcare costs.

site_title: Bitcoin market cap back above US$1 trillion in broad crypto rally
summary: Bitcoin's market capitalization surpassed US$1 trillion for the first time since December 2021, driven by a 21% year-to-date gain. The cryptocurrency rallied alongside other assets, including Ether, Avalanche, and Polkadot, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid economic uncertainty. The Securities and Exchange Commission's approval of Bitcoin ETFs and the upcoming Bitcoin halving in April are seen as supporting factors. However, analysts caution that technical signals suggest the rally may temporarily pause or dip to the high US$30,000s.

images.alt_text: Optimism about the quadrennial Bitcoin halving due in April is also filtering across crypto.

site_title: Nominations open for BT, UOB Sustainability Impact Awards, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The European Union is facing severe consequences as the continent experiences a prolonged heatwave. Rising temperatures are expected to lead to crop failures, food shortages, and increased mortality rates. The EU's agricultural sector is projected to lose up to €10 billion annually, while the tourism industry is expected to decline by 20%. The heatwave also poses significant risks to EU's water resources, with droughts affecting 70% of the continent. The EU's climate policies are under scrutiny, and the bloc is urged to take drastic measures to mitigate the effects of climate change and protect its citizens.

site_title: Bitters and Love wants to be a bar for would-be sweethearts
summary: Bitters and Love, a Singaporean bar, has introduced a new cocktail menu inspired by distant lands, following the post-Covid era of travel recovery. The menu features seven region-specific drinks, including a reinterpreted Singapore Sling and a gin-based cocktail with a Mediterranean vibe. The bar also offers a section of bitters, including five negroni variations and a unique bak kut teh bitter, and an off-menu selection of unique drinks featuring local ingredients. Bitters and Love aims to spark memories and personal connections among drinkers, making it a popular date-night spot.

site_title: Cooking over the fire at Tribal
summary: Tribal Dining, a new restaurant in Mondrian Singapore, offers fuss-free cooking in relaxed surroundings. Located at #01-07, 83 Neil Road, it is open for dinner only from Monday to Saturday, 6 pm to 11:30 pm. This addition to the culinary advent calendar in Mondrian Singapore brings a unique dining experience, blending primal instincts with online grocery elements, providing a new option for foodies to enjoy.

site_title: Asia’s lead in global carbon markets is one to follow
summary: Asia is leading the way in global carbon markets, with countries such as Singapore, Japan, and Thailand experimenting with their own alternatives to international agreements. Asian projects supplied over half of the credits sold on the voluntary carbon market in 2021, and demand for credits is rising. Singapore is well-positioned to become Asia's biggest international carbon trading hub, with its enhanced carbon tax and innovative domestic strategy. The region's innovation in carbon markets is expected to have a significant influence on global carbon markets and climate decisions, particularly at the COP29 climate summit.

site_title: Luxury wine and spirits travel retail goes up a notch
summary: Lotte Duty Free has revamped its Terminal 3 store at Changi Airport with a US$19 million makeover, featuring the world's first The House of Suntory shop-in-shop boutique and interactive wine sommelier. The store offers luxurious shopping experiences with brands such as Hennessy, Penfolds, and Pernod Ricard. The revamped store is part of Lotte Duty Free's 19 stores at Changi Airport, covering over 8,000 square meters of retail space. The company projects a high-double-digit percentage increase in sales for fiscal year 2024, driven by growing demand for premium and luxury alcoholic beverages in Asia.

site_title: Hershey and Cadbury chocolate makers eye price hikes to cover cocoa crunch
summary: Hershey and Cadbury chocolate makers, Mondelez, plan price hikes to cover the record-setting surge in cocoa prices, which have roughly doubled over the past year. The price increases will be implemented to manage the business amid declining sales and inflation. Consumers have cut back on purchases, with Hershey's sales volumes down 6.6% in the last quarter. The companies will focus on new products to boost demand, but retailers in Europe may resist the price hikes, leading to lower sales in the region.

site_title: Chef Daniel Boulud banks on classic cooking to keep diners returning
summary: French chef Daniel Boulud has opened his rebranded restaurant Maison Boulud at Marina Bay Sands in Singapore, featuring a double-storey space with an outdoor terrace. Boulud, who has four Michelin-starred restaurants in New York, is banking on a classic formula of decent pricing, fine ingredients, and updated flavors to keep diners interested. He aims to create a relaxing and tasty meal at an affordable price, with a prix fixe menu starting at S$62 for two courses. The restaurant is part of Boulud's expansion plans, which include openings in Riyadh and the US this year.

site_title: Budget 2024: Quick takes on Refundable Investment Credit scheme
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Refundable Investment Credit (RIC) scheme to support high-value and substantive economic activities, including manufacturing, innovation, R&D, and green transition. The scheme offers a refundable cash feature to help companies offset corporate income tax and encourages foreign investments. The RIC will be awarded on qualifying expenditures incurred by companies and will have a qualifying period of up to 10 years. The scheme aims to help Singapore stay competitive and attract investments from global companies with the right know-how.

site_title: Departing from Singapore, a luxe locomotive redux
summary: The Eastern & Oriental Express, a luxury train operated by Belmond, has resumed operations after a four-year hiatus, offering two new seasonal itineraries connecting Singapore and Malaysia. The train features ornate furnishings, locally sourced materials, and region-inspired cuisine, including dishes created by culinary curator Andre Chiang. The journey offers scenic views of Malaysia's natural landscapes, opportunities to immerse in local culture, and a chance to experience sustainable travel. Prices start at US$3,410 per person for a three-night trip. The train's appeal has broadened to attract a new generation of passengers, with a focus on slow travel, nature, culture, and sustainability.

site_title: Bullish investors drop recession calls for first time since April 2022
summary: Global investors have become the most bullish in two years, cutting recession calls for the first time since April 2022. A Bank of America survey found 65% of fund managers now expect a soft landing, while 11% predict a hard landing. The S&P 500 has hit record highs above 5,000, driven by enthusiasm for AI and a strong earnings season. Investors are also increasing global stocks allocations to a two-year high, with tech stocks being a major focus.

site_title: Willin Low in Niseko: ‘The community has become my family’
summary: Singapore chef-restaurateur Willin Low has found a new home in Niseko, Japan, where he opened a seasonal restaurant, Roketto, serving Singaporean flavors with Japanese ingredients. After winding down his Wild Rocket restaurant in Singapore, Low chose Niseko for its unique ingredients, snowboarding opportunities, and warm community. Despite initial challenges, including navigating bureaucracy and a labor shortage, Low's experience has been rewarding, with the community becoming his "family." Roketto is now on track to break even, with a possible Enterprise Singapore grant to support its recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Australia consumer confidence jumps to 20-month high in Feb
summary: Australia's consumer confidence surged to a 20-month high in February, jumping 6.2% from January, driven by a slowdown in inflation to a two-year low of 4.1% and expectations of interest rate cuts. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index reading of 86.0 showed pessimists outnumbering optimists, but overall sentiment remains optimistic. Consumer spending intentions and outlook for the economy also improved, with a 11.3% increase in the index measuring whether it's a good time to buy major household items.

The Reserve Bank of Australia held interest rates steady at a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent last week, having last hiked by a quarter point in November.

site_title: There’s no limit to what the negroni can do
summary: The Negroni, a classic Italian cocktail, has inspired a variety of adjacent alternatives. Bartenders and enthusiasts can experiment with different ingredients, such as swapping gin for Campari, sweet vermouth for dry wine, or adding aquavit for a savory twist. The article highlights several variations, including the Milano-Torino, Americano, and bicicletta, offering readers a range of options to modify the classic Negroni recipe and discover new flavors.

site_title: Bezos sells US$2 billion of Amazon shares in first major stock sale since 2021
summary: Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder, sold 12 million shares worth over $2 billion, marking his first major stock sale since 2021. This sale is part of his plan to sell up to 50 million shares over the next 12 months, potentially increasing his net worth to over $221 billion. Bezos has sold over $30 billion in shares since 2002, including $20 billion in 2020 and 2021.

site_title: Dollar eases as market shrugs off inflation revision data
summary: The US dollar eased on Friday as it headed for a fourth week of gains, despite revised US monthly consumer prices that rose less than initially estimated in December. Traders reduced bets on the Bank of Japan raising interest rates and the Federal Reserve cutting rates, citing a mixed inflation picture and Fed officials' signal that there's no pressing need to cut rates. The dollar index fell 0.07% to 104.04, while the euro rose 0.08% to $1.0785.

images.alt_text: Core goods prices fell in the first half, but not as steeply as had been previously estimated, while the increase in the cost of services was revised down for November and December.

site_title: Temu spent millions on six Super Bowl ads as it tries to win back US shoppers
summary: Temu, a Chinese e-commerce app, spent an estimated tens of millions of US dollars on six Super Bowl ads in an attempt to boost US sales. Despite a 12.5% month-on-month sales drop in December and 4.8% drop in January, Temu's parent company PDD Holdings has seen its valuation hover around that of rival Alibaba Group Holding. Analysts predict that Temu's rapid growth may be slowing, with declining margins and a need for steep discounts to regain market share.

images.alt_text: In Temu’s first full year of operation in the US, Gen Xers and Baby Boomers shopped there more frequently and spent more than younger shoppers.
Chinese car maker BYD is

site_title: ShopBack feels the pinch as voucher revenue dips 50% in FY23
summary: ShopBack, a Singapore-based cashback and rewards platform, posted US$87.7 million in revenue for FY23, a 20% year-on-year decline, with voucher revenue dropping 50%. The company's losses before tax widened by 29% due to one-off expenses. Despite this, ShopBack remains optimistic about its growth prospects and is preparing for a potential IPO, with sufficient cash reserves to sustain operations for over three years. The company has also expanded its business into new markets, including Germany, and plans to enter new markets annually.

images.alt_text: "Organisations cannot place sole reliance on their employees to perform their duties properly as a security arrangement to protect personal data," said the Personal Data Protection Commission.

site_title: Mattel forecasts annual profit above expectations as costs ease
summary: Mattel forecasts annual profit above expectations, driven by cost-saving measures and a US$1 billion share buyback program. The company announced a new cost savings program focused on streamlining its supply chain. Despite missing market estimates for holiday-quarter sales and profit, Mattel expects 2024 net sales to be in-line with 2023, and adjusted profit per share to be between US$1.35 and US$1.45.

images.alt_text: Mattel Films is also developing projects based on other popular toy lines, including American Girl, Hot Wheels, Magic Ball, Barney and more.
The Aequs toy manufacturing facility in Belgaum, India..
Hasbro has struggled to shake off a post-pandemic hangover.
Hasbro now expects fiscal 2023 revenue to fall 13 per cent to 15 per cent.

site_title: Barclays buys Tesco bank for £600 million
summary: Barclays has acquired Tesco's banking business for £600 million, including £4.2 billion in credit-card receivables, £4.1 billion in unsecured personal loans, and £6.7 billion in customer deposits. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, is expected to complete in the second half of 2024. Barclays will use the Tesco brand to market and distribute credit cards, unsecured personal loans, and deposits for a 10-year period. The transaction is expected to reduce Barclays' common equity tier 1 ratio by 0.3%, with minimal impact on financial returns and shareholder distributions.

images.alt_text: Barclays has one of the lowest valuations among peers, with shares down by around 24 per cent in the last year, driven in part by a hefty disposal of stock by a top investor, Qatar Holding.

site_title: Clearbridge Health sees ‘material decrease’ in FY2023 results; expects impairment, fair value losses
summary: Clearbridge Health has reported a "material decrease" in its FY2023 financial performance due to lower revenues from medical clinics, centres, and the distribution of medical and pharmaceutical products. The company expects impairment, fair value losses, and an allowance for credit losses, primarily related to its medical centres and receivables. These losses are expected to be material but cannot be quantified at this stage. The company's FY2023 financial results are set to be released on or before February 29.

images.alt_text: Biolidics, who produces and distributes Covid-19 test kits, is seeking to extend its debt repayment deadline to Clearbridge Health.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Feb 8)
summary: Former transport minister S Iswaran was conditionally approved to leave Singapore to settle his son in an Australian university, with his case transferred to the High Court. Su Jianfeng, a money laundering accused, was handed two new charges for submitting forged documents. Fullerton Health's three co-founders were charged with corruption and falsifying nearly half a million dollars in entertainment claims.

site_title: Singapore’s tripartite guidelines on non-compete clauses to be released in second half of 2024
summary: Singapore plans to release tripartite guidelines on non-compete clauses in employment contracts by the second half of 2024, aiming to educate employers and shape norms. The guidelines will help balance employers' needs to safeguard their businesses with employees' ability to earn a living. The Manpower Ministry will assess whether the clauses are reasonable, justified, and fair. Employers who fail to comply with the guidelines can be approached by the Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices (Tafep) or the Ministry of Manpower (MOM).

images.alt_text: Of 16,300 mandatory retrenchment notifications received by MOM from 2019 to 2023, around 30 per cent were submitted more than five working days after affected employees were notified, said Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng.
Chiam Sheng Shi from Endowus conducting a financial literacy course to delivery partners from foodpanda.
Lazada and the FDAWU have settled on a better support package and training fund for laid off union members.

site_title: Boustead Projects to delist on Feb 9
summary: Boustead Projects will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on February 9, 2024, after its parent company, Boustead Singapore, failed to acquire 90% of its non-controlled shares. The exit offer received 89.36% valid acceptances, leaving about 0.64% of shares held by minority shareholders. Boustead Singapore now controls 99.45% of Boustead Projects.

site_title: JPMorgan’s China CEO Mark Leung to retire after 25 years
summary: JPMorgan Chase's China CEO Mark Leung, a 25-year veteran, will retire at the end of 2024 amid increasing challenges for global lenders in China. Under his leadership since 2018, JPMorgan's China revenue doubled, and the bank became the first foreign firm to fully own a securities business and a futures company. Leung's departure comes as lenders struggle to generate profits in China's slowing economy and amid geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: The shuffle, halfway through Dimon’s five-year retention package, places Jenn Piepszak and Troy Rohrbaugh atop an expanded commercial and investment bank

site_title: China’s central bank adds 150 billion yuan in cheap housing funds
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has added 150 billion yuan (S$28.5 billion) to its low-cost funds for housing and infrastructure projects, supporting the economy amid a record property downturn. The Pledged Supplemental Lending (PSL) programme has a total outstanding amount of 3.4 trillion yuan and aims to drive credit and investment through construction projects. Analysts forecast the programme could eventually drive new credit by 1.5 trillion yuan, but its impact may take time to manifest.

images.alt_text: Outstanding PSL loans totalled 3.4022 trillion yuan at the end of January, compared with 3.2522 trillion yuan at end-December, the central bank says.
The PBOC has increasingly leaned on tools that steer credit to specific sectors since 2020, when the pandemic hit economic growth.
The People’s Bank of China and the National Financial Regulatory Administration will allow bank loans pledged by developers’ commercial properties to be used to repay other loans and bonds.

site_title: Billionaire Gautam Adani’s Group reports its cash pile has risen
summary: Billionaire Gautam Adani's conglomerate reported a 60% increase in Ebitda to $2.3 billion in the third quarter, driven by its transport, infrastructure, and energy units. The group's cash balances have improved, allowing it to fund long-term debt repayments for over 15 months. Following a short-seller attack last year, Adani Group has taken steps to shore up its finances, with no refinancing risks anticipated in the near term. The company's net debt has dropped 3.5% to $21.72 billion, and it has secured new funding and investors.

images.alt_text: Gautam Adani’s rebound is happening as global investors increasingly focus on the nation, helping boost stocks.
The flagship firm of billionaire Gautam Adani’s empire posted net income of 18.9 billion rupees (S$305 million) for the quarter through December

site_title: What do an Apartment and a secret garden have to do with luxury?
summary: Luxury brands Louis Vuitton and Van Cleef & Arpels have unveiled new retail concepts in Singapore, focusing on storytelling and showcasing their heritage. Louis Vuitton's "Apartment" features a 7,427 sq ft space with a mini-museum, archives, and exclusive salons for men's and women's ready-to-wear and high jewelry. Van Cleef & Arpels' "Les Jardins Secrets" boutique features a 678 sq ft exhibition area with a secret door, highlighting the brand's heritage and craftsmanship. Both spaces are by appointment only, prioritizing a personalized luxury experience.

site_title: Thailand airport operator expects 8 million Chinese visitors this year
summary: Thailand's airport operator, Airports of Thailand (AOT), expects 8 million Chinese tourists to arrive in 2024, following the mutual visa waiver agreement between the two countries. This increase is driven by the removal of visa requirements for Chinese nationals, which was implemented in late 2023. The move aims to revive tourism, particularly from China, which is Thailand's former top source market. AOT is prepared for the sharp increase in flights and passengers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tourists arrive, ahead of brace of an influx of Chinese tourists as COVID restriction are dismantled, at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi airport, Thailand, January 4, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

site_title: Cote Steakhouse gives Korean BBQ a New York accent and party vibe
summary: Cote Korean Steakhouse, located in Level 3 of Como Orchard, Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with a New York-style bar and party vibe. The restaurant features dimly-lit dining rooms and a smokeless grill for cooking beef. The Butcher's Feast, priced at S$98, offers four cuts of beef, including hanger steak and marinated galbi. The restaurant also serves a variety of Korean dishes, such as the oyster omelette and spicy kimchi tofu, and has a dessert menu featuring soft-serve ice cream. Despite high prices, Cote's friendly service and lively atmosphere make it a standout dining option.

images.alt_text: Takahashi's zen-like interiors.

site_title: Executive condo prices are stretching affordability limits. Is it time to refine the model?
summary: Singapore's executive condo (EC) market is facing affordability issues, with prices stretching limits for young couples. The average price of new EC units is around S$1,464 per square foot, making them unaffordable for many. A single EC unit of 1,000 sq ft costs around S$1.46 million, or 7.6 times the annual income of S$16,000. Experts suggest capping unit sizes, raising the income ceiling, and increasing the number of EC sites to make the model more affordable for young Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of private property- condominiums as seen from Dawson taken on August 1 , 2023. Can be used for property stories.

site_title: Ferrari shares surge as strong orders underpin growth
summary: Ferrari's shares surged 9.5% following upbeat forecasts, pushing the company's market value towards a record $100 billion. The luxury sports car maker reaffirmed revenue and core earnings growth for 2024, driven by a strong order book spanning 2025. Ferrari plans to launch its first fully electric car in the fourth quarter of 2025 and expects adjusted Ebitda to reach at least $2.45 billion this year, up from $2.28 billion in 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Ferrari is seen in the headquarters as CEO Benedetto Vigna unveils the company's new long term strategy, in Maranello, Italy, June 15, 2022. REUTERS/Flavio Lo Scalzo/File Photo

site_title: Japanese restaurants fight back with lower prices and new concepts to woo diners
summary: Japanese restaurants in Singapore are adapting to the post-pandemic market by introducing lower prices and new concepts to attract budget-conscious diners. Some high-end restaurants, like Zeniya and Sushi Kimura, are offering one-for-one promotions and reduced menu prices to entice customers. Meanwhile, smaller, more affordable concepts like Iru Den and Hashida are also lowering prices to stay competitive. However, ultra-premium restaurants like Shoukouwa and Sushi Sakuta are holding steady, with business remaining steady despite price cuts. As the industry adjusts to smaller wallets, some casualties are expected, but those with strong chefs and high-quality ingredients may be able to survive.

images.alt_text: Revolver’s interiors are done up in shiny silver, black and copper tones. The restaurant is located at Tras Street.
Zeniya's S$88 set menu features a choice of three rice bowls.

site_title: Young sushi chef, zen vibe at Takahashi
summary: Takahashi, a new sushi restaurant in Singapore, is the Singapore offshoot of its Tokyo flagship. Head chef Rinto Sasagawa, 24 years old, is the envoy and protege of chef-owner Jun Takahashi, who worked at Sushi Saito. The restaurant features an indoor zen garden and offers a S$220 lunch set with seven pieces of nigiri sushi. While the food is not the prettiest or most precisely cut, it is decent and well-executed by Sasagawa. The ambience is serene and the service staff are warm, making Takahashi a place to "zen out" despite not being the best value or having the best ingredients.

images.alt_text: Quenino's plush yet patio-like interiors.

site_title: Saudi National Bank reports more than 7% jump in 2023 net profit
summary: Saudi National Bank reported a 7.7% jump in 2023 net profit to 20.01 billion riyals (S$7.17 billion), beating analyst estimates. The bank's operating income rose 5% and provisions for bad loans dropped 45% year-on-year. The 10% increase in its financing portfolio and higher benchmark rates contributed to the jump in special commission income. Total assets grew 10% to over 1 trillion riyals.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Saudi National Bank (SNB) can be seen at the banks' headquarters in Riyadh on March 27, 2023, after the chairman of SNB, the main shareholder of troubled lender Credit Suisse which was bought out this month, resigned. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)

site_title: S$88 menus and comfort food at Zeniya
summary: Zeniya, a two-starred Japanese restaurant in Singapore, has introduced an S$88 set lunch menu featuring comfort food with a Michelin touch. The set lunch includes three rice bowls, such as oyakodon, tendon, and maguro rice bowls, and a starter course. The menu is part of the restaurant's pricing adjustments in response to industry challenges. The S$88 set is considered a more accessible option, offering a taste of Zeniya's high-end cuisine at a lower price point.

images.alt_text: Takahashi's zen-like interiors.

site_title: Enter the Dragon: Hongbao to get your hands on
summary: For Chinese New Year 2024, luxury brands have released auspicious hongbao designs featuring the Year of the Dragon. Lamborghini's packet features a dragon's face with a raging bull crest, while Julius Baer's includes the dragon and phoenix, symbolizing balance and harmony. Tiffany pays homage to Jean Schlumberger with a dragon facing its Bird on a Rock design, and Dior marks the occasion with a subtle, gold-embossed dragon. Other brands, such as JW Marriott, Ode to Art, Givenchy, St Regis, Louis Vuitton, Mini, and The Ritz-Carlton, offer unique and creative designs, ranging from scanimation to embroidered peonies, to celebrate the Year of the Dragon.

site_title: US job growth surges in January; wages rise
summary: US job growth surged in January, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 353,000 jobs, exceeding economists' forecasts. Average hourly earnings rose 0.6% and wages increased 4.5% over the past 12 months, supporting views that the Federal Reserve may not cut interest rates in March. The unemployment rate remained at 3.7% despite some high-profile layoffs. Strong worker productivity and cooling labor costs are seen as key factors in the resilient economy, which could shield it from a recession this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A "Help Wanted" sign hangs in a restaurant window in Medford, Massachusetts, U.S., January 25, 2023. REUTERS/Brian Snyder/File Photo
Initial claims increases by 9,000 to 224,000 in the week ending Jan 27, according to Labor Department.
Announced layoffs reach 82,307 in January, a 136 per cent surge from December’s 34,817, according to data released by outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas.
The employment cost index, which measures wages and benefits, increases 0.9 per cent in the fourth quarter, the smallest advance since 2021, after rising 1.1 per cent in the prior three-month period.

MILL VALLEY, CALIFORNIA - NOVEMBER 03: A now hiring sign posted in front of an In-N-Out restaurant on November 03, 2023 in Mill Valley, California. According to a report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, job growth slowed in October with a total of 150,000 new jobs added compared to analyst expectations of 180,000. The unemployment rate inched up to 3.9% from 3.8%.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, are up 101,000 to 9.026 million on the last day of December.

site_title: Chinese investment into BRI nations hits highest since 2018
summary: China's investment in Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) countries reached its highest level since 2018, with almost $50 billion invested in high-technology projects, including electric-vehicle manufacturing. This marks a 80% increase from 2022, taking total BRI engagement to over $1 trillion since 2013. Despite concerns over China's influence and lending practices, the country will continue to pursue BRI engagement at 2023 levels, focusing on renewable energy, mining, and related technologies.

images.alt_text: An employee works on a steel pipe at a factory in Weifang, in China's eastern Shandong province on January 31, 2024. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Seatrium’s profit warning has a silver lining
summary: Seatrium's profit warning has sparked concern among investors, but some see a silver lining. The company's loss for 2023 is significantly higher than the previous year, but its 2022 loss was only S$261.1 million. Seatrium's net loss for the first half of 2023 was also higher than the full-year 2022 loss. Minority investors may view the company's asset write-down as a negative, but the bigger picture is that Seatrium has been struggling, and investors should be cautious of its ability to deliver consistently healthy earnings.

images.alt_text: Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: India’s Paytm says company, CEO not under money laundering probe
summary: Paytm, India's largest fintech company, has denied being under investigation by the country's anti-money laundering agency. Despite regulatory concerns over multiple transactions beyond limits, the company claims it has cooperated with authorities in the past. Paytm Payments Bank, owned by Paytm's CEO Vijay Shekhar Sharma, is facing potential license revocation and deposit restrictions due to regulatory lapses. The Reserve Bank of India has issued an order barring the bank from taking deposits or allowing top-ups after February 29.

images.alt_text: Vijay Shekhar Sharma Photographer: Ruhani Kaur/Bloomberg
The bank is important to the company’s app and wallet eco-system, which could be hit if Paytm cannot find banking partners to replace its payments bank.

The RBI says the bank will not be allowed to take any further deposits or conduct credit transactions or carry out top ups on any customer accounts, prepaid instruments, wallets, cards for paying road tolls after Feb 29.
SoftBank has loosened its hold on Paytm over the past few years, trimming its stake through various open market deals.
Paytm is overhauling its operations in an attempt to achieve its first net profit since listing in November 2021.

site_title: French bank SocGen to cut about 900 jobs at Paris head office
summary: SocGen, France's third-largest listed bank, plans to cut approximately 900 jobs at its Paris headquarters through voluntary departures, representing less than 2% of its total workforce. The move aims to streamline operations and achieve US$1.8 billion in gross savings by 2026, similar to other global banks such as Deutsche Bank and Citi. The job losses come as SocGen CEO Slawomir Krupa seeks to reduce costs and adapt to the changing financial industry landscape.

images.alt_text: A visitor arrives at the Societe Generale SA bank headquarters in the La Defense business district of Paris, France, on Wednesday, Aug. 2, 2023. SocGen reports earnings on August 3. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

site_title: A week of MOUs; Sino-Asean trade flows getting a boost
summary: Asean leaders signed four memoranda of understanding with Chinese trade bodies in Singapore, aiming to boost collaboration between Chinese companies and Singapore businesses, and facilitate their entry into the South-east Asian market. The move is expected to support Asean's trade and investment flows, particularly amid persistent trade tensions between China and the US. Meanwhile, Indonesia's presidential election approaches, with the three candidates facing off in the final debate on Feb 4, and the country's tech startup funding expected to stay sluggish in the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: Delegates convened at the fourth Asean Digital Senior Officials Meeting in Singapore on Jan 30 in preparation for the Feb 1-2 Asean Digital Ministers Meeting.

site_title: Sorry no longer the hardest word at Africa Cup of Nations
summary: Senegal's Moussa Niakhate and other Africa Cup of Nations players have taken to social media to apologize for errors that led to their elimination from the tournament. Niakhate, who missed a penalty in the shootout that eliminated Ivory Coast, posted a heartfelt message expressing his regret and taking responsibility for the team's loss. Similar apologies have been made by Morocco's Achraf Hakimi, Cameroon's Vincent Aboubakar, and Ghana's Dede Ayew, as the players seek to mitigate fan backlash and disappointment.

images.alt_text: Senegal's defender #19 Moussa Niakhate reacts after failing scoring a goal from the penalty spot during the extra time of the Africa Cup of Nations (CAN) 2024 round of 16 football match between Senegal and Ivory Coast at the Stade Charles Konan Banny in Yamoussoukro on January 29, 2024. (Photo by KENZO TRIBOUILLARD / AFP)

site_title: Chef Andre Chiang returns to Singapore for pop-up event
summary: Chef Andre Chiang, a renowned Taiwanese chef, is returning to Singapore for a two-week pop-up event at La Dame de Pic at Raffles Hotel from March 13-24, 2024. The residency, titled "Andre's Homecoming," will feature a menu with signature dishes from his two-Michelin-starred Raw restaurant in Taipei and his former restaurant in Singapore, Restaurant Andre. Chiang aims to give fans the opportunity to experience both restaurants and celebrate the 10th anniversary of Raw. The menu will include classic dishes like Poussin en Vessie, which Chiang describes as a timeless and groundbreaking French dish.
